From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jan  1 03:20:39 1997

Received: (from simitzis@localhost)
          by atari.saturn5.com (8.8.4/8.8.4)
	  id DAA18354; Wed, 1 Jan 1997 03:23:26 -0800 (PST)
Date: Wed, 1 Jan 1997 03:23:26 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <199701011123.DAA18354@atari.saturn5.com>
From: Steve Simitzis <steve@saturn5.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: NYE... and a Call to Arms.
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Oh geez, what a strange night. Gateway and Pacific threw an *amazing*
party, but (of course) it was busted by Officer Not-so-friendly and
had to be shut down at 1am. 

Fuck that! It's New Year's, for god's sake... Can they just let a
bunch of people be happy for once? I find it so sick that the
government considers a permit (which is just a piece of paper) to be
so much important than the happiness of their citizens. Our government
is Pathetic. To make matters worse, it was clearly a dangerous hour to
be driving home. Drunk drivers, wind and rain, etc.

Freedom of assembly? Oh yes, that's right, the law in the City of
Oakland takes precendence over the Constitution. Silly me, as always,
I've forgetten to read the fine print.

CCC unfortunately was full to capacity. It really sucked after walking
there in the pouring rain only to get turned away, but it happens, and
I can certainly understand. So we're just going to hang out at
Natoma-on-the-Lake until the Hunab-Ku after party. Thanks, Jonas, for
having that party. :)

I've spoken to some of you about this before, and it is definitely
time to change the cabaret laws in the city of San Francisco (I rave,
and I vote!).  Seriously, way too many parties have been busted
lately, and it's time for this to change. Instead of fighting and cursing
at the Law, *we* can change it through ballot propositions. 

Well? Anyone else up for this? I propose a meeting sometime this
month. With some research, a lawyer or two, a petition, and some
financial backing, we can have a ballot prop for 1998 to decriminalize
dancing. I'm sick of complaining. It's time for *change*.

I hope all of you in Montery are having a great time, and I wish I
could have been there to share it with you. :( Happy New Year
everyone!!! :)

Steve

--

From: Steve Cooley <Stevec@pobox.com>

To: SFRaves List <sfraves@hyperreal.com>

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

ok, our party got shut down before our very eyes almost at exactly
midnight, new years eve.
Ok, police got a little crazier than they needed to.
ok, we hung out in the rain for 2 hours waiting for both parties to 
    out.
ok, sticking around does pay off.  There was a teeny party after almost
everyone left.
ok, we had to wade out to our jeep, in at least 12" of flooded street.
ok, we almost got into two accidents on the way home.
ok, we got lost in Oakland.
now we're home and everything's ok now.
<sigh> it's just another night.  Bad things happen, but write it off and
have a Happy New Year! :)
-- 
Steve Cooley

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jan  1 08:58:29 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id IAA22826; Wed, 1 Jan 1997 08:58:29 -0800 (PST)
Received: from mail-e2b.gnn.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id IAA22822; Wed, 1 Jan 1997 08:58:26 -0800 (PST)
Received: from 68-79.client.gnn.com. (65-203.client.gnn.com [205.188.65.203])
	  by mail-e2b.gnn.com (8.7.6/8.7.3/GNN-1.0.7)
	  with SMTP id LAA29424 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>;
	  Wed, 1 Jan 1997 11:56:55 -0500 (EST)
Message-Id: <199701011656.LAA29424@mail-e2b.gnn.com>
X-Mailer: GNNmessenger 1.3
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 01 Jan 1997 08:51:48
From: DJFro@gnn.com (Dave Arias)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: What A Riot... Cool World Review (Very, Very, long!)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

OK, we get there about 6:45, tons of security, noone knows 
anything. I'm trying to get in because I was supposed to be 
on laser crew (the only reason I spent my night at cool 
world), and I keep getting sent from one person to the next. 
7:30 rolls around, the doors are open, and I'm still 
standing outside waiting for god knows who to finally figure 
out why they should let me in. By this time, one of the 
staff security guys offers me two comp. tickets, just so I 
can get in and get to work. 8:00, finally I am in. I realize 
this night is going to be an unorganized nightmare.

OK, things go relatively smoothly, we get the first laser 
system up and running in the theater, and all that. 

10:00 and it's time to start up the laser in the main room. 
On stage, on the runway, the crowd was being entertained by 
teeny-boppers, with the DJ way far from the front of the 
stage. Then comes the live performances.. o boy. They we're 
pretty good at that lip-syncing thing, besides that, they 
sucked. 

11:30ish, they're done performing (yay!), and Dj Ghost is 
on. I've only heard ghost a couple of times, and both times 
he's started his set with my oh-so-(un)favorite phone sex 
record. After that record had been playing for about a 
minute, I notice 3 new people on the runway, giving the 
crowd their own live (clothed) sex show.... lovely. After 
this, the stage becomes packed full of scantily-clad 
teeny-booppers, strutin their stuff all over the stage (some 
of them earned a few bucks, too, probally for showing the 
crowd their g-strings). H

Happy New Year! Balloons fall, someone rambles on the mic 
about the new year, and a bunch of other unintelligable 
stuff.

1:30a, the theater is packed full of people, and some fool 
decides it's time for fun with the fire alarms! Managment 
gets mad, closes the theater, and the chill room soon after.

Main floor is now packed. People are hot and pissed, but the 
night goes on.

Somewhere between 3:30 and 4, the lights start coming on. 
Guess what! An early night! At the time, I was very excited. 
So the all the lights are on, but the music keeps going. I'm 
walking around asking security whats going on, and noone 
knows... big suprise. Finally one of the staff security 
dudes starts telling Garth it's time to stop, party's over. 
It took a bit of yelling for Garth to stop. I asked one of 
the management people why the party was shutting down, and 
find out Cool World broke their contract with HJK, because 
they didn't have any medical teams on duty. That's not the 
story the crowd heard, however... they we're all told it 
was because people had kept pulling the fire alarms. 

Now the fun begins. 

Incoming! The first bottle hits the stage... the next thing 
you know, they're coming at us from all angles. I rush to 
protect the equipment, while ducking behind road cases, to 
avoid the next juice bomb. Over the speakers, we keep 
hearing the words "patience" and "peace" over and over. Too 
bad noone cared. The bottles kept flying in for the next 
20-30 minutes, weird purple juice stuff and glass flying 
everywhere. We keep wondering where the cops are. Finally 
two cops are backstage, and I find out there's a lot more 
officers in the front of the building (great place for them 
to be, while we're all getting attacked). Well, finally 
20-30 cops come in backstage, dressed in full riot gear, and 
get almost everyone out.

We clean the weird purple juice stuff off the gear, pack it 
up, and leave.

Definatly the most interesting New Years I've ever had.

The End.



dave

   Well I must say that if it was not for CCC allocating so much time
prior to the actual event, distributing tickets via BASS. Then finding
out that tickets are selling for $35 at the door, I really was expecting
something along the lines of Disneyland and Eden combined in large
"well  staffed", check every last item so there will be no chance of
tangling the vibe, once it started building up. Unfortunately I have to
comment about the medical staff statement. If I were to rent, say a
large sports arena for
holding a CPR training class for 15,000 people. Security services are
included "hello" in the contract. That means that the Convention center
provides the security and any other emergency service which might be
needed to deal with the type event you "plan" to have.
   Fire Alarms, Fire Trucks, or not enought band-aids, new microphone
volume knob, items like these should be collected and recorded to
something like a "check-list" maybe? I have learned one valuable lesson
from all the chaos. Don't piss alot of people of when they are dancing!
                                      Erik

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jan  1 11:47:23 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id LAA02270; Wed, 1 Jan 1997 11:47:23 -0800 (PST)
Received: from proxy1.ba.best.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id LAA02264; Wed, 1 Jan 1997 11:47:20 -0800 (PST)
Received: from shellx.best.com (shellx.best.com [206.86.0.11]) by proxy1.ba.best.com (8.8.3/8.8.3) with ESMTP id LAA18068 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 1 Jan 1997 11:46:11 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [206.86.235.114] (lesliea.vip.best.com [206.86.235.114]) by shellx.best.com (8.8.4/8.8.3) with SMTP id LAA23223 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 1 Jan 1997 11:45:49 -0800 (PST)
Date: Wed, 1 Jan 1997 11:45:49 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v01530500800a4f1c9e74@[206.86.235.114]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lesliea@best.com (Leslie Ayres)
Subject: New Year's Awakening
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The recap of my experience first:

Last night, I was going to stay home, but decided to go to the
Gateway/Pacific party with some of my closest friends.  We arrived at the
location around 11:30 to find a several cop cars and a long, unmoving line
up the alley.  The music was coming out of the warehouse on the left-- the
Origin party-- and the warehouse on the right -- the Gateway/Pacific party
(cool-looking 2-floor brick warehouses).

There are cops in the street and one (the nice young Asian one in case you
were out there) tells the crowd that the party is being shut down.  We
wait, not wanting to believe, but it's true.  At about 10 'til 12, they
begin asking people to leave.

As I walked the crowd, looking for missing friends, I had the great
pleasure of handing out the New Year's fortunes that I had made.  The Asian
cop took one and thanked me, said it was perfect for him (it said "in 1997,
pay attention to spending more time alone"!) and he'd put it on his
refrigerator.

He told me he appreciated my presence there (I guess because I wasn't just
yelling at him and was trying to remind people that we need to behave with
respect even when our party's being busted, because it will reflect on us
in the long run) .... and I told him that that street was FILLED with
wonderful positive people who only wanted to go in and dance with their
friends, there was little bad about it, except now, they were being put on
the highways at midnight on New Years, and I hope all of them made it
safely where they were going.

And so the new year came as I milled around such a wonderful and
interesting crowd, it was pretty intense, the combination of the positive
potential and the disappointing reality.

The cops also assured me they were shutting down the Origin party next.  I
assume the whole process took a long time because they then aggressively
cleared the street, and Steve said the inside party didn't shut down until
1 am, an hour later.  I wish I could have been inside with everyone.

(And hearing about the Cool World event, I suspect that  "bust" was just
one in this whole series of crackdowns on raving.)

Now my concerns about responsibility:

The nice cop told me that the problem was lack of permits, which would have
required certain security provisions.  We hear this over and over, and we
also hear horror stories of trying to get the proper permits.

I see both sides, and I value the underground scene, but it seems to me
that there's no way a large party, especially next to another large party,
on New Year's Eve, can possibly expect not to be "noticed" by the
authorities.  This would seem to me to clearly show that ALL permit
processes must be observed so that the party is LEGAL.  Not taking care of
business is ignoring responsibility.

That responsibility is to the rave community, and to the people who paid
$20 for a ticket, and who committed this special evening to share with
their friends in that place.

Promoters are providing an environment for a positive experience, and part
of that environment is a sense of security, that, as much as humanly
possible, that party is not going to be busted.  Yes, sometimes of course
we choose to take chances, but in my opinion, New  Years Eve in that
location is not one of those times.

I believe that it was the responsibility of those throwing the party to
either follow the rules or to accept that it just wasn't possible to do a
New Year's event this year (which is sad, but to me, not sadder than how I
and many others ended up spending their New Years).

Galen apologized on his voicemail, saying "it was unavoidable."  I'm not
trying in any way to single out anyone (especially since both Gateway and
Pacific give SO MUCH to our community) but I am saying maybe it's time that
we wake up and find a new way to play the game, because it's clear our
current "close-your-eyes and hope-they-don't-see-you" way isn't working.

I'm tired of being so consistently busted, and I think we need to
strategize how we can keep this from happening.  "Unavoidable" doesn't cut
it with me .. we need to learn how to avoid busts, even if it means fewer
parties.  Busts are bad for everyone, and do NOT forward our cause in any
way.

Maybe this means we work with the authorities in a new way, maybe it means
we only can have small small parties, maybe it means .... something else.
I don't know, but I'm happy to be a part of the solution in any way that I
can.  If anyone has suggestions of who we should be working with and
talking to, who we can write to, or has things that I may be overlooking
about this and other recent bust scenarios, I'd like to hear.

Maybe a "committee" of representatives of the rave community can present
our case to the authorities to try to work out a solution with them,
because, like it or not, we need to understand them and they; need to
understand us.

Working with authorities doesn't mean not being underground - - underground
is about how parties are publicized, it doesn't have to mean illegal.

Bottom line, we have no rave scene if we are constantly busted, and the
more busts there are, the more busts there will be.  I want to party,
please!

Love and hopes that 1997 brings safe and joyous dancing to us all,
Leslie

(p.s.  to those who kept asking about "getting their money back" I'd like
to again remind you that Pacific brings your FREE Sunsets almost weekly for
8 months a year)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jan  1 11:58:07 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id LAA02841; Wed, 1 Jan 1997 11:58:07 -0800 (PST)
Received: from emout09.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id LAA02835; Wed, 1 Jan 1997 11:58:03 -0800 (PST)
From: TeKnODiVa@aol.com
Received: by emout09.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id OAA12572 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Wed, 1 Jan 1997 14:57:31 -0500
Date: Wed, 1 Jan 1997 14:57:31 -0500
Message-ID: <970101145730_1889438178@emout09.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Quiet New Years
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

  Knowing how ultimately crowded the cities would be, I avoided everything
and went to a few smaller parties with my friends.  (No, this had nothing to
do with my age.)  We wandered around meeting people and finally settled at
someone's house to count down to 1997.  As soon as the count-down was over we
ditched our champagne glasses and headed back out to another house.  Partied
there for a while, caught up with a surprisingly large amount of people I
knew.  Travelling with my own music and as many black lights, strobe lights,
and portable systems we could cram into the car definately made the party
wherever we were.  (At least I thought so.  But who cares when you're having
fun?)  At some point during the morning I decided to bless my parents with my
prescence, and headed home.  Their party, that I had so carefully avoided,
was still in progress.  Mingling with adults isn't my thing, but everyone was
so punchy the jokes kept me smiling.  I waited for everyone to leave, and
once again left my champagne for another activity... sleep.  It wasn't a very
eventful or riot-filled night, but considering how sick I am, I think I did
pretty well.  Happy New Year everyone!!!

           hugs,
            'trice                     <<<<RAVEON>>>>

 P.S.  This is a question for Ran... your closing signature reads, "Namaste."
 Would that be the word meaning "I recognize the god in you" from Budhism?  I
can't remember which religion it comes from.  It's a perfect closing for a
letter on this list.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jan  1 12:09:35 1997

Subject: Re: Cloudfactory..heavenly NYE
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



..After reading about Cool World and Pacific...imagine that the party was
held in a warehouse that houses a rockclimbing school.  No need to ransform
the space, it's already surreal looking inside, with 18 tons of cut up
rubber tires for the dance floor..lots of bouncy fun, and paths everywhere
else, with twinkling lights. Great computer light show on the walls...

the cloudfactory dj's played in pairs on 4 turntables...pounding,terrific,
crazy all night...deaks/tim, drenalin/sabin, scott/swoops....k-go/and
?....cool idea....worked great, someone else will probably write more about
the sets...I'm a little too tired right now......

A cop comes inside, over by me at the computer table, to look at the
equipment..he says.."great party..looks like you guys are having a lot of
fun..."  That tells you something about what the vibe was like. I talk to
the owner of the business, and thank him for letting these kids have such a
great party. He says he was a little worried...but everything was cool. He
touches one of the rockclimbing walls and says that with the bass pounding
it was kinda like having an earthquake indoors and wonders what it would
feel like to be scaling the walls while the music was playing. Heavenly.

I'm gonna go to bed now, but I know the cloudfactory boys even impressed
themselves with this party. Great space,great music, great people, etc.,
doin it right, and all for $10.00!!!! They deserve all the credit and
another feather in their cap for putting on "raves," not ripp-off parties
for $35.00.

 I met Micron and wanted to have him introduce me to a lot of sfr people I
haven't met...but, next time.

                                              
                                                          Happy New
Year....SpinSilver

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jan  1 13:26:58 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id NAA06534; Wed, 1 Jan 1997 13:26:58 -0800 (PST)

MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: a quickie Cloud Factory review
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Happy New Years all!!!

	Still haven't slept yet, had to let everyone know C.F. was really 
the place to be this year. And I guess what happened w/ Gateway getting 
busted around MIDNIGHT (yuk) really sealed it.

High Points-

-A very unique space. An indoor rock-climbing facility. Wow! A nice 
change of pace from some of the dirtier places to party around the Bay 
Area.

-The shredded-up rubber material on the floor inside the place. (Like 
someone threw some CLEAN old tires in a giant blender?). A very 
refreshing surface to dance on -- footing not TOTALLY solid, but my 
normally concrete-weary knees were in heaven from the nice cushy effect. 
The stuff was great to just chill in, too. And it's a good thing, too. 
Spent a great deal of the night just sitting w/ my fiance, who was 
feelin' ill all night :(

-*Perfect* capacity. Especially for a New Years event. (no way was I 
personally ready to deal w/ a Cool World-size crowd!!) About 350 or so is 
the number someone @ the map point told me. Plenty of elbow room, and 
actually being able to RECOGNIZE people!!!

-The beats were intense! It was cool to hear some hardcore, some drum n' 
bass. The set immediately following the countdown was very eclectic, very 
cool. But Cloud and whoever was spinning w/ him between 2 and 4 really 
tore it up!!

-The crowd was awesome, very vibe-oriented it seemed. Kept reminding 
myself that this is why I went w/ a relatively underground party this 
NYE. Four Twenty really stretched out until shortly before five, and I 
got the chance to smoke and talk w/ some very cool people (Hey Uncle 
Noah, Chris (Pac Bowl shirt) and Sean (Shawn?) from Santa Cruz!!!)

Some Low points :(

-getting HEAVILY disrepected from two people who I guess actually ran the 
business during it's "Normal Person Hours". Both insisted that they had 
told us numerous times to not smoke where we were (the rubber was highly 
flammable). All that had been done was a pipe was packed (in preparation 
for the windy outdoors) and someone flashed a lighter to find something 
in their backpack. Straight up being called a liar when I told the guy 
that "NO ONE had approached me or my friends all night and told us not to 
smoke" and "Sorry" and "We weren't even planning on it". They still 
took some convincing after all that. Still a mystery to me how they got 
confused.

-The outdoor area was being blown about pretty heavily, a little too much 
to be enjoyable -- the tent raising off the ground, only shelter being 
the "Chill Trailer". Only reason this was dissappointing was I built up 
the idea of a spacious outdoor/patio area too much. Nobody can help the 
weather, though.

Nothing much more to bitch about. All in all, one of the most enjoyable 
parties I have been to this fall/winter. Cloud Factory, give yourselves a 
BIG hug for this one.

						Hugs :)
						DAVE


-Swear to god there were multiple narcs there. Did anyone else sense that

Even though the floors were way to slippery, I had a pretty good New Years.

  I don't blame the people for there behavior when the party stopped.
Everyone was pretty bummed when they said "parties over" on the stage but.
People didn't really get pissed off, tell after that stupid lady on the
microphone started "laughing" and telling everyone they had to go home. She
didn't have to be like that. "Hahaha, nee ner nee ner. You all gotta take
off. suckers"
  Much thanx to all the idiot taggers that attended. There was more
graphitti in that place than on all the walls down 880, from San Jose to
Oakland. Thats one way to bring our community together, or whatever it is
ravEs are suppost to do. It's funny seeing people in the parking lot,
stashing there markers down there pants. Must be hard, only having a talent
for scribbling..
  I like the tiny bopper dancers on stage though. Thats fun. Ever been to a
Brasilian party? But the Wild107.7 materialistick hoochie momma's on stage
freaking each other... Bla bla..... Save it girls.   =]
  
  Anyone get a hold of them Blue Cats Eyes last night? Can anyone say
rollercoaster to hell? Damn that shit was intence..!  For about an hour I
had to be babysitted while E'ing my ass off on the balcony... Much PLUR
goes out to Jessie for sticking with me through that.

  I like Dj Ghost but. You sure he played last night? Couldn't see the
turntables. It sounded like they were just playing his tape.

  I get a kick out of how the Security and Bar tenders start dancing after
awhile..

  I had fun damnit!    I saw Adam too..  Kind of.. My vision was blurry....
  =]:..
  Jeff

Subject: Another NYE story
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Okay its 9 o'clock, im on my way to New years Eden to hear Dj sin tear shit
up... I arrive at the location and I quickly notice that im in the
ghetto.....part of the ghetto! Anyway, i go inside and I see pools of water
on the floor, a couple of guitar amps and junked cars... I talk to Sin , he
wants to bail cause this is really scary, nobody is even there  so we all get
in our cars and decide to search for the Pacific party! 

We get to the map point and i buy my ticket... The whole time im calling
people telling them what the situation was like( Sorry Sweatie!!!)
Everythings cool, really nice production, every room had sick visuals... Come
to think of it this was one of the best productions I think i have ever
seen.. so much effort!! anyway.. im dancing my booty off, when i see the fuzz
the music stops... then 10 minutes before NY's it starts back up... everyone
screams!!! But alas poor yorick we were just being teased....the music was
shot off at 1 am and all those really violent drunk ravers where sent home! I
hope everyone I know, and don't know for that matter, made it home safely... 

I don't think the cops even care who they are sending out into the crazy
weather and scary highways n stuff...:( It was trippy have the parties so
close to each other....
Couple of things I don't understand though... Why did origin make people go
all the way to Sf if the party was in Oakland???? It would have been cool if
everyone got togeather and people could just go from party to party...Oh
well, I saw a lot of really cool people, I raved into the new year and I
think it is time to make a change... 


THE RESPONSIBLE RAVER COMMISSION... Lets make a change, lets make it easier
to get permits... lets cause commotion.. lets not just sit back and say Ok,
Mr. officer, what ever you tell me! FUck, we pay there salaries, you think
they could be a little more respectful, but they where just doing there job..
Anyway... i hope everyone had a safe and happy new years...

Sorry for the rambling, I am being kept awake by my parents and their guests
enjoying the new year... singing on top of spaghetti!!! LOL = )


Jonathan

...was spent at Mel's house - my best friend in the whole world.  We 
decided we couldn't afford to make a 1.5 hour trek in the windy stormy 
weather for a rave. From the reviews I've read, I'm glad I stayed home in 
Sac.  We watched videos we recorded from the 80's and I showed her my 
Duran Duran video "Arena" and we marveled at how much we have grown up 
over the years.  I thought it was a good way to spend NYE.

Anyway, I am in full agreement with Steve S. and Leslie.  As soon and Mel 
and I get settled in SF, we will both be more than willing to help in 
anyway we can to simply have the freedom to dance.

happy new year;)
Amy

anyone actually see that movie?  I haven't, but my understanding is that
it's about this little city where it's illegal to dance.  I think we
need a modern day documentation style film about our problems raving.

I've now heard that our parties got shut down because of a lack of
permits.  A cool cop told us very politely that, "Everyone knows ravers
aren't out to cause any problems.  What we all need to understand is
that it's our job to enforce fire code.  If you don't have your permits,
there's fire hazards to consider, and if something went wrong and people
got hurt, everyone would be looking at us (the police) and asking why it
happened."...or something really close to that.

To counter that, I also heard last night that some promoters have such a
hard time getting the permits that they take chances and pray to not get
busted.  

maybe throwing out the legitimate problems out into the open can help us
decide the best course of action to take..

-- 
Steve Cooley

All I have to say, was I had a great time on New Years 95-96 at Gateway,
but this New Years DEFINITELY took the cake for an all out KICK ASS
time.
Among the amazing music (Sabin ROCKED, the lady outside who's name I
don't know was AMAZING, I loved the Sesame Street Dance!), the people
there made the night what it was, in my eyes.  I met some WONDERFUL
people (Uncle Noah, Orson, Derek, Joe, and MANY others..) and I saw
SO MANY people that I love and missed!  And seeing Omar for the first
time in I don't know how long was just amazing, he can still, even in
freezing cold wind and rain, make you warm with his smile.  Thank you to
EVERYBODY who was there for making it as incredible of a night as it
was, and a great big hug and thank you to all the Cloud Factory people
for being so good to us and providing us with an explosive start to the
new year. =)

Love you all!
  --Noah

P.S. Thank you for the necklace, Melanie! =)

This message is aimed mostly toward Pao... but actually, this is to
anyone interested.

Deeje and I have a program that he wrote called Virtual Turntable!  It
simulates a turntable using Quicktime technology on a PowerPC MacOS
machine.  

It works, I can beatmatch with it.  Anyone want to take a look, and
maybe form a beta testing team?

email me and I'll send you a copy.

From: Uncle Noah <napodaca@ucdavis.edu>

Subject: NYE stuff

Well, looks like I picked a good time to get outta SoCal... I'll have to
watch the news and stuff to see how the media is depicting that whole 7th
Heaven situation... My heart goes out to all those who were hurt and
scared on such a wonderful night.

BUT I went northward with my buddy Joe (It is beginning to seem like I
don't leave the house without this boy!  But the ravers dig him, so he
keeps on comin' back!  But watch out ladies, I think someone has staked a
claim...)

So me and Joey are happily riding the Amtrak Coast Starlight train (a
really fun ride, BTW) when we get to Santa Barbara.  The cunductor and
porters tell us this is the 'smoking stop' and we should feel welcome to
'stretch your legs' and such.  They say we'll be there for about 10
minutes.  Sounded good.  So we strolled over next to the station and kind
of looked around.  Then we looked back to the train just in time to see it
pull away from the stop.  We ran like madmen to try to catch up, only to
have passengers and porters laugh at us throug the windows.  :(
So there we were with _nothing_ -- all of our stuff was onboard, including
our tickets home! (AND all our raver goodies!).  So I go inside to rap
with the Amtrak representative only to be told that, "Smoking stops are
five minute stops only and you are supposed to stay right next to the car
and if you didn't follow the rules, that's your own fault."  Luckily a
kind cap driver heard our sad plight and rushed us post haste to the SLO
train station and we got back on the train.  YES!

We go to our destination and shortly found our good friend Heather adn we
off for a wonderful evening!

I don't think there's anything I could write about CF that could
communicate how much fun it was or what a good job everyone did putting it
on!  The music was fun (I put on my white gloves and danced at the speaker
during the hardcore stuff -- see, I'm learning things in So Cal...), the
people were _great_, the visuals kept us all going al night (The Muppet
Show rocked!) and even with some rain and wind, everyone seemd to have a
fun time!

But alas, I seem to have lost one item!  I had a small black and brown
case for my camera... if you happened to find it, could you let me know?

Alrighty folks, as always it was wonderful partying with all of you!  I
hope to be having fun in the north sometime soon!

I have been thinking about organizing around the permit thing as well.  The
"scene" represents a lot of people, a lot of jobs and a lot of money.  I
know this is not what the scene is about to most of us, but #1 that is a
reality and #2 that is the only talk that politicians/bureaucrats
understand.

ANyway, with all the brains, creativity, and energy that this list alone
represents, I am sure we could go a long way.  So I'm in for meeting with
people and getting something organized, brainstorming, etc.  There, we
already have one of our "one or two lawyers".

Excited about 1997 already.  Think of the fundraisers we can have!

peace.....Rob

Precedence: bulk

Great New Years Everyone!

Hello. Hope everyone had fun. This is a story about 4 ravers on a quest
to rave on the last day of 1996.

Paul - Thats me.
Victoria- My best Friend.
Jeremey- Cool Friend.
Amber- Another cool friend.

It must have been 6:30 at my home in San Jose. Victoria and Jeremey come
over to discuss what we are going to go to, because Erik(1,000 blow pop
man)'s car is making weird noises or something or other and now we can't
go to Cloud Factory. Sucks for us. Then Amber comes over.

Well, Jeremey has to get the car back to his grandparent's house back in
CONCORD, so we decide we will take BART from Concord to Frisco and then
go to whatever Rave in Frisco.
Okay so that's cool.  So we get to the BART station in Concord and
decide, that while we are waiting for the BART we will call some
voicemails and finf out where what is and when and how much. Okay, there
was a map point for Origin on Haight. Metamorphosis was in Oakland. COOL
WORLD was a no, no. So obviously we are gonna go to  Origin.

We get on BART and we are all putting on glitter and stickers on the BART
adn people are lookign at us like we were psycho, but who cares.

We get off BART on 16th and Market in Frisco. Its drizzling. I didnt
bring a jacket, I am so cold. It took us a good ass 10 minutes to get a
cab to stop. We get in and it takes us to Haight, it was only about $6.00
or so so we're cool, thinking Origin will be like $20 at the most.

Yeah right!!! It was $25. So now all of us are definetly sober tonight.
We then get the directions and find out that its in OAKLAND!!!!! We
barely have enough money to spend.

Luckily some terrrrrrific Ravers gave us a ride. Much PLUR to them, too
bad they are not on SFRaves list and are knew to our scene. From LA area.
First, they only have a spot for two people. So Amber and I decide to go
with them and Victoria and Jeremey will get a ride with some other
people.

Well, first of all we need to go to the house of one of the girls who
gave us a ride.
No problem we are cool. They change, we put on more glitter. Its all
good. Then we need to go pick up thier friend, Todd.  And he has given us
some wrong  ass directions to bumb fucked Egypt! ( Actually to his work)

We needed to make a right on Vanness and go down Oak and turn onto Marke
and stuff, I swear this guy, must work for some people's voicemail
because his directions where right of a voicemail. We ended up allmost
dying.

We were on some street, we roll down the window and ask the cab driver
where Vaness is and he points right. So when the light turned Green, we
went right.  We are in the middle of the block, when some bumb on a bike
(I LOVE THIS BUM!) yells, "Hey you're on a ONE WAY street!!!" We all look
at each other with a what did he say look, just then we see four lanes of
cars rushing at us. We spin aroudn and drive like crazy. 

Okay, fuck Todd and his bootsy ass directions! We are going to the rave.
So we get on the freeway and go to Berkely, because we need to stop at
some other guys house for a minute to get something or other. We get to
his house fine. We leave and go to the rave.

Parking was just wonderful!!

We park at exactly 11:30.We get to the "RED BUILDING" just as someone
yell's their shutting us down!!! 
So we like mad rush into Origin. We finally meet up wiht our friends and
are so happy.
While, we are all hugging, we hear. Happy New Year!!
That was the highlight of the night.

Well, after that, he music sucked. I didn't hear almost any good House at
all. It was tiny, too many small passages. And that visual of the naked
South American indiand dude with an erection, was sending out bad vibes.
All in all it was a piece of shit!!!
It was not worth $25 at all.
So it tursn out that the rave they were talking about that was shut down
was either Metamorphosis or something else.

Turns out they shut us down at 1:45 or so. I was there for almost 2
hours. I didn'r really mind that much since it was a piece of shit!!!

Well we gather our friends together and decide to go back to Todd's house
in Berkely. Victoria and Jeremey go with Todd and we go with our knew
foudn raver friends, who are Eing their asses off. Amber is Frying and I
am so scared.
This was the stragnes ride in a car.

We get to Todd's and we're fine and we kick it their till 10:30 or so in
the morning and leave for BART. We take the BART back to Jeremey's house
in Concord.
We sleep until 8:30, then we take the car all the way back to San Jose
and that's what happened. 

Great New Year's ? I don't know about that, but it sure was interesting.

PLUR,
Paul

P.S. Welcome to 1997 everyone!
P.P.S I heard Cool World was busted up at  2:30 too. This was a shitty
New Year's for any raver no at Cloud Factory!

On Thu, 2 Jan 1997, Paul Hayden FUZZY PANTS wrote:
> P.P.S I heard Cool World was busted up at  2:30 too. This was a shitty
> New Year's for any raver no at Cloud Factory!
> 
Hey glad to hear you kids had a good time, I hadn't kept in touch, and I'm
glad to hear you got to at least got out to one for the night!

My group of eight took the BART from SF to Oakland for Planet...  I had a
really cool night!  The party itself was mostly ok until it was busted,
but Cool World truly does suck every bit as much as everyone said.  But, I
am _glad_ I went.  I had a kick ass time!  But there is so much that is
sh*tty about cool world that I won't even get started.  (maybe a future
post, or if you want details ask me :) Let me just say though, that it's
the PEOPLE who make the party, and there was so much good vibe that I
could hardly believe it, because I almost didn't expect it... even as riot
police were ushering people down the steps in the front of the convention
center, hordes of us were smiling under trees, listening to cool tunes on
portables, dancing in the rain... and there were plenty of smiles to go
around even at 4 to 5 to 6 to 7 ..all the way until 8am waiting around
oakland for the BART to open again...  I'm really glad I went, and met the
beautiful people I wouldn't have met had I not come.  Whereever you go,
there you are, and there is always going to be something to experience
whereever that is. 

I heard about busts from NYC to LA to Seattle and Vancouver....  SF was no
exception to this modern rule...  As long as you enjoyed yourself and came
away with something positive, don't regret your life experiences!

Now, positivity aside, promoters need to be more responsible!!

Wow time to try to catch up on all this lost sleep...
peace all, and welcome to 97!

=)
Max

adam, et. al:

At 12:24 AM 1/2/97 -0800, you wrote:
>I heard that in LA at 7th heaven or some other crazy coolworld style
>massive someone passed out a bunch of poison and killed a bunch of
>ravers.  Anybody know the scoop on this?

yes, there was a nasty riot at 7th heaven.  somebody passed around free
vials of a drug called "fx" and a lot of people overdosed.  as i understand
it, about 40 people were hospitalized and then, of course, the police came
with their riot gear.  

lots of people got nightstick sandwiches and rubber bullets, police car
windows got smashed, the party was broken up and everybody was sent into the
night wishing for a better start to the new year.

thankfully, it looks like socal-raves is avoiding the finger pointing, but
it looks like a VERY BIG setback to the california rave community, our own
included.

(you better believe sfpd has heard about it already)

pauly

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jan  2 01:43:44 1997

From: Leonardo <wizard@armory.com>
To: Leslie Ayres <lesliea@best.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: New Year's Awakening (and how mine went)
In-Reply-To: <v01530500800a4f1c9e74@[206.86.235.114]>
Message-ID: <Pine.SCO.3.91.970102003238.24893B-100000@deepthought.armory.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'd love to be as optimistic as you, Leslie, but I have a different
view on the possibility of resolving all conflicts between ravers and
authorities.  Surely spitting in their face is not the type of thing
to do, they'll just come after us with more vengeance.  And I hate
to be prejudiced.. but cops are cops.  They chose to live their lives
as a police officer most likely because they found a passion in
policing things.  I dare not generalize and say all cops are pigs;
there must be some with a (twisted?) sense of virtue that made them
want to go into the proffession with "altruistic" motives.  But
being a police officer entails much more than "to serve and protect"
the people.. I think it's more of "to serve and protect" bureaucracy,
often against the will of the people.  It would seem to me that to
be a cop you had to either be blind to this, or in support of it.

I came very close to also having a disastrous New Year's.. I had
wanted to volunteer work for someone at the Goa party, but we (or I)
never found a ride.  I took a bus down to Monterey with hopes of going
to the Cloud Factory party, but it was sold out.  So I went to
First Night in Santa Cruz in hopes of enjoying some music and meeting
some drummers.. and I did.  There was Arican drumming and dancing on the
sidewalk, and there were happy listeners gathered around on the street,
and it was better music than that of any of the "organized" events.
Then comes along Mr. Police Officer, steps right up to us and makes
a throat-slitting sign at one of the drummers.  Not giving the music
five seconds to die down, the puts his hands on one of the drums
and says with a cold, stern face, "You stop now or you're all going
to jail."  I guess he had expected us to mumble under our breaths
and whimper off, for he was taken completely by surprise when the
drummer shouted out to the crowd protesting the injustice and asking
for their support.  Mr. Police Officer tried getting in the drummer's
face, then thought better after a few people took flash pictures of
them.  Then he said something between his teeth about us violating
a city ordinance, another jail threat, and walked off.

There is some city law about No Drumming Downtown Past 5 PM, because
the people anal enough to dislike the music are the same ones that
get those laws passed.  So I support the cause of legal organization
in an effort to make a change.  But the law is almost ultimately in
Mr. Police Officer's hands.  Maybe that ordinance has some reason to
it if drumming on Pacific Av. every night keeps some people from
having a good night's sleep (laugh), but for crying out loud.. it
was New Year's Eve, there was music up and down the street, all of
downtown was up and partying, and there must have been over 100 people
enjoying that drumming.  Some might say the cop could have wanted
to stop the drumming because the city wasn't making any money off
of it.. my personal opinion is that the guy has something against
hippies, African drumming & dancing, and/or anything that "rubs him
the wrong way."  Also, he's the type of person that loves to play tough
guy... and so many of us know that's how the vast majority of cops
are.  I asked him who was really "disturbing the peace," and he
was deaf to me.  Then, as if it was karma at work, it rained.

Thankfully, the spirit of Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect prevailed.
After five minutes we began drumming again under the shelter of the
Rhythm Fusion store.  When more and more people came and danced under the 
rain, the cops did not dare to even throw us a dirty look.  With
much life, music, and celebration, I smiled as the new year came
to be.


Much love to you all,

Leonardo

jungle/drum 'n' bass site:

        ...junglism (sf)...
        ...junglism (sf)...
        ...junglism (sf)...

(a.k.a. "Jungle at the Top" -- its about time we got it together, eh?)

Content to be updated weekly, available NOW:

...REAL AUDIO (RA) 3.0 (This week: DJ Noel/D'Angelo, DJ Soulslinger,=
 EBTG/Jobim)
...DJ Top 10s (This week: DJ UFO)
...Events Calendar (BetaLounge, Audio Impact, Jungle Love)
...DJ Stuff (This week: DJ UFO)
...SF Scene (This week:  Future Primitive Sound Session II)
...Jungle Links
...Total Graphic Redesign!

With a focus on serving info and RA from the local jungle/drum 'n' bass
scene, we'll also be putting up RA samples from DJ mixes from all over the
U.S. If you're interested in posting events, reviews, etc., please e-mail us
or use our self-posting news page, which will be active this weekend.

hi all:

more info from the socal-raves list...

pauly

-- begin forwarded message --

We have been told by a close friend and supporter of Dr. Freecloud's Mixing
Lab that one of their crew was stricken last night by ingesting the contents
of three of the "fX" vials, and was taken to the hospital after feeling
seriously ill and had their stomach pumped for five hours last night.  We
only hope that this person is well today and now back home safe and sound.

We were also told that the contents of his stomach were tested and traces of
LSD (?), GHB, Cocaine, and Heroin were found.  The person who was stricken
swears that they have never ingested any of the above illegal substances,
and knowing his nature, I believe them.  It may hint to an explaination as
to why people were getting so sick and passing out and stuff. Kava Kava has
always seemed fairly harmless when I have used the ground root in a cup of
strong tea several times in the past when I was suffering from insomnia and
I didn't feel the slightest nausea.  I have heard of only one case where
someone got a little queezy.  In fact, the color of my tea was a darker
brown than what was in the vial.  What really was in those vials seems like
the biggest mystery now.

One thing that I did note this year was that there were more outside
vendors, whereas a last year's Circa 1996 I only recall Ken's booth being
the only outside vendor and being told that all of the other booths were run
by CPU 101. That was different.

As for who's responsible, everyone is and no one is.  It was just frickin
chaos out there and it seemed like so many factors brought the evening down.
You try to cover all the bases but sometimes shit happens.  It's over.  As
long as everyone is okay is the most important thing and that no one died.
Let their lawyers deal with the legal shit now.  Whether you personally will
continue to support the promoters, or not, is up to you.

Webhead

-- end forwarded message --


_____________________________________________________ x-radio _____
_______ http://www.x-radio.com/ ___________________________________


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jan  2 05:46:29 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id FAA29163; Thu, 2 Jan 1997 05:46:29 -0800 (PST)
Received: from cats.ucsc.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id FAA29156; Thu, 2 Jan 1997 05:46:26 -0800 (PST)
Received: from si.UCSC.EDU by cats.ucsc.edu with SMTP
	id FAA27901; Thu, 2 Jan 1997 05:46:26 -0800 (PST)
Received: by si.UCSC.EDU (8.6.13/4.7) id FAA01317; Thu, 2 Jan 1997 05:46:23 -0800
Date: Thu, 2 Jan 1997 05:46:23 -0800 (PST)
From: Randy C Cone <randream@cats.ucsc.edu>
X-Sender: randream@si.UCSC.EDU
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>, Is it Trance? <604@party.net>,
        Know 1 <knowoneness-l@teleport.com>
Subject: San Francisco NYE Trance
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.970102050240.1152A-100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Hi all!  ]=)


 Whoosh! I'm still a bit beat but here goes...

 First my personal situation leading up to the party;

 I had been working on a fluro-banner for this party. This meant 6, 12 
to 14 hour days in a row before the party with the last three days 
seeing only about 8 hours of sleep. The banner did not get completly  
finished but looked good anyway.
 Then my ride flaked on me the morning of the 31st so I had to try to get 
a ride for me and my equipment. CJay was kind enough to come from Palo 
Alto to pick up me and my equipment.
 Get to the warehouse about 7 pm and discover that there is about three 
circuits of AC for two sound systems, a lot of black lights and my 
slide/light show. Needless to say my slides/lights didn't play but as I 
was tired I really didn't care.
 I had also brought a fellow student (Bob) to the party. He was crewing 
for me and researching for his senior thesis (part 2) on the evolution of 
public gatherings. His part two had to do with raves.
 My apologies to eveyone who had to deal with my grumpiness and loud 
voice. The grumpiness was due too exhaution and my voice has always been 
loud. People are always welcome to tell me I'm too loud since I usually 
don't think I am.


 The Party;

 Well it was fun!! We had a beautiful meditation with toning chants that 
segued into drumming and dige playing into the first DJ. Anon was up at 
midnight and we ushered in the new year with a female DJ at the helm. 
YEA!! Anon was suberb and maintained her cool throught the power problems 
that shut down the audio several times. Props to the sound crew for 
getting the system up and running quickly. Due to my exhaution I didn't 
dance a whole lot. Also there was woefully inadequte ventilation and 
things were hot and sopping wet in no time. I didn't dance for 4 hours 
and my shirt was still wringing wet. The chill room downstairs was 
playing some great stuff but it was a little bit small and clausterphobic 
for me. Kode IV was awesome!! And the very last DJ was playing the most 
enjoyable stuff!!

Great stuff;

 Without a doubt the people there were it for me! Such a good bunch of 
people. The music (psi-trance) was super-duper!!!! Seeing my first 
fluro-banner hung and being enjoyed was wonderful. There was a bountiful 
supply of great fluro art there. The free bottled water didn't hurt 
either. :)

Less than great;

 Most importantly the lack of planning for power. At one point the 
circuit breaker for one set of outlets was not only shutting off but had 
jumped off the power rails. Scary!!! The lack of ventiation really 
sucked! Due to the power problems not all the fans could be used.

 Overall a wonderful time. I'm sorry that the folks from the Origin and 
Chrysalis parties could not all get in. We were solidly packed!

 Hi to Liza (smooch), Ericka (thanks for the help), Kristen (double 
smooch), KC and Nancy (phat fems!), Russ the amazing doorman, Tom, Loran, 
Ben, Dhiren (sp?), everyone at CCC and Hunab Ku and to everyone else whom 
I may be forgetting.

 Double big thanks and hugs to Cjay for getting me and my equipment there 
and to Brandon and Anne who helped get me, Bob and the equipment back too 
sant Cruz.

 This party was truley underground as we had no flyering/word of mouth 
only. And it really showed in the quality people who came. Thanks 
everyone and happy '97.


smiles,


Ran D.Dreams



                                      (Namaste)

From: "John S. Lee" <jsl@netcom.com>
Subject: Happy New Year!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, well , well!

Here we are, another year together.  I usually make some type of prediction
about the upcoming year, but won't this year.  Too busy making sure MY i's
are dotted and t's are crossed.  I will say this much, since I have some
control over these aspects of my life.

- Flava, will happen in '97, and that will be the capacity that I'll
continue to participate in dance culture.  I will try to make it a browner
dance culture, if possible, with inclusion in mind.

- Crackerjackin' is over for me.  No white powder substances, nor liquid
pleasures.  My motto for '97 if it grows in the ground, then I'm down.  And
even then, if it's mind expansion then I need to be in the expanse of the
great outdoors.  A boom box, my woman, and a tape (my own), will be all
that is needed for a real rave...in the woods.

I'm happy that I stayed with friends.  For the first time in years, I
attended no party (i.e. "partay") to bring in the New Year.  I brought it
in with new friends, a new attitude, and a new woman in my life.  This has
been the BEST New Years I've had in ages.  And I brought in in right this
time.  Was slightly buzzed from the booze and smoke, and didn't need no
hokey-doke.  Very little house music, lotsa conversation and smiles.  Now
that's how we do it in '97!

I will also try to make it to other types of events, hip/hop & jungle/drums
& bass is it.  Since I buy house music, and am very, very, picky about who
I will allow to assualt my ears, it's time to listen to some other stuff
that ain't so 4/4.  time to listen to something else for a real change.

Sorry to hear about all the busted parties, but what else do you expect?
This city and the surrounding areas hate raves.  The cops aren't being paid
off like they used to, along with the club owners playing an ACTIVE ROLE in
GETTING EVERY NON-CLUB  (i.e. SoMA Niteclub) BUSTED, and the general
political apathy of a disjointed rave community, I have grave doubts about
this year being any better than the previous.  As a matter of fact, I
expect things to get alot hotter since 215 passed, permits or no.  Oh yeah,
Presshard is BACK! "You know how difficult it is to prosecute a cop?" <-
Dirty Harry, Magnum Force.  Good luck, since this guy has never given a
rat's ass about permits.

SF Politics 101 bka my .02 worth:
So, now you wanna get politically active, in the city that is now OWNED by
one Willie Brown?  I gotta laugh.  Ok, first, you have GOT to get every
promoter behind your efforts, since these are the people who would actually
apply for permits anyway.  You will also need to rally the legit club
owners in SoMA to sign on, or else they will act against you (they are way
more powerful than you could know people, since they have CASH!). Next you
will have to be a presence at as many parties as possible, getting
registered voters of SF to sign some type of petition.  This may have to be
done more than once.  You will have to know the current permit process, and
have a proposal ready that EVERYONE has bought into.  The hardest part has
yet to come.  You will have to get Willie's ear, and there better be
something in it for him.  It would be good if you talked to one of his
relatives (I know a couple of them), or better yet a paid lobbyist/attroney
who is in tight with Willie.

Can it be done?  Sure.  Does the dance community have what it takes to get
this done?  I think there is potential in everything, although to date, the
dance community has been rather limp-dicked bouthewhoe thig. It
wol e liktryingto e10 peoe om the Somyarty estedy o
omit to political action (uh-huh...)...I hink tcan sart asanSFRav
niatve,but ust ebrae a cltren it'sentiry i it's gnnwork  M beswshes o hoe bre enogh t rs fward.
(I prfe bac oom eling ethod myself, ad twrsut fi).
Pec HappyNe Year. May i b aproserus n rwding yar for ll,
o S Lee -Te Rh ered o Boooke Everywhee

In a message dated 1/1/97 11:49:15 AM, lesliea@best.com (Leslie Ayres) wrote:

<<I see both sides, and I value the underground scene, but it seems to me
that there's no way a large party, especially next to another large party,
on New Year's Eve, can possibly expect not to be "noticed" by the
authorities.  This would seem to me to clearly show that ALL permit
processes must be observed so that the party is LEGAL.  Not taking care of
business is ignoring responsibility.

That responsibility is to the rave community, and to the people who paid
$20 for a ticket, and who committed this special evening to share with
their friends in that place.

Promoters are providing an environment for a positive experience, and part
of that environment is a sense of security, that, as much as humanly
possible, that party is not going to be busted.  Yes, sometimes of course
we choose to take chances, but in my opinion, New  Years Eve in that
location is not one of those times.

I believe that it was the responsibility of those throwing the party to
either follow the rules or to accept that it just wasn't possible to do a
New Year's event this year (which is sad, but to me, not sadder than how I
and many others ended up spending their New Years).
>>
i wholeheartedly agree with you Leslie, but in the instance of this past NYE,
I think there's more at work here.  As we now know, even permitted parties in
established venues like Spundae were even busted.  Why? In addition to that,
it's my understanding that the Pacific/gateway crew inquired about permits
for their party, but they were told by the City that there was not enough
staffing to administer one.  The catch 22 therein is obvious. Not enough
staff to issue a permit, from which the City makes money off of, but enough
staff(i.e. police) to bust THREE parties in one night, consequently costing
the City of Oakland a substantial amount of money in salaries, and overtime
hours, etc.

I think the Cloud Factory had the right idea, maybe it's a good idea to just
stay away from SF & Oakland for a while...
--Monty 

---------------------
Forwarded message:
From:	lesliea@best.com (Leslie Ayres)
Sender:	sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
To:	sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: 97-01-01 14:49:15 EST

The recap of my experience first:

Last night, I was going to stay home, but decided to go to the
Gateway/Pacific party with some of my closest friends.  We arrived at the
location around 11:30 to find a several cop cars and a long, unmoving line
up the alley.  The music was coming out of the warehouse on the left-- the
Origin party-- and the warehouse on the right -- the Gateway/Pacific party
(cool-looking 2-floor brick warehouses).

There are cops in the street and one (the nice young Asian one in case you
were out there) tells the crowd that the party is being shut down.  We
wait, not wanting to believe, but it's true.  At about 10 'til 12, they
begin asking people to leave.

As I walked the crowd, looking for missing friends, I had the great
pleasure of handing out the New Year's fortunes that I had made.  The Asian
cop took one and thanked me, said it was perfect for him (it said "in 1997,
pay attention to spending more time alone"!) and he'd put it on his
refrigerator.

He told me he appreciated my presence there (I guess because I wasn't just
yelling at him and was trying to remind people that we need to behave with
respect even when our party's being busted, because it will reflect on us
in the long run) .... and I told him that that street was FILLED with
wonderful positive people who only wanted to go in and dance with their
friends, there was little bad about it, except now, they were being put on
the highways at midnight on New Years, and I hope all of them made it
safely where they were going.

And so the new year came as I milled around such a wonderful and
interesting crowd, it was pretty intense, the combination of the positive
potential and the disappointing reality.

The cops also assured me they were shutting down the Origin party next.  I
assume the whole process took a long time because they then aggressively
cleared the street, and Steve said the inside party didn't shut down until
1 am, an hour later.  I wish I could have been inside with everyone.

(And hearing about the Cool World event, I suspect that  "bust" was just
one in this whole series of crackdowns on raving.)

Now my concerns about responsibility:

The nice cop told me that the problem was lack of permits, which would have
required certain security provisions.  We hear this over and over, and we
also hear horror stories of trying to get the proper permits.

I see both sides, and I value the underground scene, but it seems to me
that there's no way a large party, especially next to another large party,
on New Year's Eve, can possibly expect not to be "noticed" by the
authorities.  This would seem to me to clearly show that ALL permit
processes must be observed so that the party is LEGAL.  Not taking care of
business is ignoring responsibility.

That responsibility is to the rave community, and to the people who paid
$20 for a ticket, and who committed this special evening to share with
their friends in that place.

Promoters are providing an environment for a positive experience, and part
of that environment is a sense of security, that, as much as humanly
possible, that party is not going to be busted.  Yes, sometimes of course
we choose to take chances, but in my opinion, New  Years Eve in that
location is not one of those times.

I believe that it was the responsibility of those throwing the party to
either follow the rules or to accept that it just wasn't possible to do a
New Year's event this year (which is sad, but to me, not sadder than how I
and many others ended up spending their New Years).

Galen apologized on his voicemail, saying "it was unavoidable."  I'm not
trying in any way to single out anyone (especially since both Gateway and
Pacific give SO MUCH to our community) but I am saying maybe it's time that
we wake up and find a new way to play the game, because it's clear our
current "close-your-eyes and hope-they-don't-see-you" way isn't working.

I'm tired of being so consistently busted, and I think we need to
strategize how we can keep this from happening.  "Unavoidable" doesn't cut
it with me .. we need to learn how to avoid busts, even if it means fewer
parties.  Busts are bad for everyone, and do NOT forward our cause in any
way.

Maybe this means we work with the authorities in a new way, maybe it means
we only can have small small parties, maybe it means .... something else.
I don't know, but I'm happy to be a part of the solution in any way that I
can.  If anyone has suggestions of who we should be working with and
talking to, who we can write to, or has things that I may be overlooking
about this and other recent bust scenarios, I'd like to hear.

Maybe a "committee" of representatives of the rave community can present
our case to the authorities to try to work out a solution with them,
because, like it or not, we need to understand them and they; need to
understand us.

Working with authorities doesn't mean not being underground - - underground
is about how parties are publicized, it doesn't have to mean illegal.

Bottom line, we have no rave scene if we are constantly busted, and the
more busts there are, the more busts there will be.  I want to party,
please!

Love and hopes that 1997 brings safe and joyous dancing to us all,
Leslie

(p.s.  to those who kept asking about "getting their money back" I'd like
to again remind you that Pacific brings your FREE Sunsets almost weekly for
8 months a year)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jan  2 09:30:38 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id JAA12044; Thu, 2 Jan 1997 09:30:38 -0800 (PST)
Received: from franc.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id JAA12037; Thu, 2 Jan 1997 09:30:33 -0800 (PST)
Received: from smtp.ucdavis.edu by franc.ucdavis.edu (8.8.4/UCD3.8.4)
	id JAA18705; Thu, 2 Jan 1997 09:29:54 -0800 (PST)
Date: Thu, 2 Jan 1997 09:29:54 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <199701021729.JAA18705@franc.ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: szriffle@peseta.ucdavis.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 2.1.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Rick Riffle <rdriffle@ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Metamorphasis - Long
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Got a call from my partner Brad from C-Lab around 1 pm the day of the party.
Turns out they want C-Lab to do some live stuff.  My other partner Eric who
usually plays live with me can't make it so the plan is to mix live to
record to live to record between Brad and I.  Sounds fun to me.  Pack up the
gear and head down.  We get there before it starts and watch it all come
together.  Three rooms, all totally beautiful.  The Gateway room was just
incredible with full intellibeams.  Their soundsystem is just the best IMO.
The Pacific room reminded me of Sunset parties with scenery projected on the
back walls, and a dolphin hanging over head.  The ambient room was totally
beautiful with carpet, couches and two beautiful altars.  There was a huge
crystal handing from the ceiling in the center and they were shining a laser
through it producing a really cool effect.  I get all my gear set up and
sound check with a new drum and bass thingy I'm working on.  Turns out to be
the only sound I make all night.  Oh well, it was fun to hear it on a big
system.  11:45, I'm dancing in the Gateway room and Sutekh is getting ready
to go on.  He's one of C-Lab, and we are stoked that he is getting some main
room action.  He goes on and just then I find out that the party will be
ending at 1:00.  Bummer.  Then I think you better have some fun now, cuz
it's gonna be over in an hour.  So I dance my ass off.  Seth does great.
Had a couple of moments while dancing catching small glimpses of the never
ending nowness of it all.  I head down to the ambient space just before one
and just after getting there someone from Pacific walks in and shuts off the
sound announcing there will be a free make-up party in the near future.  As
if they havn't all ready thrown enough free parties for SF'ers, but it was a
good gesture.  The place clears of everyone except for crew and people
riding with them.  About 100 or so I'd imagine.  I put my stuff away and
soon the music in the ambient space comes back on.  From what I understand,
the promotors talked with the cops for well over an hour, and finally
convinced them to let us continue the party for those left at the event.  So
everyone is in the ambient space dancing to triphop by Brad and (sorry I
forgot your name).  Then Solar comes on starting with an old Craftwerk song
that gets everyone on thier feet, then house and what not.  Then the someone
from Pacific convinces Freaky Chakra and Single Cell to go ahead and play
for those left at the part.  By this point, both had....well....indulged.
Daum is totally into playing, but Miguel(sp) kept saying "I don't know if I
can, I don't know man."  We encouraged him and told him we'd all move the
equipment so he didn't need to worry about it.  We get everything moved and
reconnected and Solar plays for another hour or so.  Then Daum and Miguel.
They rocked.  First some techno, then some electro that was really cool,
then ended with some drum and bass which made the night for me.  Some time
during thier set, NUB Chai comes in with free hot chai for everyone.  That
stuff is so good.  Took me back to Burning Man.  A little earlier while
Solar was playing, I went up to the Gateway system and Minor was spinning
some easy listening techno.  It was great.  There were about 20-30 people up
there, and they had the system turned way down.  It was really cool to hear
techno on a huge system with the volume turned way down.  Quite relaxing
actually.  I wish they had some couches up there.  Later when I went back up
to check things out, John Carol was spinning and the system was at full
volume again.  Maybe I'm getting old, but I just can't take loud music for
that many hours straight anymore.  I was wishing for the low volume again.
Soon I carried the gear out to the car and in the 30 seconds it took I got
completely soaked.  It was pouring and the streets were rivers.  My
berkinstocks got..well...wet.  The gear was fine though due to cases for
everything.  

All in all I had a great time.  I'm sorry for all of those made to leave,
and all those who never even got in.  I hope you all made the best of it.
One of the highlights for me was a converstation with Andrew (AstralMatrix)
when he enlightened me as to the only real lasting archival medium for
music.  Rekids :)  When you think about it, all other mediums break down
well before 50 years.  But the "lacker" (I think that's what it's called)
that makes the plates which stamp the records is made from metal, and will
last several thousand years.  Cool.  

Happy new year.

Rick

Ok, so how was your New Years?!?!?!

No long review here,  Just snippets of the event higlights.

Gateway: - I must say that when 12:00 rang in that "it's time" jam made
me GO OFF!!!!  

              -Enjoyed seeing the SFR bunchies dance and dance till the
Oak PO ushered us away.

              -That crazy jungle making me move like never before.

              -Seeing Steve S.'s shirt with the quote "Are you
Connected?  Yes we are." (Or someting like that)...

Other events:  -Thomas T.  Running around in his skivies trying to get
the sound running.  
                     -Maxin' with a bunch of newfound "pals" in the very
dark chill room.

                     -Socalizing with this one girl from Estonia about
life, energies and the Vibe...

                     -Running around w/Wonka, tryin' to set up a fan to
help happy scensters stay cool.

Wish:           -Dancing on the floor while everyone is "spun" and
chilling out.

                   -Trying to tell one guy that it's the VIBE that's
keeping me up while he's insistent that I was on something.

Afta:          - Getting home @ 11PM thinkin that I WILL MAKE IT to work
today...


So what's up for Friday?


___Adam

"Stay Connected"

Keep me apprised of when you plan to meet.  I hope I can attend.   I 
 think a "venting/assessment" mtg is the best way to start to keep 
 track of ongoing problematic themes and put one-time-only cases to 
 rest.  I think we need to approach this diplomatically and rationally 
 because politicians can make promises, laws can be passed, people can 
 understand  concepts...but law enforcers won't necessarily apply these 
 liberties if they feel it's an "unsafe" situation.

I, too, was disturbed to hear how many parties had been busted 
 throughout Alameda and SF counties and would like to keep track of the 
 reasons so we have some basis to work with.  So aside from Gateway and 
 1015 being busted, what else was shut down earlier than planned?  
 Also, what was the reason?  If memory serves me right (don't comment 
 ;) someone told me that Vanilla Fudge got busted too.  And didn't Cool 
 World get closed down early?

 I don't think it's just a rave issue our even a youth issue but an 
 overall understanding of responsible rituals and rites in modern day 
 society.  There's an attorney for human rights in HMB that might be 
 interested in helping us out and Tony ?? in SF/Marin who's renown for 
 taking some underdog cases.  Tony might have a representative that 
 could attend and provide some info on the innerworkings of our local 
 government but I don't think we should include them until we've got a 
 platform/defined agenda.  Also, is there any such thing as a youth 
 council that advises local governments in SF and Alameda counties to 
 have a representative attend to give us their slant or at least 
 educate them to the issues at hand.

And lastly, IMHO, this discussion/meeting should also include promoters 
 who aren't necessarily in aligmment with "rave culture" but put on 
 parties that can be construed as a representative of part of our scene 
 because this contributes to the identity that the general public views 
 as a liability (raves=irresponsible drug use).

But irregardless of the constrictive laws that suppressed us, we still 
 know how to get off...Did you catch some of that spirited groove at 
 Stompy?  Props to Preston & crew!


Diane
----------
>I've spoken to some of you about this before, and it is definitely
>time to change the cabaret laws in the city of San Francisco (I rave,
>and I vote!).  Seriously, way too many parties have been busted
>lately, and it's time for this to change. Instead of fighting and cursing>
>at the Law, *we* can change it through ballot propositions.

>Well? Anyone else up for this? I propose a meeting sometime this
>month. With some research, a lawyer or two, a petition, and some
>financial backing, we can have a ballot prop for 1998 to decriminalize
>dancing. I'm sick of complaining. It's time for *change*.

Can it be done?  Sure.  Does the dance community have what it takes to get
this done?  I think there is potential in everything, although to date, the
dance community has been rather limp-dicked about the whole thing.  It
would be like trying to get 10 people from the Stompy Party yesterday to
commit to political action (uh-huh...)...I think it can start as an SFRave
initiative, but must embrace dance culture in it's entirety if it's gonna
work.  My best wishes to those brave enough to press forward.

(I prefer back room dealing method myself, and it works just fine).

Peace & Happy New Year.  May it be a prosperous and rewarding year for all!,
John S. Lee - The Right Reverend of Boot Knockers Everywhere.

 Well, I'm a day late to complement this one!!  I've been sick, & resting.
All I have to say        is SNOOOCHIE BOOOCHIE NOOCHIIIEEEEES!!!!.   Just
kidding, I had a gggrrrreeaaaaat evening.
I was smiling from ear to ear the whole time,(wasn't even on e, never need
to be) even though I was sick as a dog, and had lost my voice. I felt the
most absolute positive vibe there.  Nothing felt better than dancing in the
rain after being drenched in sweat from dancing inside.  It was funny
watching the others cram under the tent outside cuz they didn't wanna get
soaked.  I met people there that had never been to a rave before,(they were
in awe) and so was I, for it the was first time in a long time, I heard any
of the harder edged stuff.=).  I remember Ernie in his primary spinning
days, and man, has he progressed!!!!!.  Hats off to you honey, you rocked
my world.  You all did.  Thank you, I needed that. Thank you Scott for
everything, It was so nice to meet you, finally. It's so refreshing to
finally meet some compassionate people.  It was definately family oriented,
I met some wonderful people.  All the hugs, all the people, all the
music----You filled my cup with utter elation. Thanks everyone.(CF)  This
party was beyond all my expectations.  My girlfriend was happy cuz she saw
all these people wearing clothes from her mom's store in Mty, Devaz.  I'll
be looking forward to the next event. Good Vibes all over, and then some.
Next time I'll try not to be sick, that was the ONLY thing that sucked.
I've been to alot of parties, and not may leave such an afterglow of energy
like this one. Sorry for the long post, I'm still excited thinking about
it.
Peace and Huggs,  Elina                                .

Subject: new years & SOULSTICE
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

i am sorry to hear that so many of you had to deal with parties breaking up
on new years.

my friends and i went to the minna street gallery to hear soulstice ring in
the new year!!!
the crowd was a perfect size for the space, there was enough room to groove
and not bump anyone!  the vibe was great.  everyone was in such a great mood
and just into having a great time ringing in the new year.

soulstice went on just 10 minues before the new year showed up, and
immediatly got a great show going.  there was the countdown, streamer poper
things all around, the confetti flying, everyone yelling, hugging and
kissing!!!!  
when the band took a break to switch to a dj, jamalski jumped up to the
microphone and did a jam with the band.  it was superb, he was rapping about
1997 with soulstice and jamalski.
we were dancing with strangers and old friends, everyone was there together. 
(not to mention some great art and visuals on the walls)

when soulstice finished for the night and dj's felix the dog and laron took
over.  everyone was just grooving!
i hope you all saw mark camp's post listing soulstice's show dates and you
get a chance to check out one of their shows.  they were worth the $10.00 i
paid.

funniest part: walking to the car with whipping winds, felt like i could fly!

i hope this is a good sign for more great parties to come in the new year. 

peace
shannon

To the brothers and sisters that know how to tap into the inner grooves 
 of the rhythmic heart.
Wrote this last night so the sentiments still linger some...hope you 
 can groove off it, too.
---

I'm still resonating with the infectious vibe
that our governments' finest tried to quell
around the many Bay Area gatherings
this NYE.

This vibrating spirit of joyous energies
sing high and low frequencies
  awakening our etheric fields
    pulsing a common rhythm
      of inner drives...
   all in the house of Jack                <--this is for Geoff
and JSL was nowhere to testify.   <--and this is for the Man! ;)

It was a glorious reflective gray day
  filled with curious wonderment and awe
of what we can still put together
  if we desire to share
    --openly and unconditionally--
  with all of it's nuances (good and bad)
embracing it fully as a common rhythm of life.

Simple enough as each breath we take
inhaling deep,
  expanding our bouyant cells of light/energy
and exhaling sharply from the lower diaphram
  releasing any impurities from our hearts.
---
I think I hit a moment of bliss  at this point and drifted into slumberland
'cause that's all I wrote. The running theme among many old timers 
 yesterday was:
"Make it happen!"  So what's keeping you?...

Love and much light,
Diane

this was my 5th consecutive new years in sf and the first time i was definitly
not in the mood for any kind of rave-like experience, i think it had something
to do with nye falling on a tuesday this year. instead, cami and I chilled at
home with some thai take out and a little wine, it was refreshingly mellow. and it 
was fun watching the silly people down at the ferry building gettin loose (ha ha) 
to the sounds of chris isaak and los lobos on the toob, i'm sure it was well worth 
the $85.  "amatuer night" indeed.

we made it over to stompy the next afternoon for awhile, it was a happy older-skool
crowd and the music was decent (if a little uninspired at times). one of the dj's
(johnny? from la?) played a 4-5 track herbert medly that was awesome.  overall, a nice 
way to ring in the new year on a rainy sf afternoon...

this recent wave of nye busts (nationwide) is unfortunate, '97 is going to be
"interesting" to say the least. my prediction is that i'll be going out less
frequently in general, but i'm going to try and check out more weeklies...

happy new year everybody,

andy
