>> Sorry to hear about all the busted parties, but what else do you expect?
>> This city and the surrounding areas hate raves.

	Maybe it's true that "the authorities" hate raves in particular, 
but I don't see that it's necessary to believe that to explain what 
happened NYE.


	There's wisdom that comes under the general category of
"don't follow the herd" which can be stated thusly: "those nites when
everybody else wants to go out & party are very good nites to stay home" 
& "those nites when everybody else throws massive parties are really
excellent nites to stay small & underground". 


	If you're going to throw a permitted massive on New Years eve, 
*expect* to have to jump through at least three extra hoops that wouldn't 
be there on a random Saturday nite. Apply months in advance. And maybe 
you still won't be able to get a permit at all. After all, you're competing 
with Willie Brown's Embarcadero bash & a thousand other huge parties thrown 
by people with serious political muscle. No city can handle more than a 
certain number of events on any given nite.


	As far as the police presence goes, pretty much every beat cop on 
every force in every city is on duty NYE. It's just routine. It has as much 
to do with the fact that your parents are going to be drinking cocktails & 
driving as it has with the fact that you want to go out & dance & maybe do 
some E. And yes, some of those cops are going to be in a *bad* mood. 
Some of them would rather be out partying themselves. Some of them have 
girlfriends or boyfriends that just don't understand why they can't get
off work to take them out on NYE. They're only people, after all. And some
of them aren't above taking out their bad mood on whoever's vulnerable. 
They're only people. 


	My friend Vince is a 39-year-old retired Oakland cop. He served 20
years on the force. Do the math - that'll tell you how old a lot of these 
cops are. Many of them are kids who played football in high school & went
thru a year or two of training & then went straight out onto the streets
(or maybe got some ink & piercings & got "enrolled" in SFSU or SCU or UCB 
and waited to be brought into some drug scene or other, but that's another 
story altogether.)


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jan  2 15:09:46 1997

Received: from ucdata.Berkeley.EDU.ucdt (ucdata.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.165.25]) by nak.berkeley.edu (8.7.3/8.6.10) with SMTP id PAA22302 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 2 Jan 1997 15:08:51 -0800 (PST)

Date: Thu, 2 Jan 1997 15:06:25 -0800 (PST)
From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: NYE-Nightmare on Linden Street
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9701021401.A23452-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


...and party on Clementina!

All dressed up, lookin' more like disco queens than ravechicks, K, Ivana, 
me and (non-disco queen) Josh rushed to Oakland in a haze of glitter, 
feather boas, and excitement, so ready for our first party in 
oh-so-long.  We arrived at 11:30, but the police were faster.  I took one 
look at the police cars, the long unmoving lines, and the two parties 
sandwiched together, and I knew that this was _not_ happening.  After a 
wrong turn into Origin, and about 10 clueless minutes outside Gateway, I 
announced that Plan B was in effect.  We were racing over to SF before  
the mappoint for CCC closed at 1!

So many details had to fall into place with split-second accuracy - 
locating an errant car, finding friends at a drunken party, getting home 
and then over to the city - all in the space of 60 short minutes.  
Midnight found us during a desperate trek by desolate Oakland Army Base, 
searching for a fast way to the freeway.  Wild 107 yelling, "'97, what's 
up, y'all!" and the four of us answering with a weak and despairing, "yay."
But somehow, someway, all these impossible tasks worked out perfectly.  
We hit the mappoint at one on the dot - zero hour.  Our friends found the 
party an hour later and we managed to get them in.  And finally, at two, 
our New Year's celebration at a killer party had begun!!

And what a party!  The music was amazing, ruthless goa trance.  The 
people were wonderful.  And the vibe was thick on the dancefloor.  Oh, 
there were limitations - the space was unbelievably hot and muggy, and 
crowded (no doubt swelled by all the busted parties).  The sound cut on 
and off.  And you couldn't sit without becoming covered with a wet black 
ooze.  But we were ecstatic at our luck to be at a real party with the 
greatest music and all our brothers and sisters.  We danced and celebrated 
and suddenly it was eight in the morning.  You know - "where did the 
night go??"

Thanks to that crew for providing a lovely NYE party for just $10.  Our 
Nightmare on Linden Street turned into a wonderful night - and we 
properly celebrated _our_ "Happy New Year" with the first rays of light 
of the new year.  :)

Rob posted:

>ANyway, with all the brains, creativity, and energy that this list alone
>represents, I am sure we could go a long way.  So I'm in for meeting with
>people and getting something organized, brainstorming, etc.  There, we
>already have one of our "one or two lawyers".

Count me in as attorney number two, although my professional experience
doesn't exactly give me any great knowledge of permits, zoning, and the
constitutional right to dance (in unsafe warehouses, all night long, for an
admission fee).  I think the key to any meeting of this sort is to have
some of the organizers share their war stories so we can get a better grip
on what needs to be done to stop having parties busted.

Having said that, this isn't really a legal issue, but a political one
which differs from city to city.  Cops in SF have shut down parties, but we
seem more likely to get away with an underground in the City than in the
East Bay or South Bay.  In Oakland, they seem to find out about the
parties, and after Fnf in July, they busted the Fnf in October and the NYE
events which weren't permitted.  Monty's point about the hypocrisy of
Oakland is even more telling when you know at midnight there was gunfire
all over the City -- a newbie friend who almost came with me to
Gateway/Pacific was awoken out of a brownie-induced nap at midnight in East
Oakland to ten deafening minutes of unbustable "celebrations."

But if there is a bright side, it may be this -- Oakland needs $$
desperately, due to their Raiders fiasco, and hopefully Officer Friendly's
comments about ravers to Steve Cooley, and observations that the Gateway
crowd peacefully dispersed (in marked contrast to Cool World), can lead to
successful dealings with Oakland officials in the future.

>From Pauly's forward from SoCalRaves about the NYE problems in LA:

>You try to cover all the bases but sometimes shit happens.  It's over.  As
>long as everyone is okay is the most important thing and that no one died.
>Let their lawyers deal with the legal shit now.  Whether you personally will
>continue to support the promoters, or not, is up to you.

Lawyers ain't gonna save the asses of incredibly sloppy massive promoters.
Raves encompass many different types of people, locations, sizes, music,
etc., and the risks go up exponentially when you have thousands of people.
Keeping things small, and more underground (invite only/tix only in
advance, whether or not seeking permits is necessary), will only help the
odds in the near future.

Diane Tabellija posted:

> I don't think it's just a rave issue our even a youth issue but an
> overall understanding of responsible rituals and rites in modern day
> society.  There's an attorney for human rights in HMB that might be
> interested in helping us out and Tony ?? in SF/Marin who's renown for
> taking some underdog cases.  Tony might have a representative that
> could attend and provide some info on the innerworkings of our local
> government but I don't think we should include them until we've got a
> platform/defined agenda.  Also, is there any such thing as a youth
> council that advises local governments in SF and Alameda counties to
> have a representative attend to give us their slant or at least
> educate them to the issues at hand.

You're probably talking about Tony Serra, whose personal life reveals he
would be sympathetic to our cause -- I have seen him getting down seriously
during Drums at Grateful Dead shows.  But it's a different matter getting
someone with a name to commit to the rave cause.  We do need to get our
shit together before seeking outside help, which might not be needed if we
can cope ourselves.

peace,

leftjab

Precedence: bulk

Cloud Factory was truly the gem of New Year's Eve! 

Space: A Rock Climbing gym, naturally surreal and absolutely 
       beautiful, was set-up to its greatest potential. I loved 
       dancing on top of shredded rubber! Plus it was also nice to
       get away from the city on such a crazy night.

Police: I have never seen authorities so cooperative with an event 
        like this. They seemed optimistic, and even drove past the 
        front door with their lights on and waving at midnight to 
        ring in the new year!

Music: Phat-ass beats outta four turntables almost all night long
       and into the morning! There was a great diversity in music  
       throughout the night, which insured booty shakin' for ravers
       with discriminating tastes.

Chill space: A 40' truck insured that CF guests would have
            a chill space regardless of the unpredictable weather. As
            it turns out, the rain wasn't bad so we got an
            outside dance area and a chill area. 

Visuals: Two giant screens and and a multitude of video sources
         produced some absolutely spectacular effects.

Free water *and* Chai: An unexpected and surprising double bonus. 

Cloud Factory was one of the most impressive productions I've seen in a
while. Their foresight, organization, attention to detail, and
importantly, their passion, really shone throught at this event. And
with an admission price of $10, I think those nutty kids really spoiled
us.

love, energy, and viberations,

Terry

	One more thing I want to throw out to the list before
I hear more whining about how the cops hate us and want to shut
us down. Remember that huge storm that was predicted to hit on NYE,
yet another "storm of the century"? Well, it didn't quite hit that
hard, at least as far as the wind was concerned, but imagine for a
second that it had. And imagine that we got the same kind of massive
power outages we saw last year. 

	Now imagine you're in Origin, or Gateway, or Cool World,
and the power goes out & stays out - all the power for miles around.

	Well, what do you do?

	And what does everyone around you do?

> Date: Thu, 2 Jan 1997 16:36:57 -0800
> From: leftjab@well.com (leftjab)

> Count me in as attorney number two, although my professional experience
> doesn't exactly give me any great knowledge of permits, zoning, and the
> constitutional right to dance (in unsafe warehouses, all night long, for an
> admission fee).  

Having an attorney available simply means having someone who can do
proper legal procedures and interpret (the often confusing) law and
legal language. Much research probably needs to be done, however, into
cabaret laws.

> I think the key to any meeting of this sort is to have
> some of the organizers share their war stories so we can get a better grip
> on what needs to be done to stop having parties busted.

Yes, very good idea. It would also be nice to contrast how things are
being handled now by rave promoters with what is expected by the law,
and the roadblocks that arise. Then we can get a better understanding
of what laws need to be changed, what laws cannot be changed, and what
are the workarounds or compromises that we need to make.

I'd like to organize a mailing list on my server for people interested
in participating in this movement. As interesting as it may be, I'm
not sure how much of this SFRaves as a whole would need to hear about,
and it may be useful for organizing people for a meeting, etc. to have
a separate mailing list.

Please send me email (privately!) if you'd like to see a mailing list
about this. If there's enough interest, expect it to appear sometime
this week. 

It's time to show the community that we're not just a bunch of "kids
on drugs". Ranging from struggling to wealthy, high school to
retirement, we're no different than any other cross section of
society; we just happen to enjoy electronic music and dancing.

heh. "Footloose" unfortunately does come to mind. :)

Steve

> Date: Thu, 2 Jan 1997 15:52:58 -0800 (PST)
> From: Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com>

> 	One more thing I want to throw out to the list before
> I hear more whining about how the cops hate us and want to shut
> us down. Remember that huge storm that was predicted to hit on NYE,
> yet another "storm of the century"? Well, it didn't quite hit that
> hard, at least as far as the wind was concerned, but imagine for a
> second that it had. And imagine that we got the same kind of massive
> power outages we saw last year. 
> 

Rob, the issue isn't about New Year's Eve, it has to do with the
Police hating the rave scene in general. They *do* want to shut us
down, and much of it has to do with money, and even more with the
perception that raves are "evil drug parties". A police officer
herding people at Gateway/Pacific was overheard as calling us a bunch
of "fucked up fairies". So, yes, they hate us.

The Police weren't out there because they care about us. If they were,
they would not have sent us home at 1am on rainy, windy freeways with
drunk drivers. We were safe and dry in our respective warehouses.  Had
the power gone out, we would have lit candles and been happy sharing
New Year's with friends.

Steve

Message-Id: <199701030017.QAA17478@scv2.apple.com>
Subject: My New Years Resolutions!
Date: Thu, 2 Jan 97 16:16:25 -0800
x-sender: camp@mail.apple.com
x-mailer: Claris Emailer 1.1
From: "Mark D. Camp" <camp@apple.com>
To: "sfraves" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Of course, there are the usual ones: Eat Healthy, Quit 
Smoking.....Actually, I've been doing pretty good with the eating healthy 
part.  But I'm just not ready to give up my American Spirit Lights just 
yet :)

I've had a strange past couple of weeks.  Christmas sucked.  It was the 
first Christmas I did not spend with my family.  I guess to really 
understand how I was feeling, you'd have to know and understand my past 
and my family...but I dont want to get into that.  The hollidays really 
made me think about my life and where it is going and where I want it to 
go and how the hell to get there.  I'm not saying I'm unhappy with my 
life.  I'm...well, Kinda doing what I want with my life.  I have a good 
job, I have good friends, I'm healthy, I have a kick ass music studio 
that I dont spend half as much time in as I'd like to because of said 
'good job'.  hmm...maybe its not such a good job afterall....

Anyways, I've always had a problem with expressing my feelings...well, I 
wouldnt actually call it a problem...its just how I am.  Partly because I 
am usually a really quite person.  Its not that I am shy or anything.  I 
could care less what people think about me.  Its just that I am quite.  
nough said.  but the problem with this is I dont express my feelings, my 
thoughts, my emotions, my desires, as much as I should.  or maybe I 
should say, as much as I want to.  

so, Major Resolution Number One:

Express and deal with my feelings and thoughts more.  I think dealing and 
understaning my feelings is going to be much harder than expressing them.

Now, on to Major Resolution Number Two.

I've been attending raves for about 6 years now.  I'd say at least 90% of 
the parties I've attended I've taken E or LSD.  Ectasy is an amazing 
drug.  If you take it inteligently.  Its my belief that if all the 
leaders of the world were thrown in a room each with a hit of E and a 
glass of water, all of our world problems would be solved.  Let 'em duke 
it out on E.  Everyone's would realize that we are all one person.  As 
Dub Tribe would Say "This Planet is Mine, This Planet is Ours, and we 
have GOT to live together."

I know that I have taken E way too many times.  I am not learning 
anything from it anymore.  When I am on E at a party, I'm consentrating 
on how *I* feel.  I'm not consentrating on the music or the global vibe 
and on my surroundings.  Its a *Me* thing now.  I'm beginning to attended 
more parties sober.  And I've realized that when I'm sober, I'm more 
aware of the party and my surroundings.  The music and people have much 
more impact on me, and it is actually easier to talk to people more 
intelegently.  On E, the conversation is usually 'Hows your E, Do you 
want a back rub'....etc... When sober, for me at least, conversations are 
a little bit more genuine.  Maybe its because I know its not a drug 
talking, it is one's true self that is talking.  

I'm not saying I will never take E again.  I just need to take a very 
extended brake from it.

ok, I think thats it.  Damn, it feels good.  I am very much looking 
forward to the year ahead!

See you all in life,

Mark  

                       *______________*______________*           
                                   !E.A.C!
                                  Astronout            
                               408 SpaceLounge         
                        Electronic Artists Collective

From: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Cc: leftjab
Subject: Re: NYE... and a Call to Arms.
Date: Thursday, January 02, 1997 4:36PM

Leftjab said:
>You're probably talking about Tony Serra, whose personal life reveals he
>would be sympathetic to our cause -- I have seen him getting down seriously
>during Drums at Grateful Dead shows.  But it's a different matter getting
>someone with a name to commit to the rave cause.  We do need to get our
>shit together before seeking outside help, which might not be needed if we
>can cope ourselves.

I guess that's where I feel we need to start and begin to understand 
 exactly what we are "fighting" for.  In my mind (very vast and full 
 this daydreamy afternoon ;) our issues can be defined but worthless if 
 it's not presented in a respectful and empathic manner to the key 
 people who oversee and influence the process to make things "legit" 
 (shudder!).

I tend to like the safety in numbers route and go with as much gusto 
 and influence on/to/in the system to let our needs be heard and met 
 (squeaky wheel syndrome) but "coping ourselves" is appealing if we 
 take the concerned member of the community & educational route which 
 might be the first logical and less rebellious approach.  By forming a 
 committee to interview and work with each city evaluating how to best 
 "support" our desire to dance all night.  Interviews with police, 
 fire, electrical, & other official reps can provide us with an outline 
 of their concerns and needs to legally appease the law.  Take that 
 info and create a check-list/forms and contact list to provide to 
 promoters showing what is required to throw a legit party.  It'll be 
 up to them to adhere to it.  And yeah...it takes away some of the fun 
 in "raving" but I know there'll still be renegades and smaller gigs to 
 keep some things sacred.

We must also acknowledge our weaknesses and perhaps create an 
 educational outreach table/flyer info made available at each party re: 
  resources on abuses, alternative legal ways of expanding 
 consciousness, safe practices, etc.  (Look at the gay community's aids 
 awareness and safe sex campaign.)  By taking away the stigma of 
 unknown fear that the general public and the law associates with 
 raving, it can become more palattable as we have already seen in 
 fashion and music overlaps.  (What the eyes don't see, the belly won't heave!)

We've seen, heard, and rumoured what promoters and club owners do to 
 handle things...very differently and competitively.  Individual 
 motivations can often get in the way of unifying them to openly 
 discuss their war stories and _agree_ (easier said and hardly 
 imagined) what's acceptable and what isn't.  So that path may be left 
 to a later time when other alternatives have been exhausted.

And hey, I'm impressed!  Two attorneys on this list.  And I thought we 
 were a bunch of geeks! ;)

Warm embraces,
Diane

I'm a licensed therapist with an office space and I'm thinking 
about starting a support group for anyone who feels that 
raving is part of their lives.

This group will provide people with the opportunity to explore 
how raving effects your relationships to others and yourself.
An opportunity to talk about whats going on in your life, how its
effecting you, and a chance to get support and gain insight from 
other members of the group.

This group will be limited to 10 people,
if interested please email me privately.

:)
peter

Hawaii---
Oahu
first of all funk pistol closed about a year ago. you may want to check
out the Radio Free Hawaii page at
http://www.lava.net/radio-free/
but you should check out this page first...ward industries..they throw
most of the larger parties in hawaii....
http://members.aol.com/wardindus/wardindus.html
you can get some phone numbers here...

as for clubs, there's formula 45(or forty sumptin, I don't remember)
which is the place to be on the weekends. and Kids Klub on the first
sunday of every month... 

as for the other islands, I've never really partied there.
--

from Come/Unity, but I left them at home.  If there's any more info

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday morning 9am-11am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench. Varied techno sub-genres, noise, spoken word, world
       music. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)

       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)

       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Rob Rayle wrote:
> 
>         One more thing I want to throw out to the list before
> I hear more whining about how the cops hate us and want to shut
> us down. Remember that huge storm that was predicted to hit on NYE,
> yet another "storm of the century"? Well, it didn't quite hit that
> hard, at least as far as the wind was concerned, but imagine for a
> second that it had. And imagine that we got the same kind of massive
> power outages we saw last year.
> 
>         Now imagine you're in Origin, or Gateway, or Cool World,
> and the power goes out & stays out - all the power for miles around.
> 
>         Well, what do you do?
> 
>         And what does everyone around you do?

Break out the glowsticks, flashlights, and candles?  Have a nice,
mellow, ambient time until everyone who's fucked up is good enough to go
home?  And if you're lucky there are a few people with drums, or at
least some good hollow stuff to beat on (I got a crowd dancing with a
city trashcan and a newspaper box)...

Seriously, what does this have to do with cops breaking up peaceful,
consensual gatherings for no reason other than blind prejudice or the
greed of city bureaucrats?  And how does forcing people (possibly
altered, legally or otherwise) out on the street "serve and protect"
anything but their own egos?

In my long history of going to gatherings small and large, I have
_never_ been endangered, or felt endangered, by other revelers.  This
history includes rock concerts, street festivals, punk clubs, Burning
Man, street demonstrations, and much more.  I have been physically
endangered at such events, and harassed and intimidated many times, by
police officers.

Thus my opinion.

// grigsbeast

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jan  3 00:22:32 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id AAA20214; Fri, 3 Jan 1997 00:22:32 -0800 (PST)
Received: from vmar.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id AAA20198; Fri, 3 Jan 1997 00:22:27 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [157.22.222.245] by vmar.com
 with ESMTP (Apple Internet Mail Server 1.0); Fri, 3 Jan 1997 00:33:01 -0800
Message-Id: <v03007806aef271c6e945@[157.22.222.245]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 3 Jan 1997 00:21:30 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Vince <vince@vmar.com>
Subject: Sick Revelers (LA NYE Trouble)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

--------------- Forwarded Story ---------------

Headline: Sick Revelers
Wire Service: APn (AP US & World)
Date: Thu, Jan 2, 1997

 Copyright 1997 The Associated Press. All rights reserved.
The information contained in this news report may not be published,
broadcast or
otherwise distributed without the prior written authority of the Associated
Press.
   By MINERVA CANTO
 Associated Press Writer
   LOS ANGELES (AP) -- The government warned consumers not to ingest synthetic
designer drugs with names like "Cherry fX Bomb" that violently sickened dozens
in a crowd of young partygoers at a New Year's Eve "rave" concert.
   The U.S. Food and Drug Administration warned people Wednesday not to consume
colored liquid products named "Orange fX Rush," "Lemon fX Drop," and "Cherry fX
Bomb." The liquids are stored in glass vials.
   "These products have been implicated in severe adverse reactions including
dizziness, nausea, severe shortness of breath and respiratory arrests that
affected approximately 50 people -- some of whom were hospitalized," said FDA
spokesman Jim O'Hara in Washington, D.C.
   O'Hara said confiscated vials of the "fX" products will be tested by the
FDA.
The vials were handed out at the concert, attended by about 10,000 people. Six
people have been arrested for investigation of selling and distributing drugs.
   A 17-year-old boy who suffered a heart attack and an 18-year-old woman were
upgraded from critical to stable condition today. Another boy remained in
critical condition after being struck by a car during the melee that erupted
when the concert was canceled.
   Concertgoer Charlie Bambrook had to be treated for four hours after he drank
an "fX" product and fell to the ground writhing in pain, vomiting.
   "Then they had an announcement: `Do not take this fX, whatever it is, do not
take it,'" the 18-year-old Bambrook told KCAL-TV on Wednesday.
   The rave, an advertised, all-night party known for loud, techno-music was
shut down early, angering youths who paid about $25 to attend. The concert
ended
in a bottle- and stone-hurling melee on downtown streets. A city bus was
violently rocked.
   One young man was hit in the head by an object and a policeman suffered
minor
injuries when he was hit by a bottle, Officer Mike Partain said.
   Officers in riot gear dispersed the crowd by firing rubber pellets.
Order was
restored about 1:30 a.m. Wednesday, officials said. Four people were arrested
for resisting arrest and failing to disperse.
   Dr. Robert Splawn of California Hospital Medical Center said patients
admitted at the center had symptoms from a mix of a variety of drugs.
   "Apparently several drugs were being abused," he said. "We've heard
everything from X (Ecstasy), to LSD to the new one, GHB (Gamma hydroxybutyrate
also known as Liquid X). Some participants told me people were using a
combination of them." GHB is a legal substance.
   The drugs cause euphoria, convulsions and comas, the doctor said.
   A concert promoter described the drink as a legal, herbal stimulant, but
police said they were unsure what the substance was.



--- end forwarded text

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> >
> >         Now imagine you're in Origin, or Gateway, or Cool World,
> > and the power goes out & stays out - all the power for miles around.
> >
> >         Well, what do you do?
> >
> >         And what does everyone around you do?



> Break out the glowsticks, flashlights, and candles?  Have a nice,
> mellow, ambient time until everyone who's fucked up is good enough to go
> home? 

	You know, you probably would. And maybe the rest of the people 
at Origin & Gateway would too. From the descriptions of what happened
at Cool World, it sure doesn't sound like *that* crowd would be as cool
as what you've described, but hell, maybe they would too.

	But do you think that the city officials who call the shots for 
large scale organized police activity on NYE *believe* you're cool enough 
to pull that off? Isn't it possible that some of them had nightmare scenarios
involving large scale power outages on NYE running through their minds?
And maybe even they were more concerned about people getting hurt than 
about money or control - or your personal fun time? (Hell, maybe even
a few of them were worried about people getting hurt because of general
humanness, as opposed to the "it will make *me* look bad" thing.)

	Nah, you're probably right. I'm sorry, I forgot that the rave 
community has a monopoly on all things righteous & true. For everyone 
else it's all about money and control and they're all BAD, very very 
BAD. And out to get us, too. Scuse me, I think someone's bugged my 
toilet.

> In my long history of going to gatherings small and large, I have
> _never_ been endangered, or felt endangered, by other revelers.
> I have been physically 
> endangered at such events, and harassed and intimidated many times, by
> police officers.
> Thus my opinion. 

	Well, I've been billy clubbed once by a sadistic asshole cop, 
but I've been physically harmed in various ways by fellow revelers 
at various gatherings much more often than that. I've also met
very decent cops, and thank god, very decent fellow revelers. 
Thus my opinion.

Subject: The BIG Picture (was... A Call to Arms)

Date: Fri, 3 Jan 1997 10:24:20 -0800

Precedence: bulk


Hey Everyone!

First up, massive thanks to everyone for their support at the NYE Trance
party, as well as the Afterparty the next day. Turns out Johhny Law showed
up at both events, but left us alone. We had things well under control, so
they didn't have a reason to give us a hard time. Nice!  :)

I've found that there is a certain amount of gray area in which you can
operate and not get hassled. Deviate outside of the gray, and your bound to
attrach attention to yourself. Low key is the place to be.  :)

Next. My perception on the authorities "crack down" with "Rave"

- There's been so much bad publicity with "rave" that They feel it shouldn't
happen. As Gobbels (Hitler's propaganda minister) once said: "A lie told
often enough becomes the truth." Bad media = negative perception = bias',
judgements = negative reactions. I've spoken with the local authoroties on
this, and as long as the event doesn't have any connection with the word
"Rave", they're much more willing to work with you. 

- The city governments don't make any money of the profits, so it's in their
interest to minimize the "popularity" of such events, so as to keep control
over who's makin' money. Why allow a bunch of kids to make money if the city
ain't gettin it's "fair" share?

- it's NYE. Johnny's gets paid overtime to work if he has the excuse.
Busting "illegal" parties is a good excuse to work NYE, so why not clock
some extra hours at the cities (ie taxpayers) expense. Hell, we actually
PAID the police to bust our parties with our tax dollars! What a racket!


I spoke with Steve on Wednesday about his working to mobilize the community
to change to laws here in town (BTW, thanks for the support, Steve!). Having
a group of people petition the city is a great idea. Unfortunately, city
government (esp. Willie Brown's) usual gives a rat's ass about people. The
bottom line is: Is the city making money? If so, then your argument has some
validity. If not, well talk all you want, but unless it get's national press
coverage, your wasting time. I've spoken with some people in Scaramento, as
well as city offices, about this, and that's the general consensus.

The city's trying to get money by raising the permit fees. Once they were
$500, then $750 now their $1300. Yikes! 

So it seems that in order to approach the city, you have to convince them
that they're making money by allowing us to dance. How so?

Get support from local businesses. The more people here the music, the more
music they want to buy, which means more sales from the stores, which means
more tax dollars for the city.  If local businesses are involved, and the
city's getting revenue from their business, then they're gonna be much more
receptive to your arguement. 

Lump in the "community" aspect on top of your argument, and your bound to
convince a few.

But that still leaves the negative perceptions. Sure, the city is making
money, but what about all these drugs and everything?

Change the perceptions. We at Space Station Russ have been talking of
getting a media campaing together to helps dispell a few myths about our
culture. We got to find a new name for what we do, and *bonk* the public on
the head with it until their perceptions change.

After all, the truth told often enough becomes...well...the truth!  ;)

As a music distributor, I can help rally the support of local businesses,
but I'll need help. Steve, line up some meetings so we can delegate some
responsibilities and get this thing rolling.

Oh yeah... the afterparty  on NYD went so well, that we'll be turning it
into a weekly thing. Keep your eyes and ears open for the new place to be
Sunday mornings!

later!

Jonas
 
P.S. Sorry I haven't had a chance to write everyone back personally, but
I've been EXTREMELY busy. End of year inventory SUCKS!!!!!

Mr nStuff wrote:
> 
> People were dying.

Evidently not.  People pass out from alcohol, even get hospitalized for
alcohol poisoning all the time, and no one considers it unusual.  But
someone passes out from something else and everyone gets all wound up.

> Sometimes police kind of concider fatalities at parties pretty good reason
> to shut down I guess.

And this decision prevented further pain and suffering how?

(Aside from the minor detail of there not being any fatalities.)

Seems like all they did was hurt a bunch _more_ people, _after_ everyone
had already been told to stay away from the stuff that was knocking
people out.

I'm not pointing fingers at anyone here; there's plenty of blame to go
around and, in the end, it really doesn't matter who's fault it was. 
The point is, bad stuff happened, and some people reacted wrongly to it
-- police, promoters, and partygoers too.

What can we learn from this?  I have a few tentative conclusions:
1) Don't ingest something if you don't know what it is.
2) Don't taunt people who are in a shitty mood anyway.
3) If you're going to throw a party, be prepared for the worst, and have
a sound approach planned out to deal with it (to avoid things like 2,
above)
4) If you're going to attend a party, be prepared for the worst, and
have an approach planned out.  It's good to think beforehand about what
throwing bottles around will accomplish.

For instance: I went to a Crash Worship show once with a friend.  We
agreed to get the hell out of there if the cops showed up, because he
had been busted in the infamous New Year's raid (this was a couple of
years ago) and didn't want to risk being recognized.  So when the
promoters called the cops, we got the hell out of there, even though the
dancing in the street afterwards evidently was quite cool, and no one
got arrested.  The risk wasn't worth it.  I've engaged in CD before, but
that wasn't the time.

// grigsbeast

What you wrote is pretty much the truth, as far as I know.  Almost exactly
what you wrote was on the front page of the SF Chronicle yesterday.  They
were doing tests on the drug, as no one knew what it was.  Although, it
was called FX.  I'd keep reading newspapers, especially the California
sections to find out what was the mixture that got so many people
seriously sick.  

"RAVE" does appear to be a dirty word these days and it's certainly
showing in the media.  I hesitate to use the word with my non-raver
friends because of the negative connotation.  I'm thinking about writing
to the editorials of the Chronicle about how the media portrays raving.
It's easy.  They publish most everything.  And, it's a simple way to get
the word out.  A few reasonable letters about the positive aspects of
raving might go a long way to counterbalancing all the negative stuff.  To
me, when you are dealing with the mainstream, it might be a good idea to
work within those limits.

But, it's just an idea!


-KaySEE

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Legality and Safety
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9701031510.A526-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hey kids -

I think we have no choice but to work with the proper authorities.  We 
cannot seem to throw too many events (except the very smallest) without 
being swooped on; it remains up to the generosity of the cop in question 
whether we get to party or not.  Even CCC was visited on NYE - a small 
party of about 300 people.  So, the idea of having renegade parties that 
escape the notice of police seems like a fantasy, or exceptional luck.  

I don't know if cops are out to get us, just for fun.  I see them more as 
doing their jobs - 
enforcing the fire code when they shut down parties (in most cases), 
generating revenue for the city (permits),  though also being too quick to 
use force when people don't follow their orders immediately (crowd 
dispersal).  If we were able to throw parties within 
the legal limitations, I doubt there would be much harassment from the 
cops.  After all, permit fees would have been paid.  

Honestly, I don't see the fire code as a great oppressor to us.  I 
personally am hesitant about spending all night in old brick warehouses, 
with one tiny entrance, narrow stairways and floors that threaten to fold 
with the weight of the crowd.  The reason such a location is not legal is because it is 
DANGEROUS.  

Personally, I'm tired of dirty dangerous places.  I think we deserve 
better - the right to dance all night in a safe and comfortable place.  
It's a dream, anyway.  Could organizing our community help lead to its 
creation?

Is it even possible for us to have a legal event?  Will we be 
granted permits at all?  Is the fee reasonable?  Will cover charges 
have to rise astronomically?  Will our hours of dancing be restricted?  
May we rent out a legal location (small club) all-night for all-ages if 
no alcohol is served?

I don't know if all this ground has been trod before by the many 
wonderful partythrowers in the Bay Area.  Advance apologies if this is 
all old news.  And I can see complications like political pressure from 
powerful legit clubs, cops/city officials unwilling to aid "raves" 
(perception of teens on dangerous drugs, ultimate accountability to 
taxpayer parents), and huge, extortionary permit fees.

But let's at least find out what we "officially" need to do to throw our 
events.  A show of respect and willingness to learn how we can play by 
the rules may go far to improve our image with authorities.  Coupled with 
a public relations campaign and even a ballot initiative, perhaps we can 
turn the tide that runs against all-night dance events.

What exactly is illegal about a private individual renting their own 
property to a group of people to have a party?  Especially in an 
industrial area with no residents around to be bothered?  And considering 
that the crowd is peaceful, safe, and causes no problems?? 

_I_ haven't been able to understand the problem, but there obviously are 
some.  Let's try to address the authorities' concerns, if possible, 
because eluding the authorities seems unlikely.  Although with 
_some_ of their concerns - unsafe buildings, young teens on dangerous 
drug combinations - I have to say I utterly concur!

Being legit is not selling out.  It means we are taking care of - and 
building - our community.  

With hope,
Nancy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jan  3 15:55:52 1997

Subject: orange colored drugs?
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'd have to say that anyone who takes any sort of drugs without at least a
pretty good indication of what it is, and what it does, and of the source,
isn't behaving very wisely.  Would you go into the woods and just eat any
pretty plant or mushroom without knowing what it is?  
I think not.
The key to being and staying free and healthy is knowledge.  Use any substance
wisely and knowingly, and you're not likely to have a bad trip.
much love,
Bruce.

>"RAVE" does appear to be a dirty word these days and it's certainly
>showing in the media.  I hesitate to use the word with my non-raver
>friends because of the negative connotation.  I'm thinking about writing
>to the editorials of the Chronicle about how the media portrays raving.
>It's easy.  They publish most everything.  And, it's a simple way to get
>the word out.  A few reasonable letters about the positive aspects of
>raving might go a long way to counterbalancing all the negative stuff.  To
>me, when you are dealing with the mainstream, it might be a good idea to
>work within those limits.
>
>But, it's just an idea!
>
>
>-KaySEE



The only good thing on the news was that the media didn't say "rave", they
said rock concert.
I was pretty upset awhile back when Hard Copy did their major exploitation
of raves. Now people in this conservative country town I live in, frown
upon hearing the word "rave", because they automatically think drugs and
Satan.  Ha, ha, pretty funny huh! So I'm kinda glad this time they said
concert.  I saw the story on CNN. elina

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Some Pro-Rave Points
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9701031539.A526-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>

Precedence: bulk



Some points to make with authorities:

FINANCIAL
1) The electronic dance subculture has spawned a thriving economy, 
including many small businesses, providing employment, tax revenue and 
creating successful local entrepreneurs
2) Partygoers support this economy and travel into cities for specialty 
shops, spending money in these shops and other establishments
3) Partygoers spend money in cities that host events, such as on public 
transportation, gas stations, restaurants 
4) Tourism.  The dance subculture is a global phenomenon, with many people 
traveling to other cities/even countries partly to attend events. 
5) As events cause few problems other than permit violations, precious 
police resources are wasted during otherwise dangerous weekend nights

THE ATTENDEES
1) the crowd that attends is overwhelmingly peaceful and safe
2) as opposed to clubbers and bar-goers, attendees at all-night events 
often leave in the morning.  They are not driving on the streets at 2AM, 
which is safer for them and others.
3) all-ages events are a recreational outlet for teens, who have few 
other possibilities
4) all-ages events provide a safe place where a large amount of young people 
peacefully converge, as opposed to looking for excitement on city 
streets or in drunken parties
5) there is no alcohol served at all-night dance events

THE COMMUNITY
1) The dance subculture is renowned for a strong sense of community, 
based on positive values
2) Violence at dance events is remarkably rare
3) Police visits to dance events are overwhelmingly for lack of legal 
permits, NOT because of violence or any other emergency
4) Many dance events contribute proceeds to charity causes, such as toy 
drives at Christmas, Food Not Bombs, etc.
5) Being a global phenomenon, the dance subculture is forging positive 
links between cities domestically and internationally 

and this is just off the top of my head

     Excerpt from "Chicken Soup for the Soul".  A raver type of story....

     I was in New York the other day and rode with a friend in a taxi.  When
we got out, my friend said to the driver, "Thank you for the ride.  you did a
superb job of driving."  
     The taxi driver was stunned for a second.  Then he said, "Are you a wise
guy or something?" 
     "No, my dear man, and I'm not putting you on.  I admire the way you keep
cool in heavy traffic." 
     "Yeah," the driver said and drove off.
     "What was that all about?" I asked.
     "I am trying to bring love back to New York," he said.  "I believe it's
the only thing that can save the city."
     "How can one man save New York?"
     "It's not one man.  I believe I have made that taxi driver's day.
 Suppose he has 20 fares.  He's going to be nice 20 fares because someone was
nice to him.  Those fares in turn will be kinder to their employees or
shopkeepers or waiters or even their own families.  Eventually the goodwill
could spread to at least 1,000 people.  Now that isn't bad, is it?"
     "But you're depending on that taxi driver to pass your goodwill to
others."
     "I'm not depending on it," my friend said.  "I'm aware that the system
isn't foolproof so I might deal with ten different people today.  If out of
ten I can make three happy, then eventually I can indirectly influence the
attitudes of 3,000 more."
     "It sounds good on paper," I admitted, "but I'm not sure it works in
practice."
     "Nothing is lost if it doesn't.  It didn't take any of my time to tell
that man he was doing a good job.  He neither received a larger tip nor a
smaller tip.  If it fell on deaf ears, so what?  Tomorrow there will be
another taxi driver I can try to make happy."
     "You're some kind of nut," I said.
     "That shows how cynical you have become.  I have made a study of this.
 The thing that seems to be lacking, besides money of course, for our postal
employees, is that no one tells people who work for the post office what a
good job they're doing."
     "But they're not doing a good job."
     "They're not doing a good job because they feel no one cares if they do
or not.  Why shouldn't someone say a kind word to them.
     We were walking past a structure in the process of being built and
passed five workmen eating their lunch.  My friend stopped.  "That's a
magnificent job you men have done.  It must be difficult and dangerous work."
     The workmen eyed my friend suspiciously.
     "When will it be finished?"
     "June," a man grunted.
     "Ah.  That really is impressive.  You must all be very proud."
     We walked away.  I said to him, "I haven't seen anyone like you since
The Man From LaMancha."
     "When those men digest my words, they will feel better for it.  Somehow
the city will benefit from their happiness."
     "But you can't do this all alone!" I protested.  "You're just one man."
     "The most important thing is not to get discouraged.  Making people in
the 
city become kind again is not an easy job, but if I can enlist other people
in m campaign....."
     "You just winked at a very plain-looking woman," I said.
      "Yes, I know," he replied. "And if she's a school-teacher, her class
will be in for a fantastic day."
                                   --Art Buchwald

         hugs,
           'trice                    <<<<RAVEON>>>>

<<Greetings Earthlings>>

	We here at Lepidoptera Global Headquarters are gearing up for our 
next event, and are toying w/ tentative lineups for this and future 
parties. One thing I personally am aiming for is to showcase 
up-and-coming DJ's. It seems like there is a lot of undiscovered talent 
out there. So, we would like to hear from you. If you have a tape you can 
send us, please email us privately or leave a message on our voicemail @ 
408.535.0432. Either way, please give us your name, the style or styles 
your music encompasses, and any other info you deem relevant.

	Those of you who are vinyl-deficient, please feel free to contact 
us concerning anything else (you can lend a hand, you want to be on the 
mailing list, etc). We LOVE to hear from you.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jan  3 18:17:22 1997

The Short Revue:

Best party of '96. Props -> DBN, Mushgroove, Incredibeets, Placebo, UPS :)

The Long Version (in my aimlessly meandering style):

Advance apologies 2 the sfraves folk who don't care... I thought some of u might be 
interested. I know u'all get a ton o mail, 'cause I'm on the list. Get this mw-raves; 
the sfraves list brings in twice as much e-mail as the mw-raves list and it's just Bay 
area! ;) I can't wait 2 get out there, tho I will miss u mw-ravers tons!

Before I start, does anyone know what was happenning with the passed out (I assume) 
person by the right speakers (facing the djs, in the main room)? I was kinda concerned 
about this person, who was laying on the floor (with friends trying 2 care 4 her/him) 
for about a half hour until the paramedics showed up. Maybe the DBN krew know 
something? Just curious...

Another thing, does anyone out there know how 2 contact this girl who goes by "jewel" 
(it's not her real name), from Milwaukee? I met her near the end of the evening and she 
is supra-kewl, but we got disconnected and she left before we could do the number 
thing. Any help would be wonderful and greatly appreciated. Please, reply private, TIA.

Okay, hope I don't ramble 2 much, if so jus' click <delete> :) So, here goes...

Rode up 2 'Waukee with Randy, it was a nice ride. Thanks Randy! :) Got 2 the space 
around 10:00p or so. Bumped into MikeyD at the entrance passing out flyers 4 RELEASE 
(UTC). Kewl, "kickin' kiwi-lime" Kool-Aid packet stickered flyer! :) Then bumped into 
Marc on the way up the stairs. Hi!

Wait a minute... I didn't get searched, what? I always have a slight concern about 
weapons and stuff when there's no search, but there is always a yang 4 the yin (it's 
really nice jus' walkin into a party) and I did not notice any violence/troubles all 
night long. There was some guy walking around clenching his fists, don't think that 
counts as violence, tho there was some bad vibes at times. :) I sure am glad I wasn't 
at that mega-rave in L.A. (sorry, Gage).

I had a wonderful time. I loved it. Met a buncha nice ppl (sound familiar?) and saw a 
buncha others, I can never get enough of! ;) A little too much hardcore 4 most people, 
I think. Tho, I totally dug it. Randy was unable 2 protect his soul from the evil 
hardcore and ended up spiritually depleted around 3:00a. Randy, I sure hope Satan 
has returned your soul unscathed. :) If u change your mind about the big parties and u 
decide 2 start going again, u might consider investing in a soul protection cloak. I 
think they run about 3000 gold pieces at the magic shop. :)

I, too, thought the emmcee shoulda "shut the fuck up" half of the time he was talking. 
The other half of the time, I was laughing my ass off at what I thought he was saying. 
;)

The loudest dam midnite countdown I have ever heard! Does the DBN krew have a final 
head count? My guess is 5,000 ppl. Randy and I were standing around at the countdown 
and just after midnite, saw J-Sun (who we were half-assed looking 4 since we got 
there). We ran over...big hugs! Shit, J-Sun, the 2 of us and bear hugs are a lethal 
combination! *crack* :)

Alec Empire: as I expected, my brain totally exploded! It was extremely difficult 
trying 2 gather up all of the pieces and super-glueing them back into my head... I 
totally loved his set! Yeah, it was hard as hell and u really couldn't dance 2 it, but 
it was a great trip. Just stood there 4 a while holding my white cellophane NYE hat on 
my head and jumping up and down like a maniac with J-Sun (Randy was running 4 cover, I 
think). ;) Later in his set he did some really kewl stuff with some really spatial 
droning audio. That was my favorite part. :)

Total Output: I really liked the music. BUT, the girl (singing?) was sending scary 
chills down my spine. I ended up having nitemares of her screaming all of this 
fucked-up shit at me... Eeeks! :o

P909: I ended up entering another dimension during their set. I remember hearing some 
nice stuff going on, but 4 some reason. It really didn't grab me. Which is wierd 'cause 
I love their studio work. Might have just been that time of the evening 4 me. ;)

Net Meet: Ooops. Was there supposed 2 be a net meet? ;) Sorry I missed out, It would 
have been nice 2 meet those of u I haven't met yet.

Phantom 45: Jungle has a small place in my heart and the man like Brian always 
reinforces it. Tho, I didn't catch alot of the set, what I heard was quite nice.

Around 3:00a or so, I was trying 2 find Amy and Scott 2 juggle my ride home. I don't 
get it with u 2... There is somewhere another dimension which these 2 go into, when 
they're at parties. I don't know where it is, but is certainly not within the realm of 
my perception. :|

4:40a, in the dark and scary room, stopped by with MikeyD looking 4 Amy. Wait, I know 
this song. Shit, it's Delta9! At 4:40a? Eh? "What kinda krazy party is this? Putting 
Delta9 at 4:40a?" That was pretty wild. Jumped aronud 4 a little while, didn't stay for 
the whole set. Had had enough hardcore 4 the night, but I love Dave's stuff and the 
system in that 2nd room wasn't doing it justice. So...

I looked 4 Amy until like 5:00a when I gave up and decided 2 leave with Randy and give 
J-Sun directions 2 my place 4 his krew and Amy's krew 2 crash. At that very moment 
(writing directions 4 J-Sun), the girl shows up and says "r u leaving?". I was soo 
happy 2 see her my head almost exploded (again) and I got 2 stay! :)

The Christmas Light room was very nice. At one point, I walked by the room and there 
was some booty house playing and everybody was crammed in there together squirming and 
dancing. I thought it looked like something from the remake of "The Thing", like all of 
these ppl had been morphed together. Wooo, scary dance-orgy stuff! I wanted 2 join 
in... but I ain't got the guts. ;)

I'm not sure how I feel about the strippy girls dancing on the stage. On one hand I 
thought it was kinda crude and such (especially near the end of the night when they 
were getting all nasty). On the other hand, I got a chance 2 talk a little with a few 
of them and they were really nice and all, so I don't know? There were times when a 
buncha guys were standing in front of them, just like drooling and such. That was 
pretty sad...

I think I feel the same confused yin/yang way about the video from Demon Puppet. The 
sex and bondage and such is okay (especially during the hardcore) 4 a while, but what 
about some nice fractals, colored-oil, computer animation types of stuff? After all, 
we've got live flesh on stage (smells better than video, tho the video did look better 
than the girls, at times). :)

Went up 2 the bar and this girl asks me if I have fifty cents... I just started 
laughing, 'cause I didn't think I had any money at all (ended up with $2 in quarters in 
my pocket). I couldn't stop laughing. I finally settled down and explained that I was 
pretty broke and she came across her cash and offered 2 buy me a drink. :) This turns 
out 2 be the girl like "jewel". We went and sat down and talked 4 a bit and then danced 
for a while. What a sweetheart! I love meeting nice ppl! :) I went adventuring for a 
bit alone, went downstairs, came back up and no more "jewel". Oh well, we'll see what 
fate has in store... I am sure we'll connect again, someday. :)

BTW, I was previously pretty much against alcohol at parties, but I had 2 drinks NYE 
and really enjoyed 'em. As others on the list have said, it's all good, moderation is 
the key. Anyway, I still think it's a problem 'cause of laws which can close down a 
party with alcohol.

The space was great, like others have said. I agree that it would be nice 2 see people 
use trashcans 4 a change. AND alla those flyers ain't cheap, so why are there always so 
many that end up trashed on the floor? I must again reflect on the yin and yang here; 
It sure is fun kicking all of that trash around in the morning before the party ends. 
:)

Danced mostly on the main floor until around 9:15a or so. I think it was Bernard Badies 
or Reese (or both) who kept me moving. Nice, innovative house. I would try to stop 
dancing, but it jus' wouldn't work. It's wierd, but I think I am starting to appreciate 
house music (scary). :) What a bash! ;)
Kickin' trash. :)

Never really noticed the lights 'cept the ones beaming right into your face at the 
front of the stage. ouch. Props 2 The People's Republic of China 4 kewl purple 
sunglasses! :)

Went 2 breakfast at McD's w/ Amy and krew. Amy, thanks 4 the ride back! :) Saw some 
cops hassling some ravers outside, who just came from the (tiny room) afterhours. I 
guess they looked like ravers... u know. The cops intended on shutting down the 
afterhours, I guess...

MikeyD offered me a backup ride. Thanks 4 looking out 4 me... :)

Hope all of u enjoyed a wonderful, peaceful and loving holiday season! :)

/* plur */
  matter

I am smiling, because I don't understand myself. :)

On Fri, 3 Jan 1997, BRUCE ALVIN MCDONOUGH wrote:

> I'd have to say that anyone who takes any sort of drugs without at least a
> pretty good indication of what it is, and what it does, and of the source,
> isn't behaving very wisely.  Would you go into the woods and just eat any
> pretty plant or mushroom without knowing what it is?  
> I think not.
> The key to being and staying free and healthy is knowledge.  Use any substance
> wisely and knowingly, and you're not likely to have a bad trip.
> much love,
> Bruce.
> 

Right on, Bruce.  I am always amazed by users' willingness to be ignorant
of what they ingest.  Please, folks, look into what you use before you
just gulp it down, or you don't know what could happen to you.  I mean,
what if it was orange, red, or purple-colored turpentine?  Trust is good
and all, but absolute blind trust can be a bit dangerous...  Okay, enough
of my  preachy-stuff.  Take care, all; stay healthy; love ya'!/\/\/\/
-=Joe=-

At 4:31 PM -0700 1/3/97, Mac Gaines wrote:
>can someone tell me how and  where to post comments on partys and other things
>to a newsgroup. I am using netscape 3.01 for the Mac and would like to post so
>if any one can walk me through it I would appreaciate it. And BTW whoever does
>first I will send them on of my mixed tapes.. music sound is TeKno Trance FYI.
>
>Way thanks in advance,
>
>Macadio G.

This may be a little late but I'll give ya the low down anyhow...

In netscape, go to the "Options" menu and choose "Mail and News
Preferences".  In here you'll need to enter the address of your news
server.  Click on the "Server" tab and at the bottom fill in the info for
your News server.  Your ISP should have given your the address...for
example mine is "news.isp.net".  Your's may be similiar but could be
different.

THen you can click ok to exit the preferences and then click on the
"Window" menu and choose "Netscape News"  This will bring up a new window.
Go to the "File" menu and choose "Add Newsgroup"  then type in "alt.raves"
and after downloading the articles it should display the group in the left
upper frame, the articles in the upper right frame and if you click on an
article the bottom frame will contain the actual text.  Downloading the
newsgroup may take a while so be patient.

To post an article click on the "To: News" button and your set to go.

Good luck,
G

If you run into any probs just let me know!

Gioni
pasque@isp.net
www.isp.net/~pasque

Hi all!  ]=)


 I'm a long time fan of the old skool YES (from start in 1969 to 1980) 
and in fact YES is the reason for me being a multi-media live production 
artist.

 Anyway, I was listening to some of their stuff the other day and heard 
some lyrics that really resonated with me and my relationships to raving. 
I thought I would share that bit of lyrics with you.

 I hope you all can enjoy;


	"From the moment I reached out to hold, I felt a sound.
	 And what touches our soul, slowly moves as touch rebounds.
	 And to know that tempo will continue, lost in trance of dances.
	 As rhythm takes another turn.
	 As is my want, I only reach, to look in your eyes."

Lyrics credited to YES (probably Jon Anderson) 1974.
>From the song "Sound Chaser" off the album "Relayer"



cheers!  =)


Ran D.Dreams

Digital Frontier Exhibition

Cyberspace Be-In: Avatars and Virtual Worlds

Beyond Race, Soulstice, Burning Man, Panjaya Collective Dancers, Danza
Teokalli, Loco Bloco, Hoopla Thang, Scramble/Riots, Blendo Visuals by
Dimension7 and friends, visionaries, and a *Midnight Seminar*

Event Sponsors
Apple Computer, Black Sun Interactive, Net Objects, OliVR, Silicon
Graphics, Sun Microsystems

Associate Sponsors Fujitsu, Electric Minds, Imaja, NetNoir, Java World,
Netscape World, Onlive Technologies

Special thanks to: Adolph Gasser, Anon Salon, Bay Guardian, Micro
Publishing News, MicroTimes, Mondo 2000, Outpost, Waterside Productions

The Digital Be-In is a production of Verbum, Inc. mail@verbum.com
www.verbum.com

from socal raves - enjoy
------------------------

Three mice were sitting in a bar talking about how tough they were.

The first mouse slams a shot and says, "I play with mouse traps for fun.
  I'll run into one on purpose and as it is closing on me, I grab the
bar and bench press it twenty or thirty times."  And with that he slams
another shot.

The second mouse slams a shot and says, "That's nothing.  I take those
Decon tablets, cut them up and snort them just for the fun of it."   And
with that he slams another shot.

The third mouse slams a shot, gets up and walks away.  The first two
mice look at each other, and then turn to the third mouse and ask,
"Where the hell are you going?"

The third mouse stops and replies, "I'm going home to fuck the cat."



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Jan  4 10:45:17 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id KAA23442; Sat, 4 Jan 1997 10:45:17 -0800 (PST)
Received: from netcom4.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id KAA23431; Sat, 4 Jan 1997 10:45:12 -0800 (PST)

	id KAA15792; Sat, 4 Jan 1997 10:45:08 -0800
Date: Sat, 4 Jan 1997 10:45:08 -0800
X-Sender: jsl@localhost
Message-Id: <v03007800aef3d2340b75@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "John S. Lee" <jsl@netcom.com>
Subject: Rave Stuff...scrap the name
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I think that if people are going to push for this permit thing, they might
want to drop RAVE from any mention altogether. You have enough fighting
ahead of you, so why make it more difficult by associating the thing you're
doing with rave?  Rave, despite all attempts, has a very negative
connotation with law enforcement and many civic authorities.  Just because
1 good cop says it's all good, does not mean the the strcuture he is a part
of sees it his way (I have talked to a NUMBER of cops about pot, they think
the laws are stupid, but they have a job, and the substance is illegal
so...). I think that Nancy's point should be taken as methods by which you
make your goal a win-win for the community and clubbers.  Always mention
the dollars, but don't mention the money that is part of the dance
community (all of which is cash, and cannot be traced through the IRS),
instead talk about the financial benefits to the surrounding community from
partyers spending their money in late nite cafes & restaurants.  You will
obviously need to form alliances with vendors & businesses that could
benefit from the nite crawlers.  You would also benefit from community
leaders who have direct connects to Brown.  Like I said, it will be more
than just signing a petition, getting attorneys, and corssing your fingers.
It is an all out effort, that will cost alot of time effort and money to
get organized and stay as an organized effort.

One more item, if you're going to talk about how peaceful we supposedly
are, there should be some stats to back it up.  That goes for everything,
hard numbers are the way to win any political game.  Vagueness will lose
the game.  Get as many allies from as many quarters as you can, get your
numbers ready, get ahold of the supes rally them, then present.  Oh yeah,
press, press, press.  Get as much press as you can.  SF Weekly and the Bay
Guardian are good and acessible starts.

And as always, good luck to the warriors.

PEace,
John

P.S.  All of this is IMO, take what is useful, or junk it alltogether.
Just wanted to chime in with suggestions for those who may want to take
this thing up.

UG don't need no permits so.



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Jan  4 10:45:19 1997

Subject: UG is alive and well...as it always has been.
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com

Did you know?

-There is a very active underground dance community in SF that NEVER GETS
BUSTED.  Hasn't been busted, and WON'T be busted.
-Do you know that it is completely word of mouth?  There are NO flyers.
Basically if you know who is doing things, you can find out.  It has been
in effect for YEARS, even before the rave scene.

Yeah, in a way I'm teasing, since some things should never be brought near
the surface, suffice it to say it does exist.  I have only attended one of
the events to date, some time ago.  But it recently came to my attention
that it is still alive well and thriving.

Things can be done in the city, it all depends on how slick you really want
to be.

UG never needs permits, and if done right, doesn't need greedy cops and
authorities either.

Just a thought,
John

UPDATE on DIGITAL BE-IN #9

This digest of Be-In 9 material forwarded by Brian Zisk, San FranZiskGo!  . . .

    * Thursday January 9. 7:00 p.m.

      Digital Be-In

      Thirty years ago, S.F. was host to The Human Be-In, a now-historic
      counter-culture gathering of hippies and other assorted "freaks" who
      converged on Golden Gate Park to express their commitment to forging a
      new future together. The Digital Be-In's 9th annual event is a tribute
      to the spirit of that day, and to the ever-increasing diversity of the
      wired world. Show highlights include musical performances by
      post-modern world music ensemble Beyond Race, African cultural rap by
      Hoopla Thang, Brazilian drummers and dancers Loco Bloco. Dancers
      include the traditional Aztec dance troupe Danza Teokalli, Panjaya
      Collective's "Angels in Cyberspace" performance piece, and the Burning
      Man fire dancers. Strategically held during the Macworld Expo, Verbum's
      ever-evolving Be-In is a multimedia concert, exhibition and gathering.
      The realtime event will be netcast with several video streams, virtual
      photography, and on-the-fly photojournalism, and can be accessed at
      www.be-in.com. SOMAR Gallery, 934 Brannan St. Tickets $15.00, available
      through Ticketweb, through BASS, and at the Micro Publishing News Booth
      at MacWorld - No 2348.

Response for tickets to this hot Macworld week event has been overwhelming.
We are no longer able to handle ticket orders via the Verbum hotline. To
get yours, please order from Ticketweb (www.Ticketweb.com), Bass Tickets,
or buy them at The MicroPublishing News booth at the Macworld Expo (No
2348).  Looks like this one will sell out.

____________________________________________________________________________
 Wayne D. Correia            +1.415.826.6000           900 Tennessee Street
 <wayne@club.net>        fax +1.415.826.6100        San Francisco, CA 94107

Any orbital fans out there?

For those in the know, seeing orbital live is probably one of the greatest
delicacies fer technoheads...

...Well, for all of you that have indelible impressions of Orbital Live
(remember hearing SATAN, the first time?)...and for all of you who may be
interested in getting some....

 ...

if you are in the Market Street SF area this weekend...

check out VIRGIN megastore>>

sound whack? well, i was there of friday...and they have Three (3...count
'em) import singles of <SATAN,live> which include 3 different versions of
the namesake tune, plus other live versions of early orbital classics like
LUSH, IMPact, CHIme, and more....as the bonus tracks...

They are kinda pricey at $8.99, each, but I have not seen these before
anywhere else...

oh, and the good news?>>>

you can listen to all three <de gratis, that is FREE> on the CD listening
stations!

=)

enjoy,

g.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Jan  4 16:10:09 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id QAA12753; Sat, 4 Jan 1997 16:10:09 -0800 (PST)
Received: from scruz.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id QAA12747; Sat, 4 Jan 1997 16:10:05 -0800 (PST)

Message-Id: <v01530501aef492f05df1@[165.227.109.23]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sat, 4 Jan 1997 16:13:10 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: anarch@scruznet.com (Anarch)
Subject: Re: Legality and Safety
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU> wrote:
>Honestly, I don't see the fire code as a great oppressor to us.  I
>personally am hesitant about spending all night in old brick warehouses,
>with one tiny entrance, narrow stairways and floors that threaten to fold
>with the weight of the crowd.  The reason such a location is not legal is
>because it is
>DANGEROUS.

You wouldn't think the fire code would be too tough to deal with from
looking at qualified places like 1015 and DV8...imagine being upstairs at
Nikita or way down in that back room at Spundae when some sort of panic
breaks out and you all have to leave, NOW.  It doesn't sound much nicer
than it would in a lot of warehouses I've been to.  Of course fire and
building codes have lots of other reasonable concerns, like safe wiring,
structural integrity, that sort of thing, but you never hear about
them--it's always, "What if there were a fire/earthquake/tidal wave/meteor
strike and all these people were TRAPPED INSIDE?"  Which is a good
question, but if a place like 1015 can answer it satisfactorily, a promoter
with a decent warehouse should be able to as well.  Maybe the clubs have a
bunch of secret emergency exits, or something...still, I'm sure there are
other spaces that can meet those standards.

anarch@scruznet.com

Hello Sfraves!


	Well, we hope everyone had a safe new years. We send our love and
support to all of the production crews of the bay area that had, well,
not so good luck with the police on new years. But as always, something
really good will come of it! So keep your eyes peeled!


	As for the Harmony crew, our first event in the year of '97 is coming
just around the corner. We would like to start this year by thanking
everyone who has ever participated, helped, and supported us. This event
will be a small party, devoted to our family. You guys have helped create
some of the most positive, energetic, love-filled parties that we could
ever dream of. What Harmony is today, is exactly what we dreamed it to be
over three years ago! And for this, we are eternally greatful...


<center>So, on Saturday, January 18th '97, come join us for a night
of...


<bigger><bigger>FAMILY

</bigger></bigger></center><bigger>

With dj's : Ethan - Mystr-e - Cloud - James - Greg - Matt Schmitt -
(guest)


	This party has an extremly limited capacity, so call our voice mails for
more info. The space is in the east bay somewhere and there is a strong
possibilty of all the tickets only being availible through presold ticket
locations. (like BASS, j/k) Anyways, stay tooned and keep your ears open
for where we will be with the tickets. Tickets will be $10 (if you
<underline>promise</underline> to come <underline>dressed up</underline>
in your funkiest clothes) We can't really hold you to that, so try to be honest. Anyways, until then we will see you around and happy new year!


</bigger>

On Sat, 4 Jan 1997 gavin@sirius.com wrote:

> 
> 
> Any orbital fans out there?

Orbital changed my life.  I don't know if it's just because it's what
I was listening to most when my love for music surfaced, but it was
something I loved so much it helped me consider music a career/life plan.
It also opened me up musically.. took me out of a Nine Inch Nails
fetish and let me realize there was so much out there I had never even 
been exposed to.  I moved on to many different types of music, but to
me Orbital will always be awsome.

Just thought I'd mention, since you asked.    8)

Peace,

Leonardo

Precedence: bulk

I don't think I am alone to believe that as far as raves are concerned,
California started off 1997 pretty fukked up.


I myself usually avoid larger parties in SF as they tend to draw somewhat
of a not-so-friendly crowd....=20

But this is New Year's Eve, and I have quite a few friends visiting from
out of state, and they wanted to see a SHOW. So we went to Planet New
Year, put on by Coolworld. When we first got there, it was a zoo! The
line went around the block, and instead of being helpful, the security
did their best to get people to be confused, and it worked. Finally
inside, the party was a lot of fun. After midnight we decided to
re-explore some of the back rooms... It was 12:30 and security was
already blocking off rooms and pushing people towards the front. Then at
around 2am, the lights came on in the main room. Another half hour goes
by, and a shrieky voice <underline>yells </underline>over the pa, "OKAY,
PARTIES OVER!!!, TIME TO GO HOME!!!, LEAVE NOW<< BU-BYE," going on for
about three or four minutes. I am very opposed to violence, but the way
she was starting everyone's New Year, I wouldn't have minded someone get
up there and- nevermind.=20


Anyways, coolworld made up a semi-bullshit story about fire alarms
getting pulled, and having to shut down. I say semi bullshit because I
did see firepeople there, but they were closing down rooms much earlier.
To top it off, they were still selling tickets 20 minutes before this
happened.


I did not see more than most of the booked DJs not only on stage but
anywhere at the party. I believe Coolworld ran out of the DJs they had
actually booked, and scammed the rest of the tickets.


Coolworld is not out to help the "global dance scene," Just to profit
from it.


-PLUR

my plea for New Years party information.  Although I never managed to get 
inside, I bought tickets for Metamorphosis . . . !  (Ended up at 1015 and

I ended up spending half the money I've been saving to get my wisdom 
teeth out . . . :(

also to say that the nicest thing I noticed about New Years was that no

their spitits.  It was wonderful to see.

Here is a summary of replies I got to my questions about modern DJ dance 
music and raves in Hawaii:

CLUB RECOMMENDATIONS:

"One club called Rendezvous, sometimes has after hours."

"...as for clubs, there's formula 660, which is the place to be on the 
weekends. and Kids Klub on the first sunday of every month..."

"A couple clubs you should check out are The Jungle and Wave 
Waikiki (both in Waikiki).  Also look up The Groove (located off of 
Nimitz Hwy. in Honolulu) in the phonebook to find out what events 
are happening there!"

RAVE INFORMATION:

"... funk pistol ( clothes and spray can culture store ) closed about a year 
ago. you may want to check out the Radio Free Hawaii page at
http://www.lava.net/radio-free/ "

" (Try calling) RADIO FREE HAWAII (KDEO 102.7FM) at 808-296-1027 they 
can tell you if anything is coming up on the island of Oahu.  Daniel J. 
Ward, the biggest promoter on the island is one of the DJs at the radio 
station so they always have info on his events and most others in the 
studio."

"You can also check out his homepage at:
     http://members.aol.com/wardindus/wardindus.html"


---- Thanks for the replies!

			Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com
