Date: Sun, 5 Jan 1997 18:54:34 -0800 (PST)
From: KaySEE <scarab@value.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: NYE:Better Late Than Never
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.970105180453.7283C-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This is my belated NYE review.  I've finally had time to digest everything
that occured in order to put it in some sort of literary form!  Actually
this is a really good excuse to once more procrastinate on writing a
Statement of Purpose for graduate school.  My new found ease at
procrastination has become an amazing power!! :P

Like many others, I had tickets to Gateway/Pacific.  I got mine as soon as
I found out about it and could get to the Haight.  Ended up getting
tickets numbered 2,3,4,and 5.  Hmmm....maybe I'm a BIT over-zealous.
Nah!!

I flew home from Tahoe in time to miss the wash out of Reno airport thank
gawd and landed in Oakland on NYE.  I was SOO excited.  Ran a few errands
and bought some stuff for the party, but from then on EVERYTHING fell
apart.  I tried to coordinate five ppl. and it didn't work very well
because everyone had a different idea of what to do.  I ended up hurting
more than one person's feelings and felt pretty damn shitty.  At that
point I decided I hated NYE..  There's too much pressure to have an amazing
time.  But, after shedding some tears at my predicament, we organized a
workable plan.  God only knows how!

Arrived at Gateway at 11:45 only to see it shut down.  I was with Nancy,
and our friends Ivana and Josh.  We were supposed to meet my boyfriend and
another friend later on.  As we were standing in line, we refused to
succumb to that gut feeling of disappointment.  Nancy urged us to try and
make it to the CCC party.  At this point of everything having gone wrong,
the planets aligned for us, and for the rest of the night everything went
PERFECT.  It was amazing.  We made it to the map point RIGHT on time.
Some premonition had made me bring a shit-load of money, so I was able to
foot the bill for everyone.  AND I got paid back. YAY!  Ivana had
impeccable directions and oriented us perfectly in the mired downtown area
of the city.  And Nancy had the brilliant back-up plan and the foresight 
to move on it quickly!  We were so determined to make this happen. I
WANTED it so badly.

We arrived at the smallish space which was covered with black lights and
really amazing flourescent art.  Kudos to the artists, their time and
energy really showed.  There was basically three areas: the stairs (where
it was cooler and you could cool off), the main dance room that was like a
long tunnel with speakers at many different points (where all of the
paintings were), and this darker chill room that had an amazing vibe and
upbeat music.  This room was incredibly packed most of the night, and we
never made it all the way in.  The volume was perfect.  The music was
good, and you could talk.  I don't like chill rooms where the music is so
overwhelmingly loud you can't hear anyone.

The people were really nice.  The crowd was on the older side, but with a
good age distribution.  The people were really colorful and into the
music.  I met a lot of foreigners, reminding me of the international
quality of our scene.  I met one woman from Romania and two from Israel.
One of the women from Israel was visiting and I gave here my phone number
in case she wanted to be shown around the East Bay.  I remember how people
used to do that for me when I was in South America and it felt good to
finally reciprocate the favor!

The most important thing for me at this party was the people who I was
with.  My boyfriend and I have always had a certain strain between us
concerning raving.  It was always me who was interested and not him.  He
never liked it for the longest time and resented the fact that I would do
something like that without him.  Well, our progression with the scene has
been nothing short of amazing.  He made an effort to go over the past
year, and in the process has come to enjoy it.  It has been really fun
watching another person experience a love and confidence with dancing.  I
remember the initial hesitation and embarrassment that turns into sheer
bliss after awhile.  Anyway, every now and then people post stuff about
what to do when your S.O. has a hard time with you raving.  Sometimes it
does have a happy ending :)

Two of the people that were with me are sort of newbies.  They are two of
my friends that somehow "got it."  Isn't that strange?  I've taken a bunch
of people and after that initial time you can tell if they like it or
don't.  It's a strange experience.  But, when they do like it, all of a
sudden they see you differently and you have this new-found understanding
with them.  Bizarre.

In the past six months my partying has severely curtailed for various
reasons.  But, I've already noticed a change in that small amount of time.
It's hard to explain, but I wonder if other people notice it too?  At my
first party (Basics) I remember lots of ppl. giving stuff away.  I
remember really liking that generosity.  At NYE Nancy brought a bunch of
oranges to give away and I brought some suckers and some flourescent
bracelets.  At one point when Nancy was giving oranges away, a young girl
looked at her and said, "Wow. You're old-school aren't you?"  Now I ask
you sfravers what does this mean?  Are people not giving stuff away
anymore?  Is it a fad that has passed?  Was it just the party?  To me
giving stuff away was a part of the community.  You shared what you had in
an effort to bring someone some happiness.  I ended up giving stuff away
and had different reactions.  One guy thought I was picking up on him.
Others were baffled at why I was giving stuff away.  Mostly, people were
grateful and enjoyed it, though.  Has this changed about raving?  Or was
it just this party?  This party had a great vibe, too, so I don't have an
explanation. 

Anyway, sorry for the length of this post.  It has been awhile since I
posted a review!  I did meet Randy and saw the painting he did which was
really nice.  I have to give him props for his humility.  We were talking
about the Harmony 3-Year party and complimented him on his efforts at that
amazing chill room, by far the best one I've ever encountered.  He said,
very humbly, that he owed it all to the space.  I seem to meet a number of
people like this, and I must say that a lack of arrogance is really a
special trait.

-KaySEE

*B* wrote:
> 
> OK, I am ignorant in this field.  Would somebody explain to me what it
> means when
>         DJ blah is spinning vs. DJ blah2
> 
> How does it work?  Why is it vs. rather than something else.
> 


to my knowledge the "vs." thing originated in the uk jungle / ragga
scenes (possibly hip-hop too) where dj's would "soundclash"... they
would set up two soundsytems at either end of the room and the dj's
would play in a very literal versus situation... trying to sway the
"crowd" over to their side of the room... the best sound clashes would
obviously be beat mixed to both sides, rather than one massive train
wreck... often this was a competition of sound systems as well as
dj's... i've only seen one soundclash with jungle dj's in london and the
dj that "won" got the most hype from the crowd... as a judge of
technical skill, the guy who won had less technical merit and only won
with his "visual" element through scratching and showboating... tricks
often hide that true lack of technical skill... tag-teaming promotes a
competitiveness that motivates the dj's to show the other one up...
often giving half-assed dj's the gumption to become deck wizards where
they would otherwise simply play tracks with brief windows of mixing
here and there...

alchemist

First of all, I'd just like to send a big hug out to the list..  I
re-subscribed while I am here for the holidays, and it is great seeing
familiar names, and meeting familiar faces out at parties!

Karma went off last night!  Lots of people, almost too many at one
point...  I loved Ethan's set.. cause he sure knows how to work those
frequencies... he was playing nice melodic stuff too..  Dutch's set was
exactly what I wanted to hear last night (good solid psi trance)..  

The chill room was especially fun.. Who was spinning in there during most
of the evening? Good vibe, though I did see quite a few people bustin out
with large baloons.. Is N2O making a comeback here in SF?

If you were there, I was the tall guy with mid-back length brown hair,
red bikelight, black shirt and pants.  I saw Randy (Happy Birthday!) and a
few other people with SFraves badges on (heya).  

Lots of PLUR,
Aaron.

living in toronto, where there are some mighty big virgin offices
happening, i see a clearer picture of what the "music industry" is doing
to the techno scene...

PLUS 8 records is now being distributed by Virgin, and many of their
artists (plastikman, speedy j, legion of green men) are signed to virgin
with some pretty impressive contracts...

Virgin is now allotting funds for promotion and bought out a prime time
saturday night radio slot on the local commercial dance station Energy
108... we now see huge posters adorning the streets, next to posters
announcing Evita and the next Alanis Morrisette or Green Day concerts
advertising the Transmissions radio show... with dj's such as John
Acquaviva, Terry Mullen, Stacy Pullen, etc, etc...

The show is hosted by MC Flipside... who has no credentials as an MC of
dance music, other than the fact that he graduated from Ryerson
Polytechnic University in the radio broadcasting program...

This raises an interesting point...

what gives a techno producer / promoter / MC / DJ credentials?

being an underground scene, it is hard to develop credible references in
the eyes of the "established"... there are dj's in toronto who sound
like a pair of old army boots in a clothes dryer, but they have the
frequency of public appearance (schmoozing is a disease up here) and
frequency of exposure that would convince record executives that they
have what it takes... FLIPSIDE never MC'd a rave in his life, he's fresh
out of college- and probably makes a nice five digit salary to sample
his voice going t-t-t-t-t-t-t-transmissions! every saturday night...
now he mc's all the commercial parties because he's a radio
personality...

if the underground becomes an industry... because it is established
already in a completely different business format (sort of like how
business is dealt in silicon valleys), it must be made clear to those
intending to boost us into the spotlight for the sake of profit, that
what gets the props is at least GOOD... i think this is why PLUS 8
jumped on the bandwagon when they did... otherwise you might see some
Keoki type cheeseball misrepresenting what techno is all about...
Keoki's rise to fame is within the old rock'n'roll framework... give
yourself an image, big up your ego to "superstar" status and then
promote yourself until you burn out... be the one thing that you can
sell... true techno artists are simply themselves...  i've always seen
this as a revenge of the nerds sort of movement... we who were laughed
at for being individuals in high school, are now producing some of the
best parties and music in the world...

Subject: drinking karma and a bad trip...
References: <c=US%a=_%p=netro-corp%l=NETRO-NT1-961230225821Z-563@netro-nt1.netro-corp.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

this whole alcohol versus LSD thing is ridiculous... when you're on
acid, you still have the capacity to be "drunk as a lord"...

i threw a party called bacchus for the autumn equinox 1995... we
advertised it as a wine and cheese event and had a live jazz band
jamming with an acid jazz / trip-hop dj... it was held at a club, and
there were many who ate strange fungus and smoked herb to enjoy the
event... the bar had the HIGHEST alcohol sales EVER in its 20 year
history... and the vibe was amazing... i think the fact that we served
pita with tziki and hummous and trays with 50+ types of cheese and
breads helped soak up what usually turns sour... but alcohol was being
used in its original context... for drinking... not to get drunk... we
even made the bar serve micro-brewery beer and rare import wine...

it is the promotion of alcohol by the mega-breweries to be used in a
consumative manner... drink piss, get pissed... this would disgust most
true alcohol connesseurs...

if you think about hard alcohol, and how it is often referred to as
spirits, we can gain a bit of perspective on this...

much as tequila will make you hallucinate if consumed properly... or
jagermeister with it's 56 herbs (including the opium poppy and elk's
blood)... alcohol can at times appear like the witches brews that are
hunted down by the authorities... of course, jagermeister, as it passes
through canadian border has the elk's blood removed...

although the effects of alcohol are far less subtle, what makes
fermenting barley and hops much different than the fermenting ergot on
rye...

different plants produce different spirits...

be it aminita muscaria, mushrooms, peyote, agave, grapes, potatoes, pot,
tobacco, cloves...

obviously overdosing on any of these does not produce a healthy
experience... if you were to take 20 hits of acid, i don't think you'd
be in any better shape than the drunk under a case of budweiser... not
in the context of a party anyways...

i, in my high school years, was an alcoholic.

when i first tried lsd, alcoholics bothered me...

when i discovered it was because i was one, it took a few trips to
reimprint the alcoholic condition, carefully, so i wouldn't simply
replace one vice with another...

i stopped drinking altogether for 3 years, to make sure... and found my
pious attitude that psychedelics were the end all and be all of mind
altering substances was indicative that i still had a problem i was
clinging to...

alcohol itself is not a problem... it is the lack of awareness in how to
use it that is... much of a psychedelic experience can be meaningful to
the user, and it definitely has its uses in psychotherapy (ie.
overcoming addictions)... but used in a purely recreational experience,
the only difference between the two is that alcohol, when overdone
inflates the ego... lsd dissolves it completely... i personally would
rather risk getting a black eye from speaking out of the pecking order
than imprint my subconscious with a bad mix, gansta punks with attitude
or a police raid... of course, i'd rather not have either... which is
why i limit my lsd use to private sessions or moontribe parties and
stick with my buddy herb and elaine at raves...


drugs are tools. nothing else. use them as such. consciously.

dave

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Jan  5 21:37:18 1997

Hi all!  =)

 Well, to help celebrate my B-day (actually on Jan. 3rd) I went out to 
Karma. The party was radically different than the NYE party in the same 
space.

Good points;

 Music was really awesome (dudes). David(?), Ethan, T. Trouble, Dutch and 
Graeme all tore it up and it was _really_ difficult not to dance at 
times! Likewise the chill room had some incredible sounds happening 
thanks primarily to Boomerang Fidget (a wonderfully nice person!) and 
Maya who played two looong sets that had a little bit of everything in 
there all mixed perfectly. 

 The crowd (for the most part) was very friendly. It was _overpacked_ for 
a while but by 2 am or so things thinned out appreciably. Big thanks to 
everyone who wished me a happy B-day! Both there and on this list!!

 Going out to breakfast with Julie, Peter and Graeme at the Bahgdad Cafe. 
These are just some incredible people that I feel very fortunate to have 
met.

 Hi to Julie, Peter, Graeme, Bonnie (from Germany), Leslie, Aaron, Pablo, 
Brendon (?) (thanks for the lift!!), Wayne, Marcy, Martin (and son!) and 
all the other wonderful folks I bumped into!

Not so good points;

 Mr. Trouble has some organizational skills to acquire yet. He didn't 
show at his own party until 10 pm (we were supposed to start at 9:30). He 
also yelled at Leslie when he should not have (very BAD!), and apparently 
didn't pay Maya who played really hard AND brought in his coffin for the 
chill room.

 The bottled water was being sold at $1.50 (once Mr. Trouble took charge) 
and later someone was selling water for $2 a bottle. Ya know those small 
ones.
 
 Hearing that Leslie had her wallet(?) stolen.

 Having the amps shut down as they became overheated (from the large crowd).

 Decorations were essientially non-existant. We were in a dirty warehouse 
and it looked like it.

 Then there were the street toughs trying to peddle their wares along the 
staircase. Really pathetic in it's own little sick way.

 The real heartache (for me) came when I discovered that my banner had 
been tagged. Not once but in three different spots. Luckily the #@%^^& 
punk choose to do it on the painted black areas and will not be hard to 
cover up.




 Despite the drawbacks of the evening I had a great time! The crowd and 
the music were exceptional (for the most part) and I was feeling just 
fine. Brendon was excellent company and I met some very cool people.


Have a great year!!


Ran D.Dreams

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Jan  5 22:19:55 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id WAA01354; Sun, 5 Jan 1997 22:19:55 -0800 (PST)

To: TGARCI02@ccsmtp.farinon.harris.com
CC: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: the mystical pagan pooh-bahs rant yet again
References: <00002F7C.1825@ccsmtp.farinon.harris.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

TGARCI02@ccsmtp.farinon.harris.com wrote:
> 
>      look at terence mckenna, one would
>      think the only way to touch the spiritual world is through the
>      psilocybin mushroom.  humph.
> 


having observed mckenna's novelty mailing list over the past month, i've
found much of what psychedelics do is make people fanatical over their
"mystical" experiences...

i've had several "mystical" experiences on psychedelics, many of them
changing the direction i've taken in my life, but mystical experiences
cannot be quantified, hence making them difficult to prove and hence
making them difficult to bring into this plane of reality... we're here
on this "plane" for a reason, and that's not to go somewhere else...
it's to bring several "somewhere elses" together here (i'm starting to
sound like the picard)...

it seems the difference between the trippers and the drinkers (how's
that for quaint little categories?) is that trippers have a tendency to
take each others ideas and push them forward by combining them with and
using them to catalyze their own...

when it comes down to it though, the new age / extraterrestrial-coming-
of-age trip is no more relevant than some drunken assoul spewing forth
existentialist Bukowski kibble in some rat's hole pub...

it's the "Lite" version of metaphysics... it's all just a bunch of
wurds...

timothy leary, who was a Harvard PhD, was thrown out on his ass, because
for all his research and most excellent codification of the psychedelic
experience in the english language, could still not quantify what goes
on...

to fully understand the impact psychedelics could have, and to begin
quantifying their effects, will require the combining of magick (true
empirical occultism, not the mamby-pamby James Redfields), quantum
science, the entire body of Jung's work, and several schools of eastern
meditation / philosophy...

i saw McKenna speak at The Whole Life Expo in Austin Texas, and for the
most part his drug rhetoric went over the heads of the new Age Tammy Fae
Baker Look-Alikes... if we can't describe the experience in words that
the drug-free virgin would understand... how close to the Truth are we?

Don't get me wrong, i wouldn't want to be interpreted as some soul-less
nihilistic materialist... i've explored eastern spiritual paths... i've
noticed the similarities between the Tarot, the i ching and the way DNA
is charted... i can appreciate why shiva has long legs that curl around
like a DNA helix... how the OHM symbol encompasses the original 
 < +  -  mu > of the original symbol of the TAO... and the curved line
and dot above this symbol could be interpreted as being symbolic of wave
and particle theory...

it's taken western science in all it's logic thousands of years to
appreciate what the east knew poetically... but since we have caught up,
we shouldn't let ouselves get lost in the poetics and semantics of it
all...

it comes back to the old psychedelic maxim

   the goal is not to get high... it's to be high!

and in being high, we shouldn't need the drug to produce the affect
anymore... for the effect to truly stick, and not just be a memory of
the original effect, we need to develop a language to bring forth the
new consciousness, if our vocabularies and grammars are limited in this
regard... which is why the DMT entities teach what was once known as
enochian, or to some who feel threatened by it "speaking in tongues"...
techno music (in a purist sense) is the crown acheivement of mankind
because of it's departure from the musical staff and scale... it is an
amorphous manipulation of sound itself, never repeating itself in its
analogue form...  the language we are seeking however, seems to lie
within the mind itself... and all the references to illumination and
being of a "light vibration" seems to point towards to communication
through light... our minds receive it... we haven't developed our
capabilities of sending it...

i don't think we'll reach any state of permanence simply tripping on
this realization.


the alchemist

In toronto, at the Guerilla Gatherings party i played at (w/ Dan
Curtain, Peacefrog Recs.), the DJ at New Year's played Steve Miller's
"Fly Like An Eagle" everyone was too busy hugging, etc to notice and
when they did it was like this big joke... here we are... progressive
minded folk... celebrating this inane holiday based in the gregorian
calendar (with all it's xtian flaws) and listening classic rock...
 oh yeah!


the big commercial party (our equivalent to cool world) lost their space
the week before and kept their semi-legal roller rink space (rammed to
the rafters) quiet until just the last minute, when they released the
info, packed the place in just enough to make their money and when the
cops showed up and told them they could let any more people in
(including those still outside in the multi-hundred person line-up who
had advance tickets) they just smiled smugly and told people "hey what
can we do?" and dipped into the back room to count the door receipts...
since it was a one room roller rink (with an ambient room in the some
out of the way back room) the four rooms as promised on the flyer shrunk
down to three sound systems in the one room... this makes absolutely no
sense... the Destiny Utopia Dose Syrous party didn't have it's shit
together... i guess that's why everyone was calling it D.U.D.S. for
short...

The Guerilla Gathering went off really well... 300 people max... free
vegan buffet... free champange... comfy couches in a lounge... wicked
vibe... well worth the $20 at the door (compared to $45 @ DUDS)
...

can't say much more other than, the UG is alive and well in toronto...

hope it is out there for '97 as well...

dave

CC: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re:...a Call to Arms.
References: <"<B8CACB32813E657C>B8CACB32813E657C@X-PA-PAHV-MS4.XN"@-SMF->
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

it seems police crack downs are immanent everywhere...

toronto just experienced its first big bust in ages...

since, the police have hassled us every weekend...

i was in austin, texas and there were some pretty intense cop politics
happening... including infrared cameras and 20 uniformed officers at a
party!

i heard tales from Goa DJ smiling Bhudda about a party he threw in
Isreal where 4000 ravers showed up in the desert (1% of the Isreali
population om acid!) and the military surrounded the entire area and
busted everyone... they took Smiling Bhudda aside and showed him
pictures of himself at parties, even small UG ones, over the past four
years and basically said "we know who you are... we know what you;ve
done... we know what you do..." and let him go...

in vancouver, there was a major bust of a lab where E, LSD and DMT (most
of the supply for Canada and a good chunk of the US)...

perhaps a mailing list should be started to begin observing the trends
in police infiltration and interference... start our own intelligence
agency... sort of like that Beastie Boys video... "we knew they were
watching us, so we started watching them"... i would bet there are some
interesting patterns that might arise... i don't know what happened in
austin, but there was some really pure E in the area at the time... and
the heat came down the same week that the vancouver lab went down...
double sting?... who backs the cops... is it the concerned moral
majority... or is it the same mob creeps that seek to profit on the E
market by cutting it with additive substances (crystal meth, synthetic
heroin, cocaine) or just plain crap (ketamine, GHB, PCP)... did this
same shit not happen in the late 60's early 70's... Cherry Bomb FX, Red
Rockets, Reds, Blues, Ludes, Barbs, Yellow Jackets... get the picture...
most of our "E" isn't even called "E" anymore, let alone MDMA... we have
no clue of what type of intelligence is being gathered on us... why
shouldn't we generate some awareness into this issue...
    just a thought... it might be a fun hobby for those not involved in
the drug trade... i don't care if i'm being watched... i haven't
possessed drugs with the exception of them being ingested for over two
years... i'm on the McKenna mailing list anyways, so it's too late for
that!
     it's time we take control... support free markets... vote with your
dollars... don't vote for crap!

the alchemist

Liquid,

How come you are not looking for the a**h*** who threw the bottle in the 
first place.... ??

The cops might have been wrong in what they did but on the other hand 
put yourself in their place. How would you enjoy having bottles thrown 
at you for doing your job ?

I am not saying what they did is right ... all I am saying is that this 
was brought about by one of "us" (and I am using this term in a very 
broad sense) ... they didnt just start beating up a guy cause they felt 
like it - they did in response to what somebody in the crowd did.

Some cops are corrupt but not all of them should be placed in that 
category, because what some of them do. I specially do NOT like the use 
of the term "pig" when refering to them. most of them are just doing 
what they have been ordered to do and they have to face more pressure in 
their jobs than most of us face in life. and sometimes they get carried 
away ... shit happens. 

Flame away ...

Rudi

Yes, I agree, they were just doing their jobs, *BUT*, if I were a riot
cop and had a bottle thrown at me, I'd make sure that I had the RIGHT
PERSON first.  Plus, as every job sucks in one way or another, it's
wrong to beat the hell out of him.  Arrest him, restrain him ONLY as
much as they'd need to, but to take out personal anger on him via
violence is just purely wrong.  That's my opinion, anyway.

 --Noah

Smiley Dictionary :-)

 :-o    Wow!                       :-c     Real unhappy
 :-|    Grim                       :-C     Just totally unbelieving
 := |   Baboon                     :-B     Drooling
 :-v    Speaking                   :-,     Smirk
 :-V    Shout                      :-||    Anger
 :-w    Speak with forked tongue   :-)     Smiling
 :-r    Sticking tongue out        :-(     Frowning
 :-*    Oops!                      '-)     Wink
 :-T    Keeping a straight face    ;-)     Sardonic Incredulity
 :-D    Said with a smile          %-<I>   Drunk with laughter
 :-x    Kiss kiss                  :-"     Pursing lips
 :-[    Pouting                    :-#     My lips are sealed
 :-X    A big wet kiss!            :-P     Tongue hanging out in anticipation
 :-Y    A quiet aside              8-|     Eyes wide with surprise
 >-<    Absolutely livid!!         &-|     Tearful
 |-{    "Good Grief!"  (Charlie Brown?)
 :-}	"Thish wine tashted pretty good"
 8-]	"wow, maaan"
 8-O	"Omigod!!" (done after "rm -rf *" ?)
 :-,	"Hmmmm."
 |~(	"Someone just busted my nose".
 :^D	"Great! I like it!"
 B-D     "Serves you right, dummy!!"

:-)   Your basic smiley. This smilie is used to inflect a sarcastic or
      joking statement since we can't hear voice inflection over Unix.
;-)   Winky smiley. User just made a flirtatious and/or sarcastic remark.
      More of a "don't hit me for what I just said" smiley.
:-(   Frowning smiley. User did not like that last statement or is upset
      or depressed about something.
:-I   Indifferent smiley. Better than a Frowning smilie but not quite as 
      good as a happy smiley
:->   User just made a really biting sarcastic remark. Worse than a :-).
>:->  User just made a really devilish remark.
>;->  Winky and devil combined. A very lewd remark was just made.

Those are the basic ones...Here are some somewhat less common ones:

(-:   User is left handed
%-)   User has been staring at a green screen for 15 hours straight
:*)   User is drunk
[:]   User is a robot
8-)   User is wearing sunglasses
B:-)  Sunglasses on head
::-)  User wears normal glasses
B-)   User wears horn-rimmed glasses
8:-)  User is a little girl
:-)-8 User is a Big girl
:-{)  User has a mustache
:-{}  User wears lipstick
{:-)  User wears a toupee
}:-(  Toupee in an updraft
:-[   User is a Vampire
:-E   Bucktoothed vampire
:-F   Bucktoothed vampire with one tooth missing
:-7   User just made a wry statement
:-*   User just ate something sour
;-(  User is crying
;-)  User is so happy, s/he is crying
:-@   User is screaming
:-#   User wears braces
:^)   User has a broken nose
:<)   User is from an Ivy League School
:-&   User is tongue tied.
+-:-) User is the Pope or holds some other religious office
`:-)  User shaved one of his eyebrows off this morning
,:-)  Same thing...other side
|-I   User is asleep
|-O   User is yawning/snoring
:-Q   User is a smoker

O :-) User is an angel (at heart, at least)

Note: A lot of these can be typed without noses to make midget smileys.

:) - Midget smilie
:] - Gleep...a friendly midget smiley who will gladly be your friend

:> - hmm, let me think...
:D - Laughter
:I - Hmmm, not funny!
:( - Sad
:[ - Real Downer
:< - what pretences!
:{ - oh boy, the headmaster!...

;( - Crying
[] - Hugs and
:* - Kisses

The Unofficial Smiley Dictionary
--------------------------------

:-)   Your basic smilie. This smilie is used to inflect a sarcastic or
      joking statement since we can't hear voice inflection over Unix.
;-)   Winky smilie. User just made a flirtatious and/or sarcastic remark.
      More of a "don't hit me for what I just said" smilie.
:-(   Frowning smilie. User did not like that last statement or is upset
      or depressed about something.
:-I   Indifferent smilie. Better than a Frowning smilie but not quite as 
      good as a happy smilie
:->   User just made a really biting sarcastic remark. Worse than a :-).
>:->  User just made a really devilish remark.
>;->  Winky and devil combined. A very lewd remark was just made.

Those are the basic ones...Here are some somewhat less common ones:

Changing the mouth:
:-[	A vampire.
:-E	Buck-toothed vampire.
:-F	Buck-toothed vampire with one tooth missing.
:-7	Just made a wry statement.
:-*	Just ate something sour.
:-@	Screaming.
:-#	Wears braces.
:-&	Tongue-tied.
:-Q	Smoking.
:-?	Smoking a pipe.
:-P	Sticking out tongue.
:-S	Just made an incoherent statement.
:-D	Laughing out loud.
:-X	Lips are sealed.
:-C	Really bummed.
:-/	Skeptical.
:-o	Uh-oh.
:-9	Licking his/her lips.
:-0	No yelling! (quiet hours in the dorm) - also an orator.
:-`	Spitting (tobacco).
:-1	Normal.
:-!	Normal.
:-$	Mouth wired shut.
:-%	Banker.
:-q	Trying to touch tongue to nose.
:-a	Same as above on other side.
:-e	Disappointed.
:-t	Cross.
:-i	Semi-smiley.
:-]	Blockhead.
:-[	Unsmiley blockhead.
:-}	Chapped lips, or bearded.
:-{	Indifferent with moustache.
:-j	Left smiley.
:-d	Left smiley razzing reader.
:-k	Beats me.
:-\	Undecided.
:-|	Have a day.
:-<	Real sad.
:-x	Lips are sealed.
:-c	Bummed out.
:-v	Talking head.
:-b	Stincking out tongue.

Changing the nose:
:*)	Drunk.
:^)	Has a broken nose.
:v)	Broken nose in the other direction.
:_)	Nose is sliding off his/her face.
:<)	From an Ivy League school.
:=)	Two noses.
:o)	Clown.
:u)	Funny looking nose (left).
:n)	Funny looking nose (right).

Changing the eyes:
%-)	Staring at the screen for 15 hours straight.
8-)	Wearing sunglasses.
B-)	Wearing glasses (could be horn-rims).
O-)	Megaton, cyclops, of wearing a diving mask.
-)	One-eyed.
,-)	Winking, one-eyed.
g-)	Ponce-nez glasses.

Changing more than one character:
|-I	Sleeping.
|-O	Yawning.
%-6	Brain dead.
|^o	Snoring.
:,(	Crying, but without a nose.
8-|	Suspenseful.

Adding extra characters:
::-)	Wears glasses (four eyes).
B:-)	Glasses on top of head.
8:-)	Little girl.
:-)-8	Big girl.
:-{)	Has moustache.
:-#)	Bushy moustache.
{:-)	Wears a toupee.
}:-)	Toupee in an updraft.
:-)~	Drooling.
:-~)	Has a cold.
:'-)	So happy, he/she is crying.
=:-)	Hosehead.
- - -:-)	Punk rocker.
+-:-)	The Pope.
`:-)	Shaved off one eyebrow.
,:-)	Shaved off the other eyebrow.
O :-)	Angel.
C=:-)	Chef.
*<:-)	Wearing a Santa Claus hat.
E-:-)	Ham radio operator.
8 :-)	Wizard.
@:-)	Wearing a turban.
[:-)	Listening to a walkman.
:-))	Double chin.
>:-)	Devil.
(:-)	Big smile.
+:-)	Priest.
:-)X	Wearing a bow tie.

Misc:
(-:	Left handed.
[:]	Robot.
:-{}	Wearing lipstick.
:'-(	Crying.
<|-)	Chinese.
<|-(	Chinese, but doesn't like these kind of jokes.
- - -:-(	Real punk rockers don't smile.
@=	Pro-nuclear war.
(8-o	Mr. Bill. (From original Saturday Night Live)
*:o)	Bozo the Clown.

Miniatures:

:]	Gleep.
:@	Yelling.

:(	Sad.

Subject: Re:...a Call to Arms.
Author:  alchemist@internity.on.ca at CCSMTP
Date:    1/6/97 1:54 AM


it seems police crack downs are immanent everywhere...
     
toronto just experienced its first big bust in ages...
     
since, the police have hassled us every weekend...
     
i was in austin, texas and there were some pretty intense cop politics 
happening... including infrared cameras and 20 uniformed officers at a 
party!
     
i heard tales from Goa DJ smiling Bhudda about a party he threw in 
Isreal where 4000 ravers showed up in the desert (1% of the Isreali 
population om acid!) and the military surrounded the entire area and 
busted everyone... they took Smiling Bhudda aside and showed him 
pictures of himself at parties, even small UG ones, over the past four 
years and basically said "we know who you are... we know what you;ve 
done... we know what you do..." and let him go...
     
in vancouver, there was a major bust of a lab where E, LSD and DMT (most 
of the supply for Canada and a good chunk of the US)...
     
perhaps a mailing list should be started to begin observing the trends in 
police infiltration and interference... start our own intelligence 
agency... sort of like that Beastie Boys video... "we knew they were 
watching us, so we started watching them"... i would bet there are some 
interesting patterns that might arise... i don't know what happened in 
austin, but there was some really pure E in the area at the time... and 
the heat came down the same week that the vancouver lab went down... 
double sting?... who backs the cops... is it the concerned moral 
majority... or is it the same mob creeps that seek to profit on the E 
market by cutting it with additive substances (crystal meth, synthetic 
heroin, cocaine) or just plain crap (ketamine, GHB, PCP)... did this same 
shit not happen in the late 60's early 70's... Cherry Bomb FX, Red 
Rockets, Reds, Blues, Ludes, Barbs, Yellow Jackets... get the picture... 
most of our "E" isn't even called "E" anymore, let alone MDMA... we have 
no clue of what type of intelligence is being gathered on us... why 
shouldn't we generate some awareness into this issue...
    just a thought... it might be a fun hobby for those not involved in
the drug trade... i don't care if i'm being watched... i haven't 
possessed drugs with the exception of them being ingested for over two 
years... i'm on the McKenna mailing list anyways, so it's too late for 
that!
     it's time we take control... support free markets... vote with your
dollars... don't vote for crap!
     
the alchemist

    YLEM - Artists Using Science and Technology

        is hosting a forum:

	"Manufacturing Reality"

	Wednesday, January 8, 1997, 7:30 pm
	The Exploratorium - McBean Theater
	
	3601 Lyon St.
	San Francisco, 94123
	(Admission Free. Wheelchair accessible)

	Contact: Trudy Myrrh Reagan 415-856-9593


Forum Highlights:
 ----------------

The art/technology relationship is one that emerged with photography,
and
burst out with electronic imaging.

*Mary Steiglitz* will present a survey, "The Camera is not a Mirror," of
the history of visual imaging. It will question the notion of 'realism'
connected with photographic images. She will show the links of
photography
to art, and the current transformation of visual imaging by the
computer.
Steiglitz is professor of art at the University of Idaho, and is an
artist/photographer who has exhibited and published widely.

_Cacophony Drive-In Movie Short Film/Video Festival._ excerpts. *Dave
Krzysik,* is the festival's impresario and editor of this video sampler.
He
will chat about the project as well as Cacophony's next event, the
Brainwash Movie Festival.

*Helen Golden* has worked in photography, drawing and sculpture, always
with the same goals in mind: to create art that would in its ambiguous
reality, engage, provoke and cause the viewer to reflect and wonder.
She is captivated with new technologies and will describe things she
could
not even have dreamed of doing before that are now possible, making this
the most exciting time in her life as an artist.

*Alex and Martha Nicoloff* fabricate their own plastic prisms, and
record
them as they dance in a focussed ray of pure sunlight. Using solar
spectrum illumination, they produce myriad effects synchronized with
unusual music. Their videos have won NEA awards. We will see _The Eye of
the Deity._ Alex describes its themes: "For the reason that it is rarely
attempted, we have chosen to show an interpretative documentary of an
artistic tradition in two Asian cultures. One is the masked identity of
Rangda, a wicked witch often seen in Balinese dances. The other is the
meditative image of a Khmer Boddhisatva dating to the 12th century."

===============

Upcoming Ylem Forums
March 12: "Telepresence"
May 14: "Virtual Reality"

To: "'Sfraves@hyperreal.com'" <Sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: The weekend review...
Date: Mon, 6 Jan 1997 11:47:52 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.994.63
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello and welcome to your life...


Friday:  
Since nothing was happenin' this Friday I thought "screw it" and tried
to throw together a get together so we could all be together...  A lot
of interest was in the air, but the location was nil until Foster sent
me a message about an east bay local.  Unfortunatlley I lost his VM#
(Duhh..).  So I was about to start my own party (consisting of me, me,
and me) in my garage, that's when I gota page from some fellow SFR's and
off to SJ to have a party...
Set up, 420'ed, and spun for a while (oh, about 4hrs or so). Didn't do
too much chatting, since being faded and mixing can be quite a challenge
(sorry for the misbeats everyone).. @ max I think there was
fifteen-or-so people. Which, wasn't too bad for a last minute notice,
and promising for whatever future events there may me.   Deepfog dropped
by around 4'ish and spun some decent house jams intill six and I came
back on till about 7:30 and then CDin it till 9ish...

Saturday:  _Karma 'n' GT_

Got there about 11ish. Place was PACKED (I guess this is what happens
when there's only one event in town...) .  A little dark for my tastes
but chatting w/Thomas I found he lent Galen some lights which he was
waiting for to set up, guess they never got here.  Vibe was allright but
somewhat hot'n'muggy.  Danced HARD to Ethans set, missed Thomas T's (had
to chill in the ambient area).  Helped some poor gal down the very
crowded stairwell (looks like she combined something with something
else, tsk).  Chatted w/a few in the chill room.  The sound went out @
3or so due to the heat... But came back on with a more Goa-type flavour.
 Really Didn't like the high visibility drug scene (Nitrous, E, Acid,
GHB offered to me all within 30mins.).  Esp. when most of the peddeling
was in the stairwell (I think I spent 20min. just trying to get up the
stairs).   But despite thoese minor peeves, it was a very nice event.
Nice enough for them to throw it again next week, at least...

---_Adam
"Stay Connected"

bring to all of you. A little about us we all started out as party goers and
continue to do just that. We just wanted to do something and give back to the
scene what we have learned and experienced. This will be a small event with a
limited capacity of 500. We are trying to keep it small and simple a lot of
people assume that the scene is dead and say "we need to take back our scene"
the scene was never gone just more "under ground" we want to continue with that
by keeping it small and simple. The DJ line up is Donald Glaude, Charlotte,
Alika (hawaii) DJ kexa (eternal ent.) moshe (meridian\2chakra) and others TBA.
we would like to create a specialized mail list for persons so if you would
like to get on the list please E-mail me personally so I can contact you myself
to confirm the info. oh yea I almost forgot the date DUH.. it is Saturday Feb
1.

mouth and internet only.

'People are different! How do we know? Listen through the wonders of
modern technology the thoughts of unsespecting people at a Rave'

<Tuner Adjustment>

Raver1: OhMyGod! E is the best thing in the whole world! Everyone should
take E man! My thoughts are just flowing like water. And this lotion on
this Girls hands feels soo good. It's like I'm melting with her!

<Tuner Adjustment>

Raver2: Whoa man, Acid is the best thing in the whole world! Everyone
should take Acid man! Hey I've got it! Yea E=mc2 yea! And the molecualar
structure of Plutonium when copulated with certain sub-atomic particles
can theoreticly.....

<Tuner Adjustment>

Raver3: Whoa this GHB stuff  is funky. I'll just sit here for a minute
on the toilet and.. ZZZzzzzzzzzz.

<Tuner Adjustment>

Raver4: Man who the heck is still in the Bathroom?! I gottta go! Cmon!!

<Tuner Adustment>

Raver3: Zzzzzzzzzzzzz.....

<Tuner Adjustment>

Raver5: SCHWA, select Human to abduct.

<Tuner Adjustment>

Raver6: When I get home I'm gonna put a black light in my room, in my
car, at my work, at school....

<Tuner Adjustment>

Raver1: Don't forget the bathroom.

<Tuner Adjustment>

Raver6: Hey! How can you read my thoughts?!

<Tuner Adjustment>

Raver1: It's a vibe thing man.

<Tuner Adjustment>

Raver6: Oh, hey speaking of the Bathroom, wheres Ron?

<Tuner Adjustment>

Raver3: Zzzzzzzzzzz

<Tuner Adjustment>

Raver4:Thats it! I'm gonna piss in my pants! How long is this guy gonna
take?!

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@club.net>
Subject: 'Galactic Sweatlodge' location review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

FYI - this is a review of the physical space, not the party that was in the
space. I have a feeling that the following comments will unfortunately
apply to any party held at that location.

First, it reminds me of all the dangerous parts of ACME on Howard Street
but without the any of ACME's "old brick warehouse" charm.

there were way too many people

there was *no* air flow detected (actually there was, but it was not adequate)

it was humid beyond belief

it felt like the floor was going to cave in at the chill room level with
even a few people dancing in there. This is no joke -- it was sagging to
the dancers dancing to the beat. I left that room because I honestly feared
death was approaching

there is exposed electrical wiring

and there's only one exit down the only *and always* crowded stairwell

in summary: this 'death trap' scares me more than ACME ever did.

____________________________________________________________________________
 Wayne D. Correia            +1.415.826.6000           900 Tennessee Street
 <wayne@club.net>        fax +1.415.826.6100        San Francisco, CA 94107

no way of catching the person who DID throw the bottle, but there might 
be a way of reaching the victim.

sick of the people throwing shit at them and their equipment (id be too) 
and were looking for someone to take the blow for it.

exactly

people, and 'help' us, BUT

taken.

> most of them are just doing what they have been ordered to do and they

person for the misbehavior of many.   no one TOLD them (all four of them) 
to take that 'one' guy down with EXECESSIVE violence.

absolutely hate about this list, people ALWAYS ready to pick a fight...

thankx for your post, i'd really like to catch the guy who got the other 
victim's face busted up, but id rather help the guy hurt than go pick 
another fight.

person who got beaten has little or no connection to the rave

the news media if you don't find this person through other means

Well I got there right when the party started.  It wasn't crowed, at first,
then by 12:00 or so, I was like where did all of these people come from??? 
Yeah they oversold tix, which wasn't supposed to happen.  It was an ok
party not great not bad just ok.  I didn't get to dance much because I
ended up getting too involved with people passing out and then the pepper
spray innocident.  I met a lot of new people as usual, and saw some people
from the list.  But over all it was a good party.  I'm looking forward to
the weekend as usual, but I may or may not have blow pops =(  I know most
of you will be upset, but I have way too many bills to pay, so I am going
to parties still, but I may not have blow pops.  Again I am sorry for that.

In a message dated 97-01-06 17:10:42 EST, you write:

<< 
 FYI - this is a review of the physical space, not the party that was in the
 space. I have a feeling that the following comments will unfortunately
 apply to any party held at that location.
 
 First, it reminds me of all the dangerous parts of ACME on Howard Street
 but without the any of ACME's "old brick warehouse" charm.
 
 there were way too many people
 
 there was *no* air flow detected (actually there was, but it was not
adequate)
 
 it was humid beyond belief
 
 it felt like the floor was going to cave in at the chill room level with
 even a few people dancing in there. This is no joke -- it was sagging to
 the dancers dancing to the beat. I left that room because I honestly feared
 death was approaching
 
 there is exposed electrical wiring
 
 and there's only one exit down the only *and always* crowded stairwell
 
 in summary: this 'death trap' scares me more than ACME ever did.
  >>
I fully agree with Wayne... I was there before the party started and I stood
in the stairwell giving flyers... Slowly, the place started to fill up..
people just kept coming and coming and coming.... It was soo packed I didn't
even go into the large room... I decided to actually exit the building when
you could barely stand in the stairwell... I was outside when i noticed that
the actual building was shaking! The shadows of the bars moved back in forth!
it was amazing and SCARY! I told people as they entered... remember where
this door is, cause if something happens, its the only way out!! That party
was NOT cool... Thomas came out a few times and yelled at the guys, saying no
more people, its insane! They closed the map point early but people where
still coming! The security dude, was letting people in without tickets...He
didn't seem to bright..... Anyway.. that location is a severe deathtrap! BTW
people are lucky their cars didn't get towed! That was a federal building
across the street, and you can't park within 100 hundred feet of it!! This
location needs to be boycotted..
Jonathan

Stevenson Warehouse

I have to concur with the sentiments regarding this location.  I tried my 
best to put it out of my mind on NYE, but I definitely felt unsafe.  I 
couldn't even stay in the chill room (even though I really wanted to) 
because the way the floor kept sagging under the crowd was too frightening.

I dislike complaining about locations because I know how difficult it is 
for promoters to find them... But, as I wrote before, here's an instance 
where the fire and safety code is right on.  It is too fucking dangerous 
to have a party there.

Also, considering how packed it was NYE and on Saturday night (two 
relatively "small" events), I think our scene may have outgrown this 
space.  It accomodates maybe 300 people (and how many safely?), and 
obviously our family is WAY bigger than that!  _Maybe_ this location 
would be allright for the smallest parties, with truly limited (pre-sale 
only?) tix.

-N

 I remember one night in HighSchool. I was at a party which (ofcourse) got
out of hand. People were running up and down the streets trying to figure
out why everybody was running up and down the streets.
 Us being the rebels n all, were walking in the middle of the street.
 I see a cop walking on the sidewalk, and I say "cop" because my friend Jay
had a beer in his hand. Not knowing where the cop was, Jay quickly hucks
his beer. But he throws it right at the cops feet.  It was pretty
halarious.


Guess you had to be there.

First, I just want to say I hope everyones holidays were a good one and
everyone is safe and sound.

Well, I've been talking about it, so now is the time to start taking
action. BBQ & BEATS Campout. The 1 Year Anniversary is coming up and I
would like to plan a campout for June 6th and 7th. I'm planning on it to
start on Saturday June 6th around Noonish and run until late afternoon on
Sunday June 7th. I'm trying to have this be a $5-$10 party just to cover
cost. I'd like to get as much as I can  donated and volunteered as I can to
keep the price down and the vibe up. So if your interested in helping out
and want to help plan for this, please let me know privately.

Nothing is set in stone at this time, I just thought it would be good to
get this all planned out early to avoid any hassles later.

A also want to thank everyone that has came out as well as helped in the
past and supported these events. There are very special to me and I have
had a blast throwing them for you. So let's make this one the best ever.

As far as DJs go, if your interested and would like to be considered and
don't mind volunteering your time spinning your favorite toons and have a
demo tape you can get to me to checkout that would be great. If I've heard
you spin before, then the demo tape would not be needed unless you just
want to give me one anyways.

Just want to say to everyone, Thanks for all your support and lets make
this a camping trip we all will never forget.

Tim (knucklehead)


P.S.  For all those that keep asking, YES, I will spin at this one. 8)

Precedence: bulk

Call me cynical, nay even jaded, but I can't help feeling that the people
who went to this one, and probably the Oragin one as well, were all 
victims of one of the biggest scams in recent Bay Area rave history.
Here's how it works: You do get the permits, and then take them along to
an inssurance company and insure the rave (to cover you for loss/damage of
equipment, contracted dj's not showing up, etc, etc); but this also covers
you for the termination of the party.  So at 8.00 when the fire marshall
comes to inspect the venue it is legal but by 12.00 they have removed a
fire exit and they are no longer legal.  One quick call later from a
"complaining neighour" and the cops are shutting it down because of fire
exit issue.  The organizers then clean up twice: firstly from pre-sale and
early evening ticket sales; and secondily, when they got inssurance they
estimated there toal capacity and mutiplyed that with the price for one
ticket ($30) and inssured themselves against falling below capcity.
Because the rave was officially caceled, they officially got inssurance
money back to live up to there legal responsibility to refund the
customers money.  But they did not directly sell the tickets to the
public, record shops did, and they are under no legal obligation to refund
anybody anything.  Thus, the promoters sell-out and get an additional 50%
(aprox) back from the inssurance factor.  After slipping a few scheckels
to helful parties, they then laugh all the way to the bank with a HUGE
sum of money.
Maybe I am going a bit over the top but one fact does remain: no-one is
stupid enough to organize a rave like cool world to have it shut down by
1.00am.  if this had been in England the ravers would have faught with the
riot cops and the promoters would be found and all given chelsea smiles
(which is where one takes a knife and slits a persons face from mouth to
ear) so that for the rest of the life they would all be seen to be liars
and thieves.  These people committed one of the worse crimes going: that
of profiting out of others good-will and for that they should be run out
of town.
I, myself spent new years eve at several large illegal parties that were
all free and not one of them got busted.
Have a happy 97!
Tristan.

We were really treated to some of the best music last
night.... Mixmaster Morris was incredible! He spun jungle that I had
never heard before in my life (some of it even approached really good
experimental jazz), and created a set that I can only describe as an
intricate collage of music. Mark Broom came on afterwards and proceded
to play techno (I suppose it was UK techno) that *killed*
me... Between the two of them, I was fully destroyed by the end of the
night.

I hate to say it, but anyone who missed Mad last night missed some of
the best music and dancing that I've experience in a _long_ time... Even
my grump old raver friends were buggin' out. :)

Steve

Contact: World Tribe Project
353B 29th  St.
San Francisco, CA 94131
(415) 648-8219
(415) 386-0586

Jan. 6,1997

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

The "One Tribe" benefit concert to save the rainforest involves more than 
just music from some incredible local talents. Organizers are employing 
the innovative new-media techniques to bring the tropics to life during 
the performances.

There is irony in using technology to slow the trampling  foot of the 
progress. Yet, what better to communicate the urgent need to save the 
world's rainforests than through the use of multimedia tools and the 
World Wide Web? Technology brings people closer together to find common 
solutions for the environment. 

"One Tribe" will be held Jan. 26th at the Maritime Hall in San Francisco. 
Music, dancing and multimedia shows will go from 8 p.m. to 1 a.m. The 
concert features well-known Bay Area bands Soulstice, Jamalski and 
Neomythic. Terra Deva will serve as emcee; and Mei-Lwun (BCE) will deejay.

The benefit will include an Academy Award-nominated film short on the 
rainforest. CCSI-Entersol Inc., an Internet company, will provide some 
stunning high-tech visuals; featuring a new digital art form of 
expression called "Xfrasis" visual poetry. (Samples of the event Xfrasis 
can be downloaded from www.entresol.com.)

The purpose of the concert is to raise awareness and money for a 
rainforest tribe known as the Ashuar people, an indigenous nation of 3000 
who live on 1.5 million acres of the world's most ecologically diverse 
regions. The area in the Amazon basin of southeastern Ecuador can only be 
accessed by small planes landing on dirt runways cleared out of the 
jungle. This remoteness has been a blessing in that no mining, lumber or 
mineral interests have encroached on the Achuar ancestral land, But that 
is changing.

Your support can help in preserving the Achuar traditional land and their 
way of life.
Human/Nature International, a U.S. non-profit group, is working to first 
to help the Achuar maintain their land. Second Human/Nature is developing 
a long-term plan to halt the destruction  of the Earth's rainforest,  to 
find ways in which ancient indigenous cultures can co-exist with the 
modern world.

Tickets for the concert are $10 and may be purchased at the Maritime 
Hall, 450 Harrison St. For ticket information please contact Maritime 
Hall (4150 974-0634 or 974-0633. For more information for the event, 
please call Danah at (415) 648-8219, fax: (415) 386-0588 or email: 
haidai@ccsource-inc.com. If you would like more information about the 
cause, please contact Bill Twist at (415) 616-7353 or email to: 
btwist@champion-sf.com.




                       *______________*______________*           
                                   !E.A.C!
                                  Astronout            
                               408 SpaceLounge         
                        Electronic Artists Collective

Hey. A while back I mentioned that anyone who is interested can come work 
at KZSU and get a radio show. Once a quarter, we have an organizational 
meeting where people can come find out about the station, meet the 
department heads, apply for the dj training class, and get involved.

The meeting for this quarter is tomorrow (Wednesday) at 7:30. It's being 
held on the Stanford Campus in the main quad building. Specifically, 
we're meeting in History Corner, room 2 (downstairs). For anyone who has 
access to a web browser, here's the map URL:

	http://www-pcd.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/map/map.html?history

If you're interested in becoming a dj, learning a lot about music, or 
getting your own radio show, come check us out. 

dj radon

The three places I shop in SF, based on selection and price are...

Zebra Records on Haight St
Leo's Pro Audio on Van Ness (there's also one in Oakland)
Guitar Center on Mission

There are plenty of other places, I have found these places to be the most
reliable and/or to give the best prices.

  I think preying on the good faith of thousands of happy raving people 
does irreperable damage to our scene.  It doesn't take too many experiences
 like that to cause people to build psychological walls, and distrust of 
others, and so on.  And especially on acid or e.  A lot of those people
were probably at their first rave.  While I don't know the whole story,
it is a fact that Cool (Cruel) World lied about some of the acts, as documented
in previous posts.  And as a zen master would say, the big truths are reflected
in the small details.  Those promoters obviously didn't have any integrity,
and I think it's probably true that they were out for a quick buck, fuck
everyone else.  They probably won't get chelseas but the karma sown will make
for a life (several perhaps) that I wouldn't care to live.   :))

that's all that is is a quote, as opposed to the truth.  Is parroting learned
behaviour (for example: Child abuse) the same as living true to yourself
(like Dancing for the love of it, or climbing Mt. Everest)??  Asking someone
to change learned behaviour, is just asking them to learn new behaviour to 
replace it (like recycling instead of littering, that sort of thing).
my 2cents.
Bruce

Date: Wed, 8 Jan 1997 14:03:44 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Rusty H. Hodge" <rusty@hodge.com>
Subject: Cannabis Buyers Club Injunction Lifted
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

[Cool. From KPIX Newswire -R]

A San Francisco Superior Court judge told a packed courtroom today
that he was giving state voters the benefit of the doubt on medical
marijuana.

Judge David A. Garcia, in modifying a temporary injunction that
shut down the San Francisco Cannabis Buyers Club last year, said, "I
don't think you or I are going to say that the people of California
were totally ineffectual in trying to pass a medical marijuana law."
Garcia was declining to go along with the attorney general's
request to rule that the club could not re-open because it was not a
primary caregiver as required by the law.

State voters passed Proposition 215 in November, authorizing the
cultivation and distribution of marijuana for medicinal purposes.
But Garcia warned that the club had to operate without making a
profit or it would be in violation of the law.

--
Rusty Hodge (rusty@hodge.com), Media Futurist / Cyberneticist

http://www.rusty.org  <-- Me Being Silly

This is not a flame, simply tossing in my cookies...

At 06:46 PM 1/7/97 -0800, Mr nStuff wrote:
> I would bet cha, that Tristan has lied. Cheated. And probably even stolen
>something from one of her own flesh and blood relatives somewhere in her
>past. And for that. She should of spent all of her life growing up, looking
>like the Joker on Batman.

  I understand that this is a delicate situation, but I would like to offer
the concept that people can change. I have done some kinda screwed up stuff
in my time and I would never indicate to anyone that it was okay. However,
I have paid my karmic debts and changed my evil ways into a positive
energy, which I really try to share with others. It's not easy to do here
in the midwest (I can't wait to get out there to the bay area!), but
none-the-less, I smile at people, treat them courteously and try to take
the negatives and turn them into something good. So, they look at me wierd
and think that there must be something wrong with me to be so happy. That's
their problem. ;)
  I know credibility and trust are hard to regain when someone loses them,
but it's only fair to consider that people can make a difference and
improve upon themselves, wherever they stand. Consider the following
scenario: Here in Chicago, just a few weeks ago. "ascii" who has always
thrown reliable and fun partys, was throwing "elemental2". Due to no fault
of theirs, Chicago's finest showed up and closed the thing down around
1:30a. Now, they have a bad reputation with a bunch of folks and they
didn't even do anything wrong. It's hard enough to maintain a positive
image without being damned for an eternity, because you slipped up. I guess
what I'm trying to say is that we can't support "evil" promoters (agreed),
but there should be a point in time, IMO, when you give somebody another
chance. :)
  Maybe I don't know enough about the situation and should not have made
this post?  Oh well...it was made with good intentions, anyhoo...

/* plur */
  matter


I'm smiling because I don't understand myself. :)

This is not original, nor is it new, nor is this the only place you can
find it, but it IS a raver light bulb joke... Hmmm, I think I'll just post
the first part and see if anyone else (I'm sure) knows the punch line. If
not, I'll post it l8r. ;) This just came across mw-raves and the poster got
slightly flamed for putting it up. Sooo, I am trying to avoid that. :P

How many ravers does it take to screw in a light bulb?

Hmmm, I just made up a different punchline for the rave mail lists (hope
it's funny):

1001, 100 to preview and speculate about it, 800 to wait in-line and then
stand around and watch, 1 person who actually does it (must be the dj), and
100 more to review it when it's over and comment on the vibe.

/* plur */
  matter

try to keep it under 5 a week :)

Q: How many ravers does it take to screw in a lightbulb?
A: Probably only a couple of hundred, but Hard Copy will say thousands...

Q: How many raves does it take to screw in a lightbulb?
A: None!  Screwing has not place in the scene!  You have no PLUR if you're
screwing, lightbulb or not!

resist.  You all understand, I'm sure.)

deeje cooley wrote:

> Just wanted to let you know that Soapbox Dec 1996 is posted, featuring
> music by Steve Cooley and James Furey (and, of course, the "OrbiLamp").

To anyone who checks out Deeje's page (http://www.deeje.com), sees the
"OrbiLamp" (a brilliant idea!), please keep in mind to twist open the
bottle and leave the cap at least partly unscrewed.  Otherwise your
poor-man's lava lamp will become a poor man's super soaker -- the heat
from the lights in the cup will eventually heat up the drink, increasing
the pressure in the bottle to the point of explosion.  At best the cap
will blow off, the liquid will jet out, and you'll have an electrical
hazard as well as little gummy things on your ceiling...

S

Hi all!  ]=)

 I'm just so happy and I need to share this vibe with someone!

 For those who don't know I'm a student at the University of California 
in Santa Cruz (USA). Our quarter just started here. I've been shopping 
for classes and one class I signed up for was a class called "What Is 
Dance". I thought this would be good for me as a multi-media design 
artist; you know learn some basic things about dance, what it looks like, 
what you can do with it. I also expected it to be mostly lecture.

WRONG!!! This class (taught by Tandy Beal) is about MOVING! Not only do 
we see videos and get (minimal) lectures on dance but we MOVE! We DANCE! 
And oh my goodness have I been getting high on the stuff! YIKES!!!!

 Tonight I saw two videos on art and dance and I was literally crying 
with joy. I'm so happy that I've taken this class! The funny thing was 
that I had planned on dropping this class first! But thanks to the 
mysterious universe, what I thought would be a required class is no more 
and now I can continue with the dance class!  =)  Not only does this dance 
class fulfill a basic education requirment for me to graduate but I'm 
one of 4 men in a class of about 40. Oh joy!!

 Seriously though, I am really going over the edge with glee. This is 
just fantastic!!! It is the perfect answer to my _enforced_ break. Not 
only that, but when i get back in the scene I should be able to bust a 
move or two to put JSL to shame. Sissors kick my ass! Watch these feet boy!!


smiles!  =)



Ran D.Dreams

deeje cooley wrote:

> Just wanted to let you know that Soapbox Dec 1996 is posted, featuring
> music by Steve Cooley and James Furey (and, of course, the "OrbiLamp").

To anyone who checks out Deeje's page (http://www.deeje.com), sees the
"OrbiLamp" (a brilliant idea!), please keep in mind to twist open the
bottle and leave the cap at least partly unscrewed.  Otherwise your
poor-man's lava lamp will become a poor man's super soaker -- the heat
from the lights in the cup will eventually heat up the drink, increasing
the pressure in the bottle to the point of explosion.  At best the cap
will blow off, the liquid will jet out, and you'll have an electrical
hazard as well as little gummy things on your ceiling...

S

               ...I do alot of comparing."

multimedia arts celebration with artists, musicians, fire dancers,
performers. The entire night is being professionally videotaped and live
netcasted at www.be-in.com.

the door tonite.) info: number9@be-in.com, 415-777-9199 or
http://www.be-in.com

===============================================================================

UPDATE on DIGITAL BE-IN #9

This digest of Be-In 9 material forwarded by Brian Zisk, San FranZiskGo!  . . .

    * Thursday January 9. 7:00 p.m.

      Digital Be-In

      Thirty years ago, S.F. was host to The Human Be-In, a now-historic
      counter-culture gathering of hippies and other assorted "freaks" who
      converged on Golden Gate Park to express their commitment to forging a
      new future together. The Digital Be-In's 9th annual event is a tribute
      to the spirit of that day, and to the ever-increasing diversity of the
      wired world. Show highlights include musical performances by
      post-modern world music ensemble Beyond Race, African cultural rap by
      Hoopla Thang, Brazilian drummers and dancers Loco Bloco. Dancers
      include the traditional Aztec dance troupe Danza Teokalli, Panjaya
      Collective's "Angels in Cyberspace" performance piece, and the Burning
      Man fire dancers. Strategically held during the Macworld Expo, Verbum's
      ever-evolving Be-In is a multimedia concert, exhibition and gathering.
      The realtime event will be netcast with several video streams, virtual
      photography, and on-the-fly photojournalism, and can be accessed at
      www.be-in.com. SOMAR Gallery, 934 Brannan St. Tickets $15.00, available
      through Ticketweb, through BASS, and at the Micro Publishing News Booth
      at MacWorld - No 2348.

===============================================================================

Announcing Digital Be-In Number 9

the annual digital art happening is morphing reality into higher gear on
January 9, 1997 in a swirl of drumbeat colors

the language of light

diversity, complexity

beauty, vision

7 until Late

SOMAR 934 Brannan SF

Tickets $15.00

Bass 510-762-BASS
MacWorld Expo: Micro Publishing News Booth #2348, South Hall.
In The Haight: Distractions 252-8751, Housewares 415-252-1440.
Or, reserve by phone with credit card at Verbum, 777-9199

info: number9@be-in.com, 415-777-9199
info/netcast: www.be-in.com


A Celebration of Cultural Diversity in Cyberspace

plus

30th Anniversary of the Human Be-In with Special Guests Allen Cohen, Chet Helms

Digital Frontier Exhibition

Cyberspace Be-In: Avatars and Virtual Worlds

Beyond Race, Soulstice, Burning Man, Panjaya Collective Dancers, Danza
Teokalli, Loco Bloco, Hoopla Thang, Scramble/Riots, Blendo Visuals by
Dimension7 and friends, visionaries, and a *Midnight Seminar*

Event Sponsors
Apple Computer, Black Sun Interactive, Net Objects, OliVR, Silicon
Graphics, Sun Microsystems

Associate Sponsors Fujitsu, Electric Minds, Imaja, NetNoir, Java World,
Netscape World, Onlive Technologies

Special thanks to: Adolph Gasser, Anon Salon, Bay Guardian, Micro
Publishing News, MicroTimes, Mondo 2000, Outpost, Waterside Productions

The Digital Be-In is a production of Verbum, Inc. mail@verbum.com
www.verbum.com

VERBUM, INC.
123 Townsend Street Suite 645
San Francisco, CA 94107
415-777-9901
fax 415-777-9929
email mail@verbum.com
website www.verbum.com

===============================================================================

A while back I posted info on Rubber Ducky, a 303-emulator for the PC.
Now, us mac kids have a new toy:

> If you want a 303 but can't find/afford one you might be interested in
> ReBirth, a program that gives you two 303s and a 808 on your computer. 
> 
> All instruments can be programmed like the originals and filters/tunings
> can be treated i real-time. Best of all: it sounds great. I have a 303 and
> i'd have a hard time taking the pepsi challange with ReBirth and my 303.
> 
> ReBirth also incudes a delay and a distortion section to beef up the sound.
> 
> A free demo for PowerMacs is available from Propellerheads Software's
homepage:
> 
> http://www.propellerheads.se
> 
> Win95 version is under developement.
> 
> It's a great program, check it out.
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jan  9 15:45:15 1997

From: KaySEE <scarab@value.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Your Hearing
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.970109152306.3081E-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hearing is a subject that comes up from time to time on this list.  I just
found a web page sponsored by H.E.A.R (Hearing Education and Awareness for
Rockers).  It is really informative about what kind of damage loud music
can do to you, and what to do about it (i.e. ear plugs).  I think someone
has mentioned this group before, but I thought I'd pass on the web page in
case anyone is interested.  It is an organization partly founded by one of
the founders of the Haight Ashbury Free Clinic.  Check it out.  Raves
definitely do damage to your ears.

www.hearnet.com

-KaySEE

>>> If you want a 303 but can't find/afford one you might be interested in
>>> ReBirth, a program that gives you two 303s and a 808 on your computer.
>>>
>>> A free demo for PowerMacs is available from Propellerheads Software's
>>homepage:
>>>
>>> http://www.propellerheads.se
>
>woe....
>
>This thing is pretty cool!!! I Just downloaded it.  It sounds EXACTLY
>like a 303, filters and all.
>
>wow!!

Yes, yes! I am completly smashed how fuckin cool this is!! You can make
your favorite acid/trance/techno tunes in about 2 minutes. Plenty o' knobs
and buttons to twiddle. If you have a Mac, you MUST get this!!!

I can now see how the original techno/rave types glommed onto this box. It
allows you to create some completely whacked tunes with almost NO musical
ability of any kind. Just create. Really the way to create a movement.

Another two thumbs up, way up, for this masterpiece!

doug

               RAVER POP-QUIZ * DUE AT THE END OF THE MILLENIUM

1) A raver ________ parties.

    a)detests
    b)loves
    c)enhances
    d)b and c

2) A party should ____________.

    a)cause smiles
    b)induce dancing and hugging
    c)make lots of money
    d)a and b

3) Drugs ___________ parties.

    a)are the only way to have phun at
    b)if used responsibly, can enhance enjoyment of
    c)are good for making money at
    d)are evil and disgusting, and ruin

OK, things are going again this weekend...there's the benefit for Food
Not Bombs tonight, then several parties each night this weekend.  There's
also the Digital Be-In at Somar tonight, but I haven't figured out exactly 
what it is.  

I'm back on SFRaves now, but my mailbox is so full now that I might have
lost track of some events ;)...

   Cat's Grill & Alley, 1190 Folsom @ 8th, SF. 415.431.3332
   
   _rotation_ - jazz, hiphop, soul, acid jazz, funk w/DJs racer x, yamu,
   stef, rasta cue-tip, guests. 10pm-2am, 21+. up & down club, 1151
   Folsom St, SF.
   
   _mad_ - trance, electro, old school, minimal, hard, detroit, acid
   w/DJs Alex, Joe Rice, Monty, Sho, guests. 2$ before 11pm
   10pm-2am, 18+, $3. Bahia Cabana, 1600 Market St, SF.
   
   _The Deep End_ - Experimental ambient lounge w/DJs Leath, guests. for
   info: leath@sirius.com
   9pm-2am, 21+. the Hi-Fi Lounge, 14 S 2nd Street @ Santa Clara, San
   Jose. 408.282.HIFI
   
   _Monday Night Dinner_ - a haphazard collection of ravers who get
   together weekly to properly wind down their weekend or rev their
   engines for the coming week. a different cuisine each week, usually in
   SF.
   info on SFRaves or here (when available). Ask for the SFRaves table.
   after-party at Mad.
   8:30p-All ages.
   
  Tuesday
  
   Breathe Deep - serious music for serious dancers w/DJs Jay-J, Ruben
   Mancias, Miquel, guests. 11pm-5am, 21+, $7. 1015 Folsom., SF.
   415.998.9515
   
   _Succotash!_ - tasty jazz - funk - beats - space w/DJs tom thump,
   rasta q-tip. 21+, Free. up & down club, 1151 folsom st., SF.
   
   _supper_ - funk, acid jazz w/DJs Caspar, guests. 21+, Free. Julie's
   Supper Club, 1123 Folsom @ 7th, SF. 415.861.0707
   
   _Lost in Space_ - house, hip-hop w/DJs Pause, Dark Money, Winnie B,
   Eric Lacy. 21+, Free. Cafe Mars, 798 Brannan @ 7th, SF.
   
   _Eclectic_ - house, jungle, drum & bass w/DJs Yamu, Siege, Franko,
   Foster, guests. Fresh fruit & condoms to all
   9pm-2am, 21+. Paradise Bar & Grill, 5356 College Ave, Oakland.
   
   _The Deep_ - house, techno. 9pm-2am, . Palookaville, 1133 Pacific Ave,
   Santa Cruz?. 408.425.3316
   
   _Speakeasy_ - Good Music. Deep House to Jungle w/DJs Shannon,
   Mauricio, guests. every other Tuesday
   9pm-2am, $2. Coco Club, 139 8th St, SF.
   
   _Syncopic_ - Psychostoneyrollerbeats w/DJs Arkay, guests. happens on
   the 2nd & 4th Tuesday of each month
   $3 donation.
   9pm-2am, 21+. the Top, 424 Haight St, SF.
   
   _Plush_ - house, jungle, trance, ambient w/DJs guest DJs weekly.
   9:30p-2a, 21+, $3. 2708 J St, Sacramento. 916.484.4285
   
   _Pure_ - house w/DJs Brian Brandon, guests. 9pm-, 18+. The Rage, 1890
   Arden Way, Sacramento. 916.929.0232

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday morning 9am-11am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench. Varied techno sub-genres, noise, spoken word, world
       music. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).
