Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

what will the next 303 be?

How can more and more of our brothers, sisters, children, and parents 
make music, find harmony with others, find themselves?

This list has seen countless posts about what raving is, but I finally 
understand what it means to me.  It's about the increasingly periodic 
renneasaunce (sp?) that is rising once again, in our time.  I get to 
contribute to a positive part of history.

And I get to share it with all of you.


peace

deeje

>is Pathetic. To make matters worse, it was clearly a dangerous hour to

Dear Steve,

        This is an excellent idea, one that gets tossed around from time to
time, but our community never seems to really pick it up and run with it.
Promoters usually get the blame for busts which properly rests with the
police and the authorities, perhaps because we don't take the concept
signified by the "U" in PLUR seriously.
        But if you're serious, and it sounds like you are, I can find out
the names of some people in the Libertarian Party who have experience
writing initiative measures and getting them on the ballot.  I am 100%
behind you on this, and I can almost guarantee that we will have the
support of the Libertarian Party as well, and if we show a lot of support
for this from our community, we should be able to attract serious interest
from the party and other political groups in the broader libertarian
movement..
        Right now the rave community is not visible on the radar screen of
libertarians because ravers have not been politically active in alerting
potential allies to the civil liberties violations we witness on a regular
basis as have groups like gun owners, tax protesters, and opponents of the
war on drugs.  (I should add that libertarians have also been negligent in
doing outreach to youth in general and certainly to the rave community as a
subset of youth culture.)
        But again I think that the party would be more than receptive to
our concerns if we present evidence of what has been going on and
demonstrate that we are committed to ending the repression.
        I think we also need to increase the beat of the internal drum
circle (if you'll accept the metaphor!) on this issue if we're going to be
effective in producing lasting change.  Politicians are experts at divide
and conquer -- placating special interest groups and diluting their energy.
If ravers are not sufficiently determined in demanding real rather than
just token reform, they'll dissuade many of us from our original purpose
without giving anything significant in return.
        If we actually make enough of a stir to get the attention of the
establishment, these are some of the tactics we should be prepared for:



        * The cops to calm the waters by cleaning up their act a bit --
until the issue dies down.

        * Politicians and officials who say they are on our side, but urge
us to go slow or hold off while they study the issue, refer it to
committee, try to craft a compromise, or whatever, counting on us meanwhile
losing our momentum.  If we go along, we'll find when the issue inevitably
dies down that nothing's really changed.

        * Offers to work with the largest and best organized groups of rave
promoters to make it easier for them to get through the permit process and
not get busted, in effect buying their silence while the smaller parties
have just as bad a time of it as ever.

        * Members of our community to be appointed to various committees or
otherwise involved in the political process, so that they will have a
personal investment in the glacial nature of this process and provide a
counterweight to rabble rousers like myself. ;)

        * A crackdown, perhaps accompanied by the scapegoating of
underground raves as the source of various marginally related or unrelated
problems, such as drugs, gang activity, etc.  Politicians have found that
raising public fears about the safety and welfare of children (read: anyone
under 18) is an especially effective way to get people to go along with
increases in government control, so don't be surprised to see a particular
focus on the age of rave attendees as an excuse for perpetrating fascism.

        * The licensing of rave operators.  Again this would have the
effect of dividing us by giving licenseholders a stake in the process and
pitting them against unlicensed promoters who "didn't have to go through
what I went through" to throw a party.  Or recognized operators (with or
without licensing) might be given more leeway, with a few strings attached,
such as having to police their own parties for drugs, underage attendance,
hiring off-duty cops for security, etc., under the threat of having their
recognition revoked if they are found in violation.  Nothing keeps master's
hands clean and the slaves in line like giving a few willing slaves little
whips to hold over the others.

        Besides all this, something we have to be very careful of, imho, is
buying into premises which go contrary to what our scene is about.  At the
S.F. City Hall hearings three years ago, I remember rave promoters getting
up and testifying to things that just weren't true, such as denying the
prevalence of drug use or teenagers at parties.
        Whenever we do that, we validate the point of view that says there
is something wrong with using psychedelics, or pot, that there is something
wrong with a 16-year-old being at a fun, all-night dance event.  Our line
should be that these are matters of individual choice and parental concern,
not a concern of the government at any level or in any form.  Every time we
deviate from this outlook, we undermine our own position, and give the
authorities the moral justification for busting raves.
        Similarly, we must never agree that they have the right to make us
obtain a license or permit of any kind to throw a rave.  As long as the
consent of the property owner has been obtained, we are within our rights
of free speech, free assembly, and free expression.

This was a very fun event. Good munchies all nite long, all one can devour.
There were two live acts that I didn't know but were good. 
There wasn't much seperation of the sound systems though, therefore the main
system was heard throughout the space. 
The space was a huge theatre of some sort, nice spacious room.

The music was a fun mix with a strong showing of female DJ's Pollywog, DRC,
and Jen(?) 
Jungle, Trance and some downtempo type stuff kept everyone intetested and happy.
For me though, DRC brought on the rain for the last DJ to play and Flux
played some nice earth shaking bass. 
Bummed I missed Jon Carel's set though.
 I saw kind people all nite long.

Oh well, sleep now
a dry review by
-plex-

Ahh,  the smell of a Friday....

Too bad I wasn't able to witness DRC set. Ya know, had to get to the
good 'ole 9-5 and all (Ok, 8-5 with an hr lunch).  But I'd have to say
that missing DRC's set was possibly the only lowpoint I could think of @
this event.  The place was OK,  I think it was one building away from
the last FNB benefit.  I really didn't catch what was goin' on in the
upstairs room, just gruuvin to the beats on the main floor...
Got there during Tomcat's set.  And that live mic to the jungle set was
pretty on as well.  I guess everybody was moving during Jack Acid's set
(the live set?)...  A really great cross-section of people were there
too: college folk, goths, skaters... U name it. It is nice to see people
come together for a common cause.
I really didn't eat too much food'n'all but it did wet my appetitte for
the weekend events.

Got to meet some of ya's as well (hello Nancy, KaySEE and Micron).  And
I THINK I saw someone else (shy??).  Oh well, hopefully I'll see some
more of ya'lls out @ _Happy Kids_ or _Resoultion_.

Till Then. Dare to be Different,


---_Adam

"Stay Connected"

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jan 10 09:02:15 1997

X-Sender: szriffle@peseta.ucdavis.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 2.1.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Rick Riffle <rdriffle@ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Sacto-jungle
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Went to a new club in Sacto last night.  It's at Ricci's, downtown on 7th
and J.  I never go out during the week, but dj Adrian was spinning, and he's
spins jungle.  There haven't been any flyers put out, so the turn out was
pretty minimal.  But I wasn't there to see people....I wanted to hear some
d&b.  Adrian rocked as usual, and the music fucked with my head and sent me
into hysterics several times.  Jungle is just so weird....I love it.  

I get the impression that this club, which I still don't know the name of
will be mostly house, but the resident dj (Mike Moss) who also does all the
booking told me he wants to give all the Sacto dj's a chance regardless of
style.  I thought that was pretty cool.  He even asked if we (RE:) wanted to
come out and do a live ambient/idm set.  I'm into it, so I'll post something
if it happens.  

So I stayed up hours past my bed time, and now I'm paying sitting here at
work trying to be functional.  I think I'll go home sick and sleep.

My only beef is that it costs $5, and it's really small.  But in this case
it was worth it to hear Adrian's d&b.

Rick

a friend forwarded this to me... I found it fairly amusing. I am sure it
exists somewhere out on the net. Prolly more like 457,324 places. I hope
you enjoy, else there's always *delete* ;)

>=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
>             "The Sixth Sense - The Sense of Humor"
>=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
>
>"I was recently on a tour of Latin America, and the only regret I have
>was that I didn't study Latin harder in school so I could converse
>with those people"
>  -Former U.S.  Vice-President Dan Quayle
>
>"They're multipurpose. Not only do they put the clips on, but they
>take them off."
>  -Pratt & Whitney spokesperson explaining why the company charged the
>  Air Force nearly $1000 for an ordinary pair of pliers.
>
>"The President has kept all of the promises he intended to keep."
>  -Clinton aide George Stephanopolous speaking on Larry King Live
>
>"We're going to turn this team around 360 degrees."
>  -Jason Kidd, upon his drafting to the Dallas Mavericks
>
>"I'm not going to have some reporters pawing through our papers. We
>are the president."
>  -Hillary Clinton commenting on the release of subpoenaed documents
>
>"When more and more people are thrown out of work, unemployment
>results."
>  -Former U.S. President Calvin Coolidge
>
>"It's like deja vu all over again."
>  -Yogi Berra
>
>"China is a big country, inhabited by many Chinese"
>  -Former French President Charles De Gaulle
>
>"The loss of life will be irreplaceable."
>  -Former U.S. Vice-President Dan Quayle on the San Francisco
>  earthquake
>
>"It is necessary for me to establish a winner image. Therefore, I have
>to beat somebody."
>  - Richard M. Nixon
>
>"The government is not doing enough about cleaning up the
>environment. This is a good planet."
>  -Mr. New Jersey contestant when asked what he would do with a
>  million dollars.
>
>"When I have been asked during these last weeks who caused the riots
>and the killing in L.A., my answer has been direct and simple: Who is
>to blame for the riots? The rioters are to blame. Who is to blame for
>the killings? The killers are to blame."
>  -Former U.S. Vice-President Dan Quayle on the complex social issues
>  behind the Los Angeles Riots
>
>"Things are more like they are now than they ever were before."
>  -Former U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower
>
>"A billion here, a billion there, sooner or later it adds up to real
>money."
>  -Everett Dirksen
>
>"A verbal contract isn't worth the paper it's written on."
>  -Samuel Goldwyn
>
>"I don't feel we did wrong in taking this great country away from
>them. There were great numbers of people who needed new land, and the
>Indians were selfishly trying to keep it for themselves."
>  -John Wayne
>
>"Half this game is ninety percent mental."
>  - Philadelphia Phillies manager Danny Ozark
>
>"It isn't pollution that's harming the environment. It's the
>impurities in our air and water that are doing it."
>  -Former U.S. Vice-President Dan Quayle
>
>"Without censorship, things can get terribly confused in the public
>mind."
>  -General William Westmoreland
>
>"What a waste it is to lose one's mind. Or not to have a mind is
>being very wasteful. How true that is."
>  -Former U.S. Vice-President Dan Quayle at a fundraising event for
>  the United Negro College Fund.  He was attempting to quote the line
>  "a mind is a terrible thing to waste"
>
>"If you let that sort of thing go on, your bread and butter will be
>cut right out from under your feet."
>  -Former British foreign minister Ernest Bevin
>
>"I love California. I practically grew up in Phoenix."
>  -Former U.S.  Vice-President Dan Quayle
>
>"I stand by all the misstatements that I've made."
>  -Former U.S. Vice-President Dan Quayle
>

>>>> >

>>>> >

>>>> >

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jan 10 11:17:46 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id LAA22481; Fri, 10 Jan 1997 11:17:46 -0800 (PST)

Received: from ucdata.Berkeley.EDU.ucdt (ucdata.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.165.25]) by nak.berkeley.edu (8.7.3/8.6.10) with SMTP id LAA11202 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 10 Jan 1997 11:17:31 -0800 (PST)
Received: by ucdata.Berkeley.EDU.ucdt (SMI-8.6/SMI-SVR4)
	id LAA02865; Fri, 10 Jan 1997 11:14:54 -0800
Date: Fri, 10 Jan 1997 11:14:53 -0800 (PST)
From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Boozers Do the Town
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9701101013.A2432-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Boozin' Ravers was tons of fun last night!  Though only 3 listers showed 
(the other 15 who told me they were going can start feeling guilty 
right...NOW!), plus a coupla friends and me and K, we made a happy little 
group of superfriendly ravelings.  We'll definitely have to do it 
again... though probably on an occasional basis.  Weekly is too much for a 
9-to-5'er like me.  Though I don't feel as awful as you would think 
right now, at work with a hang-over and not enough sleep!

Now, the review:

Makeout Room
I originally picked it in part because last Saturday night it was 
practically empty, lots of room in a nice bar.  But last night it was 
packed!  Must be a local SF thang.  Thumbs up for the bartenders, serving 
up well-made drinks.

Food Not Bombs 
A nice party for an even nicer cause... and still providing
us a quality party for just $5.  Good work!  An awesome food buffet, live
acts, dj's, fire dancers, and an interesting mix of people.  We were there
around 11:30-1, and there was some experimental/jungle/trance-ish music
for the dancefloor, and a live band ruminating over some dark sounds
upstairs.  Don't know who the djs/artists were, but I do know we missed
DRC and Jon Carel!  :(   Ah well, there's always another party! 

Cesar's was the site of my first real party, Kundalini two years ago, and 
I hadn't been back since.  Returning last night (as an organizer of a 
raver get-together!) was a wonderful closing of a circle... of parties 
and personal growth and experience over the last two years, both because 
of the scene and of my own path... I remember wandering through Cesar's 
that first time, so overwhelmed by all the sights and sounds, how 
everything seemed so odd and alien at first... and wandering through last 
night, but this time knowing that I belonged to the scene and it to me and 
more importantly, that I had learned how to come home to myself... that I 
could dance and talk and laugh last night so easily, without the 
trepidation and uncertainty of the me of a few years ago...

:)

> what will the next 303 be?
> 
> How can more and more of our brothers, sisters, children, and parents 
> make music, find harmony with others, find themselves?
> 
> This list has seen countless posts about what raving is, but I finally 
> understand what it means to me.  It's about the increasingly periodic 
> renneasaunce (sp?) that is rising once again, in our time.  I get to 
> contribute to a positive part of history.
> 
> And I get to share it with all of you.
> 

Just wanted to say thanks for posting this.  What a beautiful idea!  I 
hadn't thought of raving in those terms, as a renaissance of creativity 
and art bubbling up from the masses... but yes, I guess it is!

From: Ann Elizabeth Loraine <anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Message-Id: <199701102134.NAA01190@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: be-in review
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 10 Jan 1997 13:34:23 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The 9th Digital Be-in was the best ever, in my opinion.  (It was actually
the fourth...but who's counting?)

The first one I attended was three years ago at the Fashion Center.
It was great, but the one held last night at the SOMAR gallery topped it.

Why?  Because of the diverse groups that helped out last night.

First off:  Clair (of Gateway) coordinated the "altar room."  The Goa Gals
of CCC (and friends) brought their stunning black light banners and set up
(2?) altars.  The centerpiece of one was a day-glo Buddha statue painted
with fluorescent paints.  There was also an altar called "False Profits"
featuring prints of Tammy-Faye and Jim Baker, flanked by pictures of Jesus
and Mary.  Creepy.

Clair built an altar, too.  The part I liked best on this one was the
beautiful fountain she placed on the floor in front of it.  Maureen set up
her altar next to Claire's- Mo's altar featured a department store dummy
from outer space.  Mo is a champion marbler and decorated her altar with
some fluorescent marbled prints.  (Don't know what marbles are?  check
out:  http://nature.berkeley.edu/~loraine/Marbles for some samples..)

The New Moon was last night, so we were psyched when Clair invited us to
build an altar at the Be-in.  As alwasy, it was a collaboration-between
Gregg, Vanessa (the Minx!), Mona (yes..she's back!) and myself.
Peter-Rachel came with Minx in a stunning outfit.  (Androgeny rules!)
Ronan- the only member of the New Moon group who spins- got to play
the first set in the altar room.   We also had help from Miko, Java
Evangelist.  I asked him to be the New Moon Evangelist for the night, and
so he went around explaining that since the Be-In was (close) to the New
Moon, the Be-In was actually one huge New Moon rave.  Cool.

There were lots of computer folks showing their wares, mingling with many,
many raver-types:  the CCC trance-tribe, some Mad/FnF kids, and also
Gateway.  Jon Carel brought those big blue speakers of his for the main
room's sound system.  And Joe Rice brought his smaller system for the
altar room.

CCC also set up an ambient tent in an open space beside the gallery, and I
spent a while listening to Justin spin some groovy, mellow ambient tunes.
When he started playing Portishead I felt like I had come home.

Suzy and friends manned (womanned) the computer altar in the altar room.
I had loads of fun with the digital camera she loaned me...got to take 16
pictures of altars.  Hope I get to see the pictures soon!

I also met Matt, who managed the web site for the party.  

The organization for this one was impeccable...our New Moon crew got in
for free and was astonished to find lots of yummy food in a back room to
keep us staff-people well-nourished through the night.

Thanks so much to Clair for inviting us to participate!!!!  And for
coordinating so many people.  It's so good to have you back in SF,
sweetie!

Love,

Ann

Hello all Net Ravers, Promoters & DJ's,
	My Name is DJ Hardware and I'm looking for bookings for the months
of December, January, & February and further. I'm The A&R director at
Adrenalin Records in New York but I'm based in South Florida. I currently
have 9 mixed CD's out in stores all across the world and have 3 more
currently being pressed. The following are a list of the CD's:
	-Adrenalin Hardcore Rush Vol 1 
	-Adrenalin Hardcore Rush vol. 2 
	-Trip Hop Acid Phunk Vol 1
	-Trip Hop Acid Phunk Vol 2
	-Trip Hop Acid Phunk Vol 3 : The Hard Edition
	-Electro Phunk Vol 1
	-Beat Generator Vol. 1
	-Acid Warfare Vol. 1
	-House Stompin' Vol. 1

and on the press:
	-DJ Hardware presents The Rhythm Chamber
	-Adrenalin Trance Acid Experience 2 :In The Mix With DJ Hardware
	- Trip Hop Acid Phunk Vol 4: The Acid Breaks Edition

I Also have a 12" currently out with my partner called The tweakers - "All
Tweaked Out" On adrenalin Records. As you can see i play a variety of
styles of music but my favorite styles to play are Hard trance and Gabber.
i also love hard edged funky breaks. If you are intrested in booking me or
know some one intrested in booking me at an event or party please have
them E-mail me or they can call Adrenalin Records at (561) 495 - 9954 or 
(561) 495 - 3919. Thanks for your time and consideration!


						DJ HARDWARE:)
					A&R Director - Adrenalin Records


P.S. : Some people in the past have said that I make royalities of these
CD's, well, I don't. I just make money to mix them and thats all. Also I'm
not tring to SPAM the NET, I'm just using the NET as a resource to find
booking outside florida and to play to different types of ravers. If
you don't like to read this just delete it... This is part of the rave
culture.... PLUR........


				Thanks Again!!

						Hardware:)

Hello all Net Ravers, Promoters & DJ's,
	My Name is DJ Hardware and I'm looking for bookings for the months
of December, January, & February and further. I'm The A&R director at
Adrenalin Records in New York but I'm based in South Florida. I currently
have 9 mixed CD's out in stores all across the world and have 3 more
currently being pressed. The following are a list of the CD's:
	-Adrenalin Hardcore Rush Vol 1 
	-Adrenalin Hardcore Rush vol. 2 
	-Trip Hop Acid Phunk Vol 1
	-Trip Hop Acid Phunk Vol 2
	-Trip Hop Acid Phunk Vol 3 : The Hard Edition
	-Electro Phunk Vol 1
	-Beat Generator Vol. 1
	-Acid Warfare Vol. 1
	-House Stompin' Vol. 1

and on the press:
	-DJ Hardware presents The Rhythm Chamber
	-Adrenalin Trance Acid Experience 2 :In The Mix With DJ Hardware
	- Trip Hop Acid Phunk Vol 4: The Acid Breaks Edition

I Also have a 12" currently out with my partner called The tweakers - "All
Tweaked Out" On adrenalin Records. As you can see i play a variety of
styles of music but my favorite styles to play are Hard trance and Gabber.
i also love hard edged funky breaks. If you are intrested in booking me or
know some one intrested in booking me at an event or party please have
them E-mail me or they can call Adrenalin Records at (561) 495 - 9954 or 
(561) 495 - 3919. Thanks for your time and consideration!


						DJ HARDWARE:)
					A&R Director - Adrenalin Records


P.S. : Some people in the past have said that I make royalities of these
CD's, well, I don't. I just make money to mix them and thats all. Also I'm
not tring to SPAM the NET, I'm just using the NET as a resource to find
booking outside florida and to play to different types of ravers. If
you don't like to read this just delete it... This is part of the rave
culture.... PLUR........


				Thanks Again!!

						Hardware:)

Hi everyone, sorry I'm doing this... but I finally got my Keyboard to work
again!!!
(I bought a new one) I had not been checking my mail/posting since NYE! so
I figured I should make up for that time ;)

12/31/96
New Years Eve 

Eric (250blowpopguy) and I are at work and *we* decide that we are going to
"ORIGIN"... anyhow, I get to "ORIGIN" after driving all the way to SF to
buy a
ticket and come back to note that the party was 'busted'. at 12:00. isn't
that fun?
Anyhow...since Eric was already at the party I figured I should wait for
him since the party got busted... after  1.5 hours, he comes out of
METAMORPHOSIS (the party down the street) and he and his friends decide to
go to another party. Me, all alone and sober on now NY. get to go home and
sleep at 1:00am.  (I asked them if I could go, but they said: "Its not our
house" as 20 other people followed them in their cars....which I took
personally. but then, I got over it... [*sigh*]

Anyhow,
two days went by and I went to Karma III on Fri night... once again, Eric
had decided to go to Karma also..but he ended  up at ALL IN THE FAMILY. 

Karma was cool, there was a weird vibe going on but I was fairly happy
(considering I was sober) there I got to see Lara, Leslie, Aryck,
April...wait a sec. Was KarmaIII before or after NY??? oops!
nevermind....wrong review [*blush*]...

KARMA IV!
Ok..this is the right one...a week after KarmaIV, I went to KARMA V. This
time 
Eric drove me! :-) hehehe...(he didn't get away) basically I made up for
what happened on NYE, I was very happy ( ;o) ) and I got to meet reallly
cool people!
The music was rad! I recognized this song that I have on a CD that was
played
around 4 or so (whoever was DJing around that time rules :P) now I play it
all day...but anyhow, it was nice seeing Leslie, Randy, Rebecca[?], and a
bunch of other SFRavers. I would also like to say thanks to Antonio and
Hope for being so rad and I send hugs to Anthony, Nicole and Kristen (very
rad people I met, that I hope to see at Harmony -if I can get a ticket :P)
and kisses and love to "Mr. Celsius and Ms. Farenheit"...they where really
cool! Also a hug goes to Jonathan and extra love goes
to Becca and Eric even though they dis me often ;o)

Anyhow...I just needed to get that off my system! 
Thank you so much to everyone and sorry for taking up badwidth :o)
I hope to see alot of you at EMINENCE tomorrow night (I was thinking of
Karma5 but I feel like going to a Massive for a change :o)) besides, I want
a free tape! :P

I don't know what I'll be wearing...but I'll probably have my SFraves badge
with me!
so come and say hi and I'll do the same ;o) I have LifeSavers and Stickers
for everyone...

Luv
Pabs

Hmmm.  I don't know.  I absolutely NEVER watch MTV.  The only time I ever see
it is when I get home and my fiancee is watching it (at which point she changes
the channel), or when she flips to it and won't change the channel (at which
point I meander into another room - I'm not exactly sure why it is, but I 
REALLY detest MTV).

Anyway, the point is, I am never in MTV's presence for more than 2 minutes or
so at a time, and that the last two times it has been on, the video being shown
was.......... The Chemical Bros!! (Don't know the name of the song) The first
time was in the evening, the second today, after lunch, so I think it airs
regularly. Maybe some of you (less-fortunate) MTV watchers could confirm this ;)

Thinking about how when it first went on the air, I was one of the loudest
proclaiming how it would shape music for the better,
-mike

It's not just MTV that is changing their format to shift away from
alternative/rap (although the two still get the lion's share of
airtime). But the music industry in general is lagging. The big labels
and mainstream retailers are looking for a new musical genere(sp?). I've
read one article about this in TIME, one in the Wall Street Journal
(what, don't YOU read it? :P) and a few others that don't come to mind.
All of the articles mentioned Trip-Hop and Jungle as the early
contenders.

Maybe I just haven't been reading enough SFR postings, and this has
already been disussed, but to me, this sounds like a BIG DEAL! What
these indicators are pointing at is the very real posibilty that some
types of Electronic Dance Music may go MAINSTREAM! I have no idea.
however, what I should think of this. Is this a good thing? Or will the
music become generic and watered down and played out? Anyone have
thoughts on this?

-=Pengo=-
Blake "Pengo" Merriam
TOTAL ENTERTAINMENT NETWORK
WWW.TEN.NET

"The trouble with avant garde music is that it has lost its original
meaning and now has as many rules and clichs as country or rock & roll.
If in 50 years time they will look back at the early 1980s, or whenever,
and say that was the new avant garde era, that event must be avoided if
we are to remain true." - William Bennett

From: Ishak <ishak@faludi.com>

>On Fri, 10 Jan 1997 Jonathan_Dejano@Interactive.sony.com wrote:

>> this is just a rumor...  I heard that sometime in the near future, MTV will
>> change their music format from the crap that's on right now to a more dance
>> oriented flavor.

>>Just a thought, but some of the "crap" that is on now, came from some
>>really good underground scenes 5 or 10 years ago. Do you really think mass
>>exposure of the music via MTV is really a good thing?
>
>
>                                      Black Adder

i believe this to be an interesting question.  
--does the MTV projection of musical format and culture to the mainstream 
make our country an overall better place to be?

recently, i heard a discussion somewhere about how the major labels have 
a love-hate relationship with MTV because as they do need MTV's 
international delivery, it also pushes the envelope to quickly.  the 
labels can't sign the bands before they become stale and overplayed.  
and, as late night video appearances by aphex twin and chemical brothers 
suggest, MTV is poised to lead our youth to the latest scene,  what they 
don't get is that our musical youth are two steps ahead of even the djs , 
and mega corporations like MTV are always gonna be playin' catch up.  the 
lines between madison avenue and mtv seem to be blurring anyways.  and 
its the advertisers that are required to stay superfresh.  whatever the 
marketing department wants seems to be key factor determining airplay.  
yet, MTV serves our societal function of communicating the collective 
unconscience of today's youth demographic to mainstream.  and, these 
switches are inevitable if not double-edged.

thanx for the bandwidth.
~ishak


-o----=----o-------=------o------=------o-------=o=-------o-=-
If Necessity is the Mother of all Invention,
Then Conservation should be the Child of ReInvention.

                                      Ishak Kang   <ishak@faludi.com>

An opinion.

There will always be a mainstream.

There will always be an underground of purer artistic expression.

I look forward to a time when the mainstrean is as demanding of honest 
artistic integrity as the underground is.  When the emphasis is not on 
who's the biggest star, but does everyone learn to shine.

peace

deeje

In-Reply-To: <199701110116.RAA24808@scv3.apple.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.ULT.3.93.970110194433.22757A-100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk


	Yeah, either tragically or happily, depending on your point
of view, techno's about to explode and go mainstream here in the states,
as it's already done in Europe/the UK.  MTV is going to start showing
such 'techno-inflected' (their word, not mine) videos as those by Orbital,
Prodigy, Underworld, et al.  Apparently, no one's really into Seattle
grunge much any more, gangsta rap has seen its day, 'alternative' music
is no longer such, and, as pop music has always looked for something new,
now it's looking for the energy of rave, techno, and jungle.  U2's new
record, for instance, is heavily influenced by techno, and they've brought
a DJ on board, and their new video for 'Discotheque' is totally ravey.
And have you seen those Microsoft commercials w/ the techno soundtrack?
The 'this way to the internet' ones?  Really strange.  I know what 95
percent of us ravers will say to all this--"OH MY GOD! NO WAY!
CORPORATIONS CASHING IN ON OUR VIBE!  KEEP IT UNDERGROUND!" and I'm
inclined to agree.  MTV techno won't be half as cool as what we're lucky
enough to know, I know, but at the same time, how many of us have said, "I
wish the rest of the world could understand the beauty and magic of our
music and scene"?  
Now, I know that when most of us think that, we're not thinking along the
lines of MTV videos and television commercials, but this *is* the
proverbial mainstream we're talking about; there has to be some
give-and-take, I guess. 

best,
Timothy

Subject: Psychiatric Hotline

Date:    1/10/97 10:24 AM
     
     
Hello.  Welcome to the Psychiatric Hotline.
     
If you are obsessive-compulsive, please press 1 repeatedly.
     
If you are codependent, please ask someone to press 2.
     
If you have multiple personalities, please press 3,4,5, and 6.
     
If you are paranoid-delusional, we know who you are and we know what you 
want; just stay on the line so we can trace the call.
     
If you are schizophrenic - listen carefully - and a little voice will 
tell you which number to press.
     
If you are manic-depressive, it doesn?t matter which number you press, no 
one will answer.
     
If this is an emergency and you require the care and guidance of a 
highly-skilled, trained professional, you are out of luck because they were 
all cut back or forced out.  However, if you are willing to hold, one of 
our cross-trained, multi-skilled, team members will be happy to serve you 
as best as they can after he or she gets finished scrubbing the floor.

	-- C A P R I C O R N --

the santa cruz weekly, was absolutely PATHETIC & sucked imesnsly... why?

	1)  somebody was ripping off people's stuff (there were in/outs galor)
	    and madame mercury's down jacket was stolen right before us
	
	2)  we later approached 'eric' (lead promoter) about da obvious problem
	    and totally yelled & disrespected me about responsiblity!!!
	    i was only offering some constructive criticism and was completely
	    belittled as an idiot.  i could not believe his nerve and didnt
	    apreciate it ONE bit. 

  	3)  two black lights & a radioshack strobe for lighting (whatever)
	    my dorm room has better lighting

	4)  dj up on stage away from the dance floor, no watching da gods
	
	5)  the building's heating ducts were on full blast & windows closed
	    and the promoters refused to do anyting, that was rediculous.

	6)  and finally the "party" ended at 1am, what the hell? 

____BOTTOM LINE______
	chargin $5 bucks for 3 & half hours of crappy Retro Bouncy club 
	    house music, to get our stuff stolen my some santa cruz wannabe
	gangster, to sweat standing still in the poorly lit room, and to
	    be totally bitched & yelled at for NO reason ....

	has led me to NEVER RETURN... i haven't had such a SHITTY night 
"raving" in a L O N G time.   i've never "anti-promoted" before but going 
to "CRAP-ricorn" on any upcoming friday night  WOULD NOT BE A RECOMENDATION
							OF MINE.

   *****sorry for all the negatvity here, but i needed to express this***** 
			pEEs, luV, uNitE   LiQuiD

			SEE YALL AT EMINENCE!  (it will be better i know it)

Subject: future of the scene
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I've been reading all the posts about how techno music will become
mainstream and raves won't be as fun as they were before. What all the
people that are dedicated to the cause need to do is to dig deeper to find
new artists, new horizons, the sell out is unavoidable, but we have to
remember that the people who decide what music we have to listen to and
what videos we watch are after the almighty dollar, to them techno music is
nothing more than a fad, but we have to remember that WE have a big role in
how things will end up because WE have the power, WE have money in our
pockets and if we don't like what thay are stuffing down our throats we can
say "fuck-off" the money stays in my pocket. Let them find a new way to
make cash. Of course there is a positive side that many people will find a
new type of  music that will soothe their soul and help them find the
person on the inside they really are.

Late

--------------------------------PeterTews/Vontews@dnai.com----------------------

>         Naked dancers juggling fire (I'm sorry folks, there
>         just isn't anything in the world that raises the
>         energy level of a party like *naked dancers juggling
>         fire*) ...

LOL!  That cracked me up!

>         Willie Brown & Jerry Brown were both there ...
>         It didn't get busted (surprise) ...

Way back when, I put out a message to the effect that what we needed to
do was cater to Willie Brown's ego if we wanted to stop the rave busts. 
Now I suggest we start a rave series called  "Willie For Mayor" or
"Willie's Ravers" or "Heya come Da Mayor!", something to that effect.  A
very small portion of the proceeds would go towards Willie's reelection
campaign fund.

For those of you that thought having a gleefully corrupt politician as
the mayor was a good thing, I'm sure you'll agree that playing the
politics game and "greasing the political machine" (I seem to recall
those as being John S. Lee's words) is the best way to ensure that raves
stop getting busted.

Comments?

S

i think that MTV going in that direction is a good thing, as a lotta MTV
viewers will explore the scene because it'll be the "in" thing to do. i

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

hello,

well, being new to the bay area, the be-in was my first taste of what
this
new place is like. i must say, it was great!

the computer exposwere kinda cool, too bad they didnt have any extra
silicon
graphics hats left. :(

the main room with the lasers was really setup well. i really liked the
color wheels. i have to get
one of those, does anyone know of any stores that sell them? i was
thinking of making one, it doesnt look that hard.

the chill out room was cool too. i dont know the name of the dj that was
spinning, but the set was good. the decorations were excellent, and the
"altars" reminded me of my friend from india's house.

by far, the best were the live performances.  the first group of live
performers with the one man
playing the aboriginal instrument was really good. the fire dancers
added a really good flair to the whole experience. what is their name? i
need to get their cd if they have any.

i love this place :)
--
Bryan Schwab Application Engineer NetGravity, Inc.
415-655-4201 Pager:1-888-719-2949 Email: bschwab@netgravity.com

31st, here in San Luis Obispo.  WE are looking for a dj or two that

From: Austin Woffington <awoffing@tuba.aix.calpoly.edu>
To: I_wanna_Dance! <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Mixed Tape Reviews MODA, StarEyes, S. Hardkiss others..
Message-Id: <Pine.A32.3.91.970111144146.68832E@tuba.aix.calpoly.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hey all 

I wanted to post this cuz I got alot of new music over the break and I 
thought I would share.  

MODA posted about his new mixed tape a while back and I just got it last 
week but i haven't stopped listening to it.  Great progressive house/trance 
for 
chillin or doing homework or even getting your late night groove on.  
Thanks Moda for the tape I love it!

I also got StarEyes Ruffage in the mail.  I haven't listend to it to much 
cuz my roommate hates jungle and makes me turn it off when ever he comes 
home.  I just started listening to Jungle alot more and I like this 
tape.  It's got the fugee's mix on it...

I also got a DeiselBoy and Corbin tape which is more goood jungle but not 
as hard as the Ruffage tape.  There are more ambient/jungel tracks in 
this one.

Scott Hardkiss - i think it's called YES.  It's a copy of a copy. More 
good progressive.  Strange, delitful, and soothing house and progressive.

Doc Martain.  I got several of his tapes over the break.  "Flamable 
Liquid", "Unlock the House Part 2  12/5/95", and "Unlock the House 3/26/96".
The "ULH 3-26-96" is phat!  I love absolutly every song in this mix.  All 
of Doc's favorits are on this.  Sorry i'm bad with track names but I know 
all of you will recognize 80% of the tracks on this tape.  Too bad my 
copy is so shitty.  If anyone has a good copy of this mixed tape (Unlock 
the House 3-26-96) please let me know I would like to get a better copy.

Also I got a deep house tape called INHUMAN - "Return to the Deep City"
Good house grooves, disco type riffs with some waling diva choons.. I 
haven't listen to it all but I got it on sale for 5 bucks and it was 
worth it. 

I also got Dj Dan's new cd Loose Caboose.  My aunt gave me a Warehouse 
gift certificate so I got this and the WIPEOUT XL compelation.  The Dan 
disc is very good but on a few mixes they sound too perfect.  Ya know?  
Like you could tell they were studio mixed.  I prefer the live tapes but 
this is a good mix for the mainstream america.  Not as hard as I would 
like Dan to be.  

The WIPEOUT XL compelation has tracks by Chemical Brothers, FSOL, 
Leftfield, Underworld, Prodigy, umm and more.  Many jungle tracks.  i 
like Leftfield's Afro Ride and the Chemical Brothers.  Some crazy jungle 
tracks on this one too -  It's good to piss off your roommate some times 
hheee hee.  :)

Hmm I got some other cool records and tapes too but I havne't had a 
chance to get into them much enough. I've said enough anyways...

PLUR,

       Austin

        ------------------(   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )-----------------

Received: from uclink2.berkeley.edu (uclink2.berkeley.edu [128.32.136.72]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.8.4/8.6.12) with ESMTP id PAA29360; Sat, 11 Jan 1997 15:45:39 -0800 (PST)

From: Timothy McIntyre <sidewalk@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
To: SDream <SDream@tgrigsby.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: "The revolution will not be televised"
In-Reply-To: <32D7FDC0.7D7C@tgrigsby.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.ULT.3.93.970111145308.20153A-100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>

  Yeah!! I wholeheartedly agree--I mean c'mon, sure, Willie Brown has his
faults, as do all human beings, but on a very practical level, he's pretty
cool, and he's about as supportive of the underground scene as a
politician can publicly be w/out running the risk of alienating his
mainstream consituency.  His son is a DJ, I've been told, and he
understands what the scene is about, and, well, he is in a position to
enact positive change in terms of the civic perception of our community. 

  I dont know if campaign contributions are something I agree with, but
perhaps more raves for political causes, where a portion of the proceeds
is donated to a political organization?  Like what food not bombs is
doing, for instance.  I think it'd be great to go to a political rave: 
Imagine the energy level that would produce!  Everyone dancing away in the
spirit of bringing about social change.  *And* it would give ravers more
credibility when we tell our skeptics that we rave to bring about a better
world.  That's what San Francisco is known for, and we ravers could be the
catalyst/flashpoint for the fusion between the political and technological
changes that this country is undergoing right now!  

  Look at the facts: More free-thinking liberals are in power than ever
  before in American history--Clinton's got *12* Berkeley professors
  working for him, for goodness' sake!  That's incredible!

  Techno/Dance/Rave/Our Music is about to blow up globally.  It's gonna
  be huge, like it or not.  That time is now--look around, the music's
  all over the place!

  The San Francisco Bay Area is the epicenter of the digital renaissance:
  it's ground zero, it's where everything's coming from.  This is the 
  petri dish for life in the 21st century; everything's getting tested
  right here and now.  Nowhere else do people swap email addresses like
  phone numbers, or carry pagers as they do wallets. We're so far ahead of
  everything else, it's dizzying. And the rest of the world is watching
  SF, seeing what will happen here.  The spotlight is on us--so we should
  dance harder!  And whio understands all this technology?  *Young* 
  people--us.  Advancements in technology are finally bringing about the
  idea of a global community, and we're the torchbearers.

So, I know there will be a tendency by a lot of us in the coming months to
dismiss the mainstream, but in one respect, we should be flattered.  I 
mean, it's sort of cute--all these big, stumbling companies and
politicians, trying to figure out what the heck is going on out here, and
they're all scratching their heads.  The mainstream is knocking on our
door, and the big question will be, are we going to turn our backs on them
or are we going to lead and show them all that we know?  

I think we should be proud, and make ourselves heard. This is the time,
more so than ever before.  We've got the mic!  And the turntables! 

It's just been frustrating for me recently, when I keep noticing/thinking
that we really are on the verge of an enormous cultural breakthrough, and
that we have so much power, but no one seems to notice or be very
interested in it.  I mean come on!  Throughout history, for good
or bad, different points on the globe have had the spotlight--Rome had it,
England had it, China had it, Germany had it, etc. etc., and now, in 1997,
there is no place on earth which will have more significance in
determining what life will be like in the next 25 years than San
Francisco does.  How cool is that?! 

"Change the world!!  Change the world!!  Change the world!!"  

best,
Timothy

And you must remember too that you can say "fuck-off" to THIS industry
that treats it simply as a fad, to which they suck off as much money
as they can; i.e. the major record labels.  The problem being that
all the majors own sub-labels and sub-labels of sub-labels, that it
can become hard to know who's who.  So if this is a concern, simply
ask your friendly music proprietor and they should be able to help.
I guess then you can help keep the integrity in making music at it's
maximum.

> how things will end up because WE have the power, WE have money in our

I suggest you travel more.

> So, I know there will be a tendency by a lot of us in the coming months to

> mean, it's sort of cute--all these big, stumbling companies and
> politicians, trying to figure out what the heck is going on out here, and
> they're all scratching their heads.  The mainstream is knocking on our
> door, and the big question will be, are we going to turn our backs on them
> or are we going to lead and show them all that we know?  

No, people are going to welcome them with open arms, they will come in
to the house, rummage around a bit, walk out with the T.V. and go down to
the local pawn shop and sell it. They will then come back for the
computer, the V.C.R., and every other thing of value, until they have
played your house *out*. Then they will move on to the next house. Why,
given the repeated history of this occuring is it so hard to believe? You
are dealing with people that operate in a totally seperate paridigm:
"Peace, Love, Unity, Respect, uh, yeah how much is all that stuff worth,
and how can I use it to sell tee-shirts?" 

> It's just been frustrating for me recently, when I keep noticing/thinking
> that we really are on the verge of an enormous cultural breakthrough, and
> that we have so much power, but no one seems to notice or be very
> interested in it.  

It has all been done before. If people really hope to suceed this time, a
different approach is required.


> I mean come on!  Throughout history, for good
> or bad, different points on the globe have had the spotlight--Rome had it,
> England had it, China had it, Germany had it, etc. etc., and now, in 1997,
> there is no place on earth which will have more significance in
> determining what life will be like in the next 25 years than San
> Francisco does.  How cool is that?! 

Again, try getting out more. The scene is already old-hat in England and
most of Europe, along with the playing of Techno on MTV. These people are
not behind us. It is we that are playing catch-up in many regards.

                                       Black Adder


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Jan 11 20:52:20 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id UAA06233; Sat, 11 Jan 1997 20:52:20 -0800 (PST)
Received: from deepthought.armory.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id UAA06222; Sat, 11 Jan 1997 20:52:05 -0800 (PST)
Date: Sat, 11 Jan 1997 20:51:50 -0800 (PST)
From: Leonardo <wizard@armory.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: On music
In-Reply-To: <32D843C2.48D9@internity.on.ca>
Message-ID: <Pine.SCO.3.91.970111183645.25410A-100000@deepthought.armory.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

With all the discussions on the future of music floating around,
I really felt like reaching out...

To me, the beauty of music is the combined enjoyment of those who make 
the music and those who dance/trance/smile/cry to the music.  They're not 
two different sides.. everyone indulges in listening to the magical 
sounds that we call music.. everyone has their own trips, their own 
passions and desires that shape who they are how they interact with
the music.

When I began embracing new types of music and new cultures, I felt
that the greatest role of music was to provide a medium through which
people could share their passions, at least at the subconscious level.
For the first time in my life, I saw the conscious purpose of making music
to be *expression*, not impressing others.  The idea seemed so
fulfilling to me, that I decided to let music shape my life more than
ever before.  I gave up my computer science career/studies/future at
MIT because it had nothing to offer in comparison with following my
passions.  Money, fame, admiration.. it all seemed horribly empty
compared with the lust I had found for music.

Coming back to Santa Cruz, I rediscovered the other half of music I
had felt at age ten while drumming with others on the beach:  *listening*.
I saw (actually, I heard) how in drum circles, the more I listened to
the music, the more the music seemed to listen to me.  Euphoric.. that's
how I felt when I stopped thinking of music, and of the world as a whole,
as input vs. output, me vs. them, playing vs. listening.. not that I had
seen these as opposing sides, yet at best they had always been two
different sides working together.  Now they are one and the same to me..
unified manifestations of a bigger picture.  Not just a "collective
unconscious".. more like a collective conscious, a collective BEING.

Integration in every form is divine (too bad I didn't think that way
in Calculus class).. wouldn't it be awesome if cops and ravers, kids
and adults, tradition and technology, anger and peace..  all came
together to work in harmony?  Maybe it's best not set them apart
from the beginning..

Hi, this is Libby.  I've only posted once before.  For those of you who I
don't know yet, I'm about 5'3.  I have long, dirty-blonde hair.  I can
usually be found bouncing around parties wearing a big smile and lots of
glitter.  Hmmm, sounds like a lot of the ravers out there.  Anyway...

My mother and I have a really good friendship, but I've always felt like
we could be closer.  I moved out in October, because she said as long as
I lived with her I wasn't allowed to go to parties.  (I'm 19, by the way,
so I though she was being a little unreasonable.)  Ever since then, I've
been trying to convince my mom to go to a party with me.  I really want
to share myself and my experiences with her.  It took a lot of
convincing, but she finally said yes!  She's even going to bring a
"date".

Now, here's the problem.  I know my mom has an idea about what goes on at
raves, but I don't think she knows the full extent of it.  I'm really
excited that she's agreed to go to a party with me.  I just don't want
her to die of shock as soon as she gets there!  She's a musician, so
nothing can shock her (so she says).  Still, I want to make she she and
her friend are properly prepared for what they're going to experience.

So, what should I do to prepare my mom?  Can anybody out there offer me
some advice on how to handle this situation?  How about all you
parents/grown adults out there who go to parties?  Also, how about all
you "kids" who have taken your parents to parties with you?

I do plan to have a talk about raving with my mom and her friend, prior
to the party.  I do plan to tell her that I take drugs at these parties. 
I do not plan on taking drugs at the party.  My mom tried drugs when she
was younger, but she's totally against them, now.  When she found out all
the drugs I'd "tried", she flipped out!  She gets upset if she thinks I
smoked pot.  She would never try e.  A lot of people who have never done
e say that people who are xing look really scary.  I don't want to scar
my mom for life.  I just want to have fun with her and show her a world
where people are geniunely friendly and people are united by music and
love.  She's had a tough life, and I want her to see that there is hope. 
I think the rave scene could really open her up.

I would really appreciate any advice anyone can offer.

Also, what would be a good party for my mom's first time?  PLEASE TELL ME
THERE'S A LEPIDOPTERA COMING UP!  My mom knows the kids who throw it, so
that would be really cool!  Besides, anyone who goes to Lepidoptera for
their first party is spoiled, spoiled, spoiled ;)

>What exactly is an "e"? And why are people taking
>drugs to have a good time? I don't feel that drugs
>are what really make a rave or party fun. I think
>it is, in fact, the unity and love between each
>person there. I don't understand why people use
>drugs, but hey, people have their own opinions on
>things. Peace.
>
>     Cody Kime
>
>

Drugs are NOT necessary in order to have fun.  I'll admit that I have fun
when I'm on drugs, but I also have a lot of fun when I'm sober.  Drugs
can open up new worlds for people.  They can help people open up to
themselves and others.

I know a guy who used to be so painfully shy that he had almost no
friends, because he couldn't open up to people.  One night, he tried e
(ecstacy) and it helped him get rid of his inhibitions.  That night, he
opened up to himself.  Then he had this revelation: if he could open up
like that while he was on e, why couldn't he do it when he was sober?

Now that guy, a good friend of mine, has friends, a girlfriend, and a lot
of confidence.  He is finally happy.  Ecstacy helped him open up to the
world.  Some people don't need drugs to do that for them.  I fully
respect that.  I just hope non-drug-users can respect the choices that I
make for myself.

---Libby :)

>are what really make a rave or party fun. I think

drugs are not at parties to make it fun. of course you 

will find drug use anywhere, and anywhere you find drug use,

you find drug abuse. the most prominent drugs found at parties

hold properties that can enhance spiritual, emotional, and

inter-personal connections/relationships. of course, whether

or not they are used for this purpose and not just to get fucked

up or to have fun is completely up to the person who decides to 

take the drugs in the first place. drugs are not for everyone.

just as some people don't understand why others go to church, or 

why some people like pepsi while they like coca-cola, i agree...

everyone *is* entitled to their own opinion. just don't look down 

on those people whose opinion contradicts yours.

Cody Kime wrote:
>What exactly is an "e"?=20

"e" is "everything" that makes a party

>And why are people taking
>drugs to have a good time? I don't feel that drugs
>are what really make a rave or party fun. I think
>it is, in fact, the unity and love between each
>person there. I don't understand why people use
>drugs, but hey, people have their own opinions on
>things. Peace.

drugs are not at parties to make it fun. of course you=20
will find drug use anywhere, and anywhere you find drug use,
you find drug abuse. the most prominent drugs found at parties
hold properties that can enhance spiritual, emotional, and
inter-personal connections/relationships. of course, whether
or not they are used for this purpose and not just to get fucked
up or to have fun is completely up to the person who decides to=20
take the drugs in the first place. drugs are not for everyone.
just as some people don't understand why others go to church, or=20
why some people like pepsi while they like coca-cola, i agree...
everyone *is* entitled to their own opinion. just don't look down=20
on those people whose opinion contradicts yours.

> From: libbyrose@juno.com (Libby Bundsen)
> Date: Sun, 12 Jan 1997 01:16:56 EST

[snippies]

> 
> I would really appreciate any advice anyone can offer.
> 
> Also, what would be a good party for my mom's first time?  PLEASE TELL ME
> THERE'S A LEPIDOPTERA COMING UP!  My mom knows the kids who throw it, so
> that would be really cool!  Besides, anyone who goes to Lepidoptera for
> their first party is spoiled, spoiled, spoiled ;)
> 

Libby, keep in mind that the impressions she will form will depend
upon where you take her. For example, there are certain parties that
people will more likely to be on all sorts of drugs than other
parties. For example, Harmony parties (as much as I love them), are
filled with tons more E than something like a Frequency 8 event. The
kind of music and the kind of event typically dictates the type and
the quantity of drugs people will use.

Jungle and Goa parties seem to have the least amount of (noticeable!)
drug use. Not that it doesn't go on; it's just not as noticeable
as people on E.

Maybe a weekly like Mad or Audio Impact would be a good place to break
your mom in. Typically people do significantly less drugs during the
week (I would hope! :); yet the music is still really good, and many
of your friends will be there.

Steve

Paul Hayden FUZZY PANTS wrote:

Hi everyone, this is Paul. I feel sad.

Paul (and anyone else wishing they were elsewhere),

Cheer up.. there can be much more to life than being at raves.  Thing of
the greatest things a rave ever brought you, and think of other ways to
get it.  That way, when you're home, or somewhere else.. instead of
wishing you were at a rave you can find something else to do and enjoy
it in the same way.  The next time you're at a rave, you'll love it even
more.. paying more attention to what it is you really like.

Heck.. earlier I was wishing I had gone out tonight.. and it turned into
one of the greatest nights I've ever had.. playing with sound with much
love and philosophy.

I think it's great that you're tying to share another part of you with
your mother.  I think a good way to do if you're seeing it as a bridge
being crossed by people on opposite sides.. it's not horribly important
who goes how far how fast, or whether or not they end up in the middle..
as long as when they meet the bridge isn't there anymore.  So instead of
struggling with trying to see things the way she would see them, or
having her try to see things the way you would... just think of the rave
as something that you and your mother are both exploring and indulging
in, both in your own ways.

It's great to find something that unites you with her, be it the music,
the people, the dancing.. something you will both enjoy at the initial
plane.  Then branch out knowing that you're both enjoying different
things in the same way, and the same things in different ways.. and
although you are each following your own passions, you have found one
more thing to enjoy together.. to live together.. you've added it to the
list of facets of your life (and facets of you in life) that you and
your mother can go through together.  Wasn't that, after all, the
intention?  Besides.. that's a big part of what the rave culture is
about.. or of what the rave culture can bring.

Taking "E" is not recommended for all shy people.
"E" can make some people even more shy. 
: 
: I know a guy who used to be so painfully shy that he had almost no
: friends, because he couldn't open up to people.  One night, he tried e
: (ecstacy) and it helped him get rid of his inhibitions.  That night, he
: opened up to himself.  Then he had this revelation: if he could open up
: like that while he was on e, why couldn't he do it when he was sober?
:

	You must be referring to MDMA, also known as ecstasy or "e."  Some
people use it as a catalyst to unlock the doors that society or personal
situations have constructed within them to prevent them from pouring out
their light and love, and from sharing their hearts, minds, and souls with
others.  After all, this is the land of the almighty $$, and that sort of
behavior isn't in the spirit thereof; it may even discourage people from
the mind-set of greed and encourage goodwill and charity (heaven forbid!).
	No, "drugs" aren't necessary to self-exploration and awareness, but
sometimes they help where other catalysts cannot.  It all depends on the
person.  To paraphrase Shakespear, "The party's the thing."  It's just
natural that, within a social event such as a party, people will do things
they want to do that they can't do just about anywhere else.  Hope this
helps!
Peace,
Eric

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


:
: I know a guy who used to be so painfully shy that he had almost no
: friends, because he couldn't open up to people.  One night, he tried e
: (ecstacy) and it helped him get rid of his inhibitions.  That night, he
: opened up to himself.  Then he had this revelation: if he could open up
: like that while he was on e, why couldn't he do it when he was sober?
:      

	This is a pretty classic example of using a drug in a positive
way. It can show you a side of yourself you maybe didn't know was there.
If you like what you see, then you *do the work* to get to that same 
space *without the drug*. 

	One of the many traps associated with drug use, though, is to
decide, "Well, it's too hard, and besides, I'm not sure I want to
be like that all the time, so I'll just keep using the drug to get there
when I want to."  Trouble ahead for you if you're doing this ...
remember ...

	By the way, drugs can also show you sides of yourself that you 
didn't know were there and that you won't like at all. And you can also 
do work on these things *when you're not using* if you can *be honest 
about it*.

Happy Sunday Everyone!
  well, i guess it's about time that i introduce myself (especially =
since i want to talk about the party i went to last night!)
  my name is mac (like the truck without the "k"), i'm blond, blue-eyed =
(a girl) and happy to be alive right now!  i've been going to parties =
since september?...my awesome friend  matt davison (also new to sfraves) =
took me to 215 and then to F8...i've been hooked since then. thanks =
matthew!  i've been so amazed at the awesome people i meet and how darn =
friendly everyone is...it's good to know that there are others like me.  =
i'm one of those people that walks through the grocery store and when =
people look at me, i smile, and then i get no reaction back...anyway i'm =
just thrilled that i do get something back at parties.  enough about =
me....
  so i went to the Janus Project last night with my darlin' Anthony and =
a great friend (Jeremy)...mainly to check out the sac scene and when we =
finally got inside i was impressed.  but it didn't start out that way.  =
we found the mapint....price club parking lot..EEK!  and there were 3 or =
4 cop cars parked by a single car in the lot.  GREAT!  but we finally =
got where the location was (they were now selling tix at the door) and =
went inside.  the first thing i noticed was how NICE AND COOL it was =
inside.  major props for that!  the housey toonage was T-riffic.  the =
2nd dj? whose name i have no idea about was great... a little scratchin =
on the turntable and i'm impressed.  i was getting seriously tired but =
then john howard came on and bam! i hopped up to the front of the dj =
"altar" (shame shame) and got my groove again. =20
  anyway i was surprised but glad to see a cool party like that in =
sac...ohh, i met the guy who threw the party, but forgot his name if =
anyone could direct me toward him i'd be much obliged. =20
  sorry for the drawn out not so technically correct reveiw, but just =
thought i'd share my thoughts...hope everyone has a lovely relaxing =
sunday afternoon.
                                                                         =
                  much love-
                                                                         =
           mac

At 10:41 PM 1/11/97 -0800, you wrote:
>What exactly is an "e"? And why are people taking
>drugs to have a good time?

"E" stands for EDUCATION!!!! People who want to have a *really* good time at
raves bring BOOKS to parties! The classics mostly...G.W.T.W., or M.D., or
P.T.M.D. (Gone with the wind, Moby Dick, and Puff the Magic Dragon
respectively for those of you not up with the "Ravers high on E-ducation"
club)...I don't know how it all started but now it's totally out of
control!! Maybe it's the laser lighting that helps people absorb more....or
just the right amount of smiles to stimulate ideal amounts of vasopressin
release in the brain creating lasting memory, or...it could be just the
quiet, relaxing, easy to concentrate in atmosphere. I'm not really sure. One
really cool thing did happen to me a few weeks back tho, I met a
fellow-bookworm-raver that knew all the words to my favorite book, well, ok
fine... it's actually a booklet ok....you know that consumer's free
information guide from Pueblo, Colorado...that sh!t is dope! The ending is
the best part tho....you know the part when the leading male gets into it
with that one Tony Montana sounding dude from the DMV 'cause he's
confused...... "Firs, ju get de permit, den, ju take de test, den, ju getta
de license", Wait!....Whoa! almost spoiled it.... 



Steve 

Uhhhh.....huh...huh

ok, sorry (again) about the grateful dead tie-in, although it always seems
to me there's an appropriate quote for everything (if you get confused,
just listen to the music play)

last night, another west oakland "rave" was shut down by the cops at about
1 am, even though it was at someone's house, there was little if any
publicity (just a word-of-mouth phone #), there was no one else in the
neighborhood to be bothered by the not-so-loud noise, the place wasn't that
crowded or unsafe, and the cops didn't seem to find anything wrong in their
flashlight walk-through -- although someone did say the cops said something
about underage drinking.  I saw one youngish person at about midnight
walking through the party with a 6-pack of Red Nectar Ale, and a couple of
older folk sipping some beer, but very sparse -- indeed, the party was
somewhat lacking in all substances.

I asked one policeman why the party was being shut down and he said
"couldn't tell you," which to me sums up the problem.

We've gone on and on about this, and it's time to figure out what to do
(suggestion # 1 -- no more UG Oakland raves until we get some
clarification). I really want to know what went on last night, and what
justification cops have for shutting down a party in someone's HOUSE, no
matter how warehouse-y the place and rave-y the party.  Don't they need a
warrant to enter a private residence, or is volume and a party enough of an
excuse (or did they get informed consent from the owner)?   Would the cops
have busted my parents growing up because they let me have alcohol with
dinner before I was of age and listen to music loud with friends over?
What if I asked my friends for "donations"?

Enough talking about talking about doing something.

leftjab

after a rather intense period of dating, my girlfriend and i were talking
about getting married.  why am i so happy?  because on our last
conversation, we really solidified that promise to each other, that we do
want to stay together for the rest of our lives.

no rings yet, we still need to get through grad school together before we
set a date, and that's a while.

anyone ever have that feeling when you know you have met a complete
soulmate?  not just a good friend, a close friend, a person you can a lot of
things about yourself, but a complete soulmate?  well, i have, and suddenly
the world just seems a bit nicer.

some of you have met her, and those who have know that she is perfect for me.

well, now that i have such joy, if you need some, take some of it because i
have much to spare!!!!!

love to you all, and a wonderfully cloudy sunday-

last night, i let myself get talked into going to a rave that i knew was
going to suck.  i can't remember what it was called, but it was in a "home
base" warehouse in oakland, near the airport.

the music was good, but there was no energy there.  the people were there
because they knew that raves were cool, and this was a good alternative to
the palladium.

so here's why i knew it was going to suck:

1.  price over $15.

2.  capacity over 400.

3.  expensive flyers.

4.  celebrity djs.

5.  info-lines in more than one area code.

can anyone add to this list?

raves have become very mainstream and so have all the problems and lameness
of any mainstream club like the palladium.  i find that if i'm not very
selective about which rave i go to, it's really bad.

e

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Jan 12 16:17:40 1997

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 12 Jan 1997 16:16:27 -0800
To: libbyrose@juno.com (Libby Bundsen)
From: brat <jenn@cloudfactory.org>
Subject: Re: Please help me!
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>So, what should I do to prepare my mom?  Can anybody out there offer me
>some advice on how to handle this situation?  How about all you
>parents/grown adults out there who go to parties?  Also, how about all
>you "kids" who have taken your parents to parties with you?

	Well, I am one of those "kids". I think you and many others out
there may remember this incident... I know some of you were even frightened
by this, those of you that know them that is. But I took the old parental
units to the Harmony 3 year. I was in much the same situation as you for a
long time until it finally got to the point where I was sick of sneaking
around and worrying that I couldn't get out to do a party... and to say the
least, keeping giant fuzzy flowers and painting banners at home was really
hard to explain. So, I showed them my millions of pictures from parties
I've been to for the past several years, but tryied to focus more on the
ones I've been involved with. They didn't get it at first and thought we
were just throwing parties, not huge "business" like productions with
*real* budgets, contracts, permits, etc. They didn't understand what goes
into it until I took them to one.
	Anyhow, I think I lucked out because I was able to introduce them
to a party that I was involved with. This way they understood that I wasn't
just out to party all night. I was trying to do something and create
something that was important to me. They were totally amazed, to say the
least, that us "kids" could put on a production like that.  You should
consider taking her to a party that you are involved with... like the one
on the 25th... you're still involved right? Just have her there during set
up and the first few hours of the night. Let her see all the planning,
effort and love that goes into it. Just remember to warn your friends
involved to be discreet with "things" the may want to do. This way the
won't see too much of the drug use, if that's what most scares you. Just be
completely open and give them the tour of their lives!!!
	If this is still too sketchy even... I agree with Steve. Just
choose your party wisely. There are a lot of parties out there that seem to
be notorious for drug usage. I think a great place to start her off would
be Mad. It's a club, but it still has the key elements of a really good
"rave" except it lacks a lot of drug usage (well, obviuos usage anyway) and
it ends at 2. There's a few other options out there for fairly
parental-friendly parties. Just find something that you know is low key,
but has all the elements that you want her to see.
	As for prepping her on it, just tell her the truth. Be as open and
honest as you can. Communication is the key here, believe me, I learned my
lesson on this one, it only took me like 6 years!!! I have been working on
my parental units for almost a year now, finally trying to explain what I
have been up to for the past several years and why. Unfortunately, it's not
something that they are gonna grasp any time soon, but with honesty and
openness, (except for that whole drug thing, even though I have slowed down
to the point of like 98% sobriety, I ain't tellin' yet, cuz I know they
couldn't handle it, even if it is in the past) they may soon start to get
it. I know they are trying, but sometimes I don't think they'll ever even
slightly understand... which is fine. But having them know what I do and
respect it, is what's most important. They doesn't need to buy into the
meaning behind it all... though I wish they could.

good luck,
jenn

	p.s. I found that having my parents at a party was one of the
coolest things ever... kind of like that your favorite rave toy. =) My
parents are very old fashioned and straight edged, but seeing them get down
and dirty on the dance floor was really a treat. Well, okay I exaggerate,
but they did groove a little to the music and I thought that was cool. I
just think next time I'll warn everyone that my parents will be around...
maybe out it on the back of the flyer somewhere... "***WARNING*** Jenn's
parental units will be at this event. If you know her and them, be on the
lookout. Don't get caught offguard" (hehehe) Sorry to those of you who got
caught offguard and frightened... those of you who did your drugs early
anyway... Come on! It wasn't my fault... none of you *ever* take your drugs
before midnight, especially at 9 o'clock!!! How was I supposed to know! =)
	I actually want to bring them to another one... hmmm... I think
I'll take them to the next CF! How about it guys? Are you little CFers down
to set up and party  with my parents? =)


------------------------------------------------------------
"Slipping into madness is good for the sake of comparison...
               ...I do alot of comparing."
------------------------------------------------------------

Hi to everyone reading,
Since i subscribed a few weeks ago i've been checking my mail constantly,
following the flow of conversations, reviews, and recognizing familiar
names. I checked my mail this afternoon and my great friend mac (like the
truck without the "k") had her introduction to all,  so it seemed time that
i get my name out. 
I'm Matt Davison, occasionaly Matthew (it cutts down on the
confussion when half your guy friends share the name). Over the past year
I've emersed myself in dance culture, grooved to awsome music, and meet
people who make the scene the community that it is. I try to hit a party
every weekend with my friends so say hi if you ever
spot me. Hmm.. i'm tall with short bleached hair...well i'll be wearing my
sfraves badge so that my narrow it down. Hugs to all who can figure out
which smiley face in the crowd is me, hopefully i'll see some of you. Bye
for now, i'll post some reviews in the future (partiless this weekend). 

love to all    -Matt Davison-

From: brat <jenn@cloudfactory.org>
