Precedence: bulk

>didn't get angry.  She just looked a little disappointed.  If I can
>accomplish all that in such a short time (3 months) anything's possible!
>Maybe she'll try e before the year 2,000 :)

	I think maybe you need to focus less on the drugs and more on the
vibe and the family orientation behind it. It just sounds to me like that
is your big focus. I'm sure it's not completely your focus, but maybe part
of the problem is you have been talking too much about it and hoping too
much that your mom will cave and "pop the pills." So much talk about drugs
in the rave seen can definitely sway the misunderstanding parent in the
wrong direction. I also know generally, with parents, they tend to think
that raves are drug fests anyway (thank you 20/20... wait a minute while I
bust out my crack pipe...), but try to let her know the real meaning behind
it all. While it could be cool to x with mom, the focus right now, should
be getting her to understand the scene and how it works and what it means
to you and everyone. Try to explain that not all "ravers" do drugs and most
of them are in it for the community and love that it creates. Your mom may
have changed some of her views, but things like that, especially the rave
scene, being such a touchy subject, is going to take a lot of time and
discussion. Don't expect her to change her views or fully understand you
over night. It may be frusterating, but keep patient and I'm sure things
will work out for the best in the end. Just don't push it too hard.

>I asked my mom if she would go to Mad with me, tomorrow night.  I said I
>wanted her to try to get used to the music.  She won't do it.  She hates
>techno more than anything.  It makes her really nervous, or something.
>This kinda worries me...

	Something else I don't understand... she wants to go to a party
with you, but she doesn't? And because of the music? I'm confused... didn't
you say in your last post that she liked the music? Why the sudden change?
Is it just because she associates it with drugs now? If that's the case,
then she has a lot to learn and only you can help. Maybe you could find a
few "brave" friends to also talk with her about it. Let some others tell
their experiences and try to let her know what it is all about. Or at least
have them write their experiences out for you to show her. I think really,
she has a fear of the drugs and your involvement with them. Which, coming
from a parents point of view and if not educated on, can be a scary thing,
I'm sure. Just try to explain to her that Mad is really low key and mellow.
That the people are not all high and running around going crazy and having
sex on the ceiling. Just don't forget to get her some ear plugs. =)

>Does anyone know of a good, mellow album I could start her out on?  I
>guess I'll try to gradually get her into the music.  I hope it works!

	My parents tend to prefer the Orb, Orbital and Underworld, stuff
like that. My advice is to try to find an album that isn't too repetitive.
Generally people who aren't into it, don't like it because they think it's
too repetative and monotonous. Try something that has a little more
structure to it... some songs with maybe a little more vocals to it and
that changes it's sound a little more than just the same old sample through
the whole song. Something really upbeat and happy.

>When I mentioned that the predominant drug at parties was e, she said,
>"Gee, great.  I can watch a bunch of people having sex."  Augh!  I
>couldn't believe what I was hearing!  I told her that e was not a sex
>drug.  She answered, "That's not what I heard!"  So, I told her

"Harmony... no penetration." (hehehe)
	In reference to your mom thinking that e is a sex drug, all I can
say is try to educate her on it. Not just with your personal experience
because she'll just think your backing it up because you do it and like it.
But back it up with some hard core facts. There's a lot of books out there
and information on the net even, about e and all the other drugs out there.
Read up on it yourself so you know what you are talking about and then go
over it with her... don't just tell her what you read either, show her some
of the material you have been exploring. Just be sure to be able to back up
what you say so you don't sound like you just memorized section 2,
paragraph seven of page 428 in chapter 15, if you know what I mean. Make
sure you know what you are talking about. The key to the universe is
education!!! =)

love
jenn

It is what it is.

Much out there IS commercial.

Some is mindless drivel.

Some is genuine and from the heart.

Even more is there to make someone rich or famous.

True techno isn't just about music.  It's about freeing the preprogrammed
minds of those raised to believe the commercial media is always right and
represents "what people want".  What it really breaks down to for them is
the mighty dollar.  If it will make money they will be your best friend.  If
you too worship the mighty dollar then you too can let them control all you
see and hear.  If you are of free spirit and mind then you will CHOOSE your
input.

In the end, it doesn't matter what the commercial programmers do.  If peices
of the underground are adopted for commercial means then those behind the
underground will push even deeper to escape the mold trying to be enforced
upon them.

Those who know and CARE will remain true to the sound.
                   _
-robert           | |___   ____   ____ _____

                  |_____/ \___\  |_|   | |__/    / -studio- \

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Jan 12 19:43:55 1997

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Techno "Evita" and Cheez Dance
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
cc: solmania@uclink4.berkeley.edu
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9701121912.A21509-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Speaking of mainstreaming, stay tuned to Wild 107 for the dance remix 
version of Madonna's "Don't Cry for Me, Argentina."  !

Will EVERY song released now have an obligatory dance version?  And in 
this case, of a song from a Broadway musical!  

I haven't heard it, but someone told me that it is basically the same 
song set to a pounding bassline.  Which (speaking again of the effects of 
mainstreaming!) reminds me of the derivative nature of most pop (or 
"cheez") house of the Wild 107 variety... Originality is practically 
non-existant; every song has a predictable bassline, some echo-y "ping" 
noises, and the ever-present drum roll.  Dance-by-the-numbers.  
Stultifying corporatism.

Interesting that in order to create a new subgenre that will sell, the 
powers-that-be must generate a single sound, easily identifiable and 
packaged as "dance music" (or worse yet, passed off as "techno").  As 
others have pointed out, it is simply the tired old process of mainstream 
corporatizing of the music.  Just like rap originated as a vital and 
creative art form in the underground, its mainstream incarnation quickly 
became an extremely-generic "gansta rap" sound.  Rap in all its 
multifaceted expression was reduced to that proven seller, gangsta rap.

Big labels want proven success, they don't want to take a chance on 
profits.  So, just as any rap group signed was basically forced to adhere 
to a strict gangsta rap formula, Wild 107-type dance music has a 
rigid format which cannot be varied.  And artists are not even required 
to mastermind this format - its rote simplicity allows almost any 
quasi-producer with a drum machine to toss off another carbon-copy dance 
"hit."

The motivation behind all this?  What else, big money.  The music industry
is just another capitalist industry, and dance is but another product to
be sold.  The bizarre thing to me is the hordes of people willing to
consume such generic products, and for years on end.  I was once a 
passionate fan of rap, but I tired many years ago of the slop on the 
radio.  Every new song sounds just like something I was bored of five 
years ago!  Yet others remain faithful consumers...millions of them.  

So cheez dance is here to stay, at least for as long as these subgenres 
can last.  Techno "Evita?"  Not such a surprise!

Hi all  ]=)


 I hope you all had a chance to see the moon tonight (Sunday). It looked 
really beautiful (from Santa Cruz anyway).

 I've just been going through the Hyperreal archives, doing some research 
for a play I'm writing, and I was just really struck by the idealism that 
runs through raves like a backbone or perhaps more appropriately (sp?) 
like a spirit.

 I like to thank those who have letters there in the archives and 
especially I would like to thank the folks at Hyperreal (again) for 
Hyperreal itself. Hyperreal has more than once refreshed my spirit in oh 
so needful ways.

hugz,

Ran D.Dreams

	Dunno if this group can help me much, but if you have any information...
pleeeeze help... Yes, i'm humble enough to beg. =3Do)
	I moved to San Francisco this pat summer to attend Academy of Art. It's a
pretty expensive school, which scared me... I myself am not a very
expensive person. Well, halfway through this past term, I had to drop a
class due to the materials/supplies for that class *alone* costing upwards
of $100-$300 a week - which having dropped it late in the term yielded a
final grade as F - prompting the school to grant me a dismissal. I fought
it to no avail and am unable to attend the Academy this term. Which kind of
sucks because the financial aid from that school was help in my living in
San Francisco.
	Here's where I need help... In order to continue living in San Francisco,
I desperately need to get a decent job (i.e. *NOT* Tenderloin's Carl's Jr.
graveyard shift), and i've applied as many places as I can think of on my
own...

	Does anybody out there in sfraveland know of any job openings????

	I am a phun person who gets along with 99.9% of the world, and if I don't
know how to do something... I learn quickly. My web site is at
http://www.chosen.org ... my email address is iam@chosen.org

	Please help me if at all possible as I really love living in San
Francisco, and would hate to have to move away so soon after moving here...

-tonz o' thanks, and tonz o' luv
-justin

Subject: About Eminence...  and raves in general..
Date: Sun, 12 Jan 1997 21:35:38 -0600

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com

Hey there everyone...

I've got a question for anyone who was at Eminence--  was it just me or =
was there a bad vibe going around?  I mean, you know how you can just =
walk into a room and sense a bad vibe?  Especially right at the entrance =
as you first walk into the warehouse...  Maybe it's just me, but I have =
noticed that there are more and more "thug" types hanging out at parties =
as the weeks go by...  (perhaps because of the "commercializtion" that =
the scene is slowly falling into?)

I remember back in the day when you could accidentally bump into someone =
and not be worried that they might take a swing at you...  just a =
friendly "sorry!" and a smile would be sufficient....

To me it appears that raves nowadays are becoming more "commercialized"; =
and that more people are showing up not to dance or show unity, but =
instead to "pick up on chicks"... like it was a club or a bar or =
something...=20

Now, I'm not trying to pick on any lifestyle or any particular group, =
it's just that when I try to be friendly to someone by offering candy or =
a blow pop or some water, I expect to at least be greeted with a smile =
or something... not be told, "What the hell???  Get away..."

Other than that, I must say I did have fun at Eminence--  sure, Keoki =
rocked the house, but real props go out to DJ Ghost; who just =
intensified my high just a little bit more with all his killer beats...  =


PLUR...
doughboy

>   Look at the facts: More free-thinking liberals are in power than ever
>   before in American history--Clinton's got *12* Berkeley professors
>   working for him, for goodness' sake!  That's incredible!

Look at the facts: Bill Clinton signed into law the Salvage Rider,
allowing even more irreplaceable old-growth forests to be destroyed, and
refuses to reform the 18-something Mining Act, which continues to give
away billions of dollars worth of precious metals on public land for
literally pennies; Clinton signs the "Defense of Marriage" act, denying
homosexuals the right to be treated the same as "straight" people;
Clinton continues to advocate censorship for the Internet (the CDA) and
the country; the defense budget continues at Cold War levels despite the
lack of a cold war; Clinton continues to fire or muzzle anyone who calls
for the long-overdue legalization of hemp (including Joycelyn Elders,
possibly the best Surgeon General we've had); how long a list do you
want?

Politicians are very good at making you _feel_ like they are serving
your interests, via carefully crafted speeches and platitudes. 
Meanwhile, they serve their own interests and the interests of those who
helped them to power.

Words don't matter.  Actions do.

// grigsbeast

quoth: Nancy Shaw
>If so, please post a review - I'm curious!  Karma 5, Eminence, and 
>did anyone go to Resolution, the $5 trance party with Minor Minor and Seth.
>wondering if that was the small West Oak party that got shut down that 
>Jonathan wrote about...

Well Resolution was in West Oaktown and did get shut down. Bummer it was 
a good party. I had a good time seeing old friends and meeting new people 
for one and a half hours befor OPD rolled up. I hate to say this; 'cuz I 
used to be in a motorcyle gang with the guy whose space it was, but what 
a death trap. One exit; one fucked up, skinny stairway to the ambient 
room; folowed by another skinny door to the chill room. The PA was good, 
the music was OK, the vibe/people were great, lights were minimal ($5 
whadayu want?) I was having a great time until OPD showed up. The cops 
were smilling and friendly, so I tried to give one a tootsie pop, but he 
wouldn't take it. I would happily go to Resolution again if it was in a 
safe, relatively bust free space.

DJ Ulrich
standish@sirius.com

well, i checked out the emminence massive. it wasn't as bad as i thought 
it might be after hearing the cool world horror stories. the hardcore 
acid mix in the laserium part of home base was awesome. the main stage 
was happening but a bit sedate at times, with throngs crashed on the 
sidelines. my only negative experience was when my backpack loaded with 
bubbles, glow paraphernalia, and unfortunately my pet trible and marmot 
jacket disappeared suddenly. so goes life in the big city.

Dear Steve & SFRavefriends,

        Somehow I seem to have not been receiving email from the list for
the past week or so, so if there has been discussion of this issue during
that time (and I assume there has!) I have missed it.  Indeed if anyone has
saved posts on this thread since January 4 and can forward them to me, you
have my gratitude.
        Regarding support from the Libertarian Party, I was not suggesting
that this project take on any partisan affiliation, only that we look for
help from those who share our concerns.  Libertarian party support for the
anti-CDA (Communications Decency Act) movement opposing censorship of the
Internet has not resulted in this movement taking on a partisan aspect; I
think parties are usually savvy enough to realize that co-opting a movement
like this will not serve anyone's interests.  If the Democrats,
Republicans, or anyone else wants to help reform the laws that lead to
busted parties, we should welcome their support too, imho.  Frankly I doubt
you'll find as much sympathy from any other party, but hey, I could be
wrong.  I mentioned the Libertarians because I'm involved with them and
familiar enough with the party's positions to know how they would likely
feel about the issue.
        As a matter of fact, I brought it up at the San Francisco
Libertarian Party meeting last Wednesday, and they agreed to put the topic
on the agenda for next month's meeting on Weds. Feb 12th.  This will be
held at Freedom's Forum bookstore, 1800 Market Street at Octavia, at 730pm.
I hope that a lot of SFRavers will show up and demonstrate our concerns on
this issue.
        The fear voiced by those present on Wednesday was that ravers might
be all talk and no dice, so I hope to prove them wrong and show that we do
care about our freedom to dance enough to actually do something about it.
        One constructive suggestion that came out of the meeting was that
we need to go to a law library and do some research on the state or local
penal codes that may apply to our problem.  This would be a necessary step
in the drafting of any ballot proposal to revise the law, as our proposal
would have to address the wording of current applicable law.
        In any event, we have our work cut out for us, and I think we
should welcome the involvement of outside allies.

May the bass be with you,
                                        <<< Starchild >>>

On Sun, 12 Jan 1997, Mnemonic wrote:

> well, i checked out the emminence massive. it wasn't as bad as i thought 
> it might be after hearing the cool world horror stories. the hardcore 
> acid mix in the laserium part of home base was awesome. (*snip-snip...*)

Agreed!  Even in spite of the negative attitudes I felt among some of the
staff, a couple of less-than-friendly (uh-oh, here comes that word
again!) "gangsta's," and the occasional lull in vibe, I thought the tunes
from the "laser room" **rocked**!  I spent practiacally the whole night 
in or near there, since I haven't heard any thick, syrupy melodic bass
like that in ages!!  All I can say is WOW!  And I managed perfectly well
to have a *blast* dancing like mad!  (Please note, though, that I'm also a
sucker for bright, shiny objects, and _nothing_ beats a 1500W laser in
that dept.!  Except maybe TWO 1500W lasers!  Yeah!)  ;)

For me, the key to having fun lies in the heart of the individual, in the
feet of the dancer, the mind of the philosopher, and the ears of the
audiophile, not in the "hard" glares of those who choose pretense over
genuine emotion.  Together, many individuals can share this common bond of
simply having fun, and thus, we have "the vibe."  :)  And I thought that
there were enough positive people there, just having fun, to keep up a
nice vibe in spite of any of the negativity lurking.
Kudos also to the breakdancers (helmets and all!); I totally miss seeing
that stuff!  Man, that *really* brought back some 80's memories!  And
kudos to those of you out there who *did* help set the vibe there!  I love
you guys!

Not bad, overall; I personally had a whole lot of fun, and amazingly
enough, it didn't get broken up (at least, until after 4am or so, when my
ride had to leave, I'm not too sure about after that...)  Okay, well,
enough ranting for now; much pLur-
-=Joe=-
____________________________________________________________________________
_/oe /-/elgeson: jphelgeson@ucdavis.edu, http://lm.ucdavis.edu/SA/jphelgeson

Subject: Karma V and AFTERPARTY review :))
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-id: <01IE5RFAPH768Y5Q4S@SONOMA.EDU>
X-VMS-To: SMTP%"sfraves@hyperreal.com"

What a great weekend!
	Karma was at "the space" on stevenson again, and yet, they 
did as promised and sold limited tix. Even though there were half the 
people this time, it still was sweltering in the main room, hot 
enough to.. say.. fuck up the sound system around 3 am? oops that 
kinda pissed off thomas trouble right in the middle of his set. the 
people though, either hung around, or someone with drums sat around 
playing them while people clapped and danced :) it was a great party, 
less negative vibes than usual, and the chill room was *gasp* 
DECORATED! boomerang played a great set in there, as well as some 
russian guy from galactic tunnel who spun near the end and was 
playing (sorry) better than the stuff up on the main room (the music 
was kinda slow for awhile up there, kinda hard to dance to around 4 
am) and that meant people dancing in the chill room. oh my god i 
thought i was going to die! either that or fall through the floor... 
earlier they cleared about 15 people out of the room cuz of the 
safety hazard.. i just think they should close that room altogether, 
as much fun as it is to hang out in there, and make the front part (past 
the bathrooms) the chill room. i went outside and went on a walk with 
eric and understood how the building was movign to the beat. tons of 
people working the party kept telling the dancers in the chill room 
to stop because it was dangerous but they didnt stop. :(( scared the 
shit out of quite a few people! anyway, i would have to say big-ups 
to Mars for an incredibly PHAT set, and to the last dj (sorry didnt 
know you) for the last song played of the night, it was BEAUTIFUL and 
the BEST way i've heard a party end in a long time :)
	WAIT im not DONE YET! sorry this is so long. i went to 
jonas's afterparty, wondering "TREES?! is this OUTSIDE?!" and well it 
was INSIDE and so were some trees.. and candles.. and a huge rug on 
the dancefloor.. Well yay! I love this spot! i loved the party so 
much,ambient jungle and whatnot being spun all day, really very 
relaxing to hang out at especially after a party :) they had fruit, 
fruit juice, muffins, chai, and later on lunch for sale, and it was 
really great. I can't wait to go again, I want to thank Jonas and 
everyone else who worked on it for the great idea, and for the place 
to hang when home/bed just didnt' sound like the thing to do quite 
yet... Everyone DEFINITELY should check it out come sunday, whether 
you're coming from harmony or another party, or if you're just bored 
on sunday and want to hang ... cuz it goes 9-4 :) i'll be there! 
	So thus ends another great weekend... Peace and Love, and 
HUGS to all! :)
LAra

On Mon, 13 Jan 1997, matter wrote:

> If u r interested, Eudora Pro (and some other packages) can do automatic
> filing upon retrieval of mail. This is very helpful for ensuring that you
> don't miss your personal (non-list) e-mails. :) I think Eudora is the best
> out there (handles huge volumes of e-mail better than all I have used). :D

Since I received a response from this person calling me a "bitch" I can
only assume that he is not going to stop this kind of activity. Sendmail
8.8.4 has some great new filtering capabilites that allow you to block
people from our mail servers altogether. 

<Sys Admin mode>

I don't like spammers. Our customers don't like spammers. I add filters to
prevent spammers from bothering myself or our customers, which is what I
have done in this case. So now there are 3000+ people less that this
person can pester from his current account.

</Sys Admin mode>

Subject: Re: e's

At 10:41 PM 1/11/97 -0800, GRooV-DAddY wrote:
>What exactly is an "e"? And why are people taking
>drugs to have a good time? I don't feel that drugs
>are what really make a rave or party fun. I think
>it is, in fact, the unity and love between each
>person there. I don't understand why people use
>drugs, but hey, people have their own opinions on
>things. Peace.

IMO, human beings and other life forms, are constantly using chemicals. In
some cases, people choose to intake or abstain from certain chemicals,
because of their reactions to them. They all have different aspects and
affects. Some people might consider alcohol, tobacco, nicotine, caffiene
and even chocolate to be substances which people abstain from, use or abuse
to be drugs. You might even consider hot spices, which have obvious
metabolistic affects on humans to be a drug. Simply because these chemicals
are recognized by our law enforcement officals as being legal, is not to
say that they are good or bad for you at any level of consumption, persay.

There is a good book on these topics, for those of you who are interested:
Food of the Gods. I can't seem to locate the book right now and can't
remember the author... oopsie. ;)

/* plur */
  matter


I'm smiling because I don't understand myself. :)

From: Adam Guevara <aguevara@rely.com>
To: "'Sfraves@hyperreal.com'" <Sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Sometimes, it's just one of those weekends...
Date: Mon, 13 Jan 1997 13:14:26 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.994.63
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ok I guess we can call this take #2.


"Action"


Hello dear raver,  let me tell you about my weekend...  If not, then
just press the delete key.  I really won't mind.  Actually I really
wouldn't know (so there)...
(Wow, sass on a Monday)

Ahem, pardon him... Ok, take my hand and let us drift back to....


                                                 Friday  
After work (6'ish) I boogied down to a small pub (City Pub - Redwood
City, off Brodway @ El Camino) for a lil birthday celebration between a
co-worker and some friends.  Nice little gear up for the nights
festivites, dispite my abstension (sp?) of alcohol... Round seven or so,
Mr Pager started telling me the natives (i.e. raver friends) became
restless, asking "which party Im going to be at" and, "can I get a ride"
and "who's spinning at where" and blah blah blah.  So I make my exit and
arrive in Fremont to change my dud's and finalize the eve's plans...
Off to The City @ 10 or so when disaster strikes.. In order to avoid a
possible accident, I run my car up a curve and not only manage to blow
out BOTH driver-side tires, but I also tweak out one of my rims enuff so
that I'll need a replacement.  (uugh).  So here I am 10:40PM.  Dead car.
 Friends expecting me in SF.  A party starting up in OAK.  Bills are
calculating in my head very very fast.   hmmm....   
I say "Sod it, I AM going to a Fuc*ing party!"  And start playing "pager
tag" until I manage to get a set of wheels and an amped crew to go
dancing...

__Happy Kids__  Got there @ 3am and headed straight to the dance floor
Thomas T was on the wheels spinning some hard trance, then to goa, and
then to some kind of music that I was totally unfamillar with.  I would
really like to take the time to say "sorry" to anyone that might of
caught any negative vibe from me.  Despite the party being in a great
place (looked TOTALLY UG, fresh warehouse and all), the crowd had no bad
vibes at all (I remember @ one point all of us dancers forming a circle
and just acting like kids, happy kids), I was in a different frame of
mind...  Only stayed till about 5:30 but had a great time while I was
there.


Saturday:

Spent all of my daylight hours trying to get the car fixed.  I will not
go into detail (I don't want to relive it all)...

Night-  Hooked up with some friends and began our journey to
_Resoultion_.  But a page kept us from getting there.  It was Deepfog
informing us of a 420 Party in San Jose.  After convincing my pals that
allthough it's a house party it'll be cool we head down to the place.
Arriving @ 9:30 or so We meet up with a few SFR'ers (hey EZE, ect al.).
Our numbers total a bit over a dozen.  Some decks are up but we're all
generally 420ing it (hence, a 420 party) and chatting.  Talk to one of
the _koinonea_ DJ's about the eurotrance and goatrance scenes in SF and
the underground in general. A few other promoters are there and
conversation turns to more specific party type details and other stuff
that makes sense on other states of consusness.  However, my friends are
more on a phyiscal plane and want to dance, so we bail and make it
to....

_Resoultion_  @ 11:30.  I remember this mappoint, thinking it would be
cool to throw a party here.  I guess I wasn't the only one.  The main
room (downstairs) was what caught me and tossed me into that abysmal
abstract world of music.  Dancing hard till the end (i.e. bust) I really
didn't look around but noticed an upstairs lounge (chill area?) where a
bunch of people were looking down to us crazy dancers.  The lights were
nice. The house, comfy. Not too hot, not too crowded. All in all a very
well kept secret. When Oakland's finest came to visit I honestly though
they might just let us rave in peace.

hah.
ha ha.
yea right.

But they were nice in shooing us away...  My friend and I lost our ride
in the  process (actually the driver bailed once he saw the police and
then managed to get lost in Oakland for a few hours).  Allthough several
of you offered rides to _Eminence '97_, I figured that I'll try to get a
hold of the driver that skated on me.  So we (my friend and I) paged the
driver, with directions, back to the site and motored to one of my
secret hidey holes until 5:30 or so chilling out.

Site Bustabillty Table for Oakland fisical year 97':  2 for 3 so far.

Sunday:  I don't wanna remember (But I did get my car fixed! ---For a
not-so-slight denominal fee which I won't disclose, to myself even).

So all in all I pretty much had a hellofa rollercoaster ride...  I love
being a raver!

Hope to see some of you @ MAD tonight....

---_Adam

"Stay Connected"

WARNING!  THIS IS VERY NON-RAVE RELATED!!
WARNING!  THIS IS VERY NON-RAVE RELATED!!
WARNING!  THIS IS VERY NON-RAVE RELATED!!

The reason I'm sending it to you is because I consider SFRaves to be my
extended family, and sometimes you share something with your family
because you're utterly outraged and you want them to share in your
outrage.

I have a web page that, along with a slightly out of date rave diary,
contains some of my personal views.  Among those views are my opinions
and beliefs, right or wrong, on racism, gun control, and pedophilia. 
Occasionally I get comments on these, but the other day I got a message
from someone that just blew me away.  I was stunned.  According to his
letter, he's an Uzi-toting, racist, pedophile that believes...

Well, rather than try to describe it, just hit the following page.  It
doesn't contain the full text of the messages -- if you want those, let
me know and I'll forward them to you.

	http://www.tgrigsby.com/views/csmith.htm

And do me a favor: if you feel as strongly about this as I did, send
CSmith a note telling him how you feel.  I got way too pissed off and
found I couldn't keep from really getting vulgar when replying to this
guy.  Hopefully you guys can help me out here.

Thanks and sorry if I wasted your time.

S

On Sun, 12 Jan 1997, Steve Simitzis wrote:

> parties. For example, Harmony parties (as much as I love them), are
> filled with tons more E than something like a Frequency 8 event. The
> kind of music and the kind of event typically dictates the type and
> the quantity of drugs people will use.
> 
> Jungle and Goa parties seem to have the least amount of (noticeable!)
> drug use. Not that it doesn't go on; it's just not as noticeable
> as people on E.

	Or, jungle and goa parties, since they are somewhat more 
specialized, attract a crowd that is a little more discrete about it, a 
little more mature, a crowd that is basicly the same whether on something 
or not? Some parties draw a crowd that changes when they ingest or inhale 
psychoactive substances and then people go back to "normal" in the 
morning, other parties draw a crowd that take things but don't change 
much... Draw your own conclusions on why this happens, I have mine...

dave

OK, I'm a semi-lurker, so here goes!

My first rave was a Friends and Family back in 1994 or so.  Since then I've
been raving infrequently at best.  When I do rave I like to help with setup
since I was a stage crew nerd in high school and never recovered.  There's
a good energy that goes with creating the space.

1996 was a very quiet year for me ravewise; most of my life energy was
consumed with matters of the heart.  That all went through big changes at
the end of '96, and I'm still reassembling myself, but '97 looks to be much
more open energetically.  I'm looking forward to helping throw more parties
this year!

I'm deeply into high-energy thickly-layered music.  I'm developing a mighty
taste for jungle.  Here's a question for you all:  I have a CD named
"Deep Into Jungle Territory: A Jungle-Bhangra Fusion" that in my opinion
kicks ass (some tracks off it, at least).  Anyone recognize it and have any
other recommendations of DJs or CDs with a similar sound?

Raves, for me, are one of the best ways to party... the Dionysian energy is
mightily addictive, and the holistic consciousness is terribly copacetic,
compared to a more standard beer-and-cigarettes type scene.  I'm also quite
into the local sex-positive community, which throws my _other_ favorite kind
of parties, but enough about that.  Why would any free spirit want to live
anywhere other than San Francisco?  (And what a paradox:  shouldn't a free
spirit be free to live anywhere?  Am I just a herd-mentality follower, and
not a free spirit at all?  Yet humans are social animals, and we groove on
those who groove like us....)

I'm good at hacking software, and I like designing software an awful lot--
it's an avocation and a vocation.  Ideally I'd like to build systems that
many people worldwide wind up using to communicate and relate in ways that
help them grow.  That's the fundamental goal of life as the Buddha saw it:
to save all sentient beings.  Can I truly translate that into a career?
I'm going to keep trying....  (See http://www.unreal.com/robj/xancurs.htm
for one early such story, and www.communities.com for the latest version,
should you care :-)

Looking forward to doing many wonderful things in 1997, and anticipating
raves as part of the rich pageant!

Rob Jellinghaus		robj@unreal.com         http://www.best.com/~robj

Received: from shellx.best.com (shellx.best.com [206.86.0.11]) by proxy3.ba.best.com (8.8.4/8.8.3) with ESMTP id PAA25214; Mon, 13 Jan 1997 15:16:23 -0800 (PST)
Received: (from robj@localhost) by shellx.best.com (8.8.4/8.8.3) id OAA11854; Mon, 13 Jan 1997 14:33:29 -0800 (PST)
Date: Mon, 13 Jan 1997 14:33:29 -0800 (PST)
From: Rob Jellinghaus <robj@best.com>
Message-Id: <199701132233.OAA11854@shellx.best.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, SDream@tgrigsby.com
Subject: Re:  NRR: A racist pedophile
Cc: robj@shellx.best.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Well, rather than try to describe it, just hit the following page.  It
>doesn't contain the full text of the messages -- if you want those, let
>me know and I'll forward them to you.

You should put the full text up on your page.  If you really want to invite
the entire sfraves community to participate in your flame war with this guy,
you should go whole hog.  Otherwise you're asking people to flame him based
on _two lines_ of actual text from him, plus a lot of agitated commentary
from you.  Not very fair to him.  (And if you feel he doesn't deserve fair
treatment, well, what does that say?)

>And do me a favor: if you feel as strongly about this as I did, send
>CSmith a note telling him how you feel.  I got way too pissed off and
>found I couldn't keep from really getting vulgar when replying to this
>guy.  Hopefully you guys can help me out here.

How can we help you out when we don't even know what you're replying to?

And more basically, what kind of help are you _really_ asking for?  You
don't need anyone's help to tell him what you think.  If your problem is
that you don't want to be vulgar in responding to him, that's a problem
you really don't need anyone else's help to solve.

I think that you're feeling pretty upset and that you want us to help you
flame this guy because... well... because what?  How, exactly, will many
sfravers flaming him help anyone?  How would you feel if this guy posted
your emails to a white-supremacist email list inviting hundreds of them
to send _you_ flame mail?  I wouldn't be surprised at all if he does just
that in response to the many emails you're encouraging us to send him.  
Then perhaps it'll escalate and we'll have a full-on flame war
between sfraves and the white-supremacist list!  And wouldn't _that_ be
productive?

If you want to flame people like this, why not just go to the Usenet group
alt.politics.white-power and have at it?  Why involve all of sfraves?  If
any folks from here do decide to join SDream in flaming this bozo (and
please don't think that I don't agree that he is an evil bozo--I do think
him fully bozotic), make it clear that you're a personal friend of SDream's,
and that you're not doing this "on behalf of the SFRaves community."  This
will help avoid making sfraves the target of a white supremacist mailbombing
campaign.

(SDream, are you really shocked there are people like this out there?
Haven't you gone surfing for white power pages, or for child sex pages?
They're there for the finding....)

>Thanks and sorry if I wasted your time.

Just be careful you don't invoke more hassle than you really want.

I spent a couple of years wholeheartedly flaming the shit out of gaybashers
on alt.politics.homosexuality (and this during a time when I was pretty much
completely straight).  It was great!  It was cathartic!  I got lots of kudos
from people who liked what I was saying!  And I made no impression whatever
on the gaybashers--or at least on the gaybashers who were doing all the
posting.

Flame wars generally don't make much difference to the participants.  If
one piece of email could change your whole worldview, it's likely that
your worldview is barely settled enough for you to flame about it.  And if
you're ready to flame your ass off, it's likely that your beliefs are
settled enough that mere words on a screen won't make much difference.

Communication and education can do a lot of people a lot of good... but
flame wars generally involve neither true communication nor true education.
They tend to be more useful for developing rhetorical skills and for getting
some aggression out.  But for me, I lately prefer to spend my life energy
on and with my friends, working on projects that'll make a difference for
all the people whose lives _aren't_ yet driven by a particular dogma.  Flame
wars are like banging your head against a brick wall... eventually your head
starts to hurt a lot, and you've only broken a few chips loose.

IMHO, anyway....

Rob

Rob Jellinghaus		robj@unreal.com         http://www.best.com/~robj

  Thanks for the formal welcome, Eric. *hug* :) I appreciate the invitation
for introductions, it's a welcome I never received on mw-raves (unless it
got lost in the heaps of e-mail) and it makes this list seem a whole lot
more friendly. ;) I think I already, briefly, introduced myself. BUT, never
being at a lack for words (or an excuse to ramble), I will go into more
detail... :)

  I go by matter, my birth name is Matt. My brother and sister have been
living around the Oakland area for a few years now. I grew up in Harper
Woods, MI (east of Detroit) and lived there for 23 years. The past 6 years
I have been living in the Chicago area. Yes, your abacus is functioning
properly, I am 29. ;) I plan on moving out to s/f to take over the world
with my brother, Ed. I should be moving out there in the next few months.
Of course, you all will have a little time to prepare while we put our
plans in motion. I would imagine the world will be safe for another six
months, or so. ;)
  I have been going to partys for about three years and prefer hard techno,
hard trance and acidic goa over all over music. I am (I think) very
open-minded and enjoy listening and dancing to just about everything. I
have a habit of having way too much fun and frequently giggling
uncontrollably. I am also somewhat of a dichotomy and enjoy philosophy at
great lengths. I spent alot of time in the Detroit club scene between the
ages of 16 and 23, which explains my fondness of the harder techno and
acidic music styles.
  I am currently working at an insurance company in Chicago. I work in the
I/T department and roughly 400 of us support 30,000 systems at 250 sites. I
have worked in the slave, uhm, I mean systems, industry for about 11 years.
I am hoping that I will not have to keep a corporate-type job, after I
move. :)
 I spend my time with partying, marital arts and working on my original
music. I play keyboards and guitar mainly, but also dabble in bass, drums
and various percussion. My music and some nifty pictures are available from
my web site below. I also have some experience spinning CDs.

Here's to san fran! (psyched) :D

  matter

Rob,

Good advice all of it, but to answer one of your points:

> I think that you're feeling pretty upset and that you want us to help you
> flame this guy because... well... because what?  How, exactly, will many
> sfravers flaming him help anyone?

During that time that you were bashing the gay-bashers (good for you,
BTW!)
Didn't you *once* feel that you were showing them that there were some 
intelligent and articulate people out there completely disagreed with 
them and could present well thought-out arguments as to why?  Do you 
really think that not even *one* of them stopped for a moment to review 
what it was that they were standing for?  To rethink their position?

>  How would you feel if this guy posted
> your emails to a white-supremacist email list inviting hundreds of them
> to send _you_ flame mail?

Bring'em on.  Yeah, that may be asking for trouble, but hell, if I was
worried about that I wouldn't have posted my views in the first place.
I admittedly post things that I know won't be met with wide approval.
I sometimes cringe when I think of the responses I'll get, but it's 
how I feel, and I felt strongly enough to say something, even if it's
just an emotional regurgitation, like my feelings on parking tickets or
the "3 Strikes" law.

> If you want to flame people like this, why not just go to the Usenet group
> alt.politics.white-power and have at it?

Good idea.

  Why involve all of sfraves?  If
> any folks from here do decide to join SDream in flaming this bozo (and
> please don't think that I don't agree that he is an evil bozo--I do think
> him fully bozotic), 

A true bozisimo.  8)

> make it clear that you're a personal friend of SDream's,
> and that you're not doing this "on behalf of the SFRaves community."  This
> will help avoid making sfraves the target of a white supremacist mailbombing
> campaign.

Folks, that is a very good point.  Please, if you decide to flame this
guy,
please don't do so because I said you should or as a representative of
SFRaves.  It's just that I know there are people in our family that feel
as
I do, that you sometimes have to fire right back with enough support to
make
the bozos of the world stop and reflect for a moment on what it is they
stand for.

> (SDream, are you really shocked there are people like this out there?
> Haven't you gone surfing for white power pages, or for child sex pages?
> They're there for the finding....)

I guess I just don't go looking for them.  Yeah, I know they're out
there,
but when one walks through your front door, it's always a bit of a
shock.
I guess I expect them to stay under their rock and leave the more
intelligent 
people of the world alone.

> But for me, I lately prefer to spend my life energy
> on and with my friends, working on projects that'll make a difference for
> all the people whose lives _aren't_ yet driven by a particular dogma.  

A very wonderful approach.

> Flame wars are like banging your head against a brick wall... eventually 
> your head starts to hurt a lot, and you've only broken a few chips loose.

>To those of you who haven't introduced yourselves to us yet: please do so!

ok....fine...I guess I have satisfied my voyeurism on this list by now...
So here comes a lengthy introduction of myself...I suggest the easily bored
press "delete"...


Let's see...my name is Kevin....I am 23, I moved here last September to
start work doing multimedia stuff...
I grew up in Dallas, TX...lived there until I was 18 and then moved to
Austin....
By that time I had started going to a lot of clubs and getting into the DJ
culture....
But once I was in Austin I really got into it...myself and a group of
friends started throwing some great raves....that was a really fun
time....The atmosphere was a lot different back in '89-'93(not that it is
bad now...).

Well, after too many late nights and to many drugs, I slowly moved away
from that scene and more into the indie-rock scene, which I had also been
into for a long time...
I started a band ( we were into the My Bloody Valentine/Slowdivey/spacey
British style stuff) that lasted for over a year...but then we broke up, I
graduated from film school in '94, and was off to London.  I spent a good
year working for a film production co. in London before I decided to stop
being an illegal alien and move back to Austin.  Well, after HTML coding in
Austin for a few months, I got offered this job...doing digital audio and
video for CNET: The Computer Network....
Anyway, I am stoked to be here in SF...it's a great city....
UNfortunately, I moved out here alone, have been working quite a bit since
i moved, and of the few friends I have had time to make, not many are into
this scene...
Hence, I have not made it too many parties....But I want to badly!
Also...although many have expressed opposition, I think that the Thursday
Noght Booze-fest sounds like a lot of fun....I'm definately gonna try to
make the next one...
I would like to check out the Harmony party, but do not have much info. on
it or tix...
SO hopefully I will be able to meet some of you guys soon....
Well...I guess I will stop babbling now and let you get back to your life...

Thanks for reading...hope to see you guys soon.....

Kevin Wood
=========================
NEWS.COM multimedia
CNET:The Computer Network
http://www.news.com
(415)395-7805 ext:2155
kwood@cnet.com
=========================

THIS IS STILL NRR, AND THIS WILL BE MY LAST POST TO SFRAVES IN THIS THREAD.
Sorry for shouting, but I know that continuing this thread here is already
pushing it, NRR disclaimer notwithstanding.

>During that time that you were bashing the gay-bashers (good for you,
>BTW!)
>Didn't you *once* feel that you were showing them that there were some 
>intelligent and articulate people out there completely disagreed with 
>them and could present well thought-out arguments as to why?  Do you 
>really think that not even *one* of them stopped for a moment to review 
>what it was that they were standing for?  To rethink their position?

The guys I was flaming?  No, I don't think any of them rethought anything
whatsoever.  If that had been my goal I would have gotten pretty depressed
at my profound lack of progress.  None of them, to my recollection, ever
changed their points in any significant way.  Flame wars are not rational
debates; they're shouting matches.

>Bring'em on.  Yeah, that may be asking for trouble, but hell, if I was
>worried about that I wouldn't have posted my views in the first place.

And you're comfortable including sfraves in that dynamic?  I'm not.

>that you sometimes have to fire right back with enough support to make
>the bozos of the world stop and reflect for a moment on what it is they
>stand for.

I agree with this in general; if you feel moved to flame a racist bozo,
go for it.  But don't think that you will succeed in making them stop
and reflect.  I've seldom seen a flaming e-bozo whose mind worked like
that.

>I guess I expect them to stay under their rock and leave the more intelligent 
>people of the world alone.

Rest assured they feel the same way about you :-O

On Sun, 12 Jan 1997, leftjab wrote:

> last night, another west oakland "rave" was shut down by the cops at about
> 1 am, even though it was at someone's house, there was little if any
> publicity (just a word-of-mouth phone #), there was no one else in the
> neighborhood to be bothered by the not-so-loud noise, the place wasn't that
> crowded or unsafe, and the cops didn't seem to find anything wrong in their
> flashlight walk-through -- although someone did say the cops said something
> about underage drinking.
[snips]
> I asked one policeman why the party was being shut down and he said
> "couldn't tell you," which to me sums up the problem.

	Let's see. Some of us had a lengthy discussion with a couple of 
them. One of them was the bad boy cop who "likes to things just like this", 
the other was the duty officer. Please note that both like to "party".

	The main reason that they sited for busting us was money was taken
at the door. Because money was taken at the door, it was a business and
businesses need permits. There were no permits so the "business" was shut
down. So we argued that these were donations and things should then be
able to continue right? First, they thought any type of donation system
was basicly a pile of shit - if money is taken at the door, it cannot be
called donation, you have to have a basket or, I guess it was termed if we
"passed the hat around", money would not have been an issue.
	Item number 1, if money is exchanging hands, the local governments
want some. Fair enough, I will make a personal contribution. More than
half of the budget for the party?! How do we pay for things like rent for
the space and space prep (something like $3000 will put sheet rock in the
place so we are not getting covered in insulation), sound maintance (I
have this little container I put all my money into which goes to things
like drivers that get blown up at Burning Man because certain jungle DJs
from the Bay Area think red lights are pretty and then refuse to help pay
for woofers that get fried in the process - sorry, I do not flame people
often but I still kinda sore on that one, or work on cabinents as the wood
gets pounded into flakey bits, or new equipment to get more sound out of
the same system, or fix amps as capicators and transformers degrade from
heat), power bills, and lighting? 

	So then the second thing that came up was alcohol. The promoters 
should have been checking ID so no minors could have gotten alcohol, a 
system of hand stamping or the like needed to be in place.... Promoters 
were not serving alcohol, no one was "serving" alcohol. This had no 
impact, there was at least 2 six packs of alcoholic beverages found at 
the site (which was someone's home, their stuff was neatly tucked away 
for the party). So even everyone should have been marked to make sure 
that no minors recieved a sip of those 2 six packs...
	So then we have a lengthy exchange about obtaining permits. First 
the place is not up to fire codes, first real peice of "law" that we can 
be busted for I guess. Then we talk about permits more, about difficulty 
in obtaining, about run around, about how stupid it is to need permits to 
have more than 50 people come into your house (now how do coops and the 
like have 100+ person parties with money taken at the door? Nancy?). Then 
one of the cops says something about "maybe they are trying to discourage 
you from doing these" in this snickering tone of voice... Is that their 
place someone asks and we get no answer...

dave

> We've gone on and on about this, and it's time to figure out what to do
> (suggestion # 1 -- no more UG Oakland raves until we get some
> clarification). I really want to know what went on last night, and what
> justification cops have for shutting down a party in someone's HOUSE, no
> matter how warehouse-y the place and rave-y the party.  Don't they need a
> warrant to enter a private residence, or is volume and a party enough of an
> excuse (or did they get informed consent from the owner)?   Would the cops
> have busted my parents growing up because they let me have alcohol with
> dinner before I was of age and listen to music loud with friends over?
> What if I asked my friends for "donations"?

On Fri, 10 Jan 1997, Pengo wrote:

> Maybe I just haven't been reading enough SFR postings, and this has
> already been disussed, but to me, this sounds like a BIG DEAL! What
> these indicators are pointing at is the very real posibilty that some
> types of Electronic Dance Music may go MAINSTREAM! I have no idea.
> however, what I should think of this. Is this a good thing? Or will the
> music become generic and watered down and played out? Anyone have
> thoughts on this?

	Here we deal with the a thread that has been touched on and 
confronted quite often - how does one deal with the spread of something that 
has meaning to them which will most likely lose its meaning in the method 
that will be employed to spread it (radio stations, MTV, what's the 
difference?)... Whenever a message is spread without the experience that 
allows that message to be understood, how do people expect to have people 
take that message into their lives if those people were to choose to do 
so? But that right there should send light bulbs up over everyones head's 
because MTV is not trying to spread any message except buy the stuff in 
the commericals between the videos.
	So who cares what MTV shows? What is all this worry about about 
MTV screwing up raves? How is it going to make it any different than it 
is currently? Raves attract a great range of people to all kinds of 
events. There is a range of promoters out there as well, from greedy to 
people who pay out of their own pocket to make parties go off. How is 
that going to change?
	I guess more people could find out about some smaller parties. So 
people might have to be a little more careful about where they drop 
flyers and people who go out might have to be a little more careful about 
causing a scence but these are skills that most people hopefully already 
have if they are going to renegade type parties, or any illegal parties 
really (my judgement sorry).
	My judgements aside, what are people really worried about? A 
message not getting across because the people who "get it" out number 
those who "don't"? Possibly a valid point depending on what your 
definition of "getting it is", and how the party is promoted. Are people 
worried that they just cannot here someone listening to house or techno 
and assume they must be cool? If so, I think MTV is a great thing because 
it will force raver types to learn to take their plurry concepts and test 
them out (ok, sorry, that is another judgement on my part)... Back to the 
question. Are people worried that more artists will be selling out? Look 
at labels/artists like Network 23, look at the FNB party at Ceasar's. 
Those guys don't have tons of money, there are not million dollar 
contract bearing label people breaking down their doors, but they made 
people dance, and the people danced to 165+ bpm for over an hour. That is 
unheard of in SF....
	I don't have a TV let alone cable to get MTV so I could care less
what MTV plays. I will keep doing what I do, and hope there are some 
other people doing the same types of things at the same times... If the 
cops keep pushing me further away, I will keep setting up a system behind 
Travis Air force base and hopefully people will still be willing to drive 
that far...

dave

	Hi all --

	I'm Jason, but all my friends call me Zza.
	This has to do with the frequency and quantity of pizza I eat.
	I've actually beat a larger opponent in a pizza eating contest,
	but we both agreed it was the dumbest thing we had ever done and
	will never do it again: so no challenges!!  Chicago is my Mecca.
	Well I guess we all have fetishes...

	I've just moved to SF from DC (actually Centreville VA) and have
	added to my truths of life -- 

	The grass _IS_ greener on the other side of the Sierras.
	(I've been told this actually holds multiple meanings)

	My other truth is --

	Everything is better with techno.
	(Probably won't get too much disagreement here, but I was able to 
	persuade my buddies in DC when after too many hours of Olympic
	figure skating and gymnastics I hit mute and played some jungle)

	

	Anyway...
	I always seem to be wearing some horizontal stripe surf T-shirt, 
	comfy airwalks, and some sorta pants. So say hi!


	PLUR

	Zza

>at the door. Because money was taken at the door, it was a business and
>businesses need permits. There were no permits so the "business" was shut
>down. So we argued that these were donations and things should then be

>> We've gone on and on about this, and it's time to figure out what to do
>> (suggestion # 1 -- no more UG Oakland raves until we get some
>> clarification). I really want to know what went on last night, and what
>> justification cops have for shutting down a party in someone's HOUSE, no
>> matter how warehouse-y the place and rave-y the party.  Don't they need a
>> warrant to enter a private residence, or is volume and a party enough of an
>> excuse (or did they get informed consent from the owner)?   Would the cops
>> have busted my parents growing up because they let me have alcohol with
>> dinner before I was of age and listen to music loud with friends over?
>> What if I asked my friends for "donations"?






Hmmm.  This talk of protecting parties from busts becomes increasingly
difficult with further growth of the scene.  Although, what about falling
under the protection of religous rights and the freedom to assemble?  A
true rave very much resembles or some might say _is_ a religion.  The same
people attending week after week and contriubting their "tithe" to support
the "church."   There certainly are leaders -  the dj's, who in other
religions would be considered as shamans or priests administering the power
of togetherness to celebrate life through musik.   An very familiar
attribute given to dj's...especially if he/she knows what they are doing.
Many more analogies can be made, I'm sure.   Stretching the truth?
Perhaps.   It seems fairly close to me.   Convincing authourities is an
entirely different matter.   Heathens, we would be called.  These busts
sound a lot like the stories we were told as children of the "communists"
shutting down churches in Russia.  Call me crazy.  It's been done before.
:)


BTW, someone extended an invitation of introduction.  I've been mostly
lurking for the past few weeks but I recently moved with my girlfriend to
the Bay Area from Greensboro, NC.  (no, not everything you've heard about
NC is true <g>)  So a belated hello to the list...I look forward to meeting
many of you.  The stories of F&F parties and Sunsets have been told around
many a early morning afterparty even 3000 miles away.

-Nate

Hi all!  ]=)

 I finally got around digging my tape deck out of storage where it was 
sitting with the rest of my equipment. So the first things I doz is check 
out the fresh DJ Moda tape I recieved from Sir Moda.

 Phat, fresh and clean!  =) An immaculant (sp?) tape (no rude noises) 
with some _tasty_ tracks on it. An interesting progressive house blend 
that manages to be happy AND intelligant. NOT an easy trick!

 I was really swimming during some of the tracks; wish I knew the names 
so I could tell you more. Side two at about 5 minutes into it is _really_ 
fun. I highly recommend this tape if you like progressive house!! the 
opening of side one has some _nice_ ambience to gently lift you off.

 I would like to hear some of this kinda stuff at a 
Harmony/Tigger/Beautiful People party sometime! Are you listening Greg 
and Matt?

 Nice cover on the case also. I'm sure DJ Moda has some more tapes. If 
you send him a blank you could probably sweet talk him into running off a 
copy for you at no charge.  =)


peas,


Ran D.Dreams

Subject: Re: Busted...

Next time you have a party and the police come, go outside and shut the
door behind you and ask them what they need from you. When they give you
shit, tell them this is a private party in somebody's residence and you are
willing to observe noise rules, etc. but you are not ending the party AND
THEY ARE NOT INVITED INSIDE.

With regard to liquor, it is perfectly legal for a minor to consume liquor
inside a private residence, so that excuse it right out.

If they give you any trouble, go back inside and lock the door behind you.

If they break down the door, teach them the meaning of "direct
representation style democracy" and pop a few caps into them! As G. Gordon
Liddy says, "Aim for the head in case they're wearing body armor."

And lastly, make sure that they fall *inside* the doorway so that you can
make the claim that you were defending your residence from attack from
intruders.

Fucking police.

signs off the highway to "highway 1" north to U.C. Santa Cruz

go thru, and make the very first right into the west remote parking lot
and the closest buildings (wooden looking) is Oakes College,
my apartment is Casa Kahlo (A block) in the apartment area, #14

we'll have music playin all day! YEEAH!


come and kick it on friday, we'd love to Have ya!!!!  
bring reccords, music, snacks, whatver if ya can :) :)

Hi all!  ]=)


 Well, I'm just about ready to flip. It might be that the news that I'm 
about to share with you all may come to naught but oh to have the chance...

 Some of you out there may have heard of Richard Sun from the Ambient 
Temple of I*Magi*Nation, Mystery School. Richard was a big developer of 
the ambient scene in the chill rooms of SF's bigger parties during the 
heydays of, say, 1990 to about '94? He has a few CD's out. I have his 
first (Mystery School) which I often use in chill rooms.

 Richard and crew were performing at The Gathering just a little while 
back (with yours truely putting in a guest prformance).

 Anyway, Richard has asked me to represent ATOI here in the SF Bay area 
while he is living in Portland Oregon. I'll be popping over at GaiaMind 
to help out there. Richard has also mentioned that he _may_ be touring 
Europe this summer and if he does he would like me to go with him and 
perform also. (!!!!!!!!!!!!!!) wow.

 Anyway, it seems the seeds I've been sowing with Dionysus Dreams may be 
finally coming to fruit! If I do get a chance to go I'm certainly going 
to want to check out the psi-trance scene there. I would especially like 
to get over to Israel but that may be out of our way.

I'm soooooo fucking excited!!!

smiles,


Ran D.Dreams

Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com> wrote:
>> ...tell them this is a private party in somebody's residence and you are
>> willing to observe noise rules, etc. but you are not ending the party AND
>> THEY ARE NOT INVITED INSIDE.
>>
>> Fucking police.
>
>	Oh right! Sure, I'll do that at my house. <sarcasm alert!>
>
>	And when the cops gets pissed off, and come in anyway on some
>plausible pretext, and find some of the illegal things that some of
>the people are holding, I'm sure you'll be the first say "Fucking police."
>as you slink away as unobtrusively as possible.
>
>	As long as it's a drug scene, the PLUR-balls are going to cave
>in every single time they're confronted by the cops.

I don't know about Wayne or anyone else, and I may not be a PLUR-ball (this
probably proves it), but I'm happy to say "fucking police," and I've said
it before and I'll say it again, to their very faces.  And yeah, it'll get
you beat.  I've been beat, fined, jailed, probated, and fucked with by
every instrument The Law can command.  But I'll keep on fucking with them
just the same.  Because I don't care about The Law.  I don't care about the
law, I don't care about legality, I don't care about government, I don't
even care about morality, good and evil, right and wrong...that's nothing
to me.  I live my life the best I can.  Hagbard Celine (someone here knows
who I'm talking about, right?) said that true freedom is the ability to
say, "No."  What happens doesn't matter-- consequences are external.  If
you can say no, if you can accept the consequences, all of them, all the
way up to and including your own death, then you are truly free.

Lucky for me, the way my society is arranged hasn't required me to face
death, yet (no, I don't know if I could face it and maintain...please don't
bother asking).  I live as hard as I can for my own ideals within my own
situation, which probably makes zero difference to humanity-- but I would
stand up to police for a party.  I maybe wouldn't write so stridently, but
this message happens to come at a time when I've been dreaming (or
fantasizing is maybe the better word) about a party that really would stand
up to authority and make the case for its own independence.  I'm not a
promoter, I don't know anything about what's involved, but that's what I'd
like to see.  Fundamentally, I want to see people, individually or as
groups, not just claiming but *demanding* responsibility for themselves.  A
rave is a perfect (but far from the only) example of a situation in which a
group of people have insulated themselves from the rest of society/humanity
in order to live as they see fit-- that's one of the things I like about
raving, in fact one of the things I think is essential to raving.  That's
the spirit I'd like to see spreading.

anarch@scruznet.com

At 12:21 AM 1/14/97 -0800, Rob Rayle wrote:
>This text was from <wayne@club.net>...
>> Next time you have a party and the police come, go outside and shut the
>> door behind you and ask them what they need from you. When they give you
>> shit, tell them this is a private party in somebody's residence and you are
>> willing to observe noise rules, etc. but you are not ending the party AND
>> THEY ARE NOT INVITED INSIDE.
>>
>> Fucking police.
>
>	Oh right! Sure, I'll do that at my house. <sarcasm alert!>
>
>	And when the cops gets pissed off, and come in anyway on some
>plausible pretext, and find some of the illegal things that some of
>the people are holding, I'm sure you'll be the first say "Fucking police."
>as you slink away as unobtrusively as possible.
>
>	As long as it's a drug scene, the PLUR-balls are going to cave
>in every single time they're confronted by the cops. 
>
>	If those who will trade freedom for security deserve neither, 
>what do those who'll trade their civil rights for a hit of E on Saturday 
>night deserve?

IMO, this is kinda taken to the extreme, on both Rob and wayne's parts. Not
a flame, jus' trying to find the balance. Isn't there a balance somewhere
in the middle? My rambling version would go something like this:

  The pigs show up and they are pissed. They are banging the crap outta
your door. You go to the door with at least two of your friends
(witnesses). Go outside and close the door (good thinking, wayne) No matter
how much of jerks the cops are, the three (or more) of you are totally
cooperative and friendly. They will calm down if you remain calm. If they
insist on entering or busting the party, kindly remind them of the points
wayne has already mentioned and tell them your not interested in having
them join your party. I'd say "ya know, I think most officers are a lot of
fun, but we already have a few inside". ;) There is really no "plausible
pretext" for them to enter your house. Defending your civil liberties
doesn't mean you have to kill them.   You could simply pick up the phone
and call the ACLU or your lawyer. ;) Actually, I have found that calling
the police in advance is a good idea. You can ask them about some parking
regulations or something and then mention you are having a little party and
give them your name and phone number, "in case there are any noise
complaint". The lazy cops will love you for it. Now they can sit in their
office, eating donuts and drinking coffee. When they get a complaint, all
they hafta do is pickup the phone, easy. ;) Little work for them to do at all.
  If they bust the door down and you have witnesses, the city or somebody
is going to have to pay for it, eventually. AND, if u have enough money you
could prolly take 'em to the supreme court and make some difference in some
way. BUT, IMO, if u r cooperative and kewl with them, they will leave you
alone. I usually find a mix of respect and complete lack of fear work best.
  I guess, that I think: once they are in there and everyone is freakin'
they have you by the nads, but if you don't fear them, they have no power
over you. Most cops enjoy the power trip that they attempt to exhibit. If
you don't feed their power trip, they get no satisfaction. Offer them some
candy or something nifty and spread the love. That will really blow their
minds. Pigs need love too. :)

/* plur */
  matter


I was a lesbian before my sex change. ;)

Don't believe the hype. I think what we all need to do is pony up some
cash for a consultation with a civil-rights attorney to find out what our
sometimes seemingly non-existant rights are on these issues. The police
will walk all over them if we are ignorant of them. 

Please offer any suggestions of questions that should be asked, and if you
know the name of a good civil-rights attorney, let me know. I am willing
to put up $100 towards answering some of these questions. Any donations
towards the consultation gladly accepted. All questions that are
posed/answered will be posted here for the benifit of us all. If others
are interested in attending, please let me know.

I for one am tired of being ignorant.

                                          Black Adder

>I think that Mr. Wayne is correct in stating that police can be confronted

>warehouse event.  The police showed (with a wagon and all). I stood outside
>the door explaining that it was a private party, no money was being taken @
>the door, only thirty or so people were in there (Actually, it was moreso
>around 200 people).  Allthough the police didn't belive a word of it they
>informed me to keep the music down or I'd be "taken in".  Since the door was
>closed the officer had no probabile cause to enter.  The call was a noise
>complaint which is an infractionable offense.  I was sober (which was clearly
>evident) so the cops couldn't assume drugs were in the local.  But most of
>all I was in CONTROL and had an answer for evety question the had...  The
>party contenued till end (about 8Am-or-so) and everyone had a kwel time.

Date: Tue, 14 Jan 1997 12:07:16 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <199701142007.MAA16896@atari.saturn5.com>
From: Steve Simitzis <steve@saturn5.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, sfr-legal@saturn5.com
Subject: mail list announce: SFR-legal
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Mailing list annoucement: SFR-legal (sfr-legal@saturn5.com)

A couple of weeks ago, I proposed a new mailing list to organize some
action in the city of San Francisco to end the criminalization of our
rave scene... Well, I received quite a bit of response, so it's clear
that there's a strong need to get this going.

With that, I present the new mailing list:

sfr-legal@saturn5.com

(an offshoot of SFRaves) This list will serve the role of providing a
forum for discussing what is legal or not and what sorts of changes
can be made in the effort of saving our scene. In addition, it will
serve as a way of organizing meetings and generating some political
action in the city of San Francisco.

To join the list, please send email to:

sfr-legal-request@saturn5.com
with a single line that says "subscribe"

(the standard majordomo commands will work)

Or, alternately, send mail to majordomo@saturn5.com with the line:
subscribe sfr-legal <email address>

Note that all messages will have the tag SFRL: in the subject line
(great for you filter folks). Please also note that you if sent a
message previously asking to be added to the list, you will still need
to subscribe through majordomo. Also, all messages are archived. I
will eventually create something on my web server for downloading
these archives.

I hope to see many of you loudmouths ;) on this list subscribe. I'm
not looking for high volume, just a group of highly outspoken and
motivated individuals who care enough about the rave scene in San
Francisco to help generate some change and clarify many of the issues
with respect to the legality of throwing parties.

Finally, this is not a "down with the Man!" sort of thing. It's time
that we start to acknowledge how important it is to act responsibly in
accordance to existing laws, while remembering at the same time that
we have the right as citizens to actually change the laws that govern
us.

Thanks!

Steve

-- 
Steve Simitzis |   steve@saturn5.com   ||   steve@eff.org   | "Hup!" - R. Crumb

At 9:38 AM -0800 1/14/97, Eric P. Peterson wrote:
>>Next time you have a party and the police come, go outside and shut the
>>door behind you and ask them what they need from you. When they give you
>>shit, tell them this is a private party in somebody's residence and you are
>>willing to observe noise rules, etc. but you are not ending the party AND
>>THEY ARE NOT INVITED INSIDE.
>>
>[snip]
>Two words: probable cause.

Excuse me, but Probably Cause of-or-for what?

Do the presence of turntables == the presence of underage kids drinking? I
have turntables and a mixer in my home, and I am 30. There are never
underage kids drinking at my home (and it's *still* none of the police's
business if there *are*) although there is often loud thumping beats coming
from my place.

rule #1. No matter what, do not ever, ever invite the police inside any
place, -any- until they tell you exactly what their probable cause is to
require entry. They are required to tell you. And once you let them in, you
have effectively waived your rights to privacy. That means if they wander
around your house and see something else that is suspicious, that is
admissable because you invited them inside. The same goes for your
automobile.

I really think that we need to talk to the ACLU about this before assuming
much more else.

At 11:45 AM -0600 1/14/97, matter wrote:
>At 12:21 AM 1/14/97 -0800, Rob Rayle wrote:

>IMO, this is kinda taken to the extreme, on both Rob and wayne's parts. Not
>a flame, jus' trying to find the balance. Isn't there a balance somewhere
>in the middle? My rambling version would go something like this:
>
>  The pigs show up and they are pissed. They are banging the crap outta
>your door. You go to the door with at least two of your friends
>(witnesses). Go outside and close the door (good thinking, wayne) No matter
>how much of jerks the cops are, the three (or more) of you are totally
>cooperative and friendly. They will calm down if you remain calm. If they
>insist on entering or busting the party, kindly remind them of the points
>wayne has already mentioned and tell them your not interested in having
>them join your party. I'd say "ya know, I think most officers are a lot of
>fun, but we already have a few inside". ;) There is really no "plausible
>pretext" for them to enter your house. Defending your civil liberties
>doesn't mean you have to kill them.   You could simply pick up the phone
>and call the ACLU or your lawyer. ;) Actually, I have found that calling
>the police in advance is a good idea. You can ask them about some parking
>regulations or something and then mention you are having a little party and
>give them your name and phone number, "in case there are any noise
>complaint". The lazy cops will love you for it. Now they can sit in their
>office, eating donuts and drinking coffee. When they get a complaint, all
>they hafta do is pickup the phone, easy. ;) Little work for them to do at all.
>  If they bust the door down and you have witnesses, the city or somebody
>is going to have to pay for it, eventually. AND, if u have enough money you
>could prolly take 'em to the supreme court and make some difference in some
>way. BUT, IMO, if u r cooperative and kewl with them, they will leave you
>alone. I usually find a mix of respect and complete lack of fear work best.
>  I guess, that I think: once they are in there and everyone is freakin'
>they have you by the nads, but if you don't fear them, they have no power
>over you. Most cops enjoy the power trip that they attempt to exhibit. If
>you don't feed their power trip, they get no satisfaction. Offer them some
>candy or something nifty and spread the love. That will really blow their
>minds. Pigs need love too. :)

This description of a way to manage the police is a little more what I was
hoping for when I went 'postal' back there in my earlier message. I don't
actually advocate violence toward police, but I was trying to emphasize in
a very extreme way that we do have certain rights to gather in private in
our own homes. In this case, I think someone should have at least kept the
police outside of the residence. Once you allow them in to look around, you
have effectively consented to a search of your place (or car, etc.) that
you are not necessarily compelled to do. Because the police hears music,
they don't have the right to see if you are charging (or accpeting
donations, for instance) or if there are minors present, although it seems
that younger people are more easily intimidated to let the police infringe
on their rights more quickly than adults seem to allow.

I have had parties in my place before, and even with my place slamming and
bursting at the seams, I met them *outside my unit, outside my building* to
discuss their concerns, and for the most part, it worked. In one case I did
have to tell about half or more of the people to leave due to crowding but
the party did not have to end "just because they said so."

I think it would be a really good idea to find a civil rights attorney that
could either do some pro-bono or reduced rate work to find out just what
are rights are in say, San Francisco and Oakland so we're not simply hoping
or guessing what are fate is or should be next time we're visited by the
police. With specific rights info in hand we'd have a much better time
"managing" the police next time they show up at one of our homes with a
party-in-progress or one of our underground events.

I work for a nonprofit specializing in civil liberties issues, so I am
going to try to find out if there's an easier way to have a party if you
are say, a legitimate non-profit corporation. I would not mind throwing
parties that benefit one or more of that type of organization. Would you?

-w
