From: toddm@alienskin.com (Todd Morman)
Subject: Legal stuff/Visiting Boy sez thanks!
Date: Thu, 16 Jan 1997 16:21:38 -0500
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Just wanted to let y'all know that I had a great time in your city while I
was at Macworld. Hugs to all the cool folks who emailed suggestions for
parties and clubs, and to everyone who stopped by the Alien Skin booth to
say hey. We ended up seeing MixMaster Morris one night (amazing drum 'n'
bass mixing), Dubtribe one night (met lotsa cool people), and popped our
heads into a couple of other clubs on other nights. And the record stores!
Wow. I'm trying to convince my boss to move the company out there from NC.
Anyway, I'm gonna have to sign off again, so thanks to everyone who made
our visit more fun. I'll be thinking of you when I'm dancing to your boy
Carlos tomorrow night in Durham... :)

Glad to see, btw, that there's smart talk about dealing with cops on this
list. I'm on the dcraves and seraves lists, too, and similar things are
happening in Atlanta and Baltimore, with cops hassling legal parties at
clubs, and ravers not knowing just what their rights really are. Maybe
there should be a central place for sharing strategies, like Hyperreal
(although lately hyperreal's seemed kind of a static site). I do know that
the folks who run Buzz, a regular party in Baltimore, wrote about some
success in going to the city council with their complaints about the cops.
I don't know those folks, but if anyone wants contact info for them, just
email me and I'll dig it up.

S wrote:
>"Toughguy".  As in, "the rave sucked because there were too many
>toughguys hanging out, creating a negative vibe with their 'don't
>even look at me, punk' attitudes."

A friend of mine in Chapel Hill calls them "evil ravers". We laugh all the
time about it; the evil ravers can be nice people, but get them at a party
and they're all sneer. I don't get it.

todd we usually leave them alone and go find the happy ones morman

"The trouble with avant garde music is that it has lost its original
meaning and now has as many rules and clichs as country or rock & roll.
If in 50 years time they will look back at the early 1980s, or whenever,
and say that was the new avant garde era, that event must be avoided if
we are to remain true." - William Bennett

THE TOP TEN EUPHEMISMS FOR PEOPLE WITH NEGATIVE ATTITUDES AT RAVES:

RAVES:

1.  The Un-Hamsta.

Received: from localhost (sidewalk@localhost) by uclink2.berkeley.edu (8.8.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id PAA09209 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 16 Jan 1997 15:38:25 -0800
Date: Thu, 16 Jan 1997 15:38:23 -0800 (PST)
From: Timothy McIntyre <sidewalk@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: raves going overground
Message-ID: <Pine.ULT.3.93.970116150206.2722A-100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


tim raises his hand in sfr class and curiously asks:

Okay, assume these premises are correct:

	1) Raves are a good thing which generally have a positive effect 
	   on people who attend them.
	2) If more people in this world raved, then the world would
	   be a better place.
	3) There is no one singular message to be 'gotten' from raves,
	   because everyone sees things differently; therefore, you
	   cannot ever say snobbily about someone, they don't 'get' raves.

Okay, if you accept these (and you may not), then is it a net positive 
for there to be more raves in our society; i.e., raves go mainstream?

Are we ravers in any position to always rail against 'the man' and 
lament the mainstream's inability to to be as open to new ideas as 
ravers tend to be, but then not teach the mainstrea about all the 
beautiful things that we've learned, when, after all this time, they're
finally knocking on our door?
And, if we want to teach others about what raves are all about,
will we be patient enough to put up with their extreme level of
newbie-ness, or do we say, oh, they're all money-grubbers, blah 
blah blah, keep it underground and all that?

I'm not trying to be belligerent here or anything, I just keep
thinking about this all the time.  Rave culture, however that's
defined, is oozing onto radio airwaves and television stations
and websites (certainly in a heavily-formatted kind of way, yes)
but the influence is undeniably there.   

Sorry to stretch this mainstream thread a little further, but I 
can't help it!  It's *so* weird--SF was the epicenter for the
political revolution of the late 1960's, and now it looks as if
it's going to be home to a major cultural shift.
Cool, huh? 

(please discuss)

PLUR,
Timothy


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jan 16 16:11:06 1997

Timothy McIntyre wrote:

> tim raises his hand in sfr class...
> ...Are we ravers in any position to always rail against 'the man' and
> lament the mainstream's inability to to be as open to new ideas as
> ravers tend to be, but then not teach the mainstrea about all the
> beautiful things that we've learned, when, after all this time, they're
> finally knocking on our door?

SDream walks over and raps Mr. McIntyre across the knuckles with a
ruler:

Tim, that's a beautiful sentiment, but that's not what's happening.
Rave music is going mainstream, not the rave mentality or the rave
vibe.  It's the difference between a cheetah, alive, beautiful, prowling 
the African plains, rippling power and speed, one of nature's most
refined predators, and a mangey, moth-eaten, dead cheetah head 
stuffed and mounted on a board and hanging in someone's den.

Knowhatahmean?

But, and this is just me speaking, the rave culture in part lives for
it's music, and you just know that once that music has been captured
by a major fashion vendor like MTV, skinned, cleaned, stuffed, and
mounted in a publicly consumable pose, it will be a far cry from 
the wild, powerful, rippling, thunder-clap of raw energy that you
see in it's natural habitat.  And, to me at least, that's a rather 
repulsive thought.

S

I just wanted to say that, in retrospect, I have lost my kewl about two
issues on the list already. If u read this stuff, u know what I'm talking
about. Sorry if my intensity (or stupidity) has been a negative. I try to
keep it on the up and up, but it doesn't always work. I hope you all
understand. :D I sent a private mail to Randy to apologize for going off as
well. I can't promise it won't happen again, but I can say that I always
mean to do what I think is for the best. Finally after chilling a bit, I
actually found that virus hoax to be a little funny. I never took the time
to consider that the person who wrote it was prolly as annoyed with the
whole good times hoax as I was. :)

On Thu, 16 Jan 1997, Timothy McIntyre wrote:

> tim raises his hand in sfr class and curiously asks:
> 
> Okay, assume these premises are correct:

[. . .]

Tim's pretty optimistic -- and I hope that he's right.  But I fear he's
not.  The people at MTV, etc, who are pushing rave music / clothing are
pushing "Product".  They are salesmen and they don't care if you pick up
any values about tolerance along the way.  They would just as soon be
selling grunge or coca-cola or levis.

You can't make a buck off of selling spirituality (at least to young
people :)

-Matt

But I doth protest! (comments below)

On Thu, 16 Jan 1997, SDream wrote:

> Timothy McIntyre wrote:
> 
> > tim raises his hand in sfr class...
> > ...Are we ravers in any position to always rail against 'the man' and
> > lament the mainstream's inability to to be as open to new ideas as
> > ravers tend to be, but then not teach the mainstrea about all the
> > beautiful things that we've learned, when, after all this time, they're
> > finally knocking on our door?
> 
> SDream walks over and raps Mr. McIntyre across the knuckles with a
> ruler:
> 
> Tim, that's a beautiful sentiment, but that's not what's happening.
> Rave music is going mainstream, not the rave mentality or the rave
> vibe.  It's the difference between a cheetah, alive, beautiful, prowling 
> the African plains, rippling power and speed, one of nature's most
> refined predators, and a mangey, moth-eaten, dead cheetah head 
> stuffed and mounted on a board and hanging in someone's den.
> 
> Knowhatahmean?
> 
> But, and this is just me speaking, the rave culture in part lives for
> it's music, and you just know that once that music has been captured
> by a major fashion vendor like MTV, skinned, cleaned, stuffed, and
> mounted in a publicly consumable pose, it will be a far cry from 
> the wild, powerful, rippling, thunder-clap of raw energy that you
> see in it's natural habitat.  And, to me at least, that's a rather 
> repulsive thought.

   Well, I don't want to turn this into an aesthetic judgment debate,
because those don't ever go anywhere, but, well, I'm not entirely 
convinced that the stuff on MTV right now is crap.  I watched a pretty
kick-ass Orbital song/video as well as something from Underworld,
and it didn't strike me as watered-down at all.  People really *like*
the "wild, rippling, powerful, thunder-clap" stuff, and I think 
(well, more like hope, perhaps) that mass media won't dilute the stuff
very much at all.
Of course, it'll never match the feel of being 8 feet in front of an
Ethan or John Carel, sweat pouring down your face, feet stamping the floor
as hard as they can go, but maybe it's at least one little step in the
right direction?
naively optimistic, perhaps, but optimistic nonetheless,
Timothy



> 
> S
>

On Thu, 16 Jan 1997, Matthew James Plunkett wrote:

> Tim's pretty optimistic -- and I hope that he's right.  But I fear he's
> not.  The people at MTV, etc, who are pushing rave music / clothing are
> pushing "Product".  They are salesmen and they don't care if you pick up
> any values about tolerance along the way.  They would just as soon be
> selling grunge or coca-cola or levis.

	I wonder if the people at MTV would agree with you. As far as some
of them, they were ground breaking people bringing all types of music to
more people than ever before, giving airtime to the "under-represented"
artists on Liquid TV. And now, they are giving air time to the next
under-represented form of music out there (in their opinion?)... How is
this different than say local "rave" mags purportedly reporting on
something like Burning Man, or even, on what is going on in the rave
community? Is it any different? It still seems to be trying to take 
certain events, >remove them from their context<, and dump them on a page 
for your eyes to feast on... Ok, that's a little harsh, but I just wanted 
to point out the parallels...
	MTV is spreading music. Are they claiming to spread rave? Are 
they saying this is what is playing at those ultra-hip (or whatever the 
latest cool word actually is) rave parties or are they saying, here is 
some ambient, neat huh? Like I have said, I do not have access to MTV 
(although I do watch star trek on a friends TV I will admit) so I do not 
know how it is being presented...
	I do have a question. In everyone who yells that everything is 
horrible now that techno is being picked up by mainstream media types, 
how much energy are each of us putting into making sure the kind of party 
that we are interested in still exists? How many people are now on the 
sfr-legal list? How many were yelling about New Year's busts?

dave

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday morning 9am-11am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench. Varied techno sub-genres, noise, spoken word, world
       music. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Can anybody tell me where the good weeklies are? I've been up to S.F. 
(from San Jose) 3 times in a row, looking for six (6) different parties 
that had all posted to the SFRaves Calendar. They were all playing 
different (NON-techno/trance/house/etc) styles of music, such as country, 
ballroom dancing, Sinatra/Martin/Torme-shit...

I would be very grateful for the Names and Numbers for a good Wednesday 
weeklie. I favor trance, but would not be picky. As long as I can find a 
cool party to shake my booty at, I'm good to go.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jan 16 20:06:36 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id UAA28346; Thu, 16 Jan 1997 20:06:36 -0800 (PST)

Received: from beast (d129.netgate.net [205.214.160.168]) by ng.netgate.net (8.8.4/8.6.9) with SMTP id UAA24932 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 16 Jan 1997 20:06:50 -0800 (PST)
Message-ID: <32DEFB30.645E@netgate.net>
Date: Thu, 16 Jan 1997 20:08:16 -0800
From: The Grigsbeast <grigsby@netgate.net>
Reply-To: grigsby@netgate.net
Organization: Ollie's House of Cesium Pantaloons
X-Mailer: Mozilla 3.0Gold (WinNT; I)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: the difference between MTV and the u.g.
References: <Pine.APO.3.91.970116171942.2792C-100000@monsoon.berkeley.edu>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

MTV, or any 'business', exists to make money.  Any entertainment or
value you may get out of it is ancillary; programming is chosen to
attract the maximum number of viewers possible so that they can sell the
advertising for more money.  (In fact, the ONLY function of any
television program is to anesthetize you so deeply that you won't change
the channel when a commercial comes on.  They'd show nothing BUT
commercials if they thought you'd watch it...Home Shopping Channel,
anyone?)

A UG crew needs to take in some money in order to survive, but money
isn't the _reason_ you throw a UG.  You do it 'cause you like it and
hope you don't come out too far behind.

This is a large part of the 'change in vibe' that can be felt when going
between a UG and a regular concert you bought tickets for through BASS. 
If all people care about is the money, they won't get all the details
right, because their energy will go towards ensuring maximum $ intake
(shutting off the sinks and selling water, for instance, or not
permitting anyone to bring in food or water).  If people care about
throwing a good party, they will take care of themselves by making sure
they don't lose their shirts (at least, if they expect to do it more
than once), but most of the energy will still go towards making sure
everyone has the POTENTIAL to have a good time.  Of course, this is no
guarantee, but it's a good start.

// grigs

on wed: Roots at 1015 Folsom.  Jeno and Garth are the main djs, two of the
best (and oldest) of the SF djs.  They don't get boring, these guys.  And
upstairs, some hella PHAT trip-hop style grooves.
this isn't the most lovey-dovey party in the world, but the music cannot be
beat and it goes to around 5am.  get ready to get sweaty.
Bruce

hi everyone,

ive been subscribed to the list for four or five months now and know a few of
you but still dont know many of you, so i thought it would be good to say,
"howdy."

im a part time graduate student at mills college in oakland doing premedical
science stuff. i was a social science/psychology major as an undergrad at a
really small obscure school that no one has ever heard of in western mass.
(simon's rock college) but then decided i wanted to be a medical doctor, so
im catching up.

i also work at children's hospital oakland research institute trying to
figure out ways to help sick kids get better. and one night a week i
volunteer at the berkeley free clinic (a super duper clinic!) as a lab tech.
sooo, when you come in and have to pee in a cup, get your blood sucked, or
have a q-tip stuck in an orifice i get to play with it!!! wohhhh!!! it is
fun!! :-o  i love love love it!

rave type things first bit me this past summer in D.C. i was taken to Buzz by
a friend and, boom!! then i moved to berkeley in august and now i have found
my way into the rave rave rave scene here. yay!!!!! sooooo sooooo very
fine!!!  <:-)  thank you all for making the parties slick and such... 

i hope to see and meet you folks soon, maybe at f8 on friday? im a short
quiet white boy with bleached hair and glasses (sooo unique! ;-)  ) so if you
see me or someone who looks like me go up and say "oooooggggaaaaboooogaaa!".
im sure i, or the person who is not me, would enjoy it tremendously =)  yup.

okay, well, i hope that was not too long and boring.

bye bye, *hug*

jeremy

ps: i used to have the email name thing of:  MarsMyRat and FlyingEggs. so
maybe you might recognize one of those names, but maybe not.

THe folks at MTV could go only so far.  They could package the music, the
clothing style, and proibably some parties (imagine an MTV promoted "rave"
in a sports arena near you.... *GAWK*) but they can NEVER, EVER, EVER

community.  Yeah,  they might make a clone of me that's programmed to pass
out starbursts and give hugs to everyone.... "I am tymat of borg, you will
be assimilated, care for a starburst?"   My point being that MTV's plan to
package our "culture" for profit will have very little success as long as
YOU, the consumer, do not patronize it.

>Hey anthony-

>Kewl man we need more people with the vibe like you at partys =) Hey me and you

>pointers and stuff on the subject or suggest a good book or web site?

>Talk with you latah,

>Macadio G.

I do UNIX security stuff more than ever.  I read code and debug a lot of the
most common UNIX programs.  As far as systems administration there are good
pointers and papers about UNIX sys. admin and UNIX in general at
http://www.bsd.org.  If you've outgrown that kind of stuff you might wanna
get Secrets of the Magic Garden: UNIX System V Internals, a very good book
that can teach you how to find program holes such as buffer overflow or race
conditions that are security hazards in all UNIX systems.  Network wise, I
can suggest TCP/IP Illustrated vols. 1, 2, and 3.  

I will be at the F8 party this friday,  where will you be?  It's really nice
to know that some people appreciate what I do at raves.  As long as people
appreciate it I will continue to do it.  I'm not just trying to help the
vibe I'm also trying to set an example to everyone.  

Hope to meet ya soon!

much love, 
Anthony E

"high!"  hehe.. i've been using that word on IRC lately to greet my friends.

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com

hello all-

haven't we been through this before?


i, matthew d. p. k. lanier, will help anyone who asks me how to filter
their messages, either using a commercial package like eudora, or on their
unix shell account.

if you don't like the e-mail that you get, you have 3 choices:

1)leave

2)filter out offending people/topics (or, be cool like neils and post your
filtering list to sfraves for more people to enjoy!)

3)shut up and deal with your laziness.

i am sick and tired of people constantly critizing the fact that there is
so much nrr mail on sfraves.  first, they enjoy the vibe and good nature
that exists on sfraves, the sense of community, and all that goes with it.
then, they complain about the nrr mail that is, in fact, and significant
contributor to the vibe and good nature that they enjoy.  i am shouting
here, hence my capitals: EITHER TAKE SFRAVES, OR LEAVE SFRAVES, BUT SHUT
UP, DO SOMETHING, AND QUIT YOUR BITCHING!!!

i totally respect those that filter out nrr messages: that's their choice,
and i've made it onto my share of kill files (4 that i'm aware of).  i
totally respect those that decide to read the nrr posts, and enjoy them.
what i don't respect are those who incessantly post about how sfraves isn't
what they like.  unfortunately, sfraves is a living, breathing organism
that has developed a life of it's own.  either accept that life and enjoy
it, (my strategy) or leave it and start your own list.  both are fine.


thank you.  for once, i aggree with john s lee.  i thought the day would
never come ;)

love to you all-

matt l
matthew d. p. k. lanier
professional hugger and empath
independant internet consultant

> From: Sharif Torpis <storpis@crl.com>
> Date: Thu, 16 Jan 1997 23:02:43 -0800 (PST)
> Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

[snippies]

> Who said anything about prohibiting rave family communications? The key here
> is "rave". NRR are not rave related. Don't send them here. The onus should be
> on *you* not to send it, not on me to delete it.

The purpose of NRR, as has been pointed out many times, is to allow a
sense of "online" community among people of similar interests (namely
electronic music and raving).

I understand that the philosophy of "if you don't like it, delete" can
be inconvenient. But thankfully, the "NRR" marking in the subject
provides a way for filters to do the work for you. Filters are a very
non-intrusive addition to anyone's mailing list experience.

Just filter out anything with "NRR" in the Subject, and everyone will
be happy. :)

Steve

             <3.0.32.19970116231605.00e227b0@pop.v-site.net>

To whom it may concern ---

I wish to strongly disagree with a message forwarded to me by
lycos@cybertribe.com, an anonymous cyberspace entity that shreds
radical tunes while lamo suits like yourselves sit around in  dark
offices one-upping each other in puerile competition involving how
tight your ties and collars can get before all traces of normal brain
functioning is cut off.

Here is the contents of a particularly quetionable message that has
come to my attention, probably written during an incredible display of
hypoxic jurisprudence.

>Lycos believes that you have been using the Lycos name including,
>without limitation, in the designations "Sub Commander Lycos" and
>"lycos@cybertribe.com".  Lycos is concerned that this activity
>constitutes, among other things, trademark infringement, trademark
>dilution, and unfair competition under the Lanham Act and/or the common
>law.  This activity may also constitute an unfair or deceptive act or
>practice.
>
> [lawyeresque blather deleted for the good of all mankind]
> 
>Please address correspondence to:
>
>Mark D. Robins, Esq.
>Hutchins, Wheeler & Dittmar
>101 Federal Street
>Boston, MA  02110

I distinctly recall seeing the name "Sub Commander Lycos" as a DJ
and/or rave promoter name from various underground "rave" parties as
far back as maybe '92 or '93. I have a few tapes of "Sub Commander
Lycos" performances from around this timeframe as well. This would
indicate prior use of this name prior to the incorporation of Lycos
Inc, which certainly happened after 1994.

I will be happy to testify to the fact that the word Lycos has 
significant prior use before your supposed trademark. My evidence
includes DAT backup tapes created in 1993/1994 that include internet
mentions of this name prior to the existance of Lycos as a body
corporate (or even as a lamo research project at CMU). Sounds like you
lawyer-folk haven't done a proper prior use search for this word.
(Meanwhile, whois seems to indicate that the record for "lycos.com" was
created on 13-Apr-95.) Perhaps sub commander lycos should be suing you?

Oh, by the way, your search engine lists a few thousand hits of words 
that are trademarked to "Niels P. Mayer" or "Niels Mayer" (feel free to
search for my name on your site). Please note that the implicit use of 
words trademarked to me implicitly binds any for-profit corporate use
of this word to payment of $1.00 (US) for each unauthorized commercial
use of words trademarked by me.  Each user search-hit on the lycos site
for words trademarked by me consistutes a "use." Please pay up
immediately or cease and desist listing any web pages with my name
and/or trademarked words on your site. I wouldn't want my words
appearing on a site run by lawyer-plagued assholes such as yourselves.

Sincerely,
	Niels Mayer.

PS: As a result of your stupid and pointless letter, I am going to send
a suggestion to all the rave lists across the country, e.g. sfraves,
socal-raves, mw-raves, ne-raves, and USENET alt.rave the WE ALL BOYCOTT
WWW.LYCOS.COM. Each of these mailing lists ranges from 100-1000 users,
so you will hopefully get fewer hits from your scum-sucking
advertizers. I am also going to post my opinion that Alta Vista,
Excite, Yahoo, HotBot and any other sites other than Lycos contain far
better and more accurate search engines. My dog could write a better
search engine than Lycos, and I don't even have a dog.

PPPS: I am in no way affiliated with "Sub Commander Lycos", just a
satisfied fan of this excellent rave/house DJ and promoter.

------- End of Blind-Carbon-Copy

>Tim's pretty optimistic -- and I hope that he's right.  But I fear he's
>not.  The people at MTV, etc, who are pushing rave music / clothing are
>pushing "Product".  They are salesmen and they don't care if you pick up
>any values about tolerance along the way.

Yeh, but if the values are strong enough, they can't help but be picked up
along the way. Use "the salesmen's" energy to move your product at the same
time he moves his.

Do you not think that if "rave" music becomes popular, that no one will be
affected in a positive way. Imagine all the people who have never been
exposed to the music who will hear it and like it, and then be curious and
go to a party...

And if you think that the mainstream muzic biz endorsement of your music
will kill it, you're wrong. When they endorsed "alternative rock", many
smaller, true alternative labels were able to get more distribution; many
smaller underground bands were able to be heard.

And the more mainstream "raves" there are just leave room for more
underground parties.

So there. :->



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jan 17 02:34:19 1997

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Fri, 17 Jan 1997 02:25:11 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Rusty H. Hodge" <rusty@hodge.com>
Subject: Re: the difference between MTV and the u.g.
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 8:08 PM -0800 1/16/97, The Grigsbeast wrote:
>MTV, or any 'business', exists to make money.  Any entertainment or
>value you may get out of it is ancillary; programming is chosen to
>attract the maximum number of viewers possible

Wrong. Total oversimplification. (like: all raves are just big drug parties.)

Programming is chosen to attract a select demographic - a certian type of
viewer that specific ads can be presented to, be it an ad for a similar
type of music, a fashion popular with that demographic group, or even
political messages targetted and customized for that demographic group.

Narrowcasting is in, and has been for quite a while. You now go after a
specifically targetted demographic and do the best job of providing that
demographic what they need to be satisfied (so they won't go anywhere
else). Brand Loyalty!

>(In fact, the ONLY function of any
>television program is to anesthetize you so deeply that you won't change
>the channel when a commercial comes on.

So you're so anesthetized that you can't even buy the product???

The function of a program is to hook you into the story or whatever so that
you don't want to miss any of it. In fact, if it is such a good story or
program, you'll want to know who the people are who sponsor it.

>They'd show nothing BUT
>commercials if they thought you'd watch it...Home Shopping Channel,
>anyone?)

If the commercials were compelling enough, yes. But they're not going to
endanger their audience at the risk of a little fast cash. TV station
economics are much more long term than short term. MTV existed many years
while losing money because they knew they were building audience loyalty
that would pay off later (and it has).

>A UG crew needs to take in some money in order to survive, but money
>isn't the _reason_ you throw a UG.  You do it 'cause you like it and
>hope you don't come out too far behind.

Undergrounds are like "hobby businesses". They are usually great for the
consumer, as minimal thoughts were given to the economics of sustaining the
business long term.

However, you don't see many "hobby TV networks" (although some would argue
that Fox was Rupert Murdoch's hobby) because the scale of the economics are
just too high. MTV pays millions of dollars for their satellite
transponders. Of course they need to make a lot of money, of course they
are going to go after the mainstream. But they are going to go after the
fringes of the mainstream. Otherwise they'd be broadcasting soap operas all
day long.

>If all people care about is the money, they won't get all the details
>right, because their energy will go towards ensuring maximum $ intake
>(shutting off the sinks and selling water, for instance, or not
>permitting anyone to bring in food or water).

Many places are rented with the promoter guaranteeing a certian take at the
bar. If no one is drinking, and no one is buying water, then the promoter
has to come up with the difference. (Not to mention annoying the bartenders
who aren't getting tips. And they survive off tips.)

Ask yourself: would you pay an extra $4-5 for a party with free water?


--
Rusty Hodge (rusty@hodge.com), Media Futurist / Cyberneticist

http://www.hodge.com  <-- Me Being Professional
http://www.rusty.org  <-- Me Being Silly
http://www.club.net   <-- San Francisco Club Guide

WAY TO GO!

Everyone should know this is what we need more of.  The law is such a
messed up concept.. some people who have built up twisted egos with
money- and power-wielding ideals take it upon their own hands to hire or
become those "lawyer types", and intimidate anyone they please.  The
supposed purpose of the law is to keep order and fairness.. and we
should all do our best to keep it that way.  For a long time I thought
it best to ignore the law, refuse to acknowledge its authority.  But
when taken to extremes, I can see how much better it is to throw the
same shit back at them.. two can play at that game.. there's no reason
to let corporations be the ones wielding power with the law.  What the
law MEANS is whatever we make of it.. we can refuse its existence, we
can see it as an enemy....  or we can use it as a tool.  It's good to be
able to use it as a resource without having to hold it up as an ideal..

Sending great energy to all of you in sfr-legal, and those who will not
go down silently...

Subject: I have an idea
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I think promoters should consider using short range communications devices
such as a pair of walkie talkies at raves.  Assign one person to work as a
lookout and when a police car is present that lookout would send a message
to the other person that there are law enforcers present and signal the DJ
to "turn down" the music for a while until the coast is clear again.  Maybe
think about using a hand scanner to listen in the police frequency to find
out if there are any noise complaints.  this sounds like a weird idea but it
seems like this is the only way we could prevent our parties from being shut
down.  Any ideas?   

piece,
Anthony E

At , Sharif Torpis , SDream@tgrigsby.com wrote:
>At 11:02 PM 1/16/97 -0800, Sharif Torpis wrote:
>>> John S. Lee wrote:
>>> 
>>> without reading it.  Which is EXACTLY what Mr. Torpis should have done
>>> if he didn't want to read an NRR message.
>>
>>Why doesn't it work the other way? If it is NRR *and* the f***ing author
>>knows that enough to label it as such, why does the author send it here?


First of all, may I buy you a clue?

This subject is _very_ rave related, maaybe the most relevant 
topic that one could have.  JSL (as many of us who have been partying for
5+ years) is concerned by cavalier statements that seem to characterize
particular cultural or ethnic groups. We started raving particularly to
combat that type of behavior and to show folks that it was better to be
open and accepting, they fearfully and cliquish. If one goes to a party
say, in Concord
or Pittsburg (Ca), You will see a lot of attendees in tight jeans, with
marlboro t-shirts, tattoos, etc.  I never hear people talking about
rednecks or the like at parties. Last month, I helped throw a party in
Chico, a "rural" city towards the middle of california, my mind filled up
with images of beer drinking, meth snortin, cowboy hat wearing, rednecks
who would not like the looks of me:), some of my friends helped to fuel the
images :), suffice it to say that I and my possee (who was very racially
mixed), were received with open arms, appreciation, love and respect, more
"PLUR" then I have seen in many a day at some of the SF parties, and we
were there to play HOUSE music :) 
The kids there, on the visual surface, were more towards the the stereotypes
that my mind had made up, but there behavior DID NOT FIT MY PICTURES!
We all have latent racism, it is unavoidable because our society
is latently racist. The cues to respond to people by the color of their skin
HAS BEEN DRILLED INTO US FOR THE LAST 400 YEARS.  Confront the fact that
whether you are black or white or chinese you will react to this conditioning.
I find myself wanting to check my car door locks as I drive through a
neighborhood where the complexion of the population deepens, and I grew up
in Bedford Stuyvensant, Brooklyn which, is one of the hardest places on the
planet. I've observed my reactions and noticed how conditioned we all are to
react along racial lines and to call it something else.  RAVING IS PART OF THE
CURE FOR THIS BEHAVIOR! When you feel that reaction in your gut, you have
some choices to make, it takes courage but also common sense, I must admit
that it is a bit easier for me to come up to some "gangsta" looking kids
and say
"Hey, what's up! You havin a good time? Good to see you here!", I'm 6'5" and
280 lbs. So the confidence that goes with the body type can be an asset.
But I've also seen 100 lb "Rave Goddesses" melt the frontin attitude of
some of the
toughest gangsters, without them disrespecting her as well.  It's all in
the Vibe and the attitude that you portray, that is why some of us rave. If
raving is about changing the world through the Vibe (which is what it is
for me) then the Vibe starts with you and spreads out from there.
"Gangstas", cops, rednecks, soldiers, ( I was actually at a party once
where National Guard MPs told the cops to back off cuz they had no
jurisdiction here, props to Martin O!) it's all the same, the goal is to
have them all "get it".

>>
>>Would you send a NBWR (non-basket-weaving related) to the basketweavers
>>mailing list? If you feel u just have to share with somebody, start
>>a list called nrr@hyperreal.com. Seriously.
>>
>>> It's been said before more eloquently, but: This is more than a rave
>>> hotline, it's a rave family communication medium.  If that's not what
>>> you
>>> expected.... start your own mail list.  Cool?  This is not an uninformed
>>> opinion, it's a simple observation.
>>
>>Who said anything about prohibiting rave family communications? The key here
>>is "rave". NRR are not rave related. Don't send them here. The onus
should be
>>on *you* not to send it, not on me to delete it.


Why do you rave?


>>
>>For every time I post here about this issue, I'd say 1000 NRR messages
go. So
>>I can bitch every 1000 after being quiet for every 1000.
>>
>>

The fact that this keeps coming up again and again indicates that it is
something that this community needs to deal with and can't (or shouldn't)
be swept under the rug.  Just as we all have residual racism that has been
ingrained into us by way of our parents, teachers, televisions, magazines,
and yes, language, years of that can be washed away on the dance floor,
I've seen it happen time and time again,and it's truly amazing, but, guess
what?  In order for it to happen you gotta have _EVERBODY_ at your party,
rednecks, cholos, homeboys, gangstas, etc. Fight the attitude not the style.

The key is that the people who know how to generate the Vibe have to be
present in large numbers, they have to be strong and capable of radiating
that love vibe energy.  What I'm talking about is not teddy-bear hugging,
and you don't need E to get there.  You can still be a Macho/a (if that's
your thing) and radiate this energy.  It's where your coming from not how
you act or what you take, or who you are that counts. There is a critical
mass that is reached at
parties, if you have more attitude then Vibe the party will suck.  If you
have 
folks that an old mate of mine referred to as "Ambiance Engineers" come to
your
party they can transform the space.  I'm not talking about cliques or
"A-lists" or anything like that, I'm talking about VIBE.

Since I'm the author of the "NRR" post that has caused this discussion I
shall put in my $0.02!

I don't think one person out of hundreds justifies that anybody who is an
author of an "NRR" post should stop.

First of all the people on this list are my "SFRAVER" friends...

Second of all since they are my "SFRAVER" friends and we all are under one
domain then it makes perfect common sense to post it to the list for I sure
would not like to write hundreds of email addys.

I'd rather read or delete an "NRR" post then read a bunch of whining post
about an 'NRR" post that someone didn't like. (did that make sense) =)

Its all very simple.  When I feel that I can touch hundreds of people with
something funny or interesting then I'm going to continue posting "NRR"
messages.  There are people on this list that never post and maybe they are
having a bad day and I don't know that, right.  But then they receive this
silly message that makes them smile or laugh or just plain and simple makes
them forget about whatever it is bothering them for a moment.

Would you want to take that away from someone?  No!  I should hope not.

So lets look at this as a way of communicating with all our friends on the
list as opposed to governing it.

Thanks for your time,



Siphon!
________________________________________________________________________________
"You yawn to equalize the pressure on your eardrums. This pressure change
outside your eardrums unbalances other people's ear pressures, so they must
yawn to even it out." =)

> 
> I think promoters should consider using short range communications devices
> such as a pair of walkie talkies at raves.  Assign one person to work as a
> lookout and when a police car is present that lookout would send a message
> to the other person that there are law enforcers present and signal the DJ
> to "turn down" the music for a while until the coast is clear again.  Maybe
> think about using a hand scanner to listen in the police frequency to find
> out if there are any noise complaints.  this sounds like a weird idea but it
> seems like this is the only way we could prevent our parties from being shut
> down.  Any ideas?   
> 
> piece,
> Anthony E

We've used police scanners before to find out whats going on. Fortunately,
the party continued interupted, but if an officer had been called to bust
it up or investigate, we would have known. Because we throw parties in a
small town and don't do anything blatantly illegal, we don't use scanners anymore... it sucks to be on scanner duty when you should be out dancing.

I think the goal for promoters should be to reach a peace with the law enforcemnet officers...that's what we've been able to do, and its nice... no worries :)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jan 17 10:02:00 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id KAA25372; Fri, 17 Jan 1997 10:02:00 -0800 (PST)
Received: from value.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id KAA25358; Fri, 17 Jan 1997 10:01:55 -0800 (PST)
From: blkadder@value.net
Received: from localhost (blkadder@localhost) by value.net (8.8.4/8.7.3) with SMTP id KAA12488 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 17 Jan 1997 10:01:53 -0800 (PST)
Date: Fri, 17 Jan 1997 10:01:53 -0800 (PST)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Finding out our rights
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.970117093047.9491B-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


First I would like to thank those of you that have responded to me about
seeing a lawyer to find out what our rights are. Here are the
questions that I have come up with:

1) Does shutting the doors and meeting the police outside have any legal
   advantage?

2) Can the "person in charge" refuse the police entry, or does(can?) the
   property owner/renter have to?

3) What constitutes "probable cause" with respect to entering a building
   without the permission of the person in charge(or owner/renter)?

4) When is it legally necessary to have a permit for an event? I have been
   told in Oakland for instance, if there are more than 50 people in a
   building, a permit is necessary. Is this true, or is it at police 
   discretion?

5) How do questions 1-4 apply to a private residence as opposed to a 
   warehouse or other location?

6) Do the police have any right to force us to hire off-duty police
   officers in order to be granted a permit? If so, under what law? 

7) What benefits/liabilities would forming a non-profit organization to
   throw parties(with profits going to charity of course) have? 

8) We have been told in the past by police that if we are taking
   *any* money at the door, our event is a business and needs to be
   permitted. However, people can take donations at a church and they do
   not appear to need special permits to do so. Is this because they are
   a non-profit, or do they have special standing for being a church,
   or ?????


Well that is all I can think of at the moment. I am a little disappointed 
that I have not heard from any promoter on this issue. I know at least a
few of you are out on the list, and it is really in all of our best
interest to know the answers to some of these questions.  
 
I am posting this to sfraves and sfr-legal seperately. Cross-posting to
both lists makes having seperate lists silly....

If anyone has anything else to contribute, whether it be additonal
questions that should be asked, money, or the name of a good civil rights
attorney, please let me know. Also anyone interested in attending the
consultation is welcome.

                                         Black Adder

>Oh, by the way, your search engine lists a few thousand hits of words

>search for my name on your site). Please note that the implicit use of 
>words trademarked to me implicitly binds any for-profit corporate use
>of this word to payment of $1.00 (US) for each unauthorized commercial
>use of words trademarked by me.  Each user search-hit on the lycos site
>for words trademarked by me consistutes a "use." Please pay up
>immediately or cease and desist listing any web pages with my name
>and/or trademarked words on your site. I wouldn't want my words
>appearing on a site run by lawyer-plagued assholes such as yourselves.

AltaVista search for "lycos" yields about 400,000

Hmmm, which one would you use?

On Fri, 17 Jan 1997 blkadder@value.net wrote:

> On Thu, 16 Jan 1997, Timothy McIntyre wrote:
> 
> > Are we ravers in any position to always rail against 'the man' and 
> > lament the mainstream's inability to to be as open to new ideas as 
> > ravers tend to be, but then not teach the mainstrea about all the 
> > beautiful things that we've learned, when, after all this time, they're
> > finally knocking on our door?
> 
> The mainstream is knocking on the door because this is a market to
> exploited, not out of the search for some greater truth.
> 
>                                           Black Adder

   Well, I could care less if they market it or not!  MTV can sandwich as 
many commercials as they want for bottled water or neon backpacks between
the videos, which I happen to find interesting, as far as I'm concerned.
People will always trade goods--that will never change--and so advertising
will always exist.  I'm over it.

   The thing that really interests me is the fact that the videos, which
are the real attraction to viewers, are now from DJ's.  And instead of the
tired old '80's-style videos--you know, big hair, gratuitous guitar solos,
silly shots of band members running around on stage while fireworks
explode, etc.--we've finally got raytracing, computer-generated trippy 
graphics, and hard trance all coming together.  As far as aesthetic
experiences go, I don't really find music videos *that* interesting,
personally, and the medium is of course still the same, but the content
is changing, which I think is really cool.
   As far as marketing and the whole "TV is run by the man" vibe, well, 
I dunno.  Here's how I see it: commercials make TV free.  They're what pay
for it, so I tolerate them.  Because I'm aware that commercials are trying 
to manipulate me, I can filter them out, and still get the cool programs I
like for free.

Timothy

On Fri, 17 Jan 1997 blkadder@value.net wrote:

> 
> First I would like to thank those of you that have responded to me about
> seeing a lawyer to find out what our rights are. Here are the
> questions that I have come up with:
> 
> 1) Does shutting the doors and meeting the police outside have any legal
>    advantage?
> 
> 2) Can the "person in charge" refuse the police entry, or does(can?) the
>    property owner/renter have to?
> 
> 3) What constitutes "probable cause" with respect to entering a building
>    without the permission of the person in charge(or owner/renter)?
> 
> 4) When is it legally necessary to have a permit for an event? I have been
>    told in Oakland for instance, if there are more than 50 people in a
>    building, a permit is necessary. Is this true, or is it at police 
>    discretion?
> 
> 5) How do questions 1-4 apply to a private residence as opposed to a 
>    warehouse or other location?
> 
> 6) Do the police have any right to force us to hire off-duty police
>    officers in order to be granted a permit? If so, under what law? 
> 
> 7) What benefits/liabilities would forming a non-profit organization to
>    throw parties(with profits going to charity of course) have? 
> 
> 8) We have been told in the past by police that if we are taking
>    *any* money at the door, our event is a business and needs to be
>    permitted. However, people can take donations at a church and they do
>    not appear to need special permits to do so. Is this because they are
>    a non-profit, or do they have special standing for being a church,
>    or ?????
> 
> 
> Well that is all I can think of at the moment. I am a little disappointed 
> that I have not heard from any promoter on this issue. I know at least a
> few of you are out on the list, and it is really in all of our best
> interest to know the answers to some of these questions.  
>  
> I am posting this to sfraves and sfr-legal seperately. Cross-posting to
> both lists makes having seperate lists silly....
> 
> If anyone has anything else to contribute, whether it be additonal
> questions that should be asked, money, or the name of a good civil rights
> attorney, please let me know. Also anyone interested in attending the
> consultation is welcome.
> 
>                                          Black Adder
> 
>                                         
> 
>

>On Thu, 16 Jan 1997, Anthony E wrote:
>
>> THe folks at MTV could go only so far.  They could package the music, the
>> clothing style, and proibably some parties (imagine an MTV promoted "rave"
>> in a sports arena near you.... *GAWK*) but they can NEVER, EVER, EVER

>> package our "culture" for profit will have very little success as long as

>What you are missing in this equation is the fact that MTV and anyone else
>who wants to ride on this potential gravy-train is going to introduce a

Well, those who will patronize this will soon find themselves not really
getting what they expect (provided they really know what our scene is all
about).  They will be sent to the massive "raves" full of gangstas (no pun
intended, I use the term loosely) and people who don't know how to use
substances properly.  That is what the underground really has,  we have
unity, we try our best to practice PLUR, and we try to be a family and share
our experiences with everyone openly.  If MTV wants to commercialize raves,
fear not, we still have the underground to turn to and those who have been
around will know how to reach it. There is something similar happening with
the Internet... but I'm not going to discuss Internet politics here.

I remember about a year ago when MTV featured Herbal X: the E substitute...
which in my opinion was also full of shit.  The only thing I watch on MTV
thses days Beavis & Butthead... huh huh huh ... MTV sucks... huhu huhu... 

PLUR,
Anthony E

THE TOP TEN ADVANTAGES OF GIVING A 1.05 CT DIAMOND RING TO YOUR FIANCEE:

10. She can send Morse signals to the space shuttle.
9.  She can blind potential muggers -- from across the street.
8.  Rave promoters will pay to shine a laser through it.
7.  She can cut her way out of a bank vault.
6.  She can strengthen and tone muscles in her finger and arm.
5.  Can be used to defeat Superman - oops, that's Kryptonite.
4.  She can orgasm just by looking at her hand.
3.  She can light ants on fire with it.
2.  Lightens wallet, thereby reducing that annoying back strain.

1.  You win.

Date: Fri, 17 Jan 1997 17:09:59 -0800
From: The Grigsbeast <grigsby@netgate.net>
Reply-To: grigsby@netgate.net
Organization: Ollie's House of Cesium Pantaloons
X-Mailer: Mozilla 3.0Gold (WinNT; I)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: the difference between MTV and the u.g.
References: <Pine.APO.3.91.970116171942.2792C-100000@monsoon.berkeley.edu> <v03007819af04f4a4d8ed@[157.22.222.199]>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Rusty H. Hodge wrote:
> 
> At 8:08 PM -0800 1/16/97, The Grigsbeast wrote:
> >MTV, or any 'business', exists to make money.  Any entertainment or
> >value you may get out of it is ancillary; programming is chosen to
> >attract the maximum number of viewers possible
> 
> Wrong. Total oversimplification. (like: all raves are just big drug parties.)

What is your experience working for, working with, or talking to owners
or directors of large (multi-million) dollar businesses?

> Programming is chosen to attract a select demographic - a certian type of
> viewer that specific ads can be presented to, be it an ad for a similar
> type of music, a fashion popular with that demographic group, or even
> political messages targetted and customized for that demographic group.
> 
> Narrowcasting is in, and has been for quite a while. You now go after a
> specifically targetted demographic and do the best job of providing that
> demographic what they need to be satisfied (so they won't go anywhere
> else). Brand Loyalty!

And this is the way they get maximum viewership.  There are already lots
of stations out there that try to be all things to everyone (the
'superstations' like TBS) and MTV decided that instead of settling for a
tiny slice of a big pie, they could get ALL of a smaller pie.

Thus the 'diversity' of MTV, where they air all the different specialty
shows like Headbangers Ball, 120 Minutes (and I'm probably way out of
date here but I don't own a TV), exists in an attempt to get maximum
viewership.  Narrowcasting, whatever you want to call it, is an effort
to get maximum viewership *given the resources available*.  Just because
someone knows they *can't* be ESPN doesn't mean they don't *want* to be.

Big business owners think completely in terms of dollars, and exceptions
are very rare, because if you don't you will be surpassed by someone who
does.  This has been driven home to me many times in my dealings within
and with business.

> >(In fact, the ONLY function of any
> >television program is to anesthetize you so deeply that you won't change
> >the channel when a commercial comes on.
> 
> So you're so anesthetized that you can't even buy the product???

Eventually you have to sleep so you can go to work, and you'll probably
have to shop on the way back.

> The function of a program is to hook you into the story or whatever so that
> you don't want to miss any of it. In fact, if it is such a good story or
> program, you'll want to know who the people are who sponsor it.

And the reason for this is to show commercials.  TV stations *spend*
money to make shows, buy FCC licenses, operate transmitters...they spend
*lots* of money.  The only reason they can is because they *make* money
off of commercials, and they will air as many as they think you can
stand.  The more you want to watch the show, the more commercials they
can air, and the more they will charge.

I remember when I was a kid <cue Grampa toothless voice> and they would
show a whole Looney Tunes short before cutting.  Now they only show
minute-long slices of them out of context before cutting to the
commercial, because they figured out kids will watch anything
entertaining, even a commercial.

> TV station
> economics are much more long term than short term. MTV existed many years
> while losing money because they knew they were building audience loyalty
> that would pay off later (and it has).

Your words, not mine.  "Pay off."  All that matters.

> Many places are rented with the promoter guaranteeing a certian take at the
> bar. If no one is drinking, and no one is buying water, then the promoter
> has to come up with the difference. (Not to mention annoying the bartenders
> who aren't getting tips. And they survive off tips.)

I rarely go to bars (maybe twice a year, friends drag me) because I
don't drink.  I usually avoid raves at bars for this, among other
reasons (I think 21+ is discriminatory, I dislike the bar atmosphere,
etc.)

> Ask yourself: would you pay an extra $4-5 for a party with free water?

I am willing to pay whatever's reasonable given the circumstances.  Most
bars or bar events have a lower cover than warehouse one-offs, but I pay
the higher admission when I go out because the enjoyment is worth it.

For example, I have no problem paying a buck or two for a coat check.  I
wish more parties would have one, so I could wear my nice waterproof
mountaineering jacket instead of my heavy old green water-sponge army
coat, and could bring a backpack full of goodies without worrying about
it getting stolen.  Many ski areas have these, and with all the messages
on the list saying "Someone stole my backpack", ...

// grigsbeast

The NRR debate continues... I'll leave off on that for now (itching to 
get out of work!!) but I just have to say about this particular instance-

IMO, Todd is a great asset to our community, often seen (until recently) 
at every party with his Dr. Seuss hat and many toys - and contributing 
RR and NRR wisdom to this list.  Here he is sharing his joy with his 
extended family (in his particular Todd-sense-of-humor way) about a very 
major life event that's happening for him.   NRR maybe, but hardly 
trivial for Todd and shared in a way entertaining for us.  I think it's 
great.

We're a community of living people - of friends - not just rave automatons.

Even so, the filter "NRR" is a pretty good resolution to the debate 
(which he did use, BTW).

> permit.

	This is one of those things that I can see cops having a valid 
point that raves are evil because not everybody figures out that most 
smaller parties are breaking laws just by happening. Raves turn the 
average person into a law breaking criminal...
	Now having said that, I am going to turn around and say a few 
things about permits. Permits are nice ploy to keep certain things from 
happening and are issued by good God loving people who think their way is 
the only way (note, not all god loving or other loving people are this 
way). I do not like having to obtain a permit to allow people to come and 
dance at outdoor parties. I do not like having to pay for permits for a 
free outdoor party. I used to think that permits were a necessary evil to 
prevent overlap of people wanting to use the same spot, but the thing is, 
most of the time, no one is allowed to use the spot either because of 
lack of funds or the fact that their use voilates the amplified music 
laws.
	Now, taking this a astep further. Some parties out there hope that
in bringing people out that they will realize that the individual is
responsible for oneself and that this governmental bullshit that mandates
that everyone else must take responsiblity for everyone else is bullshit,
at least to the degree which it is heading. You do something, you must
deal with the consquences. That is not to say that no one will help you
deal with it, but it is the individual itself (ok, that sounds horrible
being all gender neutral but this applies to both females and males so
please try to absorb the weight of it anyway) who must deal with shit.
	Now, I pull a sound system out, the police come and bust it, it is
my responsiblity to deal with it. If I do not tell people that this a
break in party, and we get busted, it is my shit to bear because I did not
give everyone enough information to make an informed decision to act on. 
But here is one thing you can pretty much count on which will not be
reiterated (usually because it is a well know fact and people usuall don't
care and it would probably be looked down on even more if the voicemail
were to say, this party is not permitted), if it is a small underground
party, it probably does not have permits. That is the current state of 
things.

	Now some really strong personal beliefs start here, be prepared
for my opinionated rant mode. I do not like the separation between party
goer and "promoter" especially which was implied earlier in the original
post. Raves are not so much a busniess to me (though I will grant that
they provide for maintaining my sound system which is the only things that
use it), and so I really do not like pushing this kind of shit on the
promoters unless they are saying it will be a permitted party and then do
not produce the permits. If you don't like unpermitted parties, do not go
to them.
	I do not like the attitude of "we paid some money for this, so you
better produce" for underground low cost parties - it is orthogonal to
just about everything that rave represents to me (but granted, everyone
has different defintions of what rave is to them, and thus, there are lots
of different kinds of raves). That kind of shit belongs in the realm of
big commerical parties. If you want to be entertained, go somewhere else
that is about entertaining you. Do I have attitude problem? Possibly, but
as I watch raves go from open spaces where people can do what they want to
enforced 12 step workgroups where I can no longer bite my lower lip (which
is what happens when I dance) because it might look like a scowl to
someone, or blowing fire on the beach scares people, I find my kind of
rave is dying in favor of raveLite put on by WeKnowBest.
	Come on, promoters are people like everyone else. There are
promoters organizing parties cuz they love parties, there are promoters
who look at raves as a business and then there promoters who are in
between - some who throw legit parties, but it takes all their time, so it
also has to be their business, others who deliver a legit party but are
only doing it cuz it is a decnt way to make money in some parts of the
world.  People complain about setting the dj on some platform, but many of
the same people would not want to move speakers or be involved in projects
to support their supposed "community" which falls unto the shoulders of
some of these "promoter" types. 

end long long long rant

dave

On Thursday, Anthony E wrote:

> >> THe folks at MTV could go only so far.  They could package the music, the
> >> clothing style, and proibably some parties (imagine an MTV promoted "rave"
> >> in a sports arena near you.... *GAWK*) but they can NEVER, EVER, EVER
> >> package the vibe, the energy, and the family-like unity of our SFR
> >  community.


And then on Friday he wrote:

   
> We have unity, we try our best to practice PLUR, and we try to be a family 
> and share
> our experiences with everyone openly.  If MTV wants to commercialize raves,
> fear not, 


---> Even "virtual" MTV could never replace the unique love and positive 
energy that each one of us possess within our Rave "culture." 
At the first rave each of us went to, (whether it be five years ago;three years 
ago; or just last month), the experience was phenomenal in one aspect or 
another. New, invigorating, and inviting. The music blazed its way 
through our ears, and the many beautiful, happy, and unique people who 
decorated the floor -- danced and danced to the many beats of electronic 
music. Wow, what an experience! And it called us back, time and time 
again. Sucking us up into its vacuum, where we could expel our energy -- 
and open up our hearts and minds to a whole new world. 
The music, the dance, the people -- The Rave -- are all unique, and each 
compliment the experience that we share.


On Friday, Andrew Nourse wrote:

> None of us were born knowing. We found it anyway, one way or another, 
> The music itself has great power. If you get a lot more people 
> dancing to it, many of them will find it sooner or later.


---> All music, from classical to jazz to hard rock to techno, has 
its strength among various individuals. Music is universal. Music is 
eternal. And the music we share as ravers is beautiful. 
When big business wants to exploit the land to extract money, is the land 
any less beautiful or sacred?
Hence, if MTV wants to exploit the music for financial gain, should the 
music become any less beautiful or sacred within us?


		peace luv hugs ==> Ann


 



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jan 17 19:36:37 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id TAA21617; Fri, 17 Jan 1997 19:36:37 -0800 (PST)
Received: from mhaaf.inhouse.compuserve.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id TAA21569; Fri, 17 Jan 1997 19:36:31 -0800 (PST)
Received: from notes2.compuserve.com ([149.174.221.56]) by mhaaf.inhouse.compuserve.com (8.6.9/8.6.12) with SMTP id AAA16680.; Sat, 18 Jan 1997 00:03:04 -0500

Message-Id: <9701180335.AA5682@notes2.compuserve.com>

  33EB2F0BA6D70000882564230012C347; Fri, 17 Jan 97 22:35:56 
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
From: "nathan.b.beckord" <nathan.b.beckord@ArthurAndersen.com>
Date: 17 Jan 97 19:25:51 
Subject: Deep thoughts (rr)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hola Beautiful People!

Ponder this:

(1)  I work with a very, how shall we say, conservative group. Some of these 
folks are so boring, life is nothing more than running models and writing 
reports. Fun is watching TV on a Friday night. I view them as somewhat 
lifeless; i.e., they have no spunk or zest for life or vibrant aura around 
them.  Even when others of us go out and go drinking (do not start a thread) 
and get a little crazy, they avoid such situations at all cost. Human shells, 
no twinkle in the eye. Robots.

So anywho, I was thinking to myself while chopping garlic, what would happen if 
I got one of these persons to go to a super vibey rave, and _gasp_ take X? 
Would the freedom and love, with the help of the synthetic, open up the 
internal eye and allow him/her to take a step out of his/her persona, and see 
his/her life as it is-- plain and dull, without spark? Or would this only occur 
if that person was, consciously or not, seeking something? If that person were 
not seeking, would the power of vibe be unable to overcome? And if not, how 
would that person react? Would they see the lights, hear the beat, feel the 
funk and get panicky---or, perhaps worse, they do see themselves, and not like 
what they see, yet become depressed as they realize they are somewhat stuck in 
the situation theyre in? 

(2) I guess I wonder this as sometimes it seems that people need to become one 
of these work-centric robots in order to succeed. Countless friends have 
stopped going out and experiencing new things, citing a lack of energy or being 
to busy with work.  Like it or not, we are typically graded (and rewarded) 
against a jury of our peers. How does one stay  true to oneself (for lack of a 
better term), yet succeed, especially if that success comes in a more 
traditional industry? Essentially, is some level of selling out necessary to 
excel? Except for a very few chosen: artists, musicians, super-programmers, or 
the independently wealthy-- it seems that few people are able to truly excel 
without altering who they are to a certain extent. Keep in mind, in this defini
tion, success doesnt necessarily mean money, status, fame or power.  It means 
being or doing the best at what it is you choose to do. 

WELL, these thoughts may be too heavy for a Friday night, so lets talk BEATS!! 
Origin sounds good tonight. Beyond race is always a good call. Say hi if you 
get a chance: white dude, black hair, garlic breath. OUT!

Nathan

core, jungle(boogy)---basically everything except cheesy house, 
high-energy, and booty-hop !)  we just started our company, HAPPY KIDS, 
and bounced our first party last fryday. i was really pleased with all 
you lovey-dovey's that came and partied. the vibes and love and energy 
was historical. let's do it again! we'll talk.....anyways i want to 
meet all of you out there and give you fat hugs. check this idea out 
----> a coffee/tea house. the name is The Chill Room or DownTempo. 
resident dj spinning ambient, jazz-step(jazzy jungle), and other types 
of mellow chill grooves. no tables and chairs. couches, cushions, 
pillows, feathers, cotton balls, floam, and whatever the fuck else is 
comfy sittin material. little tiny tables to set yer cups on, but 
nuthin bulky. A SMOKING ESTABLISHMENT. a private back room, "the green 
room." fresh fruit. HOURS:

mon-thu  =  12pm to 3am
fri      =  12pm to 7pm
sat      =   8am to 5pm
sun      =   8am to 5pm

MUST GIVE OWNER HUGS UPON ENTERING!
LEAVE WEAPONS IN RECYCLING BINS!

yeah.....that's what i thought, foo. see you in the full moon's light.

love, ian

hello all...yes, i was temporarily deleted from the internet, but now I 
am hooked!  (.net, that is...).  some of you know me as 
TGARCI02@FARINON.HARRIS.COM AT ccstmp, however today was my last day, as 
i was a temp by choice.  =]  however, diehards diehard, so i am back as 
deepfog.  which i always was, but my friends call me Tony.  no, i am not 
dj tony.  nor am i the tony garcia from new york.  

well i decided to do a little self-intro, cause i never really did one, 
you see i just kindo blatantly moved into this list and got "keyboard 
happy" (wasting bandwidth) (like a hog.  just call me deep-hog).  

anyway, on to the intro!

my first pahty was in oct 1991.  it was a rave called sharon.  i remember 
that cause it was even more cutting edge to me than live 105 
was...remember back when they were a unique station?  my friend rob took 
me for the first time, then he like hounded me to go every weekend and i 
thought he had joined a cult or one of those pyramid schemes or some 
leftwing guerilla movement the way he was going about it, so i didn['t go 
for about another year.  

in between the times i ran off to another state with "someone" (i'll post 
it on my future webpage!)

when i came back, i decided i needed a little uplifting.  so i went to 
something out at um, you know over by candlestick.  in some little court 
in the industrial section over by JIB (jack) and had a great time.  took 
e for the first time in a while.  

then i went bonkers raving and just like raved every weekend.  but i've 
never been the type that can go out the whole weekend and stay all night 
at every party.  i noticed others did that, however that did not seem to 
fit with me.  

then i met "someone else"  (they'll REALLY be on my page.  right up 
front. =] )  

then we parted ways.  

oh, yeah in between bonkers raving and meeting someone i started 
spinning.  i decided on my way home this evening that i specialize in all 
forms and subroutines of deep house.  specially the watery stuff.  

3 years later...

still spinning in my closet i mean bedroom.  i try to go out once a week, 
now i have just released my first professionally glued house tape, 
entitled "The Deep" (on sale at a Solid Grooves near you!  oh, wait 
there's only one.  harry, come on man!  open another)

i went to the first batch of sunset parties, used to go to the mohter 
earth parties, and i even got to spin at Harmony wwwwaaaaaaaaayyyy back 
couple years ago at an outdoor event.  it was the first time ever for me, 
and it was exhilerating but really fun.  i knew then that being a dj was 
going to be one of my life's major purposes.  

i've spun a few parties up at UCSC, with about 150 kids going "faster!  
faster!  can you play run.dmc?"  that was numberous amounts of fun, too.  

so you see, i like #1  helping people (over the years, i've learned only to 
help the people that want to be helped) and i like #2  having fun.  Money is 
secondary to me, but now i have come to a realization that if you want to 
have the time and resources to live some of my life's dreams and satisfy 
#1 and #2, i must have lots of money.  therefore, i've decided to make 
lots of money and build clubs on top of hills that are like futuristic 
and have lots of antennas and telescopes so we can talk to our friends on 
Mars, and have satellite uplinks with other ravers in other cities.  

I hope to meet some more of you in the near future...

love and peace out 97,

deepfog
Aware Environments

Please do not start all this bad vibed lfaming at each other for NRR
posts or getting into the symantecs of MTV,Keoki,AIDS,Underground etc.
Lets not fight over what we all want and are working for the one goal of
PLUR for the world. It defeats our own purpose if we fight about who is
more PLURish and correct about the scene and blah blah blah. Lets discuss
about what we are going to coming up and the new rave toys we got and
what happened with you today and about what you like to do in spare time
and what talkshows you like and what you hade for breakfast or who you
kicked it with after work/school, what games you got for the computer. If
you are a raver and it has to do with you it is never non rave related.
If it asociates with you and you rave there is a connection somewhere.
Nobody know for sure about Keoki and if he has AIDS or not, its okay for
someone or nayone to put up a post questioning a rumor they heard and
asking people's own opinions. If MTV is gonna do something about raves
then lets hope that it shows the good side of raving
Music/People/Fun/PLUR and doesn't focus on the bad things of it. If you
are a lurker type and you say hi then cool for you and all I am glad you
said you were there. We all know some promoters are fucked up, we learn
from experience. We all are so differnt yet have two things in common no
matter what. Raves & PLUR. Just everyone remember that and that we all
have been through hell and back and taken shit for being a raver and
everyone is supporting everyone and we all love each other and are there
to help any raver in need.

I bet you someone will reply to this negativly. I guarntee you it. I bet
one of you right now is just itching on the mouse button with the pointer
dangling over the reply ready to outpour some mean nasty thoughts that
the person probably wouldn't ever say to another raver at a rave.

PLUR,
Paul

special.  Let's just love one-another, tell stories about our personal

Hey all you beautiful people! 
Just wanted to say hi to all of those who aren't out and partying 
tonight, and for those who are, I'm hoping you're ravin'safe :) I was 
playing around on the net and went to www.cyberzen.com/jungle and for 
those who haven't checked it out, go to the Real Audio Tracks and 
check out the Brown Sugar remix DJ Noel does on there, it's supaphat! :)

Oh for those of you who don't know me, i guess now is a good time to 
officially intro. myself (kinda late, i know but better late than 
never huh).. I've been on the list since oh i don't know when, and 
i've posted many a review.. I started raving about a year ago, 
massives were my thing up until hmm september.. when I started going 
to ugs and weeklies more and more often.. I've recently started 
looking at life in a whole new perspective that I can't even explain 
to myself.. I've always thought life is a wonderful thing, but I 
don't think I ever fully realized the beauty of it and exactly how 
grandiose some things in life are.. Ever stop to watch the sunset, 
and believe it is so beautiful that you start to cry? Ever hear a 
song that makes you so happy you can't help but grab the person next 
to you and start dancing? :) That'show I seem to feel all the time 
now.. It's kinda weird.. 
	Anyway, I'm a junglist through and through (how do ya feel 
when tha bassline moves ya? gets control of ya mind and moves ya!) 
but I'm also into goatrance, hard trance, hardcore, anything fast. 
ambient is fun to chill to of course :) you'll find me at any jungle 
party, audio impact of course.. and here and there.. i'm always 
willing to help out a fellow SFRaver/person in general because my 
theory in life is to make the world a better place, and if i can put a 
smile on someone's face or make their life easier for them in one way 
or another, then shit i'll do it! :) 
	I want to thank all you SFRavers who have been 
supa-phat-sweet to me out there at parties, and to all you SFRavers 
who've been helpful to me on-line as well.. And to those who I 
haven't met either way, much love and respect to you too! I love the 
SFRave community, what a family! I hope to meet more and more of you :)
So go back to your friday nights/saturday mornings and I'll see you 
at the next party.. 
Take care of yourselves!
Much love and hugs,
LAra

Subject: Questions/underground vs. career (long)
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.970118011325.13308C-100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
