Precedence: bulk


Hi to everyone in the world!  ]=)

		

			This is long. You have been warned.

Dilemma;

 I have been involved in the UG for quite a while know (about 5 years) 
and before that I was very involved in band parties and the carnival and 
other "notable" scenarios.

 As many of you know, I am a sound engineer, light tech., multi-media 
live production artist and all around stress monkey.

 My goal is to provide enviroments and shows for folks that are conducive 
to transcendent experiences. Why I do this will be explained below for 
those that are interested.

 The problem is that I seem close to making the jump from amatuer to 
professional in my choosen area of expertise (multi-media production). 
I'm concerned that I'll lose the artistic edge the UG has given me as 
well as the sense of comradarie (sp?) you can only get from a few close 
friends humping amp racks and cabinets after 12 to 20 hours of 
partying/working to bring about a large event. I'm also very concerned 
I'll turn into a snob at the first chance I get (like when I have my own 
truck and don't have to beg for rides). My big hope is to become 
professional (designing massives and other large events in addition to 
starting a multi-media company) while still donating time to the UG (if 
possible). I'm afraid that my standards of professionalism may keep me 
wanting to work with the UG though.

 Of course I may never be a success and my worries may be groundless. ;)

 So why am I wasting bandwidth on three lists? I am hoping to get 
insights and perspectives from folks on how these issue could be 
addressed. I'm also hoping to show others this perspective in order for 
some to understand the conflict many of us have who are trying to build 
careers (all three of us ;) from things like raving. The UG has given me 
a place to develop my skills. Not only in show production but in learning 
how to communicate and work with others. And perhaps most importantly, in 
seeing with other perspectives, especially in the areas of human 
experience and beliefs. Skills and gifts I'll always carry with me. I 
can only hope that my gifts given to the UG can match 
these gifts bequethed to me.



			Reasons for Doing this.

 I came from a fairly messed up, white trash childhood. By the time I was 
a teenaged youth and living in California, I really didn't care much 
about anything. I had disconnected most of my emotional senses and this 
caused me (I believe) not to care about anything. Including myself.

 I went to a YES concert in 1978 and was transformed. I left that concert 
deeply caring. I was so blown away by the experience that I wanted to do 
the same for others. I wanted to design light and sound shows. I wanted 
to be a multi-media artist (long before the term was coined).

 I have devoted my life to that goal but have been side tracked along the 
way by needing to take care of my messed up head. It's still needing a 
little work (a lot maybe?) but at least I'm still firmly committed to my 
path. This is the whole reason why I'm in school. To put on better parties!

 So this is very important to me. These issues I'm dealing with. My 
apologies again for the bandwidth absorbtion.


may you know peace,


Ran D.Dreams



                                      (Namaste)
                                         /
                                   -=*=-/
                                     ~

Paul, 
I think I understand where you are coming from and I must admit that the part
of my life that I have been a raver has been filled with so much fun and
love and positivity that it is really tempting to just focus on that. But
you know
even ravers die. As a dear friend of mine did a few months ago, he didn't
die of AIDS, he died of cancer, he was amazing in that he kept showing love
right up to the end, he loved us while his body started to rebel and to
contort in
grotesques ways, (when some would not hug him anymore because he looked funny)
he kept going to parties as much as he could (he loved the music and people
so much).  This person showed so much love and respect and VIBE! I miss him
tremendously, is it wrong to want to talk about fighting diseases that take
our loved ones away from the Music? 

Some of us have friends that will never dance again, people that we danced
with, made love to, stood up to the police to, do we just forget about them
because their lives are not fluffy and joyful as ours still are?

hi kids my name is marc jameson, i live in a shack in
downtown SJ, where its 6am and my body still thinks its
1. im a musician, java developer, & brandspankin new to
sfr, (although i was on it for a week once till my work
unsubbed me:)  first rave was in a park outdoors (as most
parks are) in Sacto in 91 near the american river,
they had slip 'n slides! ive always been a
music lover and have been making electronic music
for a few years.  I kind of lean toward the darker,
harder side of things.  For the past year ive been
getting especially into jungle/drum&bass.

i am insearch of some visuals/projections/etc.
i have a band, we combine elements of techno/jungle/
breakbeat, soundtrack, punk.  Multiple drummers at
times, live and electronic, intense in your face music.
i would really like to incorporate visuals into our
set. Im open to different media and vibes. i want to
tie something in with the music to create an overall
mood.  I know there are people on sfr who do this,
so if you're out there and you think you might be
interested, please let me know!!  Next show is Feb 8,
which is kinda short notice i guess, yikes...

i look fwd to talking to you,
hope you all have a great weekend!

On 17 Jan 1997, nathan.b.beckord wrote:

> Hola Beautiful People!
> 
> Ponder this:
> 
> (1)  I work with a very, how shall we say, conservative group. Some of these 
> folks are so boring, life is nothing more than running models and writing 
> reports. Fun is watching TV on a Friday night. I view them as somewhat 
> lifeless; i.e., they have no spunk or zest for life or vibrant aura around 
> them.  Even when others of us go out and go drinking (do not start a thread) 
> and get a little crazy, they avoid such situations at all cost. Human shells, 
> no twinkle in the eye. Robots.

yeah, i've been working for the sharper image for 2 weeks now and i see
people every day who hate their jobs and their jobs hate them right back.
"resistance is futile ..."

> 
> So anywho, I was thinking to myself while chopping garlic, what would happen if 
> I got one of these persons to go to a super vibey rave, and _gasp_ take X? 
> Would the freedom and love, with the help of the synthetic, open up the 
> internal eye and allow him/her to take a step out of his/her persona, and see 
> his/her life as it is-- plain and dull, without spark? Or would this only occur 
> if that person was, consciously or not, seeking something? If that person were 
> not seeking, would the power of vibe be unable to overcome? And if not, how 
> would that person react? Would they see the lights, hear the beat, feel the 
> funk and get panicky---or, perhaps worse, they do see themselves, and not like 
> what they see, yet become depressed as they realize they are somewhat stuck in 
> the situation theyre in? 

i came to the conclusion a while ago that it's not within my rights to
make that decesion for other people. it's been said before, but not nearly
often ehough, the e and raves and whatever *are not* some magic cure-all
disco discut remedy and sometimes do more harm than good.

> 
> (2) I guess I wonder this as sometimes it seems that people need to become one 
> of these work-centric robots in order to succeed. Countless friends have 
> stopped going out and experiencing new things, citing a lack of energy or being 
> to busy with work.  

it's really easy to fall into a rut. i think that a lot of my co-workers
use work as a crutch to fill whatever holes they have in themselves, or
holes that they percieve having in themselves. i think that they're
mistaking boredom for exhaustion. "you will be assimilated..."

Like it or not, we are typically graded (and rewarded) 
> against a jury of our peers. How does one stay  true to oneself (for lack of a 
> better term), yet succeed, especially if that success comes in a more 
> traditional industry? 

just get something; music, a girlfriend, a fanzine, and you'll do all
right in this world. just don't be lazy.
















Essentially, is some level of selling out necessary to 
> excel? Except for a very few chosen: artists, musicians, super-programmers, or 
> the independently wealthy-- it seems that few people are able to truly excel 
> without altering who they are to a certain extent. Keep in mind, in this defini
> tion, success doesnt necessarily mean money, status, fame or power.  It means 
> being or doing the best at what it is you choose to do. 
> 
> WELL, these thoughts may be too heavy for a Friday night, so lets talk BEATS!! 
> Origin sounds good tonight. Beyond race is always a good call. Say hi if you 
> get a chance: white dude, black hair, garlic breath. OUT!
> 
> Nathan 
> 
>

On Sat, 18 Jan 1997, Randy C Cone wrote:

> > Members of this list have just as much right to be negative as
> > they do to be positive.
> 
>  They sure do. Thanks for stating the rights of ALL posters (myself 
> included).

Read it again.  I made no claim to stating the rights of all posters.  I
did state one right of which I am certain we have.

> And I believe then that my statement (in essence a voice of dissension
> towards those who can't handle NRR humor) should be valued under your
> above generalization.

If that's the case, then why aren't the original poster's comments valued,
as well?

There is a difference between dissension/disagreement/negativity and
outright hypocracy.  Preaching openness and telling someone to start their
own list because you don't like what they have to say amounts to
hypocracy.  Forget the nonsense about "stating one's feelings truly is to
sometimes state contradictions".  That is not what this is about.  This is
about someone using cherished values *against* someone else and
simultaneously violating those values -- which is exactly what you did. 
How much more Religious Right can you get? 

	Sami

Btw, any further comments I make on this topic will made in private email.
I however felt it was important to bring into question the intolerant
positivity which must scare as many people away from this list as does
malicious negativity.

Hey all you beautiful people! 
Just wanted to say hi to all of those who aren't out and partying 
tonight, and for those who are, I'm hoping you're ravin'safe :) I was 
playing around on the net and went to www.cyberzen.com/jungle and for 
those who haven't checked it out, go to the Real Audio Tracks and 
check out the Brown Sugar remix DJ Noel does on there, it's supaphat! :)

Oh for those of you who don't know me, i guess now is a good time to 
officially intro. myself (kinda late, i know but better late than 
never huh).. I've been on the list since oh i don't know when, and 
i've posted many a review.. I started raving about a year ago, 
massives were my thing up until hmm september.. when I started going 
to ugs and weeklies more and more often.. I've recently started 
looking at life in a whole new perspective that I can't even explain 
to myself.. I've always thought life is a wonderful thing, but I 
don't think I ever fully realized the beauty of it and exactly how 
grandiose some things in life are.. Ever stop to watch the sunset, 
and believe it is so beautiful that you start to cry? Ever hear a 
song that makes you so happy you can't help but grab the person next 
to you and start dancing? :) That'show I seem to feel all the time 
now.. It's kinda weird.. 
	Anyway, I'm a junglist through and through (how do ya feel 
when tha bassline moves ya? gets control of ya mind and moves ya!) 
but I'm also into goatrance, hard trance, hardcore, anything fast. 
ambient is fun to chill to of course :) you'll find me at any jungle 
party, audio impact of course.. and here and there.. i'm always 
willing to help out a fellow SFRaver/person in general because my 
theory in life is to make the world a better place, and if i can put a 
smile on someone's face or make their life easier for them in one way 
or another, then shit i'll do it! :) 
	I want to thank all you SFRavers who have been 
supa-phat-sweet to me out there at parties, and to all you SFRavers 
who've been helpful to me on-line as well.. And to those who I 
haven't met either way, much love and respect to you too! I love the 
SFRave community, what a family! I hope to meet more and more of you :)
So go back to your friday nights/saturday mornings and I'll see you 
at the next party.. 
Take care of yourselves!
Much love and hugs,
LAra

>			Reasons for Doing this.
>
> I came from a fairly messed up, white trash childhood. By the time I was
>a teenaged youth and living in California, I really didn't care much
>about anything. I had disconnected most of my emotional senses and this
>caused me (I believe) not to care about anything. Including myself.

Not to slam you Ran, but I hate the use of the term "white Trash' as much
as I do the 'N' word.  Since you used it as a personal reference, then it
is certainly within your perrogative to use it, no problem.

I do not think that ANYONE is trash.  No person in this society is
disposable, useless, or anything less than human.  I hate it when people,
due to economic cirumstances, are labled useless or worse yet, trash.  It
just shows me how really fucked up Amerikkka really is (I am not lost on
the fact that this country regularly pits 'white tr**h' against Africans.
In fact the two groups, from an economic and opportunity standpoint are in
the same place.  But the people in power have both groups folled and pitted
against each other for the SAME resources....this kkkountry needs a
decapitation).  To see an intelligent person as yourself buy into the hype
is even more disheartening.  I may call myself the "niggah you love to
hate", but I am not a 'niggah' and never have been.  Never knew any and
haven't met one yet.  Same for the, er , trash.  I've been fortunate to run
into a multitude of human beings.  Some with lotsa faults, some with few,
but all human nonetheless.

As Roger Mudd said in a CBS editorial moment "I've met alot of people in
trailer parks who we're really nice decent Americans, and I've met alot of
rich people in big houses who were nothing but trash."

Peace out, and as Tupac said "Keep your head up!".

Good luck with your choice.  The only way to know how it'll be is to do it!
<- my .02 worth.

Peace,
John

>To those of you who haven't introduced yourselves to us yet: please do so!
>Some of us are very eager to grow this family/community and spread the vibe
>& friendly raving spirit.  So, go ahead and post your introduction, and
>WELCOME in advance :)
>PLUR,
>Eric P.  

	I'm hardly a lurker, but I haven't posted an intro since I joined 
the list about a month & a half ago, so ... 

	Hi! I'm Rob. I'm a computer programmer by trade. I'm also an 
electronic musician, a music producer. I'm a newbie sfraver. I'm 38.
My first intentional rave was the last Mantra, and I went right into 
trance focusing on that damn heavy sacred Buddha of Raven's while this 
loud weird music blew all the thoughts right out of my head ... 

	Before that I had been exposed to the music a bit at Burning Man.
And I had walked into a couple Sundowners by accident while walking my
dogs out at Point Isobel. I'm sorry folks, but if you're coming to *my*
hangouts, I'm coming to yours, too ...
 
	I'm into long-term hedonism. I seek pleasure by looking for 
things that will make me feel better & better over long periods of 
time. Some of these are well-regulated diet (ovo-lacto-pesco-vegetarian), 
prayer and medititation, exercise, not smoking anything, avoiding quick 
fixes like drugs and alcohol that bring you up for awhile then leave you 
lower than you started off ... I've been on this path for many years now, 
and I can say from experience that it's better than drugs (for me, anyway).

	Hope to see you soon. I'm different in real life than I sound 
on electric paper ...

	Love, 


		Rob

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Sat, 18 Jan 1997 14:40:23 -0800
To: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com,
        mdr@hutch.pn.com
From: sddpw@sirius.com (Shimako-Dominguez Department of Public Works)
Subject: SubCommander Lycos
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I am an attorney in California and have been made aware of your threat of
legal action against a DJ out here for using the name Lycos.

I was made aware of this threat by an e-mail from Niels P. Mayer, who, in
my opinion, though dramatic, was extremely perceptive in his analysis of
the situation.  I have worked for various corporations out here in
California and understand the concept of doing what is best for your
client, even though that may be unpopular in the eyes of most people.
However, when you take the letter of the law to the ludicrous level that
you have, you are not only doing a disservice to our profession, you are
doing potential harm to your client.  Stopping true trademark infringement
is serious business.  Suing "mom and pop" operations who were using your
corporation's name before the corporation existed is purely evil.  You are
using your money and power to hurt someone who is doing no harm to you.  It
can only backfire in the end.

You have decided to attack a community that has a lot of power.  These may
seem like "crazy kids" to the unkowing, but this is a tight community,
heavily involved in the entertainment and media industries, with lots of
energy and many connections.  I, for one, would not hesitate to provide pro
bono legal assistance to one SubCommander Lycos should he become embroiled
in a patently unnecessary legal action.

The law should be used to help, Mr. Robins, not to hurt.

Sincerely,

Robert A. Kahn, Attorney at Law

Date: Sat, 18 Jan 1997 17:54:39 -0800
From: SDream <SDream@tgrigsby.com>
Reply-To: SDream@tgrigsby.com
X-Mailer: Mozilla 3.0 (WinNT; U)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Hate and SFR
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

A few days ago I put out a message inviting people to write a certain
racist individual and express their opinions of some of his comments.  I
got a bit of negative feedback to that, with the general opinion being
that, flaming someone usually does no good whatsoever.

Ok.  But I'm not ready to let this lie.  I want to suggest something,
and you folks tell me what you think.  If the feedback is positive, I'll
go for it, although I doubt it will be.

It strikes me that this list is warm and spiritual, without color lines,
without (many) prejudices, a truly friendly place where extremely
diverse people are brought together with a common interest.  I don't
think there's anyone here who would argue that the world would be a
better place if there was more tolerance, more love, more acceptance,
qualities you find more often than not in the population of this list.

What if we led by example?  What if we invited some of the folks from
these racist groups to check out our list?  Need we be isolationist? 
Are we afraid to open up and bring these people in and, possibly, heal a
few of them?

I choose the word "heal" because I really feel racism is a mental
disease, an inability to see logically that all people are the same, and
that it's a far better thing to love your fellow man than to hate them
if there's no logical reason for that hate.

Now, I know some of you are reading this in abject horror, ready to
respond vehemently that this is a terrible idea, that we love our
SFRaves and we don't want it corrupted by such horrible people.  But
what are we saying then?  The last couple of days have seen several
messages on this list about how everyone is good deep down inside, how
there's no such thing as trash, no person so evil that they can't be
rehabilitated.

If you really believe that, and the responses I get reflect that, I'll
drop a few messages on some of the racist newsgroups, something to the
effect of:
----------------------

Hi,

I'd like to invite you all to check out a special mailing list, one that
was formed through unity in a single interest, raving.  Raving is so
much to so many people, and the people that have flocked to this list
come from all ages and all walks of life.  We have formed an extended
spiritual family.  If you love to party, if you love to dance, if you
love music, if you love good friends and good times, stop by and check
us out.

-----------------------

Ok, so that's a first draft.  Suggestions are welcome.

Now, I'm not so shortsighted that I can't see I'm inviting a certain
amount of trouble.  Some very nasty individuals will likely show up. 
What I'm asking is not a trivial thing.  But I'm willing to bet that
some of the folks that show up would first find a group of people that
they admire for their intellects and their energy, only to later find
that the very people they've made v-friends with are of different skin
color, religious beliefs, sexual preferences, etc.  

Email is a wonderful equalizer.  One is forced to recognize the mind
first.  All the barriers that we put up in our minds when we meet
someone face to face don't exist here.  The shock could force open some
very closed, dank, and dark little minds.

Just a suggestion.

S

>Date: Sat, 18 Jan 1997 12:34:25 -0800

>were addressed, but I consider the them to be an example of legal
>thuggery. Apparently this gentleman has been using the name "Lycos"
>since before your company existed. Even if if this weren't true, it
>reflects most poorly on your company that it feels that its reputation
>is so fragile that it must persue those who use the word "Lycos" in a
>manner obviously unconnected with Lycos, Inc.
>
>Consequently I will no longer use the www.lycos.com site, and will
>encourage others not to use it.
>
>Yours faithfully,
>
>Jeremy Lawrence
>
>>I am an attorney representing Lycos, Inc. ("Lycos").  Please address
>>future communications to my attention.
>>
>>Lycos believes that you have been using the Lycos name including,
>>without limitation, in the designations "Sub Commander Lycos" and
>>"lycos@cybertribe.com".  Lycos is concerned that this activity
>>constitutes, among other things, trademark infringement, trademark
>>dilution, and unfair competition under the Lanham Act and/or the common
>>law.  This activity may also constitute an unfair or deceptive act or
>>practice.
>>
>>Unless you cease this conduct immediately, Lycos will be forced to take
>>all necessary legal steps to protect its rights.  Lycos will take such action
>>unless, by February 1, 1997, you have confirmed for Lycos in writing
>>that you have ceased using the Lycos mark, any mark containing the
>>Lycos mark, and any mark confusingly similar to the Lycos mark
>>immediately upon receipt of this letter.

Subject: Re: Questions/underground vs. career (long)
Date: Sat, 18 Jan 97 18:40:42 -0800
x-sender: deeje@ricochet.net
x-mailer: Claris Emailer 1.1
From: deeje cooley <deeje@pobox.com>

Precedence: bulk

>So why am I wasting bandwidth on three lists? I am hoping to get 
>insights and perspectives from folks on how these issue could be 
>addressed

Hi Randy,

I felt compelled to share with you my current dilema.

I have been in the commercial software biz for about 8 years now, and 
have reached a peak of sorts.  I've been getting into more 
multi-dimensional forms of expression (the rave scene, my web site, my 
prophecy, etc.) and have recently come to the conclusion that I need to 
make a major career change, from programming word processors, to creating 
digital art.

But how to transition from one form of programming to another?

Well, just last friday, I got a dream opportunity from a small company to 
do all the latest cool digital technology (java, macromedia, cgi stuff, 
web sites, etc) for some of the biggest studios in entertainment today.

I'm afraid of accepting the offer.

Why?  Fear of the unknown.  With my most recent job, I walked in the door 
KNOWING I could do the job, and I have.  That feels good.  Now I'm facing 
a big unknown.

So how does all this help you?  If you were in my position, I'd tell you 
to take the job.  And if I was in your position, I'd take the leap.  Its 
evident to anyone who's chilled in one of your rooms that you really pour 
yourself into what you do :-)  I know you'll stay true to that, even when 
you're doing it full time.

peace and confidence

deeje

Alright, alright...this has starting to go too far; no one is going to sue
anyone.  I'll be so brazen as to guarantee that right now. This is silly
pseudo-legal posturing, and if you must sue someone, please do it away
from this list.

Timothy



On Sat, 18 Jan 1997, Shimako-Dominguez Department of Public Works wrote:

> I am an attorney in California and have been made aware of your threat of
> legal action against a DJ out here for using the name Lycos.
> 
> I was made aware of this threat by an e-mail from Niels P. Mayer, who, in
> my opinion, though dramatic, was extremely perceptive in his analysis of
> the situation.  I have worked for various corporations out here in
> California and understand the concept of doing what is best for your
> client, even though that may be unpopular in the eyes of most people.
> However, when you take the letter of the law to the ludicrous level that
> you have, you are not only doing a disservice to our profession, you are
> doing potential harm to your client.  Stopping true trademark infringement
> is serious business.  Suing "mom and pop" operations who were using your
> corporation's name before the corporation existed is purely evil.  You are
> using your money and power to hurt someone who is doing no harm to you.  It
> can only backfire in the end.
> 
> You have decided to attack a community that has a lot of power.  These may
> seem like "crazy kids" to the unkowing, but this is a tight community,
> heavily involved in the entertainment and media industries, with lots of
> energy and many connections.  I, for one, would not hesitate to provide pro
> bono legal assistance to one SubCommander Lycos should he become embroiled
> in a patently unnecessary legal action.
> 
> The law should be used to help, Mr. Robins, not to hurt.
> 
> Sincerely,
> 
> Robert A. Kahn, Attorney at Law
> 
> 
>

sharif, a fellow sfraves wrote the following while disagreeing with me-

>> love to you all-
>
>What's love got to do with it?

well, i guess we disagree on fundamentals, and thus can't argue anymore.
LOVE HAS EVERYTHING TO DO WITH IT.  when sfraves is no longer a loving
community of ravers, i have no problem packing up my bags and finding
another community.  fortunately, for me, that's not the case, and love has
a lot to do with what goes on on this list.

btw, flaming someone for publically announcing their engagement is a mean
thing to do.  a community is more than the topic that it explicitly
discusses:  it is the lives of those who discuss it, and for sdream, his
recent ingagement (go sdream!!!) is a big part of his life.

love has everything to do with it-

I got a nice response to Ravers with Homepages, and 
continue to recieve new links daily. I'm going to fly
with the idea, so I changed the name to Raver Whitepages 
(even though they're black). I will probably be spending 
the next year adding the links. =o) 
I also moved the site. The new URL is:

	http://www.chosen.org/ravers/

Who knows? Maybe this site will become the Raver Yahoo?
hehe

For those of you that did not recieve or see the first post,
here it is again...
ATTENTION ALL RAVERS WITH HOMEPAGES!!!!!!!!

I have just set up a new site called "Raver Whitepages"
It is located at http://www.chosen.org/ravers/
If you have a homepage that you would like added, Please
either add it via the form located at the site or send me
an e-mail containing the following:

	*Name you would like listed
	*URL
	*Your e-mail address
	*URL of homepage
	*Information about homepage (i.e. is it a business, personal, etc.)

mailto:ravers@chosen.org

You may add a link directly to this page if you like.
I hope to see this site grow quickly and help bond and
unite ravers on the internet. As time progresses, and
the list of links grow, it will be sorted, alphabetized
and searchable. Thank you for your contributions.
-pLuR
-justin

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Frequency 8 was incredible!  I liked what they did with the place 
(trash-bags and tarps covering the walls to protect the place and lots of 
black-lights everywhere so that wherever I went, my white T-shirt looked
like a *light-bulb*!).  The atmosphere was so relaxed!  After the mild
sort of tension lurking occasionally at Emminence, this was a *wonderful*
change of pace. (But don't get me wrong, I still had a blast at
Emminence!)  And yes, the chEmicals were damn nice...  a friend of mine
provided me with an expression for his state of mind at the time:
tripping bawlls!  Oh, and I thought Darcy's (sp.?) spinning was *sweet*!!
Every time I walked into the main dancefloor area, I couldn't help but
dance maniacally!  The people were so raad!!  
Want to say cheers again to Anthony  (starburst dude), Orson, Mat
Lanier(sp?) (<---BTW, cool idea to bring the free-writing rave-book!),
"Kiwi-punch" :), Robert, Maya, and every1 else I met there (sorry I'm bad
with names)!!  I love you all!

BTW, I just sorta' realized I don't think I ever formally introduced
myself, so basically, in a nutshell:  yes, I'm a newbie.  I'm just an
electronic musician/Biology student at UC Davis (soon-to-be graduate,
hopefully), who really developed my taste for techno only about a year
ago, and only recently (about 3 months ago) discovered the wonderful scene
we all know and love (thanx to Uncle Noah)!  I usually wear that silly "I
<heart-symbol> Five Hours of Flowers" T-shirt if I can, because it makes
me feel sooo good, and my "raver-pet" blue-jay velour(?) hand-puppet.  I
also now try to bring a whole bunch of Pixie Stix for all you wonderful
people (also because I luv 'em too)! (...and Apple-O's for those of you
who find me early!) There's more, but I can't think of anything else to
write right now, so...
Hope to see all you folks again really soon!
Much, much happiness and love-
-=Joe=-

On Sat, 18 Jan 1997, Michael J Casey wrote:


> > I went to a YES concert in 1978 and was transformed. I left that concert 
> > deeply caring. I was so blown away by the experience that I wanted to do
> > the same for others. I wanted to design light and sound shows. I wanted 
> > to be a multi-media artist (long before the term was coined).
> 
> that's (IMO) the best reason for being in any rave-related field... 
> having experienced something so powerful that transformed your life, you
> want to do the same for others.  as long as you keep those "others"
> foremost in your mind as the reason for doing it, and don't shift over to
> a money- or popularity-based ethos, there's no danger you'll ever become
> a snob or want to lose touch with the underground...  cuz the underground
> is where it HAPPENS...  the massives i've been to have (by and large;
> this isn't always the case) mostly left me feeling unfulfilled & sorta
> cheated, unless i *really* got what i paid for as far as light & sound
> are concerned.  but even then, the vibe just isn't the same.  if that's
> the reason you got into the scene, no doubt you'll always crave it &
> never lose touch =)


 Maybe I'm just a sic pup but what I dream about are massive's that have 
the small party UG feel. (sigh) Maybe someday my prince(ess) (party) will 
come.


 Thanks for the kind words and encouragement. Support of this sort has 
always been deeply appreciated by me. It helps me in my focus and intent 
and keeps bringing back to that moment when i decided to care.

Hugz,


Ran D.Dreams

On Sat, 18 Jan 1997, John S. Lee wrote:

> At 1:43 AM -0800 1/18/97, Randy C Cone wrote:
> >			Reasons for Doing this.
> >
> > I came from a fairly messed up, white trash childhood. By the time I was
> >a teenaged youth and living in California, I really didn't care much
> >about anything. I had disconnected most of my emotional senses and this
> >caused me (I believe) not to care about anything. Including myself.
> 
> Not to slam you Ran, but I hate the use of the term "white Trash' as much
> as I do the 'N' word.  Since you used it as a personal reference, then it
> is certainly within your perrogative to use it, no problem.

 Thanks for the gentleness in your stating of your opinion John. I know 
how strongly you feel about theses issues  :). I think than the "N" word 
is used on a overall racial basis more than white trash. WT (at least by 
me) is used to label a sub-catagory of certain "white" folks.



> I do not think that ANYONE is trash.  No person in this society is
> disposable, useless, or anything less than human.  I hate it when people,
> due to economic cirumstances, are labled useless or worse yet, trash.
 
 Well, I didn't use WT to imply someone was disposable. I used it because of 
certain lifestyle choices these people had made. My uncle's house was 
always "trashed" There was always trash in the yard, Animal(sp?) feces in 
the yard from way too many, improperly cared for pets, a house that made 
me gag when I walked in, etc.. None of my relatives have been to college. 
let alone a university (I'm the first). My Dad had never been to High 
School and displayed an open contempt for "educated idiots" (a few of 
which I've encountered ;). I'm in school because I've worked my way to 
school (after overcoming many problems from childhood) mostly because 
I've made the choice to do so. I really don't think I'm all that much 
smarter than most of my relatives. I just made a choice to improve my lot.


>   To see an intelligent person as yourself buy into the hype
> is even more disheartening.

 Thanks for the left handed compliment. ;) I don't buy into it. It is a 
conscious decision on labeling that I've choosen.



> 
> Peace out, and as Tupac said "Keep your head up!".


 Thanks John!  :)



> 
> Good luck with your choice.  The only way to know how it'll be is to do it!
> <- my .02 worth.

 Thanks for your piece. As with all advice it will be utilised in some way.

hugz,

"Food of the God's is by Terrence Mackenna and it is certainly the
difinative book on the subject of mushrroms and, possibly, LSD.  It does
not, however, contain any info what-so-ever on Extacy.  There are two
books on this subject and they are the E takers bible: the first one is
called "Extacy: the MDMA story" by Bruce McCulloch (I think that that is
his mane) and is available at a number of shops on the Haight including
Ameba; the second one, which is more difficult to get a hold of and
contains information on all drugs, is called "Love affair with chemical
substances" by A and A Shulkin.  Everything that one could possibly ever
find useful information on E will be contained with-in these pages.
happy reading!
Tristan.

Subject: Re: Questions/underground vs. career (long)
In-Reply-To: <199701190238.SAA11424@rgate.metricom.com>

Hi!  ]=)


On Sat, 18 Jan 1997, deeje cooley wrote:


> I have been in the commercial software biz for about 8 years now, and 
> have reached a peak of sorts.  I've been getting into more 
> multi-dimensional forms of expression (the rave scene, my web site, my 
> prophecy, etc.) and have recently come to the conclusion that I need to 
> make a major career change, from programming word processors, to creating 
> digital art.
> 
> But how to transition from one form of programming to another?
> 
> Well, just last friday, I got a dream opportunity from a small company to 
> do all the latest cool digital technology (java, macromedia, cgi stuff, 
> web sites, etc) for some of the biggest studios in entertainment today.
> 
> I'm afraid of accepting the offer.

 Here is some input I recieved from the Goa list;

> The best construction, I think, is one I've seen many times. Make a
> distinction between the 'real' art (i.e. where your heart lies) and the 
> more
> commercial 'art' (i.e. where the money lies). If you are strong enough to
> keep those two seperated, you can use the commercial part to make some
> money, which will enable you to continue doing the things you want to do
> with your heart.

> 
> And if I was in your position, I'd take the leap.  Its 
> evident to anyone who's chilled in one of your rooms that you really pour 
> yourself into what you do :-)  I know you'll stay true to that, even when 
> you're doing it full time.

 Thanks for your kind and supportive words!  :) I certainly am going to 
go professional if I have the oppertunity. I'm just trying like mad to 
get input on how to do it without losing my edge. You folks in SFrave 
land (both virtual and beyond) have been very supportive and helpful in 
reaffirming for me what really counts (vibe!). I'll always carry that 
with me and I hope I can show it to others.

 I know there are a few people I've worked with who are probably shaking 
their heads (is this Ran talking, the stress monstor from H3?), but yes I 
have learned a lot. Between balancing PLUR with artistic vision and 
intent. You folks did that for me. Thank you.


hugz,


Ran D.Dreams

sorry to blast this post to everyone.  

but, for the last several months people have come up to me saying something
like, "Kc, it is sooooo good to see you!!" and this would be great if i was
kc, but im just not. :-(

"hi jeremy, im kc, and for the past several months people have been coming up
to me saying, 'hi jeremy!! it is good to see you again.' so i just wanted to
meet you"

but, i never got to talk to kc after that, and would like to just let you/him
know that it was grand to finally meet you/him. 

sooo, sorry to waste everyonee elses time.

		___ACiD-BrE@KS___

**GOOD**			**BAD**
1)PHAT breakbeat all night!     1)crappy location;Marina Skate
2)sold TONS of glow-apparel!    2)waited in line for 2+ hours
3)free h20 & real toilets	3)PSYCO security w/ pepper spray
4)great vibe once inside ;)	4)1000 ravers OVER capacity= HOT
5)met/brought Newbie ravers	5)see below...

			((IMPORTANT SYNOPSIS))
Upon arriving some ASSH*LE security comes directly to us with 3 other 
'buddies' pointing their lights in our faces..."chewing already?" he 
said...  "whatcha got?"   Im totally SOBER and dont do/deal/promote drugs 
and have a completly EMPTY backpack on me (for our jackets)  and this 
jerk off comes to ME! sheesh.... so he felt stoopid after that and walked 
off in a huff...  SO

later while in line we hear yelling and stuff, and see the same security 
screaming at some guy in a red truck who'd just pulled up.  soon he had 
gotten thru the window and was punching the dood in the face, then with 
the help of another 4 securtiy, pulled the guy of of the truck as he was 
trying to drive away  and started kicking him and then beating his head 
on the side of the vehicle... once in a bloody heap they dragged him off 
somewhere and some guy took off with his truck!  WHAT THE HELL HAPPEND? 
ANYBODY KNOW?  DAMB...

even later about 10 feet from the entrance some dork in line is mouthing off 
to still the same original security guy... he hears it and looks up 
directly at me pointing his light ONCE again!  this jerkoff now is 
yelling at me "thats it, YOU LEAVE!"  i tell him in all honesty "i didnt 
say that, i swear"  and responds "GO THE F*CK HOME, LEAVE, if you DONT, 
NOBODY IS COMING IN UNTIL I *MAKE* YOU LEAVE!!"   
	so what am i supposed to do???  this nuttcase is gonna kick my 
ass if i dont leave right now... so i go take off my jacket and hat and 
slick down my hair and prayed id get searched by the other guard (there 
were 2)  and i got lucky... i got in.. once inside  YEAHHH!!!!! 
	GREAT PARTY!!!!   wierd crowd, but EVERYONE was dancing!! so it 
didnt matter at all...  i did have a blast...

	*NOTE*
if anybody knows GHOSTRIBE or their connections to their security...  
I WANT TO KNOW WHO THE 6'5" WHITE JACK*SS WITH THE GOATEE & SHORT BROWN 
HAIR IS...    that guy was SO out of line the whole night.

	Ghostribe should really be pretty ashamed for what that guy did, 
and how it reflects upon them and their parties.

im out now! ;)
pees, LiQuiD

Hi!  ]=)

 Sorry to hear about the asshole security guy. It is amazing what jerks 
those people can be. A tip; next time find the promoters in the party 
(I'm sure you can do it-it's not hard if you talk to the right people) 
and tell them what is going on. That way they can go watch the creeps in 
action (hopefully). Believe me, these asswipes have lying down to an art 
and can twist your story all around. These problems need to be witnessed 
by the working crew (Ghost Tribe in this case) and/or have LOTS of 
witnesses. 

 Sorry I missed the Madame's B-day party! HAPPY BIRTHDAY SHERRY!!  =)) 
I was very sick with a flu/viral thing (still am a tiny bit) and have 
been laying low all weekend.

> the help of another 4 securtiy, pulled the guy of of the truck as he was 
> trying to drive away  and started kicking him and then beating his head 
> on the side of the vehicle... once in a bloody heap they dragged him off 
> somewhere and some guy took off with his truck!  WHAT THE HELL HAPPEND? 
> ANYBODY KNOW?  DAMB...
> 
> even later about 10 feet from the entrance some dork in line is mouthing off 
> to still the same original security guy... he hears it and looks up 
> directly at me pointing his light ONCE again!  this jerkoff now is 
> yelling at me "thats it, YOU LEAVE!"  i tell him in all honesty "i didnt 
> say that, i swear"  and responds "GO THE F*CK HOME, LEAVE, if you DONT, 
> NOBODY IS COMING IN UNTIL I *MAKE* YOU LEAVE!!"   
> 	so what am i supposed to do???  this nuttcase is gonna kick my 
> ass if i dont leave right now... so i go take off my jacket and hat and 
> slick down my hair and prayed id get searched by the other guard (there 
> were 2)  and i got lucky... i got in.. once inside  YEAHHH!!!!! 
> 	GREAT PARTY!!!!   wierd crowd, but EVERYONE was dancing!! so it 
> didnt matter at all...  i did have a blast...
> 
> 	*NOTE*
> if anybody knows GHOSTRIBE or their connections to their security...  
> I WANT TO KNOW WHO THE 6'5" WHITE JACK*SS WITH THE GOATEE & SHORT BROWN 
> HAIR IS...    that guy was SO out of line the whole night.
> 
> 	Ghostribe should really be pretty ashamed for what that guy did, 
> and how it reflects upon them and their parties.
> 
> im out now! ;)
> pees, LiQuiD

Look, I'm not trying to get down on you or anything for your opinion, but 
yours is the first complaint about the number of NRR messages that I've ever 
seen on the list.  The rest of us seem to either enjoy the NRR messages, or 
don't mind filtering them out.  This isn't a big issue, it's quite simple to 
delete NRR messages.  I often do when I have very little time free.   
 
We are a community of ravers here.  I believe that the community is what makes 
this list interesting, not the raving.  The raving *creates* the community, 
which we all can enjoy and be a part of, and also choose to have nothing to do 
with if we so desire.  Anyhow, that's my 2 cents worth. 
 
PLUR 
 
 
Lucas Ritting 
 
**  Futuaris Non Irresus Ridebis **

DJ Tracy and I want to organize a FMR for the upcoming Full Moon.
We feel that the FMRs are important and that someone needs to once again play
funky house beats under the moon and stars.   Markie of the Wicked crew is
down for playing as well as Tracy and myself, Garth hasn't verified yet
whether he is down or not. However this can only happen if we have HELP.
We need folks to lend us energy, maybe a (small) working sound system and most
of all, be around in the morning to help carry it out (or off) the beach.
The FMR at their peak were a focalizing point, they brough people out into
nature, instead of stinky smelly clubs, they let brought younger ravers and
older ravers together and they were the best place to introduce newbies to
what it was all about.  We need help if we are to get these started again
and to keep them positive and not just be a vector for nitrous proffiteers,
and drug dealers.
Any volunteers can e-mail me here or leave a message at 541-5632

What's up SFR?

Well, considering all of the things that could have made this party bad,
I'd have to say that I had a good time until Santa Clara Po Poes showed up.
When I first arrived, the place was empty. The space was pretty nice, but
it turned out to be too small. By around midnight, there was barely room to
walk. The music was good all night long. The sound system was pretty rad
too. This party had potential, but it got busted at around 1:15 am. I was
really impressed with the turn out. I've never been to a rave in the San
Jose area, so I thought it would be pretty dead, but I was wrong. Anyways,
thanks to the promoters of Focus for thinking of us down here in the South
Bay, and I hope you can pull off another party soon.

Rave On!
Ivan

things..

someone off..  Who knows..    But I did also hear another ravE related

just grape vine shit..  So don't quote me.

From: Adam Guevara <aguevara@rely.com>
To: "'Sfraves@hyperreal.com'" <Sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: A weekend review...
Date: Mon, 20 Jan 1997 14:00:39 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.994.63
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

11:45  Saturday:

So here we are, we being six dudes ranging in age and raver expieriance,
in two cars headingtowards SJ.  My car is blasting jungle, thanks to
DJ's Hannabal Selecta and Simulacra, while my friends' Fourrunner is
playing an imported Chemical Bros. CD.  We swerve, we turn, we get lost
because Bascom turns into Washington before Layfette St. 
"Ehh, hey guys lets go to that 7-11 and check these directions"
Phoning the 411, Im verifing the details while everyone else go into
this redicilous routine on how many ways one can say 420.  Which is fun,
I admit, but they're screaming names to each other between cars:

	Raver A(My car): "Yo, you got any BOMB!!" 
	Raver B (thiers): "What? Are you speaking about the dank!!??"
	Raver C(Mine): Im looking for some Purple Haze, you got's the purple
	haze??"
	Raver D (Thiers): "Hey, do you guys smell some skunk around??"
Ten minutes and a lot of original and well known names later, we are
heading in the rigth direction, the anticipation is lingering in the
air...
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-==-=-
So I get to the F-8 mappoint @ 4PM and spend most of the time chatting
with poeples and talking to goa-trance DJ IVO.  We're discussing the
state of goa trance (in which I will correctly refer to as psyedellic
trance from now on) and where it seems to be progressing.  He shares
with me his experiences of being brought into the scene and how he
chooses to contribute in expressing his message through music via DJing
and possibly making, in the future...
Max Factor joins us and a few of my friends (former SFR, DJ Sahid 'n' a
few more) chill till about 8PM, kick everyone out and I grab a bit to
eat.  
Mappoints are funny, from street philosiphers, the guys that's sooo
stecked that he cant figure out which is the 10$ bill, to that dude who
really REALLY needs a ride there. 
Im trying to get amped off of everyone else's vibe and finally, @ 12:45,
we sellout.  Flying down 101 @ oh, 90 or so MPH (hey, mycar wasn't built
for 65...). I arrive, give my ticket to the doorguys (like I said, I'm
just another raver) I walk in....
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
to a pretty nice warehouse in the industrial section of SJ. Visuals are
displaied across the walls and some breakbeatish-house is going through
the speakers.  I ask the time and it's about 12ish. I wander and feel
the crowd.  A large hispanic and asian mix but no additiudes whatsoever.
 I get to the front and see Mr. DJ (im sooo unfamillar w/south bay
techno DJ's) working three turntables.  Nice set, no choo-choo's, I get
to gruuving... Sliding into that housey vibe I begin my journey into the
funked triipy would of down breaks, backward bass thumps and watery
wicka-wicka sounds of breakbeat...
I lose my friends to the crowd, and im pretty much a stranger in this
scene, but the coolest thing is that through dancing, I start "making
friends"... A grin here, a wink there, someone shows me thier 'move' I
show mine.  No competitiveness, at least im not trying to show any, Im
just likning my body/mind/spirit to the song at hand...
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
And what a fu*#!ng HARD song that is!!!  I head straight to the dance
floor.  Surrounded by my"family", I see soo many faces I can't list them
all...  Grins galore Im getting way into the trance that Mystr-E is now
spinning.  I must admit the jams he thru went way back to the red rock
days of 95'.  I guess you could call this set, "the history of Mystr-E"
or, "Mystr-E's Anthologies".  Dancing non-stop at a very furious beat,
I'm brought to a state where every cell of my being is resonating with
this powerful vibe.  I've gone, "c-u soon Adam" now it's just rush.  A
high without any substance.  A sense of knowing, an apex it only lasts
the duriation of a song and then mixed down to this state where my body
is somewhat complaining because its 2:30AM and Mr. body has been running
sice 6 friday morning.
I walk off to get some water in a seculded hidey hole only I seem to
know (he, he).  And when I come back I hear MARS starting off his set.
I fast-step it back to the turntables and start gruuving to a lil build
up into a dark (allthough, I've heard darker) set.  I must admit I was
floored by one jam, shookup so much I had to stop dancing alltogheter
and gather what sense was knocke outta me from that particular track...
I stop to rest by a speaker and my stomach is going through motion
sickness.  Improvement is needed. I smile.
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
at this one girl and offer her a puff of my pipe, she accepts and we
chat a bit.  She gives me this lil' panda clapper (that now dangles on
my car visor), then suddenly without any warning, the music fades down
the doors close, and a "no ins and outs" sign is tossed on the door.  I
sense the impending doom of "the bust" I ask for the time.  1 O'clock.
By one-ten we're out in the street trying to fig. what to do next...

1:30  Milpitas:
Several of us are high, some tripping. Me sober (and cold, my shirts are
very, very sweaty) sowe drop off two of our friends and drive endlessly
through backroads and county streets.  One of my friends is trying very
hard to verbalize his shroom' trip and we are all laughing at the
result.  I might be a bit high, but, with my friends, I feel a happines
that only friendship can bring.  We park off the road and wander about
some regional park @ 4:30 in the morning. We all head out in different
directions, me doing a bit of soul searching. Im happy, eventhough the
party was busted. Im content dispite the coldness around me.  Im in
love, with life in general.  Nothing coud of made this night more
perfect.  Only if you choose to can you be brought down by situations.
But we do have a friend who is wandering in the woods so I search...
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
For my shirt that I took off arounf 2:30. It's now 6 and my body is
crying, "bed,bed, pillow,pillow"  I still have enough energy to give a
few gal-pal's of mine a ride back to the city and say my thnks to the
DJ's. The clean up crew is moving trash, JK is moving the speakers and
im moving out the door...
Many many things happend that night.  I resoved some personal issues,
said some private goodbyes to persons in my life, said hello to some new
ones as well...   All in all, very fine.  I see my path musically.  I
know my niche.  Hello to all those I saw and howdy to the promoters I
spoke with as well (yeah,yeah, I might go to GT just too see all the
rooms open @ this event).  
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
So we return to society, the sun is up.  Im at my car.  I look to the
sky.  But I see myself.  A raver isn't just one who goes to parties,
I've learned, but one who tryies to keep improving themselves while
trying to spread positivity not just you yours, but the lives of others
as well...

But hey, that's just my interpetation.

-reading back, it seems a bit long, sorry.  If so I'll trimm it down
next week...

"Stay Connected"

--_Adam

Bad news, folks. 

Some dorks took a couple of keyboards belonging to the owner of the space we
used for the Sunday afterparty. The owner's cool, but he's a pretty
depressed, and doesn't want to do anything for a while, unless he get his
gear back.

Which leads us to Wed. and Audio Impact.

Since we use the same space, we're in a bit of a bind. Ideally, we'd like to
use the same location. So we're asking for a little help.

The suspect is female, dark hair, brown eyes, blue jacket. We're pretty sure
she told her freinds where the gear was, as two keyboards area lot for one
person to carry.

 Funny thing is that there were a lot of other expensive stuff where the
keyboards were. So it seems the suspects got stupid and took what they
thought was cool, and left the REALLY good stuff behind.  Whatever.

If anyone hears of sees anything that might lead us back to the goods, we'd
be forever grateful. A choice space is in jepoardy because a couple of kids
decided they want to try and become musicians.

On Sat, 18 Jan 1997, Shimako-Dominguez Department of Public Works wrote:

> I am an attorney in California and have been made aware of your threat of
> legal action against a DJ out here for using the name Lycos.
> 
> I was made aware of this threat by an e-mail from Niels P. Mayer, who, in
> my opinion, though dramatic, was extremely perceptive in his analysis of
> the situation.  I have worked for various corporations out here in
> California and understand the concept of doing what is best for your
> client, even though that may be unpopular in the eyes of most people.
> However, when you take the letter of the law to the ludicrous level that
> you have, you are not only doing a disservice to our profession, you are
> doing potential harm to your client.  Stopping true trademark infringement
> is serious business.  Suing "mom and pop" operations who were using your
> corporation's name before the corporation existed is purely evil.  You are
> using your money and power to hurt someone who is doing no harm to you.  It
> can only backfire in the end.
> 
> You have decided to attack a community that has a lot of power.  These may
> seem like "crazy kids" to the unkowing, but this is a tight community,
> heavily involved in the entertainment and media industries, with lots of
> energy and many connections.  I, for one, would not hesitate to provide pro
> bono legal assistance to one SubCommander Lycos should he become embroiled
> in a patently unnecessary legal action.
> 
> The law should be used to help, Mr. Robins, not to hurt.
> 
> Sincerely,
> 
> Robert A. Kahn, Attorney at Law
> 
>

People, if you are going to make attacks about where I work(or have worked
in this case)

1) Please do so privately, because:

   a) Unless you are correct in your statements I will flame the hell out
      of you. 

   b) I will do so publicly, as your original attack was.

   c) I will not shut up until I am done.

That said:

Brian, have you ever stopped to consider, that Value Net has *0* control
over the phone lines which you are connecting to us with? Have you
ever thought "Hey, maybe the problem is with this shitty $15 garage sale
modem?" Or "Gee, the wiring in my house is only 50 years old, I wonder if 
that might be a problem?" 

Here is what is on the other end of your call:

Your call is routed via a bay area FDDI ring to an office in Oakland via
channelized  T-1 directly into a Portmaster-3. No additional analog
conversion. No call-forwarding kludges. No bandwidth destroying Bell
SLC's. It is a digital path all the way.    

Are you so sure that your own house is in order that you can talk shit?

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jan 20 21:32:35 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id VAA12882; Mon, 20 Jan 1997 21:32:35 -0800 (PST)
Received: from emout11.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id VAA12873; Mon, 20 Jan 1997 21:32:30 -0800 (PST)
From: SmileGrl1@aol.com
Received: (from root@localhost)
	  by emout11.mail.aol.com (8.7.6/8.7.3/AOL-2.0.0)
	  id AAA15990 for sfraves@hyperreal.com;
	  Tue, 21 Jan 1997 00:31:55 -0500 (EST)
Date: Tue, 21 Jan 1997 00:31:55 -0500 (EST)
Message-ID: <970121003152_946976393@emout11.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Introducing Myself....
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello, my fellow ravers!!!!  Let me introduce myself....  My name is Julie
Mae and I have been a part of the SF scene since 1992.   I didn't have a
computer all that time, so I didn't know a thing about this...  Anyways, now
that I have caught up (at least a little) with the "information age," I want
to put my 2 cents in on raves and their related topics every once in a while.
 I have not had a chance to read every bit of sfraves mail that was here when
I signed on a little earlier (so many, too little time), but I did notice a
few things that I will try to avoid in order to make things easier for you
guys.   So, if you guys will excuse me for a moment, I must get something off
my chest.                                                              

First off, I will try not to copy and include the other mails that I respond
to in the body of my letters.   I have faith that you guys will most likely
have already read the other letters and will know what I'm talking about and
don't need a cut-and-paste reminder.  If not, you can always scroll through
your mails and look up the subject (that I will tell you).   Secondly, I will
respond to all of the letters I feel like responding to all in one letter.  I
only have room in my mailbox for so many e-mails, and then things start
getting bumped off (I believe).  Because some of you may have the same
problem, I am trying to help ease the load off in at least some small way.  I
don't know about you guys, but having 10 different e-mails written by the
same exact person can get a bit annoying.  (For those of you that do this,
please don't get offended.  I'm just getting out my personal opinion, and
would hope that what I have to say makes sense and will be taken into
consideration in the future.)  People, it can all be written in one
place.....
     Okay, I feel better now.   On to other things...  I only briefly
introduced myself earlier, so I will elaborate a little more now.   As I said
earlier, I've been in the scene since 1992.  My first party was the very
first Funky Tekno Tribe, held at the S.F. Galleria.  That was also my first
experience doing E, or any other drug, for that matter.  What a way to be
introduced!!!  I spent the night trying on people's hats (that I thought were
so cool), singing to random people, going into the men's bathroom to find my
female friends that were in there, and taking E that was being fed to me by a
cute guy that I met in line.   I liked the experience so much that I went to
several parties in the weeks following, including the New Year's Eve
Gathering at the Vallejo fairgrounds.  I took 10 of my friends that had never
been to a party before, got them all E'd out, and had an absolute blast
(despite the rain)!  For those of you who were partying back in those days,
you may remember seeing me around.  I had see-through shoes with
glow-in-the-dark soles and I used to pass out glow-in-the-dark star and moon
stickers for people to wear.  At all the parties I went to, I learned new
tricks and found out about new trip toys.  Before long, I had a backpack full
of these goodies, which earned me the nickname of Felix, because I always
have my bag of tricks!!!   I was part of the original Recycle family that met
every Wed. at The Stone and then partied the next morning at Charter Oaks.
  We lost a dear friend (I won't mention his name) of ours back then... may
he rest in peace.  We miss you!  

Yep!  Those were back in the days when there were killer parties at The Stone
(anyone remember the Vibe or Pull my Finger?), Cesar's Latin Palace (A Rave
called Sharon-Esta a Loco), The Tracadero (Tiptoe thru the Tulips,
Tilt-a-Whirl), 16th and Harrison (Green X & Ham, Vision Quest, Get Down! Get
Down! Get Down! before they fucked up... notice I didn't mention Sin and
Wally World?), and the Richmond Convention Center (Come Unity, The
Gathering).  And then there were the various random parties at other
locations that were happening too (Deep Faith benefit for Malachy, Elmo's
Magical Playhouse, Foundation, etc.)  And last but not least, the Full Moon,
Rave in the Park, and Happy Happy Joy Joy parties were always a great
experience back then.  






















































                                                                             
I miss those days... Unfortunately as 1993 progressed, the E that was going
around got bad and everyone started doing speed heavily (including myself)
and the scene started to change.  There were other reasons (besides the
speed) for the change.  One is that there was an increase in the heavily
commercialized raves that attracted a lot of people with bad attitudes.  You
know exactly what I'm talking about.... so I won't say anything further on
that.  Since the end of 1993, when I became pregnant, I have not been in the
scene nearly as much and I don't do near the variety of drugs that I was
doing then.  My week is no longer parties from Wednesday 'til Monday with no
break.  I only go maybe once a month now.  

My life has changed a lot since those days when I was sort-of a mother hen to
all my young friends from Marin County (I never understood why there were so
many 14-year-olds running around doing large amounts of Crystal Meth 5 days a
week).  I have continued to go to raves because of the music, my friends, and
to dance, among other things, but there is something missing...

I can never get back what it used to be.   I keep going, hoping that I'll
find a warehouse full of revelers that has that same euphoric aura that
embodied so many of the parties a few years back when it seemed that more
people were race-blind, style-blind, etc.   We all felt that we were part of
something truly special and there was nothing going to stand in the way of
that search for a united happiness.   Back then, the optimistic attitude of PL
UR seemed a real possibility for the world and our generation, or at least
our own "little world" within it.  Don't get me wrong... I still believe in
it, as many of you do.   It's just that we have taken a few steps back in our
quest the last couple of years.  Someone mentioned in their letter (Paul, I
think) that the scene is deteriorating.  It's been deteriorating for some
time now.  This is not a new concern for us.  We need to take hold of our
scene NOW and make it what we want.  Get the people who throw the parties to
truly take it underground again.  If not, throw your own.  That's what many
of my friends have done.  You don't need a huge warehouse, etc., to have fun.
 Some of the best parties I've been to have been in cozy little nooks or
hole-in-the-wall spaces and were free or cost next to nothing.  And best of
all, they weren't advertised at malls, high schools (please don't take this
the wrong way), etc.  For the most part, they were advertised by
word-of-mouth.  There were awesome vibes and fun was had by all.   

I'm not trying to stand on any soapbox, guys, so please don't get mad at me.
 I'm just telling you a little about how I have viewed our scene.  I love the
Bay Area.  I think we have the best scene in the world.  But most of all, I
love all of you.  
                    
Peace and Love,
JULIE MAE

P.S.  Does anyone know how to get ahold of some TMA?  Hardly anyone knows
what it is.  A friend of mine gave me a hit of it a long time ago and I've
only seen it sold at a party once.  I want to do it again.  It was truly the
best trip I've EVER had, let me tell you....

P.S.S.  Through the years, I've kept a rave journal full of cool quotes,
poems, and sayings that I've either made up, seen in books, or come across on
rave flyers or notes people have passed out at parties.  Every time I write a
letter to you guys, I'll include one of them as my Quote-For-The-Day.  I'm
not taking credit for all of them, just spreading the word...  To start out,
I actually have two that are appropriate.  The first is a good philosophy for
what the scene needs more of.  The second is a large reason for my choosing
the screen name SmileGrl1.  I hold it dear to my heart.

We pass through this world, this life only once.  If along the way, I may
touch a person, perform a kind deed, or be a friend to anyone in need, let me
do so.  We are all here for each other and we only get one chance.  Let's
make it a good trip for all.   Peace.

A smile costs nothing, but gives much.  It enriches those who receive,
without making poorer those who give.  It takes but a moment, but the memory
of it sometimes lasts forever.  None is so rich or mighty that he can get
along without it, and none is so poor but that he can be made rich by it.  A
smile creates happiness in the home, fosters good will in business, and is
the countersign of friendship.  It brings rest to the weary, cheer to the
discouraged, sunshine to the sad, and it is nature's best antidote for
trouble.  Yet it cannot be bought, begged, borrowed, or stolen, for it is of
no value to anyone until it is given away.  Some people are too tired to give
you a smile.  Give them one of yours, as none needs a smile so much as he who
has no more to give.  ;-)


Sorry, guys, about the book I seem to have just written.  Once I got started
with my thoughts, I had a hard time stopping!

Hello all...

I guess it's time to come out of the shadows and introduce myself.  My name is Omar (no, NOT 
Omar Sharif, or Omar kadafi; actually I'm central american, chapin to be exact--any other 
chapines on this list?) and my first rave was also one of Funky Tekno Tribe's Halloween Tribal 
massives.  I believe it was their second one in 1993 and also took place at the Galleria (so we 
might have bumped into each other Julie).  I grew up in Santa Barbara and went several times to 
NYC when Doc Martin dj'd there for a while.

I spent the last five years going to school in SLO town (Cal Poly), and it's club (or rave) 
scene lives up to the towns initials.  Although, the parties being thrown there have gotten alot 
better in the last couple of years.  Luckily, I was able to get a job near a place I always 
wanted to live (San FranDisco!:)  Although I don't live right in the city, I'm about 45 minutes 
south (sunnyvale to be exact), which is alot better than 4 1/2 hours.  Anyhow, now that I live 
closer to where the action is, I'm going to parties or clubs about once a week (Nikita on 
fridays, and any good parties on sat.)  So far I love being here!  Anyways, enough of my 
blabbing and I hope to actually meet some of you at a party sometime.

PLUR......................Live, Love, Laugh................

Omar

Subject:	World Meditation Day

Dear Friends,

While there have been many announcements floating around
the internet about World Meditation Day, this one stands out
to me for its clarity in explaining why and how each of us
might want to participate in our own way.-Kurt Wright
-----------------------------------------

World Meditation Day
Thursday, January 23rd, 1997
Between 12:00 and 1:30 Local Time
Dr. John Miles Evans
JohnMEvans@aol.com
11 January 1997

On 23 January 1997 a group of eight planets will form a variant of an 
unusual pattern-a six-pointed star.  Sometimes known as a Grand 
Sextile or Star of David, this pattern is an integration of various 
diverse energies into a harmonious whole.
This variant is the more unusual in that it is actually a five-pointed 
star, but aligned so that the Ascendent-the point on the horizon -- 
 makes the sixth "point".  As a result, meditation or other 
intentional activity at this time may serve to trigger the latent 
energies in the overall planetary pattern -- completing the circuit, 
as it were, through the efforts we make at this time.
The exact time when this occurs varies with locality.  For most 
locations in the northern hemisphere the time is between 12 noon and 
1:00 pm, but there are some locations where the time may be as late as 
1:30 pm; Miami, Florida is one such location.(1)
For those who are not students of astrology, a brief introduction may 
be appropriate.
One can understand any pattern of the planets as a symbolic 
representation describing the nature and qualities of a particular 
moment of time-operating through the principle CG Jung termed 
"synchronicity."(2)
While written language is linear-one word following another-the 
"language" of astrology is a complex pattern, which cannot be 
adequately translated into a linear form.  But some sense of the 
meaning of this pattern may be gleaned through studying the individual 
planets involved, and their location by "sign" and "house" (two 
indicators of qualities expressed by planets in the pattern).
In the planetary pattern for World Meditation Day, the Sun, Jupiter, 
and Uranus are all "conjunct" (together) at the beginning of Aquarius, 
in the Ninth House, along with Neptune in late Capricorn in the Ninth 
House.  These planets are harmoniously related to Saturn in Aries in 
the 11th, Pluto in Sagittarius in the 7th, and Mars in Libra conjunct 
the North Node in the 5th House.  The fifth "point" is the Moon in Leo 
in the 3rd House.
Aquarius is the sign most connected with humanity as a whole, and is 
particularly activated by group efforts.  That three 
planets-representing Being and Identity (Sun), Expansion and Wisdom 
(Jupiter), and Sudden Awakening (Uranus) -- are all concentrated in 
Aquarius is quite significant.
Mars, the planet of activity, conjuncting the North Node of the Moon, 
an indicator of spiritual integration and development, in the 5th 
house, that of creativity and personal expression, indicates that 
those who take action to participate in the pattern may further their 
own spiritual awareness.
Pluto, the planet of purification and regeneration, is located in 
Sagittarius in the 7th House, symbolizing a transformation of our 
belief systems through forming committed relationship with those 
aspects of ourselves which we may have ignored or taken for granted 
previously.  In this case "ourselves" may represent our common 
humanity, and the need to understand all human beings as being equally 
valuable and important.
The Moon, located in Leo in the 3rd house is opposing the planets in 
Aquarius.  This gives added dynamic tension to the overall pattern. 
 The Moon is symbolic of our deepest feelings, Leo has a great deal to 
do with our sense of identity, and the Third House is the area of 
mental concepts.  This implies that there may be a tendency to oppose 
the movement toward a broader understanding and a new orientation 
toward ourselves because of our emotional attachment to old ideas 
about life, and old beliefs about our sense of who we are.
Neptune, located in the Ninth House in Capricorn, indicates the 
possibility of dissolving old belief systems to make way for the new. 
 This idea is presented in different ways in several areas of the 
overall "chart" for the day.
The sixth "point" is the Ascendent in early Gemini.  Gemini is 
strongly associated with the conscious mind.  By actively engaging in 
meditation or other focused mental activity at this particular time, 
one has the opportunity both to expand one's own awareness, and also 
to further the expansion of humanity as a whole-breaking down the 
barriers separating each of us as individuals, and becoming 
participants in a type of "world mind", in which we recognize our 
common humanity as the most important component.
This is emphasized by the presence of Saturn, the planet symbolizing 
traditional structure and limits, in Aries, the sign of new beginnings 
(where Saturn's power is weakest) and in the 11th or (Aquarian) House 
where that structure which can be developed is focused on the birth of 
a "group mind".
Finally, Mercury, the planet most associated with Gemini, is in 
Capricorn in the 8th House, indicated the possibility of purification 
and transformation of our conceptual picture of life through focused 
effort, with the need to let go of old emotional ties to past concepts 
about how life is.
Astrologers will see much more in this pattern than presented here. 
 But for those who are not astrologers, I hope this overview will give 
you some sense of the significance of this opportunity for both 
individual and group development, and the importance of taking time on 
23 January between 12 noon and 1:00 pm to participate quietly in this 
important event-in whatever way seems best to you.
One last point-"intent" is all important with this pattern.  For those 
who wish to make maximum use of this unusual opportunity, a period of 
preparation in which you look at your own deepest beliefs and desires 
for change may be useful.  And practice meditations, in which you work 
on focusing your intent for what you wish to achieve on 23 January, 
may also be helpful.
My blessings to you in however you choose to participate.
Footnotes
(1)	For those who would like the exact time for your location, consult 
a local astrologer and ask for the time when the Ascendant is at 4-5 
degrees Gemini on 23 January, 1997.
(2)	Jung, CG.  "Synchronicity, an Acausal Connecting Principle".
In Collected Works, Vol. 8:  Structure and Dynamics of the Psyche.

<kwright@maui.net> with the request: remove from H/B List

SmileGrl1@aol.com wrote:
>P.S.  Does anyone know how to get ahold of some TMA?  Hardly anyone knows
>what it is.  A friend of mine gave me a hit of it a long time ago and I've
>only seen it sold at a party once.  I want to do it again.  It was truly the
>best trip I've EVER had, let me tell you....

TMA is trimethoxyamphetamine, the amphetamine analogue of mescaline
(trimethoxyphenethylamine).  Reports generally suggest a stimulating but
less substantial effect for TMA (which could be good, of course...de
gustibus and all).  Couldn't tell you myself, I'm afraid, but thought
people might be interested.

anarch@scruznet.com

Well I had a rather interesting night at Acid Breaks this Sat. It was a,
how should i say it, a differnt vibe all together. When we got there
around 11:00 the line was miles long. We didn't have pre-sale or anything
so we had to wait in the one in front. All our friends were in the very
front with  a huge mess of people and it would have been impossible to
get in with them. So we got in the way back. We were pretty pissed about
that too. 

Then some fight broke out right ahead of us between two Gs. (Go figure)
The whole line went to look at the fight. We seized the oportunity and
moved way far ahead, but still there was this huge massive clump of
people up ahead.

Oh, Yeah. Before that there was the whole security officer thing or
whatever with the guy in a truck. After that was over I went over to this
girl I know and asked her what happend. She said "Dreamer needed to get
his ass beat." No you guys this girl is not a very nice raver at all. So,
I also heardd it was DJ Dreamer. I later heard that night that he owed
Ghostribe and people a whole lot of money as well. I heard too from
someone who heard (and this is definetly a rumor and need to get this
clarafied) That the scurity were supposed to be looking for him and get
the money or kick his ass or something like that. ( I don't know abouot
all that?)

Well, the line was miles long and everything. And me and ome of my
friends decided to go and take a walk. We walked up the side of the line
saying hi to people talking to other ravers we knew. Then we went to the
pre-sale line and talked to more ravers and met some knew ones and stuff.


Then at the very end of the pre-sale line, by the back of Marina Skate,
some security guard was yelling."Tickets! Tickets!" Some we were like,
Okay. We went up and talked to him and he told us o follow him and he
brought us behind Marina Skate and he told us he would let me and him
bothe in the backdoor for $30 right now. We told him we had a group of
like seven people. He thought about it a minute. He said "Be back in
three minutes with all of them and $90 and i will let you guys in" We
literaly ran back to  the line and told our friends and another raver
friend so he could tell all the ravers (and anyone with a smile) that
were in line to do the same. We brought ten of us and $90 and went in. 

When we got in, there was just about no one inside. The vibe wasn't that
great at all, but I made my own and picked up the goodvibe somewho from
all the cool people there (ravers/goodvibes). So i saww all of my friends
in the Jungle room, where all the best vibes were. Even though we had to
listen to jungle. That room had the best vibes. Then later when Weaver
went on, he started playing some House. He played my favorite song in the
world. It goes "Yes, Yes, Y'all don't stop. Yes, Yes, Y'all don't stop" I
love that song. 

Then Carlos went on and I saw some raver girls that i met back in line
dancing on the  skating barrier wall type platform behind carlos. I
thought it was cool because for once ravers were dancing on a platform
instead of some hoey go go dancers acting all sexual. So I went and
joined them. Then it was us dancing. Later i looked over and there were
at least  five other ravers up there. It was hellza cool. 

I had a lot of fun dancing and meeting new friends and talking to my rave
family and stuff. I think it was good once you got inside and made the
best of it. I feel sorry for you Jaime (Paula's brother) because it was
your first massive and first time sober. This is was a really bad example
of a massive rave. The Gathering was a million times better.

Well, thats pretty much it and stuff. Love all you people out there.

Oh and I was sober too.

Also, Jake from Ghost Tribe, could you please tell us what happend with
DJ Dreamer and such? Also please get new security, these people really
ruin the vibe for everyone outside.

PLUR,
Paul
