>Rusty H. Hodge wrote:
>>
>> At 8:08 PM -0800 1/16/97, The Grigsbeast wrote:
>> >MTV, or any 'business', exists to make money.  Any entertainment or
>> >value you may get out of it is ancillary; programming is chosen to
>> >attract the maximum number of viewers possible
>>
>> Wrong. Total oversimplification. (like: all raves are just big drug
>>parties.)
>
>What is your experience working for, working with, or talking to owners
>or directors of large (multi-million) dollar businesses?

I've worked for four radio stations in the last 15 years, and have worked
for CBS/Westinghouse quite a bit in the last two years. I've spend a lot of
time consulting the top executives at KPIX. So I think I'm qualified to
make this statement.

Just read _Broadcasting and Cable_ and you can see this same attitude. For
example, VH-1 and E! do extremely low in the ratings (VH-1 is regularly
watched by only 90,000 homes TOTAL each week), yet the networks continue to
deliver programming to a loyal audience.

I guess you could say that any business only exists to generate pleasure
for the owners of that business; be it indirectly through money (used to
buy pleasure) or through more direct means.

The underground scene exists because it generates pleasure for the people
who create that scene. It just bypasses the money middleman.

--
Rusty Hodge (rusty@hodge.com), Media Futurist / Cyberneticist

http://www.hodge.com  <-- Me Being Professional
http://www.rusty.org  <-- Me Being Silly
http://www.club.net   <-- San Francisco Club Guide

> >> >MTV, or any 'business', exists to make money.  Any entertainment or
> >> >value you may get out of it is ancillary; programming is chosen to
> >> >attract the maximum number of viewers possible
> >>
> >> Wrong. Total oversimplification. (like: all raves are just big drug
> >>parties.)
well, being a film/tv major in college, and having the oppty to hang out 
with the right people, i have to agree with the notion that television, 
EVEN public television nowadays, exists to make money.  there might be 
some compassionate tv owners out there (and lots of independent 
filmmakers), but usually the first people that will get out and build an 
industry are motivated by money and the challenge of achieving 
something.  

> >
> 
> I guess you could say that any business only exists to generate pleasure
> for the owners of that business; be it indirectly through money (used to
> buy pleasure) or through more direct means.
> 
> The underground scene exists because it generates pleasure for the people
> who create that scene. It just bypasses the money middleman.
the same could be said for the film industry.  look at some of the 
actors/actresses that get movies all the time.  sons and daughters of 
actors usully get a good chance.  that's the way the world works.  it's 
not impossible to get on the big screen, just like it's not impossible to 
get a gig spinning at Basics/Gathering.  You just have to pay your dues, 
just like everywhere else.

Its that time again.  The time I dread.  The time to look for a new place 
to live.  My roommate met a girl and fell in love and has decided to move 
to San Francisco to become a rock star.  So I'm stuck high and dry in San 
Jose looking for a new house and a new roommate.   The house I'm in now 
is nice, but its just too small. 

The good news is, I have untill the end of March to find a new house.  So 
I'm starting to look early to find the perfect place.  Ideally, I'd like 
to find a house somewhere in the Race St/The Alameda/Cafe Lavidacus 
(SP?)/Town Theater area of San Jose.  If that doesnt work out, maybe the 
Los Gatos area or some parts of Down Town, like the Taylor and 2nd street 
area.  I'm looking for 1 or 2 other roommates.  I think 4 people in a 
house is getting a little too crowded, unless its a big house.  I 
absolutly do not want to live in an apartment or duplex or condo or town 
house or anything with another living quarter attached to it.      

I work at Apple in the MIQ department.  I work alot.  I'm looking for a 
quit responsible person.  DJ's are fine as long as you dont spin at 3 am 
on a tuesday night.  I have this pet peeve with dirty dishes left in the 
sink.  I used to be really bad with doing dishes.  But then I started to 
hate having to wash a dish everytime I wanted to eat.  Plus, dirty dishes 
start to smell after a while and its really hard to get that dried 
spaghetti sauce off.  So please, no non dish washers.  I am a smoker, but 
I dont smoke inside the house unless what I'm smoking is very green.  I 
have a really cool cat named Midi.  He's my bud.  He sits on the fence in 
front of my house and waits for me to come home everday.  He greets me 
with a simple meow.  He's the most loving cat I have ever met.  He loves 
to curl up on anyones lap.  And he gets along well with others in the 
feline community.  When I'm not working I try to spend as much time at my 
studio doing what I really love, Makin' Music.   So I dont spend too much 
time at home.  Only to eat and sleep.  I'm really not into TV.  I own 
one, but its only to catch the Simpsons and the news on occation.  I dont 
like Cable.  With cable, instead of having 3 channels with nothing on, 
you have 60 channels with nothing on and you get charged 40 bucks a month 
for that.  Although I do kinda miss the Discovery channel!  I dont go to 
Raves as much as I used to.  Maybe one every other month or so.  But I do 
go out to weeklies every now and then.

Well, thats about it.  Please give me a call or email me if you are 
interested in living with a peacefull, easy-goin' guy.  I can pay up to 
about $500 a month.  Any thing more than that is pushing my budget to the 
limit.

Peace,

Mark
408 974 8096 work
408 293 0554 home
 

                       *______________*______________*           
                                   !E.A.C!
                                  Astronout            
                               408 SpaceLounge         
                        Electronic Artists Collective

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@club.net>
Subject: Re: Introducing Myself....
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

That was really beautiful. I am so passionate about the underground because
it's changed my life forever.

Please keep posting about your past experiences, both good and bad. There
is something to be learned from our past since we are doomed to repeat it,
we at least can improve a bit each time!

I believe that more now than ever, we really need some fresh (even if old)
thoughts to help us find our way to a positive future. Rave used to be a
new kind of creature with exciting new energy. It needs to be that again.
We can do it as long as we are 'doing' with intent.

Your letter inspired me to write this:

Lately I have been telling everyone I know that they should create new
energy by having a party in their living room, learn to be a DJ, learn to
make music, be an artist, be beautiful, and to spread inspiration at any
cost. Try to make parties cost nothing but deliver something that can never
be purchased. Change peoples' lives by doing nothing more than express from
your heart. Inspire and lead.

That's what makes a real UG, and as 1997 quickly becomes 1993 again -- it's
going to happen, I sadly promise -- we, the UG, will still exist in our
unoppressible passionate and truth filled expressions that can only come
from real love for what we do. And that most beautiful and truthful
outpouring of energy can never ever really be copied, bottled up and sold
as the product known as rave. It can only be given and shared, because when
it's that real, it is priceless.

Don't be interested, be committed.

I have three folders my sf raves mail may be routed to.

1. into my sfraves folder.
	most things go here.
	(I read most of it)

2. into my sfraves/nrr folder
	everything w/ nrr in the title
	anything posted from certain people
	(I read the contents of this folder when I have insomnia)

3. into my trash folder.
	anything from some other people goes here.
	anything posted my anyone that promotes wearing a d i d a s.
	anything that has the word a d i d a s in it.
	(And I never even see it)

This distillation system works pretty well, although it's not going to stop
a 50 message long thread about e or some other dead horse that is routinely
beaten here.

And that's not even using procmail!

ps: the / character was used in the title to ensure this message got past
Steve Simitzis' NRR procmail filters. Hi Steve! :-)

>     THIS IS MY KIND OF COOKING...
>
>     "Best Ever" Fruitcake Recipe
>
>     You'll need the following:  some music on the stereo, a cup of water,
>     a cup of sugar, four large brown eggs, two cups of dried fruit, a
>     teaspoon of salt, a cup of brown sugar, lemon juice, vanilla, nuts,
>     and a bottle of whiskey.
>
>     Sample the whiskey to check for quality. Make sure the stereo is
>     playing softly (maybe something from Kenny G).  Try another cup of
>     whiskey to be      doubly sure it is OK.
>
>     Take a large bowl.  Check the whiskey again. To be sure it's the
>     highest quality, pour one level cup and drink.  Repeat. Turn on the
>     electric mixer, beat one cup of butter in a large fluffy bowl.  Add
>     one teaspoon of sugar and beat again.  Raise the volume of the stereo,
>     with all this racket you can't hear his melodious sax.
>
>     Make sure the whishkey is still okay.  Cry another tup.  Turn off the
>     mixer. Beat two leggs and add to the bowl and chuck in the cup of
>     dried fruit.  Mix on the turner.  If the fired druit gets stuck in the
>     beaterers, pry it loose with a drewscriver.  The stereo volume seems
>     to be on the low side, jack it up a bit.
>
>     Sample the whishhhkey to check for tonsisticity.  Next, sift two cups
>     of salt. Or something.  Who cares?  Check the
>     whhhis...whizk...boooooze.  Now sift the lemon juice and strain your
>     vanilla.  Add one table.  Spoon.  Of brown sugar  or something.
>     Whatever color you can find.  If the music seems too low, raise the
>     volume a little moore.
>
>     Grease the oven.  Turn the cake tin to 350 degrees.  Don't forget to
>     beat the turner.  Throw the bowl out of the window.  Check the bottle
>     again, max out the stereo and bo to ged.

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Spundae Fun
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9701211729.A24310-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Had an absolute blast at this party!  A far cry from the usual suburban 
hell of Nikita, the only club I frequent on a semi-regular basis (I won't 
throw MAD into this category!).  I was expecting a cheese pick-up scene 
with great music, and instead was happy to find a pure dance scene with 
great music.  

Only $5 to get in, which we thought was a deal until we started buying 
drinks.  Almost $5 a pop, so a night out at da clubz rivals "expensive" 
raves...but that's no surprise.  This time Spundae stayed at DV8 for 
their special party, and it was PACKED.  The family was out in full 
force - somehow seeing people with glowsticks fills me with a warm gushy 
feeling...

The music rocked all night - the most difficult part of the night was 
deciding which of three rooms to dance in!!  We got down to Carlos' set, 
lotsa breaks and scratches, which sounded great to my tranced-out ears.  
We migrated upstairs during Donald Glaude's set and stayed there the rest 
of the night.  He was bouncing around as usual, getting the crowd into 
it.  Dan came on after and spun a totally trancey set!  Last I heard a 
set of his it was pure house, but that was ages ago.  Then Jerry Bonham, 
who completely rocked the house with trancey techno.  I gazed around and 
saw that EVERYONE was getting down - the people on the dancefloor, on the 
"stage", even the stairs and the balcony!  Not a still pair of feet in 
the house and the energy was palpable.  

After Jerry Bonham came a dj I didn't recognize, but his set of 
unrelenting trance was absolutely addictive.  My body wanted to stop and 
couldn't!  Finally I was on the verge of collapse, and asked someone the 
time - 5:30!!  What happened to the night?  We realized it was hours past 
when our bodies should have shut down, and straggled out, covered in 
sweat, hair frizzed into rave-fros, and smiling.  All I know is that 
after that I fell into the deepest sleep, awakening more than 12 hours 
later!

If anyone knows who that dj was, I'd love to know.  He was a white guy 
with short dark hair and a t-shirt that said "Acid Rules."  

DV8 is _nice_ after dirty warehouses.  Sculptures and fountains?  Wrought 
iron balconies?  Artsy bathrooms?  Pure luxury.

I think I have new faith in the club scene.

:)

well ... i finally understand what it must be like for all you kids when
you hit a F&F party.  We here in the northwest just had our first nw-raves
mailing list party,called PLUR, in seattle.  the love and vibe were
untterly astonishing.  no "big name" djs but we didn't need em .. the
talent we had dropping rekkids was JUST FINE! 

The space was The Lish House in Sea., which was the first theater built in
that city apparently ... and it was once used as a jam space by Jimi
Hendrix, so the atmosphere was jussst right!  :)  we had a turnout of
about 200 ppl.  i can't even believe how amazing it all was!  Free water
and tons of fruit and candy and small toys, a table with lots and lots of
paper and pens to draw with, and a professional photographer taking
portraits for free ... copies will cost the amount of the film!  woohoo!

Went from 9pm to 8am and every moment utterly KICKED  and we're gonna have
MORE of em :) i can't wait!  now i know what i've been missing all this
time!

pounce

provided the Whump-Whumps with enough Gubbywub fur and flesh to last the
entire winter.

Adding a small comment, below... (keeping good relative info for those who
delete everything) :D

>Lots of talk about this on sfraves (pleez, excuse the cross-post) thought
>some of you might be interested. :)
>
>>World Meditation Day
>>Thursday, January 23rd, 1997
>>Between 12:00 and 1:30 Local Time
>>Dr. John Miles Evans
>>JohnMEvans@aol.com
>>11 January 1997
...
>> But for those who are not astrologers, I hope this overview will give 
>>you some sense of the significance of this opportunity for both 
>>individual and group development, and the importance of taking time on 
>>23 January between 12 noon and 1:00 pm to participate quietly in this 
>>important event-in whatever way seems best to you.
>>One last point-"intent" is all important with this pattern.  For those 
>>who wish to make maximum use of this unusual opportunity, a period of 
>>preparation in which you look at your own deepest beliefs and desires 
>>for change may be useful.  And practice meditations, in which you work 
>>on focusing your intent for what you wish to achieve on 23 January, 
>>may also be helpful.

Although, I strongly disagree with this "concept" of meditation, I will
attempt to be gentile expressing my opinion here... :)

Some of you who are unfamiliar with meditation techniques may want to
experiment with different ones before the alignment... I practice a
technique known as tan tien meditation: simply sit with your butt on your
heels, toes flat on the floor (keeping your back straight) and relax,
breathing deeply through your nose and into your abdomen. you visualize the
energy in your breath flowing through your body, around your head, down
your back and back up the front of your body and out your mouth. this all
happens while breathing. This energy also flows all throughout your body in
a very specific pattern. you focus your energy on a point 3 inches below
your belly button and 3 inches inside of your body, which is your tan tien.
you visualize it as a green (the color of life) sphere, radiating limitless
energy and light... if you concentrate on the tan tien (and ignore any
distractions) you will achieve "one thought". after practicing for a long
while, you may achieve "no thought", where you truly become one with all
that exists. I haven't reached that point, myself, but sometimes I feel
like I have... ;)

I mention this because, I believe that trying to "get something" from
meditation (purposefully) simply will not work. The point of meditation,
IMO, is to unify with all which exists... the universe will have an
oppurtunity to tell you what to do, as your most sublime and "important"
dreams will be communicated to everything that is.

>>(1)	For those who would like the exact time for your location, consult 
>>a local astrologer and ask for the time when the Ascendant is at 4-5 
>>degrees Gemini on 23 January, 1997.
>>(2)	Jung, CG.  "Synchronicity, an Acausal Connecting Principle".
>>In Collected Works, Vol. 8:  Structure and Dynamics of the Psyche.

matter

By the way, I'm a Cancer (July 13th), not an Aries.  I agree about people's
posts.  People should donate whatever energy they want to the list.  I learn
so many new things that way, even if it is considered "NRR."  I get so many
perspectives on life, love, community, etc., and I wouldn't trade it for the
world.  It is stuff like that that has been filling up my little groovy rave
book all these years, and these philosophies, thoughts, etc. are related to
us in a very REAL way.  If one little "thought" brings a smile to someone's
face, it is worth it.  Talk to you later!
                           Much peace and love,
                                                  Julie Mae

P.S. Here's my thought for the day:
THE PLEASURE YOU GET FROM LIFE IS EQUAL TO THE ATTITUDE YOU PUT INTO IT.

I don't know if word of this has leaked out yet, but there was a
party in Seattle on Saturday night sponsored by nw-raves that was
just totally da bomb.  Held in an old movie theatre/converted loft
space where Jimi Hendrix used to play back when he was just a local
cat playing in bar bands.  Decorations, video portraits, two rooms
of excellent music, total smiles all around.  DIY all the way, and
it works.

The answer to the current woes of the 'scene', encumbered by aimless
music, profiteering, corruption and incipient commercialization:
go deeper, and never ever ever give up.

phred

harsh looks from anyone, just a whole lotta love...

just totally rocked the house with his spinnin, and the next DJ (sorry I =
didn't get a name-- "Rainbow Bridge" or something???) was phat! Good =
work mixing the CDs with the turntables...  did anyone who was there =
catch his name?  He was the one with the long hair with the shirt that =
said "city of angels" on it...

someone from here-- if you were there, I was the big guy wearing the San =

From: Mnemonic <anemec@sirius.com>

X-Mailer: Mozilla 2.01 (Win95; I)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: NRR: More ways to save Headwaters Forest
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear fellow tree huggers,

With the Headwaters rave benefit coming, I thought I would mention (for anyone not 
already in the know) that there are scoping hearings taking place. In fact, there was 
one last week in Oakland and one upcoming in Sacramento. If you make it to a meeting 
you'll be impressed by how people of all kinds have come together to try to save the 
forest. If you can't make it to a hearing, please take a minute and send a letter to 
USFWS. The address is given below. If you want to know more check out 
http://www.igc.apc.org:80/headwaters/hwhome.html or email baaction@igc.apc.org to get 
their updates. The main talking points, at least the ones I used, are to ask the USFWS 
to re-scope the deal to save all 60,000 acres (as opposed to just 7,500 acres), work a 
debt-for-nature swap (as opposed to a nature-for-nature swap which threatens other 
ancient forest and allows the taking of endangered species), ensure that there is 
public oversight of the deal making this time (an end to backroom corporate controlled 
dealmaking which doesn't take biology and sustainability into account), and reinstate a 
moratorium on logging during negotiations. What it boils down to is respecting the 
earth.

Peace, love, and tree hugs.

******************************************************************************

HEADWATERS EIS/EIR SCOPING HEARINGS

Meetings are from 1-4 PM and 6-9PM
1/16 -- Oakland Convention Center, West Hall, 550 10th St. at Broadway
1/23 -- Red Lion, 3100 Camino del Rio Ct., Bakersfield
1/28 -- Red Lion, 1830 Hilltop Dr., Redding
1/30 -- Radison Hotel, 500 Leisure lane, Sacramento
2/5 -- Redwood Acres Fairgrounds, Franceschi Hall, 3750 Harris St., Eureka
2/11 -- Radison Plaza, 1400 Park Ville Ave., Manhattan Beach

Comments on the scope of the EIS may be sent before 1/31 to: Bruce
Halstead, USFWS, 1125 16th St., Rm. 209, Arcata, CA 95521-5582, FAX (707)
822-8136.

For more information on the Headwaters scoping hearings, call Helen
Wagenvoord of the Headwaters Sanctuary Project, (510) 444-4710.

hello?
THE Raver Whitepages haz moved.
The new address is
http://www.chosen.org/ravers/

I NEED HELP!!!
The Raver Whitepages is a non-profit effort to offer the rave scene
something it has lacked previously, a search engine/database consisting of
homepages belonging to ravers, rave related business' (i.e. record stores,
promoters, etc.), and other sites belonging to the rave scene (or the
people in it). I started this on a whim, and flew with the idea - probably
a little too fast. =o)

I am using space on my personal shell account, and spending a lot of my
time checking the sites and entering the data manually after it is e-mailed
to me.

I know there are some brainy sfravers out there...? maybe?
If anyone knows cgi and perl, I would greatly appreciate a script that
would ease the addition/maintenance of the Raver White Pages. I will work
out some kind of a deal, I cant offer money, as I don't have a job
currently, and am spending what little money I get on my internet
access/shell account, but I'm sure that I work out a satisfying deal (if
doing it for a couple Karma Coupons isn't enough). =o)

Any suggestions, help, info, is greatly appreciated. Even if it has nothing
to do with cgi.
If you are offering help, please do not respond to this e-mail using
reply... rather - use this link: mailto:ravers@chosen.org 

-thank you all... much love
-justin

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 22 Jan 1997 02:02:39 -0700
From: Collectively Unconscious <swarm@doitnow.com.>
To: az-raves <az-raves@gn5.getnet.com.>,
    mtn-raves <mtn-raves@hyperreal.com.>, Goa List <goa@party.net.>
Subject: [GOA] Re: ELF: EN: Canada's 1st Marijuana Store (fwd) {FYI}

> ***********************************
> Subject:  Canada's First Marijuana Store
> From:  muggles@hempbc.com (Cannabis Canada)
> Date:  Thu, 16 Jan 1997 21:29:32 EST
> Message-id: <mt2.0-6920-853468172@cloud9.net>
> 
> I've been a tad slow in announcing this monumental event...
> 
> On December 20th, 1996, the Vancouver Harm Reduction Club opened what must
> be North America's first modern marijuana storefront.
> 
> The Harm Reduction Club opened the "Dutch Embassy Flower and Tea Room" at
> 420 Grove Street and have been selling pot out of the small store every
> day since then. They've got banners in the window with slogans like
> "Marijuana is Medicine" and they've even got a sandwich board out on the
> sidewalk. They do a brisk business and have not yet had any police hassles
> at this new location. (Note that 420 Grove Street is actually their real
> honest-to-goodness address. Cool, eh?)
> 
> (As you might remember, the Harm Reduction Club was operating out of a
> private home, but were busted on December 4. The three main organizers of
> the club face charges of possession for the purposes of trafficking, but
> are persisting in their efforts to sell marijuana openly and responsibly.
> See CClist posts #56 & #64 for more details.)
> 
> What follows is the full text of the full page ad which the Harm Reduction
> Club bought in local weekly paper Terminal City, announcing the December
> 20 opening of the new location.
> 
> To get in touch with the Vancouver Harm Reduction Club call their new
> number at (604) 291-7729, or call David Malmo-Levine at (604) 617-1169, or
> email him at growpotkin@hempbc.com. (He may take a while to answer email.)
> 
> *
> 
> THE VANCOUVER HARM REDUCTION CLUB IS PLEASED TO ANNOUNCE THE OPENING OF
> THE "DUTCH EMBASSY FLOWER AND TEA ROOM"
> 
> In other words, this gig may be North America's first shameless, above
> ground, fully accountable to the public, fully stocked cannabis
> dealership. Unlike Holland, we will not be serving any tobacco, alcohol,
> caffeine or other physically addictive drugs.
> 
> The whole point of the thing is to reduce the harm that comes with the
> inevitable use of drugs by 1) separating the hard and soft drug market and
> 2) educating everyone who chooses to use these drugs to minimize unwanted
> effects.
> 
> We stand by the studies done in Holland, Costa Rica, Jamaica, Germany and
> Australia, that the harm reduction drug policy is effective. Considering
> the police state we seem to be quickly slipping into and the environmental
> collapse looming from using too many synthetics, we feel that Canada must
> lead the way to end global cannabis prohibition, or world may one day
> become one great big Singapore. Or worse.
> 
> OUR MESSAGE TO POLICE
> 
> We know times are tough and no cop wants to lose their job over a bunch of
> whiny potheads. We don't want to  make you look evil or stupid when we
> open our business. We just want you to cut us a bit of slack to
> experiment, let us put our money where our mouth is and see if we can't
> reduce social harm or not - if not completely satisfied, double your
> drugwar back.
> 
> This isn't some joke or prank. We are deadly serious. Many of us have been
> writing letters for years, patiently filing out each Access to Information
> request after Freedom of information request....only to find out that our
> government doesn't possess any evidence whatsoever that prohibition works!
> When we confront them with this, they hang up the phone, or cut us off at
> their extremely brief "town hall" meetings.
> 
> The court system is taking too long. Bill C-8, as you know, is practically
> law, and it will give you as much power over us as German police had over
> Jews in, say, thirty-six or so - long before the gas chambers, but just
> keep in mind Newt Gingrich is now calling for "mass executions" of all
> drug smugglers.
> 
> Under Bill C-8, you can now hire our friends as narcs, set us up, search
> us without probable cause, seize our property and if you happen to be one
> of those few "bad cops", you may now choose to plant stuff on us and get
> to testify by affidavit to avoid cross examination. We don't even get a
> jury trial for dealing any more. Forgive us if we feel a little desperate
> these days.
> 
> You don't have to go along with what you know is a witchhunt. Here are
> some ways to avoid it: 1) Keep busy investigating real crimes where people
> were harmed or property was stolen or damaged. 2) Wait until someone
> complains to you of some harm we have caused before you investigate us. 3)
> Use the findings in the Ledain Commission, the BC Chief Coroners report,
> the National Task Force on Cannabis in Australia 1994 among others to back
> up your conscientious non-cooperation with what can only be called drugwar
> crimes.
> 
> Still not convinced? Take this quote for example; from the Dutch
> government report titled "Drugs Policy in the Netherlands - continuity and
> change"
> 
> "The Netherlands' view that cannabis products entail less serious health
> risks than hard drugs and thus require a different approach, is not even
> shared by all the countries of  the  European Union. Recent reports from
> abroad by authoritative experts on drugs support the distinction made in
> Dutch law between soft and hard drugs. Criticism based on views about the
> heath risks for which no support can any longer be found in the scientific
> literature can of course not be grounds for amending Dutch policy."
> 
> If you are ordered to close us down, request scientific data first to back
> up your use of force, in order to avoid looking like fools in the media.
> No one will be able to give you any, and that will buy us some time.
> 
> If you absolutely must bust us, please don't have your guns drawn this
> time. Lets be civil about these things. We may be marijuana dealers, but
> we aren't dangerous.
> 
> OUR MESSAGE TO PARENTS
> 
> Let's face it - teens use and abuse pot. You can't stop them. Throw them
> in jail? They'll buy it there too. If there is a problem with teen pot
> use, it isn't because the pot is all that dangerous, it's because
> prohibition makes a relatively safe activity more hazardous, and carries
> serious side effects of it's own. What do we mean?
> 
> -The number one health consideration, impaired driving, happens more often
> in a prohibitionist system as 1) cars are used by teens to conceal their
> crime from their parents, and 2) the stigma connected to a criminal record
> prevents honest communication about a teen's need for help - in getting
> home from a party, for example.
> 
> -The second most important health consideration, lung damage, occurs more
> in a prohibitionist system because 1) "safer smoking tools" like water
> pipes and glass pipes are banned, 2) there's no quality control on the
> cultivation methods, 3) "fake" pot and hash can be sold, with sometimes
> tragic results 4) prohibition deters some grow operations and drives up
> the price, which then prevents teens from cooking with ganja butter - a
> safer (no lung damage, no toxicity level) but more expensive way to get
> high.
> 
> Prohibition also has some serious side effects:
> 
> -To get to the soft drugs, teens often get exposed to hard drugs.
> 
> -Some teens are also exposed to guns, gangs, and easy drug money.
> 
> -Peaceful users, dealers and growers face a record, stiff fines and even
> jail time. In some countries they face much worse.
> 
> -Young people are often direct victims of the drug war, be it in gang on
> gang violence or accidental shootings like Daniel Posse - accidentally
> shot dead by Vancouver Police during a marijuana raid (a raid which netted
> less than an ounce of pot).
> 
> At the Harm Reduction Club, rather than be hypocrites (most of us started
> smoking in our teens) and turn kids away, we give teens access to safer
> "just pot" surroundings. They must promise to 1) smoke responsibly, 2) not
> operate any heavy machinery while impaired, and 3) respect our neighbors
> as they come and go. We give them a copy of the "safer smarter smoking
> guide", and we put 10% of our profits for free legal council in the event
> of a club activity bust.
> 
> If anybody out there can show us that raising our age limit would reduce
> the harm further, we would be happy to bump it up to sixteen or eighteen
> or thirty-five or whatever.
> 
> Consider this: the risks of caffeine are greater than THC in every way.
> Found in chocolate, soda pop, coffee, tea and aspirin, caffeine is
> physically addicting (with headache as the most often cited withdrawal
> symptom) and can cause unnecessary stress, lightheadedness, breathlessness
> and an irregular heartbeat - or much worse in larger-than-average doses.
> You can also die of overdose. Thousands do every year. Marijuana isn't
> even remotely as dangerous - no deaths by overdose, no physical addiction,
> and minimal health risks in a tolerant and open world.
> 
> Now think about the real "wrong message" to give to your children.
> Remember, the little rugrats are often smarter than we give them credit
> for. They see through the reefer madness. Do you?
> 
> OUR MESSAGE TO OTHER DEALERS
> 
> Change isn't always bad. Sometimes, with a bit of forethought, one can
> take advantage of inevitable changes. Let's face it - this market is
> massive. We can all make tons of money going legit - and have lots left
> over to pay for schools and hospitals and turn Canada into what it could
> be - a land of peace, tolerance of alternative lifestyles and prosperity
> for everyone.
> 
> An end to the drug war would take the economic power out of the hands of
> the drug corporations and put it in the hands of us farmers - right where
> it should be. The same thing could then happen with industrial hemp.
> 
> If you aren't into any of this legalization stuff, at least leave us be.
> We are, after all, trying to make life a lot less stressful for you.
> 
> OUR MESSAGE TO OUR MEMBERS
> 
> This is it. Gotta draw the line somewhere. The witchhunt ends this Friday,
> December 20th, 1996 at two PM. At exactly two PM (not a moment sooner, for
> security reasons) phone your local hemp store and get the address of our
> cafe. Then get your (non-impaired) assess down there for a special, one
> day only sale on memberships and pot!!! For one day only, memberships will
> be half price! (5 bucks) and pot will be only 25 bucks for an eighth, or
> eight bucks for a gram sized joint (limit one joint and one eighth per
> member to avoid obvious problems).
> 
> Now's the time. Either we risk arrest now (by the way, each club member's
> legal expenses are covered for all club activities, including this one) or
> we risk Singapore later, and not too much later by the looks of it. Bring
> cameras, warm clothes (this party may have to go late, like three or four
> days late) and all your Clay-o-quot courage, but please leave alcohol,
> aggression and weapons at home. All musicians, entertainers and
> videographers will be smoked up for free, as per usual.
> 
> Now's the time. Everyone on earth knows prohibition is a scam. It's time
> to face the evil empire. The force of truth is with us.
> 
> *
> 
> --
> Dana Larsen (muggles@hempbc.com)
> Editor, CANNABIS CANADA, Canada's Magazine of Marijuana & Hemp
> 
> Visit Cannabis Canada Online at: http://www.hempbc.com
> #504, 21 Water St., Vancouver, BC, V6B 1A1, ph 604-669-9069
> 
> Join the Cannabis Canada News and Information Email List!
> Send an email with a message of "subscribe" to cclist@hempbc.com

>>     FROM:      MANAGEMENT
>>     SUBJECT:   SPECIAL HIGH INTENSITY TRAINING
>>
>>     In order to assure the highest levels of Quality work and productivity
>>     from employees, it will be our policy to keep all employees well trained
>>     through our program of "SPECIAL HIGH INTENSITY TRAINING" (S.H.I.T.).  We
>>     are trying to give employees more S.H.I.T than anyone else.
>>
>>     If you feel that you do not receive your share of S.H.I.T. on the job,
>>     please see your manager.  You will be immediately placed at the top of
>>     the S.H.I.T List, and our managers are especially skilled at seeing
>>     that you get all the S.H.I.T. you can handle.
>>
>>     Employees who don't take their S.H.I.T. will be placed on
>>     "DEPARTMENTAL EMPLOYEE EVALUATION PROGRAMS": (D.E.E.P S.H.I.T).
>>
>>     Those who fail to take D.E.E.P. S.H.I.T. seriously will have to go to
>>     "EMPLOYEE ATTITUDE TRAINING" (E.A.T. S.H.I.T.).  Since our managers
>>     took S.H.I.T before they were promoted, they don't have to do S.H.I.T.
>>     anymore and are full of S.H.I.T already.
>>
>>     If you are full of S.H.I.T you may be interested in job training
>>     others.  We can add your name to our "BASIC UNDERSTANDING LECTURE
>>     LIST" (B.U.L.L.  S.H.I.T). Those who are full of B.U.L.L.  S.H.I.T.
>>     will get the S.H.I.T jobs, and can apply for promotion to "DIRECTOR OF
>>     INTENSITY PROGRAMMING (D.I.P.  S.H.I.T).
>>
>>     If you have further questions, please direct them to our "HEAD OF
>>     TRAINING, SPECIAL HIGH INTENSITY TRAINING (H.O.T.  S.H.I.T.).
>>
>>     Thank You,
>>
>>     "BOSS IN GENERAL SPECIAL HIGH INTENSITY TRAINING"
>>     (B.I.G.  S.H.I.T.).

worse than any other club DJ I'd seen before. But if you say so. You and
Madame BigSig  seem to have some kind of unhealthy infatuation for him. I'd

didn't suck? I mean, Mr. Kirk's 96? What the hell? I just figured that they
were releasing all that crap cute 10" vinyl to make their stuff more
consumeable. I mean if the record sucks it at least looks unique. That will
at least attract the attention of the bubblegum chewing dayglo
teeth-grinding girls out there, but I don't know a single DJ that owns any
of that stuff. :-)

bring guns to raves?

To: Troy Sheets <tsheets@saturn5.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "an underground freedom fighter" <wayne@club.net>
Subject: Re: MEDIA ALERT: 20/20 does raves.
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 2:46 PM -0800 1/22/97, Troy Sheets wrote:
>20/20 is doing a segment on raves this Friday at 10pm on ABC.
>
>It will be very interesting to see what this "respected" news magazine
>has to say after all the sensationalized rave reporting.

I am *absolutely positive* that it's going to be bad.

	A B S O L U T E L Y

Why, and who's fault is this?

There are a few guilty parties:

#1	Large party promoters that *are* creating huge drug fests for 15
	year olds. They do exist, and if you don't think that's the reason,
you
	are simply in denial.

	There is definitely a category of shitty, drug filled kiddy raves that
	only exist as a manufactured channel created for the purpose of
selling
	drugs. I dare you to dig deep and find out where these pimped-out 15
	year olds are getting the $$$ backing to have these parties.

	Do the math:
	$20-$30  for entry    	x 3000  =  $60,000 - $ 90,000
	$20-$100 for drugs	x 3000  =  $60,000 - $300,000
					= $120,000 - $390,000

	Now would *you* produce an drug-fest event with multi-thousands of
	high 15 year old's if you could earn $100,000-$400,000+ in *one* night?

Now go look at the SF Raves calendar for 1996/1997 and look for all those
parties you know fit this mold. Compare that with the number of HUGE
parties in 1992 or 1993. There were probably quite a few of them then, too.

Now move forward to 1994 and notice that there probably aren't that many
parties like this at that time. Well, that's because parties like those,
with that intent, is what caused the entire community to cave in on itself.

Did those huge party promoters care that they were shitting on your
community or your passion? I really doubt it. They were at home "taking a
break" during 1993/4/5, counting the hundreds of thousands of dollars they
made while selling you out in 1992/3 and waiting for their next big chance.
Well, 1997's here.

Well, if you were still really interested in the 'church of rave', you were
probably going to small parties in people's houses and to small, unpromoted
renegades in 1994-1995... but then what happened?

Okay, fast forward to 1996/7. The HUGE parties came back again..... to cash
in -- again.



#2	The media salivates to run a "do you know where your teenager is --
	at an all night drug fest having sex with strange people in a secret
	location. (thanks, sLeeza!)

	Based on this "yellow journalism" style of  reporting, why would the
	media *want* to know anything more than #1 exists.

	Thousands of 15 year olds on designer drugs are *news*.

	Dozens achieving personal transformation are *human interest*.



There you have it. Next question! (said in a John Maclaughlin tone) :-)



PS: *I *DO NOT* put the Gathering/Freedom in this category.

Flame me or thank me, I don't care.
I'd be happy to hear your comments either way.

One time I saw DJ Dan in the basement of 1015 (a long long time ago)
and basically couldn't help but place myself infront of the DJ booth
and watch this superhuman DJ mix record after record after record
seamlessly with an average of about 1 mix every minute or two (this
might be somewhat shocking to those used to Goa Trance or whatever one
calls the trendoid psychedelic trance enjoyed by twitchingly unfunky
WASP/EuroTrash types worldwide where they mix the same boring crap for
hours on end unrelentingly while everybody is off pretending they're
stars in some lame step aerobics video on fast-forward :-) :-). Anyways
IMHO, DJ Dan is way awesome. Check out his CD "loose caboose" -- one of
the better mix CD's i've heard in a long time, though i'd rather see
him live.

> Breakbeat? Isn't that for 15 year olds that wear a lot of sportwear and
> bring guns to raves?

I don't think I'd call Dan's style "breakbeat", though he gets good n'
funky, hard n' acidic, or just nicely prog-housy. And quite frankly,
i'd rather listen to breakbeat than all this psychedelic/goa trance
shite that's plaguing the scene lately. Maybe I'm just too old but I
just can't wrap my head around that "music" -- seems designed for the
post-acid-casualty-lost-all-sense-of-rhythm-after-snorting-too-
much-crank-just-got-abducted-by-aliens-they-stuck-cold-metallic-probes-up-
my-bunghole-so-now-i-hop-around-like-the-energizer-bunny set :-) :-) :-)

PS: Breakbeat at Tiffanys -- Audrey Hepburn decked out in a/d/d/i/d/a/s.

-- Niels.

Subject: MIND: New media uproor in England (fwd)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

<look who this is from...  ;)   -troy>

-----

Last week a pop star called Brian Harvey, lead singer of E17, stirred the
shit when he gave an interview saying that Ecstasy can make you a better
person. Unfortunately, he also said that he'd taken 12 at a go without any
problem and driven home on E. Brian looks like a sexless sweetie who
appeals to teeny boppers and who is very high in the charts but of course
despised by ravers.

There was the most amazing response. The Prime Minister even mentioned it
in parliament. The MP who is proposing a new bill that will make club
owners liable to lose their licenses if drugs are found also mentioned it
in parliament, and asked a minister to have Brian arrested on the charge of
incitement to break the law; really over the top!
As one of my readers wrote to me:

" Now Brian Harvey went on the record yesterday as saying what he sees as
the truth about ecstasy. I've never been able to stand Brian Harvey either
as an artist or as what I've seen of him as a person. I think he looks
ridiculous and his 'music' is shit. However, yesterday I thought he
actually made a bit of sense.
"He is the the first person I've ever heard reported as saying that ecstasy
can help to make you a better person - a sentiment that I whole-heartedly
agree with and know to be true for myself and several friends. But look
what happens! He gets kicked out of his band, their new single is
practically banned, suddenly every club in the country is in imminent
danger of being shut down, and the name of Leah Betts is once again
plastered across our headlines. Harvey has to be an absolute dickhead to
take 12 E's in a night (if it's true!) and even more so to say so, but all
credit to him for 'coming out'."

There followed a 5 page spread in the Daily Mirror (Britains biggest
selling paper) all about the horrors of Ecstasy and with spreads ringed by
oval-framed portraits of innocent young people who were victims of the
killer drug. 17 radio stations announced an immediate ban of E17 records. I
was invited to go on TV twice with the Betts which I refused, but I
accepted Newsnight who edited me (fairly) saying that Brian's remarks and
hysteria were just what the government needed to push through its new bill.

The serious papers said very little. The Guardian had a funny piece headed
"Pop star trips up over E",
but the popular morning radio programme interviewed clubbers who all made
positive comments like: "Yes, its true Ecstasy does make you a better
person".

Nicholas
------------------------------------------
American Ecstasy site: ecstasy.org
European Ecstasy site: www.obsolete.com/ecstasy
E for Ecstasy (complete book online): http://hyperreal.com/drugs/e4x/
Psychoactives for spiritual purposes (work in progress):
http://www.csp.org/entheogen
email address: nicholas@ecstasy.org

the start of every ending,
and the end of every race"

has brown hair), these things are neat." What I can see is her asking so
what are the authorities doing to try and stop these things. My parents
watch this everytime I visit them and Barbara Waters never seems to like
anything, everything is always an outrage. I cannot see their
investigative report actually finding out about one that I would consider
decent. How does someone who does not know anything about raves, does not 
know people who go to raves, get into raving and do an accurate report on 
what's going on? I guess we'll see.

>   mixing in and out of tracks that fast tells me one of two things
> 1) he's showing off
> 2) he doesn't have any records that he likes

(1) The only reasons us human monkeys do anything at all other than
scratch our butts is cuz we're showing off. Unless you're a solipsist
or a pathological masturbator, a creative pleasure enjoyed alone is not
equal to a creative pleasure shared, IMHO.

(1.5) DJ Dan, IMHO, doesn't grandstand. He doesn't backspin records
with his hands behind his back. He just DJ's, slickly, smoothly,
professionally and very, very well. Why should the audience be ashamed
of appreciating quality and talent? Why should the performer not use
the skills he has to increase our enjoyment? Yeah, "rock star syndrome"
is a sickening thing when people get all Beatlemania about their fave
performers. But that doesn't change the fact that someone like Paul
McCartney had a great genius for writing catchy songs.

(2) perhaps Dan has so many records he likes that he wants to play them
all within his limited DJ slot and within the confines of our short
attention spans. I personally get bored when a DJ plays a dance music
track for more than 3 minutes (unless the track itself puts forward a
changing soundscape that isn't monotonous from beginning to end).

== When yer swimming in a creek and an eel bites yer cheek, that's a moray!==

  So this weekend my best friend and I decide to cheer up our boyfriendless
selves and go blow our entire paychecks.  (or at the very least a good chunk
of them)  We headed down towards a mall somewhere in the east bay... looking
for some everyday clothes to suit our mood.  I got to the mall when Lo and
Behold... that famous comercialized gothic store Hot Topic lay before us.
 Never one to pass up a new opportunity, I cruised in and had a looksee.  Oh
sure, dressing in black,maroon,and purple velvet, vinyl and chains can get
boring; but why not just pick a few items to mix and match.  After all,
 variety is the spice of life.  Never mind the morbid thread labels on every
item, or the fact that if a group of gothics saw people in all black talking
about being spirtual and giving out hugs they'd slit their wrists, I needed a
change.  And then I saw it... my one true weakness in life-- VINYL.  Just to
try them on, I thought and carried them into the black dressing room.  Once
they hit my skin I knew I had to by them.... black vinyl hip huggers with
three silver stripes (no not addidas) running down each leg.  As much as I
wanted to resist, I couldn't help myself.  Of course I had to wear the brand
new pants, so I headed to school on Tuesday with my matching vinyl sneakers
and silver thermal.  Smile spread from ear to ear, the only thing I heard all
day was, "COOL PANTS!!!"  I even got some people singing disco and dancing in
the halls.  So the moral is gothic clothes don't make gothic people... try on
some vinyl today!!

        hugs,
          'trice                      <<<<RAVEON>>>>

    "swish, swish, swish.....'there goes that girl again'. "

> that has anything to do with American designer Tommy Hilfiger again. 
> In fact, if this up and coming designer really did insult my people,
> you can bet that I will do every single thing I can in my power to
> make sure that his label never makes it here.
> 
> All my name-brand conscious friends are reworking their imported-
> label wardrobes these days.  No, not that they have finally decided to
> buy completely Filipino goods (even though I think that isn't a bad
> idea). My friends are just tossing out their Tommy Hilfiger designer
> clothes.  And to think many of them spent a small fortune on these
> expensive polo shirts and the like.
> 
> Apparently, world-class designer Ralph Lauren and this Tommy Hilfiger
> guested on fashion authority Elsa Klensch's 'Style' on CNN recenty to
> talk about the latest trends on what's in and what's out.
> 
> During the course of her interview with the pair, Klensch told
> respected Polo maker Ralph Lauren that his brand has become quite
> popular all over the world -- including in Asian nations such as the
> Philippines.  Lauren graciously thanked the CNN 'Style' host, saying
> that he sincerely appreciated the support from all those who endorsed
> and purchased his line.
> 
> Hilfiger then supposedly butted in then with a comment, something like
> it is one thing for one's label to go popular worldwide, but there are
> some people who just don't look well in "their" designer clothes. 
> Hilfiger then allegedly named several Asian races, apparently saying
> that he preferred if "these people" wouldn't wear their line --
> particularly Filipinos!
> 
> I am shocked by the idea that a supposedly respected new fashion
> designer
> would be so crass as to make a statement such as that.  Talk about
> being too big for his breeches.  And to think that someone as big as
> ralph Lauren was only too happy to thank those who buy his line,
> including the Filipinos who have made Polo big in Asia.  After all, if
> you think about it, Polo has indeed made it as a big name here in the
> Philippines, even if we are not as rich and affluent as our Asian
> neighbors.
> 
>       ...
> 
> (Cristina Peczon can be reached at cristina@iconn.com.ph)
> ------------------------------------------------------------------

good evening all!
  well, it's nearing the new weekend and i'm still thinking about last, =
but i thought i'd share my awesome experience with all.  if you went to =
the F8 party i would not doubt that you saw me or i saw you because i =
think i smiled and offered peppermint candies or lifesavers to =
all....and a HUGE smile along with the treats.  i went with my honey =
anthony (wearing a white fat albert t-shirt)..(i was in a white tank top =
with rainbow stripes across the front and a tigger backpack)...anyway we =
got in there pretty early and did a little groovin' and just got our =
minds and bodies ready for the awesome night ahead.  DRC was greaaat!  i =
love chick music makers...so cool.  she just got me stompin' and =
smilin'.....then mystr-e!!! yikes my cheeks were so sore from smilin and =
groovin'...at this point i began my rounds on the smile patrol....i made =
it my duty (one which i thoroughly enjoyed) to talk to everyone i could. =
 i met so many people and of course can't really remember any names, but =
i do remember erin the bongo guy...he went off on those things...a guy =
who was relly tall with bleached short hair and these awesome Wicked =
pants...and the girl with the buzzed orabge hair who rooms with rob? and =
the other guy with the awesome english accent, but alas...i'm taking way =
too long here.  point being i had a GREAT!!!! time and if you saw me let =
me know.  i hope anyone who might have gone had as good a time as i =
did...and if you didn't go....go next time.  one stellar party! =20

peace, love, and hugs to all:
                                                                         =
                      mac: a girl ;)

Paul Hayden FUZZY PANTS wrote:
> 
> Yep, I think that the scene is deteriorating. And right about the time I
> came into it May of last year. It really sucks, but I think It will
> really get a whole lot bigger, before it gets really smaller.

in toronto it got so big that the mafia apparently got involved in it,
because the drugs were big business, and apparently they demanded 10% of
all door profits at the big new years party plus "control of all the
drugs", whatever that means... apparently, when they found the owner of
X-static (toronto's "rave headquarters" clothing + mix-tape shop) hung
in the shop, those who were close to him were saying it wasn't
suicide... and apparently the employees of x-static were threatened at
the new year's party... when it get's so big that people have to die
over money, then the whole thing collapses... we have the big shitty
commericial parties at clubs and concert venues now, and small UG things
are forced into smaller clubs... the police are everywhere... and no one
really cares to throw a party anymore... too much hassle...

all i can say to the scene of san francisco is... don't let mob elements
into the underground, or even the scene at large if it isn't too late...
don't buy drugs that have addictive substances... they ALL come from mob
sources who want return business...  heroin (synthetic and organic),
crystal meth, cocaine and any other addictive narcotic (go for
psychedelic, not narcotic) guarantee return business... you vote with
your dollars, and should not put up with crap... i've gone without e at
parties for two years now, because 95% of it was mob shit...


 Hopefully
> It will get big enough to turn into something where you can tell that it
> is commercial and everyone knows about it,

in toronto, because there was such a massive influx of people who
couldn't tell, the commercial parties became what was "in" and the
underground drowned out in commercialism... 

 then the real good raves will
> start completly underground and no one will know about them not even
> flyers or anything.

 And we can call them something else or something
> instead of raves and all the real ravers who are there for the vibe will
> go to them and we can leave the bad scene to the mean people.

the bad people have their glorified rave/club scene, and the UG can't
throw parties in warehouses because new bi-laws and zoning shit has gone
down that prevents raves in anything but a club... now who has vested
interest, and investment capital to get into purchasing a club... well,
the mobsters with money... and the establishment who want people
contained in the proper vice medium... the bar... keep 'em loaded... as
long as nothing "mind-manifesting" happens we'll let it slide... 

> The other option is too try to ignore them, or even better yet, I think
> If nothing but ravers storm a massive, there will be no room for mean
> people.

there have been successful, peaceful good-vibe massives (alien
visitation and transcendance) in toronto, but most people feel this is
because more out-of-towners came (they had really big international
line-ups) and joined the UG to make them big, because you just didn't
see your average toughguy/raver redneck at these parties... the ones who
were there were certainly 'tamed' by the good vibe, though...


 If every raver show up supper early for one massive and we all
> get in before any meanies get in and the line is miles long and for the
> first half has nothing but ravers and good vibes in it then we might be
> three times over capacity and they wont have any room to squeeze any
> meanies in.

one can only hope...


> 
> Well, somethign big will definetly happen to our scene in 97. If not then
> 98.

i really hope what happened in toronto doesn't happen in frisco... be
careful... the people i have interacted with and observed lurking on
this list have a sense of family that is seriously lacking in the
east... i am really impressed with the "call to arms" that seems to
occur when shit goes down... the main thing is to maintain a positive
outlook on where your headed, but be fully conscious and make sure that
you are headed away from the bullshit money ethic... true wealth can not
be counted... negativity always exists, balance is the key...

be aware, not weary...

good luck...

dave

In-Reply-To: <199701230249.SAA12775@netcom9.netcom.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.970122215042.15482B-100000@si.UCSC.EDU>

Hi! ]=)


On Wed, 22 Jan 1997, Niels P. Mayer wrote:


> (1) The only reasons us human monkeys do anything at all other than
> scratch our butts is cuz we're showing off. Unless you're a solipsist
> or a pathological masturbator, a creative pleasure enjoyed alone is not
> equal to a creative pleasure shared, IMHO.

 I must humbly take issue with this sentiment. No disrespects to the auther.

 When I was growing up I couldn't draw. My art instructors would try but 
I wouldn't draw. I honestly felt like I couldn't draw.

 I get into junior college for the first time (studying laser technology) 
and decide to take a drawing class to fulfill a GE. Reminder; I had never 
drawn up tp this point, not even to doodle.

 Because of the beautiful, gentle and nuturing vibe of the instructor I 
started drawing. By the time I was out of that class I had changed my 
major to the arts. I'm still there.

 Drawing (for me) was not about showing my pictures (and later poems) to 
others and going "hey, check out my cool drawing." Very few people saw my 
early work. I drew and wrote because I had to or go insane. The 
incredible mental pressure of my life was healed and the tension resolved 
through my art. In my drawings and writings my sub-concious, soul, 
spirit, forces from beyond were communicating with me and helping me. I 
recieved so much from my art that I desprately needed and could not get 
anywhere else.

 I think that Neils statement above may be true for some but certainly 
not for all.


peas,


Ran D.Dreams

i have heard of a study done on E and AIDS, and ironically (because E
apparently has a massive toll on your immune system, although i've never
experienced it) E has reversed the process of HIV infection... in most
cases reduced the count, but in some cases actually eradicated HIV from
the bloodstream... being a practitioner of eastern schools of medicine,
i am well aware of the connection of mind, body and spirit... i think
AIDS is more of a psychological virus, and E- in boosting the inner
self, has potential to boost the true bodhi-temple self so to speak...
it would of course have to be used more therapeutically...

is there anyone out there with a suspicion that AIDS has been
"created"...?

my two sensi...

alchemist

>i have heard of a study done on E and AIDS, and ironically (because E
>apparently has a massive toll on your immune system, although i've never
>experienced it) E has reversed the process of HIV infection... in most
>cases reduced the count, but in some cases actually eradicated HIV from
>the bloodstream... being a practitioner of eastern schools of medicine,
>i am well aware of the connection of mind, body and spirit... i think
>AIDS is more of a psychological virus, and E- in boosting the inner
>self, has potential to boost the true bodhi-temple self so to speak...
>it would of course have to be used more therapeutically...


Ummm...as a believer in eastern thought and having done both research
towards a cure for HIV-1 infection and amphetamine pharmacology, I don't
think that AIDS (HIV-1 actually) could be considered a psychological virus.
It is very real.  I do however tend to agree with you that the body - if
balanced - can be very effective in defending itself from such an assault.
Herbs, accupuncture are very natural and are established ways of healing
that are diametrically opposed to the practice of western medicine which
merely prescribes a drug that has a specific and singular pharmacological
action that treats a single problem.  Proper chi flow and balance are
important elements.  MDMA, however, is a synthetic.  While I am _very_ far
from condemning the use of E on occasion, I can't see it being used as
balancing agent.  There are far better ways.


>is there anyone out there with a suspicion that AIDS has been
>"created"...?
>alchemist

It is, IMHO, with the right technology entirely possible to create a deadly
virus.  However, this virus has been around for quite awhile (reported as
far back as 1951)...before the advent of the age of PCR and supercomputers
used for sequencing (no not that kind, you MIDI-heads :)  )


peas,
n8

>n8 wrote:
>
>> Herbs, accupuncture are very natural
>
>Hang on.  I've sat on this list for a long time listening to people tout
>"natural" as being better than synthetic.  I have an issue with this,
>but first,
>
>        since when has putting tiny needles into your body
>        ever been "natural"?

Yes, natural indeed.  No unnatural substance enters the body.   The needles
induce the body to release natural pain killers (endorphins.)  Once the
needles are removed, nothing foreign is left.  Again, I'm not condemning
the use of synthetics; merely the use of E as a balancing agent:

"MDMA, however, is a synthetic.  While I am _very_ far
from condemning the use of E on occasion, I can't see it being used as
balancing agent.  There are far better ways."


>Come on...
>
>> However, this virus has been around for quite awhile (reported as
>> far back as 1951)...
>
>Really?!  Could you supply the details?
>
>S

Sure can.  My stacks of research are in storage, so I can't provide you
with an immediate reference (I'll look it up on the Medline if you want)
but cases were indeed reported in the '50's.   The authenticity of this has
been debated.  Confirmed cases were not seen until the late '70's early
'80's.

Hope to see some of you at Gaiamind today.

mu.

-n8

few friends, but there's no need to make an "event" out of it and put
it up on the calendar...

to, because it would be something special and fun.

From: sho@goonsquad.spies.com (Sho Kuwamoto)
Subject: DJ style/technique (was Re: DJ Dan who?)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (sfraves)
Date: Thu, 23 Jan 1997 11:23:30 -0800 (PST)
Content-Type: text
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

presumed <presumed@uclink4.berkeley.edu> wrote:
>   mixing in and out of tracks that fast tells me one of two things
> 1) he's showing off
> 2) he doesn't have any records that he likes

...and when *I* hear someone mixing in and out of tracks
quickly, it reminds me of being in a dirty warehouse in
Detroit, listening to Jeff Mills, Claude Young, and Stacey
Pullen. 

Mixing quickly can be a problem if it impedes the flow, but
in the hands of someone skilled, a quick mix, a long ride,
and a little bit of style during the mix can turn two
records into something completely new. There's nothing like
listening to a good DJ ripping songs apart and putting them
back together all night, only to realize that the melodic
chunk you've been hearing is a snippet of "Strings of Life,"
which is just starting to come in for real.

I almost hate to say this because it doesn't seem to be a
very popular sentiment in San Francisco, but when I go out,
I am there to enjoy the mixes between the songs just as much
as I am there for the music. When a DJ leaves a song in for
five or seven minutes, only to do a smooth fade (which
takes, oh, thirty seconds) to another seven minute track, I
end up feeling bored and deprived. For me, the tension,
energy, and ephemeral nature of a live performance is only
captured while the DJ is actually working the records
together. When Robert Armani spins, he breaks up the
structure of songs and always leaves you guessing. When
Bileebob and Paris tag team, you always end up hearing
something unexpected. When Derrick May has a good night, you
leave the party shaking your head and smiling, with a new
understanding of what is possible with two turntables.

Quick mixing is not an end in itself, but it's essential for
a style of mixing in which songs are taken apart and
reassembled in new and interesting ways.

-Sho

hello all-

i'm annoyed.

i must say, changing the monday night dinner to once a month is not a good
idea.  give people the chance to come when they want.  if you want to come
once a month, do so!  if you want to come once a week, do so.  don't
require that others want abide by your own schedule.

i have met some fantastic people over the past couple weeks at small,
imtimate monday night dinners.  i've also met some people at large dinners,
and you know what?  they're all good.

saying that you might come once a month but not once a week does not make
sense.  you come when you want to, and don't require that others fit your
schedule.

i will continue to have and promote them once a week, and anyone that
wishes to come once a week, please continue!  anyone that wishes to come
once a month, please do so!  if you wish to organize a larger, more
attended one, please do so!  i've arranged my schedule around keeping this
time free each week, and changing that now would be unfair to the person
who started the whole thing.

yes, i do take this personally.  live by your own schedule, just don't
require that others live by it, also.

love and annoyance-

matt lanier
matthew d. p. k. lanier
professional hugger and empath
independent internet consultant

well I just got a look at the 20/20 report on the web, and lemmee tell 
you it aint so pretty.

here's the lowdown (according to Babs)


raves are "a haven for drug taking with a dance beat"

-over 70% of ravers are on drugs and if you aren't, well then you just 
stick out (according to an unnamed quoted "raver")

-there was a whole bit on the girl who died in Florida because of X and 
how her mother put the X dealer in jail for manslaughter

-and a last bit of advice from 20/20? - if your kids want to go to a rave 
then you better go with them


hell, i agree- I've tried to get my mom to come and check it all out- I'd 
rather have her see for herself what it's all about.  But she doesn't 
ever actually seem to want to.  Oh well- And I'm going home on Saturday -

it now...

mom:  jess, are you still going to those rave things?

me:  sometimes

mom:  wait a minute here,  you're always telling us how broke you 
are- that money we give you is for groceries.  NOT Drugs.  

me:  I don't spend my grocery money on drugs mom.

mom:  yeah when I was your age I got them for free too.  :)

Here's what I had to respond about ABC's web report on raves:

---_Adam
"Stay Connected"

*************************************************

I, for one, am utterly disgusted in the so-called' "report" on raves for
your Friday night slot. 

       Myself being in the "Scene" for 7+ years am sick of such
misrepresentation that these reporters convey.  News is news, non-biased
reports on facts.  Through the years I have gone to "parties" (Ie on a
weekend basis).  I have seen no fatalites.  Yes, there is a drug element
with the underground, but please crossection this with say, a rock
concert, garlic festival, and other events which have a crowd of people
converging to relax and be merry.  I believe the statictis will prove a
drug percentage of at least 60% if not more.  Bear in mind that the term
"drug use" is not connitated to illegal drugs, but any substance used
for the purpose to derive a feeling of euphoria.  Your report stated,
"Over seventy percent of the kids said they were on drugs,".  I would
like to know which drugs are being referenced.  Alchol?  Cannabis? Only
"hard drugs" (I.e. LSD, Ketamaine, MDMA) have been mentioned.  This
further skews the perception that is being conveied to the public.  I
would also like to see the documentation that colaberates how MDMA (or
any of its deritatives: MDA, MDMO) produces a rise in body temperature.
None of the scientific essays I have read has ever mentioned this. 
 
          Reflecting on this snippet from your 20/20 website, no mention
of the age difference was convayed whatsoever.  I understand concern for
childrens sake.  However, there is the illusion that raves are only
frequented by minors.  The crossection of ravers that I have seen range
from 16 to 45 yrs or older with the median age of 21 +/- three years.
Tradtionaly 18 is the come-of-age year in many states many parties also
have an 18 or over rule as well (due to the nationwide "crackdown" of
our scene). So I believe we're talking about more of a "generation X"
age range that frequents these events and not the Youth of America.  

America as a whole is changing. Both CA and AZ, propisitions have been
passed that were supported by the underground comunity.  Many more want
to see change.  We, the future of america see these parties as escapes
from the ritual bar scene, or monotimy of the monday - friday 9-5 grind.
 I work on a corperate envorment. I DJ and party on weekends.  I will
protect my scene from such shoddy journalistic witch hunts.  Please
understand that we on the inside are aware of our deficencies.  Are you
aware of yours?

Thank you for your time,
                                        Anakin

At 1:41 PM -0800 1/23/97, Jessica Robin Berkson wrote:

...

>-and a last bit of advice from 20/20? - if your kids want to go to a rave
>then you better go with them
>

Hmm, perhaps somebody should start a parents who support the rave scene
type group. Mine came to the first rave I threw and thought it was great.

The 20/20 report is obviously a gross misrepresentation and is the type of
thing I'd expect from a tabloid show. From the online transcript it would
appear they didn't talk to any reputable promoters and carefully selected
their quotes for maximum sensationalism. The way they describe parties
brings to mind a vision of preschool on a day all the teachers are gone.
I'd also like see the methodology by which they obtained the hypothesis
that 70% of ravers are on drugs at any given party.

What's most troubling is that this is a national prime-time show and is no
doubt watched and believed by much of america.

I think it would be wise to contact the producer of the segment as well as
the reporter. The producer should be credited on the actual show - I'm
going to make sure and tape it.

Joe

>

> command in the body of your email message:
> 
>     unsubscribe sfraves larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)

From: Steve Simitzis <steve@saturn5.com>
To: matt@saturn5.com

> Date: Thu, 23 Jan 1997 12:38:24 -0800
> From: "matthew d. p. k. lanier" <matt@saturn5.com>

> i have met some fantastic people over the past couple weeks at small,
> imtimate monday night dinners.  i've also met some people at large dinners,
> and you know what?  they're all good.

Well, that's nice and all, but I've become bored with the prospect of
meeting every week. Others have too, and many people I've spoken to
both on and off-line have seemed interested in the idea of a monthly
dinner thing instead.

Notice how small the attendance has been. Notice how people will come
once to dinner and _never_ come back. The first few dinners were cool,
when the idea was still new and fresh. But going out to restaurants
every week can be draining on even those of us who are well
employed. Speaking for only myself, if I'm going to spend $15 or so
for a dinner, there had better be a really cool occasion to do so.

Continue having it every week, if you'd like. But I like looking
forward to things that don't happen very often. I like variety; I
don't like redundancy. Those are my personal preferences, hence my
suggestions for improving something which (all IMHO, of course) is
flawed.

> yes, i do take this personally.

That's a shame. Now if I were to call you a flaming asshole, then you
should take _that_ personally. ;)

Well? If this Monday's dinner kicks ass, then I'll reconsider....:)

Steve

ps. Wait... why *are* we arguing about this, anyway?

I can see how there are benefits and drawbacks to both weekly dinners and
monthly dinners. Some people may prefer frequency others may prefer size.
Perhaps a workable middle ground would be holding one every other week, or
maybe have one "Big Dinner" every month.

I've enjoyed the dinners I've attended, but I haven't been able to make
every one. I'll keep on going to as many as I can.

Terrence.

Hi...

   I'm back on the list,  with a new Email address.    My WELL.COM Email
address is totally hosed, thanx to more attempts to sabatage my business.

   Glad to see the list admin people put in confirmation,   although it
makes it harder to get on ths list,   at lease it prevents spamming.

   Since I've been gone from the list for a long time,    how are things?
How is Omar?     Any reports?     Haven't heard much news from down here
in SD area.

   I'm no longer afiliated with the Loft,  after learning it was controlled
by a "Cult"....    Soon,  I'm going to write a very long piece on the LOft,
and all the things that happened there.    As soon as it's up on my WEB site,
I'll post a short announcement on the list.    It's rave related.

   We're doing a weekly thing down here in Pacific Beach at the Stella Bella
Coffee shop called "SideShow",   bringing in big name local DJ's....   It's a
small space,   but the music will be excellent and varied,  with trip hop,
jungle,  trance (Goa and Cybertrance),  breaks,  and other music Genre's.

  Anyway,  glad to be back on the list,  and now I won't be mail-bombed anymore
with my new address.

  Down here,  the pigs are shutting down raves much more frequently,  due to the
problems at "7th heaven" Newyears.    How is it up there?

  While up there,   I attended Karma at the so called new Acme,   now managed
by some really cool Russians,   specializing in Goa trance.    I'm jelious,  now
there are 3 possee's of Goa trance....   F-8,  CCC,  and Karma...   Way to go,
and lets continue to promote and have more Trance parties.     Yay!!

  Anyway,   it was really great to get up there and party with you,  although I
only attended the Digital Be-in (Thanx Wayne),  and Karma,   it was really great
to dance with you all again.

Crunchman

> 
> > Does anyone have anything to say about the previous Jungle Love event? I'm
> > introducing some friends to jungle, so I'd like them to come away
> > completely converted. Any opinions as to which may provide the most
> > mindblowing first jungle experience?

Jungle Love is fun.  Sure, the Troc is not the ideal venue, with fascist
security gaurds marching around like they are the sole entities preventing
the whole club from erupting into total anarchy and chaos...

But, the sound system certinaly delivers the bass, there will be plenty
of people groovin' out on the dance floor, ect.

Its still a club and not an UG like Audio Impact... but it is a very good
club.

-troy

info, I haven't picked up that much myself lately.

   Thursday, January 23rd - _Jungle Love_

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

David Minuk wrote:

> The 20/20 report on raves is already posted at:
> http://www.abc.com/primetime1/twenty/012497.html
> ...
> Anyone want to hit them with another fraud lawsuit?  Or at least some
> angry letters.

Well, what did you expect?  Honestly?  I forget who it was that did the
rather funny but frighteningly believable spoof on Barbara Walters and
her watering eyes, but they pegged it.  The media has boiled raving down
to three elements:

1. Drugs
2. Lack of parental or police supervision
3. Deaths due to various elements found in rave environment

They even occasionally harp on the idea of staying up all hours of night
dancing (a la "Hard Copy"), but these are the main three elements they
always hit on.

And we all know what an evil drug Ecstacy is, right? .........  ;)

The problem is, they're not totally off base.  These things *do*
happen.  Kids take WAY too much of whatever is available.  Moderation
and self control are not part of the culture.  This is a "burn the
candle at both ends AND the middle" scene for the younger set.  They are
busy partying harder than any generation before them, or so they think.

The point is, to the majority of parents out there, this is exactly what
they fear most, so the press is going to grab them on the back of the
neck, push their collective noses in it and scream in their ear, "DO YOU
KNOW WHERE *YOUR* CHILDREN ARE?"  It sells, they're selling it.

And I'll be honest with you, in the short time I was raving with any
frequency, I saw it go from a more spiritual coming together to a bunch
of young kids blowing their brains out with as much drugs as they could
stuff in their bodies at one time without bursting into flames.

I'm not talking about all raves, but the mid-size to massives usually
fit this stereotype fairly closely.  Nowadays, if you try to present the
spiritual, giving, loving, PLUR side at a party, you're labelled as
"old-skool".

MY POINT IS: Don't look too harshly at the media.  Yeah, they don't ever
report the whole story, but the elements they do hold up to the light,
exaggerated as they may be, are truthful in themselves.  There are bad
elements in the rave scene.  If you don't want them exposed, leave
nothing to expose.

"They're all mad cause they think I'm giving them hell.  I'm not giving
them hell, I'm just telling the truth on them."
        - Truman

S

Is everybody ready for the wild and scary prospect of actually meeting 
the people behind these anonymous computer screens?!  Tonight's your chance!

The Official Booze Plan:

9ish - Cadillac Bar
	between 4th/5th and Howard/Mission
	(behind Chevy's Restaurant in an alley, next to huge parking lot)

11ish - off to Gaiamind 
	(the $7 benefit party for Headwaters Forest - check the calendar 
	for the amazing line-up!)

So far we have about 8 people joining the festivities, so it should be a 
nice little (or maybe big!) group.  Special thanks to the ravechicks who 
came to my rescue (so to speak)!

Cadillac isn't the hippest place in the world, but last time I was there 
they had a GREAT bartender, great guac and chips, and it's right next to 
a parking lot and is close to our final destination.

Also, dancing afterwards isn't a requirement.  I may even have to flake out 
because of work.  But it's an option if ya want to dance!

I'm gettin' excited!  See ya tonight!  I'll have a star on my cheek and 
probably a faux fur coat (warm!).  Dark hair.
