Too many thanks to the many folks of this list that recommended the way
cool F8 party last week... now I need you to do it again!  Y'see, you
did such a great job with the last time that now Ive got tons of newbies
begging me to find them a good party!  Last time I had 3... this time
probably even more.  So if ya dont mind, lemme know where you think
the vibe will be this and next weekend...  cause I will probably be there
too!  (It would be cool if the event had something other than trance...
like the breakbeat at F8... and maybe an ambient room! :-)

(For those who dont recall, I am the Sailor-suited Fighter For Justice -
Sailor Moon).

Now, for a little ranting off-subject :

The 20/20 story is more trouble than you might think.  My experience in
Pgh was that, every time one of these stories runs, newbies flock to find
some 'cool underground' so that they can get high and laid.  Its not
too disasterous, but the people who want to irritate their parents latch
on immediately (and dump it once they get sick of spreading around the
nasty vibe).  In other words, I for one will be adopting the hard shell
approach when it comes to people who are cold at these things for a while.
Normally, I keep talking (I know how it can be to get people out of a
shell... I live there myself all-too-often).

But, on a lighter note, the people I will be escorting couldnt be
friendlier so there will be some happy new faces.

Njoi,
- David

>

> report the whole story, but the elements they do hold up to the light,
> exaggerated as they may be, are truthful in themselves.  There are bad
> elements in the rave scene.  If you don't want them exposed, leave

No.

no! no! no!

The damage caused by this 20/20 segment goes far beyond making parents
and authorities paranoid about raves.

The real sad thing is that millions of kids will watch this and they will
indeed beleive that this what raves are about.

***The main reason raves are becoming more like teeny drug fests is becuase the
media is telling all these kids that is what they are***

If actual ravers were in control of the media, like, for example, SFRAVES,
kids would learn that raves were about spirituality... about grooving
down to funky beats... and yes, becoming more aware through mind expansion,
in whatever form.

I look with incredible harshness to the media.  They are creating a scene
that never was.  Their lies are permiating and what stories they make up 
becomes reality for all those hooked in to them.  

-troy

                ABC NEWS "20/20" REPORTS ON "RAVES," UNSUPERVISED
                ALL-NIGHT DANCE PARTIES WHICH HAVE BECOME POPULAR,
                                FRIDAY, JAN. 24=20

     "Raves," an underground movement which gathers large numbers of
     young people at secret locations for all-night dance parties, have
     become popular in recent years. But beneath the laser lights and loud
     music, are America's youth rebelling in a new and dangerous way,
     including the widespread use of drugs? Lynn Sherr reports on ABC
     News "20/20," FRIDAY, JAN. 24 (10:00-11:00 p.m., ET), on the ABC
     Television Network.

     Raves, which are not supervised by adults, take place throughout the
     country, including large cities and small towns, in farm fields and
     abandoned warehouses or in after-hour bars or clubs. Young people
     find out about the events through a network of secret passwords and
     Internet communications. Because raves have become a haven for
     drug-taking with a dance beat, organizers are determined to keep them
     underground, far from the prying eyes of police and parents.

     "If you go to a rave and you're not on Ecstasy or some other kind of
     drug," a former "raver" explains, "then you kind of stick out like a=
 sore
     thumb. You're.... you're an endangered species."

     In addition to Ecstasy, an amphetamine-like drug which helps
     party-goers stay up all night and dance, ravers take LSD or acid, an
     hallucinogenic drug, and Special K (ketamine), an animal anesthetic
     which is snorted by users. Dr. David McDowell, a psychiatrist who has
     studied ravers=ED drug use at the scene, says that not only are an=
 alarming
     number of participants using them but they are often taking several at
     the same time.=20

     "Over seventy percent of the kids said they were on drugs," Dr.
     McDowell said. "The peer pressure to take these drugs in this
     environment is just profoundly strong. Many of these drugs are
     addicting and many of them have terrible side effects and can lead to
     tremendous devastation, both personally and biologically down the
     road."=20

     For college student Sandy Montesi, who attended a 1992 rave in
     Orlando, Florida, the results were fatal and devastating to her family.
     The previously healthy young woman suffered a massive heart attack
     from a temperature which soared to 107 degrees before her death. Her
     mother was told that the temperature was brought on by the drug
     Ecstasy.=20

     After her daughter died, Marsha Montesi learned that the
     establishment which held the rave Sandy attended had been visited by
     police 500 times in the two previous years, often to deal with drug
     activity. Through her grief, she helped enact a local ordinance to=
 close
     such places down and had the dealer who supplied the Ecstasy which
     killed her daughter put in prison for manslaughter.=20

     "We need to stop the raves," Mrs. Montesi says. "It's not a dance,
     it's not a safe place for your kids. Do anything. If your child=
 insists, go
     with them and then you'll find out. Your child doesn't want you there
     because they know what is really going on."=20



                          Also This Week On "20/20":

        Dr. Timothy Johnson reports on the strange and often lonely=20
        world of sexual addiction.=20

        And Deborah Roberts reports on a new movement among overweight=
 people
        which emphasizes fitness and good health over weight loss.=20

Wow, that was an interesting webpage to read. 
I didn't know that when I went to parties sober, I stuck out like a 
sore thumb! Silly me! I should go do some drugs! 
While I agree that the report had some truths to it, they are only 
half-truths. And the story seems to be laced with misconceptions.

	I think what the problem is, is that 20/20 did not even cover a 
single positive aspect of the scene. They focused on the negativity 
of the scene, which can be avoidable if you're one smart cat. 
However, as a somewhat-aspiring journalist, I know that any good 
reporter would cover all aspects of a story. POOR journalism is what 
it's called when a reporter fails to see other aspects. YELLOW 
journalism is what it's called when some aspects are ignored 
purposefully in order to make a juicy story. This is a disrespectable 
thing (supposedly) in journalism of any type. What we see in this 
20/20 report of raves is either POOR or YELLOW journalism. DID they 
actually see the vibe? We don't know that. Although it would be 
refreshing to say "damn them, they ignored all the good aspects," 
what if the rave they went to really WAS a drugfest (sad, but true, 
that's what SOME raves have become for many kids). 
	I agree with SDream that if we don't want to be exposed, then 
we shouldn't have anything to hide. But, I also agree that the 
exposing of the rave scene in the light of the media is entirely 
negative, and they ignore any positivity that comes out of the 
scene. ALSO, they DO (as one other pointed out) attract kids -- if 
you remember the Leeza way back, they were talking about how it's the 
new way kids rebel, and it's the place anyone can do whatever they 
want, etc. Kids are gonna go "woah! drugfest 97! I'M THERE!" and it's 
already begun to happen, and it's going to KEEP happening as long as 
shows like 20/20 and Leeza keep pumping out this yellow journalism.
	As someone I forget once said, "if you tell the same lie over 
and over again and long enough, the lie often ends up the truth."
	So the way I see it, the more the media portrays the rave 
scene as a drug-scene full of kids lacking responsibility, self 
respect and angst, that's how it's going to end up. Just go to a 
massive one of these days, you'll see that it's happening already. 

Well, aside from the wonderful show we all get to tape/watch tomorrow 
night, I hope you all have a wonderful weekend and hope to see some 
of you at Galactic Tunnel ! :)
Love and Hugs,
LAra

[TRR] - Totally Rave Related

I have already sent 2 letters to 20/20 thru their website.  Everyone should
visit
http://www.abc.com/vvoice/talk.html and give them your opinions about this
topic.  Hopefully they will read it and get our side of the story.  If you
are really involved in our scene and want to contribute something for its
well-being now is the time!  Make sure you give them both the positive and
the negative aspects.  

This 20/20 feature will definately affect our scene.  Parents and law
enforcement people will watch this show and if we miss this oportunity to
tell them what we think they will pursue on shutting us down.  

For those of you on other raver mailing lists please forward this message to
them. And also ell your friends who have web access to do too.  Let's get
the word out.  For our sake........

> I'd also like see the methodology by which they obtained the hypothesis
> that 70% of ravers are on drugs at any given party.

I have plenty to say on this topic and no time here at work, so I'll keep 
my comments to this:

Would they take their cameras to a bar and exclaim in shock, "70% of 
people in the bar admitted to drinking alcohol?!"  Ridiculous, right?  OF 
COURSE people are partying at a bar - that's its purpose.

Yes, a lot of people at a rave are in a non-sober state - just like any
other partiers, teenage or otherwise.  People (it seems naturally) seek to
alter their consciousness periodically, for play (ain't it great?!). 
Every weekend, most people who are at a party, a bar, a club, even
restaurants and their own homes are ingesting something - usually the 
notoriously dangerous drug, alcohol. 

At rave parties, there are simply different types of intoxicants than in
other party scenes.  So what's the difference?  Well, one is that the
entire purpose of a rave does not revolve around the intoxicant, unlike
most college parties and bars/clubs. 

Oh, the other difference: the drug alcohol is legal, other drugs are not. 
And therefore, by some specious logic, other drugs - and raves -
categorically evil.  (A very simple mindset - what is illegal is BAD, what
is legal is GOOD, no independent or rational thought will be tolerated). 

Yes, I usually do drugs at parties.  But you know what?  Tonight I'm 
going to a bar and I'm going to drink alcohol.  Why is one so wrong 
the other considered "normal" behavior??  ESPECIALLY when alcohol is so 
much more dangerous than any of these other drugs??  Is our culture 
at all capable of rationality??!

And the topic of drug prohibition, mainstream hysteria and straight-out 
alcohol hypocrisy to be continued later,

Nancy

PS Drug Legalization NOW

Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9701231702.A11694-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



OH MY GOD.  Worse than I had imagined.

I can't believe the lies they're perpetrating.  All in the name of 
ratings?  It's really disgusting.  Yes, E is a horribly addictive drug 
that leads either to death or personal ruination.  Oh yeah, raving is not 
about dancing or music, it is simply a haven for strung-out little kids 
to compulsively ingest these drugs until they die.  

Call in the army.  This plague must be stopped!  For the children!

But I agree that perhaps the worst direct effect on our scene are all the 
people who see 20/20 and go "COOL!  Just what I was looking for."  How 
are the new ravers to KNOW about what we are trying to create?  There are 
no handbooks, and a lot of old-skoolers have disappeared...

I have wanted to write of this for a while, and don't have the time to do 
it justice now.  But how are the newbies to learn that this is more than 
a party/dance scene?  The problem is, it's cool just on those merits, and 
people are happy to do some speed and dance all night, but it could be so 
much more...

later,
N

hello, everyone.  i just opened my email after not checking it cause the 
storm had us trying to log in from any available terminal, but to no 
avail.  

i had 173 messages from you guys.  approximately 40% of them were about 
this 20/20 thing.  

i think a lot of us ravers seem to understand that TV is an addictive 
drug perhaps far worse than substances we shoot and otherwise insert into 
our bodies.  did you KNOW that the average American watches 8 1/2 hours 
of television a DAY?  that means someone is watching 16, because i don't 
watch very much at all.  it is hard to get me away from a good star trek 
episode, but that's about it.  NOW TO THE 20/20 EXPOSE...

some of you may know that i work with equinox, a network company that 
sells environmentally conscious products.  some of you may have worked 
for this company.  i don't know.  but what i do know is 20/20 did a story 
on them, and chose to show only the negative light just like this!  i 
thought some of you might be interested in knowing this.  however, the 
founder of the company, mr. gouldd did his own TV show...and he 
broadcasted it on his own private satellite network.  i throw this out 
there, because hopefully if i can reach one or two ravers out there that 
happen to be financially well off, this is a perfect kind of thing to do 
about raves, as well!  Can you imagine, systematically taking apart John 
Stosle, Hugh Downs, and Barbara Wawa (or whatever the hell her name is) 
and somehow distributing it?  this is good incentive for more people to 
find a way to get the money issue out of their lives so we can tackle 
issues like this in the most powerful way.  find out what your dream is 
and how you can accomplish it and do it so you can be the best possible 
contribution to the scene.  

i urge you.  

we need more promoters.  we need more promoters.  we need more promoters.
love, deepfog

hey everyone,

     i just finished reading that bullshit 20/20 report and i am livid. i
shouldn't be too surprised, because our scene is never portrayed in a
positive light. 
     i didn't realize that by staying sober at a party that "i stick out like
a sore thumb". silly me, my drug addled brain had me believing that i party
because i love the music, i love to dance, and i love the people. i didn't
realize that i've been raving all this time because i like to get f*cked up
on drugs and have sex with a lot of guys.
       i also find it really funny that the same media that is portraying us
as tweaked out little kids were the same people who attended the first
woodstock. IMHO ex-hippies are hypocrites, that's what hippie means. back in
their day they were out doing acid that is 20 times stronger than the acid we
have today, they were in the habit of practicing unprotected "free love", and
they were rebelling against everything. all they wanted was for people to
understand that times were changing. today, they are treating us the same way
that the authority figures treated them.
     instead of busting criminals, cops are out on the streets busting up
parties where kids are having a good time. we can't even meet in a place to
dance without being hassled. it's time for us to do something about it.
     hopefully a lot of you feel the same way i do. it's time for us to start
educating people on the power of music and the power of our scene. express
your opinions to ABC and 20/20 and get involved in anything that will help
our movement.

PLUR,
dorena

smokin' out    of it.

I was talking to a few friends and here are a few ideas we came up with:

1) Inform all our party-going friends about the 20/20 show and 
encourage them to watch it and spread the word, and write to 20/20 in response.

2) get on all the other rave-related lists (try the regional 
hyperreal lists) and tell them to do the same

3) start a petition (this is what we're doing) that demands that 
20/20 do a segment on the positive aspects of parties and spread the 
petitions around.

4) do what deepfog said and make a tv show and somehow get it on tv 
showing the positive aspects of raves.

	. . . anyone else agree/ up for it?:))
Peace, Love and Hugs,
LAra

X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.1 10oct95)
To: sho@goonsquad.spies.com (Sho Kuwamoto), sfraves@hyperreal.com (sfraves)
Subject: Re: DJ style/technique (was Re: DJ Dan who?)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The problem I find with the quick-mix and long-overlay-mix styles both
is that they're both good hammers, and the people who learn to use them
think every record is thereby like a nail.  As a *dance* music DJ who
started in that cradle of the house groove, the SF warehouse rave, 
I naturally tend toward the long-overlay type of mix.  But I too have
done the rounds and seen what can be done otherwise.  

If anything, I think every style suffers now from DJs trying to either
suffocate their records in extra-long mixes, or trying (and often failing)
to impress with various mixer tricks.  

If you watch those who really know what to do with the mixer tricks,
you'll notice how little is actually done, but when it happens it's
aligned with the *music*.  Mark Farina gives consistent clinics in how
to do mixing tricks without overdoing it.  Even then, you can see that
hours and hours of practice go into figuring out what works and making
it dead-on-solid.  

phred

From: =?iso-8859-1?Q?=22=A4=5BOo=5D=A4=22?= <iam@chosen.org>

Rather than be mad about the misrepresentation of a scene that means
no harm, I decided to write abc televison.

This is what I wrote.

----------------------------------------------------------------------

	This Friday, a 20/20 episode "about" raves will air. I have 
read the commentary on what the show is about, and am very
displeased with the intense lack of professionalism in the
reporting of what goes on that these celebrations of life,
some call raves.
	A rave in itself is a gathering of like-minded people who -
in an age of destruction and war - decide to dispense their 
energies in a much more positive way. There are no restrictions
as to who can enter these parties, you may be 15 and you may be
85- as I have seen ages anywhere in between, you may be black,
white, indian, hispanic - ALL races, nationalities, and creeds are
accepted here. Discrimination is  very real, very destructive, and
very opressing. We as ravers through out any prejudices that may
exist outside of the gates of our raves. There are many languages 
in the world, none of us know them all. There is one language
that comes from vibrations, rather than sounds. We gather as a collective 
to listen to this language that transcends all barriers, called "music". 
	With a language that is understood by all, a language that
spans many meanings, and can be more artistic and beautiful than any 
otherlanguage yet to be heard,  begins the unification of everyone
attending a rave. 
Music is a pure source of energy, unifying all, and is a key step into the
breaking down of walls that many people learn to build as a "shield" to 
protect them from all of the violence, the hurt, and the evils of our world.
	As in any aspect of life, whether it be the slum in the city,	
 the Doctors that perform surgeries, the families in the churches, anywhere
that there is a collective of people, there will be those that
are not there for the right reasons. Drug use / abuse exists in every culture
since near the dawn of civilization. The rave scene in itself is a
civilization,
a collective of people who are not immune to self destructive behaviour, 
including drug use / abuse. Although we do not condone drugs  at raves, 
we do not look down on those who use them (once again, discrimination is  a
barrier we are attempting to destroy). Rather than demote and outcast these
people, we choose an attempt to educate them, in hopes that they will choose 
to do what is best for their health, and their mentality.
	Raves are a place that "ravers" go to celebrate their
differences from the world we live in, where we gather to release our energies
as a positive vibe that will uplift the human spirit, and in turn, our lives 
outside of the raves become more enjoyable. Many people in the world,
especially
youth, have an immense supply of energy. A lot of people know not of a way
to release
this energy, which is bottled until it blows (i.e. FIGHTS!). This is why we
can have a 
gathering of 2000-3000 people, and not a single fight, but you will see
people meeting 
for the first time with a smile and a hug, a peace offering in the form of
candy, 
and a lot of other happenings that can only make you smile,  feel warm and
loved.
A rave is proof that this world is NOT entirely composed of wicked and evil
people, 
but that there is a collective  that promote Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect.

ON A FINAL NOTE:
	Contrary to the 20/20 report, raves are not in any way meant to
be a "drug-fest", or to allow children to run rampant. Many teens do not 
understand the true meaning of a rave, but only hear of what a rave is like
from uneducated, biased television programs, which prompt parents into 
the words "NO RAVES! If I ever find out..."  which we all know (after all,
we were 
once children too) is a red flag stating "want to do something bad? go to a
rave!"
And the curiosity will send the child there, with no facts on what a rave is, 
prompting even more trouble. Parents have custody of children under the 
age of 18, and should watch over them. The fact that they are at raves is not 
the fault of the raves, but of the parents, who should be knowledgable of
where 
their children are. 

-sending you all much love
-Justin Gillard

Subject: GaiaMind: a mini-review
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk





well, all i can say about GaiaMind last night was that IT WENT OFF.
the jungle/drum'n'bass in the dance area was some of the hardest jungle
i've heard in a long time.  mad props go out to DJ Flux and StarEyes whose
set (11:30-12:30?) sent the whole place into a mad, frenetic euphoria.  the
place was filled with different types of people coming together for a good
cause -- to save the Headwaters Forest.  there was also some live acts in
the main room and tons of artwork on the walls (since this was held at an
art gallery).  i apologize if this review seems a bit one-sided but i only
stayed 'til 1:30 because i had to go work early the next day...maybe
someone out there can give a more definitive review of GaiaMind than me.

also, xtra mad props goes out to nancy for organizing Boozers II last
night.  thanx for the brew Colin.  i'll have to get you back on the next
Boozers.  hope everyone had a GREAT time last night...

PLURJ (Peas, Luv, Uni-T, Respex, Jungalism),

d0u8l3 J;)

          by precipice.v-site.net (8.8.4/8.8.4) with SMTP
	  id JAA12513 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 24 Jan 1997 09:25:20 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <3.0.32.19970124092243.009ec830@pop.v-site.net>
X-Sender: cybertrb@pop.v-site.net
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 3.0 (32)
Date: Fri, 24 Jan 1997 09:22:44 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Sub Commander Lycos <Sub-Cmdr.Lycos@cybertribe.com>
Subject: FMR:A new beginning
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I had been monitoring the long range weather forcast for several days. It
seemed like there was a chance, a small chance, that the rain would let up
and it would clear for one night, maybe just a few hours. But this time
yesterday morning, it didn't look like it. As the day progresses, it
continued to drisle, rain and mist.  It doesn't look good I started telling
people.  Then around 5 p.m. the weather broke, by 7 p.m. the concrete was
dry and there was a PHAT Moon up in the sky, beconing us to come out into
the moon light. All of the sound systems that I called didn't want to risk
the rain.  Finally around 8:30 Carlos called, he found a sound system, but
it was in San Jose, 50 miles south, but they'll bring it up!?  OK IT'S ON!
Don't forget to bring your records!
This time everything worked right, tune into GaiaMind and you can't go
wrong on this most auspicious day of days. When I got to The Stick around
12:30, everything was set up and carlos was spinning, It was small and
cozy, about 20 people, a fire and a small but nice sound system.  We
exchanged hugs and smiles. The spot was right nexttto the water,  The
ground was too wet to sit on but there were picknic tables and milk crates,
and besides, we're here to dance! Carlos spun latin house, techno, salsa
techno. He told me I wold go on at 3:30. Wow the circle is complete, from
stumbling into my first FMR almost
6 years ago, to dancing madly infront of the speaker, to parking cars, now
getting behind the decks and playing, even if it is only for 25 people, it
is still an honor.  It doesn't matter how many people come to the FMR, what
matters is that it happens, it is an offering to before the altar of Mother
Earth. An acknowledgement of our connection with her. And we give the thing
that is so precious to many of us, the gift of House Music, a unifying
force that is understood by all. And the mother accepted our gift last
night, she held back her tears, and allowed her children to dance
underneath her sister's shimmering light.  And dance we did. Playing under
the moon is not like playing in a club or in your bedroom.  You can draw
down the energy from above...
if you know how.  last night was magical in many ways, it was the first FMR
of this year. The first FMR in many months that follows in the tradition of
the Wicked FMR of years past.  Indeed two brothers from Poland were there,
they had attended the very first FMR at baker beach 6 years ago, here they
were again, a good omen.  The six pointed do-hicky in the sky blazed above
us, as I rocked tribal beats below.  Tracy shows up at 4 am to rock the
place. People shared coffee, candy, cigaretts and shrooms, weed and a
little wine, family once again.  For some it was their first and there were
some old skoolers in the house as well. Hats off to all who helped to make
it happen. It's our intention to continue the tradition, it seems the torch
has passed to us, may we share in the carrying of the torch and may it
shile bright for a long time.


				Pray to the Moon
				When She is Rounde
				Luck with you
				Shall then abounde
				What ever you seek for
				Shall be founde
				In Sea, or Sky, or Solid Grounde

See you on the dancefloor.

							S.Cmdr.Lycos

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: The Booze Review
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9701241039.A15560-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>

Precedence: bulk


Boozers 2, the Review (hey, that rhymes!)

Quite a crowd turned out, compared to last time!  What's up to: Black 
Adder, Branka, Micron, Zza, Rob J, Jonathan, Eric (*not* Eric Peterson, 
*not* Eric Dunkelberger, *not* 250 BlowPop Eric, "just Eric")`, Paulie, 
Kolin, and the famous Derek Chung (who's half-responsible for this monster 
called SFR).  Thanks for coming!!

The Cadillac Bar turned out to be a cheesy choice, but at least our crowd 
of SFRavers stuck out like a sore thumb (much like a sober person at a 
rave!).  A private corporate party took over the large front room (!), 
so we were shunted to the back "for dinner."  So we took over a big 
table, munched on free salsa and chips, and ordered nothin' but drinks.  
Our rather sedate table was completely overshadowed, though, by a rowdy 
crowd of middle-age partiers next to us, downing tequila shooters and 
howling and screaming.  (*Jeez*, and I thought strung-out teens at 
all-night drugfests were bad!)

We parted ways at 11 to drive to Gaiamind in our separate cars, and I got 
in mine only to find my tempermental starter decided to conk out again!  
After a visit from Mr. Tow Guy, it was apparent I was driving nowhere but 
straight home.  I had been REALLY excited about Gaiamind, and had just 
convinced the whole Boozers crowd to go, so the night ended on a 
disappointing note for me.  I consoled myself by dancing to a mixtape at 
home, but it just ain't the same...

All-in-all, a nice time meeting new people.  And to all the other 
boozehounds out there, see ya next time!

N

To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
From: "nathan.b.beckord" <nathan.b.beckord@ArthurAndersen.com>
Date: 24 Jan 97  9:33:43 
Subject: Gaiamind review
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

It being a Thursday, and having to be at work bright and shiny everyday at 
7:30, I knew from the start that the night  wasn't going to be a long one.  But 
after meditating for awhile, with the global alignment occuring "up there"  and 
then after awhile reading about the significance of the event on Gaiamind's 
webiste, I knew I had to make it to this. The karma was right.

Got there around 10:30 after stopping off at 11 (restaurant) for a bit. That's 
an unusual scene - suave rapsters and hip-hopsters, decked out to the max. 
Anywho, the place was very easy to find, and except for the muddy road to 
devotion, was refreshingly open and airy with huge ceilings, an art gallery 
portion, a stage with theatre seats at the opposite end of the dance floor, 
slides of Burning Man and the Headwaters Forest crew, several intricate 
shrines, and really friendly, cool, concerned staff.   

The crowd was just what I love to see: a little bit of everything.  We had the 
older, original  hippies, the new generation of deadheads/phishheads, a lot of 
funksters, many technobabies, several scenesters, various junglists, etc. ,  
The band that played was interesting,and it was great to sit in the theatre 
seats and 420 it while listening. The middle chill room had some great black 
light stuff.  But the real action was to be found in the far back room.  Here, 
massive jungle/drum&bass attacks were felt for hours. The sound system was 
superb, with nice, fuzzy basswaves giving me a massage. This is what makes me 
love jungle!

Anywho, had to skedaddle around 2:30 or so so today wouldn't be hell.  For 
those people I met, I was the white dude with black hair with silver vinyl 
pants and a blue velour shirt (just had to wear the vinyl after reading the 
posts yesterday. My accomplice in crime chose latex.  We were ready for the  
wet weather!)

Adios,
Nathan

Yes, it's true - Jungle Love went OFF last night!!!  Turntable madness from
a.r.m. assassins Sifu and Rich: Sifu tore it up despite having to replace a
faulty turntable mid-set... Rich played a amazing long set of the darkest,
hardest jungle I have yet to hear in SF, taking us all on a rollercoaster
ride through Hades and back again.  Stareyes made a surprise appearance,
for all the heads who were so eagerly anticipating the dubplates she
brought back from London... she spun a smooth set of way new jump-up with
loads of wobbly basslines, just the way I like it.  Flux took the tables
next, to show all SF junglists how it should be done.  Props to Flux for
kicking a fever to make it out and spin.  Unfortunately, I missed Madame's
set, but I hear she threw down as well.

Special thanks to Ed, the lighting guy, who took my recommendation and
chilled out on those annoying flashing strobe-like thingies... and also
thanks to all the heads who turned out to make this a great club!  The
energy surrounding this scene is so thick you could cut it with a knife!

My pick 'o' the weekend: MERIDIAN!!!!  (more info to come)
Jonathan

The Beta Lounge
http://www.betalounge.com/

>i  thought some of you might be interested in knowing this.  however, the
>founder of the company, mr. gouldd did his own TV show...and he
>broadcasted it on his own private satellite network.

Hah!!   Just what I did,  when Steve Knopper whote that shitty article
on me in Internet Underground.  First off,  I agreed to be interviewed if
he published my URL..   He did,  and now after getting tons of Email on
how poorly he represented me,  I published a rebuttal.   I fugured at
least 80% who read that article also read my rebuttal I published on my
WEB pages,  blowing apart Steve's article,   pointing out the many things
he skipped over and did NOT mention,   explaining to people that he
was careless in transcribing the interview which was put on tape,   making
him the fool he is.

I say,  that if any self respecting raver ever goes on camera for ANY
reason,   get the producer to agree to publish your or our web site as
a condition for going on camera.   Most media mongers would agree to this.

Then,   if anything is said to mis-represent our scene,   we can put up
a rebuttal on our web page.    Just a thought...   Score one for the WWW
and it's amazing ability for self publishing.    Just make sure the server
is capable of handling all the hits....    :-)

Crunchman

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: peter@niles.com (Customer Service)
Subject: What is Rave/dark/techno/industrial/gothic?  Que?
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey kiddies.  Here's a snatch of a conversation one of my co-workers found
on a keyboardist's mailing list.  More funny than accurate, I reckon...
The list address is at the bottom of the post.
:o)


>At 07:12 AM 1/14/97 -0500, Rick S. wrote:
>>I've been reading the "Who are we" posts and have discovered that I
>>don't have the faintest clue about some of the influences mentioned
>>by various listers.
>>
>>So maybe someone could help me to understand some of the musical genres
>>and sub-genres I've been seeing here.  I've heard _of_ techno and
>>ambient but I've not _heard_ either one.   What is "dark"? Gothic?
>>Rave? Jungle?  Trip hop?
>> [More snipped]
>
>Rick,
>
>Try to imagine you have a half a dozen recordings of Rossini's "La Gaza
>Ladra" including the wild all-analog synth one from "Clockwork Orange", a
>deliciosly bad Hungarian Gypsy version, and other versions each faster and
>louder than the other, but essentially identical.
>
>The one from Clockwork Orange is Techno. Slip it on your turntable.
>Remember Vinyl? If you play it at 45 while watching national geographic
>special on Pygmies of the Itruri rain forest it's jungle.  If you play it at
>78, while taking, oh, lets say a fistful of No-Doze and a couple of shots of
>Robitussin, and keep dancing to the grooves at the end of the record, that's
>rave.  If you sample just one hit from the middle plus the grooves at the
>end of the record, slow them to half speed, add a Roland 404 high hat and
>make up your own hard hitting urban lyrics about getting ripped off by "the
>bird", that's hip hop.  Speed it up a bit, Sample the aforementioned pygmies
>and use them instead of the 404, then sample the previous record for the
>phrase "it's the Bird, Man" and down the rave concotion before trying to
>sing your own lyrics and that's Trip-hop.
>
>Throw out "the bird", save the pygmies, slow the whole thing down and play
>the Bad Hungarians - backwards - while alternately screaming and whispering
>the more graphic excerpts from Lovecraft's "Tales of the Cthuulu Mythos"
>though a megaphone into a Telefunken U-32, and you have Gothic.
>
>Take any of the other orchestral versions, play as slowly as possible on
>piano and shakuhachi (acoustic, if possible) and you have new age.  Ambient
>is that same recording with a beat - the kit consists of a sample of Trent
>Reznor burping acting as the bass drum, with the rest of the kit played on
>as many "world" percussion instruments as possible.
>
>All the rest of the noise and fury is the conductors and PR men for the
>various orchestras fighting over how their version is better, more
>authentic, a new interpretation, more exiting, louder, or played on period
>instruments by nekkid women, who none-the-less, are making a statement about
>the vulnerability of classical musicians in an industrial society AND making
>the distinction that they are not merely copying the nekkid women from
Seattle.

  Geekonics
  By John Woestendiek
  Philadelphia Inquirer
  Wed., January 8, 1997

  NEWS BULLETIN: Saying it will improve the education of children who
  have grown up immersed in computer lingo, the school board in San
  Jose, Calif., has officially designated computer English, or
  "Geekonics", as a second language.

  The historic vote on Geekonics -- a combination of the word "geek"
  and the word "phonics" -- came just weeks after the Oakland school
  board recognized black English, or Ebonics, as a distinct language.

  "This entirely reconfigures our parameters," Milton 'Floppy'
  Macintosh, chairman of Geekonics Unlimited, said after the school
  board became the first in the nation to recognize Geekonics.

  "No longer are we preformatted for failure," Macintosh said during a
  celebration that saw many Geekonics backers come dangerously close
  to smiling. "Today, we are rebooting, implementing a program to
  process the data we need to interface with all units of humanity."

  Controversial and widely misunderstood, the Geekonics movement was
  spawned in California's Silicon Valley, where many children have
  grown up in households headed by computer technicians, programmers,
  engineers and scientists who have lost ability to speak plain
  English and have inadvertently passed on their high-tech vernacular
  to their children.

  HELPING THE TRANSITION

  While schools will not teach the language, increased teacher
  awareness of Geekonics, proponents say, will help children make the
  transition to standard English. Those students, in turn, could
  possibly help their parents learn to speak in a manner that would
  lead listeners to believe that they have actual blood coursing
  through their veins.

  "Bit by bit, byte by byte, with the proper system development, with
  nonpreemptive multitasking, I see no reason why we can't download
  the data we need to modulate our oral output," Macintosh said.

  The designation of Ebonics and Geekonics as languages reflects a
  growing awareness of our nation's lingual diversity, experts say.

  Other groups pushing for their own languages and/or vernaculars to
  be declared official viewed the Geekonics vote as a step in the
  right direction.

  "This is just, like, OK, you know, the most totally kewl thing,
  like, ever," said Jennifer Notat-Albright, chairwoman of the
  Committee for the Advancement of Valleyonics, headquartered in
  Southern California. "I mean, like, you know?" she added.

  THEY'RE HAPPY IN DIXIE

  "Yeee-hah," said Buford "Kudzu" Davis, president of the Dixionics
  Coalition. "Y'all gotta know I'm as happy as a tick on a sleeping
  bloodhound about this."

  Spokesmen for several subchapters of Dixionics -- including
  Alabonics, Tennesonics and Louisionics -- also said they approved of
  the decision.

  Bill Flack, public information officer for the Blue Ribbon Task
  Force on Bureaucratonics said that his organization would not
  comment on the San Jose vote until it convened a summit meeting,
  studied the impact, assessed the feasibility, finalized a report and
  drafted a comprehensive action plan, which, once it clears the
  appropriate subcommittees and is voted on, will be made public to
  those who submit the proper information-request forms.

  Proponents of Ebonics heartily endorsed the designation of Geekonics
  as an official language.

  Those involved in the lingual diversity movement believe that only
  by enacting many different English languages, in addition to all the
  foreign ones practiced here, can we all end up happily speaking the
  same boring one, becoming a nation that is both unified in its
  diversity, and diversified in its unity.

  Others say that makes no sense at all. In any language.

  But wait,  there's more!:

              Irish-American Speak -- Leprechaunics

              Native-American Speak -- Kimosabics

              Italo-American Speak -- Spumonics (or Rigatonics)

              Chinese-American Speak -- Won-tonics

              Japanese-American Speak -- Mama-san-ics

              Polish-American Speak -- Kielbasanics

              Jewish-American Speak -- Zionics

              Russian-American Speak -- Rasputonics

              Spanish-American Speak -- Flan-ics

              Scottish-American Speak -- Tartan-ics

              Eskimo-American Speak -- Harpoonics

              German-American Speak -- Autobaunics (or Teutonics)

              French-American Speak -- Cornichonics (or Escargonics)

              Oakland-School-Board Speak -- Moronics

------- End of forwarded message -------

So much energy for a Thurs! LOTS of fun people.  My analysis: astrologers
and nature freaks and dance cravers were prevalent.  People weren't all too
high to communicate. Really liked the spacious, friendly, uncrowded feeling
there. 

Surprise: great music, seeing some old friends with new dance moves.  In the
smaller room, excellent DJ "tag team" which really built and delivered solid
dance rythm with variety.  Good that you could see everywhere, it wasn't too
dark.  

Ok, so you get the idea...this was a good time for me and about 100 friends
and another 200 aquaintences.  just too bad about that parking tkt.(as
usual).  What!  You expect me to actually read the signs!

See ya at the next one.   XO  Rhoda

>I think this is a great idea.  No URL, no story!
>
Absoutely....  It kees the press on their toes,   forces them to report
truthfully,  because if they don't,   you can put up a rebuttal and
further explain and put things in perspective.

I've got an amazing amount of good positive mail from those people who've
read my IU rebuttal on my site.    Some have resulted in jobs...    And
once I put that up,   I was getting real positive mail....    IN fact,
the Internet Underground actually Published my rebuttal....    :-)
Primarily,  because I asked each person who mailed me to write to the
magazine,  expresseing their dislike and bias that Steve reported in
the article.   So there *IS* a way to fight back against the media mongers.

Crunchman

Hey there!
  Anyone reading this probably already has a good intention of helping me
out.  So, I'll cut right to it.  I live within walking distance of SJSU and
would really, very much like to do some hard dancing tonight with some
brilliant smiling faces.  If San Jose is on your way, please come pick me
up.  I'm alone, and although I'm tall and take up a lot of space in most
cars, I do come with gum and a can of Kerns fruit juice ("Pear Nectar") :) .
Terms and conditions of transport naturally are yours, but I can be ready at
any time tonight and come back whenever is convenient to you.  If possible,
please call Eric at 408.998.0581.  Thank you.  ;)
Happiness

Most of the stuff this weekend seems fairly underground, it's nice to
see a lot of different names out there.  Thanks everyone for sending in
info, I haven't picked up that much myself lately.

   Thursday, January 23rd - _Jungle Love_

   Black. free before 11:30 w/flyer.
   10pm-4am, 21+, $5. Transmission Theatre, 308 11th St @ Folsom, SF.
   415.908.6710
   
   Ubiquitous - house w/DJs Pete Avila, live congos by Brian, guests.
   9pm-2am, Free. The Phoenix Club, 325 S First St, San Jose.
   408.881.0615 415.263.0695 510.806.8588 916.491.1944
   
   _Eklipze_ - Digital Cyberave - (Teckno-Industrial) & Goa Trance w/DJs
   Vection3, Theta Blip, DJ Daniel. $5. 435 Broadway, SF. 415.289.6913
   
   _Liquid_ - dub, trip hop, trance, jungle w/DJs Rich (A.R.M.), Wallace.
   9pm-. 2925 16th St @ S.Van Ness, SF.

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night midnight-3am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats,
       Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Fissionchips wrote:
> 
> why not ...
> 
> put together a nice long letter with a bunch of intelligent thoughts
> concerning raves etc... and fax them off to a couple of local radio
> stations, see if they'll read them over the air. aside from that theres
> really no other method of 'retaliation' i can think of =)
> 
> ideas anyone ... ?



time to consult the anarchist's cookbook...
let our new york operatives take care of the biz...


actually, aside from voicing intelligent complaints on their web site,
clogging their phone lines and sending legal mail pranks to their
offices, there's not much to be done... silence usually works the
best... when the temple of psychick youth had allegations of satanic
child abuse thrown at them from a right wing program with an agenda to
bring down rave gatherings and other "psychick rallies", they did
absolutely nothing... laid low, no comments... the press wound up
feeding back on itself... the first day saw right wingers expressing
their horror at it all...  the second and third days saw left wing
outsiders coment on the harshness of it all... how the video footage in
question was simply a short film by prominent film director Derek Jarman
including footage of performance art (a little more extreme than the jim
rose circus side show, but consensual and legal between adults
nine-the-less)... all this information came to light without any
official word from the TOPY camps at all... within a week there were
media critics and all sorts of people of both persuasions coming down on
the news program...  unfortunately for us, because there is such a
saturation of companies, it is difficult to cancel events so we can lay
low... the average rave has at least $10,000 rapped up in it...

the alchemist

From: Doug Miller (J.C.) <dougm@kzsu.Stanford.EDU>

Subject: momentum (fwd)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 24 Jan 1997 21:39:51 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This looks like an interesting event for the more muscially adventurous.

Forwarded message:
> From - Fri Jan 24 20:04:24 1997
> Date: Fri, 24 Jan 1997 20:03:38 -0800 (PST)
> From: Bob Boster <boster@mills.edu>
> Subject: momentum (fwd)
> Message-ID: <Pine.SGI.3.95.970124200200.14181F-100000@ella.mills.edu>
> MIME-Version: 1.0
> Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
> 
> 
> ------------------
> 
> momentum: an uninterrupted concert of electr(on)ic music
> 		presented by friction media and 2779
> 
> 
> Saturday February 1st, 8pm-2am	 at 2779  (formerly Komotion)  16th and
> Folsom, SF, CA . 4 dollars, in and out OK. Info: 510-655-8636 (day of show
> 415-626-4420) 
> 			or email: friction@pobox.com.
> 
> 
> featuring original music and multimedia by:
> Maggi Payne, Frank Henriksen, Kent Jolly, A.L. Dentel, Detergent, Michael
> Berry, Citizen Band, Mr. Meridies, Conceptual Musik Union, 
> dj Cheb i Sabbah, and (in absentia) Lesser.
> 
> 
> 
> ----more detailed information below, feel free to delete here---- 
> 
> 
> 1	What is momentum?
> 
> 2	Artists Profiles
> 
> 3	Other Info
> 
> 
> 
> momentum is an attempt to bring together performers and audiences from
> various subdivisions of the general category: electronic music for a large
> scale meeting of minds... The concert, which runs 6 hours start to finish,
> will include collaborative moments in the crossfades from one artists set
> to another's, as well as surround audio and some video accompaniment.
> This marks the first in a series of Bay Area concerts produced by Friction
> Media which will follow the aesthetic agenda of bringing together artists
> from different creative disciplines and styles. The Bay Area member (and
> founder) of the Friction Media collective, Bob Boster, has been committed
> to smashing artistic boundaries since his experience in the eclectic
> Chapel Hill music scene (culminating in the visionary compilation CD:
> Cognitive Mapping Vol. 2.) 
> 
> It is his feeling that the divisions between such genres as dance music,
> ambient, tape music, appropriative collage, musique concrete, drum n bass,
> audio art, noise, and illbient are false and that these divisions need to
> be confronted for electronic music to expand as a whole.  This concert is
> the first fully formed attack on these divisions.  
> 
> Further, the vision of these musics as being made within something of a
> modern folk tradition binds them together - and like folk music, these
> artists are traditionally under-promoted and usually struggle to get
> access to performing opportunities.  Hence the cover charge has been kept
> low to make the show available to the largest possible audience. This is
> not a profit-driven event, all money will go towards supporting 2779
> (another collective-run venture) and the performers...
> 
> 
> Artists Profiles (in order of appearance):
> 
> Maggi Payne is co-director of the Mills College Center for Contemporary
> Music, where she teaches.  Her music tends to focus with incredible
> attention on sound design and environment, and is often presented with her
> video work. Maggi has performed throughout the US and Europe and has
> released music on Lovely Music, Music and Arts, and Centaur.
> 
> Frank Henriksen is a composer from Norway, whose work exploits the fine
> degree of detail and control available within computer synthesis.  His
> work involves movement and sonic transformation and always takes advantage
> of the possibilities of dispersing sound in space.
> 
> Kent Jollys work brings ideas of composition from the visual arts into the
> audio realm in unprecedented ways.  Using synthesis, especially in
> conjunction with neural networks, Kent presents an elaborate and
> fully-formed vision of sound in ways completely separate from the expected
> in music. 
> 
> A.L. Dentel, aside from being a cornerstone of the 2779 collective, is
> presenting one of her series of 365 Daily Pieces.  While this piece
> involves field recorded sound in both original and transformed states, her
> series has music for a variety of traditional and non-traditional
> instruments.
> 
> Detergent (Chris Palmatier) is a painter and rock guitarist (Jobys
> Opinion) as well as a recording engineer.  A recent Chapel Hill
> ex-patriate, this marks his Bay Area debut.  His sense of rhythm and form
> comes from dance music, his sense of sound design from the studio, and his
> vision from free jazz.
> 
> Michael Berry "spends his time building real-time audio processors on
> computers and then playing with them."   
> 
> Citizen Band "is a collection of three composers (Thomas Day, Xopher
> Davidson and Gregory Lenczycki) whose goal is the utilitarian pursuit of
> sound exploration through all available means."   
> 
> Mr. Meridies (Bob Boster) works with stolen material (from CDs) and noise
> to construct new musics that re-configure authorship and creativity.  His
> music has been released by Friction Media and his DJing by Knitting
> Factory Works.
> 
> Conceptual Musik Union (Floyd Diebel) arrives as a representative of the
> Sacramento noise scene.  CMU composes using formal elements applied to
> found sounds, noise, and various musical sources - often in strongly
> thematic ways.
> 
> dj Cheb i Sabbah is a long-time participant in the Bay Area club scene, an
> artist of uncompromising stylistic vision (combining beats and
> environments with North and West African samples), and promoter of great
> music both on the KPFA and in local performance venues.
> 
> and scattered throughout the mix:
> 
> Lesser is something of an enigma, and will remain one by sending in an
> offering of tape loops from the road (Lesser is on a national tour as we
> speak).  Equal parts high-energy dance music and musique concrete, Lesser
> also has the audacity to perform live on occasion. 
> 
> 
> 
> Other info:
> 
> Participants and audience alike can't be expected to sustain 6 hours of
> music (although Friction Media offers a special prize to anyone who
> actually does) so feel free to come and go.  There will be a flea market
> of the participants' music as well as some related material. This event
> should be appropriate for all ages and dancing is encouraged.  Please call
> the information numbers for directions, details, etc.
>  
> 
>

affectionately given the title "Gabber Dave", and has an infamous reputation
for making people pogo up and down madly at 7am in the ambient room of
several Friends and Family's.  He is very humble about dj-identity, but I'm
sure he would gladly accept the offer to spin at a hardcore party...

Dave, are you listening?

or later with all the drugs some people take.

I just watched the 20/20 show on raves with my mom and one of her
friends.  Afterwards, I started going off on how I wanted to bombard
20/20 with nasty letters.  My mom's friend made the point that journalism
will always be sensational; it's a business.  We couldn't really sue them
for fraud, or anything like that.  He did have a really good suggestion
on how to get heard.

He said that it's not the tv show, nor the producer that we should write
to, but the ADVERTISERS.  We should write to all the companies who
endorsed this show (I know a lot of us taped this episode) and threaten
to boycot their products.  We should tell them we have no respect for
20/20's biased and overly-sensationalized spin on the rave scene.

So, I suggest that we write to all these advertisers and make a point to
explain our scene's positivity.  We've been slandered by the media
(again).  It's time we make an honest effort to bring our side of the
story to light.  We need to let the advertisers know that we don't agree
with 20/20's views, nor will we patronize any company that chooses to
support them.

Is anyone with me on this?

---Libby Rose

1)  20/20 sucks.
1.5) some fun soundbytes out of this report though... <Uncle Noah hooks up
the DJ-70 to the VCR...>
2)
Here are some tips if you ever become a subject in one of these rotten TV
shows:
- if someone with a TV camera walks up to you at a party and asks what you
are on, turn and walk away.
- if you are invited to sit with your peers and discuss the scene and the
subject of drugs happens to come up, _DO NOT_ say _anything_ about
'spiking' the beverages of _any_ public official, even a school principal
- if you are asked what illegal drugs are cut with, _do not_ say "Heroin!"
unless you have some kind of proof.  AND if you _do_ have proof that some
stuff is being cut with Heroin, don't take it
- if you look in the mirror and see Hugh Downs, go to a rave and find out
for yorself, okay old timer?
 okay enough of that.

I've been to many 'commercial' 'above ground' concert and dance events.
And you know what?  A lot of them _depend_ on vendors selling alcoholic
beverages to make a good profit.  I've seen drunk folks falling over
chairs, getting into fistfights and (I think this is worst of all)
staggering into their cars and DUI-ing it home.  These events are havens
for drunken violence and sex.  I think that a bunch of raver folks should
do a video 'news report' about these horrible events.  I can see it now,
"Do you know where your parents are?!  They may be at local Karaoke
clubs!"  We could show people drunk and slobbering over a microphone, old
messed up men picking up on someone's mom... it would be a real hoot!

Now, one other thing.  I'd like to know how much that one woman knows
about MDMA toxicology.  I too have looked at quite a bit of data on the
substance and have not seen evidence that it causes people to heat up to
107+ degrees F.  I'd also like to know what motivated the doctor/coroner
to declare MDMA as the cause of death.

Don't spend energy to negate it! Catch it's energy and find a flow. Use it
as an amplifier for your own creativity. Change what you do, and let it
shape you. Use it's energy to your advantage. It won't be easy, and it will
take discipline. Talk about it. Then think about it. But don't use your
energy to fight it. Grab ahold of that energy and channel it into something
good.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jan 24 23:32:09 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id XAA11678; Fri, 24 Jan 1997 23:32:09 -0800 (PST)
Received: from host.domain.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id XAA11670; Fri, 24 Jan 1997 23:32:02 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [157.22.222.52] (x.domain.net [157.22.222.52]) by host.domain.net (8.7.5/8.6.12) with ESMTP id XAA27837; Fri, 24 Jan 1997 23:31:57 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v03007803af0f6767385c@[157.22.222.52]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 24 Jan 1997 23:31:54 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@club.net>
Subject: Let's thank 20/20 for a job well done!
Cc: socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

You don't realize it, but 20/20 did all of us a HUGE favor!

Consider them a part of our ecosystem. Now consider the notion of an
ecosystem in balance.

In that balance there are many factors, all pulling at each other, and once
stabilized, the ecosystem finds harmony.

Some of the components that exist our ecosystem could be: Cool new types of
music, fresh attitudes, exciting teachers (i.e. drugs), new places to
celebrate, and new faces to meet. Those are all attractors. Now other
components of our ecosystem could be: negative media coverage, law
enforcement attention, city council resolutions, bad people flooding the
scene, and exploitive greed. Those are detractors. These two sides push and
pull against each other, and, at some point, a balance occurs.

Did any of you out there feel like things have been getting just a little
bit out of control lately? Have parties been just a little too big and out
of control? Are there more and more on the SFR calendar you just couldn't
stomach going to? I sure have been noticing this!

Part of what makes our community great is vibe. Part of what makes the vibe
is dedication. Dedication proves itself when the going gets tough. When the
party's not promoted. When there are wild goose chases to find phone
numbers for elusive info lines. When we're scrambling in the middle of the
night to find the secret map point. To actually find the party and the end
of a long windy road! (I specifically site the Harmony party in the
Milpitas hills a perfect example of that!)

That difficulity in "consuming" parties, in turn, filters out exactly
what's causing the critical stress on our ecosystem! Too many of these "new
school" events are just too accessible. Accessible by anyone that picks up
any number of huge, fold-out multi-page flyers from any one of 10,000
stores, schools, shopping centers, grocery stores, malls, gas stations,
etc. in a multi-hundred mile areas where they have been dumped!

You get my point -- it's just too easy! It's the process of turning a party
from a group of friends around the camp fire into a rock concert!

The simple accessibility of these parties are exactly the thing causes
people-in-mass to jump headfirst into what can be dangerous territory.
These are the parties attracting thousands of people who don't have or know
"rave ideals". Too many of these people being attracted to these parties
are just wanting to go out to find a place to get "fucked up on a Friday
night," and there are too many of them to lead by example!

That kind of mass-adoption for the wrong reason will ultimately dilute the
collective experience, and the magic that is raving. That will dilute our
gene pool!

Parties are not meant to be huge, expensive affairs! For my first six
months of raving, I never even went to a party that had a flyer. These were
parties being planned by friends for their friends. They actually called
and invited each other to the party. It was PURE! It was REAL! I was
adopted into a group of cells, a living organism, that was inspiring. That
was a teacher, that was beautiful. I was able to learn by the example of
the many, and at some point I became one with the cell.

With that in mind, I have to say "Thanks, 20/20 -- thanks for a job well done!"

You have acted as a governor in our ecosystem which, in turn, could be just
the component that enables the longevity of our species.

You've unknowingly helped us with that which we could not do on our own.

You've helped us keep our gene pool true and pure. You've turned the clock
back to where *we* get to choose who and when people should be brought into
our beautiful world, and at what rate, to ensure that the real message of
raving will not be lost on new members. To ensure that people understand
that a rave is not something you pay to attend to be entertained. To ensure
that people trickle in at a rate that they feel involved as a participant,
not as a consumer! You've helped us to hopefully create and sustain an
ecosystem where the boundaries between "promoter", "DJ" and "raver" will
become fuzzy or dissolve, which will allow all of us to hopefully be all
three and more!

Thanks again!

the underground

something good.

Precedence: bulk


 
> Now, one other thing.  I'd like to know how much that one woman knows
> about MDMA toxicology.  I too have looked at quite a bit of data on the
> substance and have not seen evidence that it causes people to heat up to
> 107+ degrees F.  I'd also like to know what motivated the doctor/coroner
> to declare MDMA as the cause of death.

	While E itself wouldn't cause that kind of heat, there is
pretty good evidence which suggests that E does screw up your ability 
to notice that you are overheating, if you happen to overheat for some 
other reason. If it was hot in your environment, you might get up to 104 
or so & not feel it if you're E-ing. So you may not take the normal actions 
to cool down that you would without the drug. Check out the E page on 
hyperreal.com for more on this. Anyway, if you're going to do E, please 
stay conscious of your body temperature, especially if you're raving in 
Galactic Sweatlodges or in Florida during the hot humid summer.

You don't realize it, but 20/20 did all of us a HUGE favor!

Consider them a part of our ecosystem. Now consider the notion of an
ecosystem in balance.

In that balance there are many factors, all pulling at each other, and once
stabilized, the ecosystem finds harmony.

Some of the components that exist our ecosystem could be: Cool new types of
music, fresh attitudes, exciting teachers (i.e. drugs), new places to
celebrate, and new faces to meet. Those are all attractors. Now other
components of our ecosystem could be: negative media coverage, law
enforcement attention, city council resolutions, bad people flooding the
scene, and exploitive greed. Those are detractors. These two sides push and
pull against each other, and, at some point, a balance occurs.

Did any of you out there feel like things have been getting just a little
bit out of control lately? Have parties been just a little too big and out
of control? Are there more and more on the SFR calendar you just couldn't
stomach going to? I sure have been noticing this!

Part of what makes our community great is vibe. Part of what makes the vibe
is dedication. Dedication proves itself when the going gets tough. When the
party's not promoted. When there are wild goose chases to find phone
numbers for elusive info lines. When we're scrambling in the middle of the
night to find the secret map point. To actually find the party and the end
of a long windy road! (I specifically site the Harmony party in the
Milpitas hills a perfect example of that!)

That difficulity in "consuming" parties, in turn, filters out exactly
what's causing the critical stress on our ecosystem! Too many of these "new
school" events are just too accessible. Accessible by anyone that picks up
any number of huge, fold-out multi-page flyers from any one of 10,000
stores, schools, shopping centers, grocery stores, malls, gas stations,
etc. in a multi-hundred mile areas where they have been dumped!

You get my point -- it's just too easy! It's the process of turning a party
from a group of friends around the camp fire into a rock concert!

The simple accessibility of these parties are exactly the thing causes
people-in-mass to jump headfirst into what can be dangerous territory.
These are the parties attracting thousands of people who don't have or know
"rave ideals". Too many of these people being attracted to these parties
are just wanting to go out to find a place to get "fucked up on a Friday
night," and there are too many of them to lead by example!

That kind of mass-adoption for the wrong reason will ultimately dilute the
collective experience, and the magic that is raving. That will dilute our

Parties are not meant to be huge, expensive affairs! For my first six
months of raving, I never even went to a party that had a flyer. These were
parties being planned by friends for their friends. They actually called
and invited each other to the party. It was PURE! It was REAL! I was
adopted into a group of cells, a living organism, that was inspiring. That
was a teacher, that was beautiful. I was able to learn by the example of
the many, and at some point I became one with the cell.

With that in mind, I have to say "Thanks, 20/20 -- thanks for a job well done!"

You have acted as a governor in our ecosystem which, in turn, could be just
the component that enables the longevity of our species.

You've unknowingly helped us with that which we could not do on our own.

You've helped us keep our gene pool true and pure. You've turned the clock
back to where *we* get to choose who and when people should be brought into
our beautiful world, and at what rate, to ensure that the real message of
raving will not be lost on new members. To ensure that people understand
that a rave is not something you pay to attend to be entertained. To ensure
that people trickle in at a rate that they feel involved as a participant,
not as a consumer! You've helped us to hopefully create and sustain an
ecosystem where the boundaries between "promoter", "DJ" and "raver" will
become fuzzy or dissolve, which will allow all of us to hopefully be all
three and more!

Thanks again!

the underground

I can state several occasions where they had false statements. 

1) E solely caused the girl to overheat.  It was the girl's ignorance that
got her there.  If you know how to use E properly you would make sure that
you will have enough liquids and enough rest every once in a while while you
are high.  

2) E is rarely laced with heroin since heroin is already expensive as it is.
The addictive effects of this opiate can only be gained thru intravenous
injection or if you have taken too much of it at one time.  I doubt that
that kind of dose would be present in that kind of preparation.

3) I rarely see Ketamine being used in the dance scene since K will often
immobilize you while you trip on it.  

4) Being sober at a rave doesn't make you stick out like a sore thumb....  I
have raved soberr a lot of times and I don't think I stuck out like a sore
thumb and I do admire people who can enjoy the vibe sober. 

5) 20/20 featured a dance concert not a rave!  There is no such thing as an
underground party being attended by kids from 8 different states.

6) They said that we don't want to take our parents to a rave.  Not true,  I
have friends who have taken their parents to a rave so that both parents and
children could enjoy the vibe.  

>Don't live in denial!
>
We are not.  The media is pushing on enforcing a ban on raves.  Don't you
see it coming?

>Rather, come to terms with the public opinion and integrate it into what
>you do. Go underground, be small, be respectful! The chaos theory will
>prevail. Our parties will happen! It would be impossible for them *not* to
>happen! Just change your course and make it so!
>
>

I have to agree with you here.  We need to live up to the definition of a
rave.  From the PLUR to being small and underground we need to get back to
the basics, boycott the big party promoters.

Hi,

I agree there were errors in specifics, but don't even bother arguing
specifics. They are communicating with generalizations and you are arguing
specifics.

Yes, they said E caused a body to overheat, etc.

That's not the point. Either are any of the other details, i.e. laced w/
heroin.

What is true is:

	Raves exist.

	They are "secret" places that lots of kids go to do drugs.

	They often last all night.

Your personal experience may vary, as mine does, but the *general*
communication from 20/20 was correct.

Repeat: I am *not* defending yellow journalism, I am merely pointing out
that we have very little to gain by debating what drugs may be used to cut
what drugs and whether the drugs caused a death or not or whatever. Once
20/20 has extablished that you are doing something wrong, you are simply
arguing how much wrong or how little wrong you are doing. You will never
not be wrong. Get it?

The principal but not-quite-actually-spoken issue here is that America is
concerned about a bunch of their future taxpayers are out getting high when
they are supposed to be home in bed so they can get up early and go to
school to learn how to be good worker bees in society when they grow up.
Loved up free thinkers (or dead thinkers, in the case of an OD'ed raver)
are not necessarily good for society. Too many artists and not enough
factory workers, ditch diggers, soldiers and CPAs could damage the status
quo, and, of course, that's not good for the good old U S of A. That's not
my opinion, that's America's opinion.

With that established, for you to then try to deconstruct their concern
with "I am sure there's no heroin in my illegal drugs" you are not even
having the same debate.

  I think that the idea of writing numerous letters, e-mail, etc. etc. is
 a great way to: get your anger out. But, as pointed out to me the only
way to handle all this shit that we have seen and will continue to see
about our beloved rave scene is *to just ignore it!!!!* These people
that you are writing to* do not care*. They will only find someway to
exploit what you have put alot of time into saying to gain more ratings!
You can't change someone's point of view who does not want to change or
make another person understand if they don't want to understand. Just
please ignore it all;what you see on t.v., in magazines. We know what the
truth is, why do we have to prove it to those who are ignorant?!
                            love-
	                  Reagan			








On Sat, 25 Jan 1997, Libby Bundsen wrote:

> I just watched the 20/20 show on raves with my mom and one of her
> friends.  Afterwards, I started going off on how I wanted to bombard
> 20/20 with nasty letters.  My mom's friend made the point that journalism
> will always be sensational; it's a business.  We couldn't really sue them
> for fraud, or anything like that.  He did have a really good suggestion
> on how to get heard.
> 
> He said that it's not the tv show, nor the producer that we should write
> to, but the ADVERTISERS.  We should write to all the companies who
> endorsed this show (I know a lot of us taped this episode) and threaten
> to boycot their products.  We should tell them we have no respect for
> 20/20's biased and overly-sensationalized spin on the rave scene.
> 
> So, I suggest that we write to all these advertisers and make a point to
> explain our scene's positivity.  We've been slandered by the media
> (again).  It's time we make an honest effort to bring our side of the
> story to light.  We need to let the advertisers know that we don't agree
> with 20/20's views, nor will we patronize any company that chooses to
> support them.
> 
> Is anyone with me on this?
> 
> ---Libby Rose

Well, well, well, you know how sooner or later everyone has one of thoes
nights that was just plain wrong? The oh-why-the-hell-aren't-I-in-bed
kind of night? 

I think I just had my first.

Galctic Tunnel started out innocently enough: your kosher F-8 map point.
'The spot' on Stevenson (Whats this about it being the 'new Acme'??).
Cought all of Minor-Minor's set (mail me man!), then while chilling
downstairs in the basment, everything gets real quiet. Whats going on?
The poliece are upstaris and the organizers locked the door to dowstairs
to hide that half of the party from being searched. Everyones
whispering, wondering what the heck is going on. Then about 10 min
later, everyone downstaris is given the word to start going out the
back, through the furniture(sp) store. But ofcource my jacket is
upstairs still which is being picked to the bone by the boys in blue. It
was disgusting, they tore apart backpacks tossing the contents around
the room, and a few people were cought with chemicals on hand. Hope had
a few things missing after her stuff was 'inspected'. Myself and about 4
other people make our way to the 24hr Carls Jr. through the POURING rain
and ofcource most everyone from the party is there, giving the midnight
shift crew more work then the they can handle. At first we hear the cops
aren't leaving untill 6am. Not! They're out by 3. Most people come back
and the music goes back up. My jacket is nowhere in sight and neither
are my keys. Not cool. Then the landlord, who I guess also ran the
furniture store and wasn't too keen on having about 20 ravers going
through their place. Comes up and kills the music. The remaining people
plop in one room and try to make the most of 420. I go back to my car.
The ticket I see on it doesn't disturb me. At this point, why the hell
not?

-=Pengo=-
Blake "Pengo" Merriam
Total Entertainment Network
WWW.TEN.NET

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

[Warning] Heartfelt ramble below...proceed with caution....

Yes the media makes me sick. They have taken a culture in which I find
enlightenment, peace, and security and have exposed it to the public as a
sick, drug-infested cult.

In the last year Hard Copy bashed LA desert raves, Leeza showed us off as a
bunch of clowns, and 7th Heaven was portrayed on the news as a riot waiting
to happen......

I have heard nothing but negative comments about raves from those "normal"
people that I associate with. These people get their info from the
mainstream media. I have gotten into numerous discussions with them, but
have not been able to instill in them an ounce of decency about the rave
scene.

When I think back to the Leeza show. I think how silly we must have come
off to the public. A good half of the audience was fully decked out in the
most socially-obnoxious apparell you could find. It angers me that when I
spoke to the producer beforehand he assured me that both sides of the issue
would be presented and discussed. Uhhh...yeah...right.

I'm not criticizing anyone. It is just obvious to me that nobody in the
mainstream public will take us seriously with the image we project.

And when I think about what's really going on from my "conservative" side,
I become afraid.

 Yes:

   "raves" allow young kids to stay up all night and take drugs.
   "raves" on many occasions make kids lie to their parents
   "raves" often require these kids to drive long
           distances to secluded locations.
   "raves" can seriously tax your mind, body, and pocketbook

I know the media tends to focus in on these issues, but if you were a
conservative parent wouldn't you rather be warned of the dangers these
"raves" introduce to your children. Shit who cares about spirituality if
I'm slaving away at a 9-5 job just so I can put food on the table and send
my kids to school where I hope they're getting an education and not doing
drugs.

Think about it....none of us pays their salaries. There are a few of us who
have the ability to function in Corporate America, but that's not much of a
voice. I believe that by associating with the rave movement we must also
accept the fact that we will probably never be understood, and we will
continue to be put up on public display as a bunch of freaks. There is only
so much we can do...SFR-legal has the right idea. We can make the system
work for us, but we will never get Joe "necktie" Smith to think that
"raves" are a good thing.

Let the media go. Let's concentrate on taking care of ourselves and getting
our scene more underground where it belongs.

Enough babble....and yes Terry is becoming much more cynical......I guess
age and experience can sometimes do that you ya.

love, energy, and viberations,

Terry


-------------------------------------Terry Estioko-----
    ctdzine@cyborganic.net         619.214.7499
      http://www.cyborganic.com/people/ctdzine
"In order to find your mind, you have to lose it first"

Subject: my letter to 20/20 Fwd: Raves
