Precedence: bulk

hey everyone,
    here is the letter that i sent to 20/20 in regards to their rave report.

PLUR,

dorena
---------------------
Forwarded message:
Subj:    Raves
Date:    97-01-24 00:26:55 EST
From:    Dorena B
To:      2020@abc.com

Dear 2020,
     My name is Dorena C. Bernabe and I am from San Jose, California. I'm 21
yrs old and I go to school and work full-time. I am also a full-time raver
     I started raving 3 yrs ago, because of my love of house music and of
people. I was tired of going to clubs that were like meat markets. I was also
tired of the violence that could errupt at anytime in clubs because of mass
alcohol consumption. In the rave scene, I found a place where i could just
have a good time. I was able to dance all night without being hassled by
drunken men or anyone else. I raved because of the positive vibe that was
present. 
     I won't deny that there are drugs in the scene. But, i will say that
true ravers don't need drugs to have a good time. We have fun whether we are
sober or we are on Ecstasy or any other drug. you don't stick out like a sore
thumb if you are not on drugs ar a rave. The only way you stick out, is if
you have a negative attitude. If you rave just for the drugs, then you are
raving for the wrong reasons. Raving is all about PLUR. PLUR stands for
Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect.  
     I won't deny that I do drugs on occasion, but that isn't the reason why
I rave. If I were in it just for the drugs, I would have burned out a long
time ago. Drugs get old fast. I rave because I love house music and I love to
dance. When I have been grooving for close to 6 hours to some good house
beats, I feel uplifted. House music is like the gospel to me. When I listen
and dance to it, it's tremendously religious. i experience inner peace when I
am raving. I know that a lot of kids that rave feel the exact same way I do.
We rave because we love the music and we love our scene. 
    I am livid that your report is going to cast raving in a very negative
light. You never look for the positivity that makes raving what it is. Your
report is misinforming the general public about our scene. The drugs don't
factor into the experience. If you wanted to know about raving, then you
should have gone to some real raves and looked for real ravers. They would
tell you what it is all about. It's about PLUR.  
     If you decide to do a follow up piece to your report, I would be more
than happy to participate in it. Here is my addres and my phone number:
Dorena C. Bernabe
2595 Glen Alma Way
San Jose, CA. 95148
(408) 238-4205

Sincerely,

Dorena C. Bernabe
Right Front Speaker Family San Francisco

> 
> I'm not criticizing anyone. It is just obvious to me that nobody in the
> mainstream public will take us seriously with the image we project.

bout time we got our double breasted suits out and slicked our hair back 
so we look presentable to the media.

> 
> And when I think about what's really going on from my "conservative" side,
> I become afraid.
> 
>  Yes:
> 
>    "raves" allow young kids to stay up all night and take drugs.
i stayed out all night and took drugs before there were raves.  what 
makes anyone think they wouldn't do it anyway?  why not make a safe 
environment and educate people about substances and astral and physical 
side-effects?
>    "raves" on many occasions make kids lie to their parents
true.  but a lot of parents lie to their kids, too.  whoever started that 
rumor that people don't lie, well, they lied!

>    "raves" often require these kids to drive long
>            distances to secluded locations.
in the mountains of peru, people come from all over the area to take part 
in shamanistic rituals where they ingest psychedelic plants to touch the 
gods.  when i used to go to full moons, i would drive long distances, but 
it placed a value on the whole experience.  

>    "raves" can seriously tax your mind, body, and pocketbook

yes.  that is true.  but $40 or $50 in one night is average to spend, in 
fact even cheap compared to other people that go to weekend outings.  

> 
> I know the media tends to focus in on these issues, but if you were a
> conservative parent wouldn't you rather be warned of the dangers these
> "raves" introduce to your children. Shit who cares about spirituality if
> I'm slaving away at a 9-5 job just so I can put food on the table and send
> my kids to school where I hope they're getting an education and not doing
> drugs.

well, that's an important thing to remember.  most people don't care 
about the end result.  they are people who have an "instant breakfast" 
mentality and only look at the first layer of an issue.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Jan 25 15:20:48 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id PAA16050; Sat, 25 Jan 1997 15:20:48 -0800 (PST)

X-Sender: randream@si.UCSC.EDU
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>, Is it Trance? <604@party.net>,
        Know 1 <knowoneness-l@teleport.com>
Subject: GaiaMind/review
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.970125144043.23457A-100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



 Hi all!  ]=)

 Turbulent is a word that comes to mind for me on this event. The 
location was moved to the Somar Art Gallery at the last minute. Luckily 
Galena (from Galactic Dreamspell) was still at the old location to inform us 
and give us directions.

 And by the by; HUGE THANKS to Rebbeca for the lift to and from the 
event. This girl is the most special person! Her heart is so big!

 The party was supposed to be at the galactic sweatlodge but was moved. 
This was both good and bad. Good as I learned that the police have been 
notified that there are illegal parties happening there. Apparently they 
were notified by Thomas Trouble who did it in retaliation for the russian 
boys, who ran the place, stealing money at the door and the mappoint.

 It was bad as there is no sound seperation in the Somar. The back room 
has a wall, but it only goes about 10 feet up and then there is nothing 
but a black curtain between it and the backstage area (where I had set up 
shop for the chill room). Between the main stage and the chill room there 
was only a curtain.

 I think that Adam's observation that the chill room sounded like an 
Amtrack railstation was very conservative. It was, without a doubt, the 
noisest chill room I have ever been in. (that is why Im calling it a 
chill room instead of an ambient room.

 I got to play with Seofon and Daniel from the Ambient Temple of 
I*Madgi*Nation. Great fun!

 On the mainstage I caught Andiamo (sp?), a tight, well rehearsed three 
piece band. Sort of like Primus meets Phish. They were fun and I enjoyed 
dancing to them.

 Galactic Dreamspell was kinda like a pagan sideshow. They wern't bad but 
not that interesting to me. Watching the firedancers was fun; I could 
smell the scoarched hair on one girls body as she allowed the flames to 
continously carress her. It seemed silly that they were wearing bra's and 
not naked.

 The sound system in the main stage area was pretty wimpy. One speaker 
was crackling all night and the sound just wasn't strong enough to fill 
the room well. I didn't catch the psi-trance DJ's all that much.  :(

 The jungle room was well equipped for sound thanks to Gateway (although 
as the bass waves from there rolled through the chill room, I was starting 
to hate Gateway's four 18 inch drivers), but it was too bright in there. 
Lots of floor lamps in a white room. Ugh. Big thanks to Rob for helping 
us get some decent speakers in the chill room.

 I have only two really serious complaints about the party. One obviously 
was the space for the chill room. I was given the choice of that or 
outside near the freeway in a trash filled patio, where it might rain. No 
tarp was forthcoming and it was a bit cool so I opted for the noisy but 
warm experience.

 The other was that a 100 foot extension cord of mine disappeared. 
Throughout the night various people wanted to (as usual) borrow equipment 
from me. I don't like to do this as I don't feel like trying to collect 
my equipment from tired, burnt out ravers in the early am. I'm usually 
too tired and burnt to remember what all I leant out and usually to busy 
to make a list.

 Well a certain girl, who was caught taking fluro-banners that didn't 
belong to her (from the Samhain party near Yosomite), was given my cord by 
the person who borrowed it. And gee she just seemed to have forgotten 
where it went to. Not only that but she didn't try to find or even say 
she was sorry (fucking bitch!). This slacker only goes to parties (early) 
to hang out and take advantage. Apparently she is stealing to support 
herself (she has no home or job). Most folks in the trance community in 
SF know who she is. I can give her name to any who wish it. Just email me.

 Also I leant out equipment to Gateway and had to locate it, claim it, 
roll up my cables and strip the duct tape off of them.

 So thanks to the irresponsible nature of most ravers I am no longer 
lending anything to anybody.

 On the plus side the event was good for drawing attention and raising 
funds for the Headwaters purchase plan. There was also a nice diverse 
crowd there.


peas,


Ran D.Dreams



                                      (Namaste)

I'm thinking of heading out to Meridian tonight...the clubhouse mixes the dj 
spun at my house last night just teased me, I kept wishing for it to get 
deeper and more real...but of course not.  And a hometown boy is spinning 
at Meridian, Sati of Berkeley.  Wanna dance!!

But all the negativity swirling around our scene (from outside sources, 
of course) is filling me with a bad omen about tonight.  Media hysteria, 
cops swooping on every party in Oakland, and even SF clamping down on 
Stevenson Alley, after a couple of months of parties there...

I still don't get it...WHAT exactly is the problem with a crowd of 
peaceful people wanting to dance all night in a private location?  

Hope to see some of you out there tonight - and a hopeful wish that our 
parties will be allowed to go on...(and I know wishing is not enough).

N

------------------------------------------------------------

     ABC NEWS "20/20" REPORTS ON "RAVES," UNSUPERVISED ALL-NIGHT DANCE
               PARTIES WHICH HAVE BECOME POPULAR, FRIDAY, JAN. 24 

     "Raves," an underground movement which gathers large numbers of young
people at secret locations for all-night dance parties, have become
popular in recent years. But beneath the laser lights and loud music, are
America's youth rebelling in a new and dangerous way, including the
widespread use of drugs? Lynn Sherr reports on ABC News "20/20," FRIDAY,
JAN. 24 (10:00-11:00 p.m., ET), on the ABC Television Network. 

     Raves, which are not supervised by adults, take place throughout the
country, including large cities and small towns, in farm fields and
abandoned warehouses or in after-hour bars or clubs. Young people find out
about the events through a network of secret passwords and Internet
communications. Because raves have become a haven for drug-taking with a
dance beat, organizers are determined to keep them underground, far from
the prying eyes of police and parents. 

     "If you go to a rave and you're not on Ecstasy or some other kind of
drug," a former "raver" explains, "then you kind of stick out like a sore 
thumb. You're.... you're an endangered species."

     In addition to Ecstasy, an amphetamine-like drug which helps 
party-goers stay up all night and dance, ravers take LSD or acid, an 
hallucinogenic drug, and Special K (ketamine), an animal anesthetic which 
is snorted by users. Dr. David McDowell, a psychiatrist who has studied 
ravers drug use at the scene, says that not only are an alarming number 
of participants using them but they are often taking several at the same 
time. 

     "Over seventy percent of the kids said they were on drugs," Dr. 
McDowell said. "The peer pressure to take these drugs in this environment 
is just profoundly strong. Many of these drugs are addicting and many of 
them have terrible side effects and can lead to tremendous devastation, 
both personally and biologically down the road." 

     For college student Sandy Montesi, who attended a 1992 rave in 
Orlando, Florida, the results were fatal and devastating to her family. 
The previously healthy young woman suffered a massive heart attack from a 
temperature which soared to 107 degrees before her death. Her mother was 
told that the temperature was brought on by the drug Ecstasy. 

     After her daughter died, Marsha Montesi learned that the 
establishment which held the rave Sandy attended had been visited by 
police 500 times in the two previous years, often to deal with drug 
activity. Through her grief, she helped enact a local ordinance to close 
such places down and had the dealer who supplied the Ecstasy which killed 
her daughter put in prison for manslaughter. 

     "We need to stop the raves," Mrs. Montesi says. "It's not a dance, 
it's not a safe place for your kids. Do anything. If your child insists, 
go with them and then you'll find out. Your child doesn't want you there 
because they know what is really going on." 

------------------------------------------------------------------------
(EOF)

He has *another* new CD out called "Agents with False Memories", which is
much more mellow and is basically one long freaky distortion-laden hip hop
track with hundreds of vocal samples laid on top.  One of them I
recognized as a distant friend, actually, both from the voice and the
situation being described.  Quite good, though hard to find.  Dave Stein
at Ear-Rational can get it.

On Sat, 25 Jan 1997 alchemist@internity.on.ca wrote:

> debbie a. trotter wrote:

> ...or "stop the raves!"

> citizens", so its more effective propoganda in  going for the jugular of
> the concerned ignorant portions of our society...

<SNIP>

Okay, you have to admit that the whole Rave scene is a middle-class
suburban based movement.  It has it's roots (in the USofA) in teh House
music of Chicago mixing with the breakdace styles and then culminating in
the inner city in Detroit, but the Rave scene has been a middle class
suburban movement for a long time now.  I think this is part of the reason
why many inner city kids feel alienated by the Rave scene and do not
participate in it.  Much like the jazz scene, techno has changed a great
deal and become more distanced from the people it started with.  So,
talking with suburbanites is not wrong.  Did anyone notice that none of
the people on that panel were African American?  I think this kind of lack
of representation is more of an issue...

PLUR

In Southern California, cops are constantly searching people without
warrants, good cause, etc..  It was part of growing up, if you were at
all adventurous or a partier.  It sucks.  Let's not give them too many 
reasons to bust us.  If it's true that Thomas Trouble had this party busted
that's basically a betrayal of our scene, in my opinion.  I mean to fuck
over a bunch of happy ravers because of some personal revenge motives.
I really hope it's not true.  I hope he reads this and responds.

Yeah, cops are dickheads, that's just a given...  But every week at least 2 or
3 smaller underground type parties go off without a hitch.  If "they" were
really out to get us, they just could go to Housewares and pick up flyers,
or subscribe to sf-raves, and bust every single party.  Obviously someone
had to call "them".

What we may have here is (in programming terms)  !(PLUR)
! is a c++ symbol for NOT or Negation or Opposite.  But I digress...

much love...
Bruce

> Okay, you have to admit that the whole Rave scene is a middle-class
> suburban based movement.  It has it's roots (in the USofA) in teh House
> music of Chicago mixing with the breakdace styles and then culminating in
> the inner city in Detroit, but the Rave scene has been a middle class
> suburban movement for a long time now.  I think this is part of the reason
> why many inner city kids feel alienated by the Rave scene and do not
> participate in it.  Much like the jazz scene, techno has changed a great
> deal and become more distanced from the people it started with.  So,
> talking with suburbanites is not wrong.  Did anyone notice that none of
> the people on that panel were African American?  I think this kind of lack
> of representation is more of an issue...
> 


although many of my friends are from the suburbs as so am i, out east
the rave scene is from within as much as it is from without... i am not
as distanced from the people that started it (i live 2 hrs from detroit,
6 or so from chicago)... the influence is inherent...

dave

>  Speaking of disco's, at the end of the 20/20 report someone posed the
> question 'how is this diffrent from the disco scene of the 70's?' and

> designer drugs(nevermind that e was made in 1908... not very new <-- added

may i reiterate the repeating patterns of psychedelic corruption... 

the sixties ended with the speed freaks, and then came the reds, blues,
barbs, yellow jackets.... so on and so forth...

rave started with mdma, then it became exstacy and now we have "E"'s
that sound like comic book superheroes... red rockets, white lightnings,
cherry bomb FX... out east we had a meth (speed) wave of abuse followed
by the downer of heroin cut e's... it's the same cycle repeating... and
hey, with the level of commercialism, we might as well be disco at this
point... keep in mind that the underground will always remain
formless...

dave

On Sat, 25 Jan 1997, Manoj Matthew wrote:

> On Sat, 25 Jan 1997, Randy C Cone wrote:
> > 
> >  Well a certain girl, who was caught taking fluro-banners that didn't 
> > belong to her (from the Samhain party near Yosomite), was given my cord by 
> > the person who borrowed it. And gee she just seemed to have forgotten 
> > where it went to. Not only that but she didn't try to find or even say 
> > she was sorry (fucking bitch!). This slacker only goes to parties (early) 
> > to hang out and take advantage. Apparently she is stealing to support 
> > herself (she has no home or job). Most folks in the trance community in 
> > SF know who she is. I can give her name to any who wish it. Just email me.
> > 
>         I can only say that whatever experience you encounter is created
> by you for your own upliftment.

 As a person who realises that our 3-dimensional minds only seem to be 
able to comprehend 3-dimensions, I always take a grain of salt with 
advice like this. Most people can't remember what they had for dinner 
three nights ago, let alone know extra-dimensional realities. However I 
do accept the possibility of your beliefs and appreciate the compassion 
within them.



>  I sense that you aren't really
> understanding the lesson but rather reacting to the experience.

 Well there is a lot to learn and a lot to react to. Usually when someone 
hurts me that way it takes a few days for me to learn/gain something from 
it. 


>  As for
> the young lady

 She ain't no lady.



> that you are accusing/condemning,

 She was caught stealing banners. She refused to help me find a cord she 
had been entrusted with. She didn't apologise. Those arn't accusations, 
they are facts. I'm not condemning her. I'm warning people she can not be 
trusted. I'm not the only person to make this observation.


> I hope you might possibly
> realize that she is as much part of the Isness as you are.

 Maybe we are, maybe we are not. Maintaing ANY spiritual belief as true 
is as arroagant (sp?) as anyone who doesn't believe in a spiritual 
reality. We just don't know for certain either way.



>  And as you
> condemn her, you condemn youself.

 Perhaps.


>  It is a lesson I still struggle with
> myself...  Put out only that which you wish to receive.

 Tell that to the Jews who died in Nazi death camps. Or the natives in SO 
many countries who have been butchered by invading armies and settlers.



>  Karma is a real thing that
> functions outside the realm of personal retribution...   

 I have no intrest in retribution. I only want people like her to stop 
hurting the scene. I can't afford to be ripped off. I don't make enough 
money at these parties to replace stolen/lost equipment.

 While I appreciate the compassion in your message Manoj, the attitude 
that everything is okay/it's just a lesson is lame. If you take it far 
enough then what I did/am doing is okay also. It's just a lesson.

> In Lak'esh

likewise,



Ran D.Dreams

To: Sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: funny part
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com

No, the FUNNIEST part of it was when they interviewed all those K-snortin'
East Coast "wavers" and the woman asked them about Ecstacy and one of the
kids replied "If we gave you a hit of Ecstasy right now I GUARANTEE you'd
want another!" 
Humor. Straight up Humor.
Wayne is right.  20/20 got the gist of what goes on at parties without
distorting the truth too much.  It was probably the most acurate report I've
ever seen a news organization do on parties....The REAL problem is the
irresponsible people like the promoter/drug dealer in the parking lot and the
two girls showing off the acid tabs on their tongues. We need to take more
responsibility for what we do.  The majority of the reactions to the segment
that I've seen here on SFR don't echo this sentiment unfortunately.
Don't worry people. We needed this, I'm positive of it. We need to take it
back to the essence because I think we started getting too big for our own
britches....anyways, the collective American memory span is exceedingly short
so I wouldnt expect any negative fallout to last long.
--Monty

(old mail day)

If someone attempts to send a message to SFRaves and yet are not
subscribers to the sfraves list, the majordomo software bounces it to me
personally, and then I make a decision as to whether to forward it along
or not.  There have been lots and lots of make-money-fast spams and Hey-
I'll-post-to-every-rave-mailing-list nonsense which I have not forwarded. 
Sometimes it gets caught if someone's email address has changed slightly,
in which case I'll add their address to an "exceptions" file and redirect
it back to the list instead of straight forwarding.  So,
CRYSTLMTHD@aol.com isn't a subscriber to the list, so I had to forward it. 

Sometimes I don't get around to going through bounced messages for two
weeks at a time....

	Brian

having.
He did that because of his personal revenge. He was getting half of our
money, just him, for letting us borrow his shitty sound system, which would
overheat in the middle of the party and all the ravers would have to wait for
an hour for it to cool off.
He wasn't helping us at all, and he was using us to sell his fucking E at our
parties. Our parties are not about drugs we just wanted to present our music
to people. TT was using us and we broke up with him because of that. He got
mad because he couldn't use us anymore., so he threatened to kill us all
(bunch of bullshit).
he spread a bad word about us, so people wouldn't go to our parties anymore.
Thomas Trouble is not about music, he is all about money and drugs, and
people like that shouldn't have anymore parties, which he won't have for a
long time.......

 Hi all!  ]=)


 First off I would like to thank all those who have taken the time to 
respond to my post, in particular witht the regards to the missing cable. 
I feel I need to explain a bit what I was doing with my post.

 Most of us are familiar with the saying, "the squeaky wheel gets the 
grease", and what that refers to. In my post I was "squeaking" so that 
one, I could expell some bad feelings, warn some people about this person 
and hopefully force something to happen that would cause this person to 
at least acknowledge if not return my cable.

 Well something worked. I recieved a call that told me that the person 
involved had apparently "found" the "lost" cable. Not only am I glad to 
get the cable back, but more importantly that the person responsible for 
"losing" it returned it. This is a person that I poured a lot of love into 
just after she got out of an abusive relationship. We had started to 
drift apart prior to the holiday season, yet I made an effort to give her 
a holiday gift (that I made) so that she would know we (hopefully) were 
still friends.

 I was very hurt by her treatment of me at GaiaMind and I am very happy 
that the situation has resolved itself in the way it has.

 On a very happy note I have learned that we raised about a thousand 
dollars at that party for the Headwaters purchase. Considering that only 
$7 was charged at the door, I feel that is a considerable amount of 
money. In addition there was many connections made and consciousness 
raised on the issue.

 Biggest thanks to those that came out to support the cause! =) I would 
like to personally thank the folks who helped me; Rebecca, Martin, 
Leonardo, Graham, and the Gateway crew with audio support. Thanks to N8 
for trying!!

peas,


Ran D.Dreams

  Tomorrow being my little sister's birthday, we had the relatives over for
dinner.  Somehow the topic of flyer/house parties came into the conversation,
and that led to raves.  My grandmother had seen the 20/20 special and put
 her absolute faith in Barbara Walters.  Much to my dismay, she had her mind
set that raves are the stereotypical sex and drug fests.  After two hours of
arguing, I have enlightened her a little more on the subject of all night
parties, but have failed to sway her opinion.  This is what news shows are
doing to our scene.  I have very little effect on older people about this
topic due to my age.  I hate to bring up my age so much, but it's true.  Now
what do I do?  <sigh>  Oh well, it turns out I might go to Love-a-fair after
all. 

       hugs,
          'trice                        <<<<RAVEON>>>>

 Added note.... if anyone happens to be near Market and Castro on the first,
stop into the gauntlet and watch me get my tounge pierced.

I suggested that my parents watch the 20/10 special report
and they thought that it looked like "a shitload of fun" and
they encouraged me to go to more and to take them sometime.
They look down upon the drug usage in raves, but they like
the fact that it is about multi-racial groups sharing a common
interest in music, dancing and all out partying. They thought
that a few of the raves show must have taken alot of effort
to put together and saw it as a big accomplishment for teens
to achieve something like this. They got a big bang out of
how 20/10 always puts things way out of proportion. 

PLUR!				-Cody Kime-

hi
went to by the people last night.  pretty good space, decent crowd (a little
clubby feeling though), but the music was just ok.  i liked the Pure Science

I don't think most people are (quite) as dumb as the TV networks like to
think.  Things are changing fast, and people are losing trust in the establish-
ment.  It is true, though, that the suburbs erect a lot of walls between
people and keep them seperated(a bone-old tactic known as divide and conquer)
but at the same time there are a lot factors undoing this too, like raves.
And the 'Net, and the Simpsons ( :) ).  It all comes down to Yin and Yang
truths, really, so let's not worry too much.
Peace
Bruce

though is to buy the software. I hope anyone who reads this enjoys the 
site as much as I did!

Hello all Net Ravers, Promoters & DJ's,

of December, January, & February and further. I'm The A&R director at
Adrenalin Records in New York but I'm based in South Florida. I currently
have 9 mixed CD's out in stores all across the world and have 3 more
currently being pressed. The following are a list of the CD's:
	-Adrenalin Hardcore Rush Vol 1 
	-Adrenalin Hardcore Rush vol. 2 
	-Trip Hop Acid Phunk Vol 1

and on the press:
	-Adrenalin Trance Acid Experience 2 :In The Mix With DJ Hardware
	- Trip Hop Acid Phunk Vol 4: The Acid Breaks Edition

I Also have a 12" currently out with my partner called The tweakers - "All
Tweaked Out" On adrenalin Records, remixes of the Cotton Club, "Hear The
Drummer", and Remixes My partner and I did of Darkside Of The Shroom Part 
II, "OHZone Layer". As you can see i play a variety of
styles of music but my favorite styles to play are Hard trance and Gabber.
i also love hard edged funky breaks. If you are intrested in booking me or
know some one intrested in booking me at an event or party please have
them E-mail me or they can call Adrenalin Records at (561) 495 - 9954 or 
(561) 495 - 3919. Thanks for your time and consideration!


						DJ HARDWARE:)
					A&R Director - Adrenalin Records

not tring to SPAM the NET, I'm just using the NET as a resource to find
booking outside florida and to play to different types of ravers. If
you don't like to read this just delete it... This is part of the rave
culture.... PLUR........

Just a though here, but should we actually have the SFR Calendar online. If
you do a basic net search on RAVES, the first thing that will come up is
Hyperreal, then by clicking here and there you can get to the SFR Calendar.
It has loads of phone numbers and party info. Does this actually have to be
on the net.

I think it's great having it available like that. We all know we at some
point delete the emailed version and often have to goto SFR website to see
the calendar. But do we really need it up there.

It might be better if it was just emailed out.


Just a thought, what does everyone else think.

	Yes, my parents are very supportive of my interest the rave
	scene.  They used to be hippies and they see how it is the
	"hippism" of the 90's:  peace, love, good music, vibe...

	I tell them every time I go to a rave.  Where it is, who's
	spinning.  I've told them all about DJ DAN and how great I
	think HOMEBASE is.  I even brought them to the last SFRaves
	BBQ...they went even though it was raining. That was just their
	intro. into the rave scene.  Next I plan to take them to Love
	Afair.
					RaVe On....MHg :)

	id AA10864; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 09:28:21 -0800
X-Sender: knucklehead@mail.domain.net
Message-Id: <v03010d00af1285c4dbda@[205.231.222.64]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 27 Jan 1997 09:29:20 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: knucklehead <knucklehead@club.net>
Subject: Online rave things, clarification
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

What I was trying to get at was that by having a Calendar of events on the
web, it's easier for people such as cops and others we don't want to have
the info. They can get the list of events and then call the info line and
find out where it is and then go bust them.

With the current things happening in the scene, maybe having public
postings of info numbers and party info right on the web might not be a
good thing right now.

I know this would limit who get's the info, but it's better then giving up
info to people that are looking just to bust up a party.

I like having the calendar on the web too, but if not having it via the web
and only via email. What it slow down the bust. It's just too easy to get
the info and then go bust a party.

If they want to bust us, let make it a little harder to do it. We are
handing them the info if it's on the web. I'm not saying that we should
take it all off, just party locations, info numbers and names..etc..


Those are just thoughts.



Tim (knucklehead)

hello all-

tonight, matt officially joins the 20-something crowd by beginning his
23'rd year!  come and join me at m house tonight for a dinner celebration,
and warming of his new house.

why? 	meet people you never expected to meet!
	enjoy the atmosphere of the 9'th avenue posse hangout!
	play the "who's cell phone is that?" game!
	tease gearheads!
	AND
	help make matt's birthday a fun one!

where?	at the 9'th avenue posse hangoug
	1370 9'th avenue, between between judan and irving

when?	dinner at 8:30, but come early to chill, relax, and meet other random
individuals!

what?	all i ask is that each person or group of people coming brings some
sort of food dish (carnivorous, vegan, or vegetarian accoring to your own
personal tastes).  this is a robust solution that assures that, for any
arbitrary number of people in attendance, all will be fed somehow!  this
can be either for dinner, appetizer, or both! be creative, or be safeway.

boojee?	it depends on you, if you're feeling boojee or not.

if you haven't already, please rsvp at 415-753-2978 or e-mail back.

i look forward to seeing all of you tonight!

love to you all, and may your monday treat you wonderfully-

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jan 27 10:11:46 1997

Precedence: bulk

THE FRIGGIN' WALL STREET JOURNAL?

 Will Pulsing Techno Sound                Rev Up the Music Business?
               By PATRICK M. REILLY                 Staff Reporter of
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL

               When Tommy Tunes, Frankie Bones and Adam X
took                the stage recently at the Asbury Park, N.J.,
Convention                Hall, it didn't look like any ordinary rock
concert.
               Instead of guitars, the performers jammed on
computer                gear and sound machines. One performer wowed
the                crowd with a PC, his fingers flying over the
keyboard                and unleashing brief snippets of recorded music
and                sounds from the machine's hard drive. They filled
the                arena with an entrancing sound known as "techno"
--                electronic dance music with a driving beat,
psychedelic                sound distortion and occasional lyrics that
consist largely                of hypnotically repeated phrases.
               Long played in the underground culture of
"raves,"                all-night dance parties fueled by the
euphoria-inducing                drug Ecstasy, techno music is breaking
into the                mainstream. And record companies -- desperate
for the                Next Big Thing amid two years of flat music sales
and a                sense that "alternative" rock is flagging -- are
starting to                place their bets on the growing genre.
               Its stars include the influential Chemical Brothers, on
the                Astralwerks label of EMI Group PLC; the
powerful                U.K. band Prodigy, on the independent label
Mute                Records; Orbital, a duo on the Ffrr label of
PolyGram                NV; and Goldie, another Ffrr artist who features
a                "techno/jungle" sound that mixes soul, hip-hop,
reggae                and pulsating beats of 160 per minute or higher.
               EMI's Caroline Records, known as an
alternative-rock                launching pad, is trimming its rock
roster to make a big                push for techno. Influential radio
stations are now                playing more techno music; KROQ in Los
Angeles has                had Orbital and Prodigy on its closely
watched playlist,                and have played the Chemical Brothers.
"Music for the                Jilted Generation," a two-year-old record
by Prodigy,                has seen sales shoot up in the past six
months, and now                Time Warner Inc. is trying to snap it up.
               "Until the sales of Chemical Brothers and Prodigy
made                noises, there was no point in the majors investing,"
says                Mark Fotiadis, general manager of Prodigy's U.S.
label                Mute Records. "But they like to say sales can
cure                cancer."
               But the selling of techno poses some
significant                marketing problems for the music industry.
The genre                has few recognizable performers who look good
on                videos and album covers. Its stars are as
much                producers, engineers and DJs as they are
performers.                Furthermore, turning atmospheric electronic
tracks into                hit singles will be tricky, since they
usually don't fit the                three- to four-minute format of
most radio hits and                rarely have lyrics. (Chemical
Brothers' breakout hit                "Setting Sun," has a spacey,
mantra-like refrain: "I tell                you that it's just too
bad.")
               "The challenge is to establish clear-cut artists in
the                dance techno market. Club people love it, but how
do                you spread it to a wider demographic?" says
Gary                Arnold, vice president of marketing of Best Buy Co.,
a                major music retailer. Mr. Arnold says
techno's                popularity mystifies him. "As a consumer I don't
get it --                but my 18-year-old daughter loves it."
               Mystifying as it may be to an older generation,
the                techno sound is starting to creep into American
pop                culture. The Gap plays the electronic artist Goldie
on its                in-store music tapes. TV ads for the Microsoft
Network                use a techno-like sound from the Los
Angeles                producers known as Dust Brothers. MTV,
bellwether                of virtually every music trend of the past 15
years, cut its                hours of rock and rap videos and added a
new techno                show called "Amp." U2, whose brooding
alternative                rock made it one of the world's most popular
bands, is                shifting gears on its March release with
several songs its                label executives describe as "more
electronic, techno,                more experimental."
               The U2 record will open "a lot of pop and
rock                people's minds to new sounds," says Jim Welch,
a                former director of artists and repertoire at Sony
Corp.'s                Sony Music's Columbia Records. "It will be a new
kind                of crossover."
               Record executives say the techno trend also heralds
a                turn in American youth culture. They say young
concert                goers and CD buyers are burned out on the anxiety
and                grit of alternative rock and rap, the last two genres
that                ignited blockbuster music sales. Last year,
anticipated                releases from alternative rock groups like
Pearl Jam had                disappointing sales, while the number of
radio stations                with rap formats declined.
               Perhaps in reaction to rock's intensity, there's a
market                today for a more upbeat, unconfrontational sound.
An                executive at a major U.S. record label sensed the
signs                of a new market when he caught a recent New
York                show by the Chemical Brothers, "The dancing
never                stopped and there wasn't a bad vibe in the room,"
he                says.
               The rave scene still carries with it an association
with                drugs, the kind needed to stay up all night and
dance.                But as raves and techno music go mainstream,
safer                alternatives are appearing. To counter the
stereotype of                drugs at raves, Robb Hart, a co-head of the
Watermark                label, runs a sister company called Pure
Children, which                puts on squeaky-clean raves -- complete
with security                battalions to check for weapons and drugs.
"The rave                scene gets a bad rap," says Mr. Hart. "Most
kids are                there to hold hands. They are lost and need to
hold                somebody ... It's very communal."
               At the New Year's Eve rave at Asbury Park,
where                teenagers danced from 11 p.m. to 9 a.m. to the beat
of                techno music, 20-year-old Andrew Deming was
on                hand for more than just the music. "What I like
about                raving is it's a place you can go for 12 hours and
be                warm and listen to music with friends," he says.
"You                can do what you want and be yourself. There
aren't                many places like that any more."
               What about alternative rock and grunge? "Pearl
Jam                and Soundgarden are all sold out and cheesy
and                played out on the radio. Everybody sounds like
them,"                says Mr. Deming.

____________________________________________________ x-radio ____
____ http://www.x-radio.com/ ____________________________________


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jan 27 10:13:38 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id KAA20471; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 10:13:38 -0800 (PST)
Received: from misnt1.rely.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with SMTP id KAA20467; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 10:13:33 -0800 (PST)
Received: by misnt1.rely.com with SMTP (Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.994.63)
	id <01BC0C3B.99B6D070@misnt1.rely.com>; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 10:19:38 -0800
Message-ID: <c=US%a=_%p=SoftwarExpress%l=MISNT1-970127181926Z-3708@misnt1.rely.com>
From: Adam Guevara <aguevara@rely.com>
To: "'The rebellion...'" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: The weekend and then some...
Date: Mon, 27 Jan 1997 10:19:26 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.994.63
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello.

Wow, sooo much has happened in 72 hrs. It just makes my head spin....

Ok here's the 411.

Thursday-  _Gaiamind_
I pesonally don't about you but I see the scene for any reason to throw
a party, to throw a party.  Plain and simple.  (heh, I even remember one
time some pepole were disscussing to throw a going away party for an
Iguana, of all things.  And remember that Willie Brown partie???).
Anyways, a friend and I arrived fairly early to GM, round ninish (not to
be confused with Finnish) and one of the most memorable events of the
night happened...  I piaed my way in and headed straight to the first
doorway.  Which happend to be a stage where a live band was performing.
So I stood there, waved @ the audience and sneaked back out (I guess I
was a specal guest).  Like I stated in my last post I really felt for
the chill room, 'cos once both dj rooms went up that chill room sounded
like a kid with his first pair of Gemini's, train wreck city.  I will
fonly remember the chill romm as Amtrack Station.  The main room was
nice, it looked very CCC'ish.  The jungle room wis a bit too bright for
my tastes. What frigtened me was the pictures on the wall,  if someone
were to slip an hit one of thoesepieces it wiold turn from art to art
history, know what I'm sayin' ???
The crowd was nice,rainging from young to ol..., er, uh, not so young.
And I spent nearly all my time in the jungle room gruuvin' out to some
tight tunes.  Had to bail @ 1:30 to get to work tho.  All in all: 7 out
of 10 smiles. well done.

Friday: 
	Afta work, chilling with a few of my work supervisors @ a bar (yea, I
don't like bars, but I was invited, by my bosses no less).  Mr. Pager
started vibrating like a vibra... eh, hmm, well it started vibrating a
lot.  So I made my exit and headed to Oakland.  Picking up some folks
from Sweden, Finland and a good friend from Oak we headed to Castro
Valley to send regards to DJ Sahid ( techno DJ from Germ.) who was out
with the flu.  His envy was a little apperant ("we're going to a
PARRRTTTY nyah, nyah" =P ). And finnaly arriving @ _GT_ (possibly the
last party there) around 11ish.  Went straight upstairs and started
dancing...  Funny vibe that night.  My knee brace was 'swiped' within
fifteen minutes of me arriving there (not cool), but whatever.  
	I made my way down stairs to the psychidellec Trance room and very
ambient room (all thoses comfy matresses), waived hi to da DJ, (I don't
remember your name dude...).  Danced like a lil fool for a while and
went upstairs to check out what was happening.  The crowd was pretty
sparse, which isn't too much of a bad thing but nevertheless I know how
much people put into productions and if you don't at least break even,
it get's harder to throw future parties... 
	I hate to say it but it seemed the most popular place wasn't either of
the three rooms, but the stair well (ugh!) which make it increasingly
difficult to manuver up and down the stairs.  C'mon peoples, if you
gotta "Do your thang", do it in the chill room where it's traditionly
supposed to be done..  The stairs in themselves were a chore, walking
up, walking down, walking up  No need for a Stairmaster here.  Saw a few
of you, dear ravers, and said hi in my own special way.  And I know you
saw me (ya, just don't know it yet...).  
	Id say by 1:30 I setteled into the main room where (at last!) a crowd
of dancers was forming, I jumped infornt of a speaker and started,
"getting there" a few other dancers were bouncing about, but they we're
mostly set dancers, concentrating mostly on thier movements and totally
ignoring the music @ times...  Eh, experience brings skill and time
comes w/experiance. Ramptin fininshed off with a meduim size crowd
appreicating his tunes (Very technically 'On' IMO).  Then Mystr-E
stepped in...
	Talk about a 'HARD' set!!!  From the deep bass bumpin' beats to the
tweaky highs and funked midranges I completely lost "it", immersing
myself in the audio world of sound ([thump, thump] sound,[thump, thump]
sound)...  It's not that I enjoy making a spectical of myself, but when
I totally drop all my inhibitions, I jump up and doawn like a fool (a
rather cool fool, if i say so myself...).  I was thinking, "this is how
I want to play, 'On' like Ramptin yet 'Hard' like Mystr-E,  But I think
if I use the name DJ Hard-On, not too many people will understand it's
actual meaning...
	Only 20min. into Mystr-e's set one of the promoters rushes up to the DJ
booth informing the Dj (and my prying ears) that he just locked out the
cops.  I try not to laugh too hard, but it seems immensly comical
visulizing police walking around the enterance, knocking on the door,
trying to get in...
To my knowlage some one either drunk, or high (possibly both) walks out
of the front door and the SF Polo walk in...  Almost immediatly one
person is arrested for possesion of meth.  The sound is shut down and
everyone is ushered into the streets.  I find my party of three and we
pile into my car, we settle on staying in the city, rent a room and
order pizza (can someone say "munchies", I was dissapointed not to have
any cable, allthough I don't watch TV ...  I tried tuning the radio to a
decent station but the volume on the radio went to inaudable to VERY
LOUD.  So I meditated and listend to the party goin' on in my mind...

Saturday:  
	I really didnt get to sleep till 4:30PM Saturday but I was up at 8,
buzzing about and calling a different "crew" to find out who wanted to
brave the weather and get to _Meridian_.  Afta doing what hook-ups I
needed and after making too many wrong turns, stopping @ several
payphones along the way, and looking @ maps @ various gasstations only
1/2 our party makes it to the local. 
	And what a nice space it is!  Three rooms: one doing the Drumm and Bass
thang, one going off in the Trance genere and the third room spinning
I-don't-know-what.  I finally settle in the main room @ about midnite
just as Ethan starts.  I like Ethans sets. Plain and simple.  His choice
of music is very pleasent to the ear raingin from stompy stuff, to
relaxing minimal trance.  He knows how to bring a much needed slow trak
when the crowd needs it. I kept dancing, in the front of the DJ booth,
till about 1:45 and then decieded to "chill" somewheres.  I boogie over
to the Jungle room and relax on the floor and later on a couch.  Before
I left the main room I ask Deaks when he is up @ bat. 2 o'clock. Im
there.  
	I wave and say hi to the other folk I see @ this party.  A different
tribe from the GT bunch. Which is nice as well...  I've noticed that
thru my pursiuts of attaining oneness through music that I do indeed
"drift" between the tribes of techno.  Some peoples I only see once a
month, at house events, some I see every two weeks, at Psi-trance (ie
Goa) parties.  Some are only seen at Massives (once or twice a year).
But I try to make an effort to see my 'friends' every week... 
	Ding! the mental clock starts sounding and I 'know' that Deaks is about
to start, I manuver thru the crowds and get back to the main dance floor
one song before Deaks, I shed my shirt and start moving... 
	Now I must say, Deaks is one of those that, after only hearing a few
times, I know is going to help me mold my own mixing style.  He seems
also to be one of those that dosen't sit 'outside' mixing music in, but
rather, is 'in' the music blending it like a fine painter merges colours
into a work of art...  I only get to have fifteen minutes of pleasure
before the sound is shut off and we're told to disperse from the boys in
blue... Oh well, I've had my share of sooooo many busted partys i'm not
even dissapointed anymore. We are indeed the Underground Alliance ever
prused by the Evil Blue Empire. The Empire has struck again and us
Rebels are scrambeling like eggs.  Gosh I'm glad I was totally sober,
cos it seemed that nature herself was against some of us this night.  We
made a game of driving down the freeways (@ about 70Mph)  Counting all
the auto accidents for the remainder of the night...

Can't wait till friday (STAR WARS)...

--_Adam
"Stay Connected"

P.s.es

Hey for all those that asked me to dupe a copy of 20/20 I allready have
some blank tapes, I just need to get an address or something to send it
to.  I think postage for the tape is 3$, first class I'll send out out
one granted that I get put on yor guest list when you throw a party...  

Micron, yea, that sounds cool.  I'm still waiting for these rains to let
up before actually planning events.  I allready have  6 sites lined up
(3 nitetime and 3 daytime locations). Send me a tape And I'll getcha one
of mine...  

Tim, so when is the planning commite starting for your june event- still
interested.

To who you are...  _Karma_ works both ways.  I keep trying to hope we,
as promoters can live peacefully.  Bad thoughts create threats, threats
caused ill actions.  Keep pure for the scenes sake.  We are fragmented
enough allready.  I allways try to think that parties are thrown for the
peoples sake.  Not to just make a buck, chuck. Too bad politics are
allways involved.  Such a shame.

Subject: Re: Anyone else have cool parents?
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

>I suggested that my parents watch the 20/10 special report
>and they thought that it looked like "a shitload of fun" and
>they encouraged me to go to more and to take them sometime.

I had a conversation with my dad about Wrinkle in Time (11/16/96) and all
the multimedia/decorations in the chill room and we got into a great
discussion about technology, some fascinating projects going on at MIT and
technology-obsessed kids getting together and throwing BITCHIN' parties in
general...

my dad can be a pretty cool guy sometimes. (sometimes =)

He knows about the drugs and the e and all (i've told him about the drug
culture) and he seems to not mind; I suppose he trusts that I won't do
anything stupid. (like getting whacked out on 2 hits of e on my birthday,
FOR EXAMPLE =) I guess a *smart* parent's main concern should be that their
kid can be having fun and partying and doing their thing, but that the
parties don't interfere too much with what's realy important to mom & dad,
i.e. school and work and such. Media emphasis on the drug culture unfairly
cons parents into thinking that there's nothing else that goes on at our
parties, and that the drugs are so pervasive that kids can't help but get
totally sucked in. I really wish Baba Wawa (or whoever actually did the
investigating) was able to look *more* than two feet in front of his/her
own nose and seen past the fucked up club-kiddies and saw all the work that
went into producing parties.

take care,
-m.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jan 27 11:02:15 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id LAA25418; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 11:02:15 -0800 (PST)

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>        I TOTALLY AGREE!  I myself use it a lot but I did always think it
>        was a bit strange for all that info. to be so public.  I think having
>        RAVE LIST mailed out is a better idea.

just remember that there's a delicate balance between advertising and
"keeping it real." Do you honestly think *anyone* would be able to fill up
your beloved HomeBase without massive advertising? And once the massive
advertising is going on the cops are going to get wind of it, and the
Oakland PD is pretty well known for getting huge kickdowns from promoters
for the use of that space. Not that that's a bad thing in and of itself,
but big parties at places like HB tend to attract a helluva lotta media
attention (from, say, ABC) and the resulting hoopla makes it harder for
smaller organizations to throw parties.

I find it UNBELIEVABLY hard to accept BIG PARTIES when I know that their
"bigness" is partly responsible for many of the problems experienced by
smaller crews. I understand that lots of people like huge parties and big
name dj's and $25 tickets and hard ass security apes, but I also think that
all those big events are causing some pretty serious problems for the
smaller parties.

What if we stopped calling them "raves?" What if we stopped sticking events
like Acid Breaks and FnF under the same umbrella to avoid some of the
confusion that results? My friend Sam, an avid Dj Dan/Homebase fan once
said to told me that he doesn't consider the parties he attends to be
"raves." He said that "Harmony, FnF and other small crews throw RAVES. I
just go to parties. They're just parties." I tend to agree.

my two cents,
-m.


---> B A R K O D E * A R T W O R K S <-----------------------------
michal migurski tel:510.548.3225        lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu
www.cyborganic.com/people/lachim        lachim@cyborganic.net
---------------> MASS-PRODUCED GRAPHICS FOR A BETTER TOMMORROW <---

for more enjoyment and greater efficiency,
------> consumption is being standardized.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jan 27 11:12:49 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id LAA26466; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 11:12:49 -0800 (PST)
Received: from mvgate.isinc.insignia.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with SMTP id LAA26457; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 11:12:44 -0800 (PST)
X-Address: Insignia Solutions Inc., 2200 Lawson Lane, Santa Clara, CA.95054
X-Telephone: +1 408 327 6000
X-Fax: +1 408 327 6105
Received: from [205.231.222.64] (vbarr.isinc.insignia.com) by mvgate.isinc.insignia.com (5.65c8/UK-2.1.ISL) with SMTP
	id AA12903; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 11:10:19 -0800
X-Sender: knucklehead@mail.domain.net
Message-Id: <v03010d03af129e56a241@[205.231.222.64]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 27 Jan 1997 11:11:19 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: knucklehead <knucklehead@club.net>
Subject: nnrr,, Little Johnny story!!!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, this is alittle story about 25 of us on SFRaves put together since
Thanksgiving. We each added aline onto it and passed it along the list
until now. It is finally done. So I thought I'd post it here. The spacing
kinda sucks..just letting you know now.



           <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<   Little Johnny    >>>>>>>>>>>

    One day little johnny was walking home from school and he
came across a rather large tentacle monster. The monster's slippery
appendages were waving in the air and...he laughed and snapped his fingers
as the creature
rematerialized inside johnny's thermos. the creature, trying to break free,
violently rocked
the thermos, and ...johnny, always up for a challenge, busted out his
funkiest gangsta g-moved
showin' that the monster what time it was...Stepping back, the monster
laughed at johnny, knowing
how his superior strength could obviously overcome Johnny's limp-wristed
girly dance. The monster snapped a tentacle  at johnny. wrapping it around
his pink freakled nose. Johnny almost forgot what
was going on because only one tentacle could get out of the thermos, and
it was so hilarious to watch
his own plastic yellow Ninga Turtles thermos do the lambada forbidden dance
with the tentacle, this freaked the monster out, bursting with passion the
monster managed to escape from the thermos.
Thinking fast Little Johnny grabbed both his earrings, he threw them down
on the floor and upon
impact they exploded into huge clouds of thick pink smoke with glitter and
flames. Giving little johnny cover, he took that chance to make a costume
change. The smoked cleared and the croud applauded the
 new outfit. And what an outfit!  Johnny was completely nude!!!   "Oh, no,"
he shouted - just before he woke up, at home in bed.  It was another one of
those oh-no-I-am-outside-naked-in-public dreams, but worse, since in this
one, his THERMOS  was involved. This was his seventeenth strange dream this
week.
It was time to get some help.... and Johnny knew that God helps those who
help themselves, so
he jumped out of bed, put on his adidas sweatsuit, and went  down to the
basement where his elaborate chemistry set was waiting. "Surely I can mix
up something to stop my crazy dreams," thought the oh-so-clever tyke.

      Remembering what his father had told him about bad dreams,  Little
Johnny knew exactly what he needed for his secret "dreams-be-gone" potion.
So he ran back up to his room to retrieve his trusty
Ninja Turtles Thermos, which still contained some leftover  Tomatoe soup
his mother had made him for the bus ride home.  The soup was, of course,
cold by now. And all he needed was a.........
 little 3,4 Methylene-dioxy-N-methylamphetamine to give the  cold soup that
Mmmm, Mmmmm, Good taste.  So back down to the  basement he went to start
mixing up a batch. In a wink the vials were bubbling, the solutions
percolating, the tubes sweating, and strange-tasting crystals kept forming
in the back of johhny's mouth.  "aha!" he cried, strapping down the family
cat to the air hockey table and connecting the jumper cables to paws, ears,
and tail. "This is just what the doctor ordered - and now to apply the
...special life energy transfer helmet" which he had purchased  from an
obscure infomercial.  You see, by tranferring some of the cats feline
qualities into him, he could become more like them... nine lives, look
respectable naked, cool facial hair, and no bad dreams.  But as he was
about to flip the switch
that would render him virtually superhuman, an overwhelming sensation
swelled out in waves from his stomach and up his spine, eventually washing
over his brilliant yet troubled mind as he utterred ...
" Gadzooks!  There are no limits to what I can do!" He jubiliantly yelled"
one = infinity, nothingness = oneness, thank you Dr.Hoffman." His hand
spasmed and the switch was thrown!  His chemically
massaged neurons sizzled as his mind merged with his cat's!  Lightning flew
from his forehead and slammed into his 808, causing a thunderous rip of
bass to shatter all the glass in the basement!  Just before his brain
burned up completely, the power breaker tripped (his mother chose that
moment to
start the washing machine, which just happened to  contain Johnny's thermos).

  As the ozone drifted away, the cat sat up and said..."Poor Johnny, I kind
of feel sorry for that little chap.   I didn't mean for him to die.  I only
used my telepathic powers to give him that horrid dream and the idea to rig
us up to Brainswitcheroo, so that I could take over the world.   I didn't
mean to kill him. Oh well. Things to do, people to enslave." and she hopped
on to the computer to begin her evil plan.  Under the rubbage that was once
his studio, Johnny twitched and started to come to.  He looked down at his
battered and bruised body and saw....  that his arms and legs had been
transformed by the bass wave overload into rather large and slippery
tentacles. "oh my..." said Johnny, somewhat disturbed.  "It seems I have
turned into the horrific tentacled monster from my dream," and besides
being able to do the wave from his breakdancing past with a new and
profound grace, johnny didn't really see  much good in being a terrifying
tentacled monster.  But such is  life,  plum wackiness, and Johnny got up
and thought about chasing down that evil cat, whose fault it seemed all
this was. He jumped up, tentacles flailing, and slithered out the door.
Only to his greatest suprise did he suddenly...realized that it was a
powerful hallucination brought on by the energy transformation. As a matter
of fact, his tenticles then morphed into bat's wings, which then oozed into
dog's  legs, and then transformed into scaly lizard legs.  Johnny was in a
panic, seeing his body changing constantly.  He rubbed  his eyes and shook
his head.  When he opened his eyes, he saw  his human form again.  "Holy
shit, what a TRIP! Now I need to find my evil cat before it destroys the
earth!" Since  he now had part of his cat's instinct in his brain, he could
sense where it was headed, and what he saw frightend him to  the core of
his being....the cat was planning to unite all the consciousnesses of
earth in order to establish contact with the extra terrestrials of its home
planet, millions of miles away. Only with this combined energy could a
force powerful enough be conjured to tap into the minds of its
brothers/sisters at home, But first it was time for a short trip to...7-11,
where he could always rely on a good slurpee to fix all  his
intergalactic/consciousness problems.  he got his slurpee,  carefully mixed
the flavors to his liking, and, to his horror, looked into his cup and
saw....a terifying image of the cat!!!! Johnny shook his head and thought
to himself, "I must be trippin' or something!?!?...tentacles, dog legs,
world domination, a cat..........THE CAT!!!!". He looked again but the cat
was gone. Johnny had to do something fast if he were stop that nutty
feline. So he bolted to the nearest computer with a T-1 link and proceded
to... do a web search for something, anything, that would effectively
neuter the cat, clean up the broken glass and the slurpee stain now soaking
into the carpet, finish his homework, teach him to do the lambada properly
with or without tentacles, and help the new U.N. Secretary General achieve
world peace on a reduced budget, all before the Simpsons came  on at eight.
Since the boy had eaten his spinach the previous evening  (Thanks, mom!) he
knew this would be a piece of cake  (no cavities intended).

      Standing naked on his Twister board, two legs, one arm and three
tentacles contorted at various positions around his torso and each other,
Johnny held his mouse before him like a Samurai warrior as he clenched the
keyboard in his teeth and  proceeded to log in by typing with his tongue.
But Johnny's third-grade public school education hadn't adequately prepared
him for ownership of a megalomaniacal pet  with a predilection for
attacking things attached to the ends of long strings and cords.  Before he
could say the magical words of "Frammin' on the jim jam, frippen' at the
krotz, schleppin' and a fleppin' with an alakazotz!", a virtual image of
the Cat lunged out of the computer screen and grabbed his mouse in its
greedy paws! As Tweeker (the cat) toyed with the mouse, Johnny realized
frantically that only one thing could save him now  with lightning speed,
Johnny reached to the keyboard and launched three instances of Microsoft
Word.  Instantly, the unbridled processing power of his quad-heptium 500
MHz  Hypercharged PC was brought to its knees as system resources were
lapped up by the hungry application.   With a scream, the virtual cat
creaked to a frozen standstill,  hanging out of the monitor, unable to get
a timeslice.  "I  have you now!" yelled Johnny, gleefully opening documents
until the cat's fate was sealed with the inevitable GP Fault and subsequent
aptly-named Blue Screen of Death.The virtual cat was dead, but what of the
cat's physical body? Johnny bolted past the astonished patrons of the
Starbytes
Cafe ( " 30 Quad-Heptium PCs, Powered By 100% Pure Kona Coffee !!! " ) and
rushed home to confront the alien cat.

         Meanwhile, Johnny's mom Leslie had opened the washing machine  to
find a broken thermos, and all the clothes stained pink. Angry at first,
her annoyance turned to shock when a tentacle reached out from the soggy
mess! Slowly, a horrible creature  pulled itself out onto the floor. As it
shuffled past her to
the basement, the thing whispered " If it makes you feel any better, just
call me a hallucination - everyone else does " . Johnny burst into the
washroom and dashed to the basement door! Seeing Leslie frantically trying
to simultaneously phone 911 and search through the hardware drawer for a
weapon, Johnny said .. WOW!! look at all the pretty colors.. and then all
of a suddena door opened and the lights came on and there were cops at the
door yelling "Ok folks, the parties over, everyone has to go home now." As
Johnny was  gathering his things, all he could say was, "Damn, what a trip"
as he looked at the huge day-glo and neon painting on the wall with
flowers, and cats on it on his way out of the warehouse.




*****************Disclaimer************

This story is fictional as well as the characters. Any coincedence is just
that. It is not geared toward anyone..blah, blah, blah...you all know the
little disclaimers they have on movies and books.

Hi, Everyone :)
I'm sorta new to the rave/clubbing scene, and I'd love to meet new people
to party/rave with.  Even though I've been going out full force since last
August, I have yet to make friends associated with the "scene."  My
problems are two-fold:  1) I'm pretty shy, and I have yet to walk up to any
strangers and just say, "Hi," and 2) all of my friends are either too young
or too burned out to go out anymore!!!
Will anyone please help this poor boy break out of his shell and push me
headfirst into weekend-long fits of dancing mayhem??? ;)  Thanks!
-Thomas
P.S.  For anyone who went to We The People (Loveworks) this weekend, I was
the guy with the blinking red lights in each hand.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jan 27 12:32:52 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id MAA04610; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 12:32:52 -0800 (PST)
Received: from baygate.bayarea.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with SMTP id MAA04606; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 12:32:48 -0800 (PST)
Received: from nicetry (pppsf18.bayarea.net [205.219.85.200]) by baygate.bayarea.net (8.6.9/8.6.9) with SMTP id MAA05187 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 12:31:36 -0800
Message-Id: <3.0.32.19970127123218.00f5bea0@chosen.org>
X-Sender: phresh@chosen.org
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 3.0 (32)
Date: Mon, 27 Jan 1997 12:32:21 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: =?iso-8859-1?Q?=22=A4=5BOo=5D=A4=22?= <iam@chosen.org>
Subject: Mainstream is a good thing.
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Why are most of you appalled at the mainstreaming of techno?
Techno is not ours, and it is not the only music of the scene.
As I had read in someone elses mailing,
"The scene will come and go many times, and so will the people in it."
That is not exactlt paraphrased, but it is close.
The mainstreaming of "techno," excites me, and this is a very short
explanation of why...
For the past few years, techno has begun to be somewhat the same, if 
the techno that has been out is what is mainstreaming, we in the UG
scenes will always have new styles of music, and I believe this will push
the progression of music styles even faster. I heard techno for the first
time in the late 80's / early 90's. "What next," I thought... then acid,
breakbeat, hardcore... what could posssibly be next? 
Then Jungle... OH MY GAWD!!!!!!!
I cannot wait to hear what could possibly please every one of my senses more 
than jungle...?
-peas
-justin

"time to consult the anarchist's cookbook...

kicked this woman out for "too long of a post".  Now this woman did what
I think is a perfect little fuck-you that can't be traced ~ like
something to do to 20/20.

It is believed that this woman is responsible for redirecting all of the
messages from some cat group to the multimedia group.  The multimedia
group is now being bombarded with hundreds of cat messages a day, and
it's growing uncontrollably(over 300 on Saturday!).  And these messages
can't be easily filtered out.  

Here is a group of some the supposed most talented and they are having a
serious difficult time trying to correct the situation. In the meantime,
it's become quite a bothersome drag. But I have to admit, its a nice
little slam by that woman.

Does anybody know how to redirect email?

Just getting my evil thoughts out.

From: *B* <branka@sirius.com>
Subject: E & possible problems
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 7:03 AM -0000 1/25/97, Noah Apodaca wrote:
>Now, one other thing.  I'd like to know how much that one woman knows
>about MDMA toxicology.  I too have looked at quite a bit of data on the
>substance and have not seen evidence that it causes people to heat up to
>107+ degrees F.  I'd also like to know what motivated the doctor/coroner
>to declare MDMA as the cause of death.

I would just like to say, that I have also done a lot of reading on MDMA,
and I have not run across evidence that it does bad things to your body.
Which doesn't necessarily mean that nothing bad can happen to you.  It just
means that there is not enough research done on it.

I was unfortunate to have one of my best friends in 2 pretty critical
situations.  Both times she had seizures and she was taking E at the time.
Both times she was lucky that it was just a seizure and she was functioning
in reasonable time (30min or so).  But it could have turned out a different
way.  My friend does not have epileptic history and her doctor's educated
guess was that it was E that caused the seizures (one doctor said it was
low sodium because of too much water, but when it happened the second time
- just 1/2 hit followed by 1/2 hit of E, not too much water etc. I am more
in favor of blaming E).

I have posted this in a past, and I just want some of you who think that E
is a wonderful thing that can't cause problems to think about it, and not
just shut down possibilities that something bad will happen.

As I was watching 20/20 they showed doctors report why that girl died, and
although they didn't say it (they emphasized on body tem.), she have had
seizures that probably pushed her over the edge.  Maybe it was the
combination of the 2, maybe it was more stuff we don't know about.  But I
have to tell all of you that it hit me, that my friend could have been in
the place of that girl, and I was so happy she wasn't.

So, please when you do take your drugs be careful, and don't just accept
facts that you want to hear as the truth.  There is more to it.  If you
want to take drugs, it's your choice, but be aware that there might be some
truth in what doctors say - not all of them are out there to get us.  And
the bad thing about E is that it's pretty new, and nobody really know all
the side-effects and possible problems it can cause.

*B*

At 3:25 PM -0800 1/27/97, Nancy Shaw wrote:
>It's been done!  It's called "Friends and Family"

Thanks for bringing that up. I wanted to say something like that, but since
I am part of F&F, I was afraid that it would have come off too smug if I
(or any other F&F person) said it.

Just because F&F exists it doesn't mean anyone out there should be shy away
from trying it themselves.

Other people on SFR should be getting together and having their own "list"
parties, too. BBQ & Beats was SFR-inspired and those parties are totally
cool. Adam Guevara just put something together in a living room recently
and he spun at it, too. That's what it's all about, people! :-)

That's the beauty of DIY. (do it yourself)

*B* said:
> 
> At 7:03 AM -0000 1/25/97, Noah Apodaca wrote:
> >Now, one other thing.  I'd like to know how much that one woman knows
> >about MDMA toxicology.  I too have looked at quite a bit of data on the
> >substance and have not seen evidence that it causes people to heat up to
> >107+ degrees F.  I'd also like to know what motivated the doctor/coroner
> >to declare MDMA as the cause of death.
> 
> I would just like to say, that I have also done a lot of reading on MDMA,
> and I have not run across evidence that it does bad things to your body.
> Which doesn't necessarily mean that nothing bad can happen to you.  It just
> means that there is not enough research done on it.

What??  Okay, i'm confused on this.

I thought it was pretty much assumed that MDMA raises the body's temperature.  

Everything i have read about MDMA has talked about the fact
that it is easy to die of hyperthermia and/or dehydration
because of this fact.

This is usually heavily mentioned in talks about MDMA and Raves
because Ravers tend to wear hats and lots of clothing
and dance in places with poor ventilation and a lack of free water,
AND because most of the MDMA related deaths have been attributed to this.

I don't know about 107 degrees, but everone's body is different
and we don't know what she was wearing or where she was at the time.

Other than hyperthermia, on hyperreal.com, there is also mention of:

high pulse or blood pressure, faintness, muscle cramping, or panic attacks,
dryness of mouth, jaw clenching, teeth grinding, nystagmus (eye wiggles), 
sweating, or nausea, fast or pounding heartbeat, dizziness, restlessnes

(from the MDMA FAQ) 

This is all not to mention the neurotoxicity theories
about MDMA depleting seratonin levels in the brain.

There are also three articles on Hyperreal talking about "Ecstacy"
use leading to death.

I'm not sure what people are reading, but i would highly reccommend:

http://www.hyperreal.com/drugs/mdma
http://www.ecstacy.org/


 ,
dana

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jan 27 16:40:54 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id QAA00934; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 16:40:54 -0800 (PST)
Received: from wired.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id QAA00929; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 16:40:48 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [204.62.132.48] (looking.hotwired.com [204.62.132.48]) by wired.com (8.7.6/8.7.3) with SMTP id QAA07851; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 16:40:46 -0800 (PST)
Date: Mon, 27 Jan 1997 16:40:46 -0800 (PST)
X-Sender: harli@get.hotwired.com
Message-Id: <v02130504af124060d2b3@[204.62.132.48]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: harli@hotwired.com (m e r i = harli@)
Subject: First Contact Review /or/ How I Learned to Love the Fire Marshall...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey Folks...

I don't usually do party reviews but I had such a great time at First
Contact that I can't help myself. The gorgeous Lightseed folks out-did
themselves completely. The music in all 3 rooms kept changing and evolving
- creating a constantly changing atmosphere, I found myself wandering
happily around all three rooms - everytime finding something new, something
weird, something totally different.

My favorite was the goa/psychedelic trance in the main room which kind of
became like a 2nd home to me after awhile. Cimino & Caban & Brad destroyed
the place and then built it back up again - kind of like the Hindu god
Shiva - who destroys and creates at the same time. Brad at 6 am came out
with sounds I've never heard before. Brilliant.

The back room was also a weird place - everytime I went out there something
different was happening. My friend loved the digerdoo performance (which I
missed), describing it as "an hour of beautiful nothingness".

All night I kept spying the fire marshall standing on the stairs above the
entrance. At first I thought, oh oh he's going to bust us... but he stayed
there hanging out with a vaguely bemused look on his face. He actually
ended up staying until 6.30 am or thereabouts. Wandering around, chilling
out in his tight black uniform. I saw alot of people talking to him,
smiling at him, and I came to the realization that he was INTO it.. This
got me thinking ... WE CAN TURN THE FIRE MARSHALL INTO A RAVER ... I could
see it in his eyes, he's ready to convert... he he he... this would be
changing the system from within.... so next time you see him at a party,
smile at him, give him a hug.

Enough rambling, thankyou for indulging me...

... thanks and hugs to all the Lightseed crew (I miss your smiling faces in
my loungeroom every Wednesday) and to those associated with them....just a
few names (pls forgive any exclusions)... Dagny, Brett, Melaniefish (you GO
girl!), Chin, Mark and Philip.

Meri

*Meri France Harli*

Pleasantly surprised last night to turn on the radio and find a brand-new 
weekly show dj'ed by the jungle queen, Stareyes.  

"Shortwave" is on midnight-1AM Sunday nights (or Monday mornings, I guess!)
on the mighty KALX (90.7 FM).

Last night she did an interesting retrospective of artists from various 
points of their careers...and with quite a smooth, silky voice 
(especially for a 19-year-old!), I think she has a future as a radio dj!

My favorite station just got a little better :)

	I TOTALLY disagree.  Just because they are bigger doesn't mean it
	isn't a rave.  Sure it may be on a much larger scale all around, but
	it is still a rave...of course I suppose it depends on YOUR definition
	of a RAVE.  
	
	Mine : friends, vibe, great techno, mixed group of people
	gathered together for one thing...TO HAVE PHUN, releasing all tension
	and stress and escaping the "real" world and entering the rave world
	that has been created for them  whether it be in HOMEBASE warehouse
	or some basement.
					I'm sad to see the massives taking
					all the wrap once again.

						((RAVE ON)) --> MHg ;)

Precedence: bulk


For the record, I wasn't trying to say that there are no dangers in using
E (or any other drug).  Pills/capusules and the like are especially
dangerous since you never really know what you're getting.  
The bottom line is if you choose to buy and take _any_ drug, you are
taking a _big_ risk.  I worked in a pharmacy for a couple of years and you
wouldn't believe the interactions and 'side' effects that even legal,
regulated 'healing' drugs can cause.  
So, be smart.  
I feel for all those who have related E-related horror stories to me.
Sadly, there _is_ a down side to _any_ drug use, kids.
