From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jan 27 17:29:04 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id RAA05863; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 17:29:04 -0800 (PST)
Received: from wired.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id RAA05845; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 17:28:59 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [204.62.132.48] (looking.hotwired.com [204.62.132.48]) by wired.com (8.7.6/8.7.3) with SMTP id RAA15681; Mon, 27 Jan 1997 17:28:55 -0800 (PST)
Date: Mon, 27 Jan 1997 17:28:55 -0800 (PST)
X-Sender: harli@get.hotwired.com
Message-Id: <v02130500af128dd504ce@[204.62.132.48]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: DWATANAB@UCI.EDU (Dana Watanabe)
From: harli@hotwired.com (m e r i = harli@)
Subject: Re: E & possible problems
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>Everything i have read about MDMA has talked about the fact
>that it is easy to die of hyperthermia and/or dehydration
>because of this fact.

Hey Dana... I liked and agreed with your post except for one thing - and
we should not lose perspective on this - it is not 'easy' to die from
taking MDMA. In England where at least (these are rough figures) a
half-million people take E every weekend there have been only about 10-20
deaths in the last 5 years or so (again these are rough figures). I have a
visitor who is an english dj and he tells me that statistically more people
die from EATING PEANUTS than from MDMA. These people have allergic
reactions to certain chemicals in peanuts and the same is true for the
majority of e-deaths - people react allergically to the drug. It doesn't
suit everyone - neither do peanuts. I think he even said that riding in a
car is a much riskier activity statistics-wise than taking e.

And while i agree that you need to drink water and be very careful to rest
during dancing - its also important to remember that Leah Betts - the
english girl who died and was splashed all over the media as an E death
actually died from drinking TOO MUCH water. She drink 10 glasses of water
one after the other.

Lastly, I think we have to be careful not to get caught up in our fears
about mind-altering substances so that we can make well-informed choices.

Meri

 ;-)

Precedence: bulk


> All night I kept spying the fire marshall standing on the stairs above the
> entrance. At first I thought, oh oh he's going to bust us... but he stayed
> there hanging out with a vaguely bemused look on his face. He actually
> ended up staying until 6.30 am or thereabouts. Wandering around, chilling
> out in his tight black uniform. I saw alot of people talking to him,
> smiling at him, and I came to the realization that he was INTO it.. This
> got me thinking ... WE CAN TURN THE FIRE MARSHALL INTO A RAVER ... I could

This is actually a pretty old concept. go to any live music venue in
SF, check out the "hall capacity" sign, then do a rough headcount of
the number of people in the venue. From practical experience (from
knowing people in the biz back in the late 80's) I know that music
venues in SF regularly go to 1.5 to double the capacity of the venue.

How do they do it?

Simple -- they bribe the fire department with free tickets, free drinks
for certain employees, and LOTS OF CUTE YOUNG GIRLZ :-)... I know for a
fact that Slim's has been doing this for years. It's just good business
ya know!

Now that techno has become mainstream (c.f. the W.S.J. article recently
posted, playing Robert Miles' "Children" as the segue music during the
recently televised pro ice skating championships, the use of housy
techno as background music during a recent televised basketball
game...) ... anyways, now that techno has become mainstream, maybe the
fire dept will become interested in attending techno/rave events --
they will be willing to bestow their "blessing" to such an event for a
kickback. So who wants to be the sacrificial rave hoochie-girl (or boy)
for the lonely men (and women) of the SFFD?? :-)

== When yer swimming in a creek and an eel bites yer cheek, that's a moray!==

Date: Mon, 27 Jan 1997 19:54:52 -0600
To: Chris Richards <earber@pacbell.net>, AICSUE123@aol.com
From: matter <dork@immersivearts.org>
Subject: Re: wav files (2)303s &(1)808
Cc: Sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 11:19 PM 1/26/97 -0800, Chris Richards wrote:
>AICSUE123@aol.com wrote:
>> 
>> Does anyone know of any websites that have cool wav sound files that i can
>> use to sample for a techno song?
>>  I am especially looking for a siren sample.
>> 
>> -JCSorry, if this area has already been covered but I watch a few 
>newsgroups and found a VERY COOL homepage. 
>http://www.propellerheads.se/products/rebirth.html

That's all good! In addition...

There is always the tracker software for PCs with soundblaster
soundcards... I am not sure about Macintosh support, but there are a huge
amount of mods and samples out on the net for this sound tool. Do a web
search (no using Lycos, :D) for it210.exe. I think there's a newer more
advanced software package out there, though I can't recall the name to
suggest it. If I come across it, I'll post it. Also...

If you are interested in a fully MIDI implemented 303 klone (which I
actually perfer over the TB303) check out the Syntecno TeeBee (made in
Holland). It sounds just like the real thing (much better than the
BassStation) and is full MIDI, so you can program it directly with you
sequencer. No messing with sync and backup of the TB303 internal sequence
memories... not sure of their url, but you can link from the "gear" section
of my www, listed below... tell 'em I sent you, there all good over there
(I like them to know how much I love and refer people to their unit, NO I
don't get any kick backs for the referral) ;) The guy who designed and
builds them is a great guy who is fully involved with the scene in
Amsterdam. Perhaps you have heard of Robbie 303?

plur y'all,
matter


"it's silver" -Kate

Yeah, I tried NOT to reply, really I did...

At 03:04 PM 1/27/97 -0800, *B* wrote:
>So, please when you do take your drugs be careful, and don't just accept
>facts that you want to hear as the truth.  There is more to it.  If you
>want to take drugs, it's your choice, but be aware that there might be some
>truth in what doctors say - not all of them are out there to get us.  And
>the bad thing about E is that it's pretty new, and nobody really know all
>the side-effects and possible problems it can cause.

This is all good info and extremely valid. In addition, some people may
overlook the other aspects of health and drug experiences. EVERYTHING you
eat and EVERYTHING you do and EVERYTHING you are plays a role in your heath
and life experiences in general... I am truly sorry to hear about *B*'s
friend, BUT there is no way of telling exactly what the cause of the
problem was. It seems that it could have been the E, BUT it could have been
a bad hot dog or lack of sleep or anything, who knows... I guess my point
is: I see us all commenting on how 20/20 twisted the incomplete facts they
had for their report (as expected). I hope that all of us realize that
without the complete and accurate story on *B*'s friend, it's all just
speculation (as read in *B*'s email, the professionals weren't even clear
as to exactly what the problem was). We wouldn't fill in the blanks like
20/20 did? Would we?

pluR,
matter (a far cry from an expert on the topic of medical science)

 Niels P. Mayer wrote:
>
> > All night I kept spying the fire marshall standing on the stairs
above the
> > entrance. At first I thought, oh oh he's going to bust us... but he
stayed
> > there hanging out with a vaguely bemused look on his face. He
actually
> > ended up staying until 6.30 am or thereabouts. Wandering around,
chilling
> > out in his tight black uniform. I saw alot of people talking to him,
> > smiling at him, and I came to the realization that he was INTO it..
This
> > got me thinking ... WE CAN TURN THE FIRE MARSHALL INTO A RAVER ... I
could
>
> This is actually a pretty old concept. go to any live music venue in
> SF, check out the "hall capacity" sign, then do a rough headcount of
> the number of people in the venue. From practical experience (from
> knowing people in the biz back in the late 80's) I know that music
> venues in SF regularly go to 1.5 to double the capacity of the venue.
>
> How do they do it?
>
> Simple -- they bribe the fire department with free tickets, free
drinks
> for certain employees, and LOTS OF CUTE YOUNG GIRLZ :-)... I know for
a
> fact that Slim's has been doing this for years. It's just good
business
> ya know!
>
> Now that techno has become mainstream (c.f. the W.S.J. article
recently
> posted, playing Robert Miles' "Children" as the segue music during the
> recently televised pro ice skating championships, the use of housy
> techno as background music during a recent televised basketball
> game...) ... anyways, now that techno has become mainstream, maybe the
> fire dept will become interested in attending techno/rave events --
> they will be willing to bestow their "blessing" to such an event for a
> kickback. So who wants to be the sacrificial rave hoochie-girl (or
boy)
> for the lonely men (and women) of the SFFD?? :-)
>
>

moray!==

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

    This is in response to the above posting.  We hope to clarify the
presence of the fire inspector at First Contact last Saturday.  In order
to throw First Contact, we needed to go through legal permiting in order
to have a public assembly.  That meant that we needed to talk to the
SFFD.  They told us that they would permit us but that because there
were over 100 people expected that a Fire Inspector needed to be there
the whole time.  That meant that we had to pay the Fire Inspector
through The City some outlandish rate like $56.75 an hour to inspect.
That cost us a lot of money that could have been donated to our
charities.  The police came three times throughout the night but partly
with help from the Inspector they left us alone.  We went til' 7:00.
The Inspector was very nice and danced for part of the evening.  As for
sacrificial "hoochies" there were none.  Upon leaving our event he told
us he had enjoyed his evening.  The only thing that anyone gave him all
night long was a cup of Chai tea from Nub Chai.

    Thanks to all of you who came out last Saturday, we hope you enjoyed
yourselves.
    We had an awesome time.  The crowd makes the party.  Thank YOU.

If you want to find out more information or contact anyone from
Lightseed, visit our website
                        www.intrepidnet.com/lightseed
    Osmosis is another party that a couple of us in Lightseed are
working on.  Check it out. ( :

        Jeff Taisch
        Lightseed Collective

<DT>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; This is in response to the above posting.&nbsp;
We hope to clarify the presence of the fire inspector at First Contact
last Saturday.&nbsp; In order to throw First Contact, we needed to go through
legal permiting in order to have a public assembly.&nbsp; That meant that
we needed to talk to the SFFD.&nbsp; They told us that they would permit
us but that because there were over 100 people expected that a Fire Inspector
needed to be there the whole time.&nbsp; That meant that we had to pay
the Fire Inspector through The City some outlandish rate like $56.75 an
hour to inspect.&nbsp; That cost us a lot of money that could have been
donated to our charities.&nbsp; The police came three times throughout
the night but partly with help from the Inspector they left us alone.&nbsp;
We went til' 7:00.&nbsp; The Inspector was very nice and danced for part
of the evening.&nbsp; As for sacrificial &quot;hoochies&quot; there were
none.&nbsp; Upon leaving our event he told us he had enjoyed his evening.&nbsp;
The only thing that anyone gave him all night long was a cup of Chai tea
from Nub Chai.&nbsp;&nbsp;</DT>

<DT>&nbsp;</DT>

<DT>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thanks to all of you who came out last Saturday,
we hope you enjoyed yourselves.</DT>

<DT>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We had an awesome time.&nbsp; The crowd makes the
party.&nbsp; Thank YOU.</DT>

is another party that a couple of us in Lightseed are working on.&nbsp;

Re: Wall Street Journal article:


Oh, this is bad, this is very very bad.  I wasn't so concerned when raves were 
slandered on Sleeza or even 20/20;  I wasn't even that worried that MTV would 
pollute the scene with goofy trendies.   But this article, in what is perhaps 
the most studied and trusted newspapers, worries me.  It firmly attaches the 
statements "emerging" and  "potential profits" to the techno scene. It lays out 
record companies' plans to push into the market.  This article was really the 
first wake-up call that woke me up. 


It's time to go deeper...
  
  much deeper...

   underground. 












Just don't go so far down that I can't find youz!  ;-)

Also, I agree that the SFRaves calendar on the Hypperreal site, although 
convenient, is probably too readily accessible. How about a password protected 
one? The password could be some little bit of trivia or something that most 
people on the  list would remember. 



Peace, 
Nathan

I read one review of First Contact that was held at the somar 
gallries on sat. the 25th. Any one else on the list make it 
to this one? There was 3 or4 other parties that night
but quite a few people made it despite other events and the skechy 
weather.
This party was a benifit for the cbc and the headwaters.There were
alot of new faces there and every one of them seemed to be having a 
great time. If you went, let me and the other readers know what you
liked/disliked.This way we can keep striving to have great parties
that support a great cause.
Hats off to everyone involved, this was one of the better parties
Ive played in quite a while.Great music,great space,cool fire
inspector:) what elese could you ask for! 
 
                Thanx and keep smilin...sean...

Hi!  ]=)

 Your post really resonated with me so i felt I had to respond.



On Mon, 27 Jan 1997, Angela M. Gallagher wrote:


---ran wrote---

> >  On the mainstage I caught Andiamo (sp?), a tight, well rehearsed three 
> > piece band. Sort of like Primus meets Phish. They were fun and I enjoyed 
> > dancing to them.
> 
> I absolutely LOVED this band.  It's been a long time since I heard 
> and was able to dance to really goooood live psychedelia.  It reminded me 
> of the good old days in Santa Cruz where you could see Doors Hotel for $1!
> I also fondly recall a band called QSO (Quasi Stellular Object).

 Interesting connection there. I used to work with QSO. The 2nd rave I 
ever went to (and my first ExpEriencE) was a show called LightHouse 2. It 
was on Halloween at the Old Jose's Cantina in Santa Cruz (which when 
closed down in 95 I threw a LOT of UG parties there for free). I was in 
charge of sound (three rooms running off of the DJ's coffin and mixing 
the house equipment with what we could scrape together) and had to pick 
up an emergency sound system at the last minute when the ambient sound 
system truck broke down in SF. QSO played that night.



> >  The jungle room was well equipped for sound thanks to Gateway (although 
> > as the bass waves from there rolled through the chill room, I was starting 
> > to hate Gateway's four 18 inch drivers), but it was too bright in there. 
> > Lots of floor lamps in a white room. Ugh. Big thanks to Rob for helping 
> > us get some decent speakers in the chill room.
> 
> I spent much of my time in the Jungle room and was quite impressed.  
> There was a female (trim, short blond hair) who played at about 3pm who was 
> phenomenal!  Tho at this point the music wasnt jungle: It was much slower. 
> She really manipulated the speed and pitch so you felt as if you were 
> descending.  VERY POWERFUL. 
> I had been lucky enough to get a ride with some folks to whom I am very 
> greatful.  I was however disappointed to leave such an interesting 
> DJ w/out hearing the end of the story.  Anyone know her name?

 That was Claire from Gateway Sound Systems.


> >  I have only two really serious complaints about the party. One obviously 
> > was the space for the chill room. I was given the choice of that or 
> > outside near the freeway in a trash filled patio, where it might rain. No 
> > tarp was forthcoming and it was a bit cool so I opted for the noisy but 
> > warm experience.
> 
> 
> I thoroughly enjoyed the chill room tho you are right- there was some 
> cross noise.

 Well thanks. "Some" cross noise?  ;)



>  But if there was any music I heard that night that I could 
> have taken home, it would be the sounds I heard in there.

 Well some of that music is available.



>  Especially 
> liked a guy who played about 2am?  Sorry, I'm new and cant put names w/ 
> faces yet. 

 There was essientially two of us. Me (Dionysus Dreams) and Seofon from 
Ambient Temple of I*Magi*Nation. ATOI has three CD's on silent records. 
They are quite good. Seofon was on the wing portion of the tables and I 
was in the center. (under the mandela)


> >  So thanks to the irresponsible nature of most ravers I am no longer 
> > lending anything to anybody.
> 
> I can really hear your frustration over wanting to share/ help and 
> getting burned.

 Wow. Someone who understands. Thanks!  :)



>  Unfortunately, not everyone is honest and sees that 
> things get back where they originated.  (You mean everyone's not like 
> us?  I keep learning this lesson over and over and...)  I had 200 dollars 
> (my rent $) stolen about 1 week before christmas, probably by a 
> certain someone I knew.  This represented a large amount of my income. SHIT! 

 I'm so sorry. That must have really hurt. (((((hug)))))



> All I can do is protect myself better in the future.  I think you 
> are justified in being upset and deciding to ensure better care of your 
> equipment.  After all, you are keeping it in good condition so that we 
> ALL may enjoy! (THANKS btw)

 Wow again! I'm glad someone can appreciate what I'm trying to do. (your 
welcome)



> This environment attracts some people who are only interested in drugs and 
> a party, period. Experience has taught me that these needy folks have gotten 
> themselves to a place where they are unpredictable and sometimes desperate.  
> I use to be at that selfish place and I looked at situations for what I could 
> GET/GAIN/USE/HAVE (mine mine me me me).  
> Aren't you glad you aren't like this girl whose behavior you loathe so much?  
> Should we thank her for showing us this truth or would that be too much....

 Well, thanking her would just be too spiritualy smug for my tastes, but 
I think you are right in that she is showing us (me) some important 
stuff. I used to not be very different then her in some ways.


> >  On the plus side the event was good for drawing attention and raising 
> > funds for the Headwaters purchase plan. There was also a nice diverse 
> > crowd there.
> 
> If any more 16 year olds offer me x, I'm going to spank them!  I'm high 
> on life dammit!  and isnt it past your bedtime?  kids nowadays...sheesh! :)

  Yup! Just like us!  ;)


hugz,

Ran D.Dreams

Hi all! ]=)

On Mon, 27 Jan 1997 harli@hotwired.com wrote:

[snip]

> All night I kept spying the fire marshall standing on the stairs above the
> entrance. At first I thought, oh oh he's going to bust us... but he stayed
> there hanging out with a vaguely bemused look on his face. He actually
> ended up staying until 6.30 am or thereabouts. Wandering around, chilling
> out in his tight black uniform. I saw alot of people talking to him,
> smiling at him, and I came to the realization that he was INTO it.. This
> got me thinking ... WE CAN TURN THE FIRE MARSHALL INTO A RAVER ... I could
> see it in his eyes, he's ready to convert... he he he... this would be
> changing the system from within.... so next time you see him at a party,
> smile at him, give him a hug.

 Sorry. We beat ya all to the punch. The fire marshall was at GaiaMind 
also. I told him that I had a 1st aid kit and a fire extinguisher by my 
table and that I was trained in 1st aid and CPR. He replied that I was 
all set then (grinning the whole time). I replied that he must not be 
doing to bad as he was making overtime (he had told a friend of mine this 
earlier). He smiles even more and says "It's all good." YIPPEE!

 We poured so much love and good vibe into him. He was practically 
floating that night

 Let's keep up the good work!  =)


peas,

Ran D.Dreams

To: Thomas Cuellar <jedimac@netwizards.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Anthony E <tymat@community.net>
Subject: Re: Shy dude new to tha scene...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>Hi, Everyone :)
>I'm sorta new to the rave/clubbing scene, and I'd love to meet new people
>to party/rave with.  Even though I've been going out full force since last
>August, I have yet to make friends associated with the "scene."  My
>problems are two-fold:  1) I'm pretty shy, and I have yet to walk up to any
>strangers and just say, "Hi," 

You need to think of a really kewl ice-breaker.  Perhaps offer candy to
everyone in the chill room circle?  How about lotion?  There are lots of
kewl things that you can consider an ice-breaker at a rave.  Perhaps you
have some glitters, or toys, or even glow in the dark pendants.  Be creative.

>and 2) all of my friends are either too young
>or too burned out to go out anymore!!!
>Will anyone please help this poor boy break out of his shell and push me
>headfirst into weekend-long fits of dancing mayhem??? ;)  Thanks!

Exchanging phone numbers among people you have met at the party usually
helps.  Bring an organizer or even a notebook (my friend Matt brings this
raver autograph book where everyone can write or doodle something)   This
helps you remember names too!   

Also, being involved in ridesharing to a rave is a good way to meet friends.

Hope this helps.....

PLUR + Starbursts + Star Trek,
Anthony E

On Mon, 27 Jan 1997, Rob Rayle wrote:

> 	Did you see the cops show up? Notice how when they see the
> fire marshall is there they just go away?

	Actually, the cops came barging in, where interspetted and 
brought outside. The party was fully permitted (even the public assembly 
if I heard things right) so the cops could not lawfully even enter the 
SOMAR. Instead, they drove around outside all night writing tickets to 
any car they could find a potential problem with.
	I don't know how Lightseed got the public assembly permit as that 
is reported to be the most difficult to get...

dave

On Mon, 27 Jan 1997, knucklehead wrote:

> Just a though here, but should we actually have the SFR Calendar online. If
> you do a basic net search on RAVES, the first thing that will come up is
> Hyperreal, then by clicking here and there you can get to the SFR Calendar.
> It has loads of phone numbers and party info. Does this actually have to be
> on the net.

	Think for a minute. A cop gets an account on some ISP. Subscribes 
to sfraves or sfraves-calendar and gets it delivered once a week free of 
charge. To take it off the web, would be pointless unless we take it out 
of the mailing lists. And why should the calendar be hidden?

dave

This is a smile note. It means you should smile. Upon receiving
this note, it is customary to...


1.) Smile, someone loves you.

2.) Turn and smile at the person next to you.

3.) Smile at at least one cute and fuzzy little animal. (they might

    not smile back, but know that they appreciate it)

4.) The next time you see them, smile at the person who sent this

    to you.

5.) Send this along to anyone you know who needs a smile. (no, this

    isn't a chain letter, it's just a smile)



                        __ooooooooo__

To: "[Oo]" <iam@chosen.org>
CC: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Mainlining is a good thing
References: <3.0.32.19970127123218.00f5bea0@chosen.org>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

in all my bitching and cynicism out here on the east coast, someone
pointed out to me the other day that a "scene" is not a tangible thing,
so how could one ever place any sort of expectations on it... our music
is a product of our scene... the scene is the sum total of anyone
involved in it actively or passively at any given instant... with the
mainstreaming of techno, many artists, usually the ones with most
commercial appeal, will be spoonfed upon the consuming masses... this
will of course make many strive harder to push the envelope, but it will
also result in a more passive audience and the appearance of passive
musicians (like existing commercial dance music where only 10% new
succeeds)... i think the reason much of techno has begun to sound the
same, is because of the new found passivity in the collective... in some
respects, i have found that i can not play experimental "new" mu-sick at
large scale parties because people have an adversion to it... it doesn't
fit the norm (which in Toronto consists of snare drum builds and
progressive hard-house) so i am relegated to the "ambient room" and
yesteryear's folklore... meanwhile, the elements that "work" within the
mainstream are ripped off by dj's that attended their first parties
hosted by yours truly... i am not the only UG DJ to experience this...
ALGOrhythm and Jarkko have also had their share of frustration... and i
suspect this may be the case all over north america... we perservere
however, in the hope that someday down the road, innovation will be the
key to success, true originality within sound production (as a live
artist and a dj) will become the factor with which the mainstream
decides, rather than the displaced respons-abilty currently upon the
shoulders of marketing executives who continually give us musical pablum
in the guise of the next big product...

pipe dream or pied piper?

the alchemist

i've also heard of a prank by the church of the SubGenius out of Dallas
which involved an investigation of the US postal system and timing the
delivery of some 10,000 or so letters to the SPAM company requesting
free product for several quasi-religions that utilized it as a
sacrament... they had to hire a temp to sort it all out... if every rave
mailing list member decided to send some mail, one could create quite a
backlog in their public relations department... they do have to read
every single letter... what if someone saw their long lost son on the
"addicted to sex" article and wanted to track them down... or what if
someone actually had something positive to say... they'd need that for
reading over the air...

To: *B* <branka@sirius.com>
CC: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: E & seizures
References: <v03007802af126eb1b346@[205.178.41.41]>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

i ran mind-machines at raves in toronto for about 2 years and we had a
trend towards people on E being more susceptible to seizure type
reactions while on the machines...

mind-machines, in case you don't know, are devices that flash
full-spectrum light at specific frequecies that entrain the mind into
various states of consciousness... obviously not a toy for epileptics...

the reactions we'd commonly see with people on large quantities of E at
the peak of their experience ranged from eyelid blinking to facial
twitching to (and i only had one of these) a grand mal seizure... all
with people having no epileptic history...  we hypothesized that E
generates electrical activity in the brain that at times could become
the same as a seizure... i don't know if this is attirubutable to MDMA
or if it is because of impurities ala unsterile clandestine labs or cuts
in the E...  but there was a trend towards epileptic-like reactions to
the mind-machines... fortunately 98% of them were not uncomortable to
the user...


just athought....

the alchemist

Tony Rose wrote:
> 
> I know that I have seen some of this type of information on sfraves before
> but I cant seem to find it again...I am investigating making some type of
> after e packet to give/sell AT COST to people at parties. Something that
> contains all of the stuff that your body needs after taking e and dancing
> all night...can I get some leads on where to look for this or if some
> informed knowledgeable people can help me out that would be really cool,
> the compiled knowledge will be made available publically and will
> hopefully be making it into your scene...
> 
>

everyone who takes E should invest in the following ingredients for this
fabulous come-down rice-milk-shake:


blend


one quart of Rice Dream Rice Milk (Carob is best)
two bananas
three tablespoons cashew butter
two tablespoons powdered ginseng
one teaspoon spirulina
one half teaspoon liquid gingko biloba 
one half teaspoon liquid echinacea & goldenseal
one half to one teaspoon powdered ascorbic acid
ice if desired...


ginseng and gingko biloba act as excellent cleaning 
agents for the blood-brain barrier

vitamin c, spirulina and echinacheal & goldenseal boost
 the immune system

bananas and cashews help the body replenish lost seratonin

the rice milk is good for digestion

always consume some vitamin c from an organic source (if not a real
orange, than "not from concentrate" juice).

vitamin c evaporates into the atmosphere when exposed to air... so try
to stay away from concentrated juices... keep a lid on your OJ... or use
a juicer...

to buy all the ingredients (in Canadian $$$) runs around $50 to start
and then you should have enough for a couple months solid buying rice
milk and bananas thereon in...  beleive me, it's well worth it, and the
combination of banana, cashew butter and carob rice dream tastes great.


organic lab 023
the alchemist

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jan 27 23:44:47 1997

Subject: Timothy Leary's Declaration of Evolution (2.3 printed pages long)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The Declaration of Evolution

When in the course of organic evolution it becomes obvious that a
mutational process is inevitably dissolving the physical and
neurological bonds which connect the members of one generation to the
past and inevitably directing them to assume among the species of Earth
the separate and equal station to which the Laws of Nature and Nature's
God entitle them, a decent concern for the harmony of species requires
that the causes of the mutation should be declared. 

We hold these truths to be self evident: 

That all species are created different but equal; 
That they are endowed, each one, with certain inalienable rights; 
That among them are Freedom to Live, Freedom to Grow, and Freedom to
pursue Happiness in their own style; 

That to protect these God-given rights, social structures naturally
emerge, basing their authority on the principles of love of God
andrespect for all forms of life; 

That whenever any form of government becomes destructive of life,
liberty, and harmony, it is the organic duty of the young members of
that species to mutate, to drop out, to initiate a new social structure,
laying its foundations on such principles and organizing its power in
such form as seems likely to produce the safety, happiness, and harmony
of all sentient beings. 

Genetic wisdom, indeed, suggests that social structures long
established should not be discarded for frivolous reasons and transient
causes. The ecstasy of mutation is equally balanced by the pain.
Accordingly all experience shows that members of a species are more
disposed to suffer, while evils are sufferable, rather than to discard
the forms to which they are accustomed. 

But when a long train of abuses and usurpations, all pursuing
invariably the same destructive goals, threaten the very fabric of
organic life and the serene harmony of the planet, it is the right, it
is the organic duty to drop out of such morbid covenants and to evolve
new loving social structures.

Such has been the patient sufferance of the freedom-loving peoples of
this earth, and such is now the necessity which constrains us to form
new systems of government. 

The history of the white, menopausal, mendacious men now ruling the
planet earth is a history of repeated violation of the harmonious laws
of nature, all having the direct object of establishing a tyranny of the
materialistic aging over the gentle, the peace-loving, the young, the
colored.
To prove this, let Facts be submitted to the judgement of generations
to come. 

These old, white rulers have maintained a continuous war against other
species of life, enslaving and destroying at whim fowl, fish, animals
and spreading a lethal carpet of concrete and metal over the soft body
of earth. 
They have maintained as well a continual state of war among themselves
and against the colored races, the freedom-loving, the gentle, theyoung.
Genocide is their habit. 
They have instituted artificial scarcities, denying peaceful folk the
natural inheritance of earth's abundance and God's endowment. 
They have glorified material values and degraded the spiritual. 
They have claimed private, personal ownership of God'd land, driving by
force of arms the gentle from passage on the earth. 
In their greed they have erected artificial immigration and customs
barriers, preventing the free movement of people. 
In their lust for control they have set up systems of compulsory
education to coerce the minds of the children and to destroy the wisdom
and innocence of the playful young. 
In their lust for power they have controlled all means of communication
to prevent the free flow of ideas and to block loving exchanges among
the gentle. 
In their fear they have instituted great armies of secret police to spy
upon the privacy of the pacific. 
In their anger they have coerced the peaceful young against their will
to join their armies and to wage murderous wars against the young and
gentle of other countries. 
In their greed they have made the manufacture and selling of weapons
the basis of their economies. 
For profit they have polluted the air, the rivers, the seas. 
In their impotence they have glorified murder, violence, and unnatural
sex in their mass media. 
In their aging greed they have set up an economic system which favors
age over youth. 
They have in every way attempted to impose a robot uniformity and to
crush variety, individuality, and independence of thought. 
In their greed, they have instituted political systems which perpetuate
rule by the aging and force youth to choose between plasticconformity or
despairing alienation. 
They have invaded privacy by illegal search, unwarranted arrest, and
contemptuous harassment. 
They have enlisted an army of informers. 
In their greed they sponsor the consumption of deadly tars and sugars
and employ cruel and unusual punishment of the possession of life-giving
alkaloids and acids. 
They never admit a mistake. They unceasingly trumpet the virtue of
greed and war. In their advertising and in their manipulation of
information they make a fetish out of blatant falsity and pious
self-enhancement. Their obvious errors only stimulate them to greater
error and noisier self-approval. 
              
They are bores. 
They hate beauty. 
They hate sex. 
They hate life. 

       We have warned them from time to time to their inequities and
blindness. We have addressed every available appeal to their withered
sense of righteousness. We have tried to make them laugh. We have
prophesied in detail the terror they are perpetuating. But they have
been deaf to the weeping of the poor, the anguish of the colored, the
rocking mockery of the young, the warnings of their poets. Worshipping
only force and money,they listen only to force and money. But we shall
no longer talk in these grim tongues. 

       We must therefore acquiesce to genetic necessity, detach
ourselves from their uncaring madness and hold them henceforth as we
hold the rest of God's creatures - in harmony, life brothers, in their
excess, menaces to life. 

       We, therefore, God-loving, peace-loving, life-loving, fun-loving
men and women, appealing to the Supreme Judge of the Universe for the
rectitude of our intentions, do, in the name and by the Authority of all
sentient beings who seek gently to evolve on this planet, solemnly
publish and declare that we are free and independent, and that we are
absolved from all Allegiance to the United States Government and all
governments controlled by the menopausal, and that grouping ourselves
into tribes of like-minded fellows, we claim full power to live and move
on the land, obtain sustenance with our own hands and minds in the style
which seems sacred and holy to us, and to do all Acts and Things which
independent Freemen and Freewomen may of right do without infringing on
the same rights of other species and groups to do their own thing. 

And for the support of this Declaration of Evolution with a firm
reliance on the protection of Divine Providence, and serenely confident
of theapproval of generations to come, in whose name we speak, do we now
mutually pledge to each other our Lives, our Fortunes, and our Sacred
Honor. 

Author: Dr. Timothy Leary, Ph.D.

From: caedge@ix.netcom.com (Matt Likens )
Subject: First Contact 
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

First Contact was honestly one of the best parties that I've been to in 
quite a while.  The vibe was simply incredible!!!  Cimino tore it up.  
That was the first time I had ever seen him spin and I was impressed 
big time.  Tracy was amazing as usual.  I think one of the best things 
about this party is that towards the end of the night, I realized that 
not one person at this party approached me or any of my friends 
attempting to sell E or what not.  Don't get me wrong, I love E, but 
for some reason I honestly had no desire to put any drug into my system 
at this party because I was simply having A LOT of fun without it.  
The location was incredible.  Three good sized rooms, one of which had 
jungle going for a lot of the night which is a bonus for me.  There was 
a lot of room to dance.  In the main room, towards the back, Lightseed 
provided a movie theatre with trippy films and cartoons going the 
entire night.  
Basically, First Contact was an awesome party.  With a can of food the 
party was only $10 and I probably would have payed more.  The best 
thing about this party is that it benifitted the Headwaters, the 
C.B.C., and Food Not Bombs.  Kudos Lightseed, First Contact was the 
bomb!!!

Peace,

Matt

this seems to be my occassional Timothy Leary posting craze...

it is relevent however to observe the eight stages of consciousness as
Leary set out in his works "Neuropolitique", "Info-Psychology" and "The
Game of Life" as well as being echoed throughout the work of Robert
Anton Wilson ("Quantum Psychology") and Antero Alli ("Angel Tech: A
Modern Shaman's Guide To Reality Selection")... all these books are
available at most independent alternative thinking (occult, new age)
book shops and they are all published by New Falcon Press... 
"Neuropolitique" gives you basics... "Info-Psych." is very technical...
"The Game of Life" is very occult orientated... and the Alli and Wilson
books are set up sort of like text books with excercises (they're the
easiest reads for the initiate and the excercises can be fun in
groups)... I highly recommend checking them all out, and pick the one
that most suits you...



the eight stages have also been divided up into 24 stages where each
stage has an reception, integration, transmission phase... and Leary has
paralled this system (in the Game of Life) to most of the other occult
systems such as Qabbalah, The Tarot, I Ching and the Zodiac...


to the best of my recollection, i will review the 8 stages and apply
them to why psychedelic experience should be a right of passage into
adulthood... now there are exceptions to every rule, and the world being
a relative place could see the age of adulthood being 13 for some and 30
for others... it all depends on the development of the first four
stages...


CICUIT ONE: the bio-survival circuit>>>  this circuit is the infant who
is attracted / repulsed by things that nurture / threaten... this
circuit can be activated in later life in instances of life-or-death...
since our offspring are an extension of our consciousness through DNA,
this circuit has also been activated in instances of mothers lifting
volkswagons from pinned children...

CIRCUIT TWO:  although i forget the specific name of this circuit, it is
developed around "the terrible twos" as the infant/toddler attempts to
figure out what he/she can get away with... it is the ego figuring out
its status within the tribe... undeveloped second stage circuitry can
result in bullies in older years...
	 "Reality is what you can get away with" - R.A.W.

CIRCUIT THREE:  symbol/ dexterity circuitry>>> this is where the mind
develops language capacities and tool using skills... the capability of
navigating within this reality...

CIRCUIT FOUR:  the Socio-Sexual Circuit>>> this is where the adolescent
becomes the adult... it is figuring out the social patterns and sexual
imprinting that will carry the string of consciousness into its next
generation ultimately... our "first" experiences imprint, which is why
those who have a first experience with the same sex often become
homosexual... and which also explains the homophobia in many north
american males as they are subjected to moral dogma which dictates same
sex experience as being wrong... many people accidentaly imprint in very
casual circumstances like "playing doctor"... the conflict of experience
to imposed morality often causes the male to repress the experiences and
LOUDLY voice and reinforce the dogma...

CIRCUIT FIVE:  the somatic circuitry>>> this is the mind totally aware
of the body... marijuanna accesses this state... as do many forms of
meditation and martial arts...

CIRCUIT SIX:  this circuit is the brain aware of the hardware of the
brain...  in this stage one can reimprint any of the previous stages...
LSD accesses this stage which is why minds that have not fully imprinted
their previous stages risk becoming an acid casualty as they can
re-imprint their developing cicuitry every time, even though they don't
realize it... it would not be healthy to re-imprint while police raid a
party, or the power goes out and there is a lot of confusion... one can
see how delicate this imprinting time frame is, and it usually is a
window of about one second (to my experience, unless one consciously
maintains the window at its most open state)... you have this dilation
of reality into chaos... and then there's a moment where it all clicks
and comes together... and it seems to be downhill from there...

CIRCUIT SEVEN:  this is genetic consciousness which can be accessed
through large doses of psychedelics combined with the right diet...
this is the brain becoming aware of the language which programmed it in
the first place...

CIRCUIT EIGHT:  quantum consciousness>>> this is where you leave the
scale of consciousness and fuse with all around you... i wouldn't even
begin to attempt to describe it outside of a fractal equation... chaos.


i probably haven't done any of this justice, so please go and check out
the books, they're definitely worth the read...  everyone has a little
bit of a different slant on the 8 stages, which makes it a real existing
school of thought that is very relevent to psychedelic culture...

happy trails


timothy in your bandwidth...


the alchemist

	I say boycott it unless you want to be in some place that is just
completely unsafe and horribly dangerous. I was there for the first time
ever this weekend and I am surely not going back. I had the wonderful
pleasure of getting a serious electrical burn from some of the faulty
wiring there and all I was doing was sitting on the floor up against the
wall groovin' to some phat jungle. ;) Maybe it was my fault for not
examining the entire place for a safe spot to sit, I don't know.
	I don't really blame anyone for it, but I am choosing to take
myself out of a situation that I know to be a bad one. Just a warning to
those of you out there who don't already know the space... if you go there,
I suggest that you be as careful and aware of your surroundings as you
possibly can, you always should be, but in this place, definiteley be
careful.

jenn

this weekend, sorry about it getting busted and all the other crap that
came along. My support is with you guys.

like crap. I did notice that TT didn't seem to mind occasionally
clipping his amps, which is pretty much the kiss-of-death for speakers

I don't think cops have to search the net for a party to bust on a 
Saturday night.

Cops have beat areas that are relatively small.  A large gathering of cars
in an industrial area is suspicious.  A crowd, of course, is suspicious.
Even if they didn't notice the party already, cops also must respond to any
complaints from "neighbors" or anyone else.  And I'm sure they become
familiar very quickly with often-used locales like Stevenacme Alley, and
know to drive by on the weekend. 

Cops "own" their area of patrol.  A party going on - or a well-known party
locale - is pretty difficult to hide.  And we all know the economic forces
driving the crackdowns.  Cops must enfore permit fees and "legal" business
interests. 

N

The Happy Fire Marshall story reminded me of a funny thing I saw at 
Spundae... A big, beefy security dude stood at the edge of the dancefloor 
all night, headphones and perpetual tough-look on.  But the dancefloor 
was going OFF, and I knew the energy had to be contagious.  So I 
concentrated on him, willing him to feel the music and abandon the 
security attitude...I danced harder and harder, c'mon, security guy, 
dance dance!  And finally the music got the best of him, and he suddenly 
broke out of his rigid stance and went crazy right in front of the dj!

The music'll get them all, every time. :)

N

ALL,
	I believe making people happy is rave related, but some people.....


The top 18 signs you've hired the wrong clown for your child's party

18. By the end of the party, he's got every damn kid doing the "pull my
finger" trick.

17. Clown car must be started with breathalizer device.

16. Keeps screaming, "My name's not BO-zo, it's bo-ZO!"

15. References to Kierkegaard and Nietzsche are lost on most 5 year olds.

14. Props for his "disappearing" trick: a moving van and your wide-screen TV.

13. Scares the holy hell outta the kids during the "Severed Limb" trick.

12. Tells the kids he killed Barney in a blood match in Newark

11. Didn't bring balloons but managed to twist your dachshund into other
animal shapes.

10. Prefaces each trick with, "Here's a little number I learned in the      joint."

9. NOt exactly the Peewee Herman impression you were expecting.

8. Wears a t-shirt that says, "Drug-free since March!"

7. More interested in squirting seltzer into his Scotch than in his pants.

6. Those huge ears look too darn life-like, and the entire act consists of
showing charts and complaining about the deficit.

5. A sad clown is one thing - a clown who spends the entire party with a gunto his temple is another thing entirely.

4. Only balloon animals he can make are a snake and a "snake on acid."

3. Business cards include the phrase, "From the mind of Stephen King."    

2. Price list includes "lap dance" and "around the world."
and the number 1 sign you've hired the wrong clown for your child's party
.. . 
1. All the balloon animals are ribbed and lubricated. 




----- End Included Message -----



----- End Included Message -----

Yes, I noticed the firemarshall at GaiaMind and decided that the best
thing to do would be to make him welcome, so I ended up chatting with
him for probably about an hour! He was a really nice guy, just doing
his job and making sure people were safe. I asked him what he was looking
for (enough exits and correctly placed fire extinguishers), I also asked
about the permit process from his point of view, and in general we had
a very pleasant chat (I even took his photo! He struck a very "official"
pose and said he didn't want it to appear that he was condoning anything!).
Sounds like the fire department and police department have very different
agendas - he didn't know too much about the legal side of things vis-a-vis
underage kids or whatever - all he was concerned about was safety. And he
was having a great time! He said the last event he had inspected at SOMAR
was a "devil worshipping party" (!), so this by comparison was a very 
healthy crowd! 

I definitely agree that the presence of a happy fire-marshall will do a lot
to discourage overzealous cops from busting an event. If people go out of
their way to welcome fire-marshalls, it'll certainly help defuse the 
likelihood of a bust, and maybe even make for a better overall relationship
with the authorities. If First Contact got Fire-Marshall Bill again, he
was already on our side! Glad to hear it went off so well!

- Martin  =]

[enter Tim, face flushed with excitement]

U2! U2! U2!  Given the trend of their last three albums, I should've
noticed sooner that they'd be the torchbearers for bringing techno
outside!  
"We were born from the underground, and that's where U2 is going back to.
And the underground music is infinitely more interesting than what you
hear over the radiowaves, and we're trying to alert the world to this!
It's revolutionary but not necessarily evolutionary, though--you can
find the roots of techno all the way back in the mud of the delta blues,
and the hip-shaking of R&B.  It's just taking on a whole new form.."
						-U2's Bono

POP can be purchased from your local evil and capitalistic record store
on March 4.  Because advertisers want to brainwash you, they will put
the record in a highly visible place, probably near the fron of the store,
so it'll be easy to spot. ;)

Their most shameless fan,
Timothy 


On Mon, 27 Jan 1997, pauly wrote:

> THE FRIGGIN' WALL STREET JOURNAL?
> 
>  Will Pulsing Techno Sound                Rev Up the Music Business?
>                By PATRICK M. REILLY                 Staff Reporter of
> THE WALL STREET JOURNAL
> 
>                When Tommy Tunes, Frankie Bones and Adam X
> took                the stage recently at the Asbury Park, N.J.,
> Convention                Hall, it didn't look like any ordinary rock
> concert.
>                Instead of guitars, the performers jammed on
> computer                gear and sound machines. One performer wowed
> the                crowd with a PC, his fingers flying over the
> keyboard                and unleashing brief snippets of recorded music
> and                sounds from the machine's hard drive. They filled
> the                arena with an entrancing sound known as "techno"
> --                electronic dance music with a driving beat,
> psychedelic                sound distortion and occasional lyrics that
> consist largely                of hypnotically repeated phrases.
>                Long played in the underground culture of
> "raves,"                all-night dance parties fueled by the
> euphoria-inducing                drug Ecstasy, techno music is breaking
> into the                mainstream. And record companies -- desperate
> for the                Next Big Thing amid two years of flat music sales
> and a                sense that "alternative" rock is flagging -- are
> starting to                place their bets on the growing genre.
>                Its stars include the influential Chemical Brothers, on
> the                Astralwerks label of EMI Group PLC; the
> powerful                U.K. band Prodigy, on the independent label
> Mute                Records; Orbital, a duo on the Ffrr label of
> PolyGram                NV; and Goldie, another Ffrr artist who features
> a                "techno/jungle" sound that mixes soul, hip-hop,
> reggae                and pulsating beats of 160 per minute or higher.
>                EMI's Caroline Records, known as an
> alternative-rock                launching pad, is trimming its rock
> roster to make a big                push for techno. Influential radio
> stations are now                playing more techno music; KROQ in Los
> Angeles has                had Orbital and Prodigy on its closely
> watched playlist,                and have played the Chemical Brothers.
> "Music for the                Jilted Generation," a two-year-old record
> by Prodigy,                has seen sales shoot up in the past six
> months, and now                Time Warner Inc. is trying to snap it up.
>                "Until the sales of Chemical Brothers and Prodigy
> made                noises, there was no point in the majors investing,"
> says                Mark Fotiadis, general manager of Prodigy's U.S.
> label                Mute Records. "But they like to say sales can
> cure                cancer."
>                But the selling of techno poses some
> significant                marketing problems for the music industry.
> The genre                has few recognizable performers who look good
> on                videos and album covers. Its stars are as
> much                producers, engineers and DJs as they are
> performers.                Furthermore, turning atmospheric electronic
> tracks into                hit singles will be tricky, since they
> usually don't fit the                three- to four-minute format of
> most radio hits and                rarely have lyrics. (Chemical
> Brothers' breakout hit                "Setting Sun," has a spacey,
> mantra-like refrain: "I tell                you that it's just too
> bad.")
>                "The challenge is to establish clear-cut artists in
> the                dance techno market. Club people love it, but how
> do                you spread it to a wider demographic?" says
> Gary                Arnold, vice president of marketing of Best Buy Co.,
> a                major music retailer. Mr. Arnold says
> techno's                popularity mystifies him. "As a consumer I don't
> get it --                but my 18-year-old daughter loves it."
>                Mystifying as it may be to an older generation,
> the                techno sound is starting to creep into American
> pop                culture. The Gap plays the electronic artist Goldie
> on its                in-store music tapes. TV ads for the Microsoft
> Network                use a techno-like sound from the Los
> Angeles                producers known as Dust Brothers. MTV,
> bellwether                of virtually every music trend of the past 15
> years, cut its                hours of rock and rap videos and added a
> new techno                show called "Amp." U2, whose brooding
> alternative                rock made it one of the world's most popular
> bands, is                shifting gears on its March release with
> several songs its                label executives describe as "more
> electronic, techno,                more experimental."
>                The U2 record will open "a lot of pop and
> rock                people's minds to new sounds," says Jim Welch,
> a                former director of artists and repertoire at Sony
> Corp.'s                Sony Music's Columbia Records. "It will be a new
> kind                of crossover."
>                Record executives say the techno trend also heralds
> a                turn in American youth culture. They say young
> concert                goers and CD buyers are burned out on the anxiety
> and                grit of alternative rock and rap, the last two genres
> that                ignited blockbuster music sales. Last year,
> anticipated                releases from alternative rock groups like
> Pearl Jam had                disappointing sales, while the number of
> radio stations                with rap formats declined.
>                Perhaps in reaction to rock's intensity, there's a
> market                today for a more upbeat, unconfrontational sound.
> An                executive at a major U.S. record label sensed the
> signs                of a new market when he caught a recent New
> York                show by the Chemical Brothers, "The dancing
> never                stopped and there wasn't a bad vibe in the room,"
> he                says.
>                The rave scene still carries with it an association
> with                drugs, the kind needed to stay up all night and
> dance.                But as raves and techno music go mainstream,
> safer                alternatives are appearing. To counter the
> stereotype of                drugs at raves, Robb Hart, a co-head of the
> Watermark                label, runs a sister company called Pure
> Children, which                puts on squeaky-clean raves -- complete
> with security                battalions to check for weapons and drugs.
> "The rave                scene gets a bad rap," says Mr. Hart. "Most
> kids are                there to hold hands. They are lost and need to
> hold                somebody ... It's very communal."
>                At the New Year's Eve rave at Asbury Park,
> where                teenagers danced from 11 p.m. to 9 a.m. to the beat
> of                techno music, 20-year-old Andrew Deming was
> on                hand for more than just the music. "What I like
> about                raving is it's a place you can go for 12 hours and
> be                warm and listen to music with friends," he says.
> "You                can do what you want and be yourself. There
> aren't                many places like that any more."
>                What about alternative rock and grunge? "Pearl
> Jam                and Soundgarden are all sold out and cheesy
> and                played out on the radio. Everybody sounds like
> them,"                says Mr. Deming.
> 
> ____________________________________________________ x-radio ____
> ____ http://www.x-radio.com/ ____________________________________
> 
>

hi. my name is philip. i am a graphic designer and architecture student
and "the fuken bomb" according to meri. i have no job. i used to have
one, but i moved to san francisco last week and figured the commute to
san jose would be hell. i was right. i took CalTrain to san jose this
morning. eek. loooooooong, leisurely roll down the peninsula... fine
every so often, but not something i'd want to do on a daily basis.
ANYWAY, i digress. i'm basically posting this hoping that it will save
me a bunch of searching, but i'm not counting on it. sooo...if anyone
knows of any design/production artist positions (especially in the
advertising or architecture fields), please let me know! i once read
that something like 70% of jobs are filled by word-of-mouth
(word-of-email?) references. fishing through the classifieds sucks,
although that's how i found my last job/internment. part time or full
time welcome, although i think that another 40 hr/wk job will just make
me go kookoo. freelance? sure!

thanks for your time. :)
philip-yeah-i'll-design-your-party-fliers-and-i'm-good-at-it-too-diaz

Eric Pederson wrote:
> 
> Deepfog writes...
> > well, i don't know...when we fax-bombed 20/20, they got the message
> > REAL good.  They not only couldn't receive anything else for 3 days, they
> > had to change their fax number twice.  Of course, we found out what the new
> > one was.
> 
> yeah they got the message that ravers are a bunch of malicious idiots.

Yeah, swallow your pride, folks!  The media loves to pigeonhole special
interest groups, ethnic groups, etc.  There are some really important
things that we've done such as support Headwaters, CBC, the Rainforest,
Food not Bombs, just by showing up to these parties. So many wonderful
people I see in this city, smilin', whenever people seem to have a grip
on a way of life that really works, others who are not "tapped in" have
a need to blame it on the drugs.  It's just way that the U.S. media
distracting us from our real problems.  It's like were starting a new
Counter Culture like in the 60's, so it's bound to be misunderstood by
the ignorant.

One thing I've learned is that no press is bad press.  Any soundbyte or
quote for empty minds to chew on, keeps 'em busy.  The 20/20 segment is
a trite issue when a every second the rainforest is being cut at the
rate of a foot a second, or when there are Feds saying that Prop 215 is
invalid.  

Keep on dancin', mixin', playing, recording, recycling, supporting good
causes, and quit worrying about our image!  We know we're right and it's
obvious.

--Goldilox

(Galactic Dreamspell)-- Yeah, the sound really sucked that night, but we
tried our hardest to put on a good show.  We couldn't hear anything on
stage and we've definitely had better shows.  Pseudopagan???  At least
you are half right. The common misconception of New Age dogmas is that
Paganism and New Age Spirituality, and even Astrology, is Satanism. 
Fire is one of the four Earth "elements" and Christianity associated it
with Satan. 
The whole backbone of throwing Gaiamind (on Jan 23 specifically) was the
planetary alignment, (Won't happen for another 26,000 years the way it
did on Thurs!!) the dawning of the Age of Aquarius, which is the end of
the age of Pisces, which dawned when Jesus was born and the religous
symbol was the Fish, --and of course, the benefit for Headwaters.  
Thanks for coming, though.  Promise next time we'll sound better.

Well, that's all very interesting, but:

alchemist@internity.on.ca wrote:
>
> The history of the white, menopausal, mendacious men...

"menopausal...men?"  I can't say I've run into very many of those...
But then, if they were mendacious, perhaps they were lying about
being menopausal?

> In their impotence they have glorified murder, violence, and unnatural
> sex in their mass media.

"Unnatural sex?"  Would Mr. Leary have been a homophobe?  I wouldn't
think so, but what kind of "unnatural sex" was he referring to in our
mass media?

> In their greed they sponsor the consumption of deadly tars and sugars
> and employ cruel and unusual punishment of the possession of life-giving
> alkaloids and acids.

"Life-giving alkaloids and acids."  I don't think there's any mystery
here that Mr. Leary is referring to LSD and other psychoactive drugs.
I would hardly call those "life-giving."

> They are bores.

That's hardly a crime.

> They hate beauty.
> They hate sex.
> They hate life.

These are emotional jabs, not facts.

> ...and all governments controlled by the menopausal, ...

Ah, the menopausal governments again.  How evil menopause must be...?

OTHERWISE, that was a very good diatribe...

S

On Sat, 25 Jan 1997, Anthony E wrote:

> 2) E is rarely laced with heroin since heroin is already expensive as it is.
> The addictive effects of this opiate can only be gained thru intravenous
> injection or if you have taken too much of it at one time.

	Or through snorting it.

> 3) I rarely see Ketamine being used in the dance scene since K will often
> immobilize you while you trip on it.  

	It's supposed to be big out east.

> 4) Being sober at a rave doesn't make you stick out like a sore thumb....  I
> have raved soberr a lot of times and I don't think I stuck out like a sore
> thumb and I do admire people who can enjoy the vibe sober. 

	Here at least. They seemed to be talking solely about the east 
coast which from what I hear is completely different to out west...

> 5) 20/20 featured a dance concert not a rave!  There is no such thing as an
> underground party being attended by kids from 8 different states.

	This is typical for the east coast. People gather from about half 
way up and down the coast. They drive 4+ hours to go out without finding 
it a pain in the ass (it's half of the adventure from what I got when I 
was on ne-raves).
	
> 6) They said that we don't want to take our parents to a rave.  Not true,  I
> have friends who have taken their parents to a rave so that both parents and
> children could enjoy the vibe.  

	Not all people want their parents to go to a rave. I wouldn't 
want to bring my parents to a Harmony, but I would take them to a full 
moon or a party I am involved with...

> 
> >Don't live in denial!
> >
> We are not.  The media is pushing on enforcing a ban on raves.  Don't you
> see it coming?

	Some raves are pretty much exactly what 20/20 reported on, but
there are other types and that is where 20/20 lacked integrity. They
reported solely on one side of the "rave" phenoneum and didn't even seem
to be looking into what it encompasses in other places than Flordia and
parts of New York. They reported on an evil scruge maybe, but portrayed
that evil scruge as encompassing far more than it really does. 20/20 heard
about something that even a lot of people in the SF scence would probably
be shocked by if it was true (10 years olds strung out on e in Flordia? 
If that's true, that certainly isn't the same scence I am part of.. But 
the thing is I couldn't tell how much of that report was sensationalism 
and how much was accurate). But they didn't report on any of the aspects 
that we have come to know as raves, especially the underground raves that 
they were supposedly talking about... So 20/20 did a real good job at 
alientating those who go to raves and parents. They drew a division in a 
segment of the population of ravers and their parents for who raves are one 
thing and what 20/20 portrayed is another. In trying to "protect" teenagers 
(or maybe protect parents feelings?), 20/20 increased the division 
between parents and teenagers though providing parents with a view of 
"reality" that was not the same reality that the teens experienced. The 
parents assume the teen is lying because the 20/20 report made raves out 
to be, as I think Wayne said, drug distribution networks.

dave

From: SDream <SDream@tgrigsby.com>
Reply-To: SDream@tgrigsby.com
X-Mailer: Mozilla 3.0 (WinNT; U)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Ants Raving at my company
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

There's been a problem with ants lately in the office building I work
at  in Redwood Shores.  Seems with all the rain, they've been taking
refuge in the offices.  The building management has tried spraying, but
to no avail, so they sent out a memo to ask us all to not leave food or
empty soda cans laying out.

The line I found funny was:

"...Above all, don't leave goodies such as lefover birthday cake sitting
around overnight.  Our ants then send party invitations to their friends
at Oracle and they have a rave at our expense!"

This leads me to ask a few questions:

1.  Do the ants advertise on SFRaves?  I think Derek has been remiss in
listing these events on the calendar.

2.  Who is spinning for them?  DJ Logcat? 

3.  Are they having problems with tough guy aardvarks showing up and
ruining the vibe?

4.  When someone yells "Raid", are they talking about the cops or the
spray?

5.  When ants say the party is "underground" does that mean it's a
secret or that it's in someone's private anthill?

6.  Do ants wear baggies?

7.  Don't they have to be really careful with the lasers so they don't
burn themselves up?

8.  Now that we know ants rave, shouldn't we be inviting them?  Think
how much easier clean up would be...

S

From: Diane_Tabellija@xn.xerox.com (Tabellija,Diane)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: 20/20 Retaliation
Message-Id: <"<3E51EE32813E657C>3E51EE32813E657C@X-PA-PAHV-MS4.XN"@-SMF->
Cc: iam@chosen.org ("?[Oo]?")
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

As I grow wiser (so I like to think ;)  I'm beginning to understand a 
 friend's comment about picking your fights (or causes) wisely.  So 
 many times I've reacted to situations rather than being proactive.  
 And in the end, did I change anything, or anyone's opinion?  Living by 
 example is probably the best remedy here.

Rather than giving 20/20 cause to react to any negative actions of 
 their judgement  (e.g., mailbombing), why not put some energy into 
 positive enhancements for the rave community?  And then 20/20 and 
 others will pass a new judgement on how creative and affirming raves 
 can be.  Acknowledging our downsides and doing something about it is 
 much more effective.  Proactive examples are:  Geoff White's 
 suggestion of creating a RaveMed team a while back,  Tony Rose's E 
 pamphlet, health & drug education referral tables, setting up benefits 
 that support an aids project or youth center, etc.

Just MHO...

Love and light,
Diane
----------

Special K, or ketamine, is a tranquilizer used for both HUMANS and
ANIMALS...

I agree, it is not a very good drug for a party or to dance on, but the
trip you go on is absolutely amazing! Some people dislike it (mostly
because of what they have heard about it), but I personally thoroughly
enjoyed it, not as a drug to be used often, but it was a very spiritual
journey. I was <underline>completely removed</underline> from my
surroundings, left only with my thoughts, and my God.


Read up on it at hyperreal, there should be a whole bunch of information
there.

A different Rave angle in a more respected media... </troy>

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Hey, what do you know??  A mainstream article about techno and its actually
positive???

In Yesterday's Wall Street Journal (who knew?) on the front page of the
Marketplace section is an article titled "Will Pulsing 'Techno' Sound Rev Up
Music Business?"

It goes on to talk about sagging record sales of alternative rock last year and
how many major labels are now looking to artists like The Chem. Bros, Prodigy
and Goldie as "the next big thing."  It also discusses the difficulty of
marketing faceless music to the mainstream.  

Sure, people can yell and scream to keep it underground, but at least this WSJ
writer seems to get the fact that the scene is something important and seems to
treat the scene with some respect in the piece.  (sorry i can't type the whole
article for ya)

-Brad   


Here's a couple of excerpts:

"An executive at a major U.S. label sensed the signs of a new market when he
caught a recent New York show by the Chemical Bros, 'The dancing never stopped
and there wasn't a bad vibe in the room"

On the subject or raves and drugs:

"The rave scene still carries with it an association with drugs, the kind needed
to stay up all night and dance.  But as raves and techno music go mainstream,
safer alternatives are appearing.  To counter the stereotype of drugs at raves,
Robb Hart, a co-head of the Watermark label, runs a sister company called Pure
Children, which puts on squeaky-clean raves - complete with security battalions
to check for weapons and drugs.  'The rave scene gets a bad rap,' says Mr. Hart.
'Most kids are there to hold hands.  They are lost and need toold
somebody...It's very communal.'  At the New Year's Eve rave at Ashbury Park,
where teenagers danced from 11-9am to the beat of techno music, 20-year-old
Andrew Deming was on hand for more than just the music.  'What I like about
raving is it's a place you can go for 12 hours and be warm and listen to music
with your friends,' he says. 'You can do what you want and be yourself.  There
aren't many places like that any more."

What about alternative rock and grunge? "Pearl Jam and Soundgarden are all sould
out and cheesy and played out on the radio.  Everybody sounds like them," says
Mr. Deming.

  While reading an article in some book on overall health and well being, I
noticed a section on why it is vital to your health to have some spiritual
aspects to you life.  Without some sense of higher purpose you cannot be
truly healthy.  Part of it read as follows....

          Spiritual health involves your relationship to other living things
and the role of spiritual direction in your life.  This description means
various things to people.  For some people, spiritual health is defined by a
religion.  For others, it involves understanding your individual purpose in
life.  Being spiritually healthy means you are working to achieve your
spiritual potential, to find harmony in living.  You are at peace with
yourself and those around you.

      I suppose this means raving is a valid form of a healthy lifestyle.
 Should this be included in our list of reasons as to why raving is necessary
to people?  The headlines should read something like, "Raving Found to Save
Lives" or "Need to be Healthier?  Go to a Rave".  Not to mention all the
exercise you are getting from dancing all night.   Have a good day.

         hugs,
           'trice                 <<<<RAVEON>>>>

> elephants head....i may be wrong...
>  

	My take on this is that God/dess manifests any way He/She/It
wants to. Don't put your limits on the forms God can or can't take. 
He/She/It will surprise you every single time. This belief works for
me. Take it if you like, or ignore it if you don't.

	But the story of Ganesh is really beautiful. Did you know 
that He has an elephant's head because His own father, who was also
God, killed Him by cutting His original human head off? Really, you
should understand the myth behind the form before dismissing the form
as silly...

what you're saying is true, then there really is no show."

that.  these were the outtakes that weren't televised to make their story

television market.

Dear Dorena C. Bernabe:

Thank you for your note regarding our segment on RAVES.  We made serious 
note of your comments and have shared them with others at the program and at 
ABC News.

We regret that our presentation met with your disfavor. Our goal is to 
present news stories fairly, and although some of our viewers may have

From: DorenaB @ SMTP (DorenaB) {DorenaB@aol.com}
To: 2020
Subject: Raves
Date: Fri, Jan 24, 1997 3:02AM

Dear 2020,
     My name is Dorena C. Bernabe and I am from San Jose, California. I'm 21
yrs old and I go to school and work full-time. I am also a full-time raver
     I started raving 3 yrs ago, because of my love of house music and of
people. I was tired of going to clubs that were like meat markets. I was 
also
tired of the violence that could errupt at anytime in clubs because of mass
alcohol consumption. In the rave scene, I found a place where i could just
have a good time. I was able to dance all night without being hassled by
drunken men or anyone else. I raved because of the positive vibe that was
present.
     I won't deny that there are drugs in the scene. But, i will say that
true ravers don't need drugs to have a good time. We have fun whether we are
sober or we are on Ecstasy or any other drug. you don't stick out like a 
sore
thumb if you are not on drugs ar a rave. The only way you stick out, is if
you have a negative attitude. If you rave just for the drugs, then you are
raving for the wrong reasons. Raving is all about PLUR. PLUR stands for
Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect.
     I won't deny that I do drugs on occasion, but that isn't the reason why
I rave. If I were in it just for the drugs, I would have burned out a long
time ago. Drugs get old fast. I rave because I love house music and I love 
to
dance. When I have been grooving for close to 6 hours to some good house
beats, I feel uplifted. House music is like the gospel to me. When I listen
and dance to it, it's tremendously religious. i experience inner peace when 
I
am raving. I know that a lot of kids that rave feel the exact same way I do.
We rave because we love the music and we love our scene.
    I am livid that your report is going to cast raving in a very negative
light. You never look for the positivity that makes raving what it is. Your
report is misinforming the general public about our scene. The drugs don't
factor into the experience. If you wanted to know about raving, then you
should have gone to some real raves and looked for real ravers. They would
tell you what it is all about. It's about PLUR.
     If you decide to do a follow up piece to your report, I would be more
than happy to participate in it. Here is my addres and my phone number:
Dorena C. Bernabe
2595 Glen Alma Way
San Jose, CA. 95148
(408) 238-4205

Sincerely,

Dorena C. Bernabe
Right Front Speaker Family San Francisco

Okay i have to give my $2 (hey, it's in canadian funds) on this whole 
thing.  A friend and i were discussing the raves/bad media/drugs issue 
etc. and the fact is, that a very large proportion of people who go to 
raves take illegal drugs.  There are NOT many people who go sXe.  This is 
a fact you must accept, and the media jumps on it because it's very 
true.  Also, many of the younger kids who are out at these events are 
taking substances which they have no information about, and they don't 
even know the ppl they're purchasing from.  I'm sure you will also admit 
that this is true.  

The whole angle of the media reports that i have seen have been aimed
straight at the "normal" parents, who are a HUGE majority in this country. 
If you had a child, regardless of your view on the scene, would you like
to be told that your ten-year-old was out somewhere without your knowledge
ingesting something that could be anything?  Even i shudder when i 
visualize this scenario, and i'm a fairly regular drug-user.

The fact is, having raves is no more a "right" than having a giant 
unauthorized alcohol festival.  Cops would shut that down just as fast, 
for pretty much the same reasons, and the press would cover them in the 
same way.

I too wish that we could all party undisturbed and that everyone who went 
raving was intelligent and responsible abou;the drugs they choose to 
ingest, if any.  But this just ain't gonna happen in today's 
instant-gratification let's-do-it-NOW-who-cares-about-the-consequences 
society.  What all the negative mdeia WILL do, however, is to help keep 
the giant money-sucking huge 4,000+ gigs down and help the smaller, 
undergroubd scene to blossom and grow.  That's not so bad, IMHO.

pounce

Nuggles the Whump-Whump bird flew quietly above the wonderful greenness of
Happy-Tree Meadow, eagerly awaiting the cheerful humming that always
signalled the beginning of the Gubbywub Parade and Picnic, which annually
provided the Whump-Whumps with enough Gubbywub fur and flesh to last the
entire winter.
                                         - Bruce K. MacDonald
                                           Scarborough, Ont.

In-Reply-To: <199701290018.QAA10852@lithuania.it.earthlink.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.970128214614.16528H-100000@am.UCSC.EDU>
