 Hi Regina!  ]=)


 First off let me say that I appreciate your response as well as all the 
others. Each has shown me something and taught me something. And more 
than a little healing has occured.  :)

 I would just like to respond to a few things you mention;



 On Tue, 28 Jan 1997, Regina Flores wrote:

> I think it is a shame that there can
> not be trust with in individuals with in this "rave family."

 True, but as any other group there is a mix. Some good, some bad, most 
pretty middle of the road. Of course this is all relative within each 
group. One groups good may not make that same label in another group.


>  If someone
> stole a cord that's too bad.

 I'm sorry if I'm misinterperting your intention here but that sounds 
pretty callous. Cables are not cheap (typically from $20 up to a $100 or 
more). I am really poor. Each cable has been carefully considered for 
it's need and worth in my equipment reality. When the cable enters my 
reality it is cared for in a very tender fashion (much to the dismay of 
those that work with me  :). There is a whole cable-zen philosophy I 
have adopted with cables. And what I do with my equipment is as close to 
a religious ceromony as I come to in public. (most of my personal 
religious stuff I tend to in private)

 Not to mention _who_ stole it. A person who insisted I was her friend. 
Someone I helped right after she left an abusive boyfriend. Someone I was 
very attracted to but never asked out or made a pass at her BECAUSE 
she had just left an abusive relationship.


>  There are many other beautiful deeds that
> have been done at raves.

 True. A lot of it done with my equipment. I have worked a lot of free 
parties, benefits, supplied a back-up spot for a birthday girl I didn't 
know. I'm probably much more aware of beautiful deeds done at raves then 
you are by virtue of how long I've been doing it and my level of 
commitment to the scene.


>  Look, we do not need to dwell in the past, because
> life is too short.

 So who is dwelling?

>  Let the natural world of Karma take care of the
> punishing.

 I am part of that natural world of Karma. Why is it if the world does 
something out of Karma it is okay, but not if a person does something as 
an agent of Karma?


>  In the mean time don't lend things out that are too expensive or
> valuable that will ruin your expieriance at the rave if they get lost.

 Sure. Then people start headtripping me on how I'm not supporting the 
scene and such. As I stated; due to certain fuckups I am not lending my 
equipment out. I never wanted to in the first place but I always want to 
help a party go off. I guess I'm just stupid that way.


> Remember the whole purpose behind raves and why we put so much time and
> energy into making them happen.

 I think that is different for everyone. I know I have more than one 
reason why I put up with so many jerks and problems. Sure. Take the easy 
way out and say "Randy, it's just a reflection of you." or "If you don't 
like it don't do it". Except for every thief, jerk and idiot there are a 
hundred shinying people who love what I'm doing. I'm there for them. And 
the challenges of the problem people and problems are like a mountain to 
climb for me. I want to make it work despite the problems.  :) Just the 
capricorn in me I guess.



>  This is a revolution that we're a part of.
> A revolution to spread consiousness.  If one person hasn't learned to "turn
> the switch on" don't let him/her ruin for the rest of us. 

 Exactly. That is why I'm calling an alert on this individual. So the 
rest of us who are working so hard at providing revolutionary change in 
society _have_ a chance to do it. Whenever we get hit by these kind of 
people it slows down the process. Although I'm starting to believe that 
this situation is another aspect of the evolution of society.



> Gee Wiz!  If it
> is really that big of a deal I'll buy a new cord for who ever lost it.

 Well Dionysus Dreams is allways accepting donations for new equipment (I 
could really use a van!!  :) 

 The cord was returned two days later by the person who "misplaced" it. 
And the person who originally borrowed it had already agreed to replace 
it if neccessary. Which is MUCH more than what the individual entrusted 
with it offered (not even an apology).


>  The
> movement is all that matters, waking up the minds if the future
> generation!!! 

 To move one needs to look where one is going. To avoid treacherous 
pitfalls and such.


> Don't get ditracted by one person who stole a cord.  Put it
> behind you and think of what you can do to make sure that people see the
> light and never engage in such activities again.  Shed some light on the
> situation!!!

 I'm not distracted. I'm far to busy working two jobs and being a full 
time university student AND raving, to be caught up in such a petty thing 
as a missing cable. Again it's not so much the cable but how I was 
treated by someone who called me her friend. My way of shedding light was 
to reveal what occured;     "and the truth shall set you free"




>                         Keep Love in your Heart,
>                                 I Love You

 Thank you!  =) Despite the fact I may not agree with you (and others) on 
certain issues, I deeply appreciate the effort and time people have taken 
to talk about this situation.

in Love and humility,


Ran D.Dreams

special K is HUGE at some parties out east... there's a company in
Toronto called Destiny where I've found at least 50% of the crowd is on
K  (most are on "E" that is really K)... it has FX similar to PCP
although when injected somewhere around your shoulders (i don't know the
specific spot, having never done it) it has been called one of the most
psychedelic experiences around... i question that... as far as other
areas out east i know that K is really big in some factions of New York
and there's quite a few people that get into it from Detroit... i don't
have any opinion on it other than that i don't like spinning to a crowd
on K, they're very unresponsive... must be the tranquilizer effect...


d

At 02:47 PM 1/28/97 -0800, you wrote:
>At 02:24 PM 1/28/97 +0000, you wrote:
>>>  3) I rarely see Ketamine being used in the dance scene since K will often
>>> > immobilize you while you trip on it.  
>>> 
>>>         It's supposed to be big out east.
>>
>>
>>Isn't that what you call special K?  If so, that's what you give  horses
>>when you need to tranquilize them!!!  And, it is common out east, but
>>I've only known few people to actually go there.
>>
>>--Goldilox
>>
>
>Special K, or ketamine, is a tranquilizer used for both HUMANS and ANIMALS...
>I agree, it is not a very good drug for a party or to dance on, but the
trip you go on is absolutely amazing! Some people dislike it (mostly because
of what they have heard about it), but I personally thoroughly enjoyed it,
not as a drug to be used often, but it was a very spiritual journey. I was
completely removed from my surroundings, left only with my thoughts, and my God.
>
>Read up on it at hyperreal, there should be a whole bunch of information there.
>

It is a SCARY but enjoyable trip.  I've tried almost every psychidelic drug
available and K has some profound effects to the mind, body, and soul.
Imagine being separated from your body, you're only a soul, alone.... Then
you see yourself lying down on the floor not breathing.... you try to make
yourself breathe and your body responds even tho you're 2 feet away from it.
On other times i would be able to channel my senses to a single part of my
body, like being able to concentrate my soul on that part.  It is an amazing
trip but it often scares me, like acid.    If you plan on doing any kind of
drug please read up on it before you do anything, specially K.  Make sure
you are prepared for the kind of journey that i have described and make sure
you are physically, emotionally, spiritually, and mentally fit and remember
the powers of positive thinking.

SLURP (Starbursts, Love, Unity, Respect, and Peace),
Anthony E

Subject: Re: I'm down...
References: <Pine.3.89.9701281755.A10327-0100000@opus.vcn.bc.ca>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Karen Hardie wrote:
>>>
Also, many of the younger kids who are out at these events are 
taking substances which they have no information about, and they don't
even know the ppl they're purchasing from.  I'm sure you will also admit
that this is true.  
>>>

I'm sick of closing my eyes to this. This was one aspect of the show
that really struck me. Not that I didn't know about it. Indeed, the
person who took my ticket at the door last fri was sixteen. Hearing it
from Mr. TV really made me realise that this is something that I have a
problem with. A lot of people who are activly part of colletives are
under eighteen and sometimes this little voice inside me wants to tell
them "Hey! Shouldn't you be puting this kind of energy twards your
schoolwork instead?" (Sorry for sounding like your mom).

	If youre at least 18 you should be able to make your own educated
choices about what goes into your body. But how the hell do you tell a
fifteen or sixteen year old that MDMA will lower your seritonin and
dophamine levels, you need to take antitoxants afterward or even the
difference between Methanphamine, MDMA, MDA, Keptiane(sp), LSD,
Mescaline, and MDEA? These are all things you should know BEFORE you
take E. Kids aren't going to know this.

So I ask myself, can I continue to participte in this kind of setting?
Can I conciously help throw or just go to another party knowing I am
evangilising an activity that facilitates the ignorant use of something
like E by kids as young as 15? I can't lie to myself much longer.

Heh ;)  Glad you have a sense of humour about it.

Sounds like I jumped in without really knowing the background.  Sorry
about that.  On the other hand, I do believe in "taking the high road"
whenever possible, although like most, I struggle to practice what I
preach.

Something that your response made me realize, is that taking the high
road doesn't mean never doing anything annoying or even possibly illegal.
There are probably laws against fax-bombing someone, but that doesn't
_make_ it inherently injurious to do so (what a revelation that is),
and if it can help you acheive your goals, so be it.  But, watch
yer karma-meter =)

This discussion is probably stretching the bounds of rave-relatedness,
I hoped to provide some moderation for the brewing mod mentality
("bomb 'em, yeah, we'll show 'em").

Peace,

-scott

actually the Ward Valley radioactive waste dump, following a similar event
last year in LA.  But it would be a good opportunity for any other sort of

like a civil disobedience thing--deliberately and overtly breaking the
rules you're protesting against--but they might complement each well.

night...

This account is entirely personal.


Special K and Nitrous Oxide are very looked down upon by many people -
such as though speed is. I have tried many drugs, including the three I
had just mentioned. Now speed has never done anything outstanding for me
(besides keeping me awake when my body NEEDS sleep) =oP , and I had told
you in an earlier message that I really enjoyed the Special K trips I
have had. Here are my thoughts on Nitrous Oxide.


Nitrous Oxide is (like many drugs) safe, if you are being careful. This
drug, like K, is not a great drug for doing at parties. I hate Whip-its
(the little whip cream compressor carteidges), but medical grade nitrous
oxide has had a profound effect on my life. 


Most people I know like taking in a breath of nitrous and getting that
WA-WA-WA-WA sound, and maybe getting a little dizzy. I know that the
psychedelic effects happen during the disorienting awakening after you
have passed out.


This may disgust some of you, but it is my personal likening, and I am
not reccomending it for anyone. 


Unlike other psychedelics, every time I pass out on nitrous, I awakening
to an amazing discovery, and all of a sudden I start to see how/why
everything is the way it is. After I pass out the second time, it is like
an extension of the first, and I get another piece of the puzzle. This
happens in subsequent times, each an extension of those before it. It
takes very few times for the whole picture to come together. 


The last time I did nitrous (in early 1996) I put together the puzzle
that is everything, yes EVERYTHING. I had passed out twice, when I
realized someone, something, trying to tell me something... and every
time I passed out I learned more. After passing out four times I got very
excited, yet very scared. I knew that the next time I passed out I was to
learn something very exciting, <italic> </italic>I was to know the thread
that is to hold everything together.


Yes, I found out. 


STAY TUNED.


hence the name,

i was talking with an esteemed colleague raver friend of mine the other 
night and it reminded me that someday i will have a few little deepfogs 
(or deepfoguettes) ribbit  running around my house, here's a little poem 
from an anonymous source i picked up in my travels, and i want to share 
this with you guys...

=====================
PLEASE, MOM AND DAD...
 
My hands are small
I don't mean to spill my milk
 
My legs are short
Please slow down so I can keep up with you
 
Don't slap my hands
When I touch something bright and pretty
I don't understand
 
Please look at me when I talk
It lets me know you are really listening
 
My feelings are tender, don't nag me all day
Let me make mistakes without feeling stupid
 
Don't expect the bed I make 
Or the picture I draw to be perfect
Just love me for trying
 
Remember I am a child, not a small adult
Sometimes I don't understand 
What you are saying
 
I love you so much, 
Please love me for being me
Not just for things I can or cannot do

To my rudementry knowlage...

N2(subscript)O displaces the oxygen to the brain at an alarming rate.
O2(subscript) 'sits' at the bottom of the lungs allowing minimal oxygen
to enter the brain... (hence the feeling of going
away-way-way-ay-ay-ay....).  Yes without O2(subscript) braincells die,
this is a fact, but at the same time braincells die, say, smoking
tobacco (or other leafy substances), consuming alcohol ect al.  When the
person, "passes out" then the body does what it is used to doing,
breathing... bringing the person back.  N2O is dangerious if one were to
pass out sucking on a tube. =20

but then again, we all figure ways to validate our desires...

---_Adam
"Stay Connected"

alchemist@internity.on.ca wrote:

> > "Unnatural sex?"  Would Mr. Leary have been a homophobe?
> 
> leary did claim LSD to be a "cure" for homosexuality in an mid 60's...

Hm.  Back when homosexuality was still considered a "condition" that
could be remedied.  I'll cut him some slack, I suppose. ;)

> > ...what kind of "unnatural sex" was he referring to in our
> > mass media? 
>
> fucking, fucking and more fucking... 
> ... if you're going to link up
> your astral bodhies, you have to be fully conscious about what you are
> going to cross fertilize with... this is based in Leary's adoption of
> tantrist principles...

To quote another person on this list out of context: "It's allllll
good!"
What's natural and what's man-modified or strictured are two different
things.  "Astral bodies", "tantrist principles", these are all concepts.
What's *natural* is, as you put it, fucking, fucking, and more fucking.  
The problem with sex in media is you rarely see any protrayal of the 
emotion that belongs with sex.  As for genetics, fucking and reproducing 
are two separate issues.  Humans are not the only species that use sex 
the way we do, for fun, manipulation, and reproduction.  Look at the
Bonobo
chimps.  There are many studies on their social interactions and the
part
sex plays therein.

> > "Life-giving alkaloids and acids."  I don't think there's any mystery
> > here that Mr. Leary is referring to LSD and other psychoactive drugs.
> > I would hardly call those "life-giving."
> 
> And why not?  especially in comparison to the vices that menopausal
> middle aged white men condone...

Geez, I *hate* those menopausal middle aged white men!  ;)
But my point is, I don't think anyone of any intelligence would take
MMAWM's vices or LSD and call any of them "life-giving".

> > > They are bores.
> >
> > That's hardly a crime.
> 
> It is when boredom as a way of life is imposed on free-spirited
> individuals

That assumes that boredom can be imposed.  I'm a free person and so are
you.  It's been noted many times, not the least of which in the 
Declaration of Independence, that power is derived from the consent of
the governed.  In other words, they only have power over you if you
give it to them.  To quote Will Rogers, "People are about as happy as
they make up their minds to be."  Your life is as boring as you make 
it.

> > > They hate beauty.
> > > They hate sex.
> > > They hate life.
> >
> > These are emotional jabs, not facts.
> 
> if you were a menopausal middle age white man, you might feel
> differently...

I think I'm having hot flashes....

> this is past their prime... it basically is a statement against the
> elderly, or dying generation which is trying to control the chaos that
> makes up the learning experience of the new youth...  as if they know
> what's really going on in the world...

When you are a MMAWM, maybe you'll look at the youth and think, "Damn,
I was just like that, and ya know what?  I could find my ass with
both hands and a road map!"  We are, each of us, thinking intelligent
beings (well, most of us anyway), and we can make our own choices, but
we should not be guilty of the very crime of which we accuse our 
elders, that of having a closed mind.  We should draw on the 
experience of those that came before us.  That's not to say that we
shouldn't periodically stand up and say, "Uh, Grandpa, the [Escape]
key will let prisoners escape from prison.  Honest."  But we also
shouldn't ignore facts just because we want to have one kind of fun.

Just my $1.25....

S

Actually, it's funny you said that...

One time I was acting stupid with nitrous, I woke up with people everywhere
standing, looking at me, thinking I was dead there were sirens, and I saw
flashing lights off of the ambulence. I had to jump to my feet so that I
could prove I was not dead. After about two seconds, and a little more
reality settled in, I found that the people around me weren't looking, they
were dancing. The sirens were coming from the music that the DJ was
spinning, and the lights were, well, a sunflower and an i-beam.



.much.love.

>
>Now you've heard it direct from a chemist.  Nitrous is toxic.  You get
>high 
>because it deadens brain cells.  If you experience hallucinations, it's
>due 
>to the toxic effect.  What more do you need?

I'm not going to debate whether nitrous gives you cancer or whether it will
make you give birth to Jesus. As I stated in my first mailing I am not
reccomending the use of this drug to anyone, I like it, it has had more a
profound effect on my beliefs, loves, and character than any other drug. I
have had no desire to use it since that experience, such was the same with
acid (unless i find l-25 again), but that's not saying I will not do it again.

If nitrous is a neurotoxin, then why does the government permit dentists
to administer it to children?

Here's the real story:  nitrous will indirectly result in the death
of brain cells if you asphyxiate yourself with it (i.e. recycle the gas
through a balloon for a minute or more).
It is also a heavy gas, which means it sinks to the bottom of your lungs
and can reside there for quite a while.=20

But no, nitrous is not neurotoxic.

=09=09jon

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I voyaged all the way to Fortuna (near Eureka) to be-in at Tu b'Shevat
seder for Headwaters Forest on Sunday. 

The level of spirituality was incredible. An activist group of "redwood
rabbis" prayed and called for Hurwitz to live by the principles of his
religion and, to not just stop the clearcutting, but to begin restoring
the forest. The seder was staged in a beautiful ancient grove. The sense
of community and spirituality peaked as we told tree stories to each
other (thanks for sharing your story, Dawn) and later, as we ventured
out alone into the grove, to hug trees and reflect. All the best people
were there, some even glittered out, including some new friends from
S.F., my friend Adam and his friends from Santa Cruz, Darryl Cherney and
other Earth First!ers, and other children of the earth visiting from
Seattle. Our act of civil disobedience, to plant redwood saplings on
Pacific Lumber property and begin the restoration, resulted in no
arrests or police presence, in spite of the company's refusal to grant
permission to do so and the history of strict enforcement of trespassing
laws.

If not for the absence of driving beats, although there was some joyful
dancing nevertheless, I'd say I'd just been to a rave. 

plur,

Troy Sheets wrote:

> > But my point is, I don't think anyone of any intelligence would take
> > MMAWM's vices or LSD and call any of them "life-giving".
> 
> In fact, the above blanket statement seems to indicate a lack of intelligence
> on your part.  How do you know what other intelligent people think about
> something so complex as LSD?

You're absolutely right, Troy.  What I should have said, rather than
assuming that all intelligent people would consistently think
intelligent
thoughts, was that the concept that LSD was "life-giving" was ludicrous.
There are no "life-giving" aspects to hallucinogenics.  It's a fun
ride, but then so is a roller-coaster, and there's no "life-giving"
properties there.  Could roller-coaster change your views, give you a 
new and healthy respect for life?  Yeah, I'm sure a really scarey one
could.  But "life-giving"?  Absolutely not.  Thanks for straightening 
me out.

S

From: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (michal migurski)
Subject: NRR Re: [GOA] ...spirituality
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>> ...I personally believe that I am my own religion...and everyone should be
>> theirs.....how can people be given beliefs...bit like being told waht to do
>> really...
>
>YES!!


re-lig-ion... from the latin root word "lig" as in "ligament" meaning
something that binds or ties. A one (wo)man religion is by definition a
contradiction in terms, because the very word "religion" implies that it is
a set of shared beliefs and traditions that bring a group of participants
together, allowing them to share a common discourse which facilitates more
effective communication and allows for stronger interpersonal bonds.

I think that guy meant "spirituality." One of the eight central
"commandments" of buddhism is "right speech," meaning be damn careful of
what you say so your thoughts are not misunderstood or misinterpreted and
your mind not polluted by your own imprecise use of language. Many people
(including myself) believe that the human mind/consciousness is DEFINED by
language and grammar, meaning that fundamentally, english speakers THINK
differently than speakers of other languages. (e.g.: all those inuit words
for "snow" or the existence of "proper" forms of address in languages like
french)

Just being a total nitpicky bastard,
-m.

------> consumption is being standardized.

Hi!  ]=)

On Wed, 29 Jan 1997, =?iso-8859-1?Q?=22=A4=5BOo=5D=A4=22?= wrote:

> I have heard in years past that there are vibrational frequencies that can
> induce euphoria, and even orgasms. If there are, where can I buy the record?


 ummm, from what I have heard the frequency that is needed to resonate 
with the body in such a way as to cause orgasms is somewhere between 7 
and 8 Hz. Which is far lower than the human ear can percieve (the lowest 
frequency being about 20 Hz. but usually a little higher around 25 to 30 Hz. 
Everybody hears a little differently so some variations exist) and lower 
than most sound systems can reproduce.

 This frequency can be "faked" with audio trickery. 7 Hz. just means the 
cycle repeats 7 times a secound. If you make something go "ping" once a 
secound and then speed it up to 7 times a secound you should (in theory) 
be able to reproduce the resonating frequency sought after.

 WARNING! The resonate frequency for the human bowels (again allowing for 
individual differences) is in the same area (7 Hz. to 8 Hz.). Be careful! 
In any case have a towel handy.  ;)

 Devo supposedly did an experimental concert where they pumped enough 
bowl-resonating frequencys to have an effect on the whole audience. They 
handed out diapers at the door and made shower facilities available.

peas,


Ran D.Dreams

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>I only know what I have read, and read as much as I can on subjects that
>interest me. I have been under the impression that nitrous oxide is not
>toxic (prompting doctors/dentists to use it). I have never studied these
>subjects scholastically, so i am forwarding this reply to my message...

 Essentially, the dangers are from prolonged exposure (dentists in poorly 
ventilated offices) and lack of oxygen.


A PRIMER OF DRUG ACTION: Robert M. Julien:
"Occasionally, certain anesthetic agents become misused drugs. Nitrous
oxide is an example. A gas of low anesthetic potency, it is incapable of
inducing deep levels of anesthesia if an adequate oxygen concentration
is maintained. Nitrous oxide induces a state of behavioral
disinhibition, analgesia, and euphoria. One of the problems occasionally
encountered when nitrous oxide is used for recreational purposes is
that, unless the compound is administered with at least 20 percent
oxygen, hypoxia (decreased oxygen content of the blood) can be induced.
But in order to achieve high enough concentrations of nitrous oxide to
get a good behavioral effect, concentrations of 50 percent or greater
must be inhaled. If such concentrations are mixed with room air, inhaled
oxygen concentartions drop to low levels and the hypoxia may result in
irreversible brain damage."


Weil & Rosen:
"Physicians and dentists have long considered nitrous oxide to be a safe 
pharmacological agent. Nevertheless, there is some evidence that 
excessive or prolonged use of it can damage the bone marrow and nervous 
system by interfering with the action of vitamin B-12. Moreover its use 
in nonmedical settings presents several hazards that users should keep in 
mind. Breathing it directly from pressurized tanks is dangerous for two 
reasons. First, gas flowing from such tanks is very cold -- cold enough 
to cause frostbite of noses, lips and (most serious) vocal cords. Being 
anesthetized, a user may be unaware of such injuries until too late. 
Second, because nitrous oxide does not support life, it should be mixed 
with oxygen if it is to be breathed for more than a few minutes. At 
private parties, oxygen tanks are rarely supplied, and people have died 
of asphyxiation by breathing straight nitrous oxide through face masks. 
One way to avoid these dangers is to fill balloons from tanks and breathe 
from the balloons. 

'Further, nitrous oxide rapidly leads to complete loss of motor control, 
and anyone who breathes it while standing will soon reel about and fall 
down. Therefore, it is unwise to try the gas unless one is in a 
comfortable sitting or lying position. Serious injuries have resulted 
from people inhaling laughing gas while standing in front of open 
windows, when driving cars or when operating machinery. Others have been 
badly hurt by accidentally pulling heavy tanks of nitrous oxide over onto 
themselves while intoxicated. 

'People who breathe nitrous oxide for more than a few minutes at a time 
may experience nausea, especially if they have just eaten. They may also 
feel hung over for some time after. Addiction to nitrous oxide is a real 
possibility. Addicts may suffer serious mood and personality changes in 
addition to the bone marrow and nervous system damage already mentioned."

Couldn't let this one go by...

>>  Let the natural world of Karma take care of the
>> punishing.

> I am part of that natural world of Karma. Why is it if the world does 
>something out of Karma it is okay, but not if a person does something as 
>an agent of Karma?

Ding!  Thank you, Randy, for pointing this out.  Saying "Karma will take
care of it" often means that you are dodging responsibility for dealing
with an uncomfortable problem, by letting the person get away with
crummy behavior, and hoping the next person who gets screwed somewhere
down the line will punish the offender.

It's just a nice way of saying "Well, someone's going to punish them
eventually, and they deserve it, but I'm not willing to do the
punishing."  Shit!  Take some responsibility, people!

// grigsbeast

their asses off. It also upsets me as well, because it's a friend of 
mine that is ingesting something without even caring what it does to their body.

don't we say, "HEY you are UNINFORMED< here is some information!"

archives, or don't know about books regarding drugs, why not create a 
pamphlet called "what E/LSD does to you" and pass it out at parties? I

explaining the affects of E and acid on your brain and what's the

scene of uneducated kids made me realize it worrys me too. So hey,

offended or something (the second i should hope wouldnt happen).

Forwarded message:
From:	anemec@sirius.com (TreeHugger Mnemonic4)
Sender:	sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Reply-to:	anemec@sirius.com
To:	sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: 97-01-29 18:18:37 EST

I voyaged all the way to Fortuna (near Eureka) to be-in at Tu b'Shevat
seder for Headwaters Forest on Sunday. 

The level of spirituality was incredible. An activist group of "redwood
rabbis" prayed and called for Hurwitz to live by the principles of his
religion and, to not just stop the clearcutting, but to begin restoring
the forest. The seder was staged in a beautiful ancient grove. The sense
of community and spirituality peaked as we told tree stories to each
other (thanks for sharing your story, Dawn) and later, as we ventured
out alone into the grove, to hug trees and reflect. All the best people
were there, some even glittered out, including some new friends from
S.F., my friend Adam and his friends from Santa Cruz, Darryl Cherney and
other Earth First!ers, and other children of the earth visiting from
Seattle. Our act of civil disobedience, to plant redwood saplings on
Pacific Lumber property and begin the restoration, resulted in no
arrests or police presence, in spite of the company's refusal to grant
permission to do so and the history of strict enforcement of trespassing
laws.

If not for the absence of driving beats, although there was some joyful
dancing nevertheless, I'd say I'd just been to a rave. 

plur,

I think the term we all need to be thinking about here is "Tikkun", the
hebrew word for "Restoration".  It is a deeply spiritual word, one that we
should keep in mind in our daily lives and when we dance.  Isn't it nice to
know that we can actually learn something from the Judeo-Christian
tradition?

Dear All;

	I've personally tried in a couple of times, thanks to a Blip. It's
a comfortable bent reality; where speed when smoked is just bent. I felt
mentally connected to everyone in the room that was doing it, and really
needed to do heavy mental processing regarding my profound experience
afterword; but people didn't seem to be into it.

	I changed form; I felt like I became a liquid, then a gas, and
then a solid; like every molcule of my body was broken down into it's
smallest components; then suddenly sent across the universe, back, and
then reassembled. Time; though only 15 minutes of real-time passed, this
experienced seemed to take hours. 

	During the experience there were times that I couldn't comprehend
what was happening to me and almost quietly freaked out; like I had
completely forgotten what it was like to be solid, a human in the material
world. Just remember and say to yourself before you do it, that you will
be fine in a few minutes and that nothing bad is going to happened to you,
even if it seems like hours. 

	Try it, experience it, with people you trust, people who will be
interested in hearing your feelings afterwords, without judgement; BUT
READ MY LIPS PEOPLE; I STRONGLY SUGGEST NOT MAKING A HABIT OUT OF IT!!!!!
I've met a few heavy long term users of this drug, and they appear to have
a disease/symptomology similar to narc-co-leps-c(uncontrolable sleep),
that they feel was caused by their frequent and repeated use of this drug. 

	So have fun peoples, and use your head; don't lose it; and when it
stops being fun, I'll be waiting in NA for you; ready with a big smile & a 
hug.

Peace & Love
Brian

Subject: Music silenced on Net in Australia
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Music silenced in Net copyright war  -
http://www.australian.aust.com/computer/fulltext/c0129a.htm


           By RICHARD JINMAN 

           JANUARY 29: Song lyrics and music files have been removed from Web
           sites at two Australian universities in the first round of a
crackdown on
           copyright infringement on the Internet.

           Solicitors acting for the Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners
           Society (AMCOS) and the Australian Music Publishers Association
           Limited (AMPAL) wrote to vice-chancellors at Monash University and
           the University of Western Sydney demanding the removal of material
           from four Web sites.

           AMCOS believes such copyright infringement is widespread and claims
           the action will be the first of many.

           The campaign has outraged sections of the Internet community who
           believe the sites promote music as well as satisfying fans. For
           universities it raises new questions about the policing of Web
sites.

           Professor Peter Darvall, a deputy vice-chancellor at Monash, said
           copyright infringement was a "distributed responsibility" and
students
           and staff were issued with "clear copyright instructions".

           "This is a huge community and there will be cases of
transgressions of
           this kind," he said. "When it does happen we act properly."

           Mr Shane Simpson, the principal of the Sydney law firm representing
           AMCOS and AMPAL, said the four sites were targeted because they
           were accessed via the universities' official Web sites.

           The four sites contained lyrics to popular songs and MIDI (musical
           instrument digital interface) files allowing computers to reproduce
           instrumental versions of popular songs. All the offending
material has
           been removed and both universities have undertaken to review
material
           made available through the sites, Mr Simpson said.

           He emphasised the AMCOS campaign would be extended and
           university sites carefully monitored. "This is absolutely the
opening
           shot," he said. "Quite clearly if the universities had not
responded they
           would now be in the Federal Court."

           He said one Web site at the University of Western Sydney had
           contained "literally thousands" of files allowing the playback
of hit
           songs. Another site at Monash University had the lyrics to many
of the
           most popular songs in Australia since 1989.

           The webmistress of the Australian Music World Wide Web Site, Ms
           Eva Zsigri, is one of many veteran Net users who question the
           AMCOS campaign.

           "For someone like me who has been on the Net for years, it's all
about
           freedom of information," she said.




_____________________________________________________ x-radio _____
_______ http://www.x-radio.com/ ___________________________________
______________________________________ the evolution of music _____

On Wed, 29 Jan 1997, michal migurski wrote:

> >> ...I personally believe that I am my own religion...and everyone should be
> >> theirs.....how can people be given beliefs...bit like being told waht to do
> >> really...
> >
> >YES!!

> 
> re-lig-ion... from the latin root word "lig" as in "ligament" meaning
> something that binds or ties. A one (wo)man religion is by definition a
> contradiction in terms, because the very word "religion" implies that it is
> a set of shared beliefs and traditions that bring a group of participants
> together, allowing them to share a common discourse which facilitates more
> effective communication and allows for stronger interpersonal bonds.


 Michael, Michael... expand that brilliant brain you have.

 Binds or ties; how MANY ways can that be applied? Just because there is 
a system of shared beliefs does that mean people MUST be together? Are we 
not together when we agree to be apart. On a spiritual plain, when are we 
really alone. Can communication be facillitated and strong bonds formed 
when we are apart?





> I think that guy meant "spirituality." One of the eight central
> "commandments" of buddhism is "right speech," meaning be damn careful of
> what you say so your thoughts are not misunderstood or misinterpreted and
> your mind not polluted by your own imprecise use of language. Many people
> (including myself) believe that the human mind/consciousness is DEFINED by
> language and grammar, meaning that fundamentally, english speakers THINK
> differently than speakers of other languages. (e.g.: all those inuit words
> for "snow" or the existence of "proper" forms of address in languages like
> french)
> 

 Also; religion or spirituality (or the states of) perchance existed 
before we labled them. Human labels are human constructs and susceptible 
to human error and failure (or at least possibly not being accurate and 
not evolving with what they intially described)

 The thing is and exists independent of speech. We have mearly created a 
refrence system to relate to and communicate and store data. I am me, not 
the label you give me.

peas,




> Just being a nitpicky bastard,

 Well, .500 ain't bad.  ;)

> Ding!  Thank you, Randy, for pointing this out.  Saying "Karma will take
> care of it" often means that you are dodging responsibility for dealing
> with an uncomfortable problem, by letting the person get away with
> crummy behavior, and hoping the next person who gets screwed somewhere
> down the line will punish the offender.
>
> It's just a nice way of saying "Well, someone's going to punish them
> eventually, and they deserve it, but I'm not willing to do the
> punishing."  Shit!  Take some responsibility, people!
> 

	Not to minimize Randy's hurt feelings or anything, but I
just don't believe the amount of bandwidth taken up on this list 
over the karma of a $20.00 cable. 

	I mean there is some *real* ugly stuff going down, 
folks. I've read about promoters acting like Mafia loan sharks, 
using their security people to beat someone to a pulp in order 
to collect a debt (the "DJ Shadow" incident). I've read about one 
promoter calling the cops on somebody over a ripoff, then getting 
beaten & put in the hospital by the folks he called the cops on 
(the Thomas Trouble vs. the Russians thing). Shit like this makes 
me question whether this scene is really something I want to be 
part of. This part of it looks like a typical drug scene.

	Can we get a little perspective here?

	It's real easy to ostracize someone who's so far down
they're just helpless, and maybe that makes some people feel
powerful. But I think that if we want to worry about doing
some kind of Karmic enforcment, maybe we should pick a worthy
challenge, like getting the fucking sharks out of the scene.

Electronicool is the weekly event at 111 Minna that Spesh from Trip'n'Spin
Records has been putting together for the last few months.  He describes
it as "house music for people who work 9 to 5," but actually the music
ranges across house, techno and jungle, but in relaxed fashion.  If you
haven't been to 111 Minna, it's a gallery at the edge of the financial
district, very pleasant, has a permanent wine and beer bar.  

I've been graciously offered a DJ slot this week, along with Spesh, Gil
and Kimon, so I hope some of y'all can come check it out.  

Electronicool - Thursday, January 30 - 5 to 9 pm - 111 Minna - free

The event moves to Wednesdays starting on February 5...

phred

Hello...is this thing on?  There *is* a protest party on the way, though
not for a month or two.  It's a public, outdoor, daylong event at the San
Francisco Federal Building being put on by Moontribe, from LA, in
association with Inner Eye and some other SF folks.  The focus is
environmental protest, in particular Ward Valley, but it would be an
excellent venue for public demonstrations about anything to do with raves,
ravers, or raving.  If you want to know more or get involved (I'm not, and
this is all I really know) you should probably try to get in touch with
Inner Eye (646-0751).

The food drive thing is a fine idea, of course, and already being pursued
to some extent by all the parties that are collecting food at the door in
exchange for cheaper admission.

here's some info pertinent to this discussion i dredged up from a program
called cooledit (an excellent sound editing shareware,btw, that can generate
these patterns encoded in "pink noise")
:
The major brainwave patterns are:

Beta	> 13 hz	Normal state of alertness, stress and anxiety.
Alpha	8-12 hz	Light relaxation, "superlearning", positive thinking.
Theta	4-7 hz	Deep relaxation, meditation, increased memory and focus.
Delta	1-3 hz	Deep sleep, lucid dreaming, increased immune functions.
Gamma	200+ hz	Not sure exactly what these do...

i've tried the theta (for 20 minutes) with questionable results
and the delta (:20) with trippy results.  i felt like i was still asleep
for the next few hours as i walked around the lower haight at like 4am.
fun, but i havent done it again either...

Bruce

>From some of the conversations i've had with sfravers in the past 90 
days, the goa-trance heads would understand this the best:

The last time i did acid, this saying came rolling right off my tongue as 
i was talking to a goa-trance dj:

"Music is just simply encoded bits of information given to us by the 
higher intellegence"  (the higher intellegence being god to some)

So it occurred to me as I was reading a raver's story...if this is true, 
and I take no credit for making the phrase up, just passing it on, it is 
no wonder there are so many misconceptions about raving, music, etc.  
most people are not aware that music is information that is so 
sophisticated that the information could never be written down in a book 
in the english, spanish, or cardassian languages!  

i don't know, i don't really have anything more to say about this.  maybe 
someone else does.  

speak up goa-heads!--->deep

Siphon!



>EBONICS!!!!!"
>A few terms to help you get started on your merry way towards the
>ve-nak-u-lar...
>
>
>"Damn- that s**t is DOPE!"
>~~~~~ That is a wonderful concept/object/action.
>
>
>"I can't FADE that!"
>~~~~~ I am unable to handle this at this time.
>
>
>"Shante ain't HAVIN' it!"
>~~~~~ This is not something that Shante will allow to occur..
>
>
>"Homey- Boo was dropping PHAT beats."
>~~~~~ Our friend Boo was playing some wonderful music.
>
>
>"YO!- Let me GAFFLE that BLUNT!"
>~~~~~ Might I be able to indulge in your marijuana cigarette?
>
>
>"JIMMY was on and I was HITTIN' it!"
>~~~~~ I had in my posession a condom, which was used in my engagement of
>sexual activity.
>
>
>"What's up? Why you ALL UP IN my s**t!?!"
>~~~~~ Please sir/madam- stay out of my affairs.
>
>
>"She is HELLA' CLOWIN' you HOMEY!"
>~~~~~ The woman is creatively informing you that her interest in dating you
>is non-existant at this time.
>
>
>"Woooooo- Renaldo was PITCHIN' STRAIGHT GAME to baby-doll, and it was
>SMOOOOOOOVE!"
>~~~~~ Renaldo was creatively inquiring as to the marital status of the
>female, with the intention of asking her on a date.
>
>

>     The laws of love and dating
>     
>     1. If you meet a woman, and you like her, then she...
>     o has a jealous boyfriend 6'4" 280 pounds 
>     o is a confirmed lesbian
>     o only wants to be friends
>     o doesn't notice you're even alive
>     
>     2. About who tries to pick you up; if you're:
>     o heterosexual, then homosexuals will try 
>     o homosexual, then heterosexuals will try 
>     o bi-sexual, then, no one will try
>     o with someone special, everyone will try
>     
>     3. About finding love; if you:
>     o hope you found it, you'll be disappointed 
>     o think you found it, you're wrong
>     o believe you found it, you're misinformed
>     o have found it, you won't know until too late
>     
>     4. About winning/losing; if you:
>     o don't have anything to lose, you won't win 
>     o have something to lose, you'll lose it and still wont win
>     o do win, it's only so you can lose more later
>     
>     5. If she appears to be having a good time, it's because:
>     o she's fanatisizing, and not of you, either 
>     o she's been eyeing-up someone else
>     o she's trying to make someone jealous
>     
>     6. About dating, if she:
>     o arrives with a man, it's the boyfriend she never
>     told you about, and he has a few "questions" for ya
>     o arrives with her girlfriend, it's because she wants
>     some protection, not for anything kinky
>     o comes alone, it's because she looks at you as a friend;
>     there isn't a chance you'll ever be more either

Subject: NRR: A tale:  The 100-yard Dash
X-Sun-Charset: US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


                        THE 100-YARD DASH

10 runners are at the starting blocks,
Poised on knuckles, legs taught, leaning forward,
Ready to run the 100-yard dash.
The starting gun fires:  they're off in a flash
But one runner stumbles and falls to the ground.
Peristent dream and sustained training for naught,
His hopes are destroyed in that accidental instant.
First one, then the next and the next...
All of the other nine stop,
Turn, trot back to the fallen one, and
Extend hands and arms to help him rise,
Brush cinders from his scraped elbows and knees.
Then all of them, hand-in-hand,
WALK together to the finish line,
Crossing it as a single unit.
10 gold medals are awarded.
This is a true story.
It happened in Northern California
Not long ago at the Special Olympics.

>>From some of the conversations i've had with sfravers in the past 90

I'm not really into GOA (haven't really heard that much of it).....but I
understand it anyway.  

>"Music is just simply encoded bits of information given to us by the 
>higher intellegence"  (the higher intellegence being god to some)

Yes, I can agree with this statement.....or "music is reality".....or "we
are the music".....  I believe music speaks to us.  When I create music, it
is my intention to transmit a picture or message from God/the
Goddess/Jesus/Buddha (insert name of your particular Deity here) in the form
of art....in this case sound.  I say this because my first realizations
about things spiritual were transmitted to me through music.  Since then I
have aspired to do the same for others. 

Rick

>"Smiles, everyone, smiles!"
>"Captain, we're all out of Columbian Coffee!"
>"Turn this ship around, now!"

Hey Tony.... hummmm .... I like your idea about music being sophisticated
bits of information....this makes me think of how every genre of electronic
music (house, d&b, trance etc) grapples within itself to label itself. We
humans have a love for labelling things and attaching names to things and
categorizing things into boxes. I know people who write for music magazines
and they continually baffle me with the ever-evolving labels for music that
they use. I ask them what they mean and they can't really make it clear to
me at all. And also, I've noticed how one person's "hard trance" can be
another person's "progressive house". These labels are becoming
meaningless. The point I'm getting to is that it seems like music lately
seems to be slipping away from the rational mind - we are increasingly
finding it difficult to use language to describe it. This makes me very
happy, because I believe that music exists in the realms of non-language,
non-rationality and non-intellectualism - and this to me is where all that
great mysterious stuff is. I tried to write a mix-tape review once, it was
~really~ hard. Music can be seen as the 'gateway' to the 'other' realms of
ourselves that pesky rational mind has no dominion over.

....I think this is one of the things I like about goa - my rational,
intellectual brain can't grip onto it, so it kind of gives up and starts to
dance....or something like that.....

Ciao.....Meri

All,
	This thread really hits a spot on my polka-dot brain. 
	To myself, music are two things:
	1) Music is Life: 
		 Music is the steady heart beat of our mothers heart which
keeps us content, reminds us that we are alive and part of the universe.
	2) Music tells a story:
		I believe the dance music we listen (dance) to is
comparable the the music of the classical (expressanist (sp?),
nationalist, etc.) eras. These musics tell us a story and take us on
a mental ride to another reality. 
	
	I have never expressed these thoughts to but a few and hope
they are well received by this list.

				Respect,
					VERTIGO

> are the music".....  I believe music speaks to us.  When I create music, it

> Goddess/Jesus/Buddha (insert name of your particular Deity here) in the form
> of art....in this case sound.  I say this because my first realizations
> about things spiritual were transmitted to me through music.  Since then I
> have aspired to do the same for others. 
> 
> Rick
> 
> 
> "When the iron bird flies and the horses run on wheels, the Tibetan people
> will be scattered like ants across the world and the Dharma will come to the
> land of the red man."
> 					--Padmasambava (8th Century)
> 
>

Hey everybody, I recently added and linked a Chill Room on the XLR8R Site, at:

	http://www.xlr8r.com/chillroom/

This is a threaded discussion forum where you can... (site copy below):

Want to share rave-related experiences, comments
on the scene or review your latest favorite music
purchase? Start or join in threaded discussions
here! You can also post inline image URLs (so that
the images show up on the message page -- no
images larger than 15K please) and links back to
your own site. XLR8R supports free speech; we're
not responsible for content found here (but do reserve 
the right to remove messages at our discretion). For 
more info on how the XLR8R Chill Room works, please 
read the FAQ Sheet.

Hope this contributes to the SF Raves Community.  Please send comments to
XLR8R's Online Editor, Jesse Singer, jsinger@cs.oberlin.edu

ALSO:  The Chill Room is linked from the Listening Station (now with an
actual Real Audio server for true streaming audio) and the Events Calendar
(also interactive and ass-kicking).

Have a nice weekend and don't forget to check out the junglism site with
Audio Impact, SOLID and Betalounge event photos, *NEW* Real Audio stuff,
top 10s at:

	http://www.cyberzen.com/jungle/

(I wrote this yesterday, but f*cked up the sfraves address and it got
bounced back to me.  So, here goes again!!)--KaySEE
__________
On Wed, 29 Jan 1997, Guillermo Lemus wrote:

> 
> > 
> > Hello every  body,
> > 	I wanted to ask some of you for an interpretation of an article
> > about the influx of "musica electronica". I can't tell if it is pro or 
> > con. Do you suppose some of the liberal periodicals could enlighten us
> > with legal advice? All thoughts are well-come.
> > 				A Dios,
> > 					VERTIGO
> > 
> > PS URL is  :  http://www.sfbayguardian.com/frameset.html
> > 

> 
I read this article and like what the guy is saying.  The article is
called Dance Nightmare Pt. 2.  The author talks about how dance music is
starting to get bigger.  He finds that silly and reflects back on the
Disco Movement.  I don't think he trashes the scene at all, but rather
says it is too amorphous to really be greeted with a lot of success in the
U.S.  He says:

"Today's dance acts are invisible for a reason. Techno, house, jungle and
trip-hop are heard in tandem with a sub-culture, not as the vanguard of
it. The music is only part of the experience. It's not the
impetus or the scene's reason to be. One might argue that the drug
Ecstasy, or the secret rites that go along with the rave culture are more
important than the interchangeable soundtrack."

This is an interesting "outisider's" point of view, and somewhat valid,
IMO.  I would disagree with the importance he places on music, but I can
understand where someone who isn't into the "scene" would come up with
this.

My favorite part is the following because it is exactly what I think.  I
just can't imagine dance music becoming super huge in the U.S. for the
same reasons.  He says,"

"But no matter what MTV or the business juggernauts do in the States, this
music is likely to do even less business than the altie rock craze of the
last five years. It's producer-driven, not musician-made. It's anonymous
rather than glamorous. These are the qualities that Americans have
found unattractive for decades. Americans like their stars with faces and
personalities. They like music that is reflective of someone we can
identify with. And all the hype in the world won't change that. No way. "

However, I do sense a little bit of bitterness from the author as an
outsider.  "Raving" is maybe more "alternative" than "alternative music".
For music critics who pride themselves on knowing EVERYTHING about all
music, especially the most alternative groups, they DO NOT know a thing
about "techno."  So the get techno-envy, I guess!! :)  hehehe

-KaySEE

                                A Pattern

A seagull skims the ocean at dawn--
Youth.
The flutter of wings, the dust of feathers;
a raven in the churchyard caws.

Timelessness.
The earth will spin evermore.
/What has been will be again./
Time is but a game.
You've been,
                You've seen,
                                You've thought,
You've twisted this spiral before.

10:18 a.m.
A fetus settles in the vacuum.
A pause in creation--
it will be born again.

God's fingers trip mathematics
on the humble scales of time--
and hereness
and nowness
in human weight
makes  no sense to the stars.

The churchyard at dusk--
poets and politicians and junkies sleep.
A raven picks the frozen ground.
The earth buckles with frost.
A fencepost twists in timelessness.

An ancient oak by the graveyard's edge:
naked branches break skyward
again and again
                again and again
                                in random patterns--
heavenward.

Springtime.
The children dance until dawn.
A synthetic heartbeat pounds
between womb and earth,
reality and non-reality:
                boom boom boom boom
                boom boom boom boom
One hundred and twenty beats per minute.

/"Meaningless!  Meaningless!"/
cries the child to the ancient stars.
/"Utterly meaningless!
Everything is meaningless!"/

The planets line in soldier's stance:
                Hup, two, three, four.
                Hup, two, three, four.
A pattern.
        A pattern.
                A pattern.
/What has been done will be done again./

A baby is born.
A heartbeat tapers.
Gravestones mold and crumble.
A seagull skims the ocean at dawn.

/There is nothing new under the sun./


~b))merang
(c) Peter Alden Sandifer, 1994
Italicized words hijacked from the Book of Ecclesiastes.

       daily.

     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night midnight-3am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats,
       Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

On Wed, 29 Jan 1997, Rob Rayle wrote:

> 	I mean there is some *real* ugly stuff going down, 
> folks. I've read about promoters acting like Mafia loan sharks, 
> using their security people to beat someone to a pulp in order 
> to collect a debt (the "DJ Shadow" incident). I've read about one 
> promoter calling the cops on somebody over a ripoff, then getting 
> beaten & put in the hospital by the folks he called the cops on 
> (the Thomas Trouble vs. the Russians thing). Shit like this makes 
> me question whether this scene is really something I want to be 
> part of. This part of it looks like a typical drug scene.

	So how you we "do" something about it? I do not know how to 
remove influences such as these from the scence I am a part of. well, 
except by not going and if people ask me, point to what has happened and 
let people make choices for themselves... And maybe this is the shit that 
prompts 20/20 to do their reports. How can we have an open environment 
and still weed out the "typical drug scene", especially when that typical 
drug scene does not always merge with our own except by staying out of it 
and knowing where things come from. Hint, if you don't know who you are 
buying things from, can you trust them? Probably not all the time...

dave

>prompts 20/20 to do their reports. How can we have an open environment 
>and still weed out the "typical drug scene", especially when that typical 
>drug scene does not always merge with our own except by staying out of it 
>and knowing where things come from. Hint, if you don't know who you are 
>buying things from, can you trust them? Probably not all the time...

the only way to keep it an "open" environment, but free from the problems of
the typical drug scene, is to have big, expensive, commercial raves, with
lots and lots of security.

the alternative is to make it a "closed" environment, with smaller, more
private parties, with a more selected group of people.

anyway, buying drugs at a rave seems like a very unwise thing to do.

e

Rob Rayle wrote:

>         Not to minimize Randy's hurt feelings or anything, but I
> just don't believe the amount of bandwidth taken up on this list
> over the karma of a $20.00 cable.
[snip]
>         Can we get a little perspective here?

I wasn't talking about the cable anymore, I was talking about attitudes
in general.  Even so, keep in mind that U2 losing a cable is a different
perspective from Randy losing a cable.  For that matter,
me-as-poor-student losing an extension cable (happened) versus
me-as-employed-engineer losing an extension cable (also happened).

>         It's real easy to ostracize someone who's so far down
> they're just helpless, and maybe that makes some people feel
> powerful. But I think that if we want to worry about doing
> some kind of Karmic enforcment, maybe we should pick a worthy
> challenge, like getting the fucking sharks out of the scene.

Everyone needs to do what they can, on whatever level they can do it. 
If you believe your own argument, you ought to drop what you're doing
right now and go do something about genocide in Latin/South America, the
AIDS plague devastating Africa and SE Asia, political prisoners all over
the world, global CO2 levels rising, destruction of the biosphere
everywhere...shit, you name it.

But there are some things that can be done in the course of one's daily
life, which is different from individual to individual.  Excoriating
someone from doing so because there are bigger causes is pointless. 
There is always a bigger cause.

Maybe the world would be a better place if everyone stopped worrying
about Big Causes like Bosnia or Chile or the drug war or whatever and
started taking care of their own freedoms and responsibilities.

// grigsbeast

All of you internet nerds should check out the IRC channel #SFRaves on
EFNet.  There you could discuss about anything without having to say it's
NRR.  It's just a place for everyone to chit-chat.

If you are not familiar with IRC here are a few URLs to check out:

ftp://cs-ftp.bu.edu/irc/support/IRCprimer1.1.txt
ftp://cs-ftp.bu.edu/irc/support/alt-irc-faq

Kwiq Start

Download an IRC client for your computer.  If you are on a UNIX shell you
probably already have an IRC client installed.  For Windows 3.11 or Windows
95 users check out the program mIRC.  You can get it from
http://www.mirc.co.uk  it has all the nice features for an IRC client.  I'm
not sure about Macintosh but someone told me that htere is an IRC client for
the Mac called IRCLE.  Do a websearch on it.

EFnet IRC Servers

Here are a few servers that are currently linked to the EFNet IRC Network
where #SFRaves is:

irc.cs.rpi.edu <- personal favorite
irc.blackened.com
irc2.phoenix.net
irc.frontiernet.net
irc2.phoenix.net
IRC.VoyagerOnline.net
piglet.cc.utexas.edu
irc.nwlink.com 
anarchy.tamu.edu
irc.sintercom.org
irc.best.net 
irc.ionet.net
irc.digex.net
irc.cdc.net
irc.vianet.on.ca
irc.law.emory.edu
irc.eng.yale.edu 
irc.mindspring.com 
irc.idt.net 
irc.voicenet.com
irc.lightning.net
irc.sprynet.com 
irc.visi.com 

NOTE: All of these servers are connected to the EFNet IRC Network unless a
netsplit occurs.  If you find that #sfraves is empty on a given server try
out other servers.

If you are an AOL user use:

irc02.irc.aol.com 

Once you get on IRC just type /join #sfraves 


hope to I R See everyone......

Peas,
Anthony E

Dave Bayer wrote:

>>>>>
How can we have an open environment 
and still weed out the "typical drug scene", especially when that
typical 
drug scene does not always merge with our own except by staying out of
it

This sort of thing reminds me of the argument between the First
Amendment and perventing Klu Klux Klan ralies or flag burning. And the
awnser is the same: Having personal freedom over ones actions carries
with it the responsibility to be able to tolorate the sometimes unwanted
actions of others. (I'm shure there is a better way to word what I'm
trying to say. Excuse me I'm quite stoned right now thankyouverymuch.)
Raves after all _are_ TAZs. Open enviorments bring with them many other
activites that we might not nessesaraly want. And if it's underground
you want then its underground you get. 

And people wonder why there isn't ever a cop around when you need one.

On Thu, 30 Jan 1997, Tom Leichardt wrote:

> 
> hello =)
> 
> anyone know anything about teh carvin CS 900 ?

 From what I have been told (by knowledgeable folks) The QSC's in general 
are not so good for low frequency drivers and bins as they don't respond 
well to large (relativly) variations in impedence. You tend to get this 
situation in bass bins much more than in mids or highs. Another thing to 
consider is; what is the lowest impedence this amp can safely drive? If 
you can only go to 8 ohms and your driving two 16 ohm cabinets in 
parallel, than that is the only cabinets you can _safely_ drive with that 
amp.

 For more info on impedance, amps, calculating impedance's and (way) 
more, see the Yamaha Sound Reinforcement Handbook. It is filled with a 
LOT of information and anyone thinking of owning or operating a sound 
system for public enjoyment should have one. It will save you money and 
stress related headaches.

peas,


Ran D.Dreams



                                      (Namaste)

                                   -=*=-/
                                     ~

me, cause i played the bumbling idiot "wwwwmmmppphmf i can't find my 
proof of insurance" so he cited me for that and no registration instead...

ALL, i didn't hear about the big ass fine you get for not having 
insurance...i shouldn't be fined for it but the system doesn't know that 
they assume i didn't have insurance so i get this bill for $1652 (USD)

another position has come available across my table.  it is located in 
Redwood Shores and i believe is in the nighttime.  anyone interested 
should email me PRIVATELY, preferrably with their resume attached.  I 
will get you in touch with the right people then.  the pay will be 
discussed upon interviewing (don't worry, i won't be doing that part, i'm 
just a funnel)

oh, it's part time...

=============

Here it is:

1.      Perform routine standard operations procedures

2.      Starts, operates, and monitors computer runs maintaining and following  
        schedules in proper order

3.      Separates & distributes reports as instructed

4.      Maintain logs in I.S.T. operations

5.      Notifies proper person of equipment or program mal-functions

6.      Minx and Unix operations support

7.      Responsible for Printers and Terminals Troubleshooting

8.      Responsible for running Payroll and Personal jobs on IBM

9.      Good attendance and reliability are essential

10.     After hour help desk support (answer the phone and take message)

Requires:  Knowledge of Unix and Sun equipment, PC and Network.  Knowledge of 
VAX helpful.

Willing to learn hardware and software and interaction of files and systems 
operations.

Dave Bayer wrote:

>         So how you we "do" something about it? I do not know how to
> remove influences such as these from the scence I am a part of. 
> ...

	I think the best way to make sharks go away is to not
	feed them. 

	Don't go to their parties, don't buy their drugs - 
	even if it means not going to any party some nite, or 
	(God forbid) doing without drugs altogether for a while. 

	Which is pretty much what Dave said in the "..." anyway.

	While this won't necessarily remove the sharks from the 
	collective scene unless many/most of us do it, it does 
	remove them from your personal scene pretty effectively 
	right away ...

The Grigsbeast wrote:

> I wasn't talking about the cable anymore, I was talking about attitudes
> in general.  

	I understand about the attitudes. 

> Even so, keep in mind that U2 losing a cable is a different
> perspective from Randy losing a cable.  For that matter,
> me-as-poor-student losing an extension cable (happened) versus
> me-as-employed-engineer losing an extension cable (also happened).

	When I was a poor student, I would much rather have lost an 
	extension cable than have gotten beaten to a pulp because I
	happened to accept a little "financial aid" from the wrong
	type of person... or got into some weird competition with
	the wrong type of person ... so perspective still matters.

> Everyone needs to do what they can, on whatever level they can do it.
> If you believe your own argument, you ought to drop what you're doing
> right now and go do something about genocide in Latin/South America, the
> AIDS plague devastating Africa and SE Asia, political prisoners all over
> the world, global CO2 levels rising, destruction of the biosphere
> everywhere...shit, you name it.

	This type of argument is called "reductio ad absurdum", 
	or, in English, reduction to absurdity. Exagerrating 
	something reasonable into the unreasonable. 

	The problems in our local scene are more personal, 
	immediate, and solvable than the examples you give. 
	The jump from flakiness/petty theft in the local 
	scene to violent gangstERism in the local scene is 
	staying on topic - local rave-scene related. Jumping 
	from there to Bosnia (for example) is a total change 
	of subject.


> But there are some things that can be done in the course of one's daily
> life, which is different from individual to individual. 

	Well, we agree on this.

I like what Michal wrote about religion and language.. 
I do think, however, that our written/spoken/thought
language is not the only thing that defines consciousness.  It is
possible to articulate, to interpret and apply, through other mediums as
well.  Body language, movement (athletics/dance), music, art,
spirituality.. are all ways in which we can express ourselves,
frequencies at which we can "think" or be conscious.

Hey there, everybody!  This is Julie Mae (SmileGrl1@aol.com) and I'm
currently using my friend's account to send this letter, so if you are going
to respond, please don't click on "reply to sender."  Please address it to my
actual e-mail address... Thanks in advance...  Also, if neither of the two
problems that I (my friends, actually) need help with can be addressed by
yourself, please at least scroll down to the bottom of this letter to read
the "Quote for the Day."  I really love this one in particular!

FIRST OFF, since I'm not at home to get my new SFRaves calendar, I don't have
some information that a friend of mine needs to be able to make arrangements
to go out this weekend.  If anyone could please forward her (GOrelly@aol.com)
a copy of the calendar as soon as possible, we both would greatly appreciate
it.  I believe that she is particularly interested in information (DJs, etc.)
pertaining to a party that is supposedly going on Friday (Evolution?).

SECONDLY, another friend of mine (my best friend, actually), Jessica Adams,
who is an Old Skool Raver like myself (she's been raving since like 1991), is
having problems with transportation for Saturday.  She moved to the
Sacramento area from Mountain View last month and doesn't know which ravers
live in the Sacramento area that usually rave in the Bay Area.  This being
the case, she doesn't know who to call to find a ride down to the Bay Area
for parties.  I would go pick her up except for the fact that between driving
to Sac and back before the party and driving to Sac and back after the party
(when I'd be very tired and sometimes coming down from E) constitutes a lot
of driving for me, especially when my car hasn't been running so well
lately...  I love her dearly, but I can't put my car, nor myself, through all
that driving...
So, if any of you live in the Sacramento area or know someone who lives there
that comes down here for parties every once in awhile, PLEASE let me know...
I haven't been able to really see her in a long time, so it would truly make
our day if one of you lovely people could possible help us out on this one
anytime in the future, but ESPECIALLY THIS SATURDAY.  She or I can help out
with gas money and I thought I'd let you also know that Jessica is one of
coolest ravers around and she's fun to travel to parties with and adventure
with!  She's one of the POSITIVE and TRUE ravers that we all value so much in
our scene.  It would be a shame if our scene lost one of these wonderful
ravers because of transportation problems!  Also, FYI, that little groovy
rave book that I keep my treasured quotes, poems, and sayings in is actually
a collaboration of the energies of Jessica and myself.  We share that book
that contains all those beautiful thoughts that I have been sharing with all
of you.....our family.  So, if that doesn't truly convince you that she is
worthy of the help of a ride to a party, I don't know what will.  PLEASE
HELP!!!!  If you can help in any way with info. or a ride for this
Saturday/Sunday (or any weekend, for that matter), please voice-mail/page me
at (415) 253-2568.  Thank you so much!  We'd appreciate it more than you
could possibly imagine!

For everyone else who took the time to read this, thank you for caring...  I
love you all.   Much PLUR to everyone!

                                    Peace and Love,
                                                    Julie Mae
                                              (SmileGrl1@aol.com)

P.S.  Here's the "Quote For The Day":
THE REAL VOYAGE OF DISCOVERY CONSISTS NOT IN SEEKING NEW LANDSCAPES BUT IN
HAVING NEW EYES.
                                                    ~~ Marcel Proust

Ummm.. I've watched the show several times and have yet to see them play a
single jungle tune.  Maybe they'll get daring and play an Everything But
the Girl Drum 'n' Bass remix.  Or dig deep and play a two-year old Goldie
song from 'Timeless'.

Oooohh.... cutting edge.  I'm quakin' at the thought of too much 'new' music!

On the flip side, consider the 1am programming alternatives...

Regular MTV
Saturday Night Live
Nick at Nite
USA Network
SciFi Channel

The last one is the only thing that could keep me up, unless there was
something trippy on Bravo. Just my 2 cents worth.

And I do recommend checking AMP out once (hell, I taped two three episodes
until I realized they were replaying a lot of stuff over and over).  And is
one hour really enough for all those songs?  And why do the AMP intros take
up almost as much time as the songs themselves?  Lastly, haven't seen any
actual ambient stuff.  Just Chem Bros', Prodigy "accessible" techno.  Are
you an MTV employee?

And my last comment:  You can also discuss this in XLR8R's new Chill Room, at:

http://www.xlr8r.com/chillroom/

The Top Ten List

"Ways You Can Tell Your Pilot is on Drugs"

As presented on the 01/30/97 broadcast of LATE SHOW with DAVID LETTERMAN

10. All the in-flight meals are missing their dessert squares
9. In between "May I" and "have your attention" there's a 45 minute
pause
8. He's constantly yelling, "Take that, Red Baron!"
7. Shuttle from New York to Boston includes stopover in Colombia
6. His co-pilot: Robert Downey Jr.
5. For the last hour, he's been riding the beverage cart like a rodeo
cowboy
4. Keeps coming on the P.A. to point out clouds that look like his old
high school teachers
3. His wings are pinned to his bare chest
2. When you fly over international date line, he yells, "Dude! We're,
like, time traveling!"
1. When he exhales, the oxygen masks drop

From: toseland@econ.Berkeley.EDU (Dennis Toseland)
Subject: Re: Musical Information Thoughts from God
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>All,
>        This thread really hits a spot on my polka-dot brain.
>        To myself, music are two things:
>        1) Music is Life:
>                 Music is the steady heart beat of our mothers heart which
>keeps us content, reminds us that we are alive and part of the universe.
>        2) Music tells a story:
>                I believe the dance music we listen (dance) to is
>comparable the the music of the classical (expressanist (sp?),
>nationalist, etc.) eras. These musics tell us a story and take us on
>a mental ride to another reality.
>
>        I have never expressed these thoughts to but a few and hope
>they are well received by this list.
>
i listen to a great deal of free improv music.  Basically plug in your
instrument and play.  I also make this type of music.  Although the pieces
created for dance music aren't improv per se, when a good Dj spins them and
plays with the sund it is an improv experience.  Again and again i hear
from some of the great musical creators such as John Coltrane, mathew
bauer, etc, that they do not strictly create the music but rather "channel"
the sounds from somewhere.  I too have experienced this, where me and my
bandmate will be making sounds and this cool sound emerges and neither of
us is sure who is really making it.  To me these moments are like riding on
a wave, whihc i can direct very slightly, but it has a force and a
direction of its own at any one moment.  I am not really sure what is being
channeled.  Is it the "one" cosmic sound.  Is it alien communication?  Is
it communication with elves?  How much control does the performer really
have over the sound, so is it a mix of yourself with the "one" cosmic
sound?  There is something here, but I am not really sure that anyone
really knows.  And as one Jazz guy said," if i could say what it is in
words then I would not need to make the music."  To roughly paraphrase.
        Well enough on this for now.  I have lots more to say on this
subject though.  It's kinda a main interest of mine.
peace,
Dennis

Dennis Toseland
Nothing........Like a glowing...........ember.....in a.........
.........Plastic can........full of papers........

Precedence: bulk

What i see happening with the underground music/dance scene is this:

Techno/house etc. IS becoming mainstream and it won't falter like they
are predicting.  The producer driven, faceless star bit isn't what is
going to happen.  As i see it, the well established mainstream groups
are going to "jump on the bandwagon".  Some examples, smashing pumpkins'
next album is supposed to be all electronic music, U2's new album is
heavily influenced by it, NIN is starting to use drum and bass in their
music,....etc. etc. i have some more examples, but can't recall them
right now.  DOH!

I think the music is going to get pirated and then spit back out to the
masses.

my thoughts for today.
:)
Micron

P.S. SMILE it's friday!!!!!!!!!!!!
