[ to sfraves list ]

 I was just on Bascom Ave earlier this week ( this being a street in
the South Bay, 1/2 mile east and parallel to HW 880 in San Jose ).
I was surprised at the new Rasputin's Records store that has opened
up just 1/2 block north of Tower Records! I actually parked in the
Tower Records parking lot and checked out both stores.

 Seems that Rasputin's has got Tower Records beat as far as 
"Alternative" music is concerned - Rasputin's has clearly marked
sections for Techno, Experimental, and Industrial. They also
have used CDs and vinyl. A good complement to the Tower store
down the street.

 Two miles up the street are two more music stores - Streetlight 
Records ( 980 S. Bascom Ave., south of HW 280 and the hospital )
and Solid Grooves ( 368 S. Bascom Ave. (408) 999-0259 , north
of HW 280 and near West San Carlos street ). Streetlight has
new and used music , and also used videos. Solid Grooves is
a "DJ" store with the latest house, techno/trance, jungle, etc.
releases on vinyl, and turntables for previewing the music
before purchasing.

 I must watch out ... I averaged one CD purchase per store that day!

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Noah-
I know you may think its funny, but this is the kind of shit that really
really upsets me.  You dont know what Ebonics is. That's obvious from this
tired ass mail you posted to this list. Nor do you care about the subject,
probably because you have no idea what you are talking about. But that's OK,
beacuse most Black people dont even know what Ebonics really is. Seeing as
though tomorrow, February 1st marks the beginning of Black History Month,
consider the following your first official lesson for the month....

 The vast majority of examples that Noah was so gracious to fwd to us WERE
NOT examples of Ebonics.  They are exmples of Slang. Make no mistake: Ebonics
is language that is structured and patterned and has rules similar to widely
accepted forms of language such as Standard English, Japanese, French, etc.
Slang is random and colloquial, and has nothing to do with syntax,
grammatical usage, etc. For example:  it's Monday night at the Bahia and Joe
Rice and I are there. During the course of the night, Monty snubs him for
some reason and is generally being a contentious jerk. After the club. Sho
says to Joe: "What's up with that fool Monty?" Joe replies, "I don't know,
but he be trippin'." 

In Joe's response, "he be" is the ebonical phrase meaning "he is" and
"trippin'" is slang for "acting strangely."

If that Ebonics article that was sent was featured on 20/20 last week
immediately following the piece they did on raves, would any of you cared?  I
doubt it.

3Strikes.....

--Monty

Tekno313@aol.com wrote:

> I know you may think its funny, but this is the kind of shit that really
> really upsets me.

I have to agree with you on this.  I see an awful lot of racist, non-PC
behaviour being masked by the currently PC line of joking about
"Ebonics".  I even wrote a letter to the SF Chron to that effect.

> Make no mistake: Ebonics is language that is structured and patterned and 
> has rules similar to widely accepted forms of language such as Standard 
> English, Japanese, French, etc.

But this I have a problem with.  Ebonics is a dialect, not a language.
Case in point: 
	What language do Mexicans speak?  Spanish.
	What language do Spaniards speak?  Spanish.

But anyone that speaks Spanish knows that Mexican Spanish and the
Spanish
commonly spoken in Spain are very different dialects of the same
language.

"Ebonics" is *at most* a dialect, not a separate language.

That aside, though, I think the Oakland teachers that created this
label for a dialect have given too many closet racists an opening for
making jokes in poor taste at an American subculture's expense.

S

Precedence: bulk


I've stayed silent as various bits of this disturbing story have  
unfolded...unsure what is rumor...but the story is pretty consistent.
Several people have asserted that the Stevenson Alley people have put 
Thomas Trouble in the hospital as retribution for calling the cops on them.

If this is true, we as a community have to take serious action against 
these thugs.  They do not deserve our patronage or money.  They do not 
deserve to have any association with the rave scene.  They, actually, 
deserve much worse.

I agree: Stay away from the Stevenson space.  Stay away from any 
"parties" these people are associated with (can somebody provide the 
names of the parties?)

Someone beaten to a pulp for supposedly owing promotors money.  Thomas 
_stabbed_ for trying to get back at unscrupulous people for allegedly 
stealing money.  There is a VERY ugly element in our scene.  The rave 
scene is about PROFITS to many people, and there is a LOT of MONEY to be 
made here, not just at the door but by controlling the drug trade.  

Because our scene is also a site of drug distribution (plus admission fees
for customers to even get into the "drug store"), underworld 
characters (and just generally bad people) associated with the black market 
will try to exploit it.  They just see ravers as dollars signs, and are 
obviously willing to use violence to secure their niche in it.

WE HAVE TO BE SERIOUSLY VIGILANT ABOUT KEEPING OUR SCENE SAFE!!!

Stay away from Stevenson.  Share information like this (DO NOT SPREAD 
RUMOR).  Buy from your friends.  Know who the promoters are.   And let's 
look out for each other and protect our scene.

Thank you.
Nancy

On Fri, 31 Jan 1997, ameba wrote:

> The four Russian guys who run the Space on Stevenson  (Galactic Tunnel)
> are violent judging from the stab wounds on Thomas Trouble. This space
> should be avoided.

 From the sounds of it (who is to know) TT called it upon himself. But as 
I already stated I can not and will not support violence of any kind. 
Especially organised gang violence.

 Some of you may remember how TexHuk (sp?) from Galactic Tunnel used names 
of friends of mine (obtained from my mail header)to send them (without 
asking) mail concerning, I beleive, their first party. While it may have 
been an accident (HA!) I immediately didn't like that and felt it was 
very inconsiderate.

 Again; I will not knowingly EVER go to one of their parties. I 
hope everyone else will do the same. If only for the survival of our scene.
 
peas,

Ran D.Dreams

On Fri, 31 Jan 1997 tina@salinas.net wrote:

> I was just wondering exactly where this space is that we should stay away 
> from?  I have been to a Pro-soy party on Stevenson alley but I'm pretty 
> sure it's an entirely different space.  

 The GT partys were at a warehouse that is halfway between 7th and 6th. 
When you take 7th to Stevenson and then turn right, the warehouse is 
almost exactly half way down the alley on the left. It has (had?) a gray 
door.

 There is a very narrow set of stairs that led from the entrance up to a 
_long_ tunnel-like warehouse.

 Remind me not to call a party Karma. Talk about playing with fire!

Precedence: bulk

Steve Simitzis <steve@saturn5.com> wrote:
>There's also a great Prong techno remix album; an even more unlikely
>combination: Prong with 303 tracks and dance-oriented song structures.

Prong has been heading this way for a while.  You don't hear too much of it
on Cleansing, their last album but one, from which this remix stuff came
("Snap your Fingers, Snap your Neck," like we heard), but it's quite clear
on their latest (forgot the name).  Most people would probably think
"industrial," but the techno influence is obvious if you know.  Kind of a
third-wave industrial, maybe, in the camp of groups like White Zombie.
Along with electronica, Prong has been blending guitar processing and other
weird, noisy sounds in a Helios Creed/NIN/Sonic Youth kind of vein into
their older thrash-metal groove, which I think is a pretty interesting
combination.

anarch@scruznet.com

	Is anyone watching Millenium???
	
	They are showing something that looks like a rave...i.e. black
	lights, lazers, people dancing with glow toys, Adidas gear...except
	it almost looks like they dubbed over with some shittier more clubby
	music.  
	
	AND THEN the story line is some guy giving women E, which
	he started off by selling @ the "rave" and then later to women else
	where, just to watch them have sex with their "boyfriends" and then
	kills them with SPECIAL K so as to keep the fantasy he had of
	them alive only in his mind. 

	WHAT THE HELL??????????

I apologized for something I didn't do!
What's up with that?!

Be more clear on what Noah your yellin at! :D
Noah R:  Stop making me feel upset! :D

So anyway, let me post the question to SFRAVES since the topic is
breached:

WHY is the techno/rave scene as we know it today so exclusionary toward
African Americans, especially in the inner-city?  True, the junglists are
starting to bridge the gap and break and opening to the scene, but that
does not really answer the question.  
Here's what got me thinking about this originally:
I have a friend who works in South Central LA promoting culture and such
and incorporating technology and multi-media stuff.  Anyway, he got a
really big grant this year and is planning a big celebration for the
'rebirth' of his organization.  I offered to spin, only to find him
respond that the 'techno' scene does not appeal to most of the kids he
works with.  In fact, he said, they feel alienated and excluded.  The
scene, he continued, appealed to Chicanos/Latinos, but not the African
Americans.  
Now all this happened about a week after URB released its issue with the
'history' of techno.  If you missed it, URB pretty much stated that techno
is an African American art form, produced for and by a community
interested in communicating the toils of inner city life (Hello Goldie?
j/k)
So what are we doing wrong??
Obviously, posting racists jokes could be one thing, but it doesn't
explain why you go to a party with a couple of hundred people and find the
limited demographics you do...

thoughts?

without backing them up. Care to explain why you think I'm a moron?  

> 
> I much rather be considered immature than to hold such a fucked up
> attitude.

 I fail to see what you consider a fucked up attitude. TT claimed he was 
going to kill someone. He already knew he was dealing with some sketched 
people.

 I think you may be confused a bit. The grammer and spelling would 
indicate that you have been firing these posts off quickly (especially 
your first one). I am not condoning the behavior of the people who hurt 
TT. As you may recall (if you had bothered to read some earlier posts on 
this situation OR asked me to explain myself) I was one of, if not _the_ 
first person to publicly say (on the net) that I was boycotting the 
russians not only for what may have happened to TT (at the time it was 
still an unconfirmed rumor) but also for their threatening him (TT) on 
SFraves.

 However; if you point a gun at yourself and pull the trigger (assuming 
of course you know what a gun can do) you have no one to blame but 
yourself for being shot. You walk into the wrong neighborhood and start 
shouting slanderous euphimisms you should expect to run into trouble.

 Thomas called this upon himself. Period. He threatened people with 
death. I'm not saying he deserved what he got (although karmically...?) 
but he is responsible for putting himself in a stupid and dangerous place.

 It would be really nice BA if we could engage in a discussion about this 
rather than you yelling and screaming and calling me names. But then you 
must be so insecure that you can't, or your side of this issue is so weak 
that you need verbal violence to give it any weight. It's amazing how 
folks think that if they are loud enough then they are right. I guess 
that is because a lot of folks believe the loudest person.


carrots,

Ran D.Dreams
